name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: I declare open the 2016-2017 session of the European Parliament.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the socio-economic situation of women in Europe.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, today is International Women’s Day and I happily take this occasion to discuss with you the situation of women and men in the European Union. It is also described in the Commission’s 2015 Annual Report on Gender Equality published today. Equality between women and men is one of the Union’s fundamental values; it has been present as a legal obligation in our Treaties since the very beginning of the integration. Our societies have progressed enormously in the past sixty years, and the position of women has advanced a great deal. Women have more access to employment than ever before. There is no denying that we are moving forward. But there are still inequalities which persist.  However, if we continue at this pace, it will take us another 70 years to achieve gender equality. Still, for every hour of women’s work, they take home 16% less than men. Still, fathers spend about an hour per day taking care of the children and the house, while mothers devote three hours. Parents, and mothers far more than fathers, face such great challenges in combining their private life with their work.  This threatens women’s economic independence and can lead families into poverty, especially, but not only, if the woman is the sole breadwinner of the family. This also has consequences on women’s pensions and risk of poverty in old age. Nowadays, women’s pensions are 40% lower than men’s pensions on average, and this gap shows no sign of narrowing.  We need to accelerate the positive changes of the previous decades, to create the kind of society where every boy and girl can thrive.  Please allow me to reflect on three key issues on how to move towards a more equal Europe. Women make up half of the European population. There are more men than women in most levels of management and supervisory positions, and there are more men than women in national parliaments in all Member States, and also in this House. In the largest publicly listed companies registered in the EU countries, only a little over 20% of all board members are women. The Commission’s proposal to achieve greater gender balance on boards of listed companies aims to tackle this inequality by ensuring that boards consist of at least 40% of both sexes. We must get this adopted, and you must help advocate it in the Member States, which are still reluctant. Secondly, we have to make it easier for European citizens to combine the responsibilities they have at work with the responsibilities they have at home. Later this year, the Commission intends to present a package of legislative and non-legislative proposals aimed at improving the work-life balance of employees. It will be well-rounded, dealing with the accessibility and affordability of high quality childcare, leave arrangements for fathers, mothers and carers, and flexible work arrangements.  It will be an important contribution to the integration of women in the labour market, which is demographically and economically necessary. It is also an important contribution in the European growth process.  And finally, there is a persisting gender-based violence. In the European Union, one in three women has been physically attacked, sexually attacked or both.  Last week, the European Commission proposed the EU’s accession to the Istanbul Convention, the first ever legally binding instrument to combat violence against women at international level. The accession of the EU to the Istanbul Convention is a key step under our ‘Strategic Engagement’. The Convention’s holistic approach to this complex phenomenon is in tune with the EU approach.  The accession of the EU will provide greater efficiency and coherence in combating and preventing violence against women where there are already common EU rules, as well as in the more effective use of EU programmes and funds.  It will strengthen our common credibility and accountability externally. It will contribute to wider EU objectives of gender equality, anti—discrimination and economic growth. Further, I have been working with Commissioner Thyssen to ensure the follow-up of the survey conducted by the Fundamental Rights Agency (FRA) in 2013. This survey on gender—based violence would be led by Eurostat and carried out by national statistical offices with EU support and funding. Eurostat will start working towards such a survey, as announced in its Annual Work Programme. The Strategic engagement for gender equality 2016-2019 clearly identifies all the above-mentioned areas as a priority within our work to promote gender equality, including on equal economic independence. The strategy sets out, in addition to the key actions, that gender equality will continue to be promoted through the integration of a gender-equality perspective into every aspect of EU intervention, such as the preparation, design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of policies, legal measures and spending programmes. Let me conclude by underlining that improving the socio-economic situation of women and promoting actions to stop violence against women are the top priorities for the Commission.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for your words, which show a very strong personal and political commitment, both in your capacity as Commissioner in charge of the issue of equality between men and women. You have given us a number of clarifications, you have pointed out a number of avenues and you have testified, once again, to the main priorities of the European Commission in terms of improving the socio-economic situation of women and combating violence against women. This is also the two main challenges for my group, the EPP Group, on whose behalf on behalf of this International Women's Day. Improving the socio-economic situation of women is simply an issue of competitiveness, an issue of equality, an issue of justice between men and women. It is about improving the economic situation of our continent through the fight against the human waste that represents the non-fulfilment of the female potential. Women in Europe are just as well trained, just as well educated as men, and therefore there is a real waste, a real loss of human resources and a loss of potential not to give women all the place and responsibilities they can aspire to in the labour market. We, the EPP Group, are particularly concerned, of course, and we will be actively working in the coming weeks and months on the instruments, on the avenues for improvement that can be proposed, which can be implemented on the initiative of the European institutions, but we will mainly ask The Member States to meet their responsibilities in terms of reducing wage inequality and reducing pension inequalities. The reduction of the gender pay gap and the gender pension gap seems to us to be, in terms of improving the socio-economic situation of women, the two main issues on which we must make rapid progress in the coming months. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation).

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, I will be extremely brief and ask my colleague Constance Le Grip the following question: think that it would be interesting to encourage the adoption, at the level of the 28 states of the European Union, of the Copé-Zimmermann law, which was adopted in France and which proposes to be successful by 2017 - but the deadline at European level could be delayed by one or two years - to parity in the boards of large companies , in corporate governing bodies, the idea of parity and promoting the presence of women in the governing bodies of our economic world?

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, recent studies show that when there is a legislative instrument that strongly encourages greater parity and greater representation of women on the boards of large publicly traded companies, there is real progress, not only in the same board of directors, but also in all other decision-making bodies. I would like to welcome Commissioner Jourova's commitment on the issue of the women on boards directive, which the European Parliament adopted by a large majority almost two years ago and to which our EPP Group is very committed. Yes, of course, European legislative instruments are needed to strengthen the presence of women on the boards of large publicly traded companies.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, mr President, Commissioner, thank you wholeheartedly for presenting in detail today the socio-economic situation of women in Europe. It is truly symbolic that it is on 8 March that we are discussing the situation of women here in plenary and on gender equality in our Community. Speaking on behalf of the S&D Group, I certainly congratulate the Commission, which has decided to propose to the European Union, as a cross-border organisation, accession to the Istanbul Convention. This would only be the second United Nations convention to which the European Union will become a country, but I would really very much like, and I wish both myself and all my colleagues and the Commission, that laws and decisions in favour of both women and men in the European Union would be remembered and taken not only on this day. And indeed, for women and for improving their socio-economic situation in Europe, we can and must do much more.  First of all, we need to create and ensure that women are more successful in re-combining work and private life. Let us admit that even in the 21st century, we have not been able to In Europe, this responsibility is most often borne by women. What can we do to prevent a woman with a family from having a job and giving up personal professional development so that a working mother finally has time for both herself and her health care? We need to legislate to ensure maternity, paternity and parental leave.  Finally, we need to legislate to take care leave for family members – disabled or old family members – without losing their jobs. Finally, it is necessary to invest to achieve the Barcelona objectives so that our children have educational and educational opportunities (I am talking about the sufficiency of crèches, the adequacy of places in kindergartens). Finally, we need to work with the social partners to find innovative solutions that allow working people to reconcile work and family responsibilities. We look forward to seeing from the honourable Commission soon that package on reconciliation between work and family.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her This morning we are discussing the socio-economic situation of women in Europe. In its contribution, the European Commission has once again made it clear that it is not on the side of women who are mothers and on the side of families. The EU Commission continues to refuse to include and recognise value added by mothers in the national accounts. Gary Becker has won his Nobel Prize with models to make the added value of families and especially mothers visible. The OECD has already recognised this, and so has the United Nations. The services and work provided by the families and especially by the mothers – that is, by women – are a hard-hitting economic factor. Value creation begins with appreciation. The European Commission refuses to value mothers in all Member States because it does not want to recognise the added value through them. Perhaps we should talk about discrimination against mothers and families. That would really be something new.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Mrs Jourová, it is a pleasure to have you here on International Women's Day reminding us that equality is not only a value, but a legal obligation. And I would say one more thing: it is our interest, it is the only thing that will make us go further and it will make us devote all the efforts to what we have to dedicate them, which is to achieve equality in the world. This obligation not only becomes, many times, a drag on women, even though, as we well remembered, we are the majority of the population, but it has different drifts.  And on this International Women's Day 2016, we are still faced with a huge pay gap , which is actually on average 16%, but there are countries, like mine, Spain, where it is close to 25%; we find ourselves at greater risk of poverty for women because the pension gap is also huge; we also find that the economic crisis has reduced women's access to the labour market and their wages are becoming lower; and we also find that we continue to have enormous inequality in board of directors and management positions.  For all this, we have instruments, gentlemen. To all this, we have the European Parliament as a co-legislator and I repeat the 'co' to advance that legal obligation that we have to achieve equality.  To this end, we have the Maternity Directive , pending a new proposal – or paternity, or parental leave, let us call it whatever it is, but which is real and appropriate for today's European families.  We must have the capacity to take forward the Women on Boards Directive because very few countries, including the current Presidency, which are blocking this agreement, and it is in our interest: reaching 40% is not capricious; it's about speeding up time.  Finally, I would like to thank you very much for your personal commitment so that we can be celebrating today that the Commission is calling on the European Union to accede to the Istanbul Convention, the first legally binding and comprehensive instrument to combat gender-based violence. Congratulations to all, men and women.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for your words, even though some of us like flowers, this is certainly not just a day to make flowers, it is a day to celebrate equal rights, which is yet to be fulfilled, and to celebrate the recognition of the difference between men and women.  I am a bit tired of repeating exactly the same things and the same formulas every year, because the socio-economic situation of women in Europe is simple: inequality has increased, the wage gap has increased, unemployment has increased, violence on women has increased and often in the most brutal way. In my country, for example, 29 women died of domestic violence in my country alone last year and the problem is, in fact, political.  I think it would be important for the Commission not to deal with this socio-economic inequality only with quota issues and words, that it brought politics because, as I said, the problem is political. Recognizing that austerity was a failure would be a good start. Putting the maternity and paternity directive back on the agenda would be a great sign that we do not just want words, because this Commission, Commissioner, got off to a bad start when it withdrew the Directive on motherhood and fatherhood, and does not really want to recognise that there is inequality. I want us to come here and talk every year, but our words have consequences.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, my mother was born in 1957 into a family of six children in the mountainous countryside in the middle of Germany. The very same year a bit further south in Europe, something really meaningful happened. European leaders, all of them men, met to sign the Treaty of Rome with a very simple yet still today unfulfilled principle: men and women should receive equal pay for equal work. Despite the fact that my mother and this principle were born in the same year, throughout her whole life my mother never enjoyed the outcomes of this decision. She never got the same appreciation, praise or simply the same money for the work she was doing as her male counterparts. And still today we see a big gender gap that is completely unacceptable, all over the European Union and especially in Germany. Just like millions of other hard-working women in the European Union, I believe that my mother has all the right in the world to be damned angry with the absolute failure of the European Union to simply make this principle a reality. Today is International Women’s Day, a reminder for us to fight for equality. The EU has in the last six decades let millions of women down on this very clear promise. Do not let me and my generation, who were born 30 years later, grow old in a Europe where we do not get what we deserve. Equal pay and equality in all European societies. We have a very clear legal base for forcing Member States to do something. I ask you, Madam Commissioner, and all of us, to act now. Let us make the principle a reality in the European Union.

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, according to Eurostat between 2010 and 2012 over 30 000 people were trafficked across Europe, 80% of them women. The National Crime Agency reported that over 3 000 people were potential victims of trafficking in the UK, an increase of 21% from the previous year.  This modern-day form of slavery is on the rise in the EU and I am afraid the EU is to blame. Because we are forced to have open borders, the EU is enabling cross-border gangs to operate freely. The UK Government report said that free movement within the EU is extensively exploited by organised criminals to bring human trafficking victims to the UK. Even Europol admitted that free movement policies make it harder to detect these crimes.  So what have all the EU gender initiatives, funding and quangos actually achieved? The only people the European Union has helped are the traffickers and those with histories of abuse and violence to come to the UK because we are banned from doing criminal background checks.  If we left the EU we would still be part of the International Labour Organization that supports equal working conditions. We will still be part of the UN agencies that promote women’s rights and we will be able to restore our links with the Commonwealth and do more to champion these causes. There is no threat to women’s working conditions or maternity leave. We do not want to actually allow the scaremongers to get away with this. There is nothing to fear and everything to gain for women if we leave the European Union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As of 8 March 2016, women are also socio-economic, and women are lagging far behind in terms of pay and career opportunities – although they vary widely in the Member States of the European Union, but nevertheless. This is despite the fact that women have long been in the fast lane when it comes to educational attainment. Numerous studies show that companies perform better with female leaders and that generations of women, politicians have fought for integration and gender equality. Women earn on average 16% less than men in the European Union, with the gender pay gap wide in the Member States: from 2.9% in Slovenia to 6.5% in Italy to 22.9% in Austria and 28.3% in Estonia. Much of this gap can be explained by children and, consequently, by a high proportion of part-time workers among women. Almost one in three women with one child work part-time in the EU, but only one in 20 men. In Austria, in my own country, two thirds of all mothers work part-time. And the more children a woman has, the more likely they are to work part-time. It is similar in leadership positions. Studies show that returns for shareholders are on average 53% higher and profit margins 42% better if at least one woman sits on the board. According to a study by the renowned Peterson Institute for Economics in Washington, a 30% increase in women's in management brings 15% more revenue. In addition to sales and profit, the market value also increases by an average of 5% when women are represented on the executive floor. So the facts and figures speak for themselves. Let us increase the incentives for women to be represented equally in economic life!

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – The picture is the usual: European Parliament, plenary, Strasbourg, about 50 out of 750-odd Members are here. However, the day is special, as it is 8 March, International Women's Day, and we spend the whole morning in this spirit. This day is also of historic importance because the European Union wants to root out one of the most desirable plans here today. It is also disgraceful because it seeks to exploit the suffering, pain and discrimination faced by women around the world for a nefarious cause. What's the nefarious goal? Promoting immigration, resettlement and migration in the following ways: the main twist is the political and, of course, the economic row behind them, that they are in trouble. Because now people, peoples, are rebelling and saying that this is not a refugee issue, but an immigration issue that does not fall within the competence of the European Union. So the European Union cannot deal with it, only the asylum issue, the refugee issue. However, we see that it is about 10% of the influx into Europe and people that actually come from war-related areas. What did they come up with? To think about a different kind of refugee status. Let us say that if women are fleeing being discriminated against or subjected to violence in their own country, but they also add that they are discriminated against, they have the subjective right to come to Europe, apply for refugee status or to be granted asylum. And then their lovely families have the subjective right to join these women because of family reunification. It is true that this will only come to light from the next report by Mary Honeyball, my dear old adversary, this outrageous plan. But everything else that's going on here with women, equality, equal dignity et cetera, et cetera, it's all just a little garnish to get this outrageous plan through. Honeyball report, point 13 – I recommend it to all Europeans who fear for their country.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Madam President, once again we are talking about inequality or rather about the issue of equality between men and women. We are not honored by this debate, but it needs to be done. You are honoured, Commissioner Jourová, for supporting the directive on the under-representation of women on boards.  I recently had the honour of presenting a report on glass ceilings, glass ceilinging, i.e. the obstacles that women face in seeking to reach the highest office, and what do we observe? Women are under-represented; only 31% of entrepreneurship is represented by women, the self-employed, while the objective of the EU 2020 strategy is, as you know, to cover around 75%, but the under-representation of women is, as I said, at all levels; in business, finance, higher education, science, research, technology, academia.  And how can this phenomenon be lifted? There are two paths: the nursery called the school, the nursery called education, education, the nursery called the family. Because if these prejudices are not lifted and if new perceptions are not born through the promotion of the right standards and achievements of women, then we will reach again in five years, in ten years' time we will be talking about inequalities; a debate that distinguishes women from men, that does not recognise that women are human beings and half the planet. It is a debate that does not honour our values, it does not honour our principles, it does not honour women, it does not honour Europe.

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Madam President, I would like to wish everyone a happy International Women’s Day. Enshrined in the founding treaty of the EU lies the commitment to reach equality between women and men. Since this founding treaty, the EU has delivered a huge amount to bring us closer to that goal. It has brought us legislation on equal treatment, equal pay, parental leave, carer’s leave and protection for pregnant workers, to mention a few of the direct benefits. I know the difference that these pieces of legislation have made; I used them in the 20 years I was a trade union official. Women have benefitted, and continue to benefit, from EU membership, in pay packets, pension provision and protection at work. But no one can suggest that we have achieved that original aim of equality. We cannot, and must not, put our feet up. Recently, we have seen that women have suffered disproportionately as a consequence of austerity policies across the EU and through employment deregulation, which has led to greater temporary and insecure employment. Looking at the Commission’s Europe 2020 strategy, there is agreement that more needs to be done – boosting female employment, reducing the pay gap, getting women into positions of power, reducing the number of people in poverty – but targets in these areas without actions are meaningless. A review of the actions of the Commission is not encouraging: refitting maternity leave directive, no progress on women directors and now no strategy on equality between women and men. So I ask the Commission to follow the talk on this day with action on all other days.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: – When talking about the socio-economic situation of women, we need to consider the ratio between their education, the income they receive and the possibility of career development. Unfortunately, the figures show that, despite the high overall education of European women, equality in relation to the other two indicators is lagging behind. A new European Union strategy for gender equality by 2020 would contribute to faster change and more effective results.  International Women's Day is an occasion to recall that, in view of the support of both the European Parliament and the Council, it is time for a new strategy to be formally adopted, but also to enter into force effectively, with real, concrete policies in the Member States aimed at improving the socio-economic situation of women and achieving gender equality. And because I mentioned today's holiday, I want to use this grandstand to congratulate the International Women's Day to all ladies in the European Union.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Madam President, the European institutions are lavish in the profusion of gender approaches which, around the implementation of equality policies and the associated promises, no longer mask the negative impacts that austerity policies have on worsening inequalities, discrimination and exploitation of women. Exploitation and impoverishment policies emanating from the European Union and implemented by governments have promoted and exacerbated inequalities. Women are the most affected by poverty, unemployment, job insecurity, wage discrimination, in addition to discrimination in and for motherhood. There is an urgent need to resume the Maternity Directive which the Commission has decided to abandon. Added to the growing difficulty of articulating personal, family and professional life, in particular by the deregulation of working hours, a situation that is aggravated by the attack on the social functions of the State and the destruction of public social security systems. It is not possible, Madam President, to promote equality without the necessary break with these right-wing and social-remedialed policies.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, every year we try to take stock of the situation of women in Europe. We note, however, that we are moving too far, because there are still huge differences in pay, especially in some Member States, the differences in pay, career obstacles and the chances for a woman to really be able to choose. Well, our real goal, as women, must be to become really free to choose: choose to study where we want and what we want, choose a job because we like it even if defined as male predominance, such as entrepreneur or computer scientist, choose to have a child or not to do it but still be free in this choice, which must not be imposed by the lack of work , precariousness or lack of childcare. Politics must give immediate answers to women, it must resolve the difficulties which have, for example, led to the failure of the directive on maternity leave or which still allow a woman to retire today, on average by perceiving 6% less than a man or preventing so many of us from not being able to have a career because we are busy caring for children , the elderly, the disabled, in the absence of a state to intervene.  Here, let us ensure that this day dedicated to our dignity and our role in society does not only serve to denounce the many things that are wrong but is a positive piece to build and look with hope to the future.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Researchers studied American basketball players and found that high-earning men earn more than niscy, which proves that high-end men are better suited to basketball. The same is the case if women earn less than men in the same position. That is, they are suitable for it less than men.  Once in Europe women ruled, because he rules the world, who raises children. Women have been removales, children have been taken away from them, sent to nurseries, kindergartens, where they are raised by the state. Women, on the other hand, are directed to lower-paid jobs, to which they are much less suitable, and therefore, of course, they earn much less. Please note that, for example, in the case of extreme sports, such as chess or bridge, women make up only 1% of the players competing there. And if, in some area, women make up more than 1%, it means that it is some artificial pressure from the European Union that is obviously reducing the level of discipline.  More besides, I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.  (The speaker agrees to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. I want to ask you, Mr. Korwin-Mikke, one question. I was a great basketball player, and as you can see I'm not very tall, but I played great basketball. Do you know that to play great basketball height is not crucial, but is it crucial whether you hit the basket or not? The same thing applies to what else you said in your speech. Do you agree with me that to play basketball height is not key?

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I want to inform you that high men also earn more than niscy – there is such a social injustice. And I played basketball in the second Polish league and we won with the first women's Polish, about 50 points.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 8 March reminds us every year of what still needs to be done to improve the situation of women in the European Union. There are still too many obstacles to the full affirmation of women in our society and we, as legislators, are called upon to restore gender balance. In 2016, women still have to work two months longer to get an annual wage equal to, or at least equal to, men. As a result, there is a marked pension imbalance, which means leaving thousands of women alone and in poverty. In the European Union, poverty among older women is three times more widespread than that of men.  Ladies and gentlemen, we are doing everything we can to bridge this gap, as do the members of this Parliament's Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality every day: a few months ago, we also voted by a large majority for my report, which aimed precisely at removing the obstacles that women encounter in entrepreneurship in Europe.  But I find it absurd that only a third of European entrepreneurs are women, just as it is absurd that, over the last five years, the proportion of women in employment in Europe has risen from only 60% to 63%. We need more commitment from the institutions all.  I welcome the work of Commissioner Jourová, who is fighting with us for it to be ratified in all the countries of the European Union at the Istanbul Convention. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. " I would like to turn to The Congresswoman, looking at history a little, if you will allow me. There is broadly a commonalation that we have been celebrating Women's Day since 1917 on March 8. Next year will be the 100th anniversary of this day and contains three main demands. One is women's equality in the field of work, the other is the protection of mothers and children, and the third is women's participation in public life. Do you agree, Congresswoman, that next year, as a fourth pillar, we will include violence against women in the demands?

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Answer to a blue card question. I do not think that this is a question, it is just a speech made by my colleague. However, if you have listened to what I have said, we are also fighting on a daily basis to ensure that all countries have to ratify the Istanbul Convention, which really requires more attention to be paid to the phenomenon of violence against women and girls throughout Europe.

name: Soraya POST
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for In europe, we do not respect women's human rights. Women are not in charge, do not earn as much money as men, do not participate in the labour market to the same extent, do more unpaid work and are poorer. Poverty particularly affects older women, as a result of a life without full rights.  Discrimination is in stock. For example, a Roma woman is suffering from the rise in racism in the EU in the form of discrimination and social exclusion. A woman who is lesbian or transsexual is also affected by the hatred that exists in society against LGBTQ people. There are numbers on this. Politicians talk about it just like we do now. They state that it is not right, that it has costs that are both human and economic, but it is human rights violations that are unfortunately accepted, because otherwise they would have done something about it a long time ago. Gender equality policy is something that is mentioned but not a priority. A telling example is how the Commission has downgraded the EU's gender equality work to a technicality, the work that should be led by a politically entrenched strategy describing how women and men in the EU should have the same power over their lives. For me as a feminist, this is totally unacceptable. The EU should have a high standard of human rights and gender equality. It is about our fundamental values. How long are we going to have a society where women, minorities and other vulnerable people are second-class citizens? What can we call ourselves as long as we do nothing concrete about this? Nothing but hypocrites. Personally, I'm not celebrating March 8th. I think it is a manifesto of the inequality that we only experience every day. I don't want a flower today, for example. It just proves that out of 365 days, 364 is not our days. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Anna HEDH
text: question ("blue card"). I agree with you Soraya Post. I'm not celebrating International Women's Day either. It should be noticed every day and everyone, both women and men, should help. My question to you, Mr Soraya, is: do you think it would help a little if we had a gender equality strategy that the Commission had in the past, as a communication to the Member States? Do you think it would be better for europe if we had this gender equality strategy, instead of just an internal paper now?

name: Soraya POST
text: answer ("blue card"). Yes, I am absolutely convinced that strong signals are needed in the Member States, and a gender equality strategy that was preferable in the past. Absolutely! (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: "blue card" question. I must say that I am actually very happy that you are throwing some pepper into the debate here this morning. Should we work for international women's day? I hear two colleagues here saying: no, that is no longer necessary!  I very much regret that. Having heard the Commissioner today, I believe that we, as women, must continue to fight for equal rights for men and women. And actually, that should happen every day. Not just on the woman's day. But please let us put this fight in the flowers on this day! I would like to ask you a very specific question. You said, men and women have the same rights. Do you therefore agree with me that we should be able to distribute maternity leave freely between men and women, so that women can also develop their careers to the fullest?

name: Soraya POST
text: answer ("blue card"). "Well, it's absolutely the case that you should share equal men and women when it comes to parents taking care of their children, 100 percent, but I don't understand what 8 March would have to do with it. That is why I think we are fighting 24 hours a day for our rights, for a society where we want to let our children grow up, where girls and boys can develop and live out to their full potential right to the grave. From the cradle to the grave. That's my goal.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Madam President, combating machismo and inequality in Europe is about acting every day and not confining this debate only to 8 March. There are three elements that I would like to highlight. Firstly, inequalities in the European Union are related to the few areas of power where women interact and have a presence. Without going any further, in this Parliament women preside over only ten of the twenty-five existing committees.  Secondly, we suffer from the worst working conditions, the ones with the highest unemployment rates, the ones with the greatest difference in pensions and a pay gap in the European Union of more than 16%. We carry on our backs, mostly, the economy of care, a work as invisible as necessary for social support. Finally, this difference is exacerbated between northern and southern Europe. The cuts in social rights imposed by austerity policies have a double burden on us. The deterioration of public services and the degradation of working conditions mean that we are the ones who bear the brunt of austerity. Ladies and gentlemen, there is a Europe that calls for equality and challenges us. We must live up to it. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, you, like the other colleagues, have spoken of this inequality and said about the European Parliament. If the population is majority female in many of our countries, how do you explain that women do not vote for women?

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: "blue card" response. – Mrs Grapini, the problem is that most people in spaces of power are not women: most people in spaces of power are men. Not to say that inequality and machismo are something that is sociologically embedded and that must be fought from all institutions and by budgeting adequate funds for it, not just with good debates and good words.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her rational approach and the concrete proposals she is putting forward for the following period. It turns out that the situation in the area of gender equality and the position of women in society are still not what we would like. They're getting better slowly. For example, in the Czech Republic, even at a time of economic growth, we still have a gender pay gap of more than 12%, both in the civil service and in the business sector.  This is partly because women are employed in sectors where there are lower salaries, whether they are teachers, nurses, but above all women are engaged in childcare and needy family members.  The European Union cannot, from its level, tell the Member States what to do, but we can say from this level that we respect women who have children, that we respect women who have the courage to have more children, and that these women need to have adequate maternity leave, parental leave and also financial security at this time. From this level we can say that we also respect women who want to have children, want to have a family and want to continue their profession. Therefore, they need to be able to work flexily, support employers and care for children at the time of their employment. From this level we should thank all the mothers and I also want to thank my mother, who was a politician, a doctor, but always was an excellent mother.  (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: blue card question to Michaela Šojdrová. – The demands of today's consumer society have led women to a race for professional recognition, but women have the divine gift of giving birth to children. The current financial situation allows them to have a child at most. So we say that Europe is getting older. Shouldn't families be financially supported so that mothers can take care of their own children? Have they been asked? Is there any evidence of what most women want? Is what we're talking about what female careerists want?

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleague, I think that most women should have a choice. When we say that women and men are equal, they are also free and should have a choice. Of course, I see a woman as a mother, and I wish that women have the opportunity to choose to have children, to stay at home with them, and to have the opportunity to have children and then return to their profession.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her efforts and, of course, all my fellow Members who have taken part in this debate. I think we cannot fail to recognize, ladies and gentlemen, that this is, after all, a normal day for too many women. A normal day especially for those women who represent the future of our Europe. I am thinking in particular of refugee women, of the 60% of people who make up the total flow of refugees crossing the Greek and Macedonian borders. So I ask you, ladies and gentlemen, what is the point of celebrating the past when you choose to close the door in the future.  We are outraged at the exploitation of women and then completely ignore the trafficking that is made of them. Poverty scares us and, at the same time, we choose to close our borders. And so I believe that trauma, shame and violence need different attention, and that is why I would like to dedicate 8 March to them, to the women who are fleeing, to the women who are looking for that freedom that we are once again preparing to trumpet today. I believe in a different Europe, ladies and gentlemen. I believe and work for a Europe of solidarity, and that is why I propose – I have already done so in a letter addressed to each of you, but I am doing so here once again – that you go here in person to verify the condition of exploitation, violence and oppression that affects so many women on the Macedonian border. I ask you to go and see for you what is happening, to see for you the 'no' that Europe is punctuating and to try to stop this phenomenon. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Would you agree with me that all artificial constructs like International Women’s Day are little more than gimmicks and what really matters is freedom of equality, of opportunity, for people? Also, that what matters is for Western women to still be allowed to enjoy the values of Western freedom in society, and not for those to be washed away in the huge flood of new people coming into our continent, into Europe, who wish to have different values – so the freedom of opportunity for Western women to live as they wish and not to have those values eroded by newcomers?

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Answer to a blue card question. I totally disagree with my colleague, nor with the words he wanted to use. In the meantime, because I believe that International Women's Day is an important day because it celebrates the achievements that have been made by other women before us. Other women before us have fought for the rights that we consider to be obvious today and which are so important and must be remembered: I am thinking of the right to vote, the right to a fair paid job, the right to maternity, in short, all those things that we take a little for granted today.  I think it is right to recognise that, in the name of the freedom with which so many of us are filling our mouths, even today, as you have done, ladies and gentlemen, it is right to recognize that Europe, the great Europe that we are celebrating, this old continent so important that it has also been a beacon in the past, is not doing its job to the full, choosing to close our eyes to those terrible scenes that we are all seeing.  The disturbing scenes that tell of women and children piled up in front of barbed wire, who are denied the chance of a life worthy of the name. So I do not wish, my dear colleague, that after having established Remembrance Day, we should establish the Day of Shame, for all of us who are.  (The President withdrew the speaker from the floor.)

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Madam President, Madam Commissioner, women today find it harder to get a full-time job than men and face difficulties starting their own business. Women today do not receive adequate support to help align private and work life, and those who opt for motherhood are generally penalized so that they are paid less or unfortunately even lose their jobs. Women are not paid the same as men for the same work they do, and at work they are often subjected to discrimination and various types of harassment. Although women in greater numbers than men graduate from colleges, they are later not in leading decision-making positions.  I am particularly concerned about the position of women farmers who unfortunately often do not own land or real estate, who work on family farms and their work is not only not paid for, but neither health nor pension insurance. I therefore call for a minimum national pension that will not be less than the poverty threshold, as well as available healthcare in rural areas, as this is the minimum required for a decent life for rural women.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, in view of today's celebration of International Women's Day, it should be pointed out that, during this period of financial crisis and especially in the countries that have been impoverished by the Memorandums, women are the biggest victims, as their rights are affected every day at both social and labour level. In particular, in the workplace there is a gender pay gap of 16.4% and a corresponding pension gap of 39%. In addition, workplaces are discriminated against in the recruitment process, while in countries such as Greece, which is affected by memoranda and austerity policies, the new anti-insurance bill has pushed women freelancers to spend more than 80% of their annual income on contributions and taxes, while rural women are also targeted. In order for the European Union to put an end to gender discrimination, it must stop povertying the countries of the European South.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, a genuine policy of promoting gender equality must tackle the causes of inequalities and these causes are now predominantly cultural and economic. I'm just going to refer to the first part of the first ones. We cannot remain silent in the face of institutionalised forms of discrimination, such as with the Catholic Church, which continues to prohibit women from accessing the priesthood and even from teaching sacraments, just because they are women.  The Catholic Church is organized politically in a state, the Vatican, and so we must all demand that the head of that state, the Pope, put an end to this unbearable discrimination between men and women within him. When that happens we will certainly take a big step, if not to end up at least to reduce, and quite a lot, gender inequality in the world.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, although I know that I cannot determine the order, I would, of course, very much like my colleague Štětina to be able to comment on this matter.  However, on what is on the agenda today. I would like to declare for us men that chauvinism is not our own part of each of us. What we have heard from some of my colleagues here has made me very sad indeed. I'd like to wish the women their holiday, but to the point. The ratio of the population to women is 52% to 48% of the representation in society, so it is nature that decides. And that women are constantly discriminated against in the labour market, in wages, in the level of pensions, that's the fact, that's a fact. We really should do something about that. I'm glad we talk about this very regularly. The Commissioner is very often involved in these discussions. However, it would be good if what comes out of us here in this hall should also represent the awareness of the position of a woman. Unfortunately, I think that some posts did not really testify to this.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, Is docha go bhfuil sé tábhachtach go gcloisfear ní amháin guth na mban, ach guth na bhfear ar Lá Idirnáisiúnta na mBan agus táim baoch an seans a bheith agam cúpla focal a rá. Go háirithe tá sé tábhachtach go mbeadh díospóireacht againn san institiúid seo Parlaimint na hEorpa mar gan dabht ar bith níl aon institiúid ar domhan a dhéanann níos mó chun cearta na mban a chur chun cinn ná Parlaimint na hEorpa agus sin an fáth go bhfuil an díospóireacht againn. Give ndóigh tá to lán déanta, ach tá a lán le déanamh fós. I mo thír féin bhí olltoghchán againn an tseachtain seo chaite. Bhí cuta na mban againn don céad uair riamh; 30% mná do gach páirtí a bhí ag seasamh sa todhchán agus dá bharr sin toghadh níos mó ban do Dháil Iireann ná riamh. Taispeánann be sinn go n-eiríonn leo. Freisin, chuala mé ar an raidió inné go ndéanann boird comhlachtaí go mbíonn mná ar an mbord níos mó brabúis ná comhlachtaí nach bhfuil mná ar na boird. No ceacht do chuile dhuine.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I think it is good that there are so many men here, because I actually think that if women and men are not on an equal footing, that is one thing that concerns us all. Today we are talking about the socio-economic situation of women – but we could actually take any other one. Women's Day is really not a reason to celebrate, but a reason to challenge – every year again. When I think about the fact that 40 years ago it was decided in the EU that equal pay should be paid for equal work, and that there is still a 16% pay gap in the EU – in Germany it is even shamefully 22% – and then a 39% pay gap at retirement age, that is unacceptable. Violence against women is still the order of the day – and that too is unacceptable. Women are just as human as men and should be protected. Finally, we recently talked about women's entrepreneurship and found that access to finance, to credit for women, is far from being as self-evident as it is for men.  So, there is really still a great deal to be done, and I think, Commissioner, that you all have the support of all of us. We need a new strategy and this time one that really helps.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today is 8 March, and therefore a debate on the socio-economic situation of women in Europe is very timely. Despite the existence of two European directives on equal treatment in access to goods and services and on the various opportunities, there are still many gaps to be filled in order to achieve real gender equality. Women in Europe, too, suffer from a considerable socio-economic gap, a gap also confirmed in the report on the EU strategy for equality between men and women after 2015.  Although work is increasingly becoming an important aspect of women's identity, with a tendency for women in employment to grow, we still have a very low rate of female presence in decision-making processes. Women are under-represented on the boards of companies and companies, but even in the field of politics they have not yet gained the right space.  The European Union can no longer confine itself to mere denunciation, but must make a real effort to ensure that European women are no longer discriminated against, and we hope that in the next few years we will celebrate 8 March for some new concrete achievements, rather than pointing out the gaps to be filled.  Best wishes to all women.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Madam President, I have been lucky in my life, I have met many strong and brave women. One of them was my mom. I know very well that during the war it is not men who suffer the most. They're children, and they're women, and I'd like to remind you of one of them today.  I'm sure you know that on Friday last week, kidnapped and wrongly held Ukrainian officer Nada Savchenko declared a dry hunger strike. Dry hunger strike. Today is the fifth day he doesn't drink. Fifth day without water. Her condition is critical and she can die in a few hours or several days. An unfair trial is due to continue tomorrow, in which the prosecutor has requested 23 years in prison for Nada Savchenko. And I would like to call on you, ladies and gentlemen, to make every effort, as women, to be freed.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I always appreciate having the opportunity to discuss gender issues and gender policy in Parliament, because this is always important inspiration for our work in the Commission. Let me just react briefly to the points Members raised in the discussion. On better work-life balance, some of you mentioned that we withdrew the Maternity Leave Directive. We did it to prepare something better, something which will be better fitting with current needs – if you remember, we could not continue with the Maternity Leave Directive because two—thirds of Member States simply said that they already have it or need something fresher, something newer. So we are preparing – and it is a priority for me for this year in the work package for 2016 – the package of legislative and non-legislative proposals which will improve the balance between work and family life. And exactly as you said here, this is to open up choices for women – it is nothing like dictating or under-estimating the role of mothers. At this moment, the situation is the following: many young women who studied at universities – and 60% university leavers are women – have to decide whether to have children or whether to have a career. This is not possible, and also from an economic point of view, it is so irrational. We need to create the conditions for women to have both children and a career with highly qualified work. I really do not like the saying that it is the right of women to have children. Of course it is. I am a mother, and it is the best role I have ever had or could have in my life. But still, is it not society which needs children? To put it in a very cynical, or economic, way, society needs children, society needs future taxpayers, and why should only women bear this burden? This is not sustainable anymore. So this is where we tried to work, and this is our direction in working on this new package. The new things we want to bring in with this package are not only better arrangements for women, but better arrangements for working parents, and this is the real result from the previous proposals. On the pay gap, of course we need to find the proper instruments to decrease the pay gap. You are right, the 16% average pay gap in some Member States is very high – and it is even higher because it is the average figure. The 39% or even 40% pension gap is something which is not tolerable anymore, and I keep pushing the Member States to introduce into their national social and tax legislation measures which will decrease this pension gap and pay gap, because it is created in a large percentage due to the fact that women are caring for their families. This is the vote of society, so we must find the right instruments over this year.  I do not want to speak for too long, so just to quickly address the issue of multiple discrimination which Ms Soraya Post spoke about: we face a very serious situation in Europe, because we see these horrible cases. I speak to people who work with Roma citizens, and I also spoke to many Roma citizens directly. They say that the women pay the accounts for the family, and they are the victims of violence from the side of those who require the money back. This is physical violence; it is nothing like soft pressure, and that is just one example. We need to do more in fighting multiple discrimination. A last comment on more women in decision-making positions: you know that I try to promote the Women on Boards Directive, and I would like to inform you that this directive has been changed quite considerably under my portfolio, because I wanted to make it more gender neutral. There was a myth – which really hindered the process – that the Women on Boards Directive meant that highly-qualified men experts would be replaced by some women. We only want fair competition, and I think this is a very good direction for this directive. I would like to see the Member States which already have the law, like Germany and France and some others, to help us achieve the same result in the other Member States. I want to say that for more women in the decision-making positions it must not be a matter of one directive. Let us not create legislation; let us create proper policy, because this concerns not only the business sphere, where I myself have some reservations about how far to go, but it especially concerns public life and public positions, politics, and also – I am the Commissioner for Justice – in the sphere of the judiciary, because there we also do not see many women in high positions.  So thank you very much. I will finalise this positive message to send to the men: the idea that women want to fight is wrong – we want to cooperate. With this approach, things could change even more quickly, and it will also need cooperation on the side of men who understand how important this is. Thank you, honourable Members of the European Parliament, for your continuous effort to help and to support. I esteem it very much.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed.  Written statements (Rule 162)

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – On International Women's Day it is customary to profusion gender approaches, references to equality policies, promises of equality. The EU institutions themselves are lavish in these approaches. But it is almost always worth mentioning aspects such as the profoundly negative impacts that existing policies (designed, defended and imposed by the EU) have on the level of worsening inequalities and discrimination and exploitation of women. Exploitation and impoverishment policies, emanating from the European Union and implemented by governments, have promoted and exacerbated inequalities. Women are the most affected by poverty, unemployment, job insecurity, wage discrimination, in addition to discrimination in maternity. In this regard, it is worth remembering that the Juncker Commission is preparing to put the proposal for a Maternity Directive in the dustbin. Emblematic measure.  In addition, the growing difficulty of articulating personal, family and professional life is added, namely by the deregulation of working hours. This situation is aggravated by the attack on the social functions of the State, the destruction of public social security systems, along with the reduction in the value of important social benefits. It is not possible to promote equality without the necessary rupture with social setback policies that generate inequality, oppression and exploitation.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: writing – Gender equality and the related emphasis on equality between women and men must be a strong theme in individual EU Member States. Each of the women represents a unique contribution to modern society and it is therefore essential to systematically create conditions improving their quality of life. Today, on the occasion of the YJ, we are witnessing the European Commission's statement on the socio-economic situation of women in Europe. There's definitely some symbolism in that. What is important, however, is that many EU Member States, as well as the EC itself, make only a result of a real improvement in the situation of women in society, in addition to superficial statements. Examples should also be given to individual political parties and movements, which must create much greater scope for women to be applied in top structures. In addition to the annual tulips of 8 March, women deserve, above all, the preparation of effective legislation that will improve the conditions of their employment, level their income, help in their business or prevent gender-based harassment and violence. The challenge is also demographic developments, which we have been complaining about in Europe for a long time. However, reversing it also requires an adequate increase and guarantee of a woman's income during maternity leave. Indeed, it is time for the MJ to no longer be just a formal holiday, but to become a kind of opportunity when every government is able to make a clear deduction for its citizens of what it has done to improve their lives.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. – International Women's Day is a recognition of the importance of women in the world. I think it is important that, in practice, there is an acceptance in society of gender equality. Personally, I want value recognition rather than the imposition of percentages. Anthropologically, women have leadership qualities, being good organizers, stress-resistant, convincing, responsible. There needs to be a change of attitude. Women must stand in solidarity, they are in many majority countries and yet women are often not voted on when they run. I believe in the need to change the mindset among women, but also for men. It's not necessarily the laws that need to manage family life, it's understanding. Taking values in society is the recipe for gender equality. That is why I believe that education in this regard is very important. Women must assume entry into politics, because in a democratic state, politicians establish public policies and laws that govern economic and social life.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: Writing. – International Women's Day is an opportunity to balance progress in balancing mainstream women's opportunities with minority men. It is known that in the EU and in other regions of the world, women are at risk of unemployment, or so-called "working poverty" or low incomes in old age. There are areas of human activity where equality is nonsense. Still, there are plenty of areas where equalization opportunities are possible. Literally scandalous is the pay inequality between the same professions and the same employment status between men and women in Central Europe, where equal opportunities have a long tradition under laws and various sub-legal norms. The more than 20% difference between the wages of men and women in the same position can hardly eliminate the invocations for members of company boards or the various types of positive discrimination in the case of elections to representative bodies of various degrees. Unfortunately, it is those who propose such standards who do not pay attention to the low representation and management of women and the disabled in public institutions, starting with the EP, the EC and ending with the municipal authority in a small town. Unfortunately, some rational recommendations from the EU institutions are taken in a similar way. The Barcelona Declaration, which recommended in 2010 that EU states ensure nursery and nursery capacities, is not being fulfilled in the long term. It is precisely these specific rational measures that we should focus on in the future, if we are not to be ridiculous.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – International Women's Day is a good time both to take stock of achievements in respecting women's rights and challenges in this regard. One such challenge is access to education. The international community agrees that education is the best social, economic and political investment in development. The education of m.in. raises awareness of their needs and rights, affects their health and provides an opportunity to improve the economic situation of the whole family. Despite this, millions of girls and women around the world are still deprived of access to education and training. To change this situation, we need a multi-level approach to access to education. Firstly, education should be accessible to as many people as possible, regardless of gender, economic and social status or place of residence.  In this context, it is the state's task to provide free primary education and financial assistance to those whose access to education may be hindered, for example, by reason of their place of residence and to create a friendly educational infrastructure. Secondly, education must be adapted to the needs of different communities. Curricula should cover both basic social needs as well as human rights knowledge and skills. Mutual respect, tolerance, openness, justice are values that are essential in order to level the playing field between women and men.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – In Europe, poverty, unemployment and exploitation have a feminine face, as all the statistics in the system attest. Exploitation and impoverishment policies, emanating from the European Union and implemented by governments, have promoted and exacerbated inequalities, particularly affecting women. Women are the most affected by poverty, unemployment, job insecurity, wage discrimination, in addition to discrimination in and for motherhood. It is significant that the European Commission has abandoned the Maternity Directive. Austerity policies, with the attack on the social functions of the state, the destruction of public social security systems, along with the reduction in the value of important social benefits, have aggravated the situation. Only a complete break with these policies can pave the way for an improvement in gender inequalities. Everything else is just apps designed to elude citizens.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the report by Mary Honeyball, on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU [2015/2325(INI)] (A8-0024/2016).

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to greet everyone by wishing them a happy International Women’s Day.  This report on women refugees and asylum seekers is about bringing a much—needed gender perspective to the way we in the European Union deal with those seeking safety within our borders. At present, there are worrying disparities in the way different Member States handle asylum claims, particularly where those claims are related to gender. As a result, women seeking asylum in the EU are not guaranteed consistent gender—sensitive treatment. Women refugees and women seeking asylum are too often confronted with policies which fail to meet acceptable standards and where sensitive policies regarding gender are not implemented in practice. This report recommends a new set of gender guidelines to address these shortcomings. Violence is, tragically, an everyday reality for women and girls fleeing conflict. I have heard horrifying reports of women being exploited and abused. Research shows that women and girl refugees face this kind of violence, assault, exploitation and sexual harassment at every stage of their journey, including on European soil. Women – and indeed children – who are entitled to claim asylum are being coerced into transactional sex and forced into prostitution to pay for travel documents or a place in a boat or on a lorry. Traffickers and smugglers are having a field day with these desperate people.  Women need safer alternatives, as this report sets out. Pressure on the asylum reception systems should never excuse failure to protect women from violence. Nor should women seeking asylum and women refugees experience any double standards. They should have the same rights as other victims of gender-based violence.  I very much welcome the news in the past few days that the Commission has proposed accession of the EU to the Istanbul Convention. The Istanbul Convention is the most comprehensive treaty on violence against women in the world today and requires states to interpret the Refugee Convention in a gender—sensitive manner. It also requires states to implement reception and asylum procedures which are sensitive to the needs of women and girls. The proposal will now be discussed in the Council and in this Parliament, whose consent is needed for the conclusion of the convention by the EU. Only 12 Member States have already ratified the Convention and another 13 have yet to do so. We also need to look at the longer term issues. We often talk of refugees as presenting a burden, or bringing only costs to the countries which host them. However, with adequate investment, this need not be the case in the longer term. As I know we are all aware, refugees have much to offer our societies in the longer term, but we need to think carefully and develop integration strategies that are relevant to everyone. Women have specific integration and inclusion needs, such as childcare and language training. Many will not have been active in the labour market, so we need to look at properly matching skills and training provision with labour market shortages. Over 30 years ago, this Parliament acknowledged the need for a gender—sensitive interpretation of the Refugee Convention in a resolution in 1984. This was even before the UNHCR adopted gender guidelines. It would therefore be a huge step backwards if we were to fail to adopt this resolution today. Women and children now make up the majority of those seeking protection in the EU. The UN estimates it is now 55%. It is vital that we have the necessary policies and procedures in place to meet their needs. We need an approach which takes account of gender at every stage of the journey undertaken by these women refugees and provide the kind of protection that they need – and should expect – from the European Union.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Honeyball, and the shadow rapporteurs and Members who have contributed to this very important report for their excellent work. This report highlights a very important aspect of the migration crisis, ensuring the rights and needs of women and girls who are fleeing conflicts and wars.  According to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, 20% of Mediterranean Sea arrivals since 1 January 2016 were women and 33% were children. The EU has international obligations to provide protection and humanitarian support to those who need it. I fully support Parliament’s general recommendation that safe and legal routes to the EU must be made available for those fleeing conflict and persecution. No legislation and policies relating to irregular migration should ever prevent access to protection inside the EU.  We need to provide credible alternatives to irregular migration and enhance our legal channels. The Commission will soon come up with proposals in this respect. We have to proactively ensure that the newly arrived will receive protection and are enabled to participate and fully integrate in our societies. The success of integration depends on its timelines. Women face much stronger barriers than other migrants, suffering from multiple disadvantages. We need to act on this. The provision of services has been tailored to the needs of women, considering in particular childcare responsibilities.  The Commission foresees presenting further steps on improving integration in April 2016. Of course, the gender dimension will play an important role in this respect. Let me underline how important the commitment and support of Member States is; they already have important instruments at their disposal: the European Social Fund as well as the Asylum Migration Integration Fund. Both should be used to better respond to women’s needs.  The Commission is working to address the challenge of protecting women from violence and the risk of exploitation and enslavement. As regards the fight against migrant smuggling, the Commission already presented an action plan last year. In this context, we will this year propose strengthening the existing legal framework.  The Commission has already set out various elements on the issue of trafficking in the European Agendas on Migration and Security and the EU Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy for the years 2015 to 2019. I would also like to draw attention to a legal obligation on Member States to take measures to reduce demand, the importance of criminalisation, the use of services of victims and paying attention to all forms of exploitation. The Commission prioritises the fight against trafficking in human beings as a human rights issue. We raise this in dialogues with third countries.  Members call in particular on the EU to access the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women. I am happy to inform you that last week on 4 March 2016 the Commission adopted the proposal for the EU’s accession to this Convention, which is a comprehensive instrument to tackle the widespread phenomenon of violence against women. In conclusion, let me be clear. Europe will continue to provide protection for those who need it, including for women and girls seeking refuge in the EU. Actions of all the relevant stakeholders at European and national level should be mutually reinforcing and concerted efforts should translate into more protection and effective integration policies for women refugees. I thank you again for this report.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs Honeyball for her work. I regret, however, that we have not succeeded on this International Women's Day in ironing out the differences that have been at each other in the way in which this report has been drawn up and drafted.  According to the most recent estimates, 38% of asylum seekers in Europe are women. In the light of this fact, therefore, I welcome the fact that, within the report, Mrs Honeyball has included all the references to a European migration policy that is sensitive to the needs of women and girls, refugees and asylum seekers who, after exhausting journeys, fleeing war and violence, arrive at the borders of the Union. I also welcomed the call for a humanitarian approach for those most vulnerable groups, such as pregnant women, children and the elderly, but at the same time I am critical of the inclusion in the text of paragraphs referring to asylum procedures, family reunification or the very expensive requests for legal advice from refugee women.  So let us interfere in the national migration policies of the individual countries of the Union and, above all, let us encroach on our competences, because we are the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality and these issues are dealt with on a daily basis by the LIBE Committee, which is a committee that focuses precisely on justice and civil liberties.  We have therefore decided, as the PPE, to propose an alternative resolution, which aims to emphasise the need for a humanitarian approach to the migration crisis, taking specific account of the needs of women and girls at risk of abuse and violence during this route, and also to create a system of maximum cooperation with agencies on the ground, such as Frontex and Europol.  I also considered including in the text references to the need to create reception facilities that respond to the specific characteristics of women, such as dormitories and toilets separated from men.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, there are several crises that have stalked the European Union in recent years: the economic crisis, the euro crisis, the situation in Greece; but it is undoubtedly the refugee crisis that is currently threatening to destroy the European Union's own project, destroying Europe's project of values such as solidarity, justice and equality. And, in this context, we must be aware that, in the face of the reality of hundreds of thousands of people crossing the Mediterranean and reaching the European Union, when they flee hunger, when they flee war, when they flee from fear, there is a part of this group that are even more vulnerable: refugee women. Women and girls. According to the latest UNHCR data, as far as the last few months, 55% of refugees arriving on European shores are women and girls. Women who lose everything, lose their dignity;  women who have to sell their bodies to pay for Europe's dream ticket; women who are raped; women who are victims of mafias dealing with people. And in the face of this situation, we cannot resign ourselves and we cannot remain impassive. We have an obligation to respond, because we are also talking about the dignity of the European Union's own project. We need to be able to implement integration policies, access to education, health services, public services, to promote the integration of these people. And I have no doubt that the solution to this problem is not to return these people to the other side of the Mediterranean. I have no doubt that Europe's responsibility has to be to resolve this situation, but also to be able to give an answer to the hundreds of thousands of people who are expecting that dream of Europe today and that we are returning it with a project that has nothing to do with what gave birth to this European Union project. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Janice ATKINSON
