text: blue-card question. – We were at the same breakfast this morning celebrating International Women’s Day, but I did not hear from you when I raised the question that actually the Islamic values of these women coming in – I am not talking about fundamental Islam, I am talking about Islam across the Middle East – is incompatible with our Western values and your feminism – and my feminism , which I think really differs. Should we not be protecting our own women and children against the rapes and assaults that we have seen across European cities before we start trying to integrate more? Because they do not integrate. They have not integrated for 40 or 50 years.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: "blue card" response. – Mrs Atkinson, I am totally against that statement. Islam is not incompatible with the European Union. The European Union is diversity, it is plurality, it is difference. And there are European citizens who profess that religion: Islam.  What is incompatible with the European Union are those radical approaches, those approaches that they do is to separate, those approaches that, not only from Islam, but from other religions, are against equal rights of people, men and women. That is what attacks the heart of Europe: intolerance, injustice; not one religion or another, but the values that are destroying that principle which, from the European Union, some want to continue to defend.  Therefore, the problem is not Islam. The problem is intolerance, the problem is the lack of solidarity and the problem is not to be aware that this is a project of all.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are discussing here a wish list of the Women's and Gender Committee for women asylum seekers in the EU. In the crisis, we must remain human, there is no question about that, even humanly towards the people in our company. The resolution now calls for safe and legal entry routes through all Member States only for women. So, in the end, all migrants and refugees should simply be waved through. I am opposed to this, against the following background: the Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Frans Timmermans, recently said that 60% of the people who come to us are not refugees. We must distinguish between refugees and economic migrants, and the Committee on Women and Gender clearly does not want that. But it is inhumane if we bring millions of people to us or lure them here, put them in gyms for months and then make their future dependent on a clerk with stamp pads, only to send them back after the decision. This report is a wish list that far exceeds the competence of the Committee on Women and Gender, which wants to patronise the Member States and which is completely out of touch with reality. Like so many reports from this committee, we can only reject it. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – First of all, allow me to wish all our colleagues a beautiful life, a wonderful spring, lots of achievements, and health and happiness for this beautiful day, 8 March. Let us wish the same things for all the women and girls of the world. But let me also ask you this: do you not think that women all need better protection, wherever they are, irrespective of their religion, ethnicity and so on and so forth?  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. It is a wonderful question that points to this. We have also put this debate on International Women's Day here, and we can see how much interest there is, how many women are here: almost none. The plenary is virtually empty, and the interest on this day seems to be huge.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, we finally have a report which is comprehensive and balanced. This is a great achievement and was possible only thanks to the very constructive spirit of the rapporteur, Ms Honeyball, and the majority of the shadows, with the aim of recognising and protecting vulnerable women. Female migration is not a new phenomenon, but it is increasing, as is the vulnerability of female refugees and migrants to human trafficking, exploitation, discrimination and abuse. However, some colleagues think that the best way to celebrate 8 March is to deprive women refugees and asylum seekers of, among other things, sexual health and reproductive rights and deny them the possibility of a faster and more efficient family reunification process. The division in the House clearly shows that the challenge ahead is not the refugee crisis, but is in fact a political crisis. In difficult times, gender equality and women’s rights are often neglected by organisations, decision makers and civil society and considered as a detail, a luxury, or, in fact, a complication. When in crisis mode, it is more difficult to see the gender perspective, but this does not mean that we can tolerate the fact that the EU is not protecting fundamental and human rights. Women seeking asylum need specific support, since we know that many reception centres are overcrowded and lack adequate lighting and separate spaces for single women and families with children.  I hope that this report will be perceived as a guideline for the work of the Commission and the Council in order to have a truly holistic approach, also tackling the causes of violence against women, including smuggling and trafficking, and integrating more women in peace processes in order to avoid and solve the conflicts that are at the origin of every refugee crisis.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for International Women's Day is a day to highlight the feminist struggle that goes on every day of the year, and today we are focusing on strengthening women refugees and the rights of emigrants. That is absolutely right. I will focus on two things, safe escape routes and family reunification, although there is a great deal more important in this report.  Safe escape routes are particularly important for women and girls because their escape route makes them particularly vulnerable. Safe roads, humanitarian corridors are therefore particularly important. The fact that the EU is now closing its borders is hitting women and girls particularly hard, and that is why it is an unacceptable path that the EU has chosen to take. Family reunification: The restrictions imposed by several countries through temporary residence permits and complicated family reunification are a blow to everyone in the family, but especially to women and children who are more likely to remain in precarious and insecure areas of conflict. It is inhumane to separate children from their parents and parents from their children and it must stop. Finally, the Left Group fully supports this report and I am sorry that the right-wing group and the racists do not do the same. Apparently, solidarity does not apply when it comes to women refugees and migrants. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: question ("blue card"). It is sad that so many young male migrants were behind the sexual attacks and rapes against European women in Cologne and Stockholm in 2015. It is also sad that the authorities, the police and the media covered this up for fear of the reaction of the citizens. If we cannot even be honest and safe in the streets of Europe for our own women, how can we protect refugee women and girls from the same kind of sexual assaults and rapes from which they have just fled?

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: answer ("blue card"). "Your parade branch is to set people up against people and welfare against refugees. You're hypocritical, and you're going to have to be untruthful. At the same time, you do not have a project to build a society that builds together and stays together. Your future is a deep, gloomy impasse.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, yesterday was again an embarrassing day for Europe. While, in Idomeni, thousands of women and children spent the night in the rain, in the mud, in desponable conditions, there was a summit at which it was decided to basically violate European law, violate the Charter of Fundamental Rights and decide that collective expulsions would be operated in the European Union, without responding to individual asylum requests, as the law says. It seems to me that it is absolutely intolerable, and we are once again witnessing how the European governments are currently operating a genuine black five-year period of the integration project. This week, Parliament is going to approve Mrs Honeyball's report, which I would like to thank for her work, with a number of policies that we recommend to protect refugee women. It would be nice if, for once, governments, the European Commission, listened to what we are telling them: that the only way to stop sexual violence, extortion, exploitation, rape, is with a change of policies in relation to refugees. Because we need safe routes. It is the only way to combat human trafficking and, in particular, women, promote family reunification, ensure that women have the right to apply for asylum outside their spouse, demand an end to the detention of children, nursing mothers, ensure psychological support for those women who have been victims of sexual violence, sexist violence; a whole series of recommendations that we think are essential, because it is the most fundamental rights of women that are at stake. Please listen to us sometime in some of the things we sometimes vote here. (He refused to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as citizens and European institutions, we are faced with a challenge of epic proportions. The immense movement of refugees and asylum seekers knocking on the doors of the Old Continent and of which women represent, together with minors, for the first time, the predominant part is not a phenomenon of the moment but is an inevitable change in the demographic balance of our planet, which has many causes.  We are fleeing armed conflicts in the countries of origin, persecution and gender-based violence, or because of a lack of respect for human rights, but also because of climate change that has put the land on hold and because of the mis-exploitation of the planet's resources.  Europe is not a foreign spectator of these causes, but it is jointly responsible. And today we have the bill. In the face of this crisis, which sees women suffer in a shocking way, we must try to do one thing first: remain human. Only through concrete solidarity, a dignified reception, a collective awareness of all 28 Member States, can we face this momentous change.  There are those in Europe who think that the only way to deal with this crisis is to close, close borders, close borders, perhaps pay certain states, such as Turkey, to keep the problem a little further away from us.  On the contrary, we believe that there is no more time to lose and that we urgently need legal avenues of access to Europe, more humane ways. No woman leaves her home unless it turns into a mortal danger to herself and her children. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: blue-card question. – Actually, one of the reasons I am not in the same group is because of its approach to socialism and the Greens en bloc. It was one of the reasons I left the group. You are not making a distinction between economic migrants and those that are real refugees – again, you seem to have a big difference within your grouping. Do you make a distinction between economic migrants and refugees?

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Answer to a blue card question. Thank you for your question. There is no difference if you run away from a situation that causes death and then running away from a country at war is like running away from a country that does not allow you to survive because there is no possibility, for example, of cultivating land or because there are dictatorial governments.  So making distinctions only creates confusion and division, which is what Europe does not need.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, I have just returned from Iraq, where I visited, during a humanitarian mission, the Christian women who were driven out and hunted by the Islamists. For decades, I have been committed to women and their dignity in Europe. It is therefore with amazement that I discover our colleague's report. We can see it as the best illustration of libertarian socialism and disconnected from reality. Where did you hear that women were seeking asylum as LGBTI victims? What is the meaning of this community membership outside the major bourgeois cities of Western Europe? By proposing to extend asylum criteria to vague and inappropriate concepts, you increase the risk of even more mass immigration. How do you prove that a person is being persecuted because of their alleged intersex gender? What evidence will be required? As a woman of Europe, I am saddened by your pernicious use of the condition of women in the name of your moral dictatorship.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which is We are already quite short of time. I have now allowed blue cards during the round of speakers from the political groups, but I will not do so from now on. I say this in a matter of time, so that you will not be disappointed if I do not take you in.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: Madam President, the European Parliament wished to dedicate this International Women's Day to the issue of refugee and asylum-seeking women, as well as to the many children who accompany them. Of course, in this Chamber, no political group, no Member, and indeed no human being, can remain insensitive to the human distress, to the poignant humanitarian situation, which is increasingly manifesting itself on the borders of Europe and also in a number of European countries, with regard to the situation of refugee or asylum-seeking women. Nevertheless, we, the EPP Group, wanted to put forward a proposal for a replacement resolution on the Honeyball report, because we could not find ourselves 100% in the recommendations of this report. This resolution therefore focuses on proposals that are both dignified, humane, but also realistic and responsible for welcoming women political refugees, refugee women and asylum seekers. We want to make concrete and, once again, realistic and reasonable proposals that are directly articulated around specific needs - the implementation of specific procedures that are truly focused on the needs of women, especially pregnant women, for example - and which provide pragmatic and, again, reasonable answers. We also wanted to make the fight against all human trafficking and sexual exploitation, which is often the work of mafia networks, a top priority.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, at present one third of asylum seekers are women, 38% of migrants in the Mediterranean are women and children and 55% of migrants arriving in Greece are women and children. These figures reflect the deplorable human conditions in the countries of origin as a result of wars and instability, but they also show us in particular that, for women, sexual violence is significant in these countries. Last week we heard the testimony of Nawal Sufi, who came to testify to these dramatic situations experienced by these women today. These figures also show us that it is important to take into account the particular situation of these women, starting with the gender dimension in the context of the refugee claim, a status that has been drafted by men for men and which must be reviewed. We must also take into account the needs of women in the migrant journey. The issue of genital mutilation, for example, needs to be taken much more seriously. We must also improve the reception conditions, and I am here advocating for access to health, sexual and reproductive rights, including the issue of safe abortion, and, finally, for the inclusion and integration of these women, so that they can live here in Europe. If we do nothing, history will remember that Europe has massively turned away from most of its values. Humanism, solidarity, human rights, this report calls for. I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate Mary Honeyball on the work she has done.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Reports of the situation of women in exile are indeed alarming, and often they pay for the very possibility of travelling to Europe with their own bodies: both during and after the journey, unfortunately, they are exposed to rape, violence and misunderstanding. The dire situation in many reception centres is conducive to further tragedies. This situation, regardless of the assessment of the migration crisis itself, requires a strong response that could improve the fate of women within the European Union. Unfortunately, once again, the European Parliament is proving that it cannot stop at what could unite us all, but it is using every opportunity to promote gender ideology, to impose the right to abortion or the equality of sexual minorities. These really are not the problems of women who are ... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to express my sincere thanks to Mrs Honeyball and congratulate her on an excellent report, not only precise and complete but, above all, timely because, beyond its increasing scale as a multifactorial phenomenon and the shameful paralysis of European governments to manage it in the only way possible with a border policy , asylum and common relocation, something very important has changed in the refugee crisis.  On the one hand, the European Union, collapsed by this colossal flow, is facing, for the first time, a humanitarian crisis within its territory to which the Commission's unprecedented initiative to allocate 700 million humanitarian aid to this end gives a letter of nature. And on the other hand, now, 60% of refugees and migrants arriving are women and children – in the middle of last year, 73% were men.  Therefore, the gender dimension of this massive displacement of people is an essential factor to consider. Men and women are exposed to various types of vulnerability, but women and girls are particular victims of discrimination and sexual and gender-based violence.  "Irregular immigration is over," Mr Tusk, President-in-Office of the Council, said last night at the end of the umpteenth summit. And, yes, Mr. Tusk. But the desperate legislation and policies of the non-management of irregular immigration should not prevent access to the right of asylum enshrined in article 18 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and which complement legal instruments such as CEDAF, such as the Geneva Convention and the Istanbul Convention, which we will finally sign as the European Union.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Madam President, happy birthday to all working women who continue to fight for their rights! It seems that Strasbourg from Brussels is divided not only by 440 kilometres but by an abyss. While we in the European Parliament are debating a report calling for the protection of women refugees humanely, the European Council in Brussels says that Austria and the other countries have closed the borders. And some governments openly pass on racism, saying they don't accept Muslims on their soil. While we are calling for safe and legal avenues for refugees and migrants, the Council is making an inhumane bargain with Turkey: For every female refugee who receives asylum, an immigrant will be forced to return to Turkey. The UNHCR is right when it says that such an agreement between the EU and Turkey could be illegal, because it would violate both international and European law.  I invite you to vote on Mrs Mary Honeyball's report. (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Madam President, more than 150 years ago the black feminist Sojourner Truth, in her ‘Ain’t I a woman?’ speech, very clearly highlighted the shortcomings on some points in the struggle for women’s rights, which was excluding black women, working class women and lesbian women. Today in this debate I am actually reminded of that very important point, when we are discussing patriarchal violence and the fight against violence against women, and there are some in this Parliament who apparently do not want to recognise the fact that many hundreds of thousands of the women that we are speaking about in the European Union are actually refugees themselves. Those on the right of this Parliament actually seem to be making a distinction between European women, who deserve protection, and the others, who are not worthy of protection.  I am very happy that most of us in Parliament have understood Sojourner Truth’s point. Women’s rights are universal. They do not stop at national borders or religious or ethnic categorisations. With this report I think that we are taking a very important step, not only to protect female refugees, but also to strengthen intersectional feminism in the European Union.

name: Margot PARKER
text: – Madam President, if the UK had sensible immigration controls, such as the Australian points system, we could do more to help genuine refugees and offer protection to those suffering persecution. But because we have 300 000 net people coming to Britain every year, the government tries to look tough to respond to legitimate public concern. So they make it more difficult for the people we actually need from the Commonwealth and those we should offer protection to, in favour of unlimited numbers of unskilled workers from Europe with no criminal background checks. It is cynical. It is disgraceful.  Over one million people came to Europe in 2015. With Chancellor Merkel saying anyone can come through the Qualification Directive, the EU is encouraging vulnerable women and children to make the deadly journey through the Mediterranean. This definitely plays into the hands of traffickers and causes the loss of life. Europol has said that 10 000 migrant children are missing, with many caught up in sexual exploitation.  The EU has opened the door to millions of people from countries and cultures that treat women as second class citizens and LGBTI people even worse. Is it any wonder that we see the shocking scenes in Cologne and Sweden with women being sexually assaulted and humiliated? For the safety of our own women, and for the welfare of those seeking refuge, we must scrap these EU policies, and leave the European Union.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to read a few passages so as not to be trivial on such an important subject: 'Be very careful to make a woman cry because God counts her tears. The woman came out of the man's rib not from her feet to be trampled, nor from her head to be superior, but from the side to be equal, a little lower than her arm to be protected; from the side of my heart to be loved." For me this is a summary of what you should think and do for women. Less hypocrisy and more concrete facts; less mimosas and more serious things and that Muslims learn these things faster than we do.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: - Madam Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. Violence against women and the multiple vulnerability of refugee women have come under the spotlight on Women's Day. It is undeniable that women and children fleeing war and persecution are subjected to a great, great suffering and violence in their own country of origin and on the extremely difficult road to the European Union. We are all, of course, sensitive to the situation of these women and children. We also have important things to do, such as designing accommodation and creating facilities for cleaning. Therefore, the People's Party also drafted an independent, alternative motion for a resolution setting them out. She did so because the reporter went beyond the powers that were intended for her and touched on issues that are not the territory of the Committee on Women's Rights. Whether I am thinking of asylum issues or asylum issues, family reunification, legal advice. We could have done that by dealing with women who are vomiting, who are pregnant or breastfeeding their children. It is a very big problem that we are constantly doing so, and instead of being able to help, we are presenting how we can go beyond these powers. That's the impediment to problem solving. I am asking my fellow Members to support the motion for a resolution that we have drafted.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to Mrs Honeyball, who has really laid a good foundation with an excellent report. It is about the situation of female refugees. Female and male refugees have many similar problems: they are afraid of being separated from their group, they are hungry, they have the cold, they have lack of prospects, the physical rigours, the concern for the future. All this is experienced by women and men on the run.  But women still have to endure additional realities. They often travel with children, and often they are pregnant. They have often also fled from situations where they have already been threatened by violence or subjected to violence. They are still not doing well on the run. They are experiencing violence, some of them from other refugees. But they also experience violence from helpers, and they experience violence from men in the countries they are crossing. And they pay. They not only pay with money from the smugglers, but they also pay with their bodies. This is very important to mention here once again on International Women's Day. They pay with money and with a rape for a life jacket. The little daughter also pays with money and with a rape for the next life jacket. All of us in this House know this. We all know that women pay a very, very high price when they are on the run. We have a special responsibility to help women and children in this situation in particular.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Madam President, no one chooses to be a refugee and no one aspires to be an asylum-seeker. No woman sets out on a journey that could lead to what is – for me – the most poignant and appalling outcome I have seen, that is, women having to separate from their children due to illness or violence. The immense suffering of women refugees is abundantly clear. We have a duty to protect them from violence and rape and to provide health care and sustenance. However, this report goes too far in some areas, particularly finance and legal aid.  My delegation, the British Conservatives, will be supporting the EPP resolution as this recognises the competences of this committee and of Parliament. But I want to make it clear that we appreciate Mrs Honeyball’s work. We understand the sentiments, we understand the political thrust and support behind her report, and we will not vote against it.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The world is on fire and people who have not been as lucky as us to live in democraticprosperous countries are fleeing for their lives.  I would like to thank Mrs Honeyball for her fine work on this report. When we discuss important issues such as how asylum seekers are to be distributed between Member States or how to control the EU's external borders, it is very easy for the people who face these systems to be forgotten, but this report commendably balanced the challenges and problems faced by women refugees. Unfortunately, I am concerned today that the Conservatives here in plenary want to destroy the report and conceal the terrible suffering of women refugees. I cannot believe that today, on Women's Day itself, you will vote to make invisible the particular oppression suffered by women refugees and deny them the right to sexual and reproductive health, which is necessary after the sexual violence they have faced.  I think we should send a clear signal that we're doing everything we can...  (The speaker was interrupted by the President).

name: Stefan ECK
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We are having a hypocrisy debate today if the Balkan route does not remain open. We are having a hypocrisy debate today if we continue to accept so uncritically the recommendations from the far-right parties camp to protect borders by force of arms if necessary. Gun violence against women and children – that is not possible! Violence against women and children – that is how we bury the European idea! Europe must show solidarity with the fleeing women and children and open or keep the borders open for them. Let us fight the right-wing populist phrases of some of the ladies and gentlemen in this House! We owe it to Europe, we owe it to humanity. It is essential that we do this in order to make progress with Europe.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, I would also like to join those who thank Mrs Honeyball for her very fine work, and I find it very hypocritous to say that this report somehow exceeds the competences of Parliament and the EU. We must recognise that the rights of all women are universal. Now that we have looked at the specific situations and specific threats to women asylum seekers and refugees through this report, we also realise that we must provide them with services that take account of their specific situation and vulnerability. I think it is important that this report leaves the statement that they also include these sexual and reproductive health services, which are precisely because they are women, and I hope that Parliament, on this International Women's Day, will indeed recognise that we must protect the vulnerable groups to which refugee and asylum seeker women belong in particular.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is good that today, on International Women's Day, we are discussing the situation of migrant women. However, it has been just as good that we have been talking this morning about the socio-economic situation of women in Europe. Because much of what is rightly called for for asylum seekers and for female migrants, refugees, must be ensured and demanded for all women. Firstly, violence against women is an absolute taboo. Sexual harassment, assaults on women, violence, rape must be prosecuted with the utmost rigour and must be outlawed socially. Only victim protection counts, there must be no protection for perpetrators.  Secondly, I believe that it is important to combat smuggling and trafficking in human beings, people smuggling. This, too, of course, primarily concerns migrant women, but it affects many, many women. We have already dealt with forced prostitution on several occasions here in this House. This is a concern on which we are all in line. I hope that, with the results of the EU-Turkey Summit, we will now also take a step forward if we are to combat illegal immigration and create legal channels, with registration and with very specific proposals, so that we can get back into orderly procedure. I am grateful for the attention and I will, of course, also support our group's alternative motion for a resolution.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, regardless of the ideological idiocies I have heard today from the benches of the nationalist right, we must know that the response to the refugee situation will be the main test of whether the European project is alive or whether we are definitively destroying the values and principles on which the birth and development of the European Union is based.  European dignity is dying between the Mediterranean and the Aegean. The inability to manage the humanitarian refugee crisis can be the seed of the cancellation of that project based on freedom of movement, solidarity, cooperation and justice. The conditions of women and children, in this context, are extremely vulnerable, at all stages of the journey. Many women who reach Europe have been victims of sexual violence, victims of trafficking and exploitation of various kinds, which causes psychological trauma, shame and stigmatisation.  That is why I believe it is necessary for all Member States to sign and ratify the Istanbul Convention, which requires that refugee status take account of gender issues and guarantees specificity-sensitive reception conditions, support services and asylum procedures, as indicated in the Honeyball report. Today, the European ruling class must demonstrate that it is capable of having a forward-looking vision, of implementing policies based on solidarity and, above all, of having a policy for the reception, social and economic integration and the defence of the most vulnerable, so that it is a moral and political obligation that they must assume with greater determination and with greater strength.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her When we discuss the situation of female refugees and asylum seekers in the EU today, many colleagues are discussing at the so-called green table. Coming from Germany, I can only say: Mrs Honeyball, please look over the edge of your own coffee cup before you write reports by the European Parliament on the refugee crisis with the wrong priorities. Britain has taken in 166 Syrian refugees in the past 12 months. I'm not criticising that, that's okay. But please do not imagine being able to tell hundreds of thousands of volunteers in Germany and other refugee states how to deal with female refugees. Germany had as many as 1.2 million refugees in 2015. Before that, Italy and Greece alone took on a lot of responsibility. This is a European problem, a global problem.  Yesterday, I discussed your draft report with volunteers. The answer was clear: go to a refugee shelter for a day, get involved, help, and you won't write such a nonsense anymore. I therefore recommend the alternative motion for a resolution by the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats tomorrow.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate Mrs Honeyball on her courageous report. I think what makes it very clear: refugee women are doubly victims and suffer all kinds of violence. The question is very clear: are we going to be listened to outside this Parliament? Will the European Council listen to us? Are the Member States going to listen to us? I'm afraid not, after the shameful agreement they've reached with Turkey. What they want to do is close the doors to the people who are suffering and who just want to survive. I'd like to take advantage of these seconds to make a little vindicative memory. In 1939, not so long ago, Swiss activist Elisabeth Eidenbenz founded in the Catalan village of Elna in southern France a motherhood to welcome women fleeing Franco's terror who were giving birth in refugee camps on the beaches of Algiers. There the children died of cold and infections, and it had to be these facilities that welcomed those poor women. In this same motherhood, women fleeing Nazi horror were then sheltered. We were the refugees very recently. Where's the historical memory? Where is European solidarity?

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, more and more asylum seekers coming to Europe are women and children. Women are often alone with their kids. Women and girls are at risk of trafficking, sexual exploitation and violence during the journey, but even when they are in Europe safety and privacy must be assured. Separate sanitary and sleeping facilities are essential. Access to healthcare, including reproductive health, must be granted to women in need. The detention of girls must be avoided. Safe places for children in reception facilities while their mothers are being interviewed for asylum should be provided. Women who have undergone trauma need psychological and physical support. We have common rules on asylum and trafficking: now it is time for the Member States to implement them. Building capacity and ensuring training for police and other officials on gender-based violence is important to identify victims and increase protection and prevention. Children must be given access to education. For girls, school means empowerment and often also protection from violence, such as child marriage. Access to language training and work for refugee women is also key for equality and successful integration.  Today, on International Women’s Day, we should be able to tell women and girls who are arriving in Europe, fleeing war and violence, that they are not alone. Europe means safety for them. Let us join forces to protect them and put their dignity at the centre of our debate.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which I have to say two things to you now, because of the way we have already made: I said at first that I no longer accept blue cards, i.e. no 'blue cards', and it will not be possible to carry out the catch-the-eye procedure. Colleagues have all spoken for far too long, so it will not be possible. We have a guest of honour at 11.30 a.m. and we have 50 minutes for the votes afterwards – unfortunately that will not work out otherwise. I ask for your understanding.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Madam President, on this International Day of Women's Rights, let us think of these refugee women who are coming to Europe to flee the war and are very vulnerable. Their plight requires the European Union to fully integrate the gender dimension into its asylum policies. I welcome the excellent work of Mary Honeyball, who in her report very well presented the necessary measures to protect women and safeguard their rights throughout the asylum process. Under the control of ruthless smugglers, many women are victims of physical violence and sexual abuse on the way to exile. Like unaccompanied minors, they are at high risk of falling into the hands of human trafficking networks. These worrying findings call for more cooperation at EU level to combat trafficking and migrant trafficking. We also call on Member States to immediately put an end to the detention of children, pregnant women, victims of rape and sexual violence, as well as victims of trafficking, as it only exacerbates their trauma in the face of the violence they have already suffered. Finally, the European Union must pay special attention to LGBTI refugees and asylum seekers, who may be subject to further persecution because of their sexual orientation. In the face of intolerable violence against these women and girls, a specific approach is therefore needed to ensure their acceptance and integration in Europe under dignified and humane conditions. It is simply regrettable that the European right has opposed this text, which is essential to highlight a reality that has too often been ignored.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: – Despite the good intentions, this report completely misses the ball. I fully agree that attention must be paid to the difficult and often predicament of women refugees. For example, it is an excellent idea to advocate for separate sleeping and sanitary facilities for single women and unaccompanied mothers with children in reception centres. Of course, rape and all forms of violence against vulnerable people and children must be vigorously combated. Prevention is also important here. The question, however, is whether, with a policy of open borders and legal migration channels, all these problems will disappear like snow. Nor is it really a solution to give all female refugees more assistance and rights simply because they are women. What about the principle of non-discrimination? Another problem is that this report does not make any distinction between people fleeing war, torture or persecution and economic migrants. It also states that under any circumstances, child asylum seekers should not be taken into detention under any circumstances. So the existing EU directive on this must be scrapped. The few paragraphs that do go to the core (...) (The President deprives the speaker of the floor)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, we are celebrating today and we are all wishing for International Women's Day, but the strong message we must send as the European Parliament is that what we are saying today on this anniversary day must be implemented and put into practice as the European Parliament. I think it is commendable that the European Parliament's initiative this day should honour the refugee woman in particular, because in the minds of all of us there are at the moment all those refugee women, who are cornered in the fences of shame, so that they can save their lives and their children and their families, all those refugee women who are embarking on the long journey of life and death. , to escape the destruction of war; all those women who really fight the battles, so that they can survive in the refugee camp.  But at the same time, next to these women, we must also honour the Greek woman, who, in front of the fences of shame, erects a wall of solidarity and dignity, supporting and helping the refugee woman in Greece, idomeni, the islands, from end to end. Just as we must honour and bow to the woman of Cyprus today. The woman of Cyprus is the refugee woman of Cyprus, the only European refugee woman, who for forty-two years has been fighting to return to her homes, is fighting to implement the human rights violated by the invasion and occupation, she is fighting and hoping to be able to live again as a human being. The European Parliament must honour the only European refugee woman, the woman of Cyprus, and the mother who has been waiting for forty-two years to find her missing child.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, the data shows that women and children account for 38% of the total number of asylum seekers in 2015. Although the propaganda machinery has convinced us otherwise for months, the figures clearly indicate that we have received significantly more militarily capable men than women and children.  I would not discriminate on the basis of gender if someone did not need to defend and liberate towns and villages in Syria and Iraq. If domestic military-capable men won't do it, who will? Europeans? Americans? We can help, but the biggest burden must be on the local forces. Unfortunately, the rapporteur has not learned a lesson from these figures and turbulence across Europe, so she continues to promote open borders and loose asylum policy. I also think that at the very least it is incorrect to use the misfortune of refugee women and asylum seekers to promote abortion. I'm not advocating for closed borders, but I'm not advocating unreservedly open borders.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – Women and children fleeing brutal violence experience horror and trauma. But we are also faced with a great paradox, because often what they are fleeing from then meets them during their escape – nay, even already on the territory of the European Union. That is why I understand the demands that are contained in the report, although not everyone should agree. However, the question must be asked why this is the case, why we are dealing with this paradox. This is because often in Europe, often in the Member States, their religion, history, tradition, principles and right of origin are placed above European law, or at least next to European law. This state of affairs is tolerated, and it is the guests who have to comply with the rights and rules of the hosts, not the other way around. Therefore, one element of our action should be the absolute application of European law, democratic norms and civil society principles to those we host on our continent. It is also necessary to ensure that all Member States sign the Istanbul Convention, that is to say, the Council of Europe Convention.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, thank you for the excellent pronunciation of my name.  Commissioner, as a refugee, most of us imagine a man aged 20 to 35 who comes to Europe and risks his life to achieve his dream goal of living in the well-being that European society can provide to these people.  But few people realise that half, at least half, of women and children are currently standing on those borders between Macedonia and Greece, which are being discriminated against in some way in the way they are received by certain authorities and constantly being attacked by men. And it is these women who are embarking more and more on the road. And we have to respond to that.  However, this report, which has excellent intentions and it is a pity that the European Parliament does not agree on it, has unfortunately fallen victim to another political struggle. This report has been used to implement a number of things that have absolutely nothing to do with the position of women and the current situation in the European Union. And I think we have to say no. I therefore support the position of the European People's Party, which is giving an alternative resolution.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, due to the fact that we have run out of time and I gave all the important and essential information in my opening remarks, I would like to limit myself to thanking Members for their comments and the discussion, and to assure this House again of the preparedness of the Commission to do its best to take all efficient measures to make the life of vulnerable people coming to the EU with the wave of refugees easier , and to reflect this in all its legislation and all its steps which will follow, be it the Istanbul Convention, be it asylum procedures or other steps.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, in our European Union we are relatively well off and relatively prosperous. Those refugees who feel that they have to leave their countries, their homes and often their loved ones to escape war and suffering are not in the privileged position that we are, and no one leaves home unless they really have to. We know, and we have heard during this debate, that women refugees have very special requirements which many of the speakers have pointed out. I would urge you all, therefore, to vote against the EPP resolution, which significantly waters down what my resolution says about women refugees and their special needs.  The EPP resolution waters down family reunification, which is an essential human right, aid for pregnant women, support for those women who have suffered violence, and childcare facilities, amongst other things. As has been said, women’s rights are universal rights. The European Union has a long history of supporting women, and we must continue that. So please, therefore, support our report in the vote today.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today. (The session was briefly suspended)) Written declarations (Article 162 CRP)

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. – "Help us restore our dignity". This short, direct phrase was written on a small poster by a refugee in one of the thousands of reception centres in Europe. Dignity is linked to freedom and respect. Refugee women and girls make up about half of the world's refugees. They face threats during the escape journey and risks that also don't end when they arrive at the place they expected for sure. Refugee women, especially with disabilities, the LGTBI collective, and older women, are vulnerable at all stages of travel, in countries of origin, transit and destination. Invisible due to her dual status as a woman and refugee. Asylum policy must be sensitive to this in order to protect the dignity on which European construction is based.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: in writing. Highlighting the vulnerability of women and children in the current migration crisis is not a gender equality policy action; beyond that, it means becoming aware of an objective reality that has important consequences in relation to the management of migration flows by the European Union. This report highlights the significant change in the demographics of the migration problem, where more and more women are fleeing persecution in their countries of origin (in January 2016 the percentage increased from 38% recorded in the year before 55% according to UNHCR data). But the dangers are not only found there. Once the journey to a safe place has begun, risky situations continue and their vulnerability is accentuated, both on the journey and upon arrival at reception centres. That is why the EU must protect women, including measures that take into account their situation in Community migration procedures and, above all, by creating legal and safe routes to the EU to protect them from exploitation networks and human traffickers.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. Nearly half of the world's refugees and more than a third of Europe's are women. Women are in a particularly difficult situation when it comes to fleeing. They are vulnerable to the convenience of people smugglers, and often to official authoritarians, while in many cases they are also responsible for caring for children. They therefore need special protection and support. I welcome the fact that the report on the situation of refugee women deals extensively with the situation of refugee women and proposes solutions to their specific problems. Of these, I consider it particularly important that women should be given priority protection in refugee camps and reception centres. Be safe places for them, do not suffer disadvantages in food and access to drinking water. It is also very important that refugee women have continuous access to medical assistance and psychological support for the processing of traumas. It is also crucial that refugee women are widely informed about their rights, actions and opportunities throughout the asylum process, of course in their mother tongue. Away from their birthplace, often away from their families, this is the only way they have a chance of not being completely vulnerable. We must also remember that we must ensure that every single refugee girl is properly trained and that women are given the opportunity to receive training and education during integration. Some of my member's archives are opposed to the proposal; as they say, its implementation is too expensive and has too much say in the tasks of the Member States. I don't see it that way. I believe that ensuring equal opportunities for women, including refugees, is our fundamental moral obligation, which we cannot escape.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this year the European Parliament has rightly made the theme of International Women's Day the status of women among asylum seekers and refugees. Much has been said in the media about the low proportion of women in the total number of refugees, but according to recent UNHCR data, the proportion of women has increased since the end of last year. In fact, since January this year, more than half of asylum seekers have been women and children. Number in itself is not the most important thing, but as the proportion of women in refugees increases, so does the need for an asylum policy that takes women more into account. Women have special needs, especially when it comes to health services and safety. We can make it easier for female asylum seekers to operate by fairly simple means, such as providing them with locked accommodation and training interviewers to identify women's areas of expertise, which would enable them to become more quickly involved in working life and other social activities. In addition, the networking of immigrant women, both among themselves and with women of the ordinary population, must be promoted. Asylum seeker women also need their own low-threshold health services, including counselling on sexual health, as well as a safety network for potential crisis situations.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. For my part, I would like to stress four points which I believe are crucial in this context: first, the establishment of an information system for women in the asylum procedure, in particular on the rights they have in this area, such as the possibility of requesting that an investigator and an interpreter be able to conduct an individual interview without the presence of a third person; second, granting migrants legal status independent of their spouses, as well as family reunification procedures that give them individual rights; third, the establishment of a programme to address the health needs of both short-term and long-term refugee women, including psychosocial counselling or access to abortion; fourthly, compliance with the 2011/36 Directive on the Prevention of Trafficking in Human Beings, as well as better police and judicial cooperation to best combat trafficking and trafficking in migrants

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. – Unfortunately, in the context of the refugee crisis that is stifling Europe, many Member State governments have only demonstrated by their actions that they do not see tragic human fates behind the statistics. Some governments spend massive millions of public money to increrate hatred and create fear against those seeking refuge here. The crisis has certainly taught Europeans one thing: to be human in inhumanity, even if it is so difficult. About half of the world's refugees are women or girls. Women and girls deprived of the protection provided by their homes, governments and often their families are more vulnerable to various threats. In addition to the adversity of escapism, they are often subjected to harassment or indifference by officials, often subjected to sexual harassment, and this is often the case even in the environment where shelter is supposed to be safe. Despite the establishment of a common European asylum system, the laws, policies and practices of each Member State remain significantly different and the lack of protection for women seeking asylum in the Union is striking. That is why I consider it important to take a European step in this respect.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she Before i go on to the sitting, I would like to say to you that we have all been deeply saddened to learn of the death of the Honduran human rights activist Berta Caceres. Mrs Coceres was a shining example for the many who fought with great courage on the front line to ensure that the country and the rights of the indigenous people of Honduras are respected. Mrs Coceres was personally known to many of her fellow Members here in the House and has worked closely with many of them over the years. The European Parliament therefore condemns this incident in the strongest possible terms and encourages the Government of Honduras to do everything in its power to bring the perpetrator or perpetrators to justice. In addition, we will continue to work hard to protect human rights defenders such as Mrs Caceres around the world. I sincerely hope that this tragic event will not discourage other activists, but will encourage them in their fight for human rights, for which so many people have sacrificed their lives, especially in Honduras. We – and I believe that all those who have known Mrs Céceres – will remember her in an honorable memory. Mr Grandi, Commissioner for Refugees, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for Refugees and Human Affairs and Human Affairs. Today, 8 March, the European Parliament is, as it does every year, here in plenary, on International Women's Day. But this year, a lot is different. We are in the midst of the biggest refugee and migration crisis since the end of the Second World War. It is therefore self-evident, and I also believe logically, that on 8 March 2016 we should pay particular attention to the women affected by this crisis. Since this February, the number of women and children coming to Europe has exceeded the number of male refugees. And we all know that women are particularly vulnerable and, on the run like the one that many have taken, are exposed to a variety of dangers. We see this every day and we receive dramatic reports every day – about discrimination, humiliation, violation of their dignity and the deprivation of fundamental human rights. And conditions continue to deteriorate as thousands are stranded in overcrowded camps and do not know where and if they will be given the opportunity to start their lives anew. That is why, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament is united in its fight against all forms of violence against women, whether in their home countries, during the flight, but also at the destinations. We owe it to the people who fought so hard for the rights of women on this continent, to the many courageous women who fought for women's rights for decades, such as the first President of this House, Mrs Simone Veil, to name but one name from our own ranks. I am aware that the legacy of these women is not irreversible. On the contrary, nothing is guaranteed forever. That is why the rights that have been defended must be re-defended every day. I am therefore pleased that the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Filippo Grandi, has come to our extraordinary meeting. Mr Grandi, Mr Grandi, you have the floor.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: UNHCR. – Mr President, thank you for welcoming me here. It is an honour for me to be with you today to mark International Women’s Day and to speak about it from the perspective of the United Nations’ refugee organisation. Last month I was on the Greek island of Lesbos where I saw the Hellenic Coast Guard bring in a boat it had just rescued at sea. The boat was carrying 200 people. Most were women with children, some of them very small, many elderly and a few sick people. As they were disembarking, I spoke with several of them and they told me stories of the conflicts they fled from in Syria or Afghanistan, the dangers of their journey and worries about what the future would bring. They were just one of many examples of today’s global displacement crisis.  Over 60 million people worldwide have been forced to flee. On average, 42 500 are forced to flee their homes every day. Half of them are women. Even though the vast majority of these uprooted people, 86%, are in other continents, Europe is now also seeing record numbers of refugees and migrants arriving on its shores. As you know very well, in 2015 a million people arrived in Europe, crossing the Mediterranean in unseaworthy dinghies and flimsy boats. We have all seen the images of the piles of discarded life jackets on the Greek beaches of those who survived the perilous journey. More than 3 700 people did not make it: a tragic testimony of our collective failure to properly address their plight. This year, to date, 138 000 refugees and migrants have arrived in southern Europe. In public opinion the image is often that of young single men arriving in Europe to look for work. Today, on International Women’s Day, I wish to report instead that nearly two-thirds are women and children, up from last year’s 41%.  Take for example Fatima, who fled the war in Syria. She was found in a state of shock in the port of the Greek island of Samos. She was severely traumatised and injured. She had suffered violence at the hands of the man she had been travelling with. She was taken to a hospital for treatment and there she revealed that her husband had entrusted her and their young daughter to a man she did not know to get her to a safe country in Europe. During this journey the man confiscated all their travel documents, mobile phone and money. He abused Fatima and denied her direct contact with her husband. Fatima is just one of thousands of women and girls who are making the journey on their own, fleeing violence and persecution only to face a similar ordeal on their way to Europe, a place where they had hoped and expected to find sanctuary. Many desperate people worldwide view Europe as a safe and prosperous place that stands up for human rights and welcomes refugees. Most, for lack of better, safer alternatives choose the services of smugglers at their great risk. Let me also be clear on an important fact that is often overlooked. The majority of the people arriving in Europe, 88%, come from the world’s top 10 refugee producing countries, chief among them Syria, Afghanistan and Iraq, but also Eritrea and Somalia. This has been, and essentially remains, a refugee movement. The number of women and children among them is increasing rapidly, as I have said, and many travel without male relatives. We also see a large number of pregnant women, or women with babies and small children, among the arrivals. A recent UNHCR study found that 20% of the Syrians arriving in Greece were families headed by women, without husband or father. Just as Fatima, these women and children are exposed to abuse and sexual violence at the hands of unscrupulous smugglers or are at great risk when they travel along insecure routes, having to stay in places that lack basic security, such as parks, bus or train stations or at the road side. In Greece we have seen a rapid build-up of stranded refugees and migrants, currently over 35 000, who as a result of border closures in the Western Balkans have been denied access into the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. This has had a direct impact on women and girls, who are suffering disproportionately and are at great risk of sexual exploitation and trafficking. We at UNHCR, with our partners, support local authorities in all affected areas to improve reception conditions and to provide assistance to people in need. We have taken measures to reduce risks and help women along the way. Many reception areas and transit points now have separate facilities for women and children. Together with Unicef and the International Committee of the Red Cross, we have set up 20 child and family support hubs. These hubs, also known as ‘Blue Dots’, provide a safe place for women and children, where they can find all available services and information about their options in a single location. The hubs aim to help vulnerable women and children on the move and mitigate the risks of trauma, violence, exploitation and trafficking. However, we need more than a humanitarian response. On other continents, countries with far fewer means than Europe have been responding to much larger movements of people forced to leave their homes and continue to do so. In this very Chamber, exhortations to states around the world to treat refugees according to principles and in an organised manner have resonated many times. Such exhortations now apply to Europe. This emergency does not have to be a crisis. It can be managed. As you know, yesterday the European Union Heads of State or Government met with Turkey on the onward movement of refugees and migrants to Europe. We were not party to these conversations and understand that discussions on the details are still ongoing. But as a first reaction, I am deeply concerned about any arrangement that would involve the blanket return of anyone from one country to another without spelling out the refugee protection safeguards under international law.  (Applause)  An asylum seeker should only be returned to a third state if the responsibility for assessing the particular asylum application in substance is assumed by the third country, the asylum seeker will be protected from refoulement, and if the individual will be able to seek and, if recognised, enjoy asylum in accordance with accepted international standards, and have full and effective access to education , work, healthcare and, as necessary, social assistance. These safeguards would need to be set out legally and would need to govern any mechanism under which responsibility would be transferred for assessing an asylum claim. Pre-departure screening would also need to be in place to identify heightened risk categories that may not be appropriate for return, even if the above conditions are met. Turkey is already hosting nearly three million refugees and it is important for the international community to share this responsibility more widely. We welcome, of course, any initiative that promotes regular pathways of admission for refugees in significant numbers from all neighbouring countries in the region – not just Turkey and not just Syrian refugees – to third countries. We hope that this will happen and that it will also apply to other countries in the region that also host a considerable number of refugees, such as Lebanon and Jordan. In fact, UNHCR has been calling on states to increase the different legal routes for the admission of Syrian refugees so that they do not have to resort to people smugglers and to dangerous journeys. These pathways include resettlement, humanitarian admission, private sponsorship and refugee—friendly family reunion, as well as student scholarships and labour mobility schemes. A key opportunity to advance these solutions for Syrian refugees will be on 30 March, in Geneva, when UNHCR will convene a high-level meeting on global responsibility sharing through pathways for admission of Syrian refugees. States will be invited to pledge concrete commitments. We hope that up to 10% of the Syrian refugee population in the region, which currently stands at 4.7 million, can benefit from these pathways. I still believe that to properly address the flow of refugees and migrants in Europe we need a coordinated European response, based on solidarity, political leadership and the sharing of responsibilities to stabilise the situation and manage the movement of people more effectively. Last Friday, we presented a set of practical proposals to the European Union and its Member States that would help achieve that. These proposals remain valid. They focus on improving registration and referral processes, including the relocation schemes within Europe. It remains imperative that relocation works and that the necessary places are made available. With the support of the Commission, for which we are grateful, we also need to boost the emergency response capacity in Greece. UNHCR is on the ground with its partner, working closely in support of the Greek authorities. Finally and looking forward, we must build on the lessons we have learned. It is crucial to strengthen compliance with and uphold the standards of the Common European Asylum System, even in times of emergency. It is of paramount importance to prevent further suffering and loss of life and to strengthen protection safeguards for people at risk, in particular women and unaccompanied children. This includes improving search and rescue operations, developing coordinated systems to protect and help unaccompanied children, and establishing measures to prevent and respond to sexual and gender-based violence. We need a new approach to develop an effective European asylum system, not only to manage the current refugee and migrant movement, but also for the future. We have to ensure that Member States located at the external borders of the European Union will not continue to bear the disproportionate burden in addressing immediate reception needs. The solidarity that is so essential today for Greece and Italy may well be required for other states in the future. Next week, the conflict in Syria will enter its sixth year. More than 4.7 million people, as I have said, have sought asylum in the region and 6.5 million people are internally displaced. Inside Syria, it is estimated that 13.5 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance, including 4.5 million in hard—to—reach areas. With the cessation of hostilities now holding for 10 days, the United Nations organisations, including UNHCR, have been able to deliver some much-needed humanitarian aid to people who have suffered years of war and deprivation. Meanwhile, in the neighbouring countries, despite the generosity of host governments and communities, Syrian refugees are facing increasingly difficult living conditions after five years in exile. A recent study we conducted with the World Bank found that in Jordan and Lebanon, 90% of the Syrian refugees are living under the national poverty line, as they have little access to legal work and many, by now, have depleted any resources they had brought with them. At last month’s London Conference, the international community pledged EUR 10 billion for activities that are meant to help the refugees and the host communities in improving education and livelihood opportunities. States must now honour the pledges made at the conference. This is very urgent in stabilising the refugees in the region and we need to take advantage of the window of opportunity given to us by the cessation of hostilities in Syria. But Syria is not the only country in the region beset by violence. In 2015, the escalation of violence in Iraq resulted in waves of new displacement. During the last two years alone, nearly 3.3 million people have been displaced across the country. Sixteen percent of the people arriving in Europe today are from Iraq. And after more than three decades, Afghans remain one of the largest refugee populations in the world, with some 2.6 million registered refugees. The vast majority of them live in Pakistan and Iran. An upsurge in violence in the second half of 2015 caused significant levels of displacement inside the country and across the border, including many unaccompanied children who try to reach Europe. Today, in Afghanistan, 31 out of 34 provinces are affected by conflict, with more than one million people registered as internally displaced, an increase of 78% compared to last year. Twenty-five percent of the people arriving in Europe are Afghans and many have urgent protection needs. Elsewhere in the world, conflict continues to disrupt lives and uproot people. Our refugee programmes in Africa remain severely underfunded, while the number of wars and displaced people increases rapidly: northern Nigeria, the Central African Republic, South Sudan and Burundi, just to name a few. The Horn of Africa remains the theatre of multiple displacement situations, especially Somali refugees. In many of the protracted displacement situations in Africa, however, we can hardly give the refugees more, and even sometimes we give them less than the bare minimum to survive. In many countries they are not allowed to work legally, so they remain dependent on very scarce aid. In South-East Asia, in the Bay of Bengal, more than 33 000 refugees and migrants, mostly Rohingya and Bangladesh nationals took to smugglers boats last year. Many died, the majority not from drowning as we see in the Mediterranean Sea, but from abuse at the hands of people smugglers, abandonment and disease. We also have a very specific refugee crisis in Central America, where thousands of Salvadorians, Hondurans and Guatemalans are fleeing deadly transnational gang violence. Again, International Women’s Day is an opportunity to remember that most of them are women and children. They use the traditional migration routes, going north to find safety and a future, but many are indeed refugees fleeing violence, extortion and persecution. In a world riddled with conflict, mass population movement is a reality. Building fences and walls to keep people out is not a solution. It will only increase the suffering of the people who have already suffered the unimaginable.  (Applause)  And women everywhere are among the most exposed. In the face of massive displacement and arrivals, very often the first reaction of politicians is to resort to scaremongering. Manipulation of public opinion and inciting hate against those who are different are unacceptable. A real response can only be based on solidarity and human rights, on responsibility sharing and respect for international law. Today we celebrate the many achievements we have made on the road to gender equality and the participation of women in social, economic and political life since International Women’s Day was first observed in 1975. It is also a moment to think about the long way ahead to reach full parity. But it is equally a day on which to reflect on the fact that discrimination and exclusion, because of ethnicity, religion and gender, are among the main root causes of conflict and persecution and, ultimately, of forced displacement. In 27 countries, for example, women still do not have the same rights as men to confer their nationality on their children. Many of the women arriving in Europe come from these countries, including Syria and Iraq. That means that if the fathers are missing or there is no proof of paternal descent, their children will not have a nationality and are at risk of becoming stateless. This may affect access to healthcare and education, and affect their ability to return home when conditions allow. As we have said and heard countless times in the past 25 years, there are no humanitarian solutions to the political problems that are the root causes of massive forced displacement. There are no humanitarian solutions to the intractable wars, the upsurge in violence and the oppression and lack of governance in many parts of the world. We need political leadership and action, both to resolve the conflicts that cause displacement and to make sure that people like Fatima and her little daughter can find the protection and safety they need without having to resort to criminal networks and smugglers who abuse and exploit them. These are not abstract concepts about which to make abstract statements. They are real, brutal facts which only courageous political leadership and considerate, forward-looking decisions based on international cooperation, respect for human rights, solidarity between states and a renewed sense of humanity can counter and redress. Europe is facing a moment of truth. This is the time to reaffirm the values upon which it was built.  (Sustained applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the High Commissioner for the wake-up call regarding the situation of women migrants today. The sheer number of people arriving on Greek shores and travelling through the Western Balkans, and the numbers we read daily in the press, risk making us forget that these are individuals and human beings, many of them vulnerable and in need of protection: many women travelling alone despite the dangers they are facing, many mothers risking their own and their children’s lives. Let me assure you that the European Commission does not forget, and does not forsake its humanitarian duties. Yes, we have to take control of the flows, make them more manageable and lower them. Yes, we need to better manage our external borders, for the European Union, for the Member States and for their citizens, but also for the people arriving. Yes, we need to stop – also with the help of Europol – the business of smugglers that send people in their thousands every day to a possible death. Instead of dangerous routes, it is our responsibility to create more legal pathways for people in need of protection to be able to come to Europe directly, legally and safely. That is why I continue to call on Member States not only to deliver on the resettlement commitments they made in July last year and for the Turkey humanitarian admission scheme, but also to commit to more, and soon. All irregular migrants who have arrived through Turkey will be returned to Turkey in accordance with European and international law. For the people who are already here, we need to improve the situation. That is why we have proposed a humanitarian assistance scheme to be used within the EU. It is why we urgently need to proceed to large-scale relocations, and why we need to further develop reception capacities. And in all of these things, the UNHCR is our steady and quintessential partner, and I look forward to continuing to work closely together with Filippo Grandi, a person who has come to lead the UNHCR in the midst of the refugee crisis, and also a veteran on these issues: he is a man with commitment to the cause of refugees , and I count very much on his invaluable help. Let me therefore once again welcome the close cooperation that we have established with the UNHCR and express my strong appreciation of the work done by the UNHCR in the current crisis. UNHCR support is highly valued inside and outside Europe. The European Commission and the UNHCR work closely together to help Italy and, especially, Greece in accommodating and relocating migrants, but also in resettling them from the outside. Together with the UNHCR we need now to ensure a quick implementation of the voluntary humanitarian scheme from Turkey and to implement projects that will further improve the situation of Syrians in Turkey. As you know, our actions are not limited to the borders of Europe. The fact that over 60 million people are refugees or internally displaced persons across the globe reminds us that we should not lose sight of the fact that migration is not a European issue only; it is a global challenge. Everyone in the international community should take their share of the responsibility. All developed countries across the world should respond to the call of the United Nations for resettlement from the affected regions. The pledging conference organised by the UNHCR for 30 March will be the next opportunity. And we need to reflect together on how to positively address the phenomenon which characterises our era, our world: people’s mobility, a phenomenon which is expected to increase for many different reasons, to take different forms and to be directed on different routes. We cannot ignore people’s mobility. We can neither deny it, nor stop it. We need to prepare ways to respond to it without destabilising our societies, but rather by turning it into a two-way opportunity for the hosting countries and the migrants. We believe, therefore, that it is Europe’s duty and in its interest to support key partners managing the migratory flows and addressing the roots causes of the displacements. Dealing with the global migration crisis requires, therefore, solid partnerships, enhanced cooperation and coordination with third countries and with regional and international organisations. In other words, it needs a global strategy.
