In a multifaceted and complex refugee crisis like the one of today, there cannot be a one-size-fits-all approach, and it cannot be the responsibility of just one country or one stakeholder. We all need each other, and we need to work together. That is why the relationship and collaboration between the European Union and the UNHCR is of utmost importance. A lot of work awaits us in the coming days and months, and we are all ready and committed to do it.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Mr High Commissioner, International Women's Day is not just about rights, it is because of the facts.  Being born a woman should be the same as being born a man, but it's not: that's a fact. In many countries around the world, women have fewer rights and less freedom: that's a fact. In Europe, women have the same rights and freedoms in the law, but not in reality: that is also a fact.  I myself, if I were a woman, would have had infinitely more difficult to come here today, on International Women's Day, to defend women's equality. That's a fact, too.  There are many people who find the usefulness of an international women's day debatable, but it is indisputable that there are millions of reasons, millions of facts justifying this International Women's Day.  There are millions of girls who do not go to school because they are girls; there are millions of women who charge less for the same job because they are women. There are millions of old ladies who will never retire because they are grandmothers.  There are millions of women mistreated, beaten, wounded, mutilated, humiliated because they are women, and many of them are even poor.  In Europe, 3,500 women die every year killed by their partners, killed by men: eight, every day; eight, today. One in three women over the age of fifteen has ever experienced sexual harassment throughout her life. We have better intentions than the Taliban, of course, but we have nothing to brag about.  Today the United Nations High Commissioner is asking us to look into the eyes of refugee women, the most vulnerable, who are fleeing not only machismo: also war.  Those who always run away with their children – because how rare it is for a man to take the children when he has to flee; which by the system and by the mafias are forced into sexual exploitation. Those that have causes of their own to flee, such as genital mutilation or rape used as a weapon of war.  In the last year, in the Mediterranean, fleeing Syria, 55% of the people who drowned were women and children. In the face of a humanitarian drama like the one we are experiencing, the solutions we are listening to are becoming more and more inhumane. Putting barriers to the inhumane flight of women with children to be difficult dehumanizes us, not them.  A society unable to feel mercy for a mother who begs asylum with her baby in a cardboard box is a heartless society, it is an inhumane society. It's not, of course, ours.  Being a woman, being born a woman is a blessing. Getting women's rights and freedoms to be, in fact, equal to the rights and freedoms of men is a task, it is a challenge not only for today, but for our whole lives, if we really want to call ourselves "European" dignity. (Applause)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D- Mr President, everyone now understands, at least I hope, that in the context of the current humanitarian crisis, refugee women, who are increasing in number, constitute a particularly vulnerable group. On international women's rights day and by your presence, Un High Commissioner for Refugees, we highlight the living, and sometimes survival, conditions of these women. For my part, I will give the floor to one of them, Reem, a young Syrian girl. I quote: "I never got to sleep in the camps, I was too afraid that someone would touch me. The tents were all mixed and I witnessed violence. Women can't really complain and don't want to cause problems that could disrupt their trip." This testimony, collected by Amnesty International, is not that of a woman in Syria, Iraq or, I do not know where, who is plagued by endemic violence. This is happening here in Europe, as these women flee the horror of war in their home countries, they continue to experience the fear of aggression at every stage of their journey. What Reem's heartbreaking testimony reminds us is that migration policies have so far given too little weight to the issue of gender. The revision of the "Asylum" package has helped to raise the bar a little, but implementation on the ground is still far too weak. As my colleague Mary Honeyball's report recommends, this particular attention to migrant women must be given at all stages of their journey. This means from the asylum procedure itself, through the reception conditions and to the integration measures. It also means that reception staff need to be trained. This includes the establishment of sanitary facilities and non-mixed dormitories and access to adequate health care. What Reem's testimony also reminds us forcefully is that there is an urgent need to act together. The European Union and its Member States can no longer continue to multiply European summits without taking decisions on effective and collective actions to combat the humanitarian and moral crisis, in which the European Union is currently plunged. However, there are ways to create and strengthen the opening of legal and safe routes to Europe, but I see this as the best way to combat smugglers, who continue to enrich themselves; we have an effective mechanism of intra-European solidarity for a fair sharing of responsibilities - relocations from Greece or Italy, which are currently taking place on a drip-feed basis (600 people, I believe) must be implemented with political will. We also look forward to the Commission's proposal for a revision of the Dublin Regulation and we hope that this revision will drastically change the foundations; ensure full and consistent application of the common European asylum system throughout the EU, so that seeking asylum in Europe does not continue to be akin to a lottery or shopping; and strengthen cooperation with third countries of transit and origin, in clearly defined and balanced terms, including in particular compliance with human rights obligations. In the aftermath of the EU-Turkey summit, this balance is particularly crucial.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, as the UK Minister responsible for resettlement during the Bosnian crisis, I saw first-hand just what war does to a country, to its people and to their hopes for the future, and I am proud to be from a Europe that does not turn its back on the rest of the world. But the sad truth is that when some European leaders opened their doors last year to everyone seeking a better life, it merely pushed the most desperate, the most vulnerable and the most in need to the back of an already very long queue. To truly help those people most in need, I have long believed the solution is direct resettlement from conflict regions. It reduces pull factors, it presents the tragic loss of life at sea, it reduces the demand for human trafficking, and it helps stabilise our external borders.  If the EU is to continue offering a Europe of opportunity, sanctuary and community cohesion, then the EU must realise that resettlement and controlled immigration flows must be the solution. High Commissioner, as rapporteur for the Permanent Relocation Mechanism, I would like to try to link that proposal with an ambitious UNHCR-led resettlement programme with the EU. Relocation in its current form is simply not working. Let us be truthful with each other: some Member States feel as though the system was forced on them, and migrants only want to go to certain Member States. It is not a recipe for a long-term successful system. Member States will not support relocation in a meaningful way until the external borders are secure, the flow of migrants has stabilised and we start to have a sense of the numbers we ultimately need to relocate.  Keeping Europe’s borders open with no clear plan or end in sight will only exacerbate the situation. We talk about safe legal routes to Europe. Resettlement achieves that. It helps ensure safe passage, especially for women and children to whom you have referred eloquently today, taking them out of the hands of evil human traffickers. Too many female refugees are facing exploitation. Too many unaccompanied minors are tragically unaccounted for today. Europe could offer more Syrians, more women and more children refuge if we could get control of this crisis. To put in place a fair and controlled immigration system does not mean you lack compassion, but simply ensures that you can give genuine refugees the safety, the stability and the opportunities they truly deserve.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Grandi for his statements. Mr Grandi, you have taken up the post as High Commissioner at a time when unprecedented numbers of refugees have been approaching our shores. Within the space of two generations the refugee crisis has followed a financial crisis, and we can see how it is continuing to challenge the perception of our commitment to providing international protection to those entitled it. In Europe we tend to forget that we are living ever longer and, despite all our troubles, are still the richest continent on the planet. The very core of the global asylum system is currently being questioned by people who would prefer that the right of asylum was not an imperative right of an oppressed individual, but rather a kindness to be extended or withheld by the 28 Member States individually. I fear that in a world where states could choose whether to help refugees or not a lot of people in need would be left without protection, with irreversible tragic consequences, a cynical approach whereby the rich West dumps the challenges involved in receiving refugees onto developing third countries in order to sit back and hide behind walls, maybe sending a cheque every now and then so as to pretend to  care.  That is not an EU to which I wish to contribute  and, as the spokesperson on migration for the Liberal and Democrat Group and the rapporteur for this House on the upcoming revision of the Dublin Regulation, I can only give you, High Commissioner, a clear message that Liberals and Democrats in Europe will always stand up for the right to asylum. Whereas some people in this Chamber will claim that the choice is an either/or, that is to say, either you  support the UNHCR or you support the fundamental individual right of asylum, we will stand firmly by you and explain that you need both for the system to work. And, by the way, the UNHCR should be getting a lot more support, not least financially, from the EU. We are living in challenging times, but let us realise that this continent has never been in better shape to manage these challenges. You can count on my support and the support of my Group for your invaluable work and I look forward to cooperating with you in the days to come in the same way as I cooperated with your predecessor.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The UN, and the UNHCR in particular, is a key player in maintaining respect for international asylum law. That's why it's especially important that you're here with us today. I find it unfortunate that you have not been invited to take more responsibility in terms of how europe formulates its responses to the refugee situation and your words today make me even more convinced of that concern. You also give us the bigger picture that yes, there is a global refugee crisis going on, but we do not have a refugee crisis here in Europe. You highlight wise things, important things, such as the need to strengthen the rights and security of women refugees. We have debated this this morning and we will be voting for a very good report later. You highlight the fact that Europe must receive more and that we must do so in a way that divides responsibility between our countries. You highlight that the policy of closed borders is not the way forward. We need to create legal avenues. We agree with you. We need to help unaccompanied minors better and our reception systems need to be improved. I was in Calais yesterday, and the situation I witnessed there, it is not compatible with human rights. We ask you to visit Calais and see and witness the situation and evaluate the situation there. You point out that we must combat racism and Islamophobia in Europe. We agree with you. Last but not least, we cannot allow Greece to become a refugee camp. We must take joint responsibility. Mr Grandi, the way in which the EU is now trying to come to terms with Turkey to keep the refugees away bears no trace of your proposals, not a trace. Allowing the refugees to return with the same boat they came in is simply not in line with international asylum law. Thank you for drawing attention to this. It is with great concern that we see that the EU is not standing up for the right of asylum. We need your support and your pressure on Europe at this point.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, High Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The applause at the end of your speech showed you that we are very pleased that you have come here today and have reminded us, as the European Parliament, of the plight of women and children in this refugee crisis, the global refugee crisis. I think it is very good that you have once again awakened us with these individual examples, but also with these large figures, which show that we are dealing with a global problem. As Members of the European Parliament – at least by a majority still – we have recently been shocked that it has become so difficult in the European Union to implement the Geneva Convention on Refugees and the idea of political asylum. We in the European Union are shocked that, although this Union is made up of states that have all emerged from wars, from disasters, from the ravages of the last century, remembering what their own nation has been doing is no longer strong enough to adequately address this global crisis. I think that is one of the things that is why your speech is a speech that should shake us all up. If you look at what was discussed yesterday with Turkey and the European Union, it is clear that there is currently a very small check, and this pattern of 'one Syrian in, one Syrian out' should be something that shakes us up again, especially in the light of the speech you have made here. Because as much as we understand that we want to achieve an order through resettlement, we are disturbed by this so-called small approach to dealing with these big problems. In fact, I believe that you have made it clear to us that the Europeans as a whole have not yet grasped the dimension of the disaster and are therefore, on the whole, still trying to protect themselves from the disaster, and will therefore probably contribute to the worsening of the crises and disasters in our neighbourhood and in the world.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – p. – (DE) Mr President, colleagues, Commissioner Grandi, it is very good that you are here. Maybe we in Europe will finally be able to put all the dots on certain letters. Perhaps we will finally realise that the attachment of European countries is to help war refugees, not to open up their cities to all migrants. European society today eats the ripe fruits of the frivolity of its politicians. And in the future, they will only be more bitter if we get bogged down again in debates or deliberations. And there is really nothing to discuss the obvious. Yes, aid and humanitarian support for war refugees and those fleeing their homeland as a result of political persecution and a strict 'no' to those seeking a better life in Europe. You, Commissioner, you don't have to accommodate and probably don't accept guests in your house that you didn't invite. Why should european citizens do things differently? Let us therefore stop debating and start working to protect Europe from migrants, not to seek asylum for them, to protect the european Union's external borders, rather than for billions in buying Turkey's asylum, ensuring the security of community citizens. And the non-refugee resettlement of individual countries is a key matter for the United Nations and the European Union. Today, the causes of wars and conflicts need to be addressed. Yes, efforts are needed to help those affected by the fire, but without that help, real efforts are needed to prevent the fire from igniting and spreading. And, you know, it looks surreal now – for years we look at the burning of entire villages in one country or another when they burn, then we are looking for ways and conditions to help supposedly arsonists, albeit among them much more, who do not feel the smell of fire or smoke.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, how much hypocrisy on women's skin: European and foreign. Does anyone think of bringing Turkey to Europe, whose Prime Minister said that putting women and men on an equal footing is against nature and whose Deputy Prime Minister, two years ago, said that women should not laugh and provoke in public? And does anyone in this building, using women, think they're bringing people like that to Europe? I'm sorry! I'm sorry! People who say women can't laugh and provoke in public. But what are we talking about? Turkey, until it respects civil rights, is not and will never be part of civilised Europe, in my view. The EUR 3 billion, given to unemployed Europeans, not to the Turkish regime which uses them to close newspapers and reopen them when it suits them. Other than the rights of women and refugees!  Let us come to Italy. The figures, High Commissioner, say that last year, out of the 80 000 refugees who applied for political asylum in Italy – I say this to this building – only 5% were accepted as political refugees. 5%. Two-thirds of the applications were rejected. Since you talk about women, I would point out that in Italy, in January 2016, 7 000 applications for political asylum were received, of which women accounted for less than 10% – the rest, all adult and robust men – and Syrians, less than 30%. Syrian women are not seen unless someone wants to finance an uncontrolled Islamic invasion of this country and this continent. Finally, a question: how much does you Commissioner cost? How much does the UNHCR cost? How much do officials and employees cost? How many of the 7 billion budgets actually reach refugees and how many do not end up keeping people sleeping in hotels or in the office?  Real solidarity is done on the ground, not by paying people who sleep in the 5 stars. A hug to Italian and European women, precarious and unemployed, hungry and in difficulty.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr Grandi, you are the UN High Commissioner for Refugees. Unfortunately, as reality shows, you probably don't do very well in your work. Of course it is not only your fault but rather your other colleagues at the UN, those of your colleagues who have not reacted to the imperialist and neo-colonial policies of the powerful Western states, which have invaded or bombed almost half the planet. Where was the UN when the Westerners tossed Afghanistan, Syria, Iraq, Libya, Ukraine, almost half of Africa and many other countries? Where was the UN, when large multinational corporations, not just Western ones of course, exploited the work of millions of people in the least developed countries so that they could make super-corporations and serve the monster of over-consumers? when states that we consider to be our privileged interlocutors, as we saw at yesterday's summit, become donors and supporters of the Turks, who protect terrorism, traffickers and contemporary slavers? You must act immediately. You must take steps to stop the fire of war burning Syria and other countries and migrants to remain in their home countries to help their development. Together, we must preserve the distinct identities of all of us, both our own and our countries of origin, so as not to create a multicultural soup, in the hands of multinationals. As far as my country is concerned, the situation every day that passes is becoming increasingly desperate. Apart from the responsibilities and ideologies of the rulers, who have confused humanism with legitimacy and promiscuity, what is the UN's reaction? What have you done to prevent the already hard-fought Greece from the economic crisis from turning into a vast camp? We've had enough of words and postponements! We don't need any more; we need solutions and we want them now! Unfortunately, in practice it turns out that you cannot or do not want to offer them to us.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for his excellent work. Commissioner, but above all, Mr High Commissioner for Refugees, I would like to thank the Commissioner for Refugees. In parliamentary democracy, everyone in this House can express their opinion. I believe that the last two speeches you have heard are by no means representative of what this House thinks. (Loud applause and heckling) I would like to add, High Commissioner, that the European Parliament would like to thank you very much. (Sustained heckling and tumult) I would like to add, High Commissioner, that we would like to thank you and your officials very much for the excellent speech you have given. (Members of Parliament rose and applauded the speaker, still accompanied by tumult.)

name: David COBURN
text: –  Danke schön, mein Präsident! Mr President, I would just like to ask you whether, as the President of this august body, you are not meant to be neutral? Should you be siding in a partisan way with the people on this side of the House, sir? (Uproar and applause) With all due respect, Mr President, I think you should remain neutral in these regards. In the House of Commons your behaviour would be unconscionable. The Speaker of the House of Commons cannot take sides. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Coburn, I would like to thank Mr Coburn for his The United Nations High Commissioner was our guest of honour today in an extraordinary meeting. I am not prepared to insult him and his officials here. And as long as racism comes here from this side, it meets with my vigorous resistance. You can rely on that! (Continued heckling and tumult.) (The session was briefly suspended))

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The sitting is now resumed and we come to the votes. There are a great number of votes, so I would ask that we all cooperate to allow a smooth running of the session.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Pursuant to Rule 61(2) of the Rules of Procedure, I propose postponing the final vote and instead starting the interinstitutional negotiations immediately on the basis of the mandate that we have just decided.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: That is adopted. So this matter is referred back to Committee to allow the interinstitutional negotiations to begin.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Dear Fellow Members, I can't even speak with excitement. I am so pressed as to whether President Martin Schulz has reached the aircraft in Pyongyang. I hear you're in North Korea training in democracy and freedom of expression. He was running, he was in a hurry, he was in a hurry to get there and he's going to keep improving. But as far as animal health is concerned, everything that goes towards the European Union's agricultural and general economic policy and the industrialisation of agriculture is bad for animal health. Everything that's small, farm farming, family farm is good for you. After all, the owner has a direct connection to his animals, and in time he notices that if he is attacked by an infection and does something about it, he will take action against the epidemic.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, I supported this report on animal health as it represents a progressive step forward in European law and policy-making. On a personal and political level, I am strongly in favour of reforms that promote further protection of animals. It is an issue that resonates strongly with my constituents in the West Midlands, who want greater action at European level; in particular, they want to see humane treatment of stray animals, and there should be a clear strategy for how we address this. It is also important that we highlight the preventative action plan in this report, especially on transmissible animal diseases, which is a consideration in maintaining animal health across the board. In this respect, I welcome that the Commission is fully committed to defending animal health in the EU and to improving it with the help of Member States. All in all, it is a positive report that moves in the right direction.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, one of the more lamentable tendencies in our present age is to use legislation as a kind of virtue signalling, a way to show what a nice person you are rather than to look at the effects and consequences of the law. Here is a hard thing about this subject that ought to be pointed out. There is actually a contradiction between animal welfare and the prevalence of the diseases mentioned in these reports. When we had ugly, industrial, mass factory farming of the kind that was introduced fifty or forty years ago there were remarkably sterile sealed environments where animal diseases did not spread. As soon as we decided that animal welfare was important and we wanted animals outside, having organic lives and so on, they became more prone to having disease spread from one farm to another. Tension of exactly this kind, namely where you draw the line between health and welfare, is a case that ought to be decided by our elected national authorities. It is precisely these sensitive issues that we should leave to voters country by country.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I supported this regulation, I support all legislation that regulates the status and protection of animals.  In this case, it is rather technical standards to address the prevention of animal diseases and procedures to deal with the situation should an disease become an epidemic. I am a little sorry that the text does not concern ethical standards, say animal welfare. I am at least a little reassured that the document includes a Statement by the Commission which is currently drawing attention to the welfare of animals.  In the future, it would therefore be good for us not only to regulate technical standards on how animals are treated in the event of illness, but also to address more how to improve the position of animals as living creatures who feel, who are suffering and for which advanced civilization should have a different understanding than for things that are of a material or intangible nature.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: – Madam President, in recent years, progress on animal welfare legislation at EU level has slowed down, but today we have made significant progress with the adoption of the animal health legislation. Despite the fact that the law approved today is not a specific animal welfare law, it is a milestone in animal welfare and could become a real turning point in the way animals are treated, both in the European Union and worldwide. This legislation finally provides concrete measures governing animal health and animal welfare, requiring keepers and pet breeders to apply the principle of good animal husbandry and humane treatment to avoid pain, distress and suffering of animals. The animal welfare provisions would also apply to all animals – not just kept animals, but also strays. I fully support this law, which, in my opinion, is a starting point for a new wave of concrete European activities aimed at granting all animals a much higher level of protection.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr This vote concerns the resistance of animal microbes and the relevant measures to achieve them. First, the frequency of antibiotic use, their reduction, as well as the more prudent use of antimicrobial drugs.  In parallel, Member States were invited to collect more actively relevant data on the use of such medicinal products and the transmission of these data to the European Commission, which I see as extremely important. This will facilitate the collection of multinational data and more effective action and the development and implementation of an action strategy in life.  Given that animal health depends on our human health, for example, diseases can spread through animals and so on. This is an extremely important resolution. I support it with both hands. Regardless of diet preferences, our animal health is also our health. That is why I voted in favour. Thank you!

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I also supported this draft report and this regulation, because it is not just a question of whether someone likes animals or not, but I consider it our duty to promote better treatment of living creatures. I think that is beyond doubt, although, of course, in ancient Roman law animals were considered to be things. Today they can no longer be treated in this way, and they must indeed be perceived as living creatures who suffer, feel, and are simply part of the living space around us.  On the other hand, it should be noted that this is not only about animal rights, but also about citizens' rights. Because consumer rights are part of this broader picture of animal rights. Antibiotic resistance to antibiotics administered across the board is one of the main problems we face in the field of animal husbandry. And I think we should focus on that. After all, the afternoon debate tomorrow will be about that.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: – Mr President, I would like to take this initiative to express my thanks to the rapporteur, Mr Selimovic, and his predecessor, the retired Poulsen, who have done a very commendable job with this report. Animal welfare is an important issue that we must take care of, and this report actually linked animal welfare to public health for the first time. Indeed, the issue of reducing the use of antibiotics at European Union level was an important point here. This will ensure that antibiotics can also be effectively available to humans in the future. After all, residues left in animal meats have now weakened the effect of antibiotics. It is very important that cooperation is established between the Member States here, and when we live in a market economy and in the internal market, it is also important that not only nationally, but also at European level, animal health and, by extension, public health are taken care of.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Ensuring a high level of human, animal and plant health is one of the objectives of the Eu ropean Union Treaties. The recent changes in this area are aimed at improving existing legislation by implementing a common system aimed at improving disease prevention and at promoting animal health protection. In view of the comments made by the Council and the Commission, I voted against the rejection amendment, thus allowing a large part of the text to be maintained at first reading. Indeed, the European Parliament's opinion at first reading represents a fair compromise, bearing in mind the attention paid to the link between animal health and welfare and the ban on causing pain, distress or suffering to them during health checks.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. – We supported the rejection because the overall effect is to extend and bureaucratise EU control with all its negative impacts, especially in relation to family pets.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We supported the rejection because the overall effect is to extend and bureaucratise EU control with all its negative impacts, especially in relation to family pets.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against the amendment proposing to reject the agreement reached between the Council and Parliament, therefore supporting the Recommendation for the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on communicable diseases of animals and amending or repealing certain acts on animal health ('Animal Health Legislation'). This agreement greatly improves the original text proposed by the Commission on animal welfare, control and combat of diseases affecting animals, so I have not supported its rejection.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – There was only one vote here, which was a vote to reject the animal health proposal. I voted against that amendment, thereby endorsing what had been agreed. This proposal related to an effort to create a single, comprehensive animal health law to replace the current framework of around 50 Directives, Regulations and around 400 pieces of secondary legislation. The subject matter is primarily concerned with prevention and control of animal diseases. The focus is on long-term preventive measures and laying down a more efficient and streamlined system to combat transmissible animal diseases, like foot and mouth, avian influenza and other newly emerging diseases. Furthermore a list of diseases subject to regulation is included in an annex for the protection of human and animal health. This list may be easily amended to deal with possible outbreaks.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted new regulations to better prevent and stop outbreaks of serious animal diseases such as avian influenza or African swine fever. The adoption of this new legislation simplifies regulations that are more than 50 years old, and I welcome this, as it is an important victory that strengthens citizen democracy by putting the main players at the heart of the scheme in the development of contingency plans. Increased trade, climate change and the mutation of infectious agents are now increasing the risk of the emergence of previously unknown diseases such as avian influenza, which is hitting the entire palmipede industry very hard today. As such, I can only welcome the strengthening of prevention and biosecurity to protect not only animal health but also human and environmental health. However, the available funding for health measures in the event of a crisis remains largely inadequate. It is essential that the European Commission implement a compensation mechanism that will enable the violence of these crises and their health, economic and human impact to be responded to as quickly as possible. Unfortunately, prevention cannot solve everything.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as this law modernises the Animal Health Act, obliging all farmers and competent bodies to respect the principles of proper animal rearing and to implement biosecurity measures to protect them. The responsible and prudent use of veterinary medicinal products is also defined as an obligation and the list of diseases covered by the law is adopted in accordance with the line of parliament's and the Council's decision.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. With this resolution, Parliament adopted a legislative proposal aimed at establishing rules for the prevention and control of animal diseases that can be transmissible to animals or humans. I voted in favour and welcome the creation of a single simplified, transparent and clear legal framework.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The creation of a database on the use of antimicrobials, antibiotics and others, provided for by the text, could be used to denounce unfair competition from some countries, but this is quite secondary to this report. On the pretext of simplification, this regulation assigns new prerogatives to the Commission, prerogatives contrary to the principle of subsidiarity.  So I voted to reject the text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to confirm that I voted in favour of this proposal to reject the Council position. The Council wants use limit the use of antimicrobial drugs in animals. This would be a grave mistake and consequently animal welfare and health would suffer. In the UK there are strict rules governing the use of these, farmers and vets do not use antimicrobial drugs without good reason. Antimicrobial medicinal products are essential in the treatment of important infectious diseases in animals.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. EU law is already well-developed with regard to animal welfare, which applies to various species or activities, as well as to environmental standards to be met. In a difficult economic context for our farmers, I did not vote for this amendment because it would add constraints and difficulties to our European milk and cattle producers, who are struggling to make a living from their work.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒  I believe that a common healthcare  approach will be much more effective than two separate policies for animal welfare and human health. These two fields are closely interconnected – as can be seen from diseases such as mad cow disease, bird flu and swine fever. Moreover, antibiotic resistance is a serious problem at present. Resistance to existing antibiotics has increased by 67% per generation, but no new types of antibiotics are being produced. Measures, such as this piece of legislation, must be taken to prevent such important medication from losing its effectiveness. Additionally, I am pleased with the simplification of EU animal welfare policy introduced by this legislation. Furthermore, this legislation will benefit animals: a matter close to my heart. Inadequate care will no longer be covered up by the use of copious amounts of antibiotics.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this proposal, which aims to strengthen the new animal health rules to combat communicable animal diseases such as avian influenza or African swine fever. Animal health rules combine and update nearly 40 legislation in this area so far and establish, for the first time in history, the interdependence between animal and public health. There is a mandatory registration of persons engaged in the trade in animals, a clearer distribution of responsibilities between farmers, traders and veterinarians and a greater focus on prevention. At the same time, the role of farmers, traders, veterinarians and animal owners in combating the spread of diseases has been clarified. I support the granting the European Commission the right to react immediately to outbreaks of animal diseases that can have a significant impact on public health or agricultural production. It is also important to provide for mandatory registration of persons engaged in animal trafficking, as well as to establish national databases for dogs, cats and other pets.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Under the pretext of simplification, the regulation in question grants new powers to the Commission. The only thing that I think is positive, in this case on the more careful use of antibiotics for animals, is not enough to make this text acceptable. That is why I voted in favour of the single amendment rejecting the Council's position, which once again gives the Green Light to the Commission.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which approves the proposed regulation aimed in particular at strengthening the prevention of communicable animal diseases and reducing the administration of antibiotics to animals. Without prejudice to the requirements of this regulation, Member States are also invited to commit to collect relevant, comparable and sufficiently detailed data on the effective administration of antimicrobial drugs to animals and to pass this data on to the Commission, with the aim of achieving more prudent administration of antimicrobial drugs to animals and thus contributing to the reduction of the risk of antimicrobial resistance. The text also includes animal welfare provisions. Thus, all disease control measures must take animal welfare into account and avoid inflicting any pain, distress or suffering on the targeted animals.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Selimovic report, presented to Parliament today, outlined the new measures to combat communicable animal diseases. Animal health is a crucial issue involving a sector, livestock farming, worth EUR 156 billion a year. The text of the report, which I supported with my vote, amends and repeals certain pieces of legislation linking animal health and welfare to human health. The new European legislation will cover animals kept in captivity, wild animals suffering from communicable diseases and thirty million workers on a daily basis in contact with animals. Operators in the sector and owners of animals will have to comply with the rules laid down for good breeding, while respecting the biosecurity measures provided for the protection of animals. The new rules promote the responsible and prudent use of veterinary medicines, especially antibiotics, to help combat growing antimicrobial resistance. The streamlining of legislation is linked to the need to ensure that disease control procedures do not cause pain, stress and suffering in animals undergoing health treatment.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on animal health because we think it is positive that measures will be put in place to prevent and tackle outbreaks of animal diseases such as avian influenza and African swine fever, transmissible between animals and potentially also humans.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this report and voted against the EFDD Group amendment. I think it is a good agreement reached by rapporteur Selimovic from my parliamentary group. It adopts new rules to curb communicable animal diseases such as avian influenza and African swine fever, transmissible between animals and potentially also humans. The new rules also focus on prevention and clarify the responsibilities of farmers, commercial intermediaries, professionals, including veterinarians, and animal owners. Farmers, animal owners and intermediaries shall be obliged to apply the principles of good practice of breeding and prudent administration of medicinal products.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Recent news shows us that animal welfare is not so well respected, especially in view of the practices of some slaughterhouses in France. Of course, measures must be taken for animal health, but there is also a risk to human health, as stress, abuse or slaughter methods can promote the development of diseases. But this regulation, under the pretext of simplification, actually grants new prerogatives to the European Commission. Moreover, it is not in line with the principle of subsidiarity according to the Austrian parliament. The only positive element is the creation of a European database on the use of antimicrobials, antibiotics, etc., as it will expose the dumping of certain member countries. Nevertheless, I voted in favour of this text, which allows the Council's position to be rejected in order not to give the Commission more power.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the excessively liberal implementing rules on animal welfare, which create situations of regulatory chaos for farmers in particular and are a source of additional administrative burdens. I believe, however, that every useful opportunity must be used at Community level and not to change the most onerous aspects of it, and that is why I abstained in the vote on this proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the new Regulation on animal health as it lays down the rules for the prevention and control of animal diseases and zoonoses. This regulation applies to all types of animal species, both domestic and wild, and their products, as well as to means of transport and equipment that may be potential vehicles for disease transmission.  Among the most important aspects of this regulation are the creation of a system of categorisation and prioritization of diseases and the health actions to be applied to each of them, strengthening the role of each of the animal health actors by establishing the responsibilities of each (veterinarians, animal professionals, pet owners and competent authorities) , the standardisation of the requirements for the import and export of animals, animal products and by-products, the requirement that all actors participate in notification and surveillance systems and control and eradication programmes, as appropriate, and the introduction of mechanisms for farms, areas or countries to be declared disease-free progressively by facilitating safe trade in animals and products.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on communicable animal diseases. The Communication from the Commission to the European Parliament and the Council entitled 'Action Plan against antimicrobial resistance' underlines the preventive importance of the Regulation on communicable animal diseases (animal health legislation) and subsequently the likely reduction of the use of antibiotics in the treatment of animals. In addition to the requirements of this Regulation, Member States are invited to undertake to collect relevant, comparable and sufficiently detailed data on the use of antimicrobials in the treatment of animals and to send these data to the Commission in order to ensure a more prudent use of antimicrobials in the treatment of animals, thereby contributing to the reduction of the risk of antimicrobial resistance. This Regulation lays down rules for the prevention and control of animal diseases which may affect animals or humans, but there are no provisions specifically regulating animal welfare, although animal health and welfare are relevant. The Union has a well-developed animal welfare acquis covering a wide range of animal species (broilers, laying hens, pigs and calves) and activities (rearing, slaughter, transport, research, etc.). This animal welfare legislation will necessarily continue to apply. The Commission is firmly committed to taking full account of animal welfare within the meaning of Article 13 of the Treaty and within the limits laid down therein, as well as to fully implement and develop legislation in this field.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. As I said at the previous mini-session of the European Parliament in Brussels, I am very pleased that there has been a vote on the so-called Animal Health Act. Indeed, the proposed regulation combines 40 different regulations into one regulation linking animal health to human health, regulates the more responsible use of antibiotics in veterinary medicine and strengthens the fight against infectious diseases. The animals will now have more responsibility for rearing animals and using veterinary foodstuffs, which veterinarians will need to raise more awareness of. I am also pleased that the Commission will be able to take direct, but in consultation with other stakeholders, emergency measures to prevent the spread of communicable diseases, reducing the possibility of major economic damage in agriculture. In addition, the proposal for a regulation also establishes a register of professional breeders and pet traders, which I welcome. I am convinced that this will have positive effects in preventing the illegal trade in these animals, which is in some cases a very lucrative mafia business. Member States are also given the possibility to set up pet registers, which would further restrict illegal trade. If countries do, I appeal to the use of common sense, otherwise there may only be even greater collection of the system. I supported the proposal, of course.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution voted on today represents an important step forward on the road to a single legislative text for the regulation of animal health within the European Union, based on the always valid principle that 'prevention is better than cure'. In this regard, I welcome the fact that the text adopted today highlights in particular the link between human and animal health, highlighting the role of prevention in relation to communicable animal diseases, and also emphasising the responsible use of antibiotics in livestock farming and in particular within livestock farming. Protecting animal health is therefore our duty but also a necessity, from which the well-being of all can benefit. Finally, I fully agree with the importance of ensuring that care and treatment is put in place that limits pain and suffering for animals as much as possible.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒Human and animal health is increasingly interconnected due to our eating habits and intensive farming methods, which is why the problem of antibiotics must be addressed with the "One Health" approach. Alarm bells have been ringing for a long time and future generations may one day wonder why we ruined one of the greatest medical achievements in history for profit. With this law, the EU has an extraordinary opportunity to contribute to global efforts to preserve the effectiveness of antibiotics.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This text, although with positive elements such as the establishment of a European database on the use of microbials, antibiotics, etc., grants new powers to the European Commission. I therefore voted in favour of the single amendment to reject the text.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Animal health is a cause for concern. This concern stems not only from aspects of public health and food safety, but also from the economic costs of the onset of animal diseases. Given the transmissible nature of many animal diseases, a common approach, rather than a series of individual actions, will produce overall benefits. The value of the EU's harmonised approach is widely recognised both because it has helped to reduce the administrative burden on those working in the sector and because it has played a key role in the completion of the single market, facilitating intra-EU trade in animals and animal products, through the establishment of harmonised animal health conditions, and has fostered the success of the CAP. It is the task of the EU institutions to ensure a high level of public health and food safety by minimising the incidence of biological and chemical risks to humans, by promoting animal health through the prevention/reduction of the incidence of animal diseases. Parliament must therefore promote animal health legislation which takes up the 2007 animal health strategy and which lays down the general principles of good animal health in EU legislation. To this end, it is essential to apply uniform rules and to promote cooperation between member countries.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. Under the pretext of simplification, this new Regulation supported by the Council risks once again extending the scope of the European Commission's powers and thus violating the principle of subsidiarity enshrined in the Treaty on european Union.  The positive elements relating to the establishment of a European database on the use of antimicrobials and antibiotics are not enough to compensate for the risks of Member States dispossession in animal health legislation. That is why I voted in favour of the amendment rejecting the Council's position.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote. Despite our opposition to animal welfare enforcement rules (still recalled by farmers today as a negative example of 'regulatory chaos' and a source of administrative burdens), it is undeniable how close the link is between animal health and welfare, the quality of agricultural products and, consequently, human health. While rejecting an overly 'liberal' position on the subject, we would point out that every useful opportunity must nevertheless be used, at Community and national level, to change its most onerous and uneasive aspects.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this regulation to prevent and combat epidemics of animal diseases such as avian influenza or African swine fever. The adoption of this regulation on animal health is a great step forward. It makes three things possible. Firstly, it links animal health and welfare to human health. This direct link, along with a greater focus on responsible use of antibiotics, will help combat growing antimicrobial resistance. Secondly, the legislation allows authorities and producers to focus more on the prevention and control of communicable animal diseases. Thirdly, according to the principle of simplification, some 40 legal acts are combined into a single act. This new European legislation on communicable diseases should help professionals in the sector to keep up with scientific progress and ensure that farmers' and veterinary organisations and animal welfare movements are involved in drawing up contingency plans.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ We supported the rejection because the overall effect is to extend and bureaucratise EU control with all its negative impacts, especially in relation to family pets.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support the Council position on the given legislative proposal because it provides simple and transparent rules for the prevention and control of animal diseases that can be transmitted to other animals and even humans. It also allows space to accommodate new challenges that fall into this category, like new diseases or changes in trading conditions. It emphasises the link between animal welfare and public health. Additionally, I welcome the Commission’s commitment to publishing regular reports on the use of antimicrobial medicinal products in animals in the EU and to pay close attention to the general welfare of animals.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that protecting animal health is our duty that can benefit the well-being of each of us. A large part of the European Parliament's opinion at first reading has been retained, which allows us to support the final compromise. Key references have been retained in important articles highlighting the link between animal health and welfare, and the need to be cautious against antimicrobial resistance in carrying out disease prevention and control measures.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ This new law, which was passed in the European Parliament today, is a timely development. All farmers and other animal owners and traders will be obliged to apply the principles of good animal husbandry. Responsible and prudent use of veterinary medicines is also an obligation under this Animal Health Law. In particular, this law helps us to minimise the risk of animal diseases spreading across different European countries by imposing movement restrictions, culls and farming restrictions where there have been outbreaks of diseases. Preventive measures are indeed what we need in a system where there are too many different laws and high quantities of meat import and export within the EU.  This is an instance of EU legislation helping to minimise administrative burdens by consolidating different pieces of legislation. In this case, no less than 36 different laws were merged into one.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today concludes the legislative process that led to the adoption at second reading of the regulation on communicable animal diseases, which is part of the broader regulatory framework on animal health. For too many years veterinary medicine has over-used antimicrobials for preventive rather than therapeutic purposes only to anticipate the spread of diseases and infections on farms. Such prolonged use has not only not protected against epidemics but has had the secondary effect of developing strong antimicrobial resistance in animals and indirectly also in humans. With the approved regulation, Member States will be required to collect relevant, comparable and sufficiently detailed data on the actual use of antimicrobial medicines in animals and to transmit this data to the Commission in order to monitor and facilitate a more prudent use of the medicines in question in order to reduce the risk of antimicrobial resistance. I voted in favour of this resolution because it regulates an important health sector.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the Council's proposal, as it contains several points of friction.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it represents a concrete proposal to an evolving problem. In fact, in the face of ever-new diseases, this report aims first and foremost to file infirmities in a clear and precise manner, in agreement with the opinion of EFSA experts. Secondly, the proposal aims to establish national prevention measures, taking care, on the one hand, to deal with animal safety by establishing obligations for the protection of animals and, on the other hand, to increase measures to control infirmities, for example by restricting the movement of animals themselves. For these reasons, I voted against the rejection of this proposal. I believe that it is our responsibility, as Members of Parliament, to take part in a constructive dialogue with a view to improving ourselves and not to reject effective proposals such as this a priori, denying Parliament the opportunity to respond to issues of increasing importance.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Measures must be taken to avoid and halt outbreaks of animal disease, including diseases such as avian flu and foot and mouth disease. Animal and human health must be linked directly, to ensure the responsible use of antibiotics. This will enable us to fight against antimicrobial resistance. The report will allow authorities and producers to direct their attention to the prevention and control of transmissible animal diseases. Farmers, traders and animal professionals will now have clarified responsibilities with regard to husbandry and use of medicines. The Commission is now enabled to take measures aimed at tackling emerging diseases with significant impact on public health and agricultural production. The European Food Safety Authority will have to be consulted now when potentially dangerous diseases are added to the EU’s list. To avoid outbreaks of disease caused by strays or illegally traded animals, all pet keepers and sellers must now register themselves. The Commission is also empowered to ask Member States to create national databases of cats, dogs and other household animals.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ We supported the rejection because the overall effect is to extend and bureaucratise EU control with all its negative impacts, especially in relation to family pets.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Animal health is a cause for concern for all European citizens, whether because of its relevance to public health, food safety and food supply security linked to animal health, or the economic costs of outbreaks of animal diseases and the value of animal welfare. I support the Selimovic Report which adopts the Council's position at first reading on the Regulation on communicable animal diseases, establishing new rules on the prevention and control of animal diseases that can be transmitted to other animals or humans, such as avian influenza and swine fever.  The Regulation replaces some forty legislative acts, placing greater emphasis on preventive measures, disease surveillance and research and providing for greater cooperation between animal professionals, pet keepers, authorities and veterinary doctors.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We supported the rejection because the overall effect is to extend and bureaucratise EU control with all its negative impacts, especially in relation to family pets.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft resolution approves the Joint Declaration of the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council on antimicrobial resistance and the use of veterinary medicinal products. I have chosen to vote against the rejection of the text because it emphasises the role of prevention in the regulation on communicable animal diseases ("animal health legislation") and the consequent reduction in the use of antibiotics in the treatment of animals. In addition to complying with the requirements of that Regulation, Member States are also required to engage in the collection of relevant, comparable and sufficiently detailed data on the actual use of antimicrobial medicines in animals and to transmit such data to the Commission in order to allow their more prudent use and thereby contribute to reducing the risk of antimicrobial resistance. For its part, the Commission undertakes to publish periodically a report on the use of antimicrobial medicines in the treatment of animals in the EU on the basis of data obtained from Member States.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The increased use of antimicrobials in products that we consume are a concern  that has been raised by individual citizens. It is therefore positive to note that this recommendation for a second reading contains the commitment to publish a regular report on the use of microbial medicinal products on animals in EU. This will, however, necessitate a serious commitment by Member States on the collection of data.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the request to reject the recommendation for second reading of the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on animal health legislation. Parliament's position at first reading is maintained, which would include in the regulation rules to prevent and control animal diseases transmitted to animals or humans and rules governing animal welfare, given the links between animal health and welfare.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against the amendment proposing to reject the agreement reached between the Council and Parliament, therefore supporting the Recommendation for the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on communicable diseases of animals and amending or repealing certain acts on animal health ('Animal Health Legislation'). This agreement greatly improves the original text proposed by the Commission on animal welfare, control and combat of diseases affecting animals, so I have not supported its rejection.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an important initiative, which must be supported, because a new driving force is needed for animal health standards. These are fundamental and crucial rules in the prevention and fight against communicable diseases and in addressing the health and safety risks of food and feed. It is important to monitor the control paths and responsibilities of the different actors – veterinarians, breeders and farmers – who play a fundamental role in protecting animal health, ensuring effectiveness in the different levels of vigilance. Among other things, it will be essential for Member States to have contingency plans for the management of certain diseases, to introduce specific rules for vaccinations and, as a result, control measures to be taken in the event of suspected or confirmed outbreaks of pathogenic events. In the event of health emergencies due to epidemics, it is essential, as introduced by the regulation, to provide for procedures to be applied at both national and supranational level. In conclusion, the resolution fills a legislative area of great importance in the monitoring and emergency of pathological events, certainly by increasing the level of safety of citizens and consumers, as well as the welfare of the animals themselves.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in the plenary of the European Parliament for measures to prevent and combat epidemics of animal diseases, such as avian influenza or African swine fever, measures informally agreed with EU ministers in June 2015. The EU legislative proposal on animal-borne and potentially transmissible diseases to humans underlines prevention and helps professionals in the field keep up with scientific progress.  This law contributes to the realization of three important things. First, it makes a link between the good and the health of animals and connects them to human health. This direct link together with the increase in responsible use of antibiotics will help us fight the increasing resistance to antimicrobials. Secondly, it helps authorities and producers to focus more on the prevention and control of communicable animal diseases. Third, it combines about 40 legal documents into a single piece of legislation.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that necessary action is required to ensure animal health, welfare and public health. I voted in favour of this report, which merges and updates old legislation and would therefore be the first-ever EU legislation that would establish and introduce a link between these three important health factors. I believe that this report outlines a clear framework and clarifies the responsibilities of the relevant stakeholders. Through this report, we are ensuring that, via implementation of the measures listed, the spreading of diseases will be prevented, and are thus safeguarding public health and also agricultural production. This legislation promotes further accountability of professional pet keepers and sellers on the transmission of animal diseases from strays or illegally traded pets. I believe that this legislation is an important safeguard and provides a guideline for each Member State.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I understand that the new regulation is a major step towards simplifying animal health legislation and the resulting framework fulfils much of the UK Government’s negotiating aims, with the Commission taking a risk-based approach with a strong focus on outcomes, regulatory simplicity and flexibility in the management of disease, I cannot however, support this regulation as the final text contains an unsatisfactory separation of tertiary powers between Delegated and Implementing Acts , particularly for ‘listed diseases’.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report aims to establish a single framework of preventive and control measures against animal diseases transmitted to animals and humans and establishes a harmonized animal health strategy. While the Community acquis is currently made up of 50 basic directives and regulations, as well as some 400 derivative law texts, this text is therefore of crucial importance in terms of simplification but also in a difficult health context in France (sheep catarrhal fever and avian influenza) and in Europe (proud swine). The report, in addition to establishing a single framework of provisions, stresses the responsibility of stakeholders and basic knowledge of health risks, the notification and monitoring of health risks in order to combat diseases, the obligation for Member States to develop intervention plans to deal with certain and to carry out simulation exercises , registration, accreditation, traceability and movement of terrestrial, aquatic or other types of animals and standards and requirements applicable to exports and third countries shipping animals and animal products to prevent the introduction of animal diseases into the EU. I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. This legislation provides for uniform measures to prevent and control communicable animal diseases. This text establishes a unique, precise and transparent regulatory framework that helps to improve animal welfare and food security, while taking into account the emergence of new diseases or food crises.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 This legislation will make two things possible: linking animal health and welfare with human health and enabling authorities and producers to focus more on the prevention and control of communicable animal diseases. This link, together with a greater focus on the responsible use of antibiotics, will help fight the growing antimicrobial resistance. In addition, all disease control measures should aim at animal welfare and avoid any kind of pain, distress or suffering to those selected for controls, including stray. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. In recent decades, health crises have multiplied: mad cow disease, avian influenza, swine flu. The health situation of livestock in the European Union must therefore be continually improved in order to prevent the occurrence of new crises with serious consequences, in terms of public health, but also for livestock producers.  Animal health legislation is an essential part of the response. It will ensure an update of animal health rules at European level and will force all breeders, traders and pet owners to apply the principles of good breeding practices and to use veterinary medicines prudently in order to prevent the spread of infectious animal diseases.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. The Selimovic report aims to establish a single framework for preventive and anti-animal diseases transmitted to animals and humans, while establishing a harmonised animal health strategy across the EU.  This text is of crucial importance in a difficult health context in France (sheep catarrhal fever and avian influenza) and in Europe (swine fever), which is why I voted for this report.  Through this text, we stress the obligation for Member States to develop intervention plans to deal with certain diseases (vaccinations and control measures in case of outbreaks) and to carry out simulation exercises, as well as the importance of standards and requirements applicable to exports and to third countries shipping animals and animal products to prevent the introduction of animal diseases into the European Union. Finally, we ensured animal welfare by mentioning good practices in the fight against diseases.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this single amendment to reject the Council's position on this issue. The latter, on the grounds of greater simplification, wanted to give more power to the Commission. While the establishment of a European database on the use of antimicrobials and antibiotics, among others, could have helped to denounce the dumping of certain Member States, it was a secondary element in the face of the need to defend the principle of subsidiarity, which the Austrian Parliament has said is not respected by this regulation.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to support this legislative proposal because it is not only in line with the objective of simplifying European law, but also contributes to improving legal transparency. It is often not understood that we need this type of initiative, as their scope extends widely beyond simple rules and regulations for farmers, traders and animal specialists. This is an extremely important tool in combating the emergence of diseases that can significantly affect public health, agricultural production or animal welfare.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Positive, because the welfare and proper treatment of animals, places the foundations for their good health. Immediate consequence: the reduction of the use of antibiotic drugs, which indirectly affects humans as well. Of course, tough legislation is also needed to comply with the above.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 In the course of the vote, I acted in accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party in support of the political agreement reached on the draft veterinary regulation. The new Regulation combines the content of 50 existing EU legislation. Its creation makes sense to simplify and increase the transparency of veterinary procedures. It is important that the list of animal diseases registered in the European Union is based on decisions taken on a transparent and scientific basis. Member States will also have the possibility of enhanced protection of their animal disease-free zones. In addition, quarantine measures may be introduced where appropriate, in addition to the prohibition on the transport of animals.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. About 70% of infectious diseases are common to animals and humans. The new EU Animal Health Regulation places greater emphasis on preventive measures, disease surveillance and research and provides for greater cooperation between animal professionals, pet keepers, authorities and veterinary doctors. The new rules clarify the responsibilities of operators and professionals working with animals, such as farmers, pet keepers and veterinarians to prevent the introduction, development and spread of diseases. For example, farmers, people selling animals and keepers of animals will be responsible for the application of good animal husbandry practices and for prudent and responsible use of veterinary medicinal products. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the rejection amendment, because I believe that the Council wants to give too much power to the Commission on this issue.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The process of simplifying and updating EU animal health legislation has been going on since 2013. This final text, under consideration, is better than that originally submitted by the Commission. It is accompanied by an annex with three declarations. A joint on the creation of an action plan against the growing threat of antimicrobial resistance. Another on the regular reporting of the use of antimicrobial medicinal products in animals. And another on animal welfare, noting that this regulation laying down rules for the prevention and control of diseases of animals communicable to animals and humans does not contain provisions specifically governing animal welfare. Of course, it remains to be criticized by the productivism of the current Common Agricultural Policy and the models of capitalist production, which lead to a higher incidence and prevalence of infectious diseases in animals, along with the consequent defense of other agricultural policies. There are still a number of doubts about the aquatic production from which much of the fish that arrives at the consumer's table. In particular, the committee needs to clarify what the committee means by "aquatic species health professionals" and what guarantee they offer to consumers.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the proposal to reject the Council position.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The European Commission Regulation in question lays down precise and clear rules for the prevention and control of animal diseases. I therefore support this action plan against the threat of antimicrobial resistance, which will reduce the use of antibiotics in animals. The individual Member States of the European Union must start collecting thoroughly and accurately information on the actual use of antimicrobial medicines and share this information with the European Commission, thus engaging more actively in solving this acute problem.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining because other aspects of the matter would have to be changed first.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation because animal welfare and welfare lay the foundations for their good health. Immediate consequence: the reduction of the use of antibiotic drugs, which indirectly affects humans as well. Of course, tough legislation is also needed to comply with the above.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation replaces over 40 outdated and inconsistent pieces of EU legislation. Whilst that could be useful, I voted against it on the grounds that the policy implications are hard to predict at this stage, particularly with regard to the secondary legislation that could result.   I also do not accept that the Commission should be given the sole legal right to draw up a list of animal diseases which pose a risk to animal or public health, whereas the UK’s national experts are excluded from that process.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this law, which will finally streamline the law on animal health, obliging all operators and animal keepers to adhere to the principle of good animal husbandry, as well as taking biosecurity measures to protect their animals. Responsible and prudent use of veterinary medicines is also an obligation: Member States are called upon to commit themselves to collecting relevant data on the actual use of antimicrobial medicinal products in animals and to send such data to the Commission in order to ensure more prudent use of antimicrobial medicinal products in animals, thereby helping to reduce the risk of antimicrobial resistance. The list of diseases covered by the law will be adopted in line with the Parliament and Council decision, and taking account of expert advice.  All operators and animal keepers will be required to apply the principle of good animal husbandry under this law, as well as humane treatment to avoid pain, distress and suffering when disease control measures are taken.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted against the amendment as I am in favour of the measures contained in the Recommendation, as it is relevant for the EU as a whole to have a common animal health policy. It is important, in order to develop a common set of measures in the EU, for Member States to collect and send to the Commission the results obtained in terms of antimicrobial resistance to medicines.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of the animal health regulation, approved at second reading today, is a victory. Finally, a link is being established between the authorities and producers so that more attention is focused on the prevention and control of diseases such as avian influenza or swine fever. The rules agreed informally with the COUNCIL of the EU in June 2015 rationalise the issue and allow 40 legal acts to be merged into a single basic act. The regulation also emphasises the responsible use of antibiotics in view of the increasing antimicrobial resistance also recorded in animals. A step forward, therefore, in the fight against communicable animal diseases.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I welcome this report, which promotes animal health and is committed to protecting human health more closely.
