In particular, I fully share the sense of responsibility that cannot be lacking for those who live or work with animals: responsibility that must be translated into taking care of them, but also in actions of prevention and targeted and prudent intervention in the event of animal disease.  I therefore welcome the report's call for farmers, animal owners and traders to monitor the health of their animals more closely and to take sudden action in the event of illnesses, especially where there is a possibility of human infection, with specific care and reasonable use of antibiotic therapy.  I am voting in favour of adopting biosecurity measures for our animals and for our health.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on communicable animal diseases and amending and repealing certain acts in the field of animal health, as I believe that the agreement reached between Parliament and the Council today offers good animal health legislation. This is important legislation for millions of EU citizens working in contact with animals, which affects both wild and pet animals, given the human consequences of the communicable animal diseases we have seen in recent years. I support the reference to the principle of good animal husbandry, the use of humane treatment and animal health, because it is necessary to avoid unnecessary pain and suffering in animal care and in the application of health measures. I also welcome the call for the prudent and responsible use of veterinary medicines and transparency requirements in the area of antibiotics, because the issue of antimicrobial resistance is extremely important in the fight against animal diseases. Finally, the establishment and updating of a list of diseases drawn up with the cooperation of EFSA is very positive.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on animal health. The number of pathogens against which antibiotics are powerless is increasing rapidly. Antibiotic resistance in animal husbandry is a problem to which the EU must address itself in an informed and vigorous manner.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I do not support this proposal. Many of the demands are not sufficiently tailored to the problem of disease risk. I also reject the fact that two regulations in this area that have just been adopted should be replaced by delegated acts. This would weaken the European Parliament's position as a legislative power.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ We supported the rejection because the overall effect is to extend and bureaucratise EU control with all its negative impacts, especially in relation to family pets

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on animal health because we think it is positive that measures will be put in place to prevent and tackle outbreaks of animal diseases such as avian influenza and African swine fever, transmissible between animals and potentially also humans.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the Council position and have voted against the proposal to reject it because this legislation is very important for animal welfare and because it will help do things such as reduce the risk of antimicrobial resistance. It will also help limit the possibility of the spread of some transmissible diseases from animals to humans.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite many improvements, there are some problematic points related to the proper application of certain vague and legal conditions, such as "human treatment" of animals. Another problematic point is the fact that stray pets are considered 'wild animals'. This concept can serve to reduce the legal protection of stray animals. Dogs and cats should always be considered pets, stray or not, even if they are no longer under the direct control of humans. Finally, one of the biggest problems was the very large number of proposed implementing and delegated acts, which made it difficult to predict how the law could work in practice. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I had to correct my vote on this report, it was the first report to be voted on and by the time I found my voting card, the vote was open and in my rush I pressed the green instead of the red button.  Nonetheless I am in favour of this regulation that lays down rules for the prevention and control of animal diseases which are transmissible to animals or to humans. This EU Animal Health law provides a new framework to simplify the current system by clarifying the division of responsibilities between animal keepers, traders, veterinarians, and national authorities. It also puts in place better notification and surveillance tools to fight animal diseases. Operators will also benefit from more proportionate rules easing animal movements where lower risks permit, so it is also worth remembering that transmissible diseases in animals can have a significant effect on the economy, food safety and in certain circumstances human health. Transmissible diseases know no borders and so we need EU legislation to deal with this issue.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the final agreement between Parliament and the Council on this EU animal health law as it provides a new framework to modernise and simplify the current system by clarifying the division of responsibilities between animal keepers, traders, veterinarians, and national authorities, and puts in place better notification and surveillance tools to fight animal diseases. I believe a balance has been struck to ensure more proportionate rules easing animal movements where lower risks permits. I also think that this proposal will encourage greater use of new technologies in the area of animal health.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The European Animal Health Law, which is to replace 40 pieces of European legislation, will link animal welfare and public health in EU law. By requiring farmers, animal owners and traders to ensure the good health of animals and to use medicine responsibly, a greater control over diseases will be established. The Commission will have the power to take urgent measures when dealing with emerging diseases with a high possible impact. Since this law would help keep up with scientific progress and prevent new outbreaks, I have voted in favour of it. In addition, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ We supported the rejection because the overall effect is to extend and bureaucratise EU control with all its negative impacts, especially in relation to family pets.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ This legislation has animal welfare at its heart and improves upon and simplifies the current legal situation. Many areas of animal health and welfare are best dealt with at an EU-wide level, and the cooperation that the EU fosters across the continent is of great value in the prevention of animal diseases. I therefore gave my support to this proposal.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ Animal health is a key part of the European Food Safety Authority mandate. The concept of animal health covers not only animal diseases, but also the critical relationship between animal health, animal welfare and food safety. I have voted against the amendment that rejects the position of the Council’s first reading on transmissible animal diseases.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Writing. It is particularly important for the European internal market that common standards are implemented in the interests of animal welfare. The same standards should also apply to imports into the market. The welfare of the animal should also be a top priority in the pet area. There are many violations, particularly in the domestic sector. A problem of such an important cause for society is absolutely necessary for the European Parliament to co-determine. That is why I voted against the Council's position today to approve the recommendation without a vote.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒in 2012 I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation by Parliament and the Council on the transferable diseases of animals and on the amendment and repeal of certain animal health acts, as I consider it necessary to take into account new diseases developing globally, new ways of trafficking, and the volume of trade in animals and animal products. I believe that new economic, health and social opportunities require both accompanying adaptation and legislative alignment in the field of animal health. In doing so, scientific and technological developments and institutional changes within the Union itself should also be added. I therefore support a balanced and effective law that directly links animal welfare and human health. However, on the other hand, special attention is necessary when it comes to veterinary drugs and antimicrobial resistance.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Overall, this regulation, under the pretext of simplification, grants new prerogatives to the European Commission. The Austrian parliament has also stressed that it is not in line with the principle of subsidiarity. The main positive is the creation of a European database on the use of antimicrobials, antibiotics and others, which can be an asset in denouncing the dumping of certain member countries.  With the vote on an amendment to reject, it makes sense to vote in force, which makes it possible to reject the Council's position, which wants to give the Commission even more power. I therefore voted in favour of rejecting this amendment.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We supported the rejection because the overall effect is to extend and bureaucratise EU control with all its negative impacts, especially in relation to family pets.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ This report aims at reinforcing measures to prevent and halt outbreaks of animal diseases. I can only agree with the approach of this text, which links animal health and welfare and connects it to human health. It also puts a strong emphasis on prevention and control. Finally, for the sake of simplicity, it merges around 40 legal acts into one basic act. For these three reasons, I decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues Jasenko Selimovic and Marit Paulsen on THE European legislation on communicable animal diseases. The Commission's legislative proposal suggests implementing new provisions for the prevention and control of animal diseases that are transmitted to animals or humans. Thus, a single, simplified and transparent framework will be established by this proposal to achieve greater efficiency. I have therefore approved this proposal to combat animal diseases in order to improve animal health, animal welfare and food security for European citizens.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation, which aims to harmonize measures to combat animal diseases transmitted to animals and humans in a single framework. It also responds to the emergence of new animal diseases (swine fever or avian influenza) in the Eu. It was therefore necessary to simplify the rules and respond to new health challenges.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The proposal to reject the Council's position on the basis of the currently unforeseeable bureaucracy for small and medium-sized farmers is only partly to be welcomed. However, since the Council's proposal contains good approaches to animal welfare in principle, I am abstaining on the proposal.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported the proposed law, as it contains a range of measures to help EU countries tackle transmissible animal diseases, boost animal welfare levels and improve the treatment of stray animals.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The report deals with the final outcome of the trilogue negotiations between the Commission, the Parliament and the Council, which emphasises the preventive role of the proposed regulation on animal diseases transmissible to animals or humans, and the consequent expected reduction of the use of antibiotics in animals. It is important to underline that the Union has a well-developed acquis regarding animal welfare, which covers different species or activities. However, the actual legislation is considered insufficient due to the lack of an overall strategy. The proposal’s aim is to upgrade this legislation and to provide a common system in order to prevent and tackle transmissible animal diseases in a coordinated way. Despite this improvement, the new framework contains several unclear aspects that treat different animal categories under the same notion. It is a matter of concern that this could serve to decrease the legal protection of some categories. Therefore, I decided to vote against.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this rejection proposal because the Council's position it is fighting wants to give the Commission even more power over animal health.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The regulation to be voted on by Parliament and the Council concerns communicable animal diseases. In particular, it proposes the repeal of certain practices in the field of food health, which grants new powers to the European Commission. Although I am in favour of the creation of a European database on the use of antibiotics and other antimicrobials, proposed in the text, I voted in favour of the rejection amendment and therefore against this text. It is indeed impossible for me to accept further interference by the European Union in the policy of the Member States.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against the amendment proposing to reject the agreement reached between the Council and Parliament, therefore supporting the Recommendation for the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on communicable diseases of animals and amending or repealing certain acts on animal health ('Animal Health Legislation'). This agreement greatly improves the original text proposed by the Commission on animal welfare, control and combat of diseases affecting animals, so I have not supported its rejection.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development unanimously approved this proposal for a Regulation, which lays down rules for the prevention and control of diseases of animals that are communicable to other animals or humans. This proposal does not contain provisions specifically regulating animal welfare, although animal health and welfare are linked. The Union has a well-developed acquis in relation to the welfare of animals covering different species (fattening chickens, laying hens, pigs or calves) or activities (breeding, transport, slaughter, research, etc.). This animal welfare legislation must necessarily continue to apply. This proposal invites Member States to undertake to collect relevant, comparable and sufficiently detailed data on the actual use of antimicrobial medicinal products in animals and to send this data to the Commission so that more prudent use of antimicrobial medicinal products in animals can be ensured, the thus contributing to reducing the risks associated with antimicrobial resistance. For these reasons I vote in favour of this draft Legislative Resolution.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am the author of the rejection proposal, otherwise the text would pass without a vote. I voted to reject it. I reject the Commission's authority to obtain the right to decide on the identification of animals instead of the Member States. Such rules cannot be created without proper scrutiny of national parliaments and citizens. The European Union is not an institution to decide these matters for national parliaments.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ According to the latest research, animals are increasingly resistant to antibiotics and diseases are increasingly spreading among them. The report proposes to implement measures to reduce the spread of diseases, especially those that are transferable to humans. I supported this report because it defines rules for preventing and superseding diseases of animals that are transferable to animals or humans.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 Animal health is closely related to human health. A responsible policy on animal prevention and diseases therefore has a direct impact on the health of the population and, therefore, on public health funding.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on communicable animal diseases and amending and repealing certain acts in the field of animal health (Animal Health Act), for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/3/2016, and because this recommendation is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this rejection amendment. This regulation on animal health, under the guise of simplifying things, actually proposes to give more powers to the European Commission, so much so that national parliaments have stressed that this text does not correspond to the principle of subsidiarity. The only vote was on a rejection amendment, an amendment that allowed the regulation to be opposed, which I supported.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which attempts to deal with the rising threat from antimicrobial resistance and emphasises the preventive role of the regulation on transmissible animal diseases (‘Animal Health Law’) and the consequent expected reduction of the use of antibiotics in animals, hence contributing to the reduction of the risk of antimicrobial resistance.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 This document is not supported, citing the Commission statement on animal welfare "the regulation lays down rules to prevent and control animal diseases transmitted to animals or humans and does not contain rules specifically governing animal welfare despite the links between animal health and welfare."

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on the proposal for a regulation on communicable animal diseases. This text highlights the preventive role of the Regulation on communicable animal diseases and focuses on the subsequent expected reduction in the use of antibiotics in animals. Member States are invited to undertake to collect and send detailed data on the actual use of antimicrobial medicinal products in animals. Furthermore, the Disease Regulation lays down rules for the prevention and control of animal diseases which may be transmitted to animals or humans and does not contain provisions specifically governing animal welfare, although animal health and animal welfare are linked. In accordance with the position of the Czech Republic, I supported the proposal.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. My support for the new regulations that will allow, I am convinced, to prevent and tackle outbreaks of animal diseases such as avian influenza and African swine fever, transmissible between animals and potentially humans as well. We are facing a breakthrough, in which we link animal and human health in a clear way, and which will bring significant improvements in preventing and controlling situations that continue to cause great social and economic damage.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 Preventive role of the new regulation on the treatment of communicable diseases such as avian influenza and African swine fever. This is due to the increased risk of transmission of reported and other diseases as well as the parallel need to reduce the use of antibiotics in animals in order to reduce the risk of antimicrobial resistance. Under the Regulation, Member States will be obliged to provide regular reports with full data on the frequency of use of these medicines, thus gaining better knowledge at pan-European level. I am voting in favour of adopting this regulation in order to set the legal framework and rules regulating the control and prevention of transmission of animal diseases in accordance with the findings of modern scientific studies. The regulation should certainly also be in line with EU legislation on animal welfare and welfare. Finally, the adoption of this regulation will provide guarantees for more prudent use of medicines and further improvement of livestock farming with clear responsibility for persons involved in this sector in the event of their non-compliance with the principles of good livestock farming and the responsible use of antibiotics in animals.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this proposal because I believe that the new rules adopted will help to combat sinister communicable animal diseases such as avian influenza or African swine fever. The rules provide for mandatory registration of persons engaged in the marketing of animals, and a clearer distribution of responsibilities between farmers, traders and veterinarians.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this second reading agreement, which creates a clear regulatory framework for the control and the prevention of animal diseases, some of which can be transferable to humans while also curbing antimicrobial resistance.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Animal health is a concern of the European Union because of its links with public health and food security, but also because of the economic costs that animal diseases can generate. The Commission's proposal aims to simplify the rules in force in the field of surveillance and disease control to make them more effective. Full of good intentions, this report is accompanied by pompous statements on animal welfare even though the Commission regularly publishes "recommendations on breeding practices" absolutely denying this principle. I note, however, a particular attention to the problems of antimicrobial resistance and a recommendation on the "decrease in the administration of antibiotics to animals", which demonstrate a certain lucidity with regard to the action of pharmaceutical groups.  I am voting for this very fledgling text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. I note that the creation of a database on the use of antimicrobials, antibiotics and others, provided for in the text, could be used to denounce competition at all costs in some countries. But when you look at the text as a whole, it is quite secondary. In fact, by developing the argument of simplification, this regulation is not without consideration for the European Commission. The Latter is given new prerogatives, which are not in line with the principle of subsidiarity, according to the Austrian Parliament.  As a result, I voted in favour of the amendment to reject the text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on communicable animal diseases and amending and repealing certain acts in the field of animal health ("Animal Health Act"). New rules on the prevention and control of animal diseases that can be transmitted to other animals or humans are fundamental. Avian influenza is a case that shows us this danger. That is why the surveillance of animal diseases has never been more important. Further preventive measures, more research and greater cooperation between animal professionals, especially authorities and veterinarians, will be needed. For the first time European legislation recognises a link between animal health, animal welfare and public health.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the rejection of this resolution because it is important that the Union moves forward with legislation to prevent and control animal diseases.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Some communicable animal diseases are a serious animal health problem that can also be dangerous to humans. Preventing epidemics of diseases such as swine fever or avian influenza must therefore be a priority for both the scientific community and legislators. In this regard, I welcome Parliament's position on the proposed regulation on communicable animal diseases. I am particularly pleased with the clear link between animal health and animal welfare. Compliance with good breeding practices and European animal welfare standards is an essential corollary to animal health and, therefore, to human health. The careful and supervised use of antibiotics on animals is also part of a responsible policy towards animal health and, therefore, public health. Finally, I welcome the work of simplification and legislative coherence, which is now finding an end in the adoption of this legislation. It has the merit of merging nearly 40 legislative acts into one.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The first rules regulating animal health in the European area were enshrined as early as the 1960s. The onset of new problems and diseases therefore naturally requires updated legislation capable of facing current challenges. It is desirable for the EU to have a comprehensive system for the prevention, detection and control of animal diseases, as well as a common strategy to address safety risks related to health, food and feed. The current legislation contained in around 50 directives and regulations is complex and requires simplification in the form of the creation of a single piece of legislation enshrining clear rules regulating animal health issues. It is also necessary to lay down uniform rules for veterinarians and farmers who play an important role in the field of animal health, as well as to specify the reporting and surveillance obligations, the introduction of specific rules on vaccination and control measures, the import and export of animals, or the effective management of resources. It is important that the Union is also united in this area and that Member States follow the same procedures in an emergency when it is necessary to react quickly and coherently. I therefore agree with the proposal as it stands.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In May 2013, the Commission proposed a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on contagious animal diseases and the amendment and repeal of certain veterinary acts. In April 2014, Parliament adopted the Commission's proposal at first reading with amendments. The Austrian Federal Council indicated that it considered that the draft legislative act was incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity (as justified in the report of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development). In September 2014, interinstitutional consultations began on Parliament's first reading decision. The Council published its first reading position in December 2015.  In its report, the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development recommends that Parliament agree at second reading with the Council's position at first reading and declare that the regulation has been adopted in accordance with the Council's position. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This regulation, under the pretext of simplification, grants new prerogatives to the European Commission, in defiance of the principle of subsidiarity.  The main positive is the creation of a European database on the use of antimicrobials, antibiotics and others, which can be an asset in denouncing the dumping of certain member countries.  However, this element is secondary and it is appropriate to vote for the rejection amendment.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. This proposal deals with European legislation in the field of animal health, which replaces some forty European legislative acts, some of which date back to 1964.  I am voting in favour of this report because I support the creation of a simplified, transparent and clear single legal framework enabling a clear and balanced distribution of tasks and responsibilities between the competent authorities, the institutions of the European Union, the agricultural sector, animal owners, among others, on the surveillance, prevention and control of different animal diseases.  Animal welfare is of the utmost importance, including for public health, as approximately 70% of infectious diseases are common to animals and humans. I support the importance of establishing rules for the prevention and control of animal diseases that can be transmitted to animals or humans.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Overall, this regulation, under the pretext of simplification, grants new prerogatives to the European Commission. The Austrian parliament has also stressed that it is not in line with the principle of subsidiarity. That is why I voted in favour of rejecting the Council's position.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it represents a major achievement of European law and policy—making with regards to animals. The new Animal Health Law represents a positive contribution of the EU to the health and welfare of animals, the key concern of Labour supporters. Importantly, the new law will introduce robust measures to tackle transmissible animal diseases which endanger animal welfare and pose health risks to humans. The new law also contains a set of provisions that will be useful for dealing with stray animals in a humane manner. In sum, the new Animal Health Law is a great example of the EU actually delivering on a matter of direct importance to the EU citizens.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to establish a single framework of preventive and anti-animal diseases transmitted to animals and humans and which establishes a harmonised animal health strategy throughout the Union. The adoption of such provisions is essential in a context where France and Europe are experiencing health episodes such as avian influenza or swine fever.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I was not able, for medical reasons, to attend the plenary session from 7 to 10 March 2016. Nevertheless, I would like to express my support for the Selimovic report on animal health. Despite the EFDD group's attempt to bring down the text, Parliament adopted, by a very large majority, a text improving the safety rules for animal health. The new legislation will also help prevent the risk of transmission to humans.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States should assume responsibility for collecting sufficiently detailed and comparable data on the use of antimicrobials in animals. More careful use of these agents contributes to reducing the risk of antimicrobial resistance. The report (on the use of antimicrobials in animals in the EU) will facilitate cooperation between Member States and the prevention and control of animal diseases that can be transferred to animals and humans.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ On 6 May 2013, the European Commission adopted a proposal for a single comprehensive animal health law that was supposed to replace the old and complicated animal health rules. The European Parliament and the European Council also reached a political agreement on the animal health proposal on 1 June 2015. I have voted against the amendment, which rejects the first reading position of the Council.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Although the report risks increasing bureaucracy, it can, in essence, convince with its good approaches to the more sustainable use of animal antibiotics. In addition to animal health, human health also plays an important role here. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. For the first time, the report creates a link between animal health and public health, which is an important step forward, as well as addressing new and current health conditions and prioritizes responsible veterinary compliance, so the legislative changes that have been made so far are sufficient.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the draft regulation submitted. The new animal health rules will ensure animal health and welfare, the protection of public health, the environment and the interdependence between animals and public health.  It should be noted that the emergence and spread of communicable diseases have a negative not only economic but also social impact. In this context, it is necessary to aim to minimise the potential risk of communicable diseases across the EU. It is therefore necessary to establish effective measures and prevention systems for these diseases and to apply high animal and public health standards. However, the new regulation must not create additional bureaucratic burdens, but on the contrary must promote competitiveness. The EU must have a consolidated legal basis for a common Union animal health policy, which would provide for a single simplified and flexible framework governing animal health.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We supported the rejection because the overall effect is to extend and bureaucratise EU control with all its negative impacts, especially in relation to family pets.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution as it is necessary to establish a legislative framework at European level with regard to animal diseases that are transferable to humans. The proposal is a good one as it seeks to establish a common, simplified and transparent legislative framework, which at the same time also seeks to take into account the new challenges associated with the emergence of new types of diseases and the return of old diseases.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒I welcome the adoption of this Regulation, which represents a significant step in the implementation of the Action Plan against the increased threat of antimicrobial resistance. The Regulation adopts measures to collect relevant, comparable and sufficiently detailed data on the use of antimicrobial medical devices in animals in the Member States. These measures aimed at prudent use of antimicrobials allow this act to provide an emphasised link between animal welfare and public health.  Prevention measures increase the quality of life of animals in breeding, reduce the need for the use of these agents, and their smaller use allows for a longer period of safe application of antimicrobials until the appearance of resistant strains of bacteria. In this way, people are also less exposed to the consequences of antimicrobial resistance because they are less exposed to antibiotic residuals in food, but also to the persistence of the supply of antibiotics in human medicine. This is precisely what the public health interest of this Regulation focuses on the quality of life of both humans and animals. The impact is also not negligible for the globally recognised safety and high quality of European food products, resulting in a comparative advantage of European agriculture in third markets.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The vote concerns the adoption of the Council's opinion at second reading (the text was drawn up during the previous mandate). Overall, this regulation, under the pretext of simplification, grants new prerogatives to the European Commission. The Austrian parliament has also stressed that it is not in line with the principle of subsidiarity. The main positive is the creation of a European database on the use of antimicrobials, antibiotics etc., which can be an asset to denounce the dumping of certain member countries. However, as this element remains secondary, I am opposed to this text. The vote is on a single rejection amendment, for which I therefore vote.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure adopted today improves European legislation on animal health, obliging farmers and every other operator in the sector to comply with the principle of good animal husbandry and all biosafety measures for the protection of animals and human health. The obligation to use veterinary medicinal products, in particular antibiotics, even more stringent and a list of diseases covered by the law will be adopted, in accordance with the guidelines expressed by Parliament and the Council, in accordance with expert opinions. We know, in fact, that the phenomenon of antibiotic resistance is an increasingly worrying problem, which poses serious risks to the health of people and animals themselves. We need a strategy for the prevention of animal diseases that does not take account of the massive use of antibiotics. Thanks to the efforts made by our group, the importance of animal welfare has also been recognized, with the prescription of health treatments that avoid pain, stress and suffering. The link between animal welfare and animal health is now well documented by scientific studies. Measures are also important for pets, with the obligation to register for breeders and traders and the creation of databases for animals.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The Animal Health Act affects all animals in the EU, both domestic and wild, that may be affected by infectious diseases. In addition to affecting animals, this Act also affects between 20 and 30 million people in the EU involved in working with animals. It is therefore very important to apply this Act, which will simplify animal health care and oblige all operators involved in working with animals to apply the principle of good and those safety measures that protect their health. Accordingly, responsible and prudent use of veterinary drugs and antibiotics in animals must be necessary and mandatory. For this reason, I support this Act which establishes a clear and transparent way of implementing measures to combat the disease to ultimately ensure that pain, soreness and suffering are avoided when disease control measures are implemented.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. The resolution deals with the process of simplifying and updating EU legislation on animal health, which has been going on since 2013.  The annex to the final text contains three declarations concerning (i) the creation of an action plan against the growing threat of antimicrobial resistance and the consequent expected reduction in antibiotic use in animals; (ii) the regular reporting on the use of antimicrobial medicinal products in Union animals; (iii) animal welfare. The latter notes that this regulation does not contain provisions specifically governing animal welfare, which cannot be dissociated from animal health. The resolution could and should have gone further, criticising and refusing the productivism of the current CAP, and the capitalist production models that lead to a higher incidence and prevalence of infectious diseases in animals, and advocating another agricultural policy. There are still doubts about the aquatic production from which an increasing share of the fish comes to the consumer's table, in particular as to clarify the category of "health professionals of aquatic species" and what guarantee they can offer to consumers.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the amendment tabled by the Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy Group. Agreeing to it would mean that we continue to ignore the plight of animal husbandry and the use of medicinal products. I have been drawing attention to the problem of antimicrobial resistance for a long time. I am therefore glad that the legislation addresses the necessary reduction in the use of antibiotics in animals. Member States need to collect relevant data on the use of antimicrobial medicines, thus reducing the possibility of developing resistance in both animals and humans. Needless to say, the European Union reports up to 25,000 human victims a year who succumb to antibiotic-resistant bacteria. If the situation does not turn around, up to 300 million lives could be lost worldwide over the next 35 years.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 European animal health law will replace around 40 different European legislation in this area. EU law on diseases transmitted between animals or potentially also to humans will link and update dispersed earlier rules to prevent or inhibit new outbreaks and to follow scientific developments. These rules will be the first ever combination of animal welfare and public health in EU law, as well as an important tool in the fight against AMR in humans, animals and the environment. All farmers and owners of animals and their traders will be obliged to comply with the rules on animal husbandry and to apply veterinary measures prudently and responsibly. In order to address the problem of stray animals carrying diseases, provisions have been introduced requiring the registration of all owners and sellers of animals, which entitle the Commission to request EU Member States to set up a computer database of dogs and other domestic animals if necessary. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I support this report, which aims to establish a single framework for preventive and anti-animal diseases transmitted to animals and humans. Above all, this text aims to establish a harmonised animal health strategy throughout the European Union.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We supported the rejection because the overall effect is to extend and bureaucratise EU control with all its negative impacts, especially in relation to family pets.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. This report endorses the Council's position at first reading on an action plan against the growing threat of antimicrobial resistance. It also stresses the preventive role of the Regulation on communicable animal diseases and the consequent expected reduction in the use of antibiotics in animals. I voted in favour of this report because it makes Member States commit themselves to collecting detailed, comparable and relevant data on the actual use of antimicrobial medicinal products in animals and to transmit this data to the Commission to ensure a more prudent use of these medicinal products, thereby contributing to the reduction of the risk of antimicrobial resistance.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. The regulation passed this lunchtime will help to better prevent and control animal disease epidemics in the EU. With 13.7 million farms on the territory, it was important to provide a strong European response to these border-free threats. Animal epidemics cause hundreds of thousands of euros in losses to producers each year and pose a serious public health risk in the event of transmission to humans. This text simplifies European legislation by replacing some 40 legislative acts, prioritises preventive measures, clarifies the responsibilities of animal health actors and fights the over-medication of animals, which is responsible for bacteria resistance to antibiotics.  Through this vote, MEPs gave clear support for the modernisation of the rules governing animal health, ensuring the safety of consumers and guaranteeing the quality of food produced in Europe.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has adopted new rules on the prevention and control of animal diseases that can be transmitted to other animals or humans, such as influenza, foot-and-mouth disease or swine fever. Greater emphasis is placed on preventive measures, disease surveillance and research, with greater and better collaboration between animal professionals, pet keepers, authorities and veterinary doctors. It is essential to achieve this support for the principles of good breeding, as well as biosecurity measures for the protection of animals and human beings.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the new Regulation on animal health as it lays down the rules for the prevention and control of animal diseases and zoonoses. This regulation applies to all types of animal species, both domestic and wild, and to their products, as well as to means of transport and equipment that may be potential disease-transmission vehicles.  Among the most important aspects of this regulation are: the creation of a system of categorisation and prioritization of diseases and the health actions to be applied to each of them, the strengthening of the role of each of the animal health actors by establishing the responsibilities of each (veterinarians, animal professionals, pet owners and competent authorities) , the standardization of requirements for the import and export of animals, animal products and by-products, the participation of all actors in reporting, surveillance systems, and control and eradication programmes, as appropriate, and the introduction of mechanisms for farms, areas or countries to be progressively declared disease-free , thus facilitating the safe trade in animals and products.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Yesterday we approved the text on communicable animal diseases. The measures adopted, informally concluded between the European Parliament and the EU Council of Ministers in June 2015, aim to prevent and stop outbreaks of animal diseases such as avian influenza or African swine fever. This EU draft law on communicable diseases in animals, and also potentially humans, focuses on prevention and should help professionals keep pace with scientific progress. The regulation will soon be published in the Official Journal of the Union, will come into force 20 days after its publication and will then be applicable for five years.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to establish a single framework of preventive and anti-animal diseases transmitted to animals and humans and establishes a harmonised animal health strategy throughout the Union. The text stresses the responsibility of the actors and the basic knowledge of health risks; it calls for the implementation of the obligation for Member States to develop response plans to deal with certain diseases. It also stresses the importance of establishing standards and requirements for exports and for third countries shipping animals and animal products to prevent the introduction of animal diseases into the EU.  It is important that the European Union can anticipate and respond to any health threat as soon as possible.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on animal health because we think it is positive that measures will be put in place to prevent and tackle outbreaks of animal diseases such as avian influenza and African swine fever, transmissible between animals and potentially also humans.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on animal health because I consider the prevention and control of animal diseases that can be transmitted to animals or humans to be important. The proposal, which is part of a package which also includes three other proposals to modernise the acquis communautaire in the areas of plant health, plant propagating material and official controls, is supported by both myself and the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats. In the compromise negotiations on the central objective, a political agreement was reached by the negotiating team to reduce the numerous amendments by means of corresponding compromise amendments on key issues, such as 'lists of epidemics', 'basic knowledge of animal health' and 'competence of the Member States'.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against the amendment proposing to reject the agreement reached between the Council and Parliament, therefore supporting the Recommendation for the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on communicable diseases of animals and amending or repealing certain acts on animal health ('Animal Health Legislation'). This agreement greatly improves the original text proposed by the Commission on animal welfare, control and combat of diseases affecting animals, so I have not supported its rejection.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The new animal health regulation, which combines and updates almost 40 acts of previous regulations, establishes for the first time a clear link between animal health and public health. The new legislation places the emphasis on the prevention and control of diseases that can be transmitted between animals and potentially also to humans, such as avian influenza and African swine fever. It also outlines the responsibilities not only of farmers, traders and professionals in the animal world, but also of veterinarians and pet owners, who will be required to use veterinary medicines more prudently in order to combat the growing antimicrobial resistance. In the hope that these measures will be able to act effectively for the protection and protection of public and animal health, I have decided to vote in favour of approving the agreement at second reading.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 The animal health strategy should contribute to the prevention and control of diseases in animals, with particular attention to antimicrobial resistance. This is a public health issue, given the frequency of the same diseases in animals and humans and the hypothetical transmission of antimicrobial resistance between animals and humans, recently corroborated by a study conducted in China. The way in which this issue is addressed in practice should take into account the specificities of production in different regions of Europe, especially with regard to weather conditions that promote the occurrence and transmission of diseases. On the other hand, the conditions imposed on European producers on animal health should be taken into account in trade negotiations with third countries.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ We supported the rejection because the overall effect is to extend and bureaucratise EU control with all its negative impacts, especially in relation to family pets.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 It is indisputable that the current EU legislation in the field of animal health has had success in significantly reducing animal diseases and responding well to emerging crises. However, its main drawback is the existence of more than 50 dispersed pieces of legislation and several hundred implementing rules. The lack of a horizontal approach and the complex and often contradictory rules make life very difficult not only for Member States' administrations, but above all for breeders, veterinarians or traders. It is therefore welcome that the new regulation creates a harmonised legal framework in this area, which fits well with our efforts to simplify the CAP.  Another long-awaited move is to place greater emphasis on preventing disease among animals, according to the motto: prevention is better than cure. This is to m.in. to increase the responsibility of animal welfare, better monitoring and certification. Indeed, the current legal framework is aimed primarily at combating epidemics rather than preventing them.  It is also worth stressing the strong emphasis on increasing antibiotic resistance, increasing biosecurity on farms and the need to improve the qualifications of animal welfare professionals. These are some of the main demands that Parliament has made in the course of its work, and it is welcome that they have been taken into account in the final text of the regulation.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report because, in the view I share with my socialist colleagues, it represents a great achievement of policy-making and of EU law in regards to animals. The new Animal Health Law represents a positive contribution of the EU to the welfare and health of animals. This is something about which many of my constituents in the West Midlands have contacted me. For me, it was important that this new law should introduce robust measures to tackle diseases which are transmissible between animals of the same species and across species, and diseases which endanger and pose serious health risks to humans. The new law also contains a set of provisions that will be useful for dealing with stray animals in a humane manner. Overall, this new Animal Health Law represents a great example of how the EU can actually deliver on something about which many citizens across Europe are worried.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ I share the adopted regulation introducing new measures to prevent and stop the spread of animal diseases, such as avian influenza, which are communicable to other animals and often to humans. When voting on the Council's position, we in the European Parliament no longer commented on the very text of the legislative regulation, because the Council of the EU had already agreed to it in December 2015, but only on an amendment that would have repealed the entire proposal for a regulation. I therefore voted against this repeal. However, the EP's vote allowed the regulation to be published in the Official Journal of the EU.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒I supported this proposal for a Regulation as it focuses on the prevention of diseases that can have deadly consequences for animals and humans in the Member States of the Union and beyond. Animal diseases such as bird or swine flu are a threat to the economy, food safety and public health and therefore comprehensive protection should be put in place for animals and humans. The proposed Regulation introduces a thorough categorisation of diseases, clarifies definitions of responsibility for animals and their condition, and prioritizes bio-safety, i.e. vaccination instead of kill, and separation of sick animals from the rest of animals as well as new animals from old ones. In order to monitor the implementation of the Regulation, Member States should collect important, comparable and sufficiently detailed data on the use of antimicrobial products in animals and provide this information to the Commission in order to ensure the safe use of these products and to reduce the risk of cases of ammicrobial resistance. The reports to be published by the Commission on the basis of this data will help to further develop preventive measures against animal diseases in EU Member States.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ Although the EU has a very good developed set of animal welfare legislation, new phenomena have been emerging in this area recently, which undoubtedly include new diseases. Since diseases in livestock production systems cause economic losses in relation to morbidity, mortality, drug costs, extra labour, reduced production in cured animals and health safety of animal products at all policy levels, I consider it right that the proposed regulation lays down specific rules for the prevention and control of animal diseases that can be transmitted to animals or to humans. I believe that the regulation will improve animal welfare regulations more significantly and bring them to life will improve, in particular, disease prevention and control, better veterinary treatments, better nutrition, but also a more coordinated solution to safety risks. I expect that the proposed regulation will also contribute to reducing the use of antibiotics in animals and thus reducing antimicrobial resistance.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 therapeutic animal diseases, such as avian influenza, can have a major negative impact on food safety and public health and can have a negative impact on the economy. As such diseases can spread across national borders, coordinated action at EU level is needed. In 2013, the European Commission presented a legislative proposal on animal health by introducing a single and simplified regulatory framework in the field of the management of various animal diseases. The new law will clearly set out the responsibilities and activities of all actors in animal health. Disease prevention and control measures will be at the forefront; antimicrobial resistance will also be taken into account. It is intended to establish a list of priority animal diseases, including human-borne diseases, and their classification. It is noted that animal health is linked to animal welfare standards and therefore pain and suffering during controls should be avoided. Following negotiations in the trialogue, the Council adopted a position at first reading on the Regulation on 2200 animal diseases and amending and repealing certain acts in the field of animal health. In view of the above, I would like the procedure to continue at second reading, which is why I voted against the amendment rejecting the European Council's position in plenary, thus supporting the recommendation for second reading.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. The initially strong report after first reading lost some feathers after the negotiations with the Commission and the Council, but remains defensible. For example, the green proposal for a mandatory identification chip for dogs will no longer be included from 2018. On the other hand, professional breeders and sellers of pets have to register without exception. Other matters are incorporated into other legislation. For example, inspections on the identification of farm animals are included in the Regulation of official controls and the objective of reducing antibiotic use is linked to the legislation on veterinary medicinal products. I voted in favour of the proposal because the strong link between animal health and the presence of high animal welfare standards is still in the proposal. The need to ensure antimicrobial resistance in the imposition of disease prevention measures and control measures also remains a strong reference. The "main list" of diseases covered by this legislation will be drawn up through a delegated act (and not with implementing measures, as the Commission wanted) and there is a commitment to preserve biodiversity and valuable genetic material. Finally, disease control measures should focus as much as possible on avoiding pain, misery and suffering.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒This Regulation lays down rules for preventing and superseding animal diseases that are transferable to animals or humans, but does not contain provisions specifically governing animal welfare, even though animal health and welfare are linked. The Union has a well-developed acquis in terms of animal welfare covering different species (fattening chickens, laying hens, pigs, poultry) or activities (breeding, transport, slaughter, research, etc.). This animal welfare legislation will necessarily continue to apply. The Commission is fully committed to paying full attention to animal welfare in accordance with Article 13. and within its constraints, including the full implementation and appropriate development of that legislation, and therefore voted against rejecting the Council's position at first reading.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which represents a positive contribution by the EU to the health and welfare of animals. The new law will introduce robust measures to tackle transmissible animal diseases which endanger animal welfare and pose health risks to humans. The new law also contains a set of provisions that will be useful for dealing with stray animals in a humane manner. Along with my EPLP colleagues, I am proud to support this excellent new safeguard to animal welfare.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted against the amendment. In so doing, the agreement on 20 200 animals was finally approved by the Agreement on Transfer Animal Diseases and the Amendment and repeal of certain acts in the field of animal health. The new regulation summarises the 50 animal health decisions to date and updates and simplifies the existing legal framework. The Committee on Agriculture has managed to find a compromise between a number of amendments, thus preparing a balanced report. In addition to effective reporting and cooperation between all Member States, we also need more effective cooperation between the European Union and third countries.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation replaces over 40 outdated and sometimes inconsistent pieces of EU legislation with one single document, but the more detailed rules are subject to secondary legislation, which makes a full assessment of the policy implications hard to predict at this stage. Furthermore, I cannot accept the legal empowerment given to the Commission to draw up a list of animal diseases which pose a risk to animal or public health. I believe that this requires input from national experts, which the empowerment precludes.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Animal welfare and welfare lay the foundations for their good health. Immediate consequence: the reduction of the use of antibiotic drugs, which indirectly affects humans as well.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted not in favour of rejecting this report on animal health, as I think it is good that a common segment of animal and public health, transferable diseases, is finally addressed within a report. Because of the animal husbandry aspect, in this case it is also a very important food issue, and pets should not be forgotten. In both cases, the draft also targets animal welfare and illegal trade, while at the same time uniting some 40 acts, thus pointing towards simplification. The approach places a strong emphasis on prevention and helps professionals keep up with scientific progress. I am pleased that the issue of antibiotics is also included in the report, because the issue of antibiotic resistance must be a priority. By linking animal and public health, we can reduce the use of antibiotics and reduce the increase in antibiotic resistance. I believe that further reductions could be achieved with alternative non-antibiotic-based medicines. The objectives set out in the report point towards an effective, uniform protection system at European level, as it encourages authorities and manufacturers to place greater emphasis on prevention and control. In my opinion, the decentralisation of the system of public health services in Hungary can be an obstacle to this effective action.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this regulation which, among other things, provides for the obligation to prevent animals from suffering, pain, distress and suffering in carrying out disease control measures: farmed animals are sentient beings and not machines for producing meat, milk and eggs. I also welcome the fact that this regulation links animal welfare and public health at EU level. I hope that further rapid legislative steps will be taken in this direction: intensive farming, where animals are piled up on each other and living in totally unnatural conditions, is the equivalent of bacteriological bombs ready to explode and potentially seriously affect public health. It is right to try to keep these potential bombs under control with health measures, but the only real effective safeguard is the introduction of animal welfare standards that can eliminate overcrowding of farms (which makes possible contagion easy and rampant) and eliminate unnatural living conditions, which weaken the immune system of animals. Finally, I support two other principles contained in the regulation: the need to be careful against antibiotic resistance and the commitment to the conservation of biodiversity and valuable genetic resources.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – The European Union has in recent decades become a space dominated by care for animal welfare, be they pet or wild. In line with this principle, the European institutions have sought to adapt existing legislation to the relevant requirements in recent years. An essential aspect of this is to ensure animal health, in particular by preventing communicable diseases. The adoption of an "animal health law" has become a necessity, especially when we think of wild animals that can be completely vulnerable to new type diseases. At the same time, taking antibiotics to diseased animals can weaken their immunity. The incidence of animal diseases can also affect human personnel who work with them in one way or another and amount to 20-30 million people. Another aspect of the legislation concerns the treatment of animals, which must avoid their suffering, but also their controlled breeding and the protection of elite breeds. As regards pets, the registration of specialised breeders in a european database could avoid the spread of certain maladies. As this is an important document in this area, I support its adoption in its current form.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Let us emphasize the preventive role of the regulation on communicable animal diseases (the "animal health legislation") and the reduction in the administration of antibiotics to animals that is expected. Without prejudice to the requirements of the regulation, Member States are invited to commit to collecting relevant, comparable and sufficiently detailed data on the effective administration of antimicrobial drugs to animals and to pass this data on to the Commission, with the aim of achieving more careful administration of antimicrobial drugs to animals and thus contributing to the reduction of the risk of antimicrobial resistance.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that, in addition to laying down rules for the prevention and control of animal diseases which are transmissible to animals and to humans, we should also include animal welfare. It is undeniable that animal health is closely connected with their well-being. Furthermore, collecting relevant data on the use of antimicrobial medicinal products could be an important step towards reducing the risk of antimicrobial resistance.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against a proposal to reject the Council's position and a proposal bringing together and updating different parts of European animal health legislation by the new law. Many Member States have mandatory pet identification and registration systems, but I believe there are differences between the types of data stored, registrations and management levels where this data is stored. I believe that the correct conditions for identifying and registering dogs and cats would reduce the scope of document forgery and illicit trafficking.  Also, I believe that due to the low vaccination rate of animals, the risk of antimicrobial resistance among pets increases, which is an additional risk factor for the development and transmission of antimicrobial resistance in humans.  I also support the establishment of a computer database for dogs and cats to ensure effective disease control measures and to facilitate the transfer of animals between Members of the European Union, so I do not support the rejection of this proposal.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a regulation on animal health. I believe that adoption is a great achievement, as it enables the integration of animal health and welfare with human health, and we will be able to tackle increasing antimicrobial resistance by using antibiotics responsibly, and veterinary services and breeders will be able to focus more on the prevention of infectious diseases. In addition, about 40 different regulations are combined into one.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on animal health because we think it is positive that measures will be put in place to prevent and tackle outbreaks of animal diseases such as avian influenza and African swine fever, transmissible between animals and potentially also humans.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Experts believe that this should improve the prevention and control of diseases that are transmissible from animals to people. I will support any measure to promote and ensure public health and, in this case specifically, the better regulation of bacterial drugs that are given to animals, provided this does not affect animal welfare.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Overall, this regulation, under the pretext of simplification, grants new prerogatives to the European Commission. The Austrian parliament has also stressed that it is not in line with the principle of subsidiarity.  The main positive is the creation of a European database on the use of antimicrobials, antibiotics, etc., which can be an asset in denouncing the dumping of certain member countries. I therefore voted in favour of the amendment to reject the text.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union legislative proposal on communicable animal diseases contains a number of measures to prevent and combat epidemics of animal diseases, such as avian influenza or African swine fever. The fact that more than 60% of human diseases come from animals makes this proposal of major importance. This proposal underlines the need for responsible use of antibiotics to fight increasing antimicrobial resistance in animals. In this respect, veterinarians will be obliged to draw attention to the interaction between animal health and welfare and antimicrobial resistance. The European Commission will therefore monitor the use of antibiotics in the Member States and have the possibility to take urgent measures to combat epidemics that could seriously affect human health and agricultural production. In such cases, farmers' organisations and veterinary associations will be involved in the establishment of contingency plans. In addition, pet breeders and traders are required to register in a database in order to avoid the situation where homeless or illegally marketed animals transmit animal diseases. In view of these reasons, I voted in favour of the proposal on communicable animal diseases.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on animal health because we think it is positive that measures will be put in place to prevent and tackle outbreaks of animal diseases such as avian influenza and African swine fever, transmissible between animals and potentially also humans.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this dossier because, among other things, there were key references emphasising the link between animal health and good standards of animal welfare, and the need to guard against antimicrobial resistance when carrying out disease prevention and control measures. The ‘master list’ of diseases subject to EU regulation will be put together by delegated acts and there is a commitment towards preserving biodiversity and valuable genetic resources. There is also a general requirement to avoid pain, distress and suffering when carrying out disease control measures.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – This Regulation lays down rules for the prevention and control of animal diseases which may affect animals or humans, but there are no provisions specifically regulating animal welfare.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation concerning animal health, in view of the adoption of a regulation that would update animal health rules. The text specifically underlines the importance of the prevention of diseases such as avian flu, which are transmissible between animals and from animals to humans. It further urges for a more prudent use of antimicrobial medicinal products in animals, where Member States are advised to collect relevant, comparable and meticulous data on the actual use of antimicrobial medicinal products in animals. The report aims to prevent the deterioration of animal health and its negative effects on human health, which is the reason why I voted in favour of it.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a Regulation that unifies, modernizes and simplifies legislation on an issue such as animal health, a highly technical but very important issue for consumers and producers. The Regulation has a positive impact on the consumer and livestock sectors, but also on trade with third countries, and is at the culmination of what has been agreed between producers, European bodies and national administrations with regard to the EU's animal health strategy. I therefore consider it necessary to vote in your favour.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report because it represents a significant step forward in European law and policy-making with regard to animals. This new Animal Health Law puts the welfare of animals at the forefront of policy-making by introducing robust measures to tackle transmissible animal diseases which endanger animal welfare and pose health risks to humans. The report also contains a set of provisions that lay out methods for dealing with stray animals in a humane manner. There has been widespread demand from citizens for higher standards and codification in the area of animal treatment. I am therefore happy to see this report being brought forward to address these concerns. This shows the EU responding properly to the concerns of its citizens. In sum, the new Animal Health Law is a great example of the EU delivering on a matter of direct importance to the EU citizens through the improvement and codification of animal welfare standards.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this proposal because these rules will contribute to a higher level of prevention and better control of communicable animal diseases in the European Union. These diseases have no borders and a European response to them is therefore more than appropriate.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. We can praise the principle of fixing legislation by replacing 50 directives and regulations and more than 400 other legislative acts, using a holistic perspective that brings human and animal health together into a single concept of public health and also seeks to integrate the issue of animal welfare as a base element in the health status of our domestic species. However, this is of course risky, as it underlies the idea that it is possible and desirable to empower the European institutions to manage health and control and eradicate the main zoonoses. Nothing more fake. Good sanitary management implies proximity and knowledge of the terrain. Moving decision-making centres away from countries and regions can be a tragic mistake for animal health and, consequently, for public health. What the EU could and should do is radically change the CAP, as it generates intensive production, the emergence of new diseases and the intensive use of medicines. This, yes, would be a big step towards improving animal health by reducing the impact of zoonoses.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Overall, a good approach, but also associated with currently unforeseeable bureaucracy for small and medium-sized farmers. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the text presented, which will help to improve animal health legislation by obliging all operators to respect the principles of proper animal husbandry. In addition, the prudent and responsible use of veterinary medicines will be ensured, with a list of diseases regulated by legislation in line with the decisions of Parliament and the European Council.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on animal health. The European Animal Health Act is intended to replace 40 different Member States' legislation in this area. The EU-wide scheme aims to create the first link between animal welfare and public health in EU law and will make it mandatory for all farmers, pet owners and traders. I oppose the GROWING influence of the EU on national concerns of the Member States. This report is clearly an example of a violation of the principle of subsidiarity. That is why I rejected this report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it represents a major achievement of European law and policy—making with regards to animals. The new Animal Health Law represents a positive contribution of the EU to the health and welfare of animals, a key concern of Labour supporters. Importantly, the new law will introduce robust measures to tackle transmissible animal diseases which endanger animal welfare and pose health risks to humans. The new law also contains a set of provisions that will be useful for dealing with stray animals in a humane manner. In sum, the new Animal Health Law is a great example of the EU actually delivering on a matter of direct importance to EU citizens.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposed text, as did my colleagues in the committee responsible for Agriculture and Rural Development. The resolution is a recommendation for second reading and, inter alia, endorses the joint declaration by Parliament, the Council and the Commission on antimicrobial resistance and the use of veterinary medicinal products.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. As reflected in the statistics, about 70% of current infectious diseases are common to animals and humans. This indicates that animal health needs to be monitored, in order to safeguard people's well-being. To this end, I believe that, as the Committee on the Environment points out, it is necessary to put an end to all disease risk factors and to be true to the motto 'prevention best than cure'. Therefore, I believe that it is necessary to study diseases from their origin and use past events as the basis for learning, before carrying out mass sacrifices. I therefore support this report for the health and well-being benefits of European citizens and EU animals.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I decided to support this recommendation. I agree with the need for Member States to commit to collecting relevant, detailed and comparable data on the real use of antimicrobial medicines in animals. I consider it necessary that these products should only be used in animals when really necessary, thus preventing possible antimicrobial resistance. I also welcome the Commission's commitment to publishing regular reports in this area.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ the new animal health regulation is intended to replace around 40 different regulations and thus not only will make the legislation more transparent, but it will also update many already outdated regulations and bring them into line with the latest scientific knowledge. The new legislation is based on binding rules for both animal owners and traders, which are based on the principle of animal welfare, but also on a very important link between animal health and public health. This concerns two areas as a matter of priority.
