Not only is the number of diseases communicable from animals to humans, but the unthinkable and irresponsible use of antibiotics in animals contributes significantly to the increase in antimicrobial resistance. The legislation therefore encourages the responsible use of veterinary medicinal products, as well as introduces the registration of professional holders and traders for more effective control of contagious diseases. Although we did not vote in plenary to adopt this new amendment as a whole, we voted on an amendment by a political faction calling for it to be rejected. However, as I believe that updating and replacing opaque legislation is the right step, I voted against the political group's proposal to reject this legislation.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Selimovic report because I believe that this proposal improves the law on animal health by obliging operators and keepers of animals to respect the principle of animal welfare in animal husbandry, as well as to adopt biosafety measures to protect their animals. Another obligation is to provide responsible and prudent use of veterinary medicinal products, in particular to prevent increased antimicrobial resistance. Finally, on the path of animal welfare, pain and suffering should be avoided when carrying out disease control measures.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. The report on animal health links animal health, also seen from the point of view of safeguarding their welfare, with human health. In order to combat the growing antimicrobial resistance in the veterinary field, it was decided to frame the issue taking into account this direct human-animal link and to place a greater focus on the responsible use of antibiotics. The report also provides for national authorities and producers to focus more on the prevention and control of animal-transmitted diseases. In this sense, all disease control measures must take into account animal welfare and prevent all animals subjected to such measures, including those in captivity such as stray, any kind of pain, distress or suffering. This also includes the responsibilities to which all operators and professionals in the world of animals will be subject, who will be obliged to make more prudent use of medicines intended for animals. I would have liked the report to have been more ambitious and incisive in the field of animal welfare, but I welcome the elements that have been introduced and have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 Good animal health contributes significantly to the sustainability of our agriculture and fisheries. We must ensure that farmers have access to the right tools for the prevention and treatment of diseases in animals. The legislative proposal that I supported is intended to lay down rules for the prevention and control of animal diseases that can be transmitted to animals or humans. The aim of the proposal is thus to establish a single, simplified, transparent and clear regulatory framework, taking into account new challenges such as the possible emergence of new diseases, recurrence of epidemics or changes in trading conditions.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Once again, the already well-known duplicity of the European Union! They support school fruit programs. And it certainly sounds great that especially when the children get the fruit produced by local farmers – it's really, really nice. yes, but where are the local farmers? But they did not support the survival of local economies and the development of local economies. However, they supported cutting down the fruit trees. So there are no fruit trees, or very few, because they have been carced out by the Union. There are no local economies, because the Union's neoliberal policies have ruined it, just as hungarian agriculture as a whole has been destroyed. But now we're getting some support for our students to eat fruit! Thank you so much.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, I supported this report and congratulate to the rapporteur on a good report. I welcome the fact that Parliament will be deciding on the budget for this scheme in 2017 and 2018 and that we have transferred existing monies to increase the annual budget by EUR 20 million for school milk, compared to the Commission’s proposal.  This is a subject close to my heart because, back in 1999, my first success in an amendment in Parliament related to the school milk initiative. What I particularly welcome is that this scheme provides nutritious alternatives to the unhealthy snacks and sugary drinks consumed by children today. It is a win-win situation for our farmers and for our children. It is also a good deal for the UK taxpayer. It is another positive aspect of the UK’s membership of the EU.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, in the 17 years that I have been here – not for much longer, I hope, depending on our referendum, but that is another question – I have never once been lobbied on the issue of school milk by a nutritionist or an educationalist. I have been lobbied a great deal by farmers. In fact, there is an argument that we have far too much dairy in the Western diet.  But, leaving that argument aside, surely this is the kind of thing we can leave to schools to work out for themselves – or, if we absolutely need coordination, then to local – not even to national – governments. How on earth have we got to the point where this kind of issue is being determined on behalf of 600 million citizens? Of course, the answer is precisely because we are so prone to lobbies in this Chamber, and precisely because there is a remoteness of distance between government and governed in Brussels which you do not get at national levels, which is what makes it so attractive to vested interests.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – I supported the report on the voluntary aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables and milk in educational establishments, because I strongly believe that it gives further impetus to improve the eating habits of adolescents. This in itself is also an investment in the public health of future generations. I believe that it is necessary to emphasise the need to use organic products in this scheme. For its target group, the consumption of organic products is of particular importance as it ensures the consumption of products with qualities closest to natural products.  The newly adopted Regulation, which entered into force in August 2017, also draws attention to one particularly important aspect, namely giving priority to local and regional producers to participate in the scheme. It increases by 20 million on an annual basis the subsidy for the supply of dairy products, which will allow, especially for disadvantaged children, to eat healthily. That is why I supported this resolution.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I was hesitant to support this material. In the end, I supported him. I consider the issue of healthy eating among young people to be a big problem. It is clear that the problem of obesity and unhealthy lifestyles is an important problem for the young generation in most parts of Europe. That was why I supported this proposal to strengthen the healthy diet of children in schools. I am convinced that it is not possible to make this to children, but we should make them such an offer.  I have doubts as to whether this needs to be addressed by subsidies. Only practice will show how effective the subsidies are, how much they will really help young people, or they will only be another form of subsidies for farmers. It would therefore be a good idea to assess, after a certain period of time, the extent to which this programme will be effective and whether young people will actually benefit more from healthy eating offers in schools under this programme.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr The health and effective upbringing of our children, education at school is a cornerstone of our Union in general, it is our future. There are no children, no future. Consequently, I support the fact that providing fresh fruit, vegetables, milk, both ordinary milk and lactose-free milk in schools is a very important and fruitful set of measures in general. It is also positive that, in this case, we can also support our European Union farmers' sector in parallel, especially in my country, Latvia, where this sector has suffered greatly after the introduction of Russian counter-sanctions, and in general, cheese, bananas, yoghurt, nuts and fresh food is much healthier than the chemicals, chips and everything that is marketed in our schools. In total, the annual funding will amount to EUR 250 million - one hundred and fifty for fruit, one hundred for milk, and I hope that we will also achieve a fair distribution of funding between the Member States. Support, thank you!

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, the story is indeed not entirely black and white, and it is true that certain products should only be promoted when necessary. I was also hesitant with this support, on the kind of side I decided to support this proposal, because there has been a significant shift compared to the original proposal last year. In the Czech Republic, this "Milk for Schools" programme is very successful, more than three thousand schools are involved and 600,000 pupils consume products from this programme. I am not saying that all the products there are completely healthy, but if we are to fight sweetened Coca-Cola, sticks and other, quite clearly unhealthy food, then the promotion of milk and products from it is, in my opinion, a much lesser evil. And it is important that these eating habits are acquired by children in their young age, rather than later.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – I supported the proposal tabled because the milk programme is of great importance to Slovakia. According to statistics, Slovak households consume the least milk throughout the European Union. In Slovakia, the programme "school milk" under the auspices of the European Union was launched in 2004. It allows children and their parents to buy dairy products on more affordable terms. Thanks to this, milk vending machines were placed in some schools. It should be borne in mind that the consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk is declining throughout the European Union. Increasing milk and fruit consumption and changing eating habits therefore undoubtedly falls within the sphere of public health care and is therefore one of the Competences of the European Union.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, for which I thank the rapporteur, Mr Tarabella. I know that this is not at the heart of the European Union, but it is very important to take care of this type of public health issue, such as school meals.  After all, different countries organise school meals in different ways, but it is still good to call for a public health aspect of healthy food, because we are currently suffering from secondary diabetes and overweight in the European Union due to the fact that young people's eating habits are very sugary and of the wrong type. In this regard, this milk and fruit project is very good. In this context, I would also like to draw attention to fellow Member Hannan, who, in this speech too, skilfully found such a critical EU perspective. He is faithful to his line, which I congratulate him on, unlike his Prime Minister, Mr Cameron, who has turned his line 180 degrees and is speaking speeches written today by ex-mep Andrew Duff. So here's a little thank you to Daniel.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, thug mé tacaíocht don tuarascáil seo chomh maith agus is dóigh liom gur maith an scéim é seo mar cuireann sé bia breá, folláin, áitiúil ar fáil do dhaltaí trasna na hEorpa ar fad rud a bhfuil géar gá leis mar is soiléir nach bhfuil a dhóthain den bhia sin á fháil acu. Dá bhrí sin cabhróidh seo chun é sin a cheartú agus jabanna a choimeád faoin tuath. So I agree with the rapporteur that in the current context of declining consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and milk products among children in the EU, an extended list of healthy and local foodstuffs eligible for EU funding should be distributed. An extended list of milk, vegetable and food products, which includes other products such as nuts, yoghurt and cheese, is necessary in order to sufficiently follow nutritional recommendations on calcium absorption, promote the consumption of these products and further help respond to the particular nutritional needs of children.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The number of obese or overweight children under the age of 5 has increased from 31 million in 1990 to 41 million in 2014. It is therefore clear how to convey the value of healthy and balanced nutrition from an early life is of fundamental importance. The EU has therefore decided to establish a legal and financial framework governing the distribution of genuine and agricultural products, through the 'School Milk' and 'School Fruit' programmes. The new rules aim to ensure greater commitment not only to providing healthier food to children, but above all to educating them to have healthier eating habits. I voted in favour because I believe that these programmes can bring significant benefits to public health and, at the same time, benefit the growth of the European agricultural sector.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. – We do want school-children to be well—nourished, but we opposed this because, even if you think taxpayers should contribute, these things should not be done centrally by Brussels.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We do want school-children to be well—nourished, but we opposed this because, even if you think taxpayers should contribute, these things should not be done centrally by Brussels.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because this is an important and necessary programme. I agree with much of the improvements made by Parliament, such as distributed foods having restrictions on the content of added sugars, salts, sweeteners and fats, as well as some flavor enhancers. Other important elements contained in the report are accompanying educational measures and the fact that Member States can give priority to sustainability and fair trade considerations.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – This Regulation was aimed at revising the School Milk Scheme (in place since 1977) and the School Fruit Scheme (in place since 2007). The revisions were primarily concerned with visibility of the scheme and amending those parts related to educational aspects. I specifically took issue with the fact that the ‘refocus’ of the already existing scheme would now require schools to publicise, at the school premises, their involvement in the scheme and the fact that it is subsidised by the Union by using official logos and graphic. The revision further allows the Commission to adopt delegated and implementing acts dictating exactly how this is to be done (methods of publicising, exact size of posters, font, website tools, etc.). The original aim of the scheme was to promote local produce and healthy eating. This new focus on publicity is an unsuitable use of funds for an already functioning scheme. Therefore I abstained on this vote.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. The European Parliament has spoken out in favour of strengthening the programme for the distribution of fruit and milk in schools. I welcome this, because priority is given to fresh fruits and vegetables, on the one hand, and it is forbidden to distribute processed products in which sugar, salt, fats, sweeteners or artificial flavours have been added, on the other hand, despite very active lobbying on the part of the agri-food industry.  It will consolidate fruit and vegetable and milk consumption programmes in schools into one and increase the budget allocated to schools to 250 million euros. This programme will encourage the consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables as well as dairy products among young Europeans. The school will play a significant pedagogical and central role in improving our children's eating habits. It will boost local agriculture and short circuits by focusing on local and seasonal products, as well as organic products.  In the context of the agricultural crisis we are experiencing, this program will support small farmers and the dairy sector by allowing them to sell their products.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational institutions, because it referred to the distribution of milk in schools and the fruit and vegetable programme in schools. There was a need to streamline and improve the efficiency of the systems, not to say because of criticism from the Court of Auditors. This report also ensures the future of school systems. In addition, management will now be more effective through a single and visible programme, where the milk programme will operate alongside the fruit and vegetable strand. The goal is to promote consumption in healthy products, fresh foods, by school children, helping them to create healthy eating habits, especially for cases of obesity. The budget is contained in this text and allows Member States to plan this action in the medium and long term.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Parliament confirmed an agreement between the Council and Parliament, approved by the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, bringing together the existing school milk and fruit programmes and increasing the annual budget by EUR 20 million to EUR 250 million. I think it is important that the EU and its Member States make greater efforts to ensure the healthy eating of our children. Since the school is the place where they spend most of the day, it is important that they can get healthy food there as well as be better taught about healthy eating habits.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report concerned the distribution of products in schools. Together with my colleagues from the National Front, we have found it particularly positive that the Member States remain free in the implementation of the programme by adapting it to their needs and specificities. This will help to promote local products and to initiate local food policies. So I voted for it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to confirm that I abstained on this legislative resolution.  I agree with the sentiment of the report that healthy eating should be promoted in schools. The UK already has healthy eating promoted in schools as part of the curriculum because it is important to educate children to make good food choices.  The report demands that any Member States taking part in the programme must promote the European Union using ‘suitable communication tools to be laid down by the Commission.’ I take issue with the fine print of the report, which will allow the European Commission to ‘be empowered to adopt delegated acts to supplement the list of food products and flavours allowed’. The EC would be automatically allowed to decide what British children can and cannot eat without any consultation. This is a dangerous precedent to set.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because, in the context of an agricultural crisis, particularly linked to the Russian embargo, it is important to provide support to EU fruit and vegetable producers. It is important to increase the consumption of these productions within the internal market, and this can be done through schools.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: In writing. The European Parliament has voted in favour of strengthening the programme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables and milk in schools. Despite active lobbying by the agri-food industry, Member States are now invited to promote healthy eating habits, to encourage short circuits by focusing on local and seasonal products as well as products from organic farming. The main change in the adopted text will be the strengthening of the budget allocated to this programme, which will be increased to EUR 250 million. While encouraging healthier eating habits, this program will also support small farmers who can find a sustainable home.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this proposal, which aims to strengthen the new animal health rules to combat communicable animal diseases such as avian influenza or African swine fever. Animal health rules combine and update nearly 40 legislation in this area so far and establish, for the first time in history, the interdependence between animal and public health. There is a mandatory registration of persons engaged in the trade in animals, a clearer distribution of responsibilities between farmers, traders and veterinarians and a greater focus on prevention. At the same time, the role of farmers, traders, veterinarians and animal owners in combating the spread of diseases has been clarified. I support the granting the European Commission the right to react immediately to outbreaks of animal diseases that can have a significant impact on public health or agricultural production. It is also important to provide for mandatory registration of persons engaged in animal trafficking, as well as to establish national databases for dogs, cats and other pets.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft regulation and its version, as amended by the Commission, provide Member States with the opportunity to choose between products that can be distributed in their schools and to prioritise local products where possible, in addition to the use of EU funds without co-financing from Member States. The report also credits the freedom to distribute specific products, such as honey or olive oil and similar products, in schools, specific only to the region. In its recommendations, it also takes care to draw attention to the presentation in training of the so-called school fruit scheme and certain agricultural links, as well as the requirements of sustainability and fair trade. It proposes a differentiated allocation of aid by Member State or even region, depending on need and access. On this basis, I supported the adoption of the regulation.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This vote was the result of bitter negotiations, including a heated trilogue, and he had received the support of my colleagues Edouard Ferrand and Philippe Loiseau in the AGRI committee. Indeed, it seems to us that this is a good measure in the sense that this text gives Member States the freedom to implement this programme in the way they wish. Member States therefore remain in control of their sovereignty over the subject and can thus promote the use of local products and engage in a form of national and/or regional food patriotism. Finally, a measure that goes in the direction of French producers!

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. It is with great pleasure that I have supported this report, which will extend and intensify the action that my colleague and friend Marc Tarabella is taking in favour of the free distribution of fruit and vegetables and milk in schools on the basis of European Union funding. This is clearly an initiative that multiplies the positive aspects such as promoting healthy eating habits in order to combat the consumption of sugary or fatty foods by children, which is a source of obesity or health problems in the future. As a result of this initiative, 30 million children will eat healthier in nearly 200,000 schools in the European Union.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today more than 20 million European children are overweight. In the adolescent group there is an average consumption of fruits and vegetables that corresponds only to 30 to 50% of the recommended daily intake. The whole of Europe seems to be suffering from a decline in fruit and vegetable consumption, while there is a steady increase in the risk of diseases related to poor nutrition and obesity. My support for the Tarabella report stems from the conviction that the increase in resources dedicated to the development of correct eating habits is a crucial investment for the future of the younger generation. The EUR 250 million allocated, compared with only THE EUR 20 million envisaged to date, is a clear confirmation of the EU's commitment to food. The merging of existing school curricula on fruit and vegetables and milk will, in particular, make it possible to improve the efficiency of European measures, while ensuring better use of funds. The measures taken provide for the exclusion of all products containing added sugars and sweeteners and guarantee priority to fresh and local products, to the detriment of processed products such as soups, compounds, fruit juices, yoghurt and cheese.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report for the restructuring of aid schemes for the consumption of fruit and vegetables and bananas and milk in schools, as these have a very positive impact on society inso as they promote healthy eating at an early age and seek to establish direct links between the two ends of the food chain , producer and consumer, enhancing the local primary sector. In addition, two productive sectors – dairy and fruit and vegetable – are indirectly promoted, representing approximately 30% of the Union's agricultural production.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported Mr Tarabella's report and negotiation on a new programme for the distribution of fruits, vegetables and milk in schools, with the aim of instilled good eating habits in children and combating childhood obesity. The initiative will bring together in a single programme two existing schemes to date: one dedicated to distribution in schools of fruits and vegetables and, the other, to the distribution of milk. As a novelty, it also plans to educate children to acquire healthy eating habits. The programme will be provided with aid of EUR 250 million per year, of which EUR 150 million will go to the fruit and vegetable programme and the rest to milk and dairy products.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Parliament's position stems from a general consensus among the various political groups following numerous debates. This program is a good measure, as it organizes the distribution of fruits and vegetables, bananas and dairy products in schools. Above all, this text gives Member States the freedom to implement this programme, which allows them to remain in control of their sovereignty and allows the use of local products. I am voting for this resolution.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report confirms the programme for the distribution of bananas and milk in schools. Although I am sceptical about the practical application of this instrument, I am convinced of the importance of the dissemination of food education in schools and, at a time like this, which sees a very serious crisis in the prices of the main agricultural products, this modest budget can be a positive sign. I therefore voted in favour of this measure.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I've abstained.  The report is of good intention in that it seeks to increase the supply of fruit and milk to schoolchildren. It is both about creating better nutrition and knowledge about food, but there are also strong lobbyist interests from the milk industry who want more EU funds. In addition, a substantial part of the fund money will be about advertising and promoting the EU as a project. The result is a report with good intentions but which actually pays maximum dividends to the milk industry and marketing for the EU. That is not enough to vote in favour of the proposal, which is why I have abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013 and Regulation (EU) No 1360/2013, as well as the agreement reached in the negotiation with the Council as regards the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools.  Problems such as child overweight or the decline in fruit and vegetable consumption are presented as extremely important to the Union, so it must promote healthy eating habits and consumption of local products, and continue and strengthen these school programmes.  The Commission shall be given the power to adopt acts relating to the obligation of the Member States to disclose the aid they receive from the Union for the application of such schemes. It is necessary for each Member State to which such aid is to be granted to establish a strategy at national or regional level and to provide the necessary publicity for intervention in the school system and the subsidies to be used. In addition, Member States will have as their priority the distribution of fresh food.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which aims to adopt a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on an aid programme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments. Based on the experience gained from the application of the current programmes, the conclusions of external evaluations, and a subsequent analysis of the various possible policy measures, and taking into account the social difficulties faced by Member States, it has been concluded that it is essential to continue and strengthen school fruit and vegetables, banana and milk supply programmes. In the current context, with the increasing consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and dairy products (in particular their consumption by children) and consumption habits (highly processed foods, which are also often high in sugar, salt, fat or additives), the number of obese children is increasing. European Union assistance in financing the supply of selected agricultural products to children in educational establishments should contribute more to promoting healthy eating habits and the consumption of local products.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 School milk and fruit schemes play an important role in the EU's common agricultural policy in two respects: on the one hand, they contribute to the decondishment of surplus produce that may accumulate on each agricultural product pathway and, on the other hand, they perform a significant social task: every child has access to healthy milk or dairy products and fruit at least once a day in the context of school meals. The latter is particularly important for promoting the development of the young organism and for the development of healthy eating habits within the framework of educational institutions. Currently, EU support for co-financed programmes is EUR 100 million per year for school milk and EUR 150 million for school fruit. In my opinion, this amount is not sufficient. We are therefore fighting with our fellow Members of the European People's Party to increase the EU budget for the programmes.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. The proposed agreement between the European Parliament and the Council on the proposal for a regulation on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to education institutions was very much supported. It is a very important measure to improve dietary habits in children, which is very important for their health, and to make fruit and vegetables on the menu at school and to transfer these habits to homes later. EUR 250 million per year is a lot of funding, for Slovenia it means EUR 300 000 more per year. It is in Slovenia that for many years we have also introduced locally produced products into primary school meals through traditional honey breakfast. And this measure now allows such traditional high-quality products to be included in this meal. I believe that the Member States will be happy to take advantage of this scheme for the benefit of the children and all of us.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against childhood obesity must be a priority for the future of the European Union. The revised aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools will support the education of children towards correct eating habits, encouraging them to consume fresh and genuine products from local and regional production. Stricter bans on the use of artificial sweeteners and flavourings among distributed products and a strengthening of the supervisory role by national health authorities are important elements of the proposal adopted today. I also welcome the increase in funding for the programme, which will allow 30 million children to benefit from free distribution, thus facilitating the development of a healthy food culture from primary school onwards. The review will also allow concrete support for the agricultural sector, which is currently experiencing a time of economic difficulties, encouraging the resumption of a strong link between farmers and the local community, always with a view to respecting the seasonality of products.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ School fruit and milk schemes are an excellent program that creates healthy eating habits from an early age, and allows farmers to place local products directly on school kitchen tables. I am happy that my amendment to exclude Croatia from the historical criteria has been adopted.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This program to distribute fruits and vegetables, bananas and dairy products in schools is a good measure. States have the opportunity to promote the use of local products. So I voted for this program.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the establishment of an aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools is a necessary measure to be taken to enable our children to eat healthily regardless of the income of the family of origin.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Healthy and correct nutrition cannot be separated from the proper use of fruit and vegetables and milk in the daily diet. Food education is a value that must be taught to children and young people also in school paths: school and family are in fact the two main educational subjects in the lives of children and adolescents. Improving the regulation in order to give priority to the development of local production and marketing on the short chain, providing for the possibility of transfers between national quotas of aid in support of the programme, is certainly a prerequisite for increasing the effectiveness and improving the Union's coordination in the field of education for proper nutrition and the promotion of local fruit and vegetables and dairy products, important resources of which many EU countries can be proud.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report recommends setting up a scheme to help distribute fruits and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools, in order to promote short circuits and nutrition for European children. This report respects the principle of subsidiarity because it grants Member States full freedom to implement the aid programme and therefore suggests that member states can engage in a (certainly homeopathic) version of national and/or regional food patriotism. That is why I voted for this common-sense program, which must be unanimous in the interests of our children and farmers.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. – The European Union is experiencing obesity among young people, with more than 22 million young people and children weighing above average as a result of excessive consumption of processed food, high in sugars, fats and other additives and, in addition, a sedentary lifestyle. The continued decline in the consumption of fruit, vegetables and dairy products among young people has led the Commission to review and include in a common framework the two separate schemes for the distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools. I believe that initiatives to promote the consumption of healthy foods should not be limited to educational institutions alone. Family and teachers are key factors that play an important role in promoting a balanced diet. The main objective of the new regulation is to convince young people that fruit and milk contribute to their health and harmonious growth. On the other hand, in order to bring young people closer to nature, it is important that they know where these foods come from. In this context, I strongly support the conduct of campaigns to promote regional and seasonal agricultural products, primarily because it supports local agricultural producers, but also because actions contribute to the formation of healthy eating habits.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The programme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools is being confirmed (with some improvements in the criteria for the distribution of funds) and, within it, the exclusive budget for milk is slightly increased. Although we remain sceptical (as in the past) about the operational application of the instrument, while acknowledging the importance of the spread of food education in schools, in the face of the worst price crisis for major agricultural products, this small budget could also be a positive sign.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it particularly important to implement the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational institutions, because the target group targeted by this project, children aged 6 to 10, must benefit from healthy and fresh food, which is significant in their growth and development. For the proper functioning of this project, it is extremely important to identify and analyse the needs and costs, from the purchase to the supply of schools, so that every school, especially those in less-favoured areas, benefits from the necessary quantity, without being wasted. This whole system, starting with analysing the problem, continuing with the selection of food and ending with the correct supply of educational institutions, will lead the target population to a healthy life by building a balanced diet from an early age.  The application of this Regulation shall seek the cooperation of the Member States to reduce the number of cases of childhood obesity and increase the immune system of children, with the help of nutrition experts and farmers. The supply of disadvantaged regions by those with high production potential is an important step towards ensuring the growth of children in a healthy environment, conducive to our future generations and a viable and strong population.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. A healthy diet is balanced and is necessary to combat the risks of obesity and other diseases linked to poor eating habits. Educating children, from an early age, to consume beneficial products can also be done at school. Programmes to promote "milk in school" and "fruit and vegetables in school" serve this purpose. These two previously separate programmes will now be brought together within the same structure. This will simplify administrative procedures and optimize the effectiveness of both programs. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report to strengthen the programme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables and milk in schools. This is an important report, focusing on food education, for which Parliament has obtained a total budget of EUR 250 million. Parliament has ensured that European funds are distributed more fairly among the Member States, setting two new key criteria for the implementation of the whole programme: the number of children aged between 6 and 10 in the Member State concerned and the degree of development of the regions within the Member State, so as to ensure that the largest aid is allocated to the less developed regions. A healthy and balanced diet is the foundation of good health, but unfortunately the consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk is declining in the EU. It is therefore essential to support this programme in order to counteract the current decline in the consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and dairy products, especially among children, and, at the same time, to put an end to the increase in the incidence of childhood obesity due to consumption habits oriented towards highly processed food products, which moreover often contain high doses of added sugars, salt, fats or additives.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ We do want school-children to be well nourished, but we opposed this because, even if you think taxpayers should contribute, these things should not be done centrally by Brussels.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the scheme as I am quite concerned at the alarming decline of the consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk products among the young people as well as the high levels of child obesity in the EU. I welcome the proposal to use the EU funds to finance the distribution of fresh fruit and vegetables as well as milk and other dairy products, including lactose-free, in schools. I believe that that this should be accompanied by formal education in order to teach young people about the impact the choice of food has on our bodies and general well-being and the impact of its cultivation on the environment. I agree that healthy eating habits should be encouraged from the earliest age.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The increase in the incidence of childhood obesity is partly due to eating habits oriented towards food products with high doses of added sugars, salt, fats or additives. EU aid to fund the distribution of agricultural products to children in schools will further promote healthy eating habits and the consumption of local products. I voted in favour.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to state first, that I am absolutely in favour of children having a healthy and balanced alimentation, including during their school time. However, I cannot support the legislative report as proposed by the rapporteur because I believe there are several problematic points in it. I do not see a case for such a strong, EU—sponsored and subsidized scheme, imposing on Member States the supply of fruit, vegetables and milk for children. I am convinced that any scheme like this should be promoted and managed mainly on the Member State level, taking into account the specificities of local educational establishments and local agriculture production. Any general, EU level, scheme does not, in my view, seem to fit the purpose.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome today’s vote in Parliament to provide schools with fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk, across the EU. This programme helps us promote the consumption of healthy food in schools and also change the food eating habits of our future generations.  From August 2017, schools will have to prioritise the distribution of fresh food over processed food. Added sweeteners and artificial flavour enhancers will also be totally banned from the products distributed under the school schemes for the first time.  Products containing added sugar, salt and fat will, as a general rule, be prohibited and would only be allowed after being authorised by national health authorities. Furthermore, limits of salt, sugar and fat will be defined at EU level by the Commission via a delegated act. In Ireland, one in four children is overweight or obese. If we do not start changing habits now, we will be faced with even bigger costs in the health system due to increased numbers of patients suffering from diabetes, diseases, cancer and a vast range of other conditions associated with obesity and poor dietary habits. There is an increasing need to restrict sugar and unhealthy fat intake. This will help our younger generations live healthier and longer lives.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 After a legislative process that lasted almost two years, Parliament approved the agreement reached in the trialogue last December on the regulation unifying the two previous regulations establishing the "School Milk" and "Fruit in Schools" programmes. Over the years, these programmes have reached some 30 million children throughout Europe. Guiding eating habits from childhood helps to develop greater awareness towards balanced nutrition and prevent obesity. Although the two programmes had the same aim - the promotion of healthy eating and the increase in the consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk by children , they were nevertheless regulated by different legal and financial frameworks which helped to make the administrative burden on local and national authorities excessive. The new regulation aims to streamline the administrative and financial procedures provided for in the previous ones and introduces an interesting novelty aimed at children: they will have the opportunity to come into contact with those who produce food and to deal with different types of products. In this way they will learn to make a conscious choice and to have more direct contact with nature. I voted in favour of this regulation, sharing its purpose and simplification, which will allow it to be implemented more widely.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress that in the current context of continuous reduction of consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and dairy products, in particular by children, and the increasing incidence of childhood obesity due to consumer habits geared towards highly processed foods, the granting of parish aid to finance the provision of selected agricultural products to children attending educational institutions can help to promote healthy eating habits and consumption of local products.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's vote on the report amending Regulation No 136/66/EEC on the application of Articles 87 and 88 of the EC Treaty to the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 December 2002 on This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. 1306/2013 as regards the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments comes at a crucial time for Europe and especially for certain regions which continue to be affected by the economic crisis. I believe that we must support any action aimed at protecting and improving the conditions for supplying educational institutions, thus helping children across Europe to feed more quality. I have therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is an important response by Parliament to the decline in the consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk, especially among children, and also to the increase in childhood obesity due to poor food education. In fact, the Commission proposes in this document to concentrate the distribution of these products in schools by educating children on the environment and public health with the aim of strengthening their link with agriculture. In my opinion, in fact, the proposal goes much further: in a world in which industry is asking the state to steer food choices in a direction that is considered desirable, I welcome these initiatives which aim to teach children the value of a varied and balanced diet, in line with their personal needs. There are no good foods and bad foods, but rather use and abuse, and individual needs dependent on multiple factors and within which the supply of nutrients must be diversified. Congratulations to Mr Tarabella on his work in the trialogues.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Action must be taken on the declining consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and milk products amongst children. Childhood obesity is increasing due to the consumption of food with high sugar, salt and fat levels. It is necessary to ensure healthy eating habits within educational establishments, along with promoting the consumption of local products. The financial stability of this scheme must be protected by ensuring Member States cannot unilaterally cut the budget or alter the criteria for the allocation of EU funds. Healthy eating standards can be promoted by educating children on local food, eating habits and organic farming, along with the challenges of food waste. The scheme must give priority to under-consumed fresh and local products to ensure maximum benefit to participants. The scheme will exclude foods with artificial flavours and added sweeteners, any foods with limited amounts of added sugar, salt and fat will receive funding as an exception pending the approval of national health authorities.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ We do want school-children to be well nourished, but we opposed this because, even if you think taxpayers should contribute, these things should not be done centrally by Brussels.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the European Parliament's position for the opening of interinstitutional negotiations on the Regulation on aid schemefor the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments, I am once again supporting the new scheme approved today, which comes together in a single framework two programmes aimed at schools that were separated: the fruit and milk distribution scheme , with a budget of EUR 250 million per school year. This simplifies the administrative procedures of the two programmes and reduces the management and organisation burden for national authorities, schools and suppliers. I applaud the educational aspect of the Programme which encourages young people to have healthy drinking habits by bringing them closer to agriculture and educating them for the origin of food, as well as the eur 20 million increase for the milk programme achieved in the negotiations.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We do want school-children to be well—nourished, but we opposed this because, even if you think taxpayers should contribute, these things should not be done centrally by Brussels.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of this proposal as it is an initiative to include in a common framework two currently separate systems for the distribution of fruit and milk in schools.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ As legislators we should reduce red tape which deters schools from participating, especially so that schools seeking to participate in both programmes should not be obliged to fill out two separate sets of forms or be subject to a variety of monitoring procedures. I concur that Member States should be left to decide and put in their strategy which fresh products should be distributed (and how) insofar as these promote healthy eating habits, including among children; ensure that their authorities responsible for nutrition and/or health agree carry out the necessary nutritional enforcement and that EU funding supplements, not replaces, national financing. Let us make best use of this scheme not to just increase awareness about healthy nutrition from an early age but also to heighten the visibility of European Union aid amongst our families.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement respects Parliament's three red lines on the legal basis. From the outset of the negotiations, the European Parliament made it clear that there would be no agreement without codecision in the following areas: on the budget it was decided that the Council cannot unilaterally cut the financing of the two systems in the future; with regard to the criteria for allocating the budget among the Member States, the objective criteria will apply both for the school fruit scheme and for the milk scheme, for which there are also historical criteria and a breakdown based on the minimum amount of aid per child, in order to ensure a fairer distribution between the Member States. On the possibility for Member States to transfer a certain percentage of funds between budget packages, the Presidency has decided to include the percentage in the basic act. With regard to the list of products to be distributed, the text now clarifies, at Parliament's request, that The Member States give priority to the distribution of fresh products over those treated, in order to encourage healthier eating habits among children. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because this is an important and necessary programme. I agree with much of the improvements made by Parliament, such as distributed foods having restrictions on the content of added sugars, salts, sweeteners and fats, as well as some flavor enhancers. Other important elements contained in the report are accompanying educational measures and the fact that Member States can give priority to sustainability and fair trade considerations.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Children in the EU should soon benefit from better funded school schemes for milk, fruit and vegetables, along with better lessons on healthy eating. I voted for separate milk and fruit schemes in the EU to be combined and for the annual budget of the new scheme to increase by EUR 20 million to EUR 250 million per year. Thus, the annual funding for milk will be EUR 100 million and that for fruit and vegetables will be EUR 150 million. A healthy, balanced diet is the basis for health. Unfortunately, there has been a downward trend in EU consumption in schools, particularly of fresh fruit and vegetables, but also of milk. That is why it is very important to strengthen the fruit, vegetable and milk scheme in schools by increasing the budget and focusing more on healthy eating education. With this vote, Parliament also ensured the financial stability of the programme, preventing Member States from unilaterally cutting the budget or changing the criteria for allocating EU funds between them.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Due to inadequate consumption patterns, the number of morbidly obese children is increasing, so it is of the utmost importance to continue and strengthen these two school programmes. Participating Member States and regions should be able to decide, in accordance with their own strategies, whether they wish to allocate the full range of products to children in educational establishments, or only one of them. In order to follow dietary recommendations on calcium intake and in view of the increase in problems with intolerance to lactose in milk, Member States should also be able to allocate other dairy products, such as yoghurt and cheese, which have a positive impact on children's health. The aid shall not exceed EUR 250 million per school year, in the following distribution: EUR 150 million for fruit and vegetables and EUR 100 million for school milk. The allocation of grants shall take into account the number of children aged 6-10 years living in that Member State and the level of development of the regions of the Member States. Member States wishing to participate in the allocation of eligible products shall submit an application for Union aid each year. This is a very good and important programme, and I would stress that the programme should ensure adequate participation and support for all applicant Member States.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 There are currently two separate EU-funded grant schemes – the School Milk Programme and the School Fruit Programme. Participation in the programmes is voluntary. The Commission has proposed to include these two programmes in a common legal framework. This is to increase their efficiency, reduce the administrative burden and improve overall performance. The agreement reached corresponds to the EP's position on the budget: EUR 150 million per year for the School Fruit Programme and EUR 100 million for the School Milk Programme (i.e. EUR 20 million in addition to the Commission proposal). The list of products covered by these programmes has been significantly expanded. In addition to fresh products, Member States will be able to distribute other low-processed dairy products, such as natural yogurt and cheese. As for processed fruit and vegetables and other dairy products such as fruit yoghurts and chocolate milk, they were included in the scheme under additional conditions. In view of the objectives of the programmes, I voted IN FAVOUR.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which focuses on merging the school milk programme and the fruit and vegetable scheme for schools into a single programme. It is an important step forward in ensuring a more efficient use of schemes which ensures that the necessary measures to promote healthy and fresh food in our educational institutions are being implemented. I believe that this is necessary to further contribute to the current obesity problem in the European Union Member States. It is important to have safeguards in place, specifically regarding processed foods, added sweeteners, artificial flavours and other additives such as sugar and salt. We need to make sure that children have healthy eating habits and this can take place through educational measures which are listed in the report.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this scheme, ultimately because it is my belief that promoting healthy eating is something which should be done at the national level, not by the EU. As a passionate advocate of healthy eating and living for young people, schemes to promote these ends are much more financially effective if delivered by national, regional and local governments. Whilst the UK does not currently participate in the EU School Fruit Scheme, it does promote healthy eating in school-age children through its own national initiatives which provide more fruit than the EU schemes offer. The scheme itself also has serious issues, with an average yearly underspend of €10 million. It is my view that it would therefore be financially imprudent to support a budget increase of €20 million when the existing budget is not adequately spent. I note that the EU’s Court of Auditors has repeatedly criticised this scheme for its inefficiency and poor value, and the new scheme is unlikely to deliver better.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. \u2012 Consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk is declining across Europe; 22 million European children are overweight and adolescents eat on average only 30% to 50% of the recommended daily intake of fruits and vegetables. Given these alarming statistics, I believe it is essential to encourage healthy eating habits from an early age and to bring young consumers into contact with local producers. Of course, in this regulation, products with the addition of cocoa will also benefit from EU funding, but the Eu ropean Union will only pay for the percentage of milk contained in them, which will in any case represent the majority. Priority will be given to local and regional production, short supply chains, organic products and quality products, such as olive oil, which undersea a healthy Mediterranean diet. By increasing the availability of fruit and vegetables, the regulation can help build good habits and increase children's well-being while promoting health and at the same time helping the fruit and vegetable sector. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this regulation and I hope that the school programme that will result from it will also be widely requested by our Italian institutes.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report aims to reform and merge the two European programmes on the distribution of milk and fruit and vegetables in schools, funded under the Common Organisation for Agricultural Markets (CMO). This is an important report in many respects.  On form first, the European Parliament has obtained to be co-legislator with the Council on the essential points of the text (budget, financial allocation criteria, financial transfers) under Article 43, paragraph 2, of the FUE Treaty.  Secondly, at a time when the risks of obesity are increasing in Europe, these programmes will enable them to promote healthy eating among the youngest populations. In addition, while the fruit and vegetable sector and the dairy market are currently in difficulty, these programmes will mobilise EUR 250 million per year within the framework of the Joint Organisation of Agricultural Markets.  Considering that this agreement also preserves France's envelope in the framework of the appropriations for dairy products, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. As an MEP but also mayor of the 7th arrondissement of Paris, I know how important a regular distribution of fruit, vegetables and dairy products is for children's food balance. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which aims to contribute to the promotion of healthy eating habits as well as the consumption of local products in school canteens.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure which will bring more funding and give new impetus to food education policies in schools. Fruit, vegetables and milk are essential products for the healthy growth and development of children and must therefore be more consumed food in all European Schools. Consuming these products at least once a day helps you live healthier and longer. In addition to the source of vitamins, fiber and mineral salts, they lower the risk of obesity and prevent the onset of certain types of cancer. It is therefore appropriate to accustom the little ones to introduce these valuable allies into their diet.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Adopting good eating habits begins in childhood. This is the main theme of the regulation on the scheme to help distribute fruits and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools, which was voted on by the European Parliament. This regulation, which aims to mobilise EUR 250 million per year to provide fruit, vegetables and dairy products to students, while supporting our farmers, will also focus on the educational dimension of nutrition.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. The Tarabella report aims to reform and merge the two programmes relating to the distribution of milk and fruit in schools, funded as part of the common organisation of agricultural markets. In view of the decline in the consumption of fruit, vegetables and dairy products among young people, I voted in favour of this report.  Indeed, the reunification of these programmes will encourage the consumption, in schools, of healthy products with a priority given to local and seasonal products, while taking into account regional eating habits. Thus, Member States will have to prioritise the distribution of fresh and local products over processed products with the aim of encouraging healthy eating habits. Finally, I welcome the fact that this initiative comes from the French fruit and vegetable sector.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Most of the Amendments tabled by the Hungarian People's Party to this report have been included in the report adopted by the European Parliament. As a result, Parliament calls on the European Commission to take account of the accelerated payment needs for cohesion investments at the planning stage and to raise funds to the necessary level. It is important that the Commission already anticipates in its draft budget the accelerated implementation of regional development programmes in the Member States, thereby increasing cohesion resources proportionately. In 2017, our aim is for the European Commission to fully pay the bills generated by the projects already carried out in the Member States. The European Parliament takes the view that the 2017 budget should also ensure that funds mobilised to deal with the migration crisis are not taken at the expense of other EU programmes already in place. This proposal protects cohesion and agricultural funds when determining resources to deal with the migration crisis. The European Parliament's resolution underlines the importance of school milk and fruit schemes. On our proposal, the European Commission should examine how EU funds to finance these programmes can be raised in the 2017 budget. We have flatly rejected the socialist initiative, which hypocritically, on the grounds of 'solidarity', wants to penalise Member States that reject plans for compulsory resettlement of migrants by means of EU budgetary instruments. We know that the Socialists aim to deprive these Member States of cohesion funds!

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. 'I support the agreement on a new school scheme for milk and fruit for the following reasons: the number of overweight or obese children is still increasing every year. In Flanders, 1 in 5 young people is overweight; the 5 to 9 age group is of the uigh. This obviously has several causes, but too few fruits and vegetables is an important factor in this story. Encouraging healthy food from childhood is absolutely necessary and the school scheme can make a valuable contribution!  Secondly, I support the reform because it seeks to increase the efficiency and effectiveness of the scheme, reduce red tape and thus lower the threshold for schools to participate. Finally, I also see an economic argument, namely that most of the products concerned are produced by local or regional producers. This agreement is a step in the right direction, but of course only part of a larger puzzle. Encouraging a healthy lifestyle, particularly in children, requires a long-term structural and integrated approach with a crucial role for the competent authorities in the Member States.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is coming to the end of its legislative journey, during which Parliament has weighed in with all its weight - I took part in it as rapporteur for the opinion of the 2016 budget - to increase the financial envelopes concerned (particularly that of milk, important in terms of opportunities in the context of the agricultural crisis , which increases from 100 to 120 million euros) and the allocation of budgetary envelopes between Member States (the distribution criteria will take into account the share of children aged six to ten in the population and the degree of development of the region within the Member State). We also objected, for health reasons, to attempts to introduce the possibility of distributing processed products in which sugar, salt, fats, sweeteners or artificial flavours were added. Finally, this programme is backed by the obligation to introduce the promotion of healthy eating habits, short circuits, organic farming and the fight against waste.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I supported this report because statistics show that fruit, vegetable and milk consumption continues to fall in Europe, that more than 20 million European children are overweight and that our teenagers consume on average only 30-50% of the recommended daily intake of fruits and vegetables. A healthy and balanced diet is the foundation of good health.  That is why I support any initiative to strengthen the school fruit, vegetable and milk diet by focusing more on healthy eating education. Moreover, considering that the programmes for milk and fruit in schools have so far operated under different legal and financial provisions, I consider it necessary to ensure the stability of the programme.  I welcome the additional EUR 20 million per year negotiated by Parliament to finance the distribution of dairy products and the implementation of educational measures. This brings the annual funding for milk to 100 million euros, while 150 million euros are allocated to fruits and vegetables.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In the Czech Republic, the "school milk" programme has been in place since 1999. Currently, about 3,100 schools, including kindergartens, elementary and secondary schools, are involved in the program. Milk and milk products are supported in part by the EU, from national sources and part of the price is paid by the parents of the children involved in the programme. "Fruit and vegetables for schools" is a younger project, it has been running in the Czech Republic since 2010 (in the EU since 2007). From the outset, an educational element has been incorporated into the project, a national strategy has been developed and the possibility of financing accompanying measures is added. As far as the administrative burden is concerned, suppliers, not schools, are asking for support, so the administrative and organisational burden for schools is minimal. I am very much in support of both projects and consider them important especially from the point of view of children's eating habits. However, I do not agree with the adaptation of fruit and milk programmes to schools at EU level. I believe that this is a national competence and the principle of subsidiarity should be respected. I see no reason for this issue to be decided at European level.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This program organizes the distribution of fruits, vegetables and dairy products in schools. It also gives Member States freedom over how to apply, for example by promoting local products, or by defending regional or national food patriotism. As the sovereignty of states is respected, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Protecting the health of the future generation, along with reducing the administrative burden, is something I can't help but support.  On the one hand, children in infancy need to be taught to eat healthy foods, such as fruits and dairy products. Also important is the fact that attention is paid to the fact that many young children are allergic to lactose, and dairy products with reduced or no content of this product are offered.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Positive, because it is important to provide fruit and vegetables and milk in schools and especially now that the economic crisis, especially in southern Europe, does not allow children to be properly ed. Also, particular emphasis should be placed on remote areas where some of the products can be produced.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 School milk and fruit schemes play an important role in the EU's common agricultural policy. On the one hand, they contribute to the decondishing of surplus produce that may accumulate on certain agricultural product pathways and, on the other hand, they perform a significant social task: each child has access to healthy milk or dairy products and fruit at least once a day in the context of school meals. Currently, EU support for co-financed programmes is EUR 100 million per year for school milk and EUR 150 million for school fruit. I don't think that amount is sufficient. We are therefore fighting with our fellow Members of the European People's Party to increase the EU budget for the programmes. We had our first success. With the amendment tabled jointly with my fellow Member Tamás Deutsch, a request to the European Commission to this end was incorporated into the parliament's report on the EU budget for 2017, voted on in the EP's Committee on Budgets.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 The bill aims to bring together the EU's school milk and fruit programmes into a common programme. In addition, in connection with the merger of the programmes, additional products in addition to fresh milk have been added. It is commendable to simplify legislation, but I believe that it is not a European competence to be responsible for school milk and school fruit. Here, the Member States must be responsible. Given this, I have chosen to vote against the report as a whole.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Overweight affects 22 million children in the EU. Adolescents consume, on average, only 30% to 50% of the recommended daily dose of fruit and vegetables. Many children grow up without knowing where the food they eat, where and how they are produced and what seasonal products are, according to data reported by the Commission. In 2013/14, around 10 million children in the EU benefited from the fruit distribution programme and 19 million from the milk programme. The report, which I voted in favour of, provides for a budget for fruit and vegetables of EUR 150 million and for school milk of EUR 100 million per school year. The new rules aim to promote healthy eating from an early age, strengthen the educational component of programmes and bring children closer to local products.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted for it during this deliberation, because I am in favour of the distribution assistance program.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 Young people need to be educated about healthy, responsible and sustainable eating, introducing sustainability, seasonality, zero km, as well as ethical criteria in the selection of products that must be without additives. That is why, as M5S, we are very pleased with the agreement reached in the trialogue on the dossier on the financing of the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools. We are very pleased both with the results achieved in financial terms and with the affirmation of the principle that we must commit ourselves to educating young people to consume fresh products, excluding as much as possible the use of added sugars and salts, and subject to strict controls by the national authorities. Education in a healthy and balanced way of life will undoubtedly have positive effects both for the health of young European citizens and for the sustainability of the consumption choices they make throughout their lives. For all these reasons, I am voting in favour of this legislative resolution.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 It is good that the total amount and figures for the two envelopes (fruit and milk) have been included in the basic act, ensuring that the Council cannot unilaterally cut funding for these programmes in the future. Even so, the amount will not be sufficient for this programme to meet the requirements of the need to encourage the consumption of these products at school ages and facilitate access to them without economic restrictions. On the criteria for allocating the budget between Member States, the additional 20 million decided for the milk programme should ensure that no Member State will lose as a result of the introduction of those criteria. Member States should give priority to the distribution of fresh products to the detriment of processed products in order to encourage healthy eating habits among children. As these schemes are all positive, the embezzlement of funds for advertising purposes (notably EU promotion) is critical. Despite efforts to increase consumption, it is a fact that the trends of declining consumption of these products have not yet been reversed, and therefore the existence of the two school schemes is valid. Unfortunately, many of the amendments we have proposed have been sinkered. These schemes could be improved, especially in the areas of promotion of local and traditional products.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the Regulation on the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools because I believe that it is essential to boost the consumption of fruit and dairy products because of their beneficial health characteristics. In addition, they are sectors of great importance for European agriculture and for the European children to acquire healthier eating habits.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that the promotion of healthy eating habits and the consumption of local products contribute effectively to combating the phenomenon of childhood obesity, which is becoming increasingly a problem within the Member States. The continuation and strengthening of the programmes covered by the report, together with the Commission's decision to bring the two programmes together under a joint legal framework, helps to make them more effective, to reduce administrative burdens and to improve overall results. Finally, I welcome, with a view to diversifying and enhancing local products, the extension of the list of products covered by the programmes which may be distributed in the Member States.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained as I believe it is ridiculous to deal with this at EU level.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ In practice, the European Union's programmes in question to combat the increasing obesity and eating habits of children have been shown to be well set up and beneficial, and it is therefore important that they continue and that children in all schools in all Member States feel their benefits. We must work together to change children's habits, because at the moment highly processed foods are preferred, which are often high in added sugar, salt, fat or additives, which is not good for the healthy development of school-age children. Member States must make greater efforts and put in place measures that begin to address specific problems in children's eating habits. However, the European Commission will have to work to make the programme more visible.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report for continued support for food education in schools.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report because it is important to provide fruit and vegetables and milk to schools, and especially now that the economic crisis, especially in southern Europe, does not allow proper nutrition for children. Also, special weight to be given to remote areas where some of the products can be produced.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I believe this report is absolutely necessary to ensure that the schemes, in future, will prioritise healthy, fresh, unprocessed and local foods as much as possible both in the main scheme and in accompanying educational measures and will also be visible as EU actions. Concerning the list of products to be distributed, the text now makes clear, at the request of Parliament, that the Member States shall prioritise the distribution of fresh products over processed ones with a view to encouraging healthier eating habits among children.  I believe the future of the school schemes is assured by this text. Management will now be more efficient through a single, visible programme with the milk part operating in parallel with the fruit and vegetable strand. We will therefore be able to promote consumption of healthy, fresh foods by schoolchildren, helping them establish healthy eating habits – especially important when we are facing an epidemic of obesity.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: in writing. – I voted for the adoption of this report as it aims to build healthy eating habits among children from an early age by increasing the consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables, milk and dairy products in educational establishments.
