The proposal for a regulation is of the utmost importance as it achieves the consolidation, continuation and strengthening of school fruit and vegetable, banana and milk schemes. I welcome the fact that the European Parliament's efforts have led to an increase in the new annual budget by 20 million euro. and thus reach up to EUR 250 million. European. I thank my colleagues for the broad support my proposal received for the inclusion in both school schemes of traditional and local products with a proven positive effect on children's health, such as honey, yogurt and cheese. New schemes will provide Member States with an additional tool to stimulate local production, organic products and short supply chains. To ensure the effectiveness of the scheme, national strategies on accompanying educational measures are envisaged.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the firm will to continue working on this line. Food programmes focused on the little ones should be the top priority as we raise awareness among future generations of the importance of consuming fresh products such as fruits, vegetables and milk, the health benefits these products have, the importance of a balanced diet and the risks of obesity.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The approval of the allocation increases of over EUR 20 million to continue the European school fruit programme marks an important step that will allow the successful continuation of the initiative to raise awareness of the consumption of fresh and seasonal fruits and vegetables aimed at children between 6 and 11 years of age. Lifestyle as prevention proves to be effective when it started at an early age. With the adoption of this amendment, we are sending a signal in terms of food education but also a breath of oxygen to the fruit and vegetable sector, which has been seriously put in difficulty by the sharp fall in prices.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. – Fruits, milk and vegetables for a food re-education of the little ones. Europe invests in children's health by activating itself through economic programmes and information and promotion campaigns for fresh and healthy food, by promoting new training in child nutrition.  These are the priorities highlighted in the report on the regulation which Mr Tarabella and Mr De Castro have brought to the vote in Parliament and which I strongly support.  Improving food education means combating the growing phenomenon of childhood obesity and related diseases, and thus committing ourselves to the well-being, health and future of our children.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Parliament and the Council on the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools, because I believe that the renewal and extension of the same is a tangible sign of the benefits that the EU brings to our citizens and territories. I am proud that Parliament has requested and obtained support for food education programmes in schools, secureing an officially confirmed budget of EUR 250 million to support the programmes that the Member States are called upon to implement in the near future, to promote the consumption of milk and milk products as well as fruit among primary school children. Promote correct food styles, referring to our traditions and at the same time supporting the business system of fruit and vegetables and dairy: the school broadens its educational horizons thus educating the little ones to become responsible consumers, favoring safe and healthy foods of our tradition. I also consider this to be an important vote inso far as the European Parliament has reaffirmed its competence in agricultural matters in the interinstitutional negotiations, strengthening its role in defending the interests of EU citizens.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational institutions, because both programmes have already been successfully run in many German schools and are benefiting from agriculture and local trade. By summarising and simplifying the programmes, the EU is sending out an important signal!

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I support Union aid for the transfer of agricultural products to educational institutions. This is a contribution to the promotion of healthy eating, but also to the consumption of local products.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ We do want school-children to be well nourished, but we opposed this because, even if you think taxpayers should contribute, these things should not be done centrally by Brussels.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. Supporting some agricultural production, even in a modest way given the amounts involved, while allowing children to consume generally healthy products is a good idea. In addition, the European Parliament has, for once, made improvements to the text: promotion of local and regional products, greater latitude of member states to implement the programme by adapting it to their specific needs and conditions, the possibility of extending this same programme to locally important products and recognised nutritional qualities... Two points, however: firstly, the excessive compulsory publicity given to the role of the European Union, which shows only a very relative enthusiasm for these programmes, which owe their existence above all to the insistence of Parliament and some Member States; secondly, the focus on the "educational" objective of these same programmes, when it is unfortunately all too often to allow children to eat food that their parents cannot afford. That will not prevent me from supporting a text that is going in the right direction.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report for the restructuring of aid schemes for the consumption of fruit and vegetables and bananas and milk in schools, as these have a very positive impact on society inso as they promote healthy eating at an early age and seek to establish direct links between the two ends of the food chain , producer and consumer, enhancing the local primary sector. In addition, two productive sectors – dairy and fruit and vegetable – are indirectly promoted, representing approximately 30% of the Union's agricultural production.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the report on the State aid scheme for the supply of fruit, vegetables and milk to educational institutions, because I consider it essential that the EU and the Member States are concerned about children's health. In the context of declining consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables, the report is also important because it promotes the habits of healthy eating and consumption of local products.  I appreciate the report because it allows Member States to include other local, national, regional specialties such as honey, table olives and processed vegetables without added sugar, salt, fats, sweeteners or flavourings. The proposed 6-year programme allows Member States to provide children with a healthy way of eating at all times, together with a healthy nutrition education.  It is important that Member States' programmes are monitored and an evaluation of the results achieved is carried out.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement. As the risks of obesity continue to rise in Europe, promoting healthy eating is a key issue for younger populations. Children need to get used to eating healthily as soon as they start school. This programme will mobilise 250 million euros per year within the framework of the common organisation of agricultural markets. This will be good news for our farmers, however modest, who are in such a serious crisis at the moment.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. Only 36% of Europeans eat the 5 fruits and vegetables a day recommended as part of a healthy and balanced diet and one in three European children is now overweight and obese. That is why I voted in favour of the adoption of the report by MEP Marc Tarabella, which proposes a strengthening of the scheme to support the free distribution of fresh fruit, vegetables and milk to the 30 million children aged 6 to 10 in schools in all European countries throughout the year.  Thanks to the proposals in this report, for which a budget of 270 million euros has been secured with European governments, fresh products will be offered to children from an early age, with an educational approach to food, which will help to combat obesity. The programme will also promote and promote short circuits and local, regional, seasonal or organically produced products and support small farmers and the dairy sector. It will also help fight waste.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the adoption of this regulation, because it will promote healthy eating habits in schools, which is of tremendous importance for Europe’s youth. This will also make distribution easier and relieve the burden on schools themselves, who might not have the best resources to provide fresh local produce. Additionally, the addition of milk products to the proposal will be of great service to children who have problems with milk. These products can also provide children with necessary calcium.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats in the European Parliament have long had a negative attitude towards European market measures for agricultural products, which has been evident when we voted on related items in the budget.  We still believe that the distribution of agricultural products and milk m.m. should not be a European issue and have not changed our fundamental approach to this.  On the other hand, since the regulation deals with the merger of several programmes, which are already in place, for lower administrative burden and simplification, we have supported improved criteria for the programme.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the objectives of the programme are commendable, these objectives tend to be neutralised in a series of articles requiring the diversion of funds from the distribution of fruit and vegetables for advertising purposes. For example, Article 23 (8) requires schools to make public their participation in the system and the fact that it is subsidised by the EU. Although Article 23a (8) states that Member States may use any appropriate communication tools they wish (websites, graphic posters, campaigns), Articles 24 and 25 allow the Commission to adopt delegated acts which require schools to implement such actions. We believe that this creates an incomplete process of using funds for a system that is already in operation and we have therefore voted to abstain.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal that sees the merger of the school milk scheme (SMS) with the School Fruit and Vegetables Scheme. This proposal should promote consumption of these products among school children, and help educate children on healthy eating habits. Statistics show that children are eating less and less fresh fruit, drinking less milk and eating more and more processed food. That is considered one of the causes of obesity amongst children. Previously this Parliament voted to reject 30%-sugar-content baby food for the same reason. In order to improve this situation this proposal merges both the school fruit and milk scheme under the same legislative framework, thus trying to make it more ‘user friendly’ for Member States and lower the administrative burden. Furthermore, it also adds an educational dimension to the scheme where children will have to be introduced to agricultural issues, nutrition/health and environmental issues.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe it represents a fair outcome to the inter-institutional trilogues held in 2015. The main issues in this regulation of the legal basis, scope and allocation criteria have been addressed fairly and I think it will be important that we have a new combined school scheme commencing in August 2017.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The report deals with the existing school milk and fruit programmes, which finance dairy products and fruit under the European Agricultural Policy and distribute them to schools. The report aims to extend the programmes and increase the total budget to EUR 250 million per year. As a family-friendly party, ALFA supports healthy child nutrition. However, in line with the principle of subsidiarity, ALFA sees no reason for children's nutrition programmes to be funded and regulated by the EU. According to the report, the taxpayer first pays into the EU budget, then the EU Commission decides which products can be extracted from which ingredients in order to transfer the tax revenue back to the Member States later, i.e. to finance the food programmes from EU funds. If the Länder and individual municipalities believe that such programmes are needed, they could make this much more effective without having to co-finance the EU apparatus. Personally, I firmly believe that it is above all the responsibility of parents to take care of their children's nutrition, and that parents do not need eu training. I have therefore rejected the above-mentioned report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. – We do want school-children to be well nourished, but we opposed this because, even if you think taxpayers should contribute, these things should not be done centrally by Brussels.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's support for the scheme to help distribute fruit and vegetables and milk and dairy products in schools. These two programmes serve two objectives: on the one hand, they help to combat obesity, which is a worrying phenomenon since the WTO, in a study published in 2015, has revealed that Europe could face an epidemic by 2030; on the other hand, they support the activities of farmers and farmers, who are severely affected by the crisis in their sector. Obesity is far from an epiphenomenon. Fighting it through the education of children and making them aware of the risks to their health is a good step. Finally, I welcome the mobilization of 250 million euros per year to promote these programmes and note with satisfaction that the envelope for France has been preserved.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ A healthy start to life is essential and schools play a valuable role in encouraging our youngsters to eat healthily. The EU has done valuable work in this area over the years and I was therefore happy to support this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The report reiterates that products distributed under this educational school program should not contain added sugar, salt, fat, artificial flavour enhancers or sweeteners, and should contribute to the physical and psychological wellbeing of children and combating child obesity. A trend has been identified in the consumption decline of fruit and vegetables and milk consumption among children, thus their distribution in all programs schools is important in combating child obesity and promotes healthy eating habits, this being the reason I have voted for this report.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Writing. I welcome the decision we have taken today. The programme fulfils an educational function by promoting the development of good eating and eating habits that will be maintained throughout their lives. I am very pleased with this regulation, as I am particularly concerned about the healthy diet of young people. The European Commission should seize the opportunity to implement the new programme as user-friendly and as unbureaucratic as possible.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 2012/2013; 1308/2013 and Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013. 1306/2013 as regards support schemes for the delivery of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments as children eat less and less fresh fruit and drink milk, while consumption of processed foods increases. In this context, I think it is extremely important to include regional and local food products in school meals, and to better educate young people about health and healthy eating. This introduces young people, from an early age, to the traditional food products of their regions, and reduces the risk of obesity and other diseases.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Parliament's position was therefore formed on a global consensus among the different political factions. And for good reason, this programme is a good measure: it organises the distribution of fruits and vegetables, bananas and dairy products in schools. Above all, this text gives Member States the freedom to implement this programme in the way they wish. Member States therefore remain in control of their sovereignty over the subject and can thus promote the use of local products, and engage in a form of national and/or regional food patriotism. I therefore voted in favour of this amendment, which conditions the final vote with which I also agree.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We do want school-children to be well—nourished, but we opposed this because, even if you think taxpayers should contribute, these things should not be done centrally by Brussels.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal aims to establish a common legal and financial framework for the distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk to children in schools. The "Milk for Schools" programme in the Czech Republic is already working successfully and, given the increasing incidence of childhood obesity due to poor eating habits, I believe that it is important to also get fruit and vegetables into schools in order to strengthen the healthy diet of children as young as possible. Indeed, the very promotion of healthy eating and the focus of education on the importance of agriculture, health and the environment now play a big role.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Marc Tarabella's report on the scheme to help distribute fruits and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools. The aim is to merge two programmes, funded under the Joint Organisation of Agricultural Markets, relating to the distribution of milk in schools on the one hand and fruit and vegetables on the other. Additional educational measures will be implemented to highlight the role of agriculture and to focus on practices that promote health and the environment. In addition, the European Parliament has managed to be recognised as a co-legislator for the budget of these two programmes. It will now be able to better defend the health of young citizens by raising their awareness of agricultural issues.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. The report on aid in the distribution of fruits and vegetables aims to create a common legal basis for fruit distribution in schools and for aid in the distribution of milk. This will enable us to strengthen the distribution of these European agricultural foods in our schools and thus to advocate for healthier eating among young people, while supporting economic sectors currently struggling in Europe.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Obesity and overweight among school children is an epidemic of economically highly developed countries nowadays. It is spreading at an ever-increasing rate and reaches younger and younger people. Bad eating habits acquired in childhood adversely affect the state of health in adulthood and consequently contribute to the emergence of many diseases.  The European Union is trying to combat this phenomenon, which is why we voted today on the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament and of the Council on an aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments. EU financial assistance for the delivery of selected products to schools is intended to help promote healthy eating habits and the consumption of local products by children. The programme aims to increase the distribution of vegetables, fruits, milk and other products in schools, i.e. cheese, yoghurt and lactose-free milk. It is extremely important to introduce nutrition education among children, to promote healthy food and to develop food programmes in educational establishments.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I support this legislative proposal. It not only contributes to a healthier diet for school children, but also supports local agriculture.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of the proposal providing for an aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments. I believe that promoting children's health in the European Union is a very important task, so this is a welcome initiative. The rules adopted in plenary provide for the meringue of eu school milk and fruit programmes and an increase in their annual budget by EUR 20 million. Member States will be able to choose or participate in this EU programme on a voluntary basis, provided that healthy eating habits and healthy eating training will also be significantly promoted at national level. Recently, this issue has also become topical in Latvia, so I believe that additional funding will help many Member States both to raise awareness of healthy eating and to introduce healthy diet habits.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Only 36% of Europeans eat their five portions of fruit and vegetables a day, while at the same time one child in three is overweight or obese in Europe. I voted in favour of the report, as its goal is to promote consumption of healthy, fresh foods by schoolchildren, helping them establish healthy eating habits.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. Mr Tarabella's report deals with the existing school milk and fruit programmes, which finance dairy products and fruit under the European Agricultural Policy and distribute them to schools. The report aims to extend the programmes and increase the total budget to EUR 250 million per year. As a family-friendly party, ALFA supports healthy child nutrition. However, in line with the principle of subsidiarity, ALFA sees no reason for children's nutrition programmes to be funded and regulated by the EU. According to the report, the taxpayer first pays into the EU budget, then the EU Commission decides which products can be extracted from which ingredients in order to transfer the tax revenue back to the Member States later, i.e. to finance the food programmes from EU funds. If the Länder and individual municipalities believe that such programmes are needed, they could make this much more effective without having to co-finance the EU apparatus. Personally, I firmly believe that it is above all the responsibility of parents to take care of their children's nutrition and that parents do not need training from the European Commission. I have therefore rejected the above-mentioned report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 On 8 March 2016, we voted on a proposal for a regulation amending the original regulation as regards the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments. Under the Commission's initial plans, there should have been substantial changes to the programme which would have led to its deterioration. Originally, financial support was to be limited to dairy products that children do not like very much, such as unflavoured milk and low-fat added sugar products. While this effort was entirely logical and aimed at improving the health of our offspring, the reality of everyday life is far more complex. Instead of improving children's health, there was talk that it would deteriorate, thanks to a rapid decline in milk consumption. I am therefore glad that all parties have finally come to a reasonable compromise. In the future, processed and flavored dairy products can be financially supported, but they can only be seasoned with a natural ingredient. The original proposal will even be extended to support processed fruit, vegetables and bananas. In addition, the envelope from which funds for milk for schools will be drawn is increased almost fourfold for the Czech Republic to EUR 1.6 million. For these reasons, I am very glad that I was able to support the text submitted yesterday.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal aims to achieve better coordination between the milk scheme and fruit scheme, so that both programs become more efficient. It is also essential that Member States should prioritise the distribution of fresh products. We manage also to achieve that products containing added sugar, salt and fat will not be authorised automatically but only after analysis by national health authorities. I voted in favour of this report in order to improve both schemes but also to reach a better use of EU funds.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I supported Mr Tarabella's report because it aims to promote the distribution and consumption of fruit and vegetables, including bananas, milk and dairy products in schools. The primary objective is to promote healthy eating habits through the consumption of local products. Given that more than 20 million European children are overweight, I am convinced that this programme will help to combat this phenomenon by encouraging young people to consume more fruits and vegetables. I believe that children should be educated from an early age to proper nutrition, and this can only start from school. In addition, there are accompanying educational measures to bring children closer to agriculture, through visits to farms and farms. Today's vote is important because it is intended for the education of future generations and it is therefore vital that they follow a healthy and balanced diet thanks to the consumption of genuine products, within a Mediterranean diet and a lifestyle that includes sport and physical movement.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament supports the continuation of EU programmes to encourage the consumption of fruit and vegetables and milk in schools in EU Member States. These programmes will therefore continue to contribute to promoting healthier eating habits among children. For this purpose, up to EUR 250 million may be allocated during the school year. eu funds. It is important to make targeted and effective use of these funds, to ensure a particularly high quality of the products in question supplied to children, with a priority given to local production and to small suppliers and growers.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it organises the distribution of fruits and vegetables and dairy products in schools, which is good for children. It also has the merit of leaving states free to promote the use of local products, which is in line with the food patriotism advocated by the National Front.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this amendment, on which the final vote of the Parliament and Council regulation, which supports the scheme to support the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools, depends. It amends Regulation (EU) 1308/2013 and Regulation (EU) No. 1306/2013 already adopted in this area. This amendment has been strongly defended by MEPs, who have joined forces with a global consensus against the commission and the Council's desire to oust them from this issue. This regulation is not only an excellent way to get our children used to healthy eating practices, but it also respects the sovereignty of the Member States for the implementation of this programme. In addition, this surge of freedom will enable the implementation of a food patriotism at the regional and national level with the use of local products.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because this is an important and necessary programme. I agree with much of the improvements made by Parliament, such as distributed foods having restrictions on the content of added sugars, salts, sweeteners and fats, as well as some flavor enhancers. Other important elements contained in the report are accompanying educational measures and the fact that Member States can give priority to sustainability and fair trade considerations.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. Today, consumption of fruits, fresh vegetables and dairy products is in decline, especially among children. In addition, there is an increase in overweight among them due to the tendency to consume highly processed foods high in sugars and fats. For this reason, the European Parliament intends to provide a number of aid to Member States to finance the provision to schools of a selection of products that promote healthy eating habits.  Such aid shall be allocated to each Member State on the account of the number of children between six and ten years of age who are part of that Member State and the degree of development thereof, in order to ensure greater support to those less developed regions.  Personally, I have always considered that investing in children is paramount, so I believe that the adoption of this report is necessary because, thanks to it, European children will soon start to enjoy milk, fruit and vegetable delivery systems in the best-funded schools, complemented by healthy eating programmes.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. Mr Tarabella's report deals with the existing school milk and fruit programmes, which finance dairy products and fruit under the European Agricultural Policy and distribute them to schools. The report aims to extend the programmes and increase the total budget to EUR 250 million per year. As a family-friendly party, ALFA supports healthy child nutrition. However, in line with the principle of subsidiarity, ALFA sees no reason for children's nutrition programmes to be funded and regulated by the EU. According to the report, the taxpayer first pays into the EU budget, then the EU Commission decides which products can be extracted from which ingredients in order to transfer the tax revenue back to the Member States later, i.e. to finance the food programmes from EU funds. If the Länder and individual municipalities believe that such programmes are needed, they could make this much more effective without having to co-finance the EU apparatus. Personally, I firmly believe that it is above all the responsibility of parents to take care of their children's nutrition and that parents do not need training from the European Commission. I have therefore rejected the above-mentioned report.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The conclusions of existing EU aid programmes indicate that their continuation is of great social importance for the benefit of citizens. The European Union's financial assistance to children in educational establishments undoubtedly contributes to the promotion of healthy eating habits, the reduction of obesity among the youngest and thus the promotion of healthy local products such as fruit, vegetables and dairy products. Personally, I believe that aid schemes for the supply of fruit, vegetables and milk to educational establishments are a proven investment in children's health. We must ensure that such programmes continue to be improved and implemented and managed more effectively. The Member States and, above all, the local authorities closest to citizens should play a major role here. That is why, in support of the objectives and objectives of marc Tarbell's report 'Aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments', I voted in favour of it.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. While I agree that children should eat healthily, I also refuse to transfer parental responsibility to a state that does not own children. I do not agree with the use of taxpayers' money for products that they can buy for their children themselves. This is just a different form of EU promotion, which is highlighted in the report. States that do not participate in the programme will, through the European budget, pay for those participating in the programme.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Due to a decline in consumption of fruit, vegetables and dairy products among young people, a new programme of support for educational institutions has been adopted. A new system for distributing products in schools has been proposed, focusing on fruit, vegetables and milk. This program is extremely important because free healthy meals are provided for children in the lower grades of primary school, and in addition to combating poverty among children, it also contributes to educating children about healthy eating. Nevertheless, it is important to ensure that the programme contributes well enough to the development of small family farms, as the products should be purchased primarily from them, as they are the guarantee of healthy food. In Croatia, due to public procurement procedures centralized at the state level, suppliers for schools become large chains, not family capitals.  I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation on programmes for the delivery of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments, as I think it is necessary for children to use healthy foods during their development and education and should be family farms.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 Cases of childhood obesity are increasingly common due to frequent consumption of foods with a high degree of processing, added sugar, salt and fat. At the same time, there is a decrease in consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables, as well as dairy products. I therefore believe that the continuation and strengthening of the two schemes for the supply of fruit, vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments is of the utmost importance. These schemes need a more flexible funding mechanism that takes into account the number of children aged between six and 10 and provides more assistance to underdeveloped regions.  One of the main positives of the schemes is the presence of accompanying educational measures, which aims to restore the link between children and agriculture. It would therefore be appropriate to allow Member States to also include local products and educational activities such as visits to the farms where these products are produced. An example of this may be the inclusion of other dairy products such as yogurt and cheeses. I therefore welcome the texts adopted by a large majority (584 votes in question).

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 Health and life of generations also affect eating habits. I support the provision of assistance and the adoption of measures that will improve the quality of meals in school facilities and contribute to changing diets and healthy eating habits of children and young people.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. A quarter of European schoolchildren are currently overweight or obese, a proportion that is constantly increasing. Better nutrition and obesity prevention are among the EU's health priorities, and the Commission proposed in January 2014 to reform schemes for the distribution of fruit and milk in schools.  This report prioritizes the distribution of fresh fruits and vegetables, while prohibiting the distribution of processed products in which sugar, salt, fats, sweeteners or artificial flavours have been added. The budget allocated to this common framework for programmes for the consumption of fruit and milk in schools is also being strengthened. In addition to combating obesity and promoting food education, this program aims to give priority to fresh fruits and vegetables. In our outermost regions, bananas and other locally produced fruit will be distributed as a priority. For all these reasons, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning Amendment (EU) No 1493/1999. 1306/2013 on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/3/2016, and because this report is not complete.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text, which once is not customary, is unanimous among political groups! Indeed, it is a very interesting text that organizes the distribution of fruits and vegetables, bananas and dairy products in schools. And, to the point that we are satisfied with, the Member States are free to organise this programme themselves, in the way they wish, without the Commission getting involved.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this proposal. In the current context of declining consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and milk products, especially among children, and an increasing incidence of child obesity as a result of consumption habits geared to highly processed foods which, additionally, are often high in added sugars, salt, fat or additives, the Union aid to finance the supply to children in educational establishments of selected agricultural products should do more to promote healthy eating habits and the consumption of local products.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of the new draft law providing for more funds for greater consumption of milk and fruit within the European Schools for better food education. Parliament has provided additional aid of EUR 20 million per year to finance the distribution of dairy products and the implementation of new educational measures. The new rules will focus mainly on programmes that lead to healthy and correct nutrition and to a better knowledge of the products on the table. The Member States participating in this aid programme must promote healthy eating habits, organic farming and the fight against food waste. European funds will also be distributed more fairly among the Member States, setting basic criteria for the implementation of the whole programme so that the most aid is allocated to the less developed regions.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a proposal for a regulation on the promotion of the supply of fruit, vegetables and milk to educational establishments. According to the findings, the consumption of milk and fruit has a decreasing tendency, especially in children, for which it represents an important source of calcium and vitamins. The distribution of these products will also encourage the consumption of domestic products. In the Regulation we also deal with the composition of such products, where the content of added sugar, salt, fats, sweeteners and artificial taste highlighters applies. Since the health of children and young people, not only as doctors, is at my heart, I supported the proposal.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Nothing is more important than the health of our children, especially given the increased incidence of childhood obesity in Europe. We must work to reverse this trend. I voted in favour of this report because I want the next generation to grow up healthy and with good eating habits.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. By voting in favour of the report of my Belgian comrade Marc Tarabella, I helped to validate the final agreement reached after negotiations between the three European institutions on a new European Union funding regime for the distribution of fruit and milk in schools.  The final text is very ambitious. Firstly, it foresees an increase in European funding for the programme to finance european schoolchildren's access to the consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and milk: around EUR 270 million will be spent on it. At the same time, processed products in which sugar, salt, fats, sweeteners or fats have been added will be excluded from any European funding.  Finally, the programme aims to promote a healthy, balanced and sustainable diet, based on short circuits, organic and the fight against waste. This type of project, which seems anecdotal, is precisely what Europe needs today. More than a public health issue, it is a question of combating the excesses of the consumer society by highlighting a responsible mode of consumption and sustainable agricultural production.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution is a small part of the wider effort to promote healthy eating habits by children and young people using local products that are not high in additional harmful substances.  The fight against childhood obesity, with all its consequences on the psychosomatic composition of children, must continue to be a priority of the Union, given that research carried out at national level is worrying in terms of its frequency and percentage. With a common legislative framework that promotes the supply of these products to schools, I believe that the above phenomenon can be addressed to some extent, since children spend much of their day at school, where they enjoy basic meals.  For this action to be effective, it should be accompanied by supporting pedagogical measures to inform and understand the beneficial effect of proper nutrition on their health as well as a continuous evaluation of this overall strategy for more targeted results. For these reasons, I am in favour of this resolution.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on an aid programme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments. This program is important because it helps to promote healthy eating and lifestyle habits for children and promotes the consumption of local products.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement, which merges the school fruit and vegetables scheme with the school milk scheme, allocating EUR 250 million annually to educational establishments throughout the Member States, while also promoting healthy diets for school children and supporting local and regional produce.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. By providing aid for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools, the European Union wants to solve two problems. On the one hand, for a public health objective, the increase in obesity in children in connection with an unbalanced diet. On the other hand, the agricultural crisis due to the decline in the consumption of fresh European products. For once, the text takes into account the growing lactose intolerance and allows the distribution of processed dairy products (without additives). The report also encourages the consumption of local products. But it does not make it a primary condition for these products to come from organic farming, which would have been an effective way to both redirect agricultural production to a sector that does not know the crisis and meet public health objectives. I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Parliament on this subject was very consensual with the Commission and the Council, which intended to remove the text from its judgment. This is because this diet is a good initiative to distribute these products in schools. What we have found above all good in this text is that the Member States remain free in the implementation of the programme. This can, among other things, promote local products and engage in patriotic food policies. As a result, I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013 and Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 on the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments. The EU should encourage healthy lifestyles and eating habits from childhood. Childhood obesity is nowadays a serious problem. It is up to the EU to encourage and strengthen the promotion of healthy eating habits and the consumption of local products. The health of EU children should always be a priority.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution, which seeks to tackle the decline in consumption of fruits, vegetables and milk products amongst children and youths. I am happy to support this proposal after a long negotiation procedure between the institutions, as it promotes a healthy lifestyle with a focus on fresh produce.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. A symptomatic of an era characterized by the rampant production and consumption of highly elaborate foods, obesity is one of the main evils of this century, especially among children. This change in eating behaviour has come at the expense of fresh fruits and vegetables, and has favoured a diet high in salt, sugars, additives or even fat. Often aware of the stakes, the authorities have so far struggled to provide a lasting solution to the problem, at a time when the difficult economic environment is making it increasingly difficult for less fortunate families to consume fresh fruit and vegetables.  I welcome the sustainability of the report. By ensuring children's access to fresh and local produce, the report raises awareness of healthy, varied and balanced diets and introduces the next generation to sustainable and organic agriculture. It therefore represents a long-term investment, both in terms of public health, economic development and environmental development.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: writing – Eating fresh vegetables and fruits, as well as milk and dairy products, is essential for the healthy physical and mental development of our children. At school age, it is especially important to pay attention to the supply of nutrients contained in these foods, as during this period physical and mental abilities, massive muscles and skeleton develop, body strength increases, reason and artistic styles develop, new knowledge is constantly acquired. A sufficient supply of protein is provided precisely through drinking milk and dairy products such as yoghurts and cheeses, while fresh and further unprepared vegetables and fruits are an important source of vitamins for building the body's defences. The downward trend in the consumption of these foods by school-age children is alarming and one of the unintended consequences of an unbalanced diet is the ever-increasing obesity rate of our schoolchildren. The EU must therefore act. I agree with the initiative to create a programme scheme under which the Union would provide assistance to schools in order to increase the consumption of vegetables, fruits, including bananas, milk and milk products, taking into account the degree of development of the regions and the number of six- to ten-year-olds, in order to provide assistance, in particular, to less developed regions and, depending on the strategy papers submitted by the Member States themselves, which wish to participate in the programme. I therefore express my support for the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on aid schemes for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in the educational establishments, which is essential to promote consumption of healthy, fresh foods by schoolchildren, helping them establish healthy eating habits – especially important when we are facing an epidemic of obesity. Management will now be more efficient through a single, visible programme with the milk part operating in parallel with the fruit and vegetable strand. The budget has been clearly established in this text, enabling Member States to plan this action over the medium to long term.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In January 2014, the Commission proposed to adopt a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulations (EU) No 1308/2013 and (EU) No 1306/2013 as regards the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments. In April 2015, the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development decided to start an interinstitutional consultation before adopting Parliament's report on the preparation of its first reading position. In January 2016, the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development approved the text adopted during the interinstitutional negotiations and, in its report, proposes that Parliament adopt the draft regulation in an amended form at first reading. I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This vote is the result of bitter negotiations, including a heated trilogue, because of the expulsion of Parliament by the Commission and the Council on this subject. Parliament's position was therefore formed on a global consensus among the different political parties. The programme is a good measure: it organises the distribution of fruits and vegetables, bananas and dairy products in schools. Above all, this text gives Member States the freedom to implement this programme in the way they wish. In this way, they can promote the use of local products and engage in a form of national and/or regional food patriotism.  It must therefore be supported.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The significant decrease in the consumption of fruit, fresh vegetables and dairy products, coupled with increased childhood obesity, as a result of the dietary habits that increasingly favour processed foods, rich in added sugars, salt, additives or fats, should be given special attention from the European Union. I believe that the Union should encourage its Member States to strengthen the promotion of healthy eating habits and the consumption of local products, especially in schools. Member States, in view of their food consumption reality, should develop their own strategies to combat the reduction in the consumption of fresh milk, fruit and vegetables, combining the effort to distribute local and regional products. I endorse the rapporteur's position that eu financial assistance should be allocated to each Member State in view of its degree of development, in order to ensure greater aid to less developed regions and the outermost regions, given their limited agricultural diversification and the frequent impossibility of finding certain products in the region concerned, which entails higher transport and storage costs.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This programme is a good measure: it organises the distribution of fruits and vegetables, bananas and dairy products in schools. Above all, this text gives Member States the freedom to implement this programme in the way they wish. Member States therefore remain in control of their sovereignty over the subject, and can thus promote the use of local products and engage in a form of national and/or regional food patriotism. That is why I voted for it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report in order to highlight the positive contribution of the EU and the CAP to the development of healthy eating habits among children and the promotion of sustainable local agricultural products. The current schemes benefit nearly 30 million children per year across the EU and their funding has been increased to EUR 150 million a year (2014-2020). In 2012-13, the UK received GBP 3.3 million worth of EU aid for the milk scheme, supplemented by GBP 0.9 million of national subsidy. Such a breakdown of funding illustrates a significant overall benefit of the scheme for the UK taxpayer.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to reform and establish a common legal and financial framework for milk and fruit and vegetable distribution programmes in schools.  This report contains provisions that require states to prioritize the distribution of fresh produce over processed products. This will also encourage healthy eating habits but also create a direct link between producers and children.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanks to today's vote, Parliament supports the extension of the 'Fruit in Schools' programme, integrating it with the milk programme and strengthening its educational dimension. The aim is for 30 million children across Europe to learn and practise healthy eating. In Europe, one in three children is overweight or suffering from obesity: in this scenario, the role of schools in food prevention and education is crucial. The programme, the implementation of which is entrusted to the Member States, is aimed at children between the ages of six and ten, and provides for preschool and secondary education classes to be able to join as well. The promotion of local and regional products is an integral part of the programme. The funds cannot be unilaterally cut by the Member States and provide EUR 150 million per year for fruit and vegetables and EUR 100 million for school milk that so requests. The European Union is close to all its citizens, starting with the smallest.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I was not able, for medical reasons, to attend the plenary session from 7 to 10 March 2016. Nevertheless, I would like to express my support for the adopted text allowing assistance in the distribution of fruits and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools. Although the list of dairy products allowed for distribution remains too restrictive, this aid measure remains important to ensure healthy eating in schools.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Based on the eating habits of today's young people, which consists mainly of unhealthy foods: added sugar, high carbohydrate and fat content, I consider it important to support the supply of quality fruits, vegetables, as well as milk and dairy products in educational institutions. In Slovakia, nearly 400 000 patients are treated with diabetes, of whom 3 000 are under the age of 19. The distribution of aid between Member States should take into account two factors: age and the development of the region. The report targets children between the age of six and 10 and ensures that less developed regions receive higher support.  It also takes into account the location of certain fruits, vegetables and dairy products in each region in order to minimise transport and storage costs. As a proud father of 4 children, there is nothing more important to me than the health of my children! That is why I support this report in its current form.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The measures presented in this report support the distribution of fruits, vegetables and milk in schools. They also represent a critical tool to reconnect children with agriculture and the variety of the EU’s agricultural products, more specifically those produced in their region, with the help of, for example, nutrition experts and farmers. I have voted for this report, which has as its objective the increased consumption of selected agricultural products.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the proposal for a regulation on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational institutions. This Regulation, which shall apply from 1 August 2017, provides for aid of up to EUR 250 million per Member State school year for the supply of fruit and vegetables and milk for schools, for accompanying educational measures and related costs. Within the overall limit, the aid does not exceed EUR 150 million per school year for school fruit and vegetables and EUR 100 million per school year for school milk. That aid shall be allocated to each Member State taking into account criteria such as: the number of children aged between six and ten years or the degree of development of the regions of the Member State concerned, so as to ensure that greater aid is allocated to less developed regions. Member States shall choose the products to be distributed or to be included in the accompanying educational measures on the basis of objective criteria such as: health and environmental considerations, seasonality, variety and availability of local or regional products. Member States may in particular encourage local or regional purchases, organic products, short supply chains or environmental benefits.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to adopt the EP amendments to Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013 and Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 on the call for the continuation and strengthening of the consumption of fruits, milk and vegetables among school children through an aid scheme to allow for a more proportionally targeted distribution of these goods based on the number of children aged 6-10 in a Member State’s population. Moreover, the Member States that at present face monetary and logistical challenges in terms of accessing milk, vegetables and fruit will be greatly helped by the proposed aid scheme.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report containing an increase of EUR 20 million to EUR 100 million in the School Milk programme and an adjustment to the conditions for drawing on the programme. It is a program that is beneficial in terms of creating healthy eating habits of children and, for example, works very well in the Czech Republic. I therefore appreciate that it does not dramatically interfere with the range of dairy products that can be supported by the programme. It is better for children to drink tasted milk or yogurt than when they reach for sweetened lemonades or chocolate bars. I consider it a reasonable compromise that dairy products with added sugar, salt or fat content will be subject to assessment and authorisation by the responsible authority in the Member State, in the case of the Czech Republic it will be the Ministry of Health, which is an institution to which one can certainly have confidence.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. In addition to more fruits and vegetables in our schools, the report also calls for a range of dairy products to provide a healthy diet for school children. I voted in favour of this report because the additional funding will also benefit our dairy farmers.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. One of the most important aspects of the negotiations was compliance with the historical budget criterion, which will remain in place in the distribution of the milk scheme budget and will provide Estonia with a slightly larger budget than before. It is also appropriate to consider the choice of eligible products (in addition to milk, but also yogurt, etc.) and the possibility of taking into account local circumstances.  The introduction of fixed budget percentages for education and supplementary measures and the preparation of national strategies for a period of six years are also positive.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. U2012 Fruit and milk consumption programmes are of vital importance for promoting the consumption of food beneficial to public health. These programs have also shown their effectiveness from a pedagogical point of view as creators of healthy habits. Strengthening the educational dimension is one of the novel elements of this new proposal, which will allow for a deeper understanding of agricultural, nutritional and environmental issues.   I can only vote in favour of a proposal which is fundamental to all of the above and which comes at a time when child poverty and, paradoxically, childhood obesity reach really worrying numbers in Europe.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal tabled. The aid programme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk is consistent with public health objectives. It is particularly beneficial for children's health and helps to develop healthy eating habits. It is therefore essential that the EU has a common legal and financial framework in place to simplify the existing system and reduce the administrative and organisational burdens. The new rules will combine both programmes currently in place separately and will extend their application to additional educational measures that will enable children to increase their knowledge of agriculture and their products. However, in order to ensure the effective implementation of the programme, evaluation systems need to be improved and a common evaluation and annual monitoring methodology applied.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Regulation is not intended to provide free lunch to school pupils, but to strengthen and subsidise food processing business groups. In fact, it defiantly states that its aim is to foster "healthy eating habits" in children, at a time when the barbaric unpopular POLICY of the EU and governments is constantly forcing thousands of grassroots families to send their children to school. The real objective of the EU, with this regulation, is to subsidise large dairy companies and food packaging, processing and marketing monopolies. That is why in the subsidised products the regulation made sure to include various processed fruit and vegetables, milk drinks with fruit, cocoa, etc., i.e. those products that the companies concerned promote for consumption at young ages, in order to increase their customers and advertise them even by getting a subsidy! And all this not for the whole year but by sampling, just 20 pieces of fruit and 4-5 euros per year for each child. The labour-grassroots movement to claim the daily provision of a free meal to all school pupils, from the state budget, by opposing the unpopular EU and government policy and their falsified programmes to strengthen monopolies.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported a proposal for legislation aimed at monitoring children's eating habits. As proclaimed by the relevant proposal for a law, Member States must - as a general principle - promote healthy eating habits, local food, organic farming and the fight against food waste.  This Regulation strengthens and broadens the system of supervision of children's eating habits in schools by adding further compulsory consumption products. In particular, the list of products that may receive European funding is amended and priority is given to fresh and local products as opposed to processed foods such as soups, compotes, juices, yogurts and cheeses. These foods will only be given in addition to fresh fruits, vegetables and lactose-free milk or milk. I can only support and be in the most positive way in EU initiatives aimed at monitoring children's eating habits.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We do want school-children to be well nourished, but we opposed this because, even if you think taxpayers should contribute, these things should not be done centrally by Brussels.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Member States are now facing major social difficulties. In view of the current decline in the consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and dairy products, especially among children, as well as the increase in the incidence of childhood obesity due to consumption habits oriented towards highly processed food products, Union aid for financing the distribution of selected agricultural products to children in schools should further promote the promotion of healthy eating habits and the consumption of local products.  I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Food habits in most European countries have changed rapidly in recent decades. Industrialisation and other socioeconomic factors have played a major role in changing the geographical distribution of the population, with densely populated cities and depopulation in rural areas. The diet in most countries across the EU, including Bulgaria, is characterised by high consumption of animal products and processed foods and low consumption of plant products. Child obesity in Bulgaria for example is growing at alarming rates, ranking 5th in the EU. Increased availability of fruits, vegetables and dairy products as components of school meals may be an effective strategy to promote healthy eating behaviours among children. That is why I voted in favour of the report to support the scheme.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. I support the rapporteur's proposal, as young people need to be educated and used to being used at the school stage. This proposal seeks to achieve a positive shift precisely in this light. It focuses mainly on the distribution of fruit and dairy products into schools, both of which have a significant impact on healthy eating. In this way, we also seek to achieve greater integration between the agricultural sector, public health and the education system.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒I welcome the adoption of this Regulation because the agreement reached abolished historical criteria that taught Croatia to participate in the use of subsidies for healthy milk meals in schools. In addition to the abolition of historical criteria for Croatia, this Regulation allows Member States to include in their measures a wider range of agricultural products, as well as other local, regional or national specialties such as honey, table olives and olive oil.  Also, this Regulation highlights the educational dimension of the programme for children aged 6-10 who will learn more about how they produce the food they eat and its connection with farmers' daily work. It is this educational dimension and the connection of the program with local production that is the greatest value of this program and should be seen as a support to local producers, not to retail chains or various industrial groups that can hardly achieve the desired and understandable connection of all segments of this program.  Because of all of the above, I supported this Regulation and I hope that this support program for the delivery of fruits and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational institutions will bring all the above benefits to children and farmers in Croatia and Europe.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This vote is the result of bitter negotiations, including a stormy trilogue. Mr Tarabella had even sent a letter, co-signed by all the groups (Édouard Ferrand for the ENF), to protest against the predatory effect of Parliament wanted by the Commission and the Council on this subject.  Parliament's position was therefore formed on a global consensus among the different political factions. And for good reason, this programme is a good measure: it organises the distribution of fruits and vegetables, bananas and dairy products in schools. Above all, this text gives Member States the freedom to implement this programme in the way they wish.  Member States therefore remain in control of their sovereignty over the subject, and can thus promote the use of local products, and engage in a form of food patriotism. I therefore speak for this text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Education for a healthier lifestyle, starting with eating habits, is one of the fundamental tasks of our school systems, especially considering the high level of childhood obesity, the result, among other things, of aggressive advertising campaigns, often aimed precisely at children, that promote the consumption of junk food. Thanks to today's vote in the European Parliament, thirty million children will eat and learn to feed themselves better. The new legislation will allow the free distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools throughout the school year. Thanks to the clear definition of the funds, the Member States will be able to plan their action better. Furthermore, the text adopted stipulates that The Member States must give priority to the distribution of fresh and locally sourced products. For the first time, sweeteners and other artificial additives are totally prohibited for products distributed in schools. Products containing added sugar, salt and fats are, in general, equally prohibited and will not be permitted only after explicit authorisation by the national health authorities. Particular attention is paid to the selection of products and their origin (local, fair and sustainable). Finally, products such as honey, olives and olive oil will also be distributed occasionally, for specific educational campaigns.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The support programme for the delivery of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments is of utmost importance as we face, in the current context, the declining consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and dairy products, especially among children, and the increasingly frequent childhood obesity caused by consumer habits directed towards products that often contain large amounts of added sugar, salt, fat or additives. It is extremely worrying that one in five children in the Republic of Croatia is obese, and that Croatia is seventh in the EU in the number of obese children. This data is alarming since obesity shortens life by up to ten years. It is very important to emphasize that obesity affects psychophysical health and for this reason I want to emphasize the importance of this unique program that promotes the consumption of healthy and fresh foods in order to instill healthy eating habits in school children, which is of utmost importance in the fight against obesity. For all of the above, I support this program of supplying children with selected agricultural products in educational institutions that should contribute to promoting healthy habits, preventing diseases and consumption of healthy, fresh local products.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 As a result of several proposed amendments, it was possible to ensure the requirement to guarantee budgetary appropriations in the basic act for the Fruit and Milk programmes, ensuring that the Council cannot unilaterally cut funding for these programmes in the future. Amounts that we consider, however, insufficient to respond to the need to encourage the consumption of these products of school age, ensuring access to them, without restrictions of an economic nature. The scheme sets out that Member States should give priority to the distribution of fresh products to the detriment of processed products in order to encourage healthy eating habits. The objectives of the scheme are commendable, but they are diluted in the face of the diversion of funds that could be used for the distribution of fresh vegetables and milk for advertising purposes. The old strategy of selling the idea that good is done on a large scale, when practice so often beress it. We believe that the scheme can still be improved, especially in the areas of promoting local and traditional products, in improving the system for assessing and monitoring the milk regime in schools and the fruit distribution system in schools, in order to ensure that the effectiveness of these schemes is possible in the medium-long term. We voted for it.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I welcome this report and fully support it. Worrying statistics show that the rate of financial fraud and irregularities is increasing year on year, and compared to 2013 the overall financial impact of reported irregularities has increased by as much as 36%. Financial fraud and irregularities cause a loss estimated annually at billions of euros. I would like to recall that the protection of financial interests and reasonable public spending are essential for citizens' trust in the Union and should therefore be among the most important elements of its policy. I also hope that the European Commission's recently adopted multiannual anti-fraud strategy will contribute to more effectively protecting the EU's financial interests and reduce the damage suffered by the European economy as a result of fraud and irregularities.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to the educational establishments of the Member States of the European Union. Its approval will link the two previous schemes, the fruit and vegetables scheme, together with the milk regime and its lactose-free variants, which should ensure an increase in the efficiency of those instruments. As Vice-President of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I am very happy that the European Union is committed to healthy consumer habits for young European generations as well. In particular, during periods of increased consumption of highly processed foods containing large quantities of sugar, fats and added substances, the consumption of fresh fruit, vegetables and milk is needed. I am very happy that the scheme will also support accompanying educational activities, which I very much hope will be optimally used by the Member States and educational establishments. According to European Union statistics, up to 3 million Europeans die each year from overweight and obesity. World Health Organisation statistics also point to an alarming trend of obesity rates among children, with up to one in three children in the 6-9 age group suffering from obesity. This is not the way Europe should go. Consumers need to be warned about the risks of highly processed foods from an early age. The sooner they instill the right habits, the better.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I strongly support the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments. Nowadays, with an increase in childhood obesity and unhealthy eating habits, it is important for children to move towards a healthier lifestyle. I think that it is the EU's support for the distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk to schools, including the possibility for Member States to include other regional products, that will help to stem the declining consumption of healthy products and increase the interest in their consumption among children. To this end, I also support accompanying training projects through various activities, such as farm visits. Such projects can lead not only to greater familiarity of children with local production, but also to greater support for the activities of farmers in the area. These measures can also serve to educate on related issues such as healthy eating habits, local food chains, organic farming, sustainable production or the fight against food waste. At the same time, however, it is necessary to ensure that other children's meals do not contain too much sugar, fat, salt, sweeteners and artificial flavour highlighters E620 and E650.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the sharp decline in the consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and dairy products, especially among children, and given the increase in the incidence of childhood obesity due to bad eating habits, I believe that the continuation and strengthening of the two school programmes, the "distribution of fruit and vegetables" programme and the "school milk" programme, are of great importance. European Union aid, intended to finance the distribution of selected agricultural products to children, will help to establish healthy food education and educational tools aimed at strengthening the link with the agricultural world. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 There are currently two separate EU-funded grant schemes under the CAP: the School Milk Programme and the School Fruit Programme. All EU Member States participate in the School Milk Programme. In 2013/2014, 25 Member States participated in the School Fruit Programme (the UNITED KINGDOM, Sweden and Finland did not participate). Participation in the programmes is voluntary. The Commission has proposed to include these two programmes in a common legal framework. This is to increase their efficiency, reduce the administrative burden and improve overall performance. The list of products covered by these programmes has been significantly expanded.  In addition to fresh products, Member States will be able to distribute other low-processed dairy products, such as natural yogurt and cheese. As for processed fruit and vegetables and other dairy products such as fruit yoghurts and chocolate milk, they are covered by the scheme under the following conditions: only the milk component of chocolate milk and other flavoured milk (which will have to contain at least 90% milk) and fruit yoghurts (which will have to contain at least 75% milk) will be funded by the EU; sweeteners and artificial flavour enhancers will now, for the first time, be completely banned in products distributed under school programmes. I hereby supported the report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We do want school-children to be well nourished, but we opposed this because, even if you think taxpayers should contribute, these things should not be done centrally by Brussels.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the final outcome of the intensive negotiations, of which I was part of the EPP rapporteur, is very beneficial for both the Member States and our young people. This new programme will bring the milk distribution scheme together with the distribution scheme for fruits, bananas and vegetables in schools, reducing the administrative burden, freeing up more resources. An increase of EUR 20 million has also been achieved for milk distribution, so no Member State will lose funds under the new financial allocation criteria. The list of distribution of products has been extended, the limitation of the transfer of funds between the two programmes has been defined and the pedagogical character has been strengthened, bringing our young people closer to producers. Finally, there is, in fact, positive discrimination between the Outermost Regions, as they have greater difficulties in implementing this programme, and they are granted an increase in the funds originally envisaged, an incentive for trade between the ORs and an increase in the authorised percentage of transfer between the two schemes. I believe that this programme will help young Europeans to increase their consumption of fresh products, especially milk, develop healthy eating habits and contribute to the disposal of European agricultural products.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. I voted with the vast majority of MEPs in favour of this report to merge the two European programmes for milk, and fruit and vegetables in schools, which were previously separate. This will enable us to put in place more effective strategies for educating our children for a healthy and balanced diet, as well as making better use of European resources.  More than ever, I hope that every effort is made to combat bad eating habits from an early age.
