The fact is alarming: more than 20 million children are overweight in the EU and adolescents consume on average only 30-50% of their recommended daily intake of fruits and vegetables.  This report represents a positive first effort. In particular, I support the decision to increase the programmes' budget from EUR 20 million to EUR 250 million. Faced with a falling consumption of fruits, vegetables, and milk, Europe must persevere in this direction and devise more ambitious policies to promote healthy eating.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. It is worrying that only 36% of Europeans eat the recommended five parts of fruit and vegetables daily. One in three European children is overweight. The EU is intended to give priority to fresh and unprocessed local products in order to encourage healthy eating habits among children. Member States shall retain the possibility to distribute other dairy products, such as natural yogurt and cheese in an additional way. As regards fruit, processed vegetables or fruit yogurts and chocolate milk, the European Parliament only accepts them if sufficient safeguard measures are incorporated. For example, chocolate or other flavour milk will have to have at least 90% milk and only this can be funded by the EU. From now on, the addition of sweeteners and artificial flavors is banned in products distributed in schools. Products containing added sugar, salt and fat are prohibited unless authorised by national health authorities. The vote in favour of this report is excellent news for the health of the 30 million school-age children who will benefit from it, as well as to boost and solidify a direct relationship between producer and consumer.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013 and Regulation (EU) No 1360/2013, as well as the agreement reached in the negotiation with the Council as regards the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools.  Problems such as child overweight or the decline in fruit and vegetable consumption are presented as extremely important to the Union, so it must promote healthy eating habits and consumption of local products, and continue and strengthen these school programmes.  The Commission shall be given the power to adopt acts relating to the obligation of the Member States to disclose the aid they receive from the Union for the application of such schemes. It is necessary for each Member State to which such aid is to be granted to establish a strategy at national or regional level and to provide the necessary publicity for intervention in the school system and the subsidies to be used.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament yesterday approved the compromise text on the EU programme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables and milk in schools (584 votes in support, 94 against and 32 abstentions). Eligible products are: fruits and vegetables and fresh produce; consumption milk and lactose-free variants; processed products based on fruits and vegetables; cheese, etc. In order to ensure the effectiveness of the programme, Member States will need to provide accompanying educational measures such as farm visits, the distribution of a wider range of agricultural products, the education of children on related topics (healthy eating habits, local food chains, organic farming, sustainable production or the fight against food waste). The EU budget for this is 250 million euros per year (for six years): 150 million for fruits and vegetables and 100 million for milk. The Council has yet to formally approve the new regulation, which will be in effect from 1 August 2017.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Marc Tarabella's report on the proposed regulation to consolidate the programme to support the distribution of fruit and vegetables and milk in schools into one programme. The programme will have an increased budget of 250 million euros and will encourage the consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables as well as milk among more than 30 million young Europeans, thus helping to combat the rise of obesity in Europe.  In this context, Parliament has strengthened the Commission's proposal by banning the distribution of processed products in which sugar, salt, fats, sweeteners or artificial flavours have been added. In an effort to promote short circuits, this programme will also help to boost local agriculture.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which introduces a scheme to help distribute fruits and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools. The new legislation, tentatively agreed with EU ministers in December 2015, merges the now separate EU school milk and fruit programmes. Faced with the increasing risks of obesity, this aid scheme is a useful programme for the health of Europeans, and especially for the youngest populations. This text will lead to more lessons on healthy eating habits and more and fairer funding.  This programme will mobilise 250 million euros per year to finance the distribution of dairy products and educational measures. Member States will also need to promote healthier eating habits, local products, organic farming and the fight against food waste. I therefore supported this report, which reminds us that getting into the habit of eating healthy and balanced starts in childhood.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the distribution of certain foods in schools is the result of an analysis carried out among young Europeans who do not consume fruit, vegetables and milk products as recommended. In order to improve the nutrition of our children, I voted in favour of this report, which proposes basing food in school canteens on more fruit, vegetables and milk.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report for the restructuring of aid schemes for the consumption of fruit and vegetables and bananas and milk in schools, as these have a very positive impact on society inso as they promote healthy eating at an early age and seek to establish direct links between the two ends of the food chain , producer and consumer, enhancing the local primary sector. In addition, two productive sectors – dairy and fruit and vegetable – are indirectly promoted, representing approximately 30% of the Union's agricultural production.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. 'A healthy and balanced diet is the basis for good health, but unfortunately the consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk is declining across the EU. I believe that it is a national task to ensure school food and school fruit. However, I am voting in favour of the proposal because the budget line can be a contribution to some of the most disadvantaged Member States and therefore to some of the most disadvantaged citizens of the European Union. However, the EU cannot and must not take over the social responsibility of the Member States.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the aid scheme for fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational institutions, which brings together the school fruit programme and the school milk programme in a common framework, because the issue of these 'core products' in schools is very important and contributes to healthy development. In addition, increased pedagogical measures will be taken to strengthen the link between agriculture, public health and the environment, and to demonstrate this to children. This is very important because more than 20 million children in the EU are overweight and adolescents consume on average only 30-50% of the recommended annual quantity of fruit and vegetables. The amendment proposed by the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats to extend the selection of products eligible for distribution under the school milk programme in order to maintain the existing and well-functioning programmes in certain Member States, that is to say to offer more than milk, natural yoghurt and cheese, was unfortunately rejected.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Written. The bill, which aims to bring together the EU's school milk and fruit programmes into a joint programme, is intended to help schools offer children fresh food across the EU. I welcome the purpose of the draft law, but do not think that this is EU competence, but it should be up to the Member States to accommodate it. I therefore believe that the proposal should be voted against in principle. However, the situation in many Member States as a result of the economic crisis is such that milk and fruit from this programme for many children is the only way to get these products into school. That is why, in this vote, I have chosen to abstain from voting against.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because this is an important and necessary programme. I agree with much of the improvements made by Parliament, such as distributed foods having restrictions on the content of added sugars, salts, sweeteners and fats, as well as some flavor enhancers. Other important elements contained in the report are accompanying educational measures and the fact that Member States can give priority to sustainability and fair trade considerations.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The school fruit and school milk programmes are two European initiatives created for the distribution of fresh fruit and vegetables and milk products in schools. Thanks to the proposal for a regulation voted on today, the two programmes will be merged in order to make them more effective, reduce administrative burdens and improve overall results. In addition, the report provides for an increase of EUR 20 million in the annual funds for milk measures, a fairer distribution of funding among the Member States that decide to participate and a wider range of eligible products. Each country will be free to choose which fresh products and milk products to distribute, so as to give priority to those produced locally and regionally. The statistics speak for themselves: more than 20 million European children are overweight and adolescents eat on average only 30 or 50% of the recommended daily dose of fruit and vegetables. I believe that it is essential to make students and teachers aware of the importance of healthy and balanced nutrition, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 The acquisition of eating habits that promote better health, especially among younger populations, should be part of the objectives of public policies. The agreement on the new scheme to support the distribution of fruit and milk in schools is a public investment in this regard. In addition, a two-way objective is to encourage the demand for agricultural products from short circuits, thus favouring local agricultural production. I am pleased with the positive discrimination granted to the outermost regions, which, under certain conditions, may enjoy a higher level of aid, supply difficulties or adverse market conditions. This device may prove particularly important at this time of crisis in the sectors concerned, in particular in the milk sector and for the Azores, functioning as a contribution to the disposal of products and thus a price guarantee for milk producers.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ We do want school-children to be well nourished, but we opposed this because, even if you think taxpayers should contribute, these things should not be done centrally by Brussels.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk continues to decline in Europe. At the same time, more than 20 million children are overweight and young people eat on average only 30 to 50% of the recommended daily intake of fruit and vegetables. That is why EU programmes are so important: School Milk and School Vegetables and Fruit. Parliament's success is to win an additional €20 million a year for milk-related programmes, which will increase annual funding for milk and milk products to €100 million, with a budget of €150 million for fruit and vegetables. It is also a good idea to increase budgetary flexibility. In the area of transfer between programmes, it has been decided that Member States will be able to transfer 20% from one programme to another, and an additional 5% of the carry-over will be possible in the event of an emergency, difficult situation, such as low consumption or market situation, and this is what we are currently facing, for example, in the milk market. It is good that both programmes provide for a ban on sweeteners and artificial flavour enhancers. As a rule, products containing added sugar, salt and fat will also be banned, which should also have a positive health and educational effect. Finally, it is a good move to increase the promotion of the EU in these programmes, which, after all, funds them. In these difficult times for the Community, any form of emphasis on its actions for the benefit of citizens is needed.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Some great work from my colleague, Marc Tarabella, on this report: It really highlights the positive contribution that the Common Agricultural Policy can have in the development of healthy eating for children, and it promotes sustainable, local agricultural products. Impressively, the current scheme benefits nearly 30 million children across the EU per year, and the funding for this has increased to €150 million per year from 2014 to 2020.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ I consider it very important that we promote the health and healthy eating habits of our children from an early age. Among other things, this legislative adjustment increases the budget for this programme by EUR 20 million, to EUR 250 million. At the same time, it is an appropriate way of supporting farmers. For this reason, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ Daily consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables is an important eating habit. The aim of the proposal for a support scheme for the delivery of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational institutions, which I have readily supported, is to establish a supply chain for children starting their primary education and need nutritionally rich food. More frequent cases of childhood obesity at this age have led to the development of fresh food delivery programmes to schools around the world, and the European Union is providing funding for the smooth supply of fresh fruit and vegetables in all Member States through this Regulation. Emphasis is also placed on the delivery of local and regional products, which will have a beneficial impact on the operations of farms, orchards and gardens in each Member State. There is also no education of children about an important healthy diet involving local farmers. It is necessary to educate children from an early age about healthy eating, and this program will ensure, since it brings them into direct contact with producers, and also with good practices of distribution of fresh fruits, vegetables and milk.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the resolution because I believe that an aid scheme for the provision of fruit, vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments can contribute to meeting short- and long-term consumption targets for selected agricultural products more effectively. I also think that with this regulation we will be able to increase the consumption of fruit and vegetables, improve eating habits in schools and stop unwanted increases in obesity and health problems in children and young people. It regrets that, despite the existing school programmes, we continue to see a decreasing tendency to consume fresh fruit and vegetables and drinking milk in educational establishments. I therefore think it is right that the Member States should give priority to these products, but from my point of view it would be right that, in the interests of balanced school meals, we should also focus on the administration of other dairy products, such as yoghurts and cheeses, which also have a beneficial impact on children's health. I expect that, by delivering more effectively the aid scheme for the provision of fruit, vegetables and milk in educational establishments, we will be able to contribute more not only to promoting healthy eating habits and to the consumption of local products, but also to further boosting the declining production of fruit and vegetables in the EU.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report amending the Commission proposal for a regulation aimed at promoting the supply of fruit, vegetables and milk to schools. The amended Regulation combines two existing programmes, 'School Milk' (1977) and 'School Fruit' (2009), and creates a new common financial and legal framework for them. In addition to supporting the supply of products, the new arrangements are intended to provide space for further education in this area, i.e. to motivate children to eat healthier on their own. The project budget alloes EUR 150 million for the 'fruit and vegetables' programme and EUR 100 million for the 'dairy' programme (with a 20 % limited possibility of realmming the funds). These funds are to be allocated among The Member States primarily according to the number of children aged between 6 and 10 years in that state, but this also takes into account, for example, the more complex accessibility of certain regions. Compared to the original proposal, the report extends the list of subsidised products to include certain processed foods (e.g. yoghurts), which is good, because otherwise the new arrangements would limit programmes that are already operating successfully in the Member States. I consider the arrangements under discussion to be beneficial for promoting a healthier lifestyle. Last but not least, the proposal also provides support for local agricultural production, with which it links the programmes.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In the period 2005-2010, consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables as well as dairy products decreased, especially among children. In addition, the number of children with overweight and obesity has increased. Educational institutions play an important role in the diet of children and young people, which is why the Commission introduced a school milk scheme and a school fruit and vegetable scheme years ago. In 2014, the Commission proposed to merge these two schemes into a single aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational institutions. This scheme promotes healthy eating habits and contributes to the consumption of locally produced products. In addition, funding will be increased and better distributed between countries. The products to be sold under the school scheme will not contain added sugars and added artificial flavour enhancers. When selecting products, Member States will also take into account objective seasonality criteria and health and environmental considerations. They will promote local or regional purchasing, organic products and short supply chains. I agree that the supply of healthy, fresh and local food products to educational institutions is essential, which is why I voted in favour of the report and therefore supported the proposal to amend the regulation on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit, vegetables and milk to educational establishments.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal for a regulation bringing together the two existing schemes for the financing of aid for the distribution of fruit and vegetables and milk in schools, because I believe it is important to actively promote healthy eating habits and the consumption of local products, especially in the face of the spread of childhood obesity. The aim of the measure is to encourage the distribution in schools of fresh, local and un processed fruit and vegetables, in order to counter harmful eating habits geared to the consumption of processed food products, containing excessive doses of sugars, salt, fats and other additives. This resolution will make it possible to manage the two existing aid schemes more efficiently by bringing them together in a single programme, which should be touted as an EU initiative and thus make visible the commitment of the European institutions to support concrete action to promote the health and well-being of young schoolchildren.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'This report on school milk and fruit combines two existing programmes into a consistent whole and allocates EUR 230 million per school year. Yoghurt, cheese and juices are also allowed. It is important that the fruit is produced as seasonally and as locally as possible. In addition to health aspects, education is particularly important, focusing on healthy food, local food chains, organic farming, sustainable food production and food waste. Millions of children have benefited from the measure since the introduction of these programmes in 1971. And that's a good thing, because research shows that in Flanders only 7% of 6 to 14-year-olds eat enough fruit and vegetables every day. The funds for the milk programme have been increased and are in addition to the funds that national authorities have to allocate to this purpose. Despite the fact that The Member States also want to allow added fruit and chocolate flavour, it is positive that the EU will only pay for the part of milk. The addition shall be borne by the Member State and the added products must be pre-approved. Added sugars, fats and salt should only be made if they are necessary for the production process. For the first time, certain flavour enhancers and sweeteners (E620 to 650) are no longer allowed. Good!

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. Mr Tarabella's report deals with the existing school milk and fruit programmes, which finance dairy products and fruit under the European Agricultural Policy and distribute them to schools. The report aims to extend the programmes and increase the total budget to EUR 250 million per year. As a family-friendly party, ALFA supports healthy child nutrition. However, in line with the principle of subsidiarity, ALFA sees no reason for children's nutrition programmes to be funded and regulated by the EU. According to the report, the taxpayer first pays into the EU budget, then the EU Commission decides which products can be extracted from which ingredients in order to transfer the tax revenue back to the Member States later, i.e. to finance the food programmes from EU funds. If the Länder and individual municipalities believe that such programmes are needed, they could make this much more effective without having to co-finance the EU apparatus. Personally, I firmly believe that it is above all the responsibility of parents to take care of their children's nutrition and that parents do not need training from the European Commission. I have therefore rejected the above-mentioned report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables is currently declining, especially in children. Therefore, as a result of unhealthy eating habits, the incidence of obesity in children increases, as foods high in sugar, fat and additives are preferred. It is therefore necessary to provide assistance in the form of promoting the consumption of selected products, thus contributing to the promotion of healthy eating habits in our children.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ In the current context of d'fewer consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and dairy products, especially among children, and increasingly frequent childhood obesity caused by consumer habits geared towards products that often contain large amounts of added sugar, salt, fat or additives, Union support to finance the supply of selected agricultural products in educational establishments should contribute more to promoting healthy eating habits and consumption of local products. The analysis of the different policy options indicates that a single approach under the common legal and financial framework is more appropriate and effective in achieving the specific objectives that the Common Agricultural Policy seeks to achieve through the school product distribution programme. This would allow Member States to maximise the impact of distribution within an unchanged budget and increase governance efficiency, and I therefore supported the report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which benefits both British children and local British agricultural producers. The current schemes benefit nearly 30 million children per year across the EU and their funding has been increased to EUR 150 million a year (2014-2020). In 2012-13, the UK received GBP 3.3 million worth of EU aid for the milk scheme, supplemented by GBP 0.9 million of national subsidy. This illustrates a significant overall benefit of the scheme for the UK taxpayer.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the regulation on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments. Healthy eating habits are an important factor in health and lifestyle, and young people are key to shaping them. I therefore welcome the merger of so far separate schemes for the distribution of milk, fruit and vegetables in schools and the granting of an additional €20 million to finance them and finance learning on healthy eating. I regret that few Member States have systematically organised and mandatory and universally available school meals in primary and secondary schools. This is particularly bad for children coming from poorly-fed families, as the quality of packed lunches that parents prepare themselves is highly dependent on the socio-economic situation of families. Therefore, more should be done to promote and promote universal free school meals, e.g. through projects to find best practices in the EU and mutual learning and with financial support from relevant European funds or programmes.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I fully accept the benefits of providing fresh fruit, vegetables and milk for school-age children, and I recognise the importance of educating children about the value of healthy eating. Sourcing products locally is also a practice I welcome, and one that I believe we need to continue to promote, in order to support our farmers in sectors like dairy during difficult times. However, from a subsidiarity perspective, I am concerned about the delivery of this project at an EU level. I believe that such schemes would be more effectively, and more efficiently, delivered within the Member States, in particular, those components on educating children about eating habits. I therefore opted to abstain at the vote on this scheme today.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important to provide fruit and vegetables and milk in schools, especially now that the economic crisis, especially in southern Europe, does not allow proper nutrition for children. Also, special weight to be given to remote areas where some of the products can be produced.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that encouraging children to eat healthily is essential, which is why I voted in favour of this report. In the future, milk, fruit and vegetables and the banana meal package will be a joint programme in educational institutions. On the one hand, I am pleased that there is a single action at EU level, since the EU is much more effective in some cases than the Member States individually. On the other hand, I find it shameful that some Member States cannot resolve this on their own and, by doing so, give up on children. I believe that only a single action at EU level can remedy member states' inaction. When implementing the programme in the Member States, a public consultation is needed to ensure the use of high-quality local products in the programme. It is regrettable that some Member States cannot solve this on their own and are therefore renouncing the health of children. Not only is the Hungarian Government unable to solve healthy meals for children, but shamefully it charges food, including products intended for children's meals, with a VAT rate of 27%. Given the central logic of the design of the programme, I believe that not only should we not be afraid of the idea of common VAT-free food at EU level, but it is high time that it was finally implemented in the interests of citizens!

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 How education systems within EU Member States ensure the harmonious development of children is an expression of the degree to which we are concerned about the future of our societies. One of the important components of this system is to ensure minimum nutritional intake during school hours. Thus, scientific studies have established that it is necessary to encourage the consumption of fruit (including bananas) and vegetables, but also milk, i.e. healthy, fresh and underprocessed foods, produced locally, including yogurts and cheeses.  At the same time, the presence of sweeteners and artificial flavourings, sugars, salts and fats in the school diet should be reduced to the maximum in order to avoid the incidence of obesity. They could be replaced by products such as honey, olives and olive oil. The European Union supports the integrated approach to this food scheme in Member States' schools with the help of national authorities. In this respect, significant financial resources of around EUR 250 000 are mobilised for each national school year. That measure supports the development of marginal European regions and can be assessed after at least six years. The current report is a very important document for the future of our children and can be adopted in its current form.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Thirty million children will eat healthier! Indeed, the European Parliament's vote was the final legislative stage of the "Tarabella Report", a new legislation that will allow a simple and free distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools in all European countries throughout the year. I started from an alarming observation: only 12% of Belgians and 36% of Europeans eat their 5 fruits and vegetables a day, while one in three European children is overweight or obese.  My goal was therefore multiple: to offer healthy food from an early age, to establish a pedagogy around food, to fight against obesity, but also to promote short circuits and local and regional products. Today's vote is great news for the health of the 30 million schoolchildren who will benefit from it and for short circuits.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that merging these two schemes will allow more coherence and more effective implementation. The text stressed the importance of the continuation and strengthening of the two school schemes in the current context of declining consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and milk products, especially among children, and of an increasing incidence of child obesity as a result of consumption habits geared to highly processed food. However, in order to promote the consumption of specific products and to respond to particular nutritional needs of children in its territory, a certain flexibility has been introduced in order for Member States to promote their products.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. As overweight becomes a real public health problem, the European Parliament is committed to 30 million European schoolchildren being able to benefit from fresh fruit and vegetables, as well as the distribution of milk in schools.  Thanks to our mobilization we have managed to unlock 250 million euros in order to distribute free of charge in schools healthy products, from local productions and short circuits. While only 36% of Europeans eat 5 fruits and vegetables a day, the programme will be accompanied by awareness-raising policies to encourage European schoolchildren to adopt better nutritional practices.  Of course, this will not put an end to the European agricultural crisis, which has been the result of liberal deregulation, which has caused prices to fall and put our producers at risk. However, in the context of this violent crisis for our farmers, the promotion of short circuits is one of the levers to develop new models of sustainable agriculture. I am also pleased that, in terms of the distribution of milk in schools, we have provided an additional EUR 430 million in 2016, in order to intensify our purchases and thus help European producers.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 A healthy diet contributes to better health but fruit, vegetable and milk consumption is declining across the EU. Member States must do more to promote healthy eating habits, organic farming, local food supply chains and the fight against food waste. We need to strengthen the school fruit, vegetable and milk programme by increasing its budget and focusing more on food education. Each Member State should also provide for accompanying educational measures to bring children closer to agriculture and healthy and quality products.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report by Mr Tarabella, a Member of the European Parliament, for two reasons. This report proposes solutions to contribute to the programme in relation to aid for the provision of fruit and vegetables to educational establishments. This is very important, as a decrease in the consumption of these products among children has recently been observed. And this is directly related to the health of young people. Our actions should contribute more to promoting healthy eating habits for children and adolescents. It is also important that the strengthening of that programme will directly contribute to the recovery of the agricultural sector by increasing the need for agricultural products identified in the report. It is very good that the proposed programme is directed at all Member States. It is important to specifically assist new Member States, such as Lithuania, where the increase in the production of healthy food specialised in this country will be able to strengthen the programme for the supply of healthy food to educational establishments.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) I supported Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 as regards the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments, as I believe that the consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and dairy products is declining sharply in the current time, especially among children, and the number of overweight children is increasing, precisely because of poor eating habits. In addition, foods are heavily processed and contain a lot of added sugar, salt, fat or additives. I believe that we must contribute more to promoting healthy eating habits and the consumption of locally produced products, which is certainly a regulation that is governed by this regulation.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report for the restructuring of aid schemes for the consumption of fruit and vegetables and bananas and milk in schools, as these have a very positive impact on society inso as they promote healthy eating at an early age and seek to establish direct links between the two ends of the food chain , producer and consumer, enhancing the local primary sector. In addition, two productive sectors – dairy and fruit and vegetable – are indirectly promoted, representing approximately 30% of the Union's agricultural production.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. Mr Tarabella's report deals with the existing school milk and fruit programmes, which finance dairy products and fruit under the European Agricultural Policy and distribute them to schools. On the basis of the report, the programmes are to be extended and the total budget increased to EUR 250 million per year. As a family-friendly party, ALFA supports healthy child nutrition. However, in line with the principle of subsidiarity, ALFA sees no reason for children's nutrition programmes to be funded and regulated by the EU. According to the report, the taxpayer first pays into the EU budget, then the EU Commission decides which products can be extracted from which ingredients in order to transfer the tax revenue back to the Member States later, i.e. to finance the food programmes from EU funds. If the Länder and individual municipalities believe that such programmes are needed, they could make this much more effective without having to co-finance the EU apparatus. Personally, I firmly believe that it is above all the responsibility of parents to take care of their children's nutrition and that parents do not need training from the European Commission. I have therefore rejected the above-mentioned report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ It is essential that children have a good education on healthy food. It is good that schools also encourage healthy eating habits and consumption of fruit and vegetables, and that this is encouraged in the European diet. I invite all Members to join this initiative, which is a long-term investment to have a healthier population in our Member States.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This vote is the result of bitter negotiations, including a stormy trilogue. Mr Tarabella had even sent a letter, co-signed by all the ENF groups included, to protest against the effect of the expulsion of Parliament wanted by the Commission and the Council on this subject. This programme is a good measure: it organises the distribution of fruits and vegetables, bananas and dairy products in schools. Member States remain in control of their sovereignty over the subject, and can thus promote the use of local products, and engage in a form of national and/or regional food patriotism. I voted for this text.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 Originally under the common agricultural policy in the 1970s and aimed at supporting farmers and milk producers, the European School Milk Programme, which was joined in 2009 by the Fruit in Schools programme, currently focuses on the objective of healthy eating, in the context of which Citizens of the European Union are facing problems such as obesity and diabetes. In the European Union, 14 million children are overweight, with the number increasing annually by 400 000, while in Romania 13.7% of children aged 2-14 are obese and 8.8% overweight. Furthermore, in recent years there has been a decrease in consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables, as well as dairy products, especially in children. It is therefore important that the supply of fruit, vegetables and milk to educational institutions is maintained. In order to better manage the two programmes, the new regulation proposes merging them and increasing the budget by EUR 20 million per year to EUR 250 million. In addition, for a fair allocation of funds, account will be taken of the number of children aged 6 to 10 years, as well as the level of development of the regions in each Member State.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The experience gained in applying the current programmes, the conclusions of the external evaluations and the subsequent analysis of the different policy options and the social difficulties of the Member States show that the continuation and strengthening of both school programmes is of the utmost importance. Consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and dairy products is on a downward trend today, especially among children, while the number of morbidly obese children is increasing due to the increasing preference for highly processed foods, often rich in added sugar, salt, fat or additives. It is therefore important that EU support to finance the allocation of certain specific agricultural products to children in educational establishments will better promote healthy eating habits and the consumption of local products. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report for the restructuring of aid schemes for the consumption of fruit and vegetables and bananas and milk in schools, as these have a very positive impact on society inso as they promote healthy eating at an early age and seek to establish direct links between the two ends of the food chain , producer and consumer, enhancing the local primary sector. In addition, two productive sectors – dairy and fruit and vegetable – are indirectly promoted, representing approximately 30% of the Union's agricultural production.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this dossier because, among other reasons, the Council conceded to Parliament that all budgetary measures relating to this file should be decided by co-decision (Article 43(2)) and not by the Council alone. This is an important procedural victory, after the Council refused to negotiate on the budgetary aspects of CAP reform, and we intend to use it as a precedent for future files. I also voted in favour because the text also provides a number of important safeguards. Firstly, the EU will only pay for the milk part of the product, i.e. the added flavouring would have to be paid for by the Member State. Secondly, national health authorities must approve the list of products to be distributed. Thirdly, added salt, sugar and fat can only be added to the extent that they are technically necessary to manufacture the product, and must be approved by national health authorities. Finally, and for the first time, added sweeteners and added flavour enhancers (E620 to 650) are banned entirely from the programme.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Colleagues, I welcome the proposal for a regulation unification of school milk and school fruit and vegetable schemes. The new rules, to be applied from the 2017-2018 school year, will encourage the consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables, milk and dairy products by the youngest pupils from the age of six to 10 and increase their knowledge of the origin of food and healthy eating.  In the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, we fought for a larger budget for school milk (an additional EUR 20 million), ing the total budget under the two schemes for one school year amounting to EUR 250 million. European. We have put a strong emphasis on educational measures to educate knowledge about the origin of food and healthy eating, local food chains, organic farming, sustainable production and the fight against food waste. We have expanded the range of products to be included in the students' menu, including honey, yogurt and cheese.  Small producers are directly affected by the crisis in the milk sector and the difficulties in the fruit and vegetable market. For this reason, I consider it necessary to prioritise local production, short supply chains, organic and seasonal products when preparing national rules for the application of the Regulation.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – Additional educational measures need to be put in place to support product allocation in order to effectively achieve the short- and long-term objectives of the programme, in order to increase the consumption of selected agricultural products and to develop healthier eating habits.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: Writing. – Milk and fruit programmes for schools are a great way to teach healthy eating habits that children unfortunately do not always learn at home. The statistics show that children eat unhealthy and move too little: more than 20 million children in the EU are overweight and teenagers eat only 30% to 50% of the average recommended amount of fruit and vegetables per day. The situation in Latvia is not very encouraging : studies show that one in four first-class is overweight. I am therefore pleased to have the opportunity to allocate an additional 20 million from the EU's annual budget programmes 'School Milk' and 'Fruit for School'. In view of the increased funding and revised criteria for allatiation, including the level of development of the regions, we can expect latvian schools to benefit. I believe that this programme should not only provide products in schools, but also promote healthier eating habits, stimulate local food chains, organic farming, sustainable production and the fight against food waste. Schools should also ensure that children are kept in a link with agriculture, for example by visiting farms.  I trust that this programme will also be an immediate and long-term support for our farmers, who are currently facing difficulties in marketing products, particularly in the dairy sector.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report supporting the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments. In the context of the declining consumption of healthy food, particularly among children, and the increasing number of child obesity cases, the report calls for simpler procedures as well as additional funding for schools that offer children free milk and fruit. The scheme is voluntary and works towards the promotion of a healthy diet, organic farming, local food and the reduction of food waste.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a proposal that reorients the current organisation of the two programmes currently in force towards achieving long-term objectives and strengthens the educational dimension of both regimes and helps connect young Europeans with food and its sources, as well as unifying and consolidating the legal and financial frameworks of both programmes , currently separated, and increase the visibility of EU intervention, maximising efficiency, management and coherence with the CAP. It is a very positive proposal to boost the consumption of these products of great importance to the EU and for the European children to acquire healthier eating habits. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative report. The current schemes benefit nearly 30 million children per year across the EU, and their funding has been increased to EUR 150 million a year (2014-2020). In 2012-13, the UK received GBP 3.3 million worth of EU aid for the milk scheme, supplemented by GBP 0.9 million of national subsidy. Such a breakdown of funding illustrates a significant overall benefit of the scheme for the UK taxpayer. UK dairy farmers enjoy the benefits of the EU milk scheme, which generates additional, stable demand for milk and dairy products. This could be particularly important now, with the continued downturn in the dairy sector. Nutrition for children is an investment in our long-term future, helping to prevent later chronic health issues.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. This aid scheme looks at the future of our children. Statistics show that children eat less and less fresh fruit and drink less milk. Current eating habits all too often lead to childhood obesity and that has to stop. It is therefore up to the European Commission to step up now. It has to promote local products and that includes yoghurt, cheese, juices and soup. This European support is also a good thing for our local fruit growers, because local fruit is included in the aid measures.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The idea behind this program is positive. However, the way it will be put into practice can make all the difference. We do not understand, first of all, why the two programmes were merged in absentia from the opinion of technicians who preferred the existence of two separate and autonomous programmes. Secondly, we stress here that this programme will only succeed if it is firmly anchored to a local development strategy, a strategy for valuing regional production and which can contribute to greater social and territorial cohesion, reconciling the city with its rural surroundings. Thirdly, it must be said that this strategy will be a failure if we continue with the aggressive presence of large food chains at school doors, or if we continue to have, even within schools, machines that dispense with all kinds of foods that nutritionists advise against healthy eating. The state and public school are a decisive element in this battle in defense of our children and young people.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The proposal not only contributes to a healthier diet for our school children, but also to support our local farmers. I therefore support this motion.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the union of the Fruit and Vegetables programme in schools and the 'School Milk' programme. I strongly believe that promoting the consumption of fresh and natural products in schools is a priority for developing correct eating habits, at a time of high levels of obesity. This text will ensure better effectiveness with a single programme in which the fruit and vegetable component and the milk component can be managed in parallel.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013 and Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational institutions. It is claimed that this report, by bringing together various EU subsidy rules, will lead to streamlined and improved legislation. The fact that this is a serious violation of the principle of subsidiarity is ignored. It is also a subsidy. We are really dealing here with one of the most absurd EU interventions: the subsidy of apples and milk for pupils by Brussels. And what's new is that there's school yoghurt now. No one can seriously think that this is an improvement.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament for a programme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments, increasing funding by EUR 20 million per year. Unfortunately, there is a downward trend in the EU regarding the consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk, especially in children and adolescents aged 6 to 10 years. This trend is driven by the increasing proportion of children struggling with overweight, obesity and lactose intolerance for dairy products. Given the length of time children spend at school, it is crucial to use increased funding in institutions to provide children with milk and fruit. It would target both distribution and activities promoting health-promoting eating habits that take into account the consumption of local products.  Member States that join this voluntary aid scheme will commit to promoting healthier eating habits, local food, organic farming and the fight against food waste. Children should also have a better understanding of what breeding and cultivation is all about, for example through visits to farms.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this important report, linking child nutrition with health and wellbeing. It highlights the positive contribution of the EU and the CAP to development of healthy eating habits among children and promotion of sustainable local agricultural products. This is particularly important in the run-up to the EU membership referendum. The current schemes benefit nearly 30 million children per year across the EU and their funding has been increased to EUR 150 million a year (2014-2020). I would like to emphasise the link between proper nutrition and readiness to learn, and educational achievement. I come from a family of teachers and I myself have worked in early-years education, with children from the most deprived urban and rural communities in the UK. I know first-hand the listlessness and attention-deficit that accompanies child hunger. The shameful removal of free school milk from British primary schools in 1971 by the Conservatives earned Margaret Thatcher the eternal nickname of ‘Thatcher the Snatcher’. She proved that Member State governments do not always have the best interests of the child at heart. So thank goodness for progressive and compassionate politicians here working for the greater good of future generations in Europe.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Written. \u2012 The bill aims to bring together the EU's school milk and fruit programmes into a common programme. In addition, in connection with the merger of the programmes, additional products in addition to fresh milk have been added. It is commendable to simplify legislation, but I believe that it is not a European competence to be responsible for school milk and school fruit. Here, the Member States must be responsible. Given this, I have chosen to vote against the report as a whole.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of this report to direct existing funds towards providing milk and other healthy products for schools. This EU money is already available and using it to help nourish children, some of whom are in desperate need of good nutrition, is exactly what we should be using EU funding for.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational institutions, because it is absolutely necessary to educate our children according to healthy eating habits. Unfortunately, according to European statistics, more than 20 million children in Europe are currently overweight and adolescents consume on average only 30% to 50% of the recommended daily intake of fruit and vegetables. The report proposes to combine milk and fruit schemes in the EU, with the annual budget of the new scheme to increase by EUR 20 million to EUR 250 million. Between 2013 and 2014, around 10 million children in the EU benefited from the EU School Fruit Scheme and around 19 million benefited from the milk scheme.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report by Mr Marc Tarabella of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. This report concerns, among other things, the very crucial issue of combating malnutrition among minors, but also the important issue of proper nutrition for children and the fight against childhood obesity. As the EU we must ensure that citizens have acquired rights and benefits in a transparent, quality and secure manner.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. As the report rightly points out, in recent years consumption of fruits, vegetables and dairy products has declined considerably among the young people of the EU. This is worrying, as it means that this sector of the population is not eating too healthy, which will undoubtedly negatively influence their health and school performance. For this reason, I am fully confident in the proposal for this report, as it will not only improve the quality of life of students, but will also be very positive for producers. The latter will have a new niche of customers, which will contribute to the increase in their income.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the food health education programme in lower schools across Europe. This proposal, strongly desired by the S&D Group, provides for the allocation of a European fund that will allow schools to obtain free healthy food and products from local companies to offer children. Each Member State will have to have a regulation on this. I believe that with this act the European Union is taking another important step towards ensuring the health of its citizens. I also find it particularly useful that the products supplied come from the territory, as a guarantee of quality and respect for the environment.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Regulation is not intended to provide free lunch to school pupils, but to strengthen and subsidise food processing business groups. In fact, it defiantly states that its aim is to foster "healthy eating habits" in children, at a time when the barbaric unpopular POLICY of the EU and governments is constantly forcing thousands of grassroots families to send their children to school. The real objective of the EU, with this regulation, is to subsidise large dairy companies and food packaging, processing and marketing monopolies. That is why in the subsidised products the regulation made sure to include various processed fruit and vegetables, milk drinks with fruit, cocoa, etc., i.e. those products that the companies concerned promote for consumption at young ages, in order to increase their customers and advertise them even by getting a subsidy! And all this not for the whole year but by sampling, just 20 pieces of fruit and 4-5 euros per year for each child. The labour-grassroots movement to claim the daily provision of a free meal to all school pupils, from the state budget, by opposing the unpopular EU and government policy and their falsified programmes to strengthen monopolies.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report, which contains many changes that will lead to a better and more comprehensive functioning of the project to promote the supply of fruit, vegetables and milk to educational establishments. The consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables in children is constantly decreasing, and therefore I consider it necessary to change this trend, and I consider projects of this type to be a very effective tool. As mentioned in the report, Member States need to develop long-term strategies in this area or, where appropriate, follow up on the initiative on already functioning national programmes with the same focus. I also agree that local and regional products should be supported in projects and offered to children in schools.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the report proposing the merger of two projects, School Fruit and School Milk. These projects have already been successfully implemented in most Member States in the past and their linking under one scheme has been decided mainly in order to increase efficiency and reduce the administrative burden. In addition to these benefits, the new proposal also brought an extension of the assortment that will be provided to children in schools, in particular the possibility for Member States to include local, regional or national specialties such as honey, or olives in southern European countries. Another novelty of the common scheme is lactose-free products, which were included in response to a growing percentage of children suffering from lactose intolerance. In addition to the distribution of milk, dairy products and fruit, so-called accompanying measures have been adopted in these projects to help build a positive relationship between children and healthy eating through various educational activities. And while I believe that children should be led to the right eating habits, especially at home, I hope that the project will help to increase the rapidly decreasing consumption of fruit and milk in schoolchildren and reduce the growing problem of childhood obesity in Europe.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. \u2012 This vote by the European Parliament, which invests in the health of our children, is very important. Today, unfortunately, the consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk is falling sharply throughout the Union. Hence the bet to encourage their consumption, starting with schools, also focusing on training in food education. It is good not only to increase the budget allocated to this measure, but also to prohibit Member States from unilaterally cutting their budgets or substantially changesing the criteria for allocating allocated Community funds. Betting on the well-being of children is very important for the future of our countries.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Tarabella report on the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments because I believe that the proposal presented promotes the consumption of healthy and fresh foods by school-age children, helping them to establish healthy eating habits. Under this scheme, Member States will be able to distribute milk and other dairy products such as natural yogurt and cheese and include other local, regional or national specialities such as honey, table olives and olive oil.  As for products containing the addition of sugar, salt and fat, as a general rule, they will be prohibited and may only be allowed after they have been authorised by national health authorities.  Finally, the administration of the scheme will now be more efficient because it will work through a single programme, which merges the milk programme with the fruit and vegetable chain programme.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. – In a continent where 26% of adults are now overweight, it is necessary to start again from schools in order to educate young people to have a healthy, responsible and sustainable diet, a diet where added sugars and salts are present as little as possible. I am satisfied that the program to bring fruit and vegetables to school canteens for children between 6 and 11 years old meets the requirements for which I have fought. Sustainability, seasonality, locality, ethical production and absence of additives will now be the criteria for food selection for our children. I am pleased that educational measures to support the simple distribution of fresh and locally sourced products have not been overlooked, in order to make students understand the benefits and benefits of a healthy and balanced lifestyle. I voted in favour of a programme that will bring to Italy some 16.7 million for fruit and vegetable programmes, plus a further 8 million for milk programmes. This is almost 25 million, up from 21.5 million in 2015. A great result. Now that the programme is in place, we must ensure that it is applied in the best possible way at national and local level.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. Data show that consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk is declining across Europe, while 20 million children in the EU are overweight, while adolescents eat on average only 30 to 50 per cent of the recommended daily intake of fruit and vegetables. That is why I supported the proposal for new legislation on the financing of a scheme for the distribution of milk, fruit and vegetables in schools and the introduction of learning about healthy eating. I believe that the scheme will help to promote awareness of healthy eating habits and to the consumption of locally produced products.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Madam President, I supported the calls made by Scottish ports and trade unionists, as did the rest of the European Parliamentary Labour Party, to reject this proposal. We believe a one—size—fits—all proposal does not recognise the diversity and complexity of ports across the European Union, and particularly in the UK and Scotland. Although the proposed piece of law will now enter a negotiation process, it is important that MEPs in the negotiating team and those representing the Council, where the UK Government has a say, recognise the UK’s legitimate concerns on this issue. There is some way to go before this House will vote on a final proposal so let us make sure that in this time the necessary exemptions for UK ports are included in the negotiation and hopefully a good result will come forward.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, whilst my West Midlands constituency is the only landlocked one in the UK, it is, however, a hotbed of manufacturing which relies on ports to export our wares. This is the third time the Commission has attempted to modernise port services and, I am afraid, it has still not got it right. My reservations about the latest proposals are that they fail to recognise the diversity of the port sector in the EU and they have equally failed to mitigate the environmental impact of ports. However, my concerns are focused primarily on employment rights and in particular the right to strike and the legal challenges which trade unions might face. I believe that this draft instrument is a blunt instrument, with the potential for the social elements being watered down still further during the trilogue process. For this reason, like my other Labour colleagues, I voted against this report.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, this directive precisely illustrates why Britain would be better off outside the European Union. Here is a directive that simply does not take account of the specificities and particularisms of our country.  European ports for the most part are much larger and much further apart than British ones. Ours tend to be small and thickly dotted along the coast. They compete with each other and they are not state owned or state subsidised. On the country, they generate a large surplus for the Exchequer. So, although there may be a case for a measure of internal competition in giant ports like Antwerp and Rotterdam – even if there is, I am not sure it has got anything to do with Brussels, but let us allow that there might be – it plainly does not affect a situation like ours, where you already have lots of competition among private ports. Why were private ports not exempted? Because the whole issue has been held hostage in this dispute about state funding between the Commission and the Parliament. Thus we see an important industry like ours being ruined in somebody else’s argument.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, I voted against the port service package today, as there are few tangible benefits for North-East ports, their workers or the environment. The proposed legislation has missed the opportunity to include strong employment and environmental provisions, and Labour MEPs will continue to work with the UK’s ports industry and trade unions to oppose this unnecessary legislation. However, we should remember that under all current models in which the UK has access to the single market these are exactly the type of regulations that we would have to adhere to, and we would have no voice or vote to challenge them if we left the EU. If we are to have a say in the EU and on its regulations both as a country and as a region, it is absolutely vital that we remain inside the EU, not just for jobs, investment and rights, but also for the future of our ports.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: – Madam President, if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it. That is a wise old saying in English, which sadly seems to have been lost in translation with the European Commission. British ports are world—class in service, performance and efficiency, and the way to compete globally is to reward excellence, not to level down the playing field. Unfortunately, the port services regulation does exactly that. It is another example of one-size-fits-all legislation that threatens to blunt the commercial edge of Britain’s ports. This tidal wave of red tape and bureaucracy means that Hull, Immingham and Grimsby in my constituency risk damaging their hard—earned competitiveness, compromising future investment and growth. I voted against this legislation and will continue to support the unions and employers who are working together to create a new sense of optimism in my region.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Of course, both historically and today, ports play a huge, extremely important role on the european union's farm, and it is clear that a clearer, fairer system of governance is quite welcome. For example, as we know, recently the Commission launched an investigation into cases of financial support for French, Dutch, Belgian ports, and of course we need new rules, but we cannot ignore national specificities, and we cannot ignore the fact that we cannot put on the same shelf that, for example, the port of Rotterdam in the Netherlands and such a small, very micro-port port in Sculte, my country, Latvia. And it is clear that national specificities also play a huge role in the operation of the port. And we cannot forget about workers' rights, too, because trade unions tell us that it is absolutely impossible to unify. That is why I voted in favour of the postponement.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – It is important to have strict and clear accounting rules for ports in the trans-European transport network. It is important to have competition and transparency in port activities. We don't want monopoly and we don't want smuggling. We want them to end. The procedure for choosing port service providers must be public and transparent, all interested parties must have access to procedures and the result must be made public.  This is also very important for Romania, where we have ports in Braila, In Constanta, in Galați, in Sulina, all of which are included in the TEN-T network. So we want transparency, advertising, no smuggling, no monopoly, and we want strict and very clear accounting rules and also very clear rules of procedure.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sa tuarascáil seo agus is dóigh liom go bhfuil a lán moltaí maithe ann agus is maith an rud é go bhfuilimid ag díriú ar oscailteacht agus soiléireacht inár gcalafort agus freisin gur ceart aitheantas a thabhairt do chearta na n-oibrithe iontu. Ar an taobh eile don scéal tá sé tábhachtach go gcuimhneoimid ar cad a tharla i bPáras i COP 21 agus an dúshlán atá romhainn chun astaíochtaí a laghdú amach anseo. Agus chun na targaidí sin a chomhlíonadh beidh orainn díriú is dóigh liom ar na calafoirt ach go háirithe. Agus i m’áit féin tá calafort iontach againn, Sionainn-Faing atá níos doimhne ná an chuid is mó de na calafoirt san Eoraip agus d'fhéadfadh sé mórán a dhéanamh maidir le trálaeirí agus longa ollmhóra a thabhairt isteach nach féidir teacht isteach ina lán calafoirt eile agus fiú féachaint orthu siúd chomh maith.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposed regulatory framework will make it possible to combat weak competitive pressure and possible market abuses, in order to increase the efficiency of port services. I would like to insist on the concept of independent supervision, which consists of providing an independent complaint mechanism. All users must be consulted and informed and must be able to complain to independent bodies.  The Italian transport system is weighed down by important and unresolved structural problems due to the weakness of the regulatory and planning framework and the modesty of private partnerships in the construction of new infrastructures. It is therefore comforting to know that the regulation adopted today, even if postponed for the final vote, should create legal certainty for ports and have a positive impact on the operation of transport networks There is time for the final vote and I hope that a way will be found to pay more attention to sustainable and environmentally friendly transport services, so as to contribute to better energy efficiency.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. – UKIP have voted against this proposal as the regulation does not take into account the commercial nature of UK ports.  In order to ensure that commercial ports are exempt from this regulation, UKIP put forward an amendment to Article 1.3.  It is important to ensure that ports are entitled to operate fully as commercial businesses; this regulation does not allow it.  Furthermore, the ambiguity of the text creates uncertainty and puts essential future investment, growth and jobs at risk.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP have voted against this proposal as the regulation does not take into account the commercial nature of UK ports.  In order to ensure that commercial ports are exempt from this regulation, UKIP put forward an amendment to Article 1.3.  It is important to ensure that ports are entitled to operate fully as commercial businesses; this regulation does not allow it.  Furthermore, the ambiguity of the text creates uncertainty and puts essential future investment, growth and jobs at risk.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. Parliament's report contains substantial improvements in relation to the Commission's proposal: for the third time, this House opposes the liberalisation of the port sector (although we fear that a new proposal in this regard will come in the coming months). In addition, work with European trade unions has made it possible to introduce recognition of vocational rights, health and occupational safety for port workers, although fringes remain in terms of the effective implementation of this standard and in aspects such as the protection of labour rights in the event of the transfer of port services. Despite this, some aspects of the Commission's initial proposal (in the financial transparency sections) open the door for competition policy to attack essential aspects of port financing and public management. That is why I have decided to abstain, pending the final proposal following negotiations with the Council.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 This report recognises the need to create a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports. The aim of the report is to enhance port development, the smooth functioning of the single market and to create an environment conducive to port and maritime activity, balancing the interests of port operators and port service users. At the same time, Member States are given a reasonable opportunity to decide for themselves on matters relating to the navigation service and ensure that social and labour rules are not affected by this report by ensuring additional training for port workers, avoiding possible accidents and ensuring the highest possible level of safety and health for workers in this area. It is generally moving in the right direction, as social standards are guaranteed and further liberalisation of the sector is halted.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Parliament has adopted a Commission proposal aimed at making a more efficient, better connected and sustainable trans-European transport network possible. This includes the modernisation of port services, such as.B. towing, sealing and refuelling services, and port operations, and the creation of an attractive environment for investment in ports. I am in favour of the Commission's aim with this regulation to counteract weak competitive pressure and possible market abuse in order to increase the efficiency of port services.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. After attacking the railways, the European Union aims to standardise and deregulate europe's major ports. The Committee on Transport to which I belong has issued amendments limiting the scope of this report by limiting its scope and the sectors concerned. These amendments were a good way. But that does not make the report good. I have obviously voted against the Commission's proposal which does not take into account the differences between European ports, which may have antipodean modes of operation and is once again seeking to liberalise a sector in spite of all common sense.  So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. I am gravely concerned that jobs could be lost at the Port of Tyne and Teesport if this controversial proposal passes through the European Parliament. This proposal will have a substantial impact on privately-owned ports. Most continental ports are in public ownership but most British ports are in private ownership. The United Kingdom will be the most affected. Ports will be forced to contract out services and appoint at least two service providers, even if only one is required. This will undermine the competitiveness of local ports in what is already a tough market. The proposed PSR would also undermine commercial confidentiality.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. This draft report is the first step towards fairer competition and reducing legal concerns for all seaports in the trans-European transport network. In addition, port package III represents a clear commitment to improve financial transparency for ports. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has moved forward with a proposal for a Regulation establishing a regulatory framework for access to port services and the financial transparency of ports. Through this Regulation, the European Commission intends to contribute essentially to increasing the efficiency and competitiveness of European ports within the Trans-European Transport Network. The production of European legislation that fits port activity is of great importance, as it contributes decisively to the standardisation of management practices and defines common general rules necessary for healthy competition between European ports. However, it was necessary to improve the initial proposal in order, among other issues, to protect port administrations greater room for manoeuvre and to strengthen the protection of workers. The rapporteur of the document we have just voted on has sought to remove these shortcomings by introducing amendments that have been supported by the S&D, Ppe, ALDE and GUE political groups. In view of the relevance of the legislation under consideration and its frank improvement that the amendments made to the TRAN Commission promote, I decided to vote in favour of the report under discussion.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. We abstain in the final vote on the third attempt to liberalise port services because, despite improving social aspects and, in particular, the surrogacy of staff, the approved text still makes a number of reservations to us.  We welcome the socialist proposal in favour of greater transparency in port funding sources, which will help to verify the State aid that ports in central and northern Europe receive, with more reason in matching this adoption with the Commission's new proposal to exempt aid to port infrastructure from ex ante control of competition. Likewise, in the face of the Commission's interest in deregulation of port tariffs, the Spanish Socialists follow the mandate of the current Spanish Constitution adopting these tariffs by congress, as it maintains in solidarity the current network of our ports, which would otherwise reduce their presence in the territory, without improving competition with European ports. Nevertheless, we prefer to abstain in the mandate from the rapporteur, who has recognised the Spanish peculiarity in working during the tripartite dialogues with the Council.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of postponing the consideration of this proposal and returning it to the Commission for improvement. There are currently different systems for the organisation of ports and port services, there are many disagreements and uncertainties, and the aspects of the Commission's proposal must be re-analysed and compromised.
