name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against the Commission's proposal to liberalise europe's major ports: our group had tabled a rejection amendment.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. There are 1,200 seaports in Europe, representing up to 3 million direct and indirect jobs. 96% of goods and 93% of passengers passing through EU ports do so through the 319 seaports listed in the Commission's proposal on the European Transport Network (TEN-T). The objective of this report, which I have approved, is to contribute to a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable operation of ten-T by creating a clear framework for access to the airport services market. The proposal also aims to establish common rules on financial transparency and fees to be applied by port managers or service providers.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I consider that this proposal for a Regulation on access to the port services market and the financial transparency of ports can be positive in some respects, such as that aimed at improving port performance in the European Union. However, other aspects, such as Article 14(3) of the Commission's proposal, are contrary to Spanish interests. This article provides for the autonomy of the port managing body to establish various issues such as the structure or level of port infrastructure fees in accordance with its own trading strategy and investment plan. It is Spain that these types of port fees are required for the special use of the port public domain. The Constitution provides that its establishment is subject to the principle of reservation of law and must therefore be fixed by the Congress of Deputies. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. 'With the adoption of the port regulation, we are laying the groundwork for a governance model that will make ports in Europe more customer-friendly and at the same time take into account the different ways in which our ports are already organising. The regulation improves access to port services and ensures greater financial transparency. It is important that the ports themselves, of course in a transparent way, can continue to set tariffs for the use of their services and infrastructure. Without causing additional red tape, the regulation guarantees fair competition.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union's port system consists of some 1,200 seaports which are a key resource for the continent's economy. In addition to providing 3 million jobs, European ports guarantee the transit of 74% of imported and exported goods and 37% of trade within the EU. The existing framework includes, at the level of organisational models of port services, considerable variations between the different Member States. The Fleckenstein report, which I supported, amends the Commission's initial proposal on market access to port services and the financial transparency of ports. By preventing the adoption of a single system for services, the proposal provides for a strengthening of the principle of the autonomy of airports for the organisation of services, allowing port authorities to lay down minimum requirements for the provision of services. I have personally committed myself to focusing on the issue of worker training. In a competitive and complex sector such as port, the training of new recruits and staff is essential to ensure not only the health and safety of workers but also the quality of services and the overall competitiveness of Union ports.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Fleckenstein report. The Commission's original proposal (2013), widely rejected by trade unions and port managers, was substantially amended in this parliamentary term, given Commissioner Bulc's position not to include the opening up of port services to the market. In this regard, the rapporteur made a report which differed significantly from the original proposal in meeting the demands of the different sectors involved. The commitment negotiations included aspects that, while not meeting all of our objectives, represent significant progress in social and labour matters, as well as improvements in the efficiency and transparency of port management, which could be lost in future legislative initiatives if the report is reversed. It is also a good basis for further negotiation with the Council.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. This report aims, as the rapporteur writes, to modernise port services and operations in Europe and to make it possible to create framework conditions to attract investment in ports. This is a laudable initiative, but as is all too often the case with our institutions, neither the Commission nor our Parliament seems to show much respect for the principle of subsidiarity which, since Maastricht, should nevertheless prevail when drafting any directive or regulation. Many ports in Europe, particularly those run by private communities, are well managed and do not need the superfetatory bureaucratic regulations that this report contains, here and there, the seeds. There is also the question of the special status enjoyed by many of our European dockworkers, in Marseille, Le Havre, but also in Antwerp and Rotterdam, and to which, I fear, the implementation of this relationship, with its free-trade spirit, risks undermining. That is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal in this case claims to help improve the competitiveness of EU ports classified in the TEN-T (the 319 largest ports, which see 96% of goods and 93% of passengers) pass compared to non-EU seaports, and fair competition between TEN-T ports. It also aims to improve the operation and interconnection of seaports by creating standardised European operating rules.  Public subsidies to ports must also appear in port accounts. Overall, the proposed regulation now covers only a few secondary areas of activity at ten-T ports, since the Commission automatically excludes passenger services and cargo handling. Furthermore, while the TRAN Commission's recommendations to exclude most other port operations are adopted, only services offered directly to the user remain. Once again, States are being forced to become more and more liberalised and this will only benefit multinationals and not employees in the port and maritime sector, nor European employees and consumers as a whole. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's intention is to liberalise, through a regulation, eight typical sectors of port operations in accordance with principles similar to those of the Services, Procurement and Concession Directives. I believe that such a measure would risk creating a new 'Bolkestein' case, opening the doors of our territories to multinationals, with a devastating impact on our local operators. For all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I voted to postpone the vote on the legislative resolution so that negotiations can begin. In voting on the content of the resolution, I have voted in favour of the crucial amendments which emphasise collective agreements, defend labour law and fundamental social rights and take a stand against privatisation.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which aims to adopt a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the market for port services and financial transparency of ports. The Commission's proposal aims to help ensure that the TEN-T network is more efficient, more connected and more coherent by creating a system that improves the efficiency of all ports and makes it easier for ports themselves to adapt to changes in transport and logistics requirements. The main tasks of the proposal may include the renewal of port services and activities and the creation of conditions to encourage investment in ports. With this Regulation, the Commission aims to eliminate the conditions of weak competition and possible market abuses, thereby increasing the efficiency of the port services provided. A clear framework of State aid rules is an important criterion for fair competition between ports on an equal footing. The Commission is currently reviewing the scope of the block exemption Regulation with a view to reaching a common position by December 2015. criteria for port infrastructure. This proposal is in line with other important EU policies and challenges, such as the White Paper on Transport, the Connecting Europe Facility and the Blue Belt initiative.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. - I support the proposed regulation on the reform of port systems in Europe. I am pleased that the rapporteur and his team have brought the proposal so far that negotiations with the Council can begin.  With the decision adopted today, we have laid down rules for Member States and port administrations that would like to limit the number of service providers. We have also s determined that ports will have to keep separate accounts for publicly funded activities, while being cautious in setting a fee for services to be provided by internal operators. These rules will have to be set in a transparent and non-discriminatory way. In addition, States are also required to appoint supervisory authorities to ensure adequate control of the level of charges for the provision of port services.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this report, which prevents further liberalisation of the sector. The social and labour rights of workers should be preserved to the fullest extent possible, and this report leads in this direction. The report also calls for adequate training of workers to prevent accidents and thus preserve workers' health, and ensuring the right to strike is also positively addressed by this report, thereby protecting the dignity of workers in this sector.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Contributing to a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable operation of TEN-T by establishing a framework that will improve the efficiency of all ports and help them address changes in requirements in the logistics and transport sectors, is certainly in the interests of European citizens. The modernisation of port services and operations and the creation of framework conditions for attracting investment to ports are a central point in the proposal, which must also be read as a condition for the implementation of fair competition between ports, on equal terms and in compliance with the Community regulatory framework. The prosperity of transport infrastructure and the efficiency of European ports are an important pillar for the long-term economic development of the European Union.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The liberalisation of public services is affecting everywhere, including port services. The European Commission wants to impose on the management authorities of European ports a separation of the various services in order to promote competition, including those that are not directly rendered to the user such as dredging.  While the Parliamentary Committee on Transport and Tourism has amended the Commission's proposal for a regulation in a way that restricts its scope, it is not sufficient and is preparing a much wider liberalisation process which will first benefit multinationals and risks speeding up the purchase of ports such as Piraeus in Greece. Because ports are a sovereignty issue, I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe is one of the world's highest port density regions, and port activities contribute directly to employment, foreign investment and GDP growth. Ports account for up to 3 million jobs in the 22 maritime states and are a major source of tax revenue for local, regional or national governments. All this is concrete evidence that maritime transport makes a significant direct and indirect contribution to job creation in the EU. A coherent maritime transport policy is therefore needed, which is of particular importance for the EU's economic development. At the same time, I believe that efficient port services are essential for the performance of seaports within the trans-European TEN-T transport network. In this respect, I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the more efficient, interconnected and sustainable functioning of the TEN-T is necessary by creating a framework that improves the performance of all ports and helps them cope with changes in transport and logistics requirements.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against postponement. To accept the postponement would be to speed up the procedure by favouring an agreement at first reading. On the substance, our opposition is clear. Such a measure, which would enter into force without even the Member States having to transpose it into their legislation, would risk creating very harmful effects for historic local operators who, for decades if not in some cases for centuries, have been carrying out certain services in our ports.  In short, in today's silence of the media and parties, there would be a risk of creating a new 'Bolkestein' case, with entire professional groups noticing that they would only see their work at risk when the regulation was adopted. Add to that the fact that, with this measure, the downfall of multinationals in our realities would be much more than a concrete hypothesis. Behind the stated attempt to harmonise the organisation of entire production sectors in accordance with the principles of free competition, there is nothing but the desire to centralise at European level important political choices, such as those on the operation of ports. The proposal therefore remains highly controversial. There are many governments in the Council which have expressed a number of concerns.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. We abstain in the final vote on the third attempt to liberalise port services because, despite improving social aspects and, in particular, the surrogacy of staff, the approved text still makes a number of reservations to us.  We welcome the socialist proposal in favour of greater transparency in port funding sources, which will help to verify the State aid that ports in central and northern Europe receive, with more reason in matching this adoption with the Commission's new proposal to exempt aid to port infrastructure from ex ante control of competition. Likewise, in the face of the Commission's interest in deregulation of port tariffs, the Spanish Socialists follow the mandate of the current Spanish Constitution adopting these tariffs by congress, as it maintains in solidarity the current network of our ports, which would otherwise reduce their presence in the territory, without improving competition with European ports. Nevertheless, we prefer to abstain in the mandate from the rapporteur, who has recognised the Spanish peculiarity in working during the tripartite dialogues with the Council.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Fleckenstein report, which aims to improve the port services market in order to strengthen the competitiveness of ports. The aim is to facilitate access to port service activities, improve financial transparency and simplify administrative procedures. Several types of services have been excluded from the scope of its scope, including cargo handling services, passenger services and dredging. This report is the result of a balanced compromise.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP have voted against this proposal as the regulation does not take into account the commercial nature of UK ports.  In order to ensure that commercial ports are exempt from this regulation, UKIP put forward an amendment to Article 1.3.  It is important to ensure that ports are entitled to operate fully as commercial businesses; this regulation does not allow it.  Furthermore, the ambiguity of the text creates uncertainty and puts essential future investment, growth and jobs at risk.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the measures outlined in the Commission proposal as well as this report, which aim to make our maritime ports more modern, efficient and environmentally sustainable and to interconnect them in line with the TEN-T objectives. I am particularly glad that the report also mentions employment and social aspects, namely that the national social standards are the minimum criteria that have to be complied with. I agree that our ports should be as safe and secure as possible. However, I also think that there are some details that still need to be discussed and additional proposals to be considered and I therefore voted to temporarily postpone the vote on this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The regulation aims to establish a common framework for regulating port services in Europe. There are many groups involved, ranging from port authorities, service providers, consumers, ship owners and workers. A number of important requests have been included in the final text. Positive elements include rules on staff training and social rights, financial transparency when there are public funds and State aid, and the exclusion of small ports from the application of additional excessive bureaucratic and administrative burdens. I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, which we believe can contribute to efforts for a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable functioning of the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T), by creating a framework that improves port performance and helps to address changes in transport and logistics requirements. The main objectives of the proposal include modernising port services and operations and creating basic conditions to attract investment to ports. The aim is to compensate for weak competitive pressures and possible market abuses in order to increase the efficiency of port services.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's vote concerned the report on a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports. I think that trying to ensure financial transparency in all aspects or sectors of the economy is an important process and I have therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the TRAN Committee in this report is to achieve a better functioning of ten-t, thus improving the efficiency of all ports. The main objectives of this proposal are greater modernisation of port services and operations and the creation of conditions for attracting investment to ports. For these reasons, I voted in favour. I believe, as this report also points out, that an essential condition for fair competition between ports is a level playing field provided by a clear framework on state aid rules. The Commission considers that the block exemption regulation (State aid) will make it possible, on the one hand, to avoid additional burdens on ports that are already functioning well and, on the other hand, will create the optimum conditions for other ports to address their structural problems. I also voted against Amendment No 98 on Article 10 of the regulation (social clause) because, in line with the Italian Ministry of Infrastructure and Transport, I consider it necessary that the application of this clause should be optional and that the choice of its application should be left to the Member State.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Rules aimed at improving the efficiency and cutting the cost of services supplied at EU maritime ports are necessary. Fees for using port services, such as mooring and towage, should be transparent. Public funding received by the port should be equally as transparent. This would result in a boost to trade by preventing the abuse of price and the distortion of markets. Port arrangements currently in place may remain in place so long as they meet the standard requirements. For safety reasons, ports must be able to choose the organisation of port services, meaning free market access cannot be obliged. Common rules for port managers and Member States who wish to limit the number of service providers must be laid out, creating minimum requirements. Minimum requirements for port service suppliers should include proving professional qualifications, also respecting maritime safety, national social standards and environmental requirements. To ensure transparency, publicly-funded activity should be kept in separate accounts. Fees must be set in a non-discriminatory, transparent manner and they should not be disproportionate to the value of the service provided.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP have voted against this proposal as the regulation does not take into account the commercial nature of UK ports.  In order to ensure that commercial ports are exempt from this regulation, UKIP put forward an amendment to Article 1.3.  It is important to ensure that ports are entitled to operate fully as commercial businesses; this regulation does not allow it.  Furthermore, the ambiguity of the text creates uncertainty and puts essential future investment, growth and jobs at risk.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because modern port management is a prerequisite for efficient use of ports and an investment-friendly climate. The measures presented will support the adaptation of port services to future transport and logistics requirements. At the same time, we will achieve improved connectivity to the hinterland, more efficient rail and inland waterways, and safe and environmentally sound use of waterways.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP have voted against this proposal as the regulation does not take into account the commercial nature of UK ports.  In order to ensure that commercial ports are exempt from this regulation, UKIP put forward an amendment to Article 1.3.  It is important to ensure that ports are entitled to operate fully as commercial businesses; this regulation does not allow it.  Furthermore, the ambiguity of the text creates uncertainty and puts essential future investment, growth and jobs at risk.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that according to recent studies throughout Europe, very high numbers of goods pass through European ports, i.e. more than 75% between imports and exports representing more than 37% of the internal market, and that this regulation would improve market access by ensuring greater financial transparency, I have decided to vote in favour of this proposal. In drawing up the text, it became clear that there are difficulties, starting with the basic differences between the ports of the countries of Northern and Southern Europe which needed convergence on several fronts. In the document arrived at, it was possible to find a satisfactory compromise in order to make ports a key point in the European economy where to work to bring together important investments. I would, however, like to point out a certain regret that it has not been possible to achieve the inclusion in the text of clarification on the question of the social clause.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this report is to enhance the long-term competitiveness of European industries in world markets while adding value and jobs in all European Union coastal regions. Particular aspects that are fundamentally important are the proposal for training of new recruits and the lifelong training of staff as essential elements for ensuring port workers’ health and safety. This is important not only to the workers but also to the quality of services and the competitiveness of EU ports. Compliance with labour standards is not an option; the exercise of legitimate collective bargaining or industrial action rights, including the right to strike, cannot be considered a disruption of port services when emergency measures may be taken.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The regulation aims to establish a common framework for regulating port services in Europe. The initial proposal provided for the liberalisation of services, which was then deleted from Parliament's text mainly because of pressure from northern European countries, such as Great Britain, where ports are completely privatised. There are many groups involved, ranging from port authorities, service providers, consumers, ship owners and workers. The chapter on the liberalization of services has been converted into a reorganisation of services. Positive elements are the rules on staff training and social rights, financial transparency when there are public funds and State aid, and the exclusion of small ports from the application of additional excessive bureaucratic and administrative burdens. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. Parliament's report contains substantial improvements in relation to the Commission's proposal: for the third time, this House opposes the liberalisation of the port sector (although we fear that a new proposal in this regard will come in the coming months). In addition, work with European trade unions has made it possible to introduce recognition of vocational rights, health and occupational safety for port workers, although fringes remain in terms of the effective implementation of this standard and in aspects such as the protection of labour rights in the event of the transfer of port services. Despite this, some aspects of the Commission's initial proposal (in the financial transparency sections) open the door for competition policy to attack essential aspects of port financing and public management. That is why I have decided to abstain, pending the final proposal following negotiations with the Council.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The more efficient, interconnected and sustainable functioning of the TEN-T is very important by creating a framework that improves port performance and helps them cope with changes in transport and logistics requirements. Port services and operations need to be modernised and framework conditions have been created to attract investment in ports.  All users of the port should be informed and be able to lodge a complaint with an independent body. Existing bodies may fulfil the role of such a body without additional bureaucratic burdens. The managing body of the port must also have autonomy to act on its economic strategy.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU Regulation/proposal establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports aims to contribute to the more efficient and sustainable functioning of TEN-T by establishing a framework that improves port operations and helps them adapt to changed transport and logistical requirements. The objectives of the Commission's proposal include upgrading port services and operations and establishing framework conditions for port investment. In addition, the Commission has set a target of counteracting low competitive competition and possible market abuses.  The proposal is in line with the White Paper on Transport, the European Network Finance Facility and the Blue Belt Initiative. The Regulation will apply to all seaports as indicated in the TEN-T guidelines. Parliament's report supports the Commission's proposal, in particular on aspects relating to financial transparency. The EP proposes that the regulation should cover only services offered directly to port users, and proposes amendments to port charges so that port operators can set charges autonomously in accordance with their business strategy. I voted in favour of this report in order to modernise it.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I believe that the efficiency of the port industry is more conducive to competition between ports than to the prescriptive regulation of the internal operation of ports. Although governments, port owners and trade unions in Poland welcome some of the improvements, they nevertheless maintain strong opposition to the document. Concerns have also often been raised that the social legislation introduced by the rapporteur will result in the excessively stringent implementation of the existing rules on the transfer of workers due to a change of service provider and the current ILO guidelines on training and labour protection. With this in mind, I voted against.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The report aims to set a framework that should boost efficiency and strengthen the competitiveness of maritime ports in the trans-European transport network. Members of the European Parliament agreed to delete the liberalisation of port services and instead to preserve the various organisation models in the European Union, while allowing authorities or port managing bodies to set minimum requirements for performing port services or limiting the number of service providers; Parliament also approved financial transparency provisions that would ensure fair competition and prevent price abuse, in particular when services are not subject to effective competition. Parliament’s position is closely aligned with that of the Council. This report provides also that social and labour rules would not be affected by the Regulation. For these reasons I voted in favour of this parliamentary report.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I do not support this third attempt at an overarching European regulation of ports. There was a reason the last two attempts failed, a one-size-fits-all approach to the hugely diverse range of ports in Europe does not work. In the UK, our ports operate in a different way to many ports in continental Europe. They are thriving and successful private enterprises competing directly with each other in a competitive market place. Competition between ports, rather than a prescriptive regulation of ports’ internal operations, is the best driver of efficiency.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to improve the efficiency of European ports and thus boost growth and trade. In particular, it proposes to modernise and to open up port services and operations to competition in order to increase the competitiveness of ports. These services include forewing, mooring or refuelling.  At the EPP group, we have been particularly mobilized to ensure that port managers retain their freedom in the organisation of port services, giving them enough flexibility to define a business strategy and investment plan tailored to the needs of the site. Considering that this text provides for an administrative simplification of the port services market, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I have approved this reform proposal to bring down the prices of services, such as mooring and towing, in more than 300 ports in the European Union. However, this project does not require any liberalization of the sector. There is a need at present to improve the performance of ports, to help them cope with changing transport and logistics requirements in Europe and around the world. Europe must be competitive in a sector as important as maritime transport.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The European port network is characterised by a wide variety of port organisation systems. The harmonisation of the functioning of EU port services is therefore necessary. This legislation will establish a clear framework for all European ports. It will reduce the cost of services provided at EU seaports by forcing port operators to be more transparent about their tariffs, thereby ensuring fairer competition. In the long run, this legal framework will promote the development of European industry, attract investment, and promote job creation in the EU's coastal regions.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the proposal is to promote the efficient operation of Europe's seaports and to contribute to better water connectivity. Modernising port services, operations and increasing investment in ports are an essential part of the proposal. The Regulation creates the necessary conditions for ports that are currently not functioning properly. It does so by applying to the 319 main seaports as set out in the TEN-T Guidelines, which account for 96% of European freight traffic and 93% of passenger traffic. Compromises have been reached between major political groups and agreement on important issues such as financial transparency, independent oversight, port services and infrastructure charges.  Among the pp's proposals, it is particularly important to highlight the amendments on financial transparency and freedom to provide services in ports. The substantial changes mentioned above will help european ports to operate better and more sustainably in the future, thereby increasing the Union's competitiveness in international transport. With my vote in favour, I have contributed to the start of tripartit negotiations.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The TRAN Committee's amendments are positive in that they limit the scope of the regulation and its normative constraint. For example, dredging, piloting, mooring, towing and squintering are no longer covered by the required liberalization. In any case, the latter risks, as is often the case, benefiting only multinationals and not employees in the port and maritime sector. Refusing to see a general liberalisation in the key sector of transport and port services, and defending the sovereignty of States, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Reality sometimes shows that it is not competition, but regulation that makes a market better. Cartel contracts between large organisations in a particular sector lead to market distortion, which affects smaller players and, of course, the end-user. The country from which I am chosen has several ports which, for Community standards, are small, and with the introduction of these regulations I hope they can fight to some extent with major European ports. That is why I supported this report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Negative as a whole, because the amendments can be generally positive and favour not only maritime transport but also the protection of workers, but no one ensures a ban on the sale of ports to private companies and indeed non-EUROPEAN interests.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the proposal is to promote the efficient operation of Europe's seaports and to contribute to better water connectivity. Modernising port services, operations and increasing investment in ports are an essential part of the proposal. The Regulation creates the necessary conditions for ports that are currently not functioning properly. With my vote in favour, I have contributed to the start of tripartit negotiations.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The main objectives of the proposal are the modernization of port services and operations and the creation of structural conditions to attract investments in ports. Through this Regulation, the Commission intends to counter weak competitive pressure and possible market abuses in order to increase the efficiency of port services. However, the scope of the Regulation should include only port services offered directly to users. On the other hand, the social provisions governing the port labour regime have been virtually excluded from this Regulation, but Member States should ensure workers' rights in the event of a transfer of undertakings or establishments.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation, because I do not want absolute liberalisation of the management of European ports.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to the legislative process relating to ports of the trans-European transmission system. The Regulation should therefore establish an organisational framework for port services, a set of financial transparency rules and the costs to be applied by management bodies (public or private) or port service providers. Market operations and handling, passenger and piloting services are therefore outside this scope. The amendments introduced by the European Parliament, in its specialised transport committee, to the European Commission's initial proposal greatly improve the initial text, with direct implications in Portugal: they exclude piloting, introduce relevant labour issues and reduce the degree of liberalisation imposed. Regardless of these changes, the end result remains bad, because completely within the logic of liberalisation. It is interesting, for example, the concern expressed with the "users" of ports. Paradigmatic and funny. At the same time that public transport users become customers, the client companies of the ports become users. Our sense of voting is therefore explained by what has been voted on: we voted in favour of the amendments to the European Commission's proposal, which make it less bad, and we voted against the original proposal and the final amended document.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am convinced that the proposed regulation will be essential to establish legal certainty for ports and to have a positive impact on the proper functioning of the TEN-T network. The amendments adopted will increase the scope for trade negotiations between the managing body and port users, while also respecting the basic principles of transparency. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because it is controversial and could put our country's economy at risk with liberalisations.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because the amendments may be broadly positive and favour not only maritime transport but also the protection of workers, but no one ensures a ban on the sale of ports to private companies and indeed non-EUROPEAN interests.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to reject the Commission’s proposal on the basis that competition between ports is the greatest driver of efficiency, not prescriptive regulations determining the internal operations of ports. This unnecessary increase in bureaucracy will increase costs for the UK’s system of privatised and market-driven ports. UK port owners have made clear that the Commission’s proposal would impact them negatively, particularly smaller ports.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. The SPÖ-EU delegation supported the report on the organisation of port services and financial transparency of ports. What is essential for us is that the liberalisation of port services is no longer possible. The protection of workers' rights as well as the right to strike could be anchored. In addition, the Socialists and Democrats have written a new article on training standards for dockworkers and have been able to push through the strengthening of social dialogue.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which clarifies the scope and aim of the Port Services Regulation, setting a framework that should boost the efficiency and strengthen competitiveness of maritime ports in the trans-European transport network. It also takes into account the specific situation of ports located in outermost regions. I strongly support it as it provides that social and labour rules will not be affected by the Regulation and that port workers should receive adequate training about their working conditions. It also invites the EU-level Sectoral Social Dialogue Committee for Ports to develop guidelines regarding training requirements to prevent accidents and ensure the highest level of safety and health for port workers. Furthermore, the report secures the right to strike, stating that industrial action does not constitute grounds for taking emergency measures (such as direct awards). Through this report, we managed to preserve and increase social standards in the EU Regulation and we have stopped further liberalisation of the sector.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the proposal is to promote the efficient operation of Europe's seaports and to contribute to better water connectivity. Modernising port services, operations and increasing investment in ports are an essential part of the proposal. The Regulation creates the necessary conditions for ports that are currently not functioning properly. With my vote in favour, I have contributed to the start of tripartit negotiations.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is particularly necessary for the EU to regulate EU ports permanently. It is important to advance policies to modernize port operations and services, while combating potential market abuses to improve port service performance and transparency and autonomously set port tariffs at each port. This will avoid additional load for those ports that already work well, while creating the conditions for other ports to meet their structural challenges. It is important that the European Parliament recognises the good management of some ports and bets on their autonomy.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. We abstain in the final vote on the third attempt to liberalise port services because, despite improving social aspects and, in particular, the surrogacy of staff, the adopted text still makes a number of reservations to us.  We welcome the socialist proposal in favour of greater transparency in port funding sources, which will help to verify the State aid that ports in central and northern Europe receive, with more reason in matching this adoption with the Commission's new proposal to exempt aid to port infrastructure from ex ante control of competition. Likewise, in the face of the Commission's interest in deregulation of port tariffs, the Spanish Socialists follow the mandate of the current Spanish Constitution for the adoption by Congress of these tariffs, since it maintains in solidarity the current network of our ports. Otherwise, its presence on the territory would be reduced, without improving competition with European ports. Nevertheless, we prefer to abstain in the mandate from the rapporteur, who has recognised the Spanish peculiarity in working during tripartite dialogues with the Council.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's position on the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on certain specific aspects of the liberalisation of port services, because I believe that the compromise reached in Parliament's Committee on Transport (TRAN) combines at the same time the need to increase the effectiveness of port services, the reduction of costs, particularly those due to inefficiency, with the development of intra- and extra-European trade. I note with particular attention the involvement at different points in the debate of the parties directly concerned: port workers, technical-nautical services, pilots, dockers and port authorities. I welcome the work done by TRAN to improve the Commission's initial legislative proposal, so that existing port management models at national level can be maintained and can continue to develop while ensuring transparency, preventing price abuses of the services offered and therefore market distortions, given that ports in different countries receive public funding. Finally, I fully agree with the introduction into the European Parliament's position of minimum requirements for port service providers limited to proving professional qualifications and adaptation to the principles of maritime and environmental safety and national social standards. I therefore hope that we will reach a fruitful and speedy agreement with the Council.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on access to the market for port services and financial transparency of ports. It is a balanced dossier that makes more efficient and cost-effective services possible in EU seaports. Such services include towing, feasting and refuelling services. The new rules can increase transparency in the charging of services and the use of port infrastructure to prevent price abuse, ensure fair competition and promote trade.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the package because the current proposal is flawed, inconsistent and lacking in logic. It will not improve the business situation, but will create additional bureaucratic burdens. I do not find any proposals to improve the competitiveness of ports or factors that can level the playing field in this sector. The diversity of the European port sector makes it impossible to establish a common legal framework for all ports and their managing authorities, without abandoning their specificities and without reducing the specific role they play in the national and regional economy. I am particularly critical of the legal form of the regulation that the Commission has chosen to achieve its objectives. I do not agree with the conditions set out in Article 14 of the draft regulation, which lays down charges and defines the components of port infrastructure. Such a situation will lead to economic uncertainty and will hold back investment. Competing port service providers must be able to set charges for their infrastructure. I am also opposed to the creation of new administrative structures or the mandatory establishment of committees of port users, which introduces the draft regulation. These provisions run counter to one of its clear objectives– cutting red tape. The project seriously interferes with the structure, organisation and independence of ports.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Ports in my region and throughout Europe are the hub of the trans-European transport network. In order to ensure competitiveness, complex administrative procedures must be overcome and simplified.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP have voted against this proposal as the regulation does not take into account the commercial nature of UK ports.  In order to ensure that commercial ports are exempt from this regulation, UKIP put forward an amendment to Article 1.3.  It is important to ensure that ports are entitled to operate fully as commercial businesses; this regulation does not allow it.  Furthermore, the ambiguity of the text creates uncertainty and puts essential future investment, growth and jobs at risk.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ In the UK, the port industry is thriving. Not only has this led the UK port industry to become the second largest in Europe, but it has also enabled it to operate independently, free of taxpayer subsidies. In fact, 75% of UK ports are privately owned, an industry model that is in stark contrast to the rest of Europe where 80% of ports are run by state or local authorities.  Due to such significant differences, especially differences in competitiveness, for the UK, this regulation poses a significant number of risks. Regulating market access to port services, port charges and financial transparency may have negative implications for UK investment and job creation. The imposition of a regulator on the UK ports industry would also lead to uncertainty and in turn, undermine commercial and investor confidence.  The Commission’s proposal is therefore overly bureaucratic and ill-fit for our UK system of privatised and market-driven ports. Indeed, I, alongside my Conservative colleagues, believe that competition between ports, rather than prescriptive regulation on ports’ internal operations, is the key driving force for efficiency. It was for these reasons that I voted to reject the Commission’s proposal.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. I must admit that the Commission is persevering. It has already failed twice to liberalize port services. Last time, anger over his project led to one of the most violent protests in Strasbourg against a European project. Like any legislation in Brussels that is in fact aimed at deregulating or even scrapping a sector, the regulation we are voting on today is in fine terms, especially in its intentions: promoting the competitiveness and therefore of jobs, financial transparency in particular state aid, administrative simplification, association of users with the economic life of ports... But behind all this, it is free market access, first for European players, and then for global players, that takes precedence over any other consideration. Of course, many of the rapporteur's amendments are improvements: better consideration of the diversity of the size, activities and method of managing ports, even relative protection of public service or security-related activities, compliance with social standards in force in the States, etc. But just because you rep rest a bad text doesn't mean it becomes good. I voted against it in the hope of a third failure of the Commission.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Fleckenstein report. The Commission's original proposal (2013), widely rejected by trade unions and port managers, was substantially amended in this parliamentary term, given Commissioner Bulc's position not to include the opening up of port services to the market. In this regard, the rapporteur made a report which differed significantly from the original proposal in meeting the demands of the different sectors involved. The commitment negotiations included aspects that, while not meeting all of our objectives, represent significant progress in social and labour matters, as well as improvements in the efficiency and transparency of port management, which could be lost in future legislative initiatives if the report is reversed. It is also a good basis for further negotiation with the Council.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is an important report for the state of ports in Europe. And Romania has ports and I think we need to improve the modus operandi.  The quality and efficiency of port activity influences economic activity because maritime and river transport has an important weight.  The report also took into account the views of the port administration and trade unions, even though the social partners were not fully satisfied.  I voted for the report in the hope that the dialogue that will follow with the representatives of the Commission and the Council will achieve optimal regulation for the parties involved. There is a need to ensure fairness and fair competition for smaller ports and not to exercise dominant market or monopoly positions.  I appreciate that the report takes a position against casual work and in favour of better training and safety conditions.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Writing. The SPÖ-EU delegation supported the report on the organisation of port services and financial transparency of ports. What is essential for us is that the liberalisation of port services is no longer possible. The protection of workers' rights as well as the right to strike could be anchored. In addition, the Socialists and Democrats have written a new article on training standards for dockworkers and have been able to push through the strengthening of social dialogue.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because it aims to increase efficiency and reduce the cost of services provided in the European Union's seaports. In particular, the ports will be able to organize themselves more autonomously. Smaller ports are excluded from financial transparency provisions because this would be an excessive administrative burden for them. Finally, non-French towing and fighting companies wishing to work in France will have to fly the French flag and therefore comply with the current legislation.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. I supported the compromise text drawn up by my colleague Knut Fleckenstein, which radically transformed the Commission's initial ultra-liberal proposal. This refers to the requirement for the most sensitive services as a national flag; Public service obligations are also present; Financial transparency is an essential part of the text; and smaller or vulnerable ports will have fewer administrative obligations than larger ports.  The text voted here provides the necessary social guarantees, while providing Member States with the necessary leeway to enable them to maintain their national models, without forcing them to liberalise and without imposing a single standard that might not work as well as existing models.  Now is the time to move on to trilogue negotiations. Parliament will remain vigilant in exercising its power of co-decision: it will only vote on the final text if it goes in the right direction, because it is better not to have harmonisation at all rather than to misal harmonisation.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the allowance of market access to port services, as well as the financial transparency of ports, and am in favour of Parliament beginning negotiations with the Council and the Commission directly. This is because allowing this market access will connect ports to the trans-European network, encourage innovation and modernisation of port services, promote social dialogue and the environmental profile of ports, as well as increasing investment in them.

Nevertheless, we prefer to abstain in the mandate from the rapporteur, who has recognised the Spanish peculiarity in working during the tripartite dialogues with the Council.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the proposal is to create a framework that will improve the competitiveness of ports and "modernise" them in order to create basic conditions for attracting investors and achieving the liberalisation of port services. However, these provisions are particularly negative for workers. The text partially betters the Commission's proposal by deleting proposals to ensure market access for port services, adds important references to the protection of labour rights and collective agreements and includes positive references to the need to ensure the health and safety of workers. However, despite the positive reports, we do not think that we could take a positive view of this regulation. That's why we voted against it.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the rapporteur of this draft regulation that aims at contributing to the goal of a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable functioning of the TEN-T, by creating a framework which improves the performance of all ports and helps them to cope with changes in transport and logistics requirements. This regulation shall apply to all seaports listed in the Commission’s proposal for a Regulation on the Trans-European Transport Network Guidelines, while ensuring a balanced approach between legislative action and a soft approach as exemplified by the social dialogue. In Ireland, our commercial ports already fulfil the principles of this regulation as confirmed by the competition authority in their report of 2013. In addition, Irish ports already fulfil the financial transparency elements of the regulation.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe the intent of the proposal is very welcome. It is important that the EU provides adequate regulation on the extent to which market access for ports should be opened. We also need to examine the social provisions concerning workers, and the importance of financial transparency and legal certainty regarding state aid.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The topic "Port Package" has been covered for 10 years. The long discussion is based on unrelated considerations of the original versions. This report cannot be satisfied on a theoretical basis. In particular, the distinction between public and private tasks is not sharp. However, this report also manifests major conflicts of interest. Of particular importance is the passage to the surrounding infrastructure. As long as this infrastructure is available to the general public, it is general infrastructure which is not geared solely to the profit intentions of port operations. This also applies, for example.B, to roads in ports that are available to the general public. It is therefore a general infrastructure which the State makes available to all citizens. This general infrastructure finds its limits where large parts of society are excluded from its use. In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, the planning, construction and maintenance of this infrastructure is not the eu's task; this can be properly assessed on the spot. I voted in favour of adoption in order to allow a minimum of legal certainty. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP have voted against this proposal as the regulation does not take into account the commercial nature of UK ports.  In order to ensure that commercial ports are exempt from this regulation, UKIP put forward an amendment to Article 1.3.  It is important to ensure that ports are entitled to operate fully as commercial businesses; this regulation does not allow it.  Furthermore, the ambiguity of the text creates uncertainty and puts essential future investment, growth and jobs at risk.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I welcome the result of the votes on the report on market access for port services, which are in line with the interests of French ports. The Commission's proposed regulation, which is currently under consideration, has two objectives: to modernise port services and operations and to promote the creation of framework conditions to attract investment in ports.  In a highly competitive industry, these measures are welcome. I therefore welcome the opportunity for ports to be able to organise themselves autonomously and the exclusion of small ports, which would certainly not have been able to bear the administrative burdens arising from the introduction of the new financial transparency rules. Finally, I should point out that piloting and dredging remain excluded from this regulation for reasons of maritime safety.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ EU legislation is supposed to be proportionate and effective. I do not consider that this text meets either of those criteria. The final result has been attacked both by port authorities and those who work in ports, and will do little to improve Europe’s port services. I therefore voted against.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that supports the Commission proposal regarding the creation of a framework that will improve the performance of ports through transport and logistics requirements. The report also calls for modernisation and transparency of services, port operations and the creation of the necessary conditions in order to attract investment in ports.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted for a report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the creation of a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports, as the objective is to achieve a more efficient and better connected functioning of TEN-T networks by creating better conditions for port operation and adaptation to changes in transport and logistics conditions.  I believe that this aims to contribute to the modernization of port services and port operations, increase the efficiency of port services and create better conditions for attracting investment in ports. This empowers competition, creates better jobs and better working conditions for employees, creates legal certainty for both investors and employees, and better information for service users. This aims to achieve greater transparency in the use of public funds, state aid control, clarity in public tenders, create a level playing field for European ports. I agree that this document constitutes a good basis for further public debate and a final legislative proposal.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal in this case claims to help improve the competitiveness of EU ports classified in the trans-European transport network, i.e. the main roads, rail and sea routes in Europe. Against the advice of the European Commission, the TRAN Committee wants only port services offered directly to the user to fall within the scope of the regulation. Dredging is therefore excluded, since it is not a commercial service, but rather a public service task.  In principle, if the amendments adopted by the TRAN Committee are positive, this is still insufficient to vote in favour, since once again States are forced, as with all transport matters, to be forced to further liberalisation. This proposal for a regulation is certainly only the first step towards a much wider liberalisation which will only benefit multinationals, certainly not employees in the port and maritime sector, nor European employees and consumers as a whole. So I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP have voted against this proposal as the regulation does not take into account the commercial nature of UK ports.  In order to ensure that commercial ports are exempt from this regulation, UKIP put forward an amendment to Article 1.3.  It is important to ensure that ports are entitled to operate fully as commercial businesses; this regulation does not allow it.  Furthermore, the ambiguity of the text creates uncertainty and puts essential future investment, growth and jobs at risk.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Knut Fleckenstein's report on the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports. This report preserves the interests of French ports. The autonomy of the organization of the ports is expanded, while protecting small ports from too heavy administrative burdens. In addition, towing and fighting companies wishing to work in France will have to adopt the French flag and comply with the legislation. I therefore agree with this text, which must now be defended by the French government at the level of the Member States. This regulation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. Mr Fleckenstein's report focuses on the Commission's proposal to contribute to a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable operation of some 330 European ports. The Commission hopes to create a framework to improve the performance of ports and help them cope with changing transport and logistics requirements. So I voted for this report.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Trans-European transport networks (TEN-T) contribute to the smooth operation and development of the internal market and ensure economic, social and territorial cohesion. The TEN-T programme is the European Union's aid programme in the field of transport and is aimed at all Member States. It aims to increase economic activity and cooperation as well as contribute to the long-term competitiveness of European industry on global markets. The motion for a legislative resolution of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the market for port services and financial transparency of ports is intended to contribute to a more efficient, integrated and sustainable functioning of the TEN-T network. The amendments and amendments to the above-mentioned Regulation aim at modernising port services and operations as well as creating framework conditions to increase investment in ports. Administrative simplifications, on the other hand, will allow for faster customs clearance and thus improve port efficiency. There are currently many systems for the organisation of ports and port services, so this resolution does not impose a single, specific model. It opens the door for port managers and gives them more freedom to make decisions. Well-functioning ports – such as those in Poland – will avoid additional burdens, while other facilities will have the right conditions to solve their own structural problems.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The final vote has been postponed, so the report is about to enter the trialogue. It is not possible to judge whether the 150 amendments will really be the basis for the proposal at the end of the vote. What is clear, however, is that this is a clear indication that the rapporteur has accepted a great deal of polarisation. As the last form of the proposal is not foreseeable, I am negative about this report.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a system of financial transparency for market access ports and ports, because I believe that the regulation will help attract additional investment and also ensure the development of Ports in Latvia. When entering the store and purchasing goods, we have the opportunity to ascertain, for example, the composition of the product in the package, the country of origin and other potentially useful information. Similarly, investors are more willing to know the rules of the game before they invest. Investors should be clear about how prices are set for the use of infrastructure and other services. It is therefore required to ensure transparent service prices for port management. Port management will also have to ensure financial transparency in the use of public funds. I believe that the people of Latvia will only benefit from transparency in our port operations, such improvements will attract investors who will develop them and create new jobs, so I supported the proposal.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to reject the Commission’s proposal for an EU port services regulation as the proposed legislation includes few tangible benefits for the port sector, its workers or the environment.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The legislative package on European ports (also known as the Port Package) has been dealt with for 10 years. The long discussion is based on unrelated considerations of the original versions. This report cannot be satisfied on a theoretical basis. In particular, the distinction between public and private tasks is not sharp. However, this report also manifests major conflicts of interest. Of particular importance is the passage to the surrounding infrastructure. As long as this infrastructure is available to the general public, it is general infrastructure which is not geared solely to the profit intentions of port operations. This also applies, for example.B, to roads in ports that are available to the general public. It is therefore a general infrastructure which the State makes available to all citizens. This general infrastructure finds its limits where large parts of society are excluded from its use. In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, the planning, construction and maintenance of this infrastructure is not the eu's task; this can be properly assessed on the spot. I voted in favour of adoption in order to allow a minimum of legal certainty. Autonomous action by the EU Commission would have been detrimental to the EU's reputation.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the proposal is to promote the efficient operation of Europe's seaports and to contribute to better water connectivity. Modernising port services, operations and increasing investment in ports are an essential part of the proposal. The Regulation creates the necessary conditions for ports that are currently not functioning properly. It does so by applying to the 319 main seaports as set out in the TEN-T Guidelines, which account for 96% of European freight traffic and 93% of passenger traffic.  Compromises have been reached between major political groups and agreement on important issues such as financial transparency, independent oversight, port services and infrastructure charges. Among the pp's proposals, it is particularly important to highlight the amendments on financial transparency and freedom to provide services in ports. The substantial changes mentioned above will help european ports to operate better and more sustainably in the future, thereby increasing the Union's competitiveness in international transport. With my vote in favour, I have contributed to the start of tripartit negotiations.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This report aims to establish a framework on market access to port services and financial transparency of ports. We amended the report, so the proposal could respect subsidiarity and the sovereignty of each Member State. It is essential that each Member State has the right to decide which authority and managing body will be in charge for the ports’ organisation. We achieved also, to defend workers’ rights on social conflict as well as the right of collective actions. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: Written. \u2012 It is important to have common rules in Europe on how port services are organised. As a member of the Board of the Finnish Port Association, I am also very much in favour of transparent use of public funds when making port investments. In Finland, port operators do not have much need to change their operations as a result of this act. In Finland, the ports now operate in the form of limited liability companies, and we have considered the arrangement to be a success. I also welcomed the fact that the law would not undermine workers' rights and that its aim is to make the work of port workers safer throughout Europe.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. – Union funding for the transport sector amounts to around EUR 26 billion in the period 2014 to 2020, focused on the TEN-T (Trans-European Networks - Transport) network, which contains the main transport routes for passengers and businesses across Europe. This proposal aims to increase the level of efficiency, interconnection and sustainability of TEN-T through the modernisation of port services and operations, while creating conditions necessary to attract investment to ports. I supported the proposal because I agree with the main objectives and content, but I would like to point out that within the EU area there are different systems of port organisation, as well as a substantial difference between North and South Europe as regards the very activities for which ports are intended. It is not always easy to strike a balance between different needs, but I also believe that it is necessary to avoid rigid positions, in order to allow all the same opportunities for investment and development.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The Commission has made numerous attempts to open up port services (anything a port provided to a boat in port: dredging, guidance, mooring, maintenance, etc.) to competition. It had failed twice and was therefore back in charge with a text that played on the financial transparency of port charges to pass its project. Fortunately, previous failures and the mobilization of trade unions and ports who did not want to see their economic model completely challenged simply to open up the market have broken the ambitions of the original text. The report rewritten by Parliament even introduces positive elements by allowing ports to force service vessels (for dredging, or facilitating the mooring of large vessels) to comply with national law by carrying the country flag, or by guaranteeing the rights of transferred personnel if one of these port service activities is taken over by another undertaking. I have kept in touch with the trade unionists in the sector to ensure that none of their red lines have been crossed and that the positive aspects of this text are maintained. With this support, I have decided to support this text.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The European Parliament and Council's proposed regulation aims to establish a framework for market access for port services and financial transparency of ports. Through this proposal, the Commission wants to improve the competitiveness of EU ports classified in the TEN-T (trans-European transport network, i.e. the main roads, sea and rail in Europe), in relation to non-EU ports and between them. In addition, the Commission aims to attract competition at ports.  However, the regulation only concerns the secondary activities of the TEN-T ports (passenger services and cargo handling are excluded from the proposal) and encourages a forced liberalisation of this sector which will face fierce competition from multinationals. The text therefore goes in contrast to the interests of employees in the port and maritime sector and European employees and consumers in general.  In order not to witness a dramatic rehearsal of the purchase of the port of Piraeus last January by the Chinese shipowner COSCOS, I spoke out against this text.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. Parliament's report contains substantial improvements in relation to the Commission's proposal: for the third time, this House opposes the liberalisation of the port sector (although we fear that a new proposal in this regard will come in the coming months). In addition, work with European trade unions has made it possible to introduce recognition of vocational rights, health and occupational safety for port workers, although fringes remain in terms of the effective implementation of this standard and in aspects such as the protection of labour rights in the event of the transfer of port services. Despite this, some aspects of the Commission's initial proposal (in the financial transparency sections) open the door for competition policy to attack essential aspects of port financing and public management. That is why I have decided to abstain, pending the final proposal following negotiations with the Council.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The topic "Port Package" has been covered for 10 years. The long discussion is based on unrelated considerations of the original versions. This report cannot be satisfied on a theoretical basis. In particular, the distinction between public and private tasks is not sharp. However, this report also manifests major conflicts of interest. Of particular importance is the passage to the surrounding infrastructure. As long as this infrastructure is available to the general public, it is general infrastructure which is not geared solely to the profit intentions of port operations. This also applies, for example.B, to roads in ports that are available to the general public. It is therefore a general infrastructure which the State makes available to all citizens. This general infrastructure finds its limits where large parts of society are excluded from its use.  In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, the planning, construction and maintenance of this infrastructure is not the eu's task; this can be properly assessed on the spot. I voted in favour of adoption in order to allow a minimum of legal certainty. Autonomous action by the EU Commission would have been detrimental to the EU's reputation.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The EU is not supposed to specifically regulate ports. Port management is to be a matter for the operator and users to agree. Ports should, where appropriate, be subject to national regulations. Under the Treaty of Versailles, the Czech Republic has the right to operate the Czech territory in Hamburg as a free port and this is not taken into account by the proposal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Commission proposal aims to contribute to the objective of a more efficient, interconnected and functional TEN-T by creating a framework to help ports cope with changes in transport and logistical requirements. It is important to define a clear framework on State aid rules, minimum requirements, limiting the number of service providers and social protection that will guarantee financial transparency I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the creation of a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports, as I believe that this proposal will improve the functionality of TEN-T.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 Seaports are an important centre of the trans-European transport network (TEN-T), a hub for services, trade and thus a source of employment and economic growth. However, globalisation problems have also affected their activities and position. I support the Commission's proposal on the table, which will contribute to increasing legal certainty for ports, help improve their performance, make transport, logistics more efficient and, at the same time, contribute to the financial transparency of these entities.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. The text voted today, fortunately, has nothing to do with the Commission's initial, very liberal proposal.  This draft regulation contains many points of satisfaction, including the requirement of the national flag for the most sensitive services. Public service obligations, including safety and dredging, will also not be open to competition. Many social safeguards have also been inserted, such as the obligation to respect current national law, to avoid social dumping.  This text also has a financial transparency component, which is of great importance to the Socialist Group. Finally, while the Commission's initial proposal did not address this crucial point, the European Parliament wanted the smaller ports, particularly those of the RUP, to be excluded from the scope of this text. This is an essential departure, since ultramarine ports are thus avoided from administrative burdens that are disproportionate to their actual activity.  As it stands, I therefore support this draft regulation, but will be careful that the progress made is not called into question in the negotiations with the Council.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of postponing the vote on the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports, in accordance with the rapporteur's proposal.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. Although, on the whole, it concerns only a few areas of secondary port activity, the fact remains that this text imposes constraints on Member States and promotes ever more liberalisation, which we oppose.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this unnecessary piece of legislation.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Favourable to the report on the proposal for a regulation establishing a regulatory framework for market access to port services and the financial transparency of ports. The aim is to contribute to the more efficient and sustainable functioning of TEN-T by regulating a regulatory framework that makes it possible to improve port efficiency in relation to the logistics and transport sectors in order to attract investment in them.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
