text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a proposal for a regulation establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports. It is a compromise text used as a basis for initiating a trilogue with the Council and was adopted after difficult and long negotiations in the TRAN Committee. The report has been able to include a ban on further liberalisation of port services and, through cooperation with the relevant trade unions, provisions guaranteeing the safety of port workers at work, the emphasis on collective agreements as well as the requirement that any changes must be addressed through dialogue with the social partners. The text also emphasises environmentally sustainable operations in seaports as well as quality requirements. I supported the proposal.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. We reject the proposal to improve the functioning of EU ports, as we believe it may be harmful to Spain. This proposal does not respond to the general interest and also interferes with the competences of the Member States which are an essential part of their organisation and economic system.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to open negotiation between the Council and the Commission in the TRANS committee. This report must fulfil its goal to create more sustainable and better functioning ports which will be able to deal with future changes in the transport sector.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The proposal for a directive, as presented by the Commission, is a further step towards the liberalisation of ports and port services. Thus, the report recommends "a high degree of simplification of customs procedures to constitute a major economic asset for the competitiveness of ports" or "the possibility of introducing exemptions to avoid disproportionate administrative burdens for seaports in the trans-European global transport network". While health and ecological controls are already insufficient on ports, this new opening will further disarm Europe in the face of the dumping of global free trade. Nevertheless, Parliament's amendments remind us of the importance of respecting social and environmental standards and also aim to exclude certain professions from the directive. Finally, the report anchors the principle of the national flag (like French law) in order to combat cabotage and social dumping. In the end, I vote against, despite the few precautions added by Parliament, and instead defend ecological and social protectionism

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. I consider the amendments adopted by the Transport Committee on the European Commission's proposal to be good. These reduce the number of activities involved and reduce their regulation. However, the liberal constraint is, once again, in place against the states. Moreover, this is most likely only a milestone on the path of ultraliberalism, which is not likely to condemn the affairs of multinationals, but rather the condition of employees, not only of the sector in question, but also that of "consumers".  As a result, I voted against the Commission's text and also against Parliament's, albeit much better.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a regulatory framework for access to the market for port services and the financial transparency of ports. It is extremely important to improve the performance of all ports so that they can cope with changing logistics and transport needs. It is also important to modernize port services and operations so that they can attract investment to ports.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution and to support the mandate to open negotiations with the Council and the Commission in the Committee on Transport and Tourism. This proposal aims to modernise port services and attract investment in Europe’s ports and this text will facilitate progress in the negotiations with the other institutions.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on market access for port services and the financial transparency of ports, because it is the result of a good balance, which could create a favourable climate for inter-institutional negotiations. This proposed regulation will contribute to a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable operation of the TEN-T without opening the door to market abuse. It will better organize ports by limiting the number of service providers, improving port performance, and helping them cope with changing transport and logistics requirements. It aims for greater transparency, the kind of unfair competition from ports and will improve job creation.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – Ports are essential gateways connecting Europe with the rest of the world. They play an important role in the exchange of goods between the hinterland and the island parts, making them irreplaceable for the functioning of the EU internal market. European ports are generally known for their quality, support the development of international trade and generate employment by providing work to more than one and a half million workers. Despite this fact, ports often have to deal with problems such as a lack of infrastructure network or a low level of services provided, which in turn represents an increased cost for both carriers and final consumers. The TEN-T Guidelines, together with the CEF financial instrument, which allocates €26 billion to improve infrastructure within the EU, aimed to kick-start growth and competitiveness within the Union's single market. However, the current wording of the legislative proposal for a regulation does not, in my view, sufficiently address the issue of the risk of possible distortions of competition and the free market in access to the market for services provided by ports, as well as the rules governing the granting of State aid. I also believe that a regulation as amended would potentially impose an additional administrative burden on ports that do not currently face more serious problems. For these reasons, I am voting against the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on market access to port services and financial transparency of ports, which clarifies the scope and aim of the regulation, setting a framework that should boost the efficiency and strengthen the competitiveness of maritime ports in the trans-European transport network. It also takes into account the specific situation of ports located in outermost regions. The report provides that social and labour rules would not be affected by the regulation and that port workers should receive adequate training about their working conditions. It also invites the EU-level Sectoral Social Dialogue Committee for Ports to develop guidelines regarding training requirements to prevent accidents and ensure the highest level of safety and health for port workers. Furthermore, the report secures the right to strike, stating that industrial action does not constitute grounds for taking emergency measures (such as direct awards).

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the establishment of a framework ensuring access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports. According to the opinion of the Lower House of the Spanish Parliament, the Spanish Senate, the French National Assembly, the Italian Senate, the Latvian Parliament, the Maltese Parliament, the Polish Sim, the Polish Senate and the Swedish Parliament, the draft is incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity. In its report, the Committee on Transport and Tourism recommended that Parliament adopt the draft regulation with almost 140 amendments at first reading. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. In this case, the Commission's proposal claims to help improve the competitiveness of EU ports classified in the TEN-T (Trans-European Transport Network).  In effect, the proposed regulation now covers only a few secondary areas of activity, since the Commission automatically excludes passenger services and cargo handling; only direct services to the user remain. Nevertheless, once again, States are being forced, as with all transport matters, to be more liberalised. This proposal for a regulation is certainly only the first step towards a much broader liberalisation which will only benefit multinationals, and certainly not employees in the port and maritime sector, nor European employees and consumers as a whole.  It should therefore not be supported, except to see European ports end up as Piraeus, sold to Chinese groups.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that we must have a strategy that makes our ports more competitive and efficient not only at European level, but also globally.  With this Regulation, Union ports can maintain their port management models. It is not a total opening of ports, because this regulation allows to limit access to the market for port services, for reasons of space limitation, for the need to apply public service obligations.  There is a respect for their diversity. An example of this is the commitment to exclude from the scope of this Regulation the ports of the outermost regions, such as Madeira. Since these regions depend on 100% of maritime transport, this single European model for access to the market for port services has a special derogation for them.  I hope that this compromise for the outermost regions, reached in the Committee on Transport, will be maintained in the negotiations with the Council and in the final approval.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. If the amendments adopted by the TRAN Committee are positive (less activities involved and less regulation in these activities), this is still insufficient to vote favourably since, once again, States are forced to further liberalisation. This proposal for a regulation is certainly only the first step towards a much broader liberalisation which will only benefit multinationals, and certainly not employees in the port and maritime sector, nor European employees and consumers as a whole. That's why I voted AGAINST.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission’s ‘one-size-fits-all’ proposal for a new port services regulation failed to recognise the complexity and diversity of the EU’s port sector. Although Parliament has managed to secure some limited improvements to the Commission’s proposal, this draft legislation remains a blunt instrument with very little added value for port operators, users or workers. For this reason, Labour MEPs voted against Parliament’s Port Services Report and will continue to work with UK ports and unions to oppose this regulation.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to improve the transparency and competitiveness of European companies in order to better win back the port services market. I particularly supported positions aimed in particular at promoting the freedom of organization of ports and excluding dredging activities from the text for security reasons.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal I support aims to enable ports to operate safely and environmentally, which it aims to achieve by establishing a well-functioning and transparent framework. The report calls for minimum requirements such as professional qualifications of service providers and technical equipment to provide quality services to be met and monitored. I also agree with the establishment of port charges in an autonomous but transparent manner, as this also contributes to the development of natural competitiveness in this sector.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission’s proposal seeks to contribute to the goal of a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable functioning of the trans-European transport network through the creation of a framework which should improve the performance of ports and help them to cope with changes in transport and logistics requirements. Romania has two core network corridors in this programme: the Orient/East-Med Corridor and the Rhine-Danube Corridor. The benefits of the TEN-T core network through its corridors are to contribute to European cohesion and strengthen the internal market, this being the reason I voted for this report.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Regulation on access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports applies to all seaports within the trans-European transport network. Ports can contribute to the long-term competitiveness of European industries on world markets, while increasing added value and creating jobs in all EU coastal regions. In order to meet the challenges faced by the maritime transport sector, such as inefficiencies in the logistics and sustainable transport chain, it is essential that the measures set out in the Commission Communication 'Ports: an engine of economic growth' are implemented at the same time as this Regulation. The complexity of customs administrative procedures, resulting in delays at ports, is a major obstacle to the competitiveness of short sea shipping and the efficiency of Union ports.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report goes straight to the trialogue because the final vote has been postponed. The final form of the proposal is therefore not foreseeable, and this has led me to decide against this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. A common framework must be established for the interoperability of the trans-European transport network to help attract investment and encourage innovation in port services.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. The aim of this proposal for a Regulation is to remove restrictions on the provision of port services and to increase transparency in funding. In short, what is pursued is the liberalization of port services.  Although I generally agree with the content of this proposal, some legal problems arise with regard to port infrastructure charges. In Spain, ports are in the public domain and fees are those required for the use or use of such port public space. In short, we have a state port policy that would be severely affected by privatization. I consider that the proposal does not take into account the different realities and does not maintain the requirement of the principle of subsidiarity in the determination of fees. I cannot therefore support the proposal for a Regulation as it is proposed.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 It should be noted that the new regulation can have negative consequences for many ports.  There are doubts as to whether the new regulation will be an effective instrument to replace the system that has been successfully functioning so far. It also concerns the effectiveness of its legal regulation to ensure the efficient provision of port services and to stimulate investment. In particular, the scope envisaged covers services the regulation of which falls exclusively within the competence of the Member States. The new additional requirements may limit competition on the TEN-T network as well as reduce security in ports. In addition, they may partially restrict the autonomy of port managers and providers of port services and unduly increase the administrative and financial burden.  It is therefore necessary to properly assess the potential impact of the new Regulation and to establish rules that ensure stable and fair conditions of competition between EU ports. This would create a targeted, balanced and continuous development of the EU seaport sector.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Regulation on "access to the port services market" paves the way for the "liberalisation of port services" in monopolies. The EU for the interests of European business groups does not establish a uniform way of delivering port services to capital, leaving it to governments to define in each country its manner and form, depending on the interests and aspirations of each bourgeoisie, amid fierce competition to expand their activity and increase their profitability. With the implementation of the regulation, the ground is laid for the further damage to the rights of port workers. In voting against the regulation, the European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece stresses that ports and their services, either in various forms of direct delivery to the capital or with an operator of the urban state, serve the profits of monopolies, destroying labour rights, imposing galleon conditions.  The JRC contributes to the development of the popular struggle in opposition to monopolies, their power, capital associations such as the EU, because only in this way can the country's ports and infrastructure become popular property and be exploited by labour-popular power, integrated into a nationwide scientific project based on meeting social needs.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP have voted against this proposal as the regulation does not take into account the commercial nature of UK ports.  In order to ensure that commercial ports are exempt from this regulation, UKIP put forward an amendment to Article 1.3.  It is important to ensure that ports are entitled to operate fully as commercial businesses; this regulation does not allow it.  Furthermore, the ambiguity of the text creates uncertainty and puts essential future investment, growth and jobs at risk.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The organisation of ports and port services is a very important issue for the European Union. The aim of this report is to contribute to the more efficient, interconnected and sustainable functioning of TEN-T by establishing a framework to improve the efficiency of all ports and to help them address changes in requirements in the logistics and transport sectors.  The main objectives also include the modernisation of port services and operations and the creation of framework conditions for attracting investment to ports. In this regulation, the Commission intends to combat weak competitive pressure and possible market abuses in order to increase the efficiency of port services.  I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Europe’s ports are vital gateways, linking its transport corridors to the rest of the world with 74% of goods entering or leaving Europe by sea. Nevertheless the sector is facing major challenges in terms of traffic growth and investment. The EU needs good performing ports across all maritime regions. The Commission’s proposal seeks to contribute to the goal of a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable functioning of the TEN-T by creating a framework which improves the performance of ports and helps them to cope with changes in transport and logistics requirements. I believe the proposal could benefit all ports that are part of the trans-European transport network and I am, therefore, in favour of it.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. I support The Postponement, which aims in particular at a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable function of the TEN-T system by trying to build a framework that increases port productivity. At the same time, we also want to help them adapt to changes in transport and logistics with this proposal. I support the modernisation of port services and operations, but at the same time it is necessary to create an environment that will be of interest for major investments in ports. With this proposal, we also want to increase the competitiveness between ports, which is now at such a low level that monopoly abuses can be frequent. It is also important to lay down common EU rules determining when State aid is allowed to ports, which must in turn exclude aid intended to build additional port infrastructure and transport routes.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the postponement of the vote on the Report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the creation of a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports and the opening of negotiations with the Council and the Commission within the Transport and Tourism Committee.  When it comes to access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports, I think it is necessary to improve the efficiency and transparency in the operations of ports, as well as their better interconnection. As the main objectives of the proposal include modernising port services and operations and creating indicative conditions for attracting investment, I believe that the European Commission's objective to tackle the weak competitive pressure and potential market abuse by this Regulation is justified, all in order to increase the efficiency of port services. An important condition for fair competition between maritime ports at EU market level is a clear framework on State aid rules. In today's global market, it is not easy to cope with the ever-faster advancement of technology and increasing logistical requirements, and that is why I think it is important to give all ports the framework within which they need to organize their business. It is therefore necessary to set clear State aid rules to ensure a level playing field.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This proposed regulation is certainly only the first step towards a much broader liberalisation that will only benefit multinationals, and certainly not employees in the port and maritime sector, nor European employees and consumers as a whole. I consider ports to be of primary importance and that the Commission has no legitimacy to dispossess States. The outrageous liberalisation of the sector makes no economic sense. I do not want the French ports to be delivered to any private investors who will have no concern for the public interest. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The reform of port services contained in this report favours the modernisation of the 329 main seaports of the European Union. After the two reforms of 2001 and 2004 dealing with the liberalisation of the sector, the focus is on transparency, workers' rights and safety, social dialogue and environmental protection. Thanks to this, for the first time the reform receives the consent of all interested parties: port management bodies, operators and trade unions. In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, the various organisational models are protected and, at the same time, a framework is prepared that will increase efficiency and strengthen the competitiveness of the seaports of the trans-European transport network. The report provides that social and labour standards will not be affected by the regulation and that port workers will receive appropriate training. It also calls on the Committee on Social Dialogue in the Port Sector at Union level to develop guidelines on training requirements, to prevent accidents and to ensure the highest level of safety and health of port workers. Equally positive, I believe, are the provisions on financial transparency, complaints and the prevention of price abuse.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation of port service market access and port financial transparency contributes to the long-term competitiveness of European industry on global markets, increasing the added value and number of jobs in all coastal regions of the Union. In order to address the challenges facing the maritime transport sector, such as the inefficiencies of a sustainable transport and logistics chain, I support the continuation of negotiations on the creation of a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports, which should strengthen the efficiency of maritime ports and the trans-European transport network.  Modernising port services and creating a framework to attract investment in ports are important to combat weak competitive pressure and possible market abuse, which would ultimately lead to an increase in the efficiency of port services. This Regulation also seeks to fully respect labour and social rights by service providers and strengthen financial transparency.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The report deals with the legislative process on ports of the trans-European transport network. A Regulation which should establish an organisational framework for port services, a set of financial transparency rules and the costs to be applied by management bodies (public or private) or port service providers. Market operations, handling, passenger and piloting services are outside their scope. The proposals put forward by the European Parliament to the European Commission's initial proposal greatly improve the initial text, with direct implications in Portugal: they exclude piloting, introduce relevant labour issues and reduce the degree of liberalisation imposed. They do not, however, prevent the final result from being negative, since it is completely within the logic of liberalisation. It is interesting, for example, the concern expressed with the "users" of ports. At the same time that public transport users become customers, the client companies of the ports become users. A paradigm that can only be a black humor note. We have therefore voted in favour of the amendments made to the European Commission's proposal, which make it less bad, but we voted against the original proposal and the amended final document.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. I agree with my colleague Fleckenstein's report. I support a proposal for a European Parliament regulation that would improve the trans-European transport network (TEN-T) by setting up a system to improve the transit of goods through seaports. This regulation would not only allow for the modernisation of port infrastructure, but also increase their usability, and would attract investors, which would mean financial viability and new employment. In Croatia, this resolution would be positively echoed because the Port of Rijeka would be modernized and become competitive on the market. One of the great advantages of this document is financial transparency, but also the creation of legal certainty without which the TEN-T network would not work.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 About 1 200 EU ports play an essential role both in the transport sector itself and in Europe's overall competitiveness. I am sincerely glad that the European Parliament has approved this proposal from the pen of my social democratic colleague. The proposal succeeded where the previous two could not succeed because they did not take enough account of the social aspects and needs of the labour market. Clear rules on market access to port services and their transparency had to be established, as well as social dialogue with sector workers and their trade unions. In the end, the trade unions also supported this proposal, which received support from across political groups. However, all the social democrats' priorities are contained in it. Better organisation and control of the functioning of ports will lead to the creation of quality jobs, transparent funding and compliance with environmental commitments. And it will therefore be for the benefit of all.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The text presented in plenary amends the Commission's initial proposal to make free market access the basic principle for the provision of port services. Instead, the regulation states that a single market access system is not appropriate as the EU port system is characterised by a number of different models of organisation of port services. In this way, the current patterns of port management established at national level can be maintained in force. I believe, in fact, that ports should be able to decide, through the agreement between the various competent bodies, on the organisation of their services. With regard to the transparency of public funding for ports, I believe that public funds should be included transparently in port budgets and that port management bodies, which receive public funding and which provide port or dredging services on their own, should maintain separate accounts for these activities or investments financed from public funds. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal as amended by Parliament.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The draft regulation is the third attempt to regulate the port services market. The EP did not adopt a position in the previous parliamentary term and the work was suspended mainly due to the provisions of Chapter II on market access. EU action in the field of maritime transport, in line with the TFEU, is a shared competence. The management of seaports remains under the discretion of a Member State which establishes itself the system of seaports in its territory, monitors and supervises it, controls the management of public funds and ensures that the rules of competitiveness in the provision of port services are integrated. EU Member States have sufficient competence to support ports in improving their quality of service, modernising port facilities and enhancing their financial independence without additional new EU regulations.  The solutions in force in Polish seaports are good enough Polish not need to accept more, and the port market is more competitive than the market in the "old" EU. The Regulation may weaken the competitive position of Polish ports and worsen the conditions for their operation, worsen the conditions of operation of companies operating ships in ports and even dissuasive them from the market, and result in arbitrary deprivation of the possibility of providing services in the port, the possibility of limiting the number of providers of port services and chaos in port activities, already in force since 1996, the "Law on Seaports of particular importance in Poland". I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the draft regulation to increase efficiency and reduce the costs of services provided at EU seaports mainly for two reasons. Firstly, the interests of the French ports will be preserved as they will be able to continue to organize freely. Secondly, because small ports will be excluded from the scope of the regulation, in order to avoid unnecessary administrative burdens. Our position is to say that port activity is essential for the economic health of many European territories. Negotiations with the Council are now underway and I am counting on the Dutch Presidency to defend the positions adopted in Parliament.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. The SPÖ-EU delegation supported the report on the organisation of port services and financial transparency of ports. What is essential for us is that further liberalisation of port services is no longer possible. The protection of workers' rights could be strengthened and the right to strike enshrined in the text. In addition, we Social Democrats have been able to write a new article on the training standards of dockworkers and to enforce the strengthening of social dialogue.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP have voted against this proposal as the regulation does not take into account the commercial nature of UK ports.  In order to ensure that commercial ports are exempt from this regulation, UKIP put forward an amendment to Article 1.3.  It is important to ensure that ports are entitled to operate fully as commercial businesses; this regulation does not allow it.  Furthermore, the ambiguity of the text creates uncertainty and puts essential future investment, growth and jobs at risk.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. After months of work, the Socialist rapporteur for port services has managed to draw up a compromise text that has radically transformed the Commission's initial ultraliberal proposal. I myself have done an important amendment work with other colleagues, and I am pleased that Knut Fleckenstein has taken over much of it. This refers to the obligation of the national flag for the most sensitive services, public service obligations are also present, financial transparency is an essential point of the text, but the smallest or most vulnerable ports will not have as many administrative obligations as the larger ones. The text voted today provides the necessary social guarantees for us socialists, while at the very least, ensuring that Member States have the flexibility to allow them to retain their national models, without forcing them to liberalise and without imposing a single standard that might not work as well as existing models. It is now time to move on to the trilogue negotiations, Parliament will remain vigilant in the exercise of its power of codecision: it will only vote on the final text if it is good, because it is better not to have harmonisation rather than poor harmonisation.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, which I voted in favour of, seeks to contribute to a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable functioning of TEN-T by creating a framework that improves the performance of all ports and helps them to cope with the evolving logistical and transport needs. It should be noted, however, that the scope of the Regulation should only include port services offered directly to users. The report recognises that a number of port service organisation systems are currently in place and intends to amend provisions on minimum requirements, limitation of the number of service providers, services covered by public service obligations and social safeguards. With its amendments, the report emphasises the need for port management autonomy to act in accordance with its economic strategy, respecting certain fundamental principles. Overall, what is intended is to create legal certainty about ports and have a positive impact on the proper functioning of the TEN-T network.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. Responding to the objectives of a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable operation of the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T), the Commission's proposal aims to create favourable conditions for investment in ports, so as to modernise them and improve their performance.  This proposal aims to increase efficiency and reduce the cost of services provided at EU seaports, by establishing a common framework for market access for port services. To avoid price abuses in the absence of market mechanisms, this proposal also strengthens the financial transparency of ports, both for the establishment of fees for the use of services and port infrastructure as for public financing.   In addition to supporting these objectives and in the face of the wide variety of models for organising port services in Europe, the report of the Competent Committee of the European Parliament favoured, with a single system, an approach based on "minimum requirements" for suppliers and granted significant autonomy to port managers.  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this text which will enable enhanced interconnection and intelligent harmonisation of the port sector in Europe.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has adopted a proposal for a reform of the Union's port services focused on transparency, the guarantee of workers' rights and safety and environmental commitments. Other objectives of the proposal are the modernisation of port services and operations and the creation of structural conditions to attract new investments to ports. The Commission aims to counter weak competitive pressure and possible market abuses in order to increase the efficiency of port services. An important condition for competition between ports on a level playing field is the existence of a clear framework on State aid rules. This Regulation will apply to all seaports identified in the TEN-T guidelines, providing for some voluntary exceptions, in particular for ports located in the outermost regions.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. After long negotiations, yesterday we adopted yesterday by a relative majority (451 for, 243 against, 18 abstentions), the report on market access to port services and financial transparency of ports, which was seen as a balanced compromise and a good basis for opening inter-institutional negotiations. The text aims, among other things, to introduce greater transparency in the setting of charges for the use of port services and infrastructure, as well as for public aid for port activity. However, it also provides for a series of exemptions in order to preserve, under certain conditions, previous arrangements and limit the number of service providers, provided that minimum standards are met.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report on access to the port services market and a system of financial transparency of ports. The document will ensure the efficient and sustainable operation of the TEN-T network, which will improve the efficiency of all ports.  I appreciate the Commission's efforts to eliminate the conditions for distortion of competition and possible abuses of the market for port services. In addition, there is a clear framework of State aid rules for ensuring fair competition between ports.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for a reform of European port services. I supported this reform because it preserves the interests of the French ports and those who work there. Ports will benefit from greater autonomy while preserving excessive administrative burdens on small ports. Dredging and piloting activities are also excluded from any liberalisation in order to guarantee maritime safety. Requesting transparency in setting fees for the use of ports and port services, and for any public funding that ports receive, is necessary in order to avoid price abuses and market distortions. The aim of this reform is to increase efficiency and reduce the cost of services provided in European seaports in order to boost trade. A new phase of negotiations must now begin between Parliament, the Commission and the Member States in order to reach an agreement and make this port reform effective.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the regulation because I believe that the ports sector needs to be reformed as soon as possible. The report as a whole is heading in the right direction, although I did not agree with the rapporteur's proposal on the social clause to be imposed only and exclusively on those who issue invitations to tender, namely Italy and a few other Member States. In spite of this, I believe that blocking the text in Parliament would have meant an excessive extension of the legislative time that we simply cannot afford.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Fleckenstein report. The Commission's original proposal (2013), widely rejected by trade unions and port managers, was substantially amended in this parliamentary term, given Commissioner Bulc's position not to include the opening up of port services to the market. In this regard, the rapporteur made a report which differed significantly from the original proposal in meeting the demands of the different sectors involved. The commitment negotiations included aspects that, while not meeting all of our objectives, represent significant progress in social and labour matters, as well as improvements in the efficiency and transparency of port management, which could be lost in future legislative initiatives if the report is reversed. It is also a good basis for further negotiation with the Council.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. It is important that Europe's ports function optimally and attract investment. Modernising port services and operations can ensure this. At the same time, the law counteracts weak competitive pressure and market abuse, and this is important for the efficiency of port services. However, it is important to ensure that liberalisation does not prejudice workers' rights and opportunities. The proposal contains several elements to counteract negative consequences for workers. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted against all the amendments tabled in plenary and the motion of rejection, so that the mandate to open negotiations with the Council and the Commission in the Committee on Transport and Tourism can subsequently be debated. The Commission's proposal aims to contribute to a more efficient, better connected and sustainable functioning of the trans-European transport network, including the modernisation of port services, port operations and the creation of an attractive environment for investment in ports. There were some differences of opinion, which is why compromise amendments were tabled. An example of this is the determination of the structure and level of infrastructure charges independently of the port's management body in accordance with its own business strategy and investment plan.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. Parliament's report contains substantial improvements in relation to the Commission's proposal: for the third time, this House opposes the liberalisation of the port sector (although we fear that a new proposal in this regard will come in the coming months). In addition, work with European trade unions has made it possible to introduce recognition of vocational rights, health and occupational safety for port workers, although fringes remain in terms of the effective implementation of this standard and in aspects such as the protection of labour rights in the event of the transfer of port services. Despite this, some aspects of the Commission's initial proposal (in the financial transparency sections) open the door for competition policy to attack essential aspects of port financing and public management. That is why I have decided to abstain, pending the final proposal following negotiations with the Council.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. About 90% of world trade is made through sea routes. In Europe in Europe in europe, its 1200 ports employ three million people. These facts reflect the importance of this theme in the European context and beyond. It is important to liberalise ports so that they operate in a commercially efficient, financially transparent manner and that unfair competition is eliminated, but it is essential to ensure that the social rights of their workers are not affected. I believe that the report presented, with the amendments suggested in Parliament, responds adequately to the challenge proposed by the European Commission. Because I consider it crucial that the ports of the outermost regions of the European Union are managed according to their specificities, I have also voted in favour of Amendments 4 and 50. We cannot treat what is different equally and, as safeguarded in the Treaties, as well as in this context, the ORs are different.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP have voted against this proposal as the regulation does not take into account the commercial nature of UK ports.  In order to ensure that commercial ports are exempt from this regulation, UKIP put forward an amendment to Article 1.3.  It is important to ensure that ports are entitled to operate fully as commercial businesses; this regulation does not allow it.  Furthermore, the ambiguity of the text creates uncertainty and puts essential future investment, growth and jobs at risk.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I have joined my Labour colleagues in voting against the Parliament’s Port Services Report because I believe that, hitherto, the Commission’s approach has failed to acknowledge the complexity and diversity of the EU’s ports sector and is applying a ‘one-size-fits-all’ approach instead. Parliament has managed to secure some improvements, albeit limited, to the Commission’s proposal, but the draft legislation still remains unsophisticated and has very little added-value for port operators, workers and users. It is for this reason that I have voted against the Parliament’s Port Services Reportk, and I will continue working with UK ports and unions to oppose this regulation.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. I supported this proposal for a Regulation, as it primarily affects the financial transparency of seaports in the south of Europe, which also includes Croatian seaports. According to forecasts from 2014, Croatian ports recorded a drastic drop in traffic, and the liberalization of seaport services would have a positive effect on their work. While the report did not fully comply with environmental criteria in creating a framework for access to the port services market, it is the third attempt to liberalise seaport services, as two past Commission proposals have been rejected by Parliament. Liberalisation of seaport services in Europe is a strategically important decision that requires caution in the following fields: meeting environmental criteria when filling at ports, considering the social aspects of the impact of the regulation, reducing long-term navigation and comprehensive protection of workers' rights. The report describes well the necessity of improving the infrastructure of European seaports and simplifying administrative and border formalities and how to reduce the costs and delays of the outpost of goods.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I support the report on the proposal for a regulation on the functioning of ports and port services, because I believe that the negotiators have managed to reach an agreement that does not disadvantage port staff. The regulation will not directly affect social and labour standards for port workers, but will require these employees to be sufficiently trained in their working conditions. We also call for the creation of training manuals setting out ways to prevent accidents and ensure that port staff are as safe and well as possible. In addition, the report emphasises maintaining the right to strike under any circumstances.  Overall, this proposal aims to improve the performance of all ports and help them cope with changes in transport and logistics requirements. The aim of the proposal also includes modernising port services and operations and creating framework conditions for attracting investment in ports. With this proposal, the Commission is also trying to counter the weak competitive pressure and possible market abuses, thereby increasing the efficiency of port services. As each Member State has its own specific practice of laying down rules for ports and port services, I am glad that the regulation leaves sufficient leeway for national regulatory authorities. At the same time, I believe that the regulation will contribute to creating legal certainty for ports and will have a positive impact on the functioning of trans-European transport networks.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The ports connect Europe to the world. European ports account for more than a third of EU trade and play a major role in the transport sector, and they also represent the potential for jobs and investment. In 2013, the European Commission attempted to introduce the liberalisation of port services. The Commission shall aim to make the TEN-T network more efficient, interconnected and sustainable by creating a framework that improves the capacity of all ports and takes into account current transport and logistics requirements. The regulation aims to prevent unfair competition between ports and to increase the commercial efficiency of port services. This proposal is also to ensure financial transparency of ports, transparency and reduce red tape for users. Unemployment is a major problem these days and the modernisation of ports can create new jobs, especially in the EU's coastal regions. Taking into account the diversity and advantages of European ports, it is necessary to strive for equal and balanced development of them. It is important to support the successful operation of the TEN-T network, which also includes Slovenia, and to promote port development and job creation in general. As a result of the above, I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation establishing a framework for market access for port services and financial transparency of ports.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. In the end, I supported Mr Fleckenstein's report. The compromise reached is not ideal and it could have gone much further in a number of respects in adapting the Commission's proposal, but it is the best possible compromise. I myself live in Antwerp. The Antwerp port community is not entirely happy with the compromise either, but they can live with it. I supported the green amendments, including on the right to strike and the proposal to include external costs. The exercise of the legitimate right to engage in collective bargaining or collective action, including the right to strike, should never be regarded as a disturbance of port services for which emergency measures may be taken. The Commission urgently needs to prepare an integrated port policy. As far as we are concerned, 2019 is the ultimate date for that. I also supported the rapporteur's proposal to start negotiations with transport ministers now, in the hope of reaching a good compromise.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The topic "Port Package" has been covered for 10 years. The long discussion is based on unrelated considerations of the original versions. This report cannot be satisfied on a theoretical basis. In particular, the distinction between public and private tasks is not sharp. However, this report also manifests major conflicts of interest. Of particular importance is the passage to the surrounding infrastructure. As long as this infrastructure is available to the general public, it is general infrastructure which is not geared solely to the profit intentions of port operations. This also applies, for example.B, to roads in ports that are available to the general public. It is therefore a general infrastructure which the State makes available to all citizens. This general infrastructure finds its limits where large parts of society are excluded from its use. In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, the planning, construction and maintenance of this infrastructure is not the eu's task; this can be properly assessed on the spot. I voted in favour of adoption in order to allow a minimum of legal certainty. Autonomous action by the EU Commission would have been detrimental to the EU's reputation.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 European ports have great potential to create a competitive environment on the world market and offer work to many people.  However, a number of problems remain in the maritime transport sector in the longer term. In particular, significant simplification of the customs procedure will be crucial, which will ultimately bring with it a significant economic advantage over competition.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. 'The port package approved today paves the way for increased competition for port services traditionally offered in a port. It is time to open up the markets and create a level playing field. The European Commission's proposal dates back to 2013, so it is urgently time to start negotiations with the Council.  The votes can count on the support of my region, Flanders. Excessive administrative burdens on financial transparency were avoided and dredging was removed from the proposal. All in all, it is a balanced agreement and a good basis for the talks with the Council.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 The vast majority of the Union's maritime transport passes through the ports of the trans-European transport network. In order to achieve the objective of this Regulation in a proportionate manner without imposing unnecessary burdens on other ports, this Regulation should apply to trans-European transport network ports, each of which plays a significant role in the European transport system, either because it manages more than 0.1% of the total EU cargo or the total number of passengers, or because it improves the regional accessibility of islands or peripheral areas.  Deep-sea piloting services do not have a direct impact on port efficiency as they are not used for direct entry and exit of ports and therefore do not need to be included in this Regulation. The managing authority of the port receiving public funds, when also acting as a service provider, should be imposed on the obligation to maintain separate accounts for activities carried out as the managing authority of the port from those carried out on the basis of competition in order to ensure a level playing field, transparency in the allocation and use of public funds and to avoid market distortions. In any case, compliance with State aid rules should be ensured, and I supported the report.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for market access to port services and financial transparency of ports. Liberalisation means having a choice for the consumer, and for entrepreneurs and businesses that they have to work hard and do a good job. All of us who grew up in socialism know firsthand what it means when you don't have a choice. The services sector in the EU is still very wrapped up in cotton wool, which costs consumers, businesses and society as a whole dearly. I therefore welcome the liberalisation of services in ports, and at the same time regret that the process of extending the regulation has been unnecessarily extended. Although some would like to see the introduction of amendments more quickly, I believe that the regulation is an appropriate compromise that gives existing and potential new ing bidders the appropriate time to prepare for the revised working conditions.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I could not support this report – I believe that competition between ports, rather than prescriptive regulation on ports’ internal operations, will be a greater driver for efficiency.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The text partially betters the Commission's proposal, as it deletes most proposals to ensure access to the port services market, adds important references to the protection of labour rights and collective agreements and includes positive reference to the need to ensure the health and safety of workers. However, we cannot ignore the fact that many individual reforms are being promoted, to reduce costs and increase competitiveness as a step towards the ultimate objective of full liberalisation of port services. There are also a number of negative, problematic reports about workers, which we cannot accept, as they neutralise, if employers so seek, the positive reports that have been included in the text. That is why we voted against the text.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the establishment of a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports. I agree with the reporter that ports play a major role in the long-term competitiveness of European industries, creating added value and jobs in all coastal regions of the Union. Increasing their effectiveness is a priority. In my opinion, the report further strengthened the Commission's material, which will thus contribute more effectively to the more integrated and sustainable functioning of TEN-T. I welcome the amendments that emphasise making port operations safer and more environmentally sustainable. Not only do the amendments promote the modernisation of port services, but the rapporteur has clearly taken a position on the importance of the social provisions governing the port labour law system and workers' rights, including advocates for better training and improved security conditions for port employees. Nevertheless, I underline that I supported the adoption of amendments 146 and 147 with particular emphasis in the vote. Overall, the rapporteur has contributed to the efficient functioning of the TEN-T network and to improving legal certainty at ports.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 For the third time in recent years, the Commission has put forward a proposal for a regulation aimed at contributing to a more efficient, integrated and sustainable functioning of the TEN-T network by creating a framework to improve port efficiency, better financing, management and competitiveness. The Commission's objectives seem to be as good as possible, but the concrete legal proposals contained in the document may raise some concerns. The proposal includes solutions to m.in. imposing public service obligations on certain providers, differentiating port infrastructure charges according to commercial practices and environmental and energy efficiency. I believe that this is too far-reaching an interference which, instead of the objectives set out in the regulation, may, as a result, lead to a reduction in the competitiveness of the sector and to the introduction of charges which some port service providers will not be able to bear. Moreover, the application of the 'one framework for all' principle may lead to worse results than those currently achieved by national legislation. Furthermore, EU action in the port sector should also take into account the local and regional dimension, as well as the specific hydrological and ecological conditions of marine areas. I have therefore chosen to vote against the EP's report on access to the port services market and the transparency of port financing.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 The Port Services Directive has been in preparation for a long time and ports should be able to determine their fees themselves. In addition, there must be an equal legal framework throughout Europe for the organisation of port services and the transparency of public funds when making port investments. In some Member States, port services have already been opened up to public competition, so a uniform practice in this sector is to be supported. That is why I support the report.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 European ports are some of the most important components of maritime transport in our continent. As gateways to other parts of the world, they must receive greater attention from the institutions of the European Union. The adoption of framework regulations to increase efficiency and strengthen the competitiveness of seaports within the trans-European transport network was imperatively necessary. The specific situation of ports located in marginal areas should also be taken into account. The process of liberalisation of services on the European market could adversely affect port activity, in particular through the disappearance of some jobs. It is therefore necessary to comply with certain social regulations in order to ensure the necessary working conditions and training, as well as a high level of safety at work and a decent state of health. At the same time, the rights of these workers, including those relating to the strike, must be respected.  Another aspect concerns ensuring financial transparency with a view to fair competition and preventing tariff abuses. Where the situation so requires, States should be able to invest in the development of port infrastructure, without this being considered State aid. This document is necessary and must be adopted without delay.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal, which has as its primary objectives the modernization of port services and operations as well as the creation of framework conditions to attract investment in ports. Through this regulation, the Commission intends to combat low competitive pressure and the risk of market abuse in the sector in order to increase the efficiency of port services.  Goods handling and passenger services are excluded from Chapter II on market access, as they are often subject to concession contracts and are therefore subject to the scope of the Directive on the award of such contracts. The proposed regulation and the 2014/23/EU directive on the awarding of concession contracts should therefore be considered jointly.  Ensuring a level playing field between ports also requires a clear framework on state aid rules. The Commission is currently re-evaluating the scope of the General Category Exemption Regulation with the aim of including port infrastructure criteria by December 2015.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ In order to save the consensus achieved in committee and to start the negotiations as soon as possible, I favoured all provisions coming for the report as adopted in the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) and rejected all proposals to amend it. I am not entirely satisfied with it as it stands as I expected further liberalisation of the market access to port services; however provisions on financial transparency for ports are an important step towards a clearer legal framework for public and private investment. The Commission proposal has been on the table since 2013, it is more than timely that we end the legal uncertainty under which we are placing the stakeholders of a sector which badly needs reforms. We will now have the opportunity to improve the text throughout the negotiations with the Council and the Commission.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. The extent of European port trade justifies the harmonisation of rules on port services, but only if it is done on the basis of high standards. While the European Commission, in an ultra-liberal approach, proposed the outright liberalisation of port services, the European Socialists rallied alongside the trade unions to radically overhaul the text.  Thus, after the work of offensive amendments, we obtained solid assurances. We guarantee the use of national pavilions for sensitive services. Public service obligations are included in the text, which takes on a social dimension. We have also made key progress on the issue of financial transparency in order to put an end to unfair competition by some ports.  Although I regret that the right voted against some of the amendments I tabled with Labour to strengthen workers' rights, it has sufficient social guarantees for me to support it. Now it's time for negotiations with the Council. But the European transport ministers are warned: if we go back to a liberalisation project, the final text will not have my voice.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for market access to port services and financial transparency of ports was supported, as the regulation provides urgently needed legal certainty for ports, increases the efficiency of the operation of ports and lowers the prices of port services. The establishment of framework conditions and the modernisation of port service activities are key to creating an encouraging and promising environment for port development, while also attracting new investment in ports. I believe that the regulation can take an important step towards a fair and level playing field for all European ports.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Fleckenstein report. The Commission's original proposal (2013), widely rejected by trade unions and port managers, was substantially amended in this parliamentary term, given Commissioner Bulc's position not to include the opening up of port services to the market. In this regard, the rapporteur made a report which differed significantly from the original proposal in meeting the demands of the different sectors involved. The commitment negotiations included aspects that, while not meeting all of our objectives, represent significant progress in social and labour matters, as well as improvements in the efficiency and transparency of port management, which could be lost in future legislative initiatives if the report is reversed. It is also a good basis for further negotiation with the Council.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The topic "Port Package" has been covered for 10 years. The long discussion is based on unrelated considerations of the original versions. This report cannot be satisfied on a theoretical basis. In particular, the distinction between public and private tasks is not sharp. However, this report also manifests major conflicts of interest. Of particular importance is the passage to the surrounding infrastructure. As long as this infrastructure is available to the general public, it is general infrastructure which is not geared solely to the profit intentions of port operations. This also applies, for example.B, to roads in ports that are available to the general public. It is therefore a general infrastructure which the State makes available to all citizens. This general infrastructure finds its limits where large parts of society are excluded from its use.  In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, the planning, construction and maintenance of this infrastructure is not the eu's task; this can be properly assessed on the spot. I voted in favour of adoption in order to allow a minimum of legal certainty. Autonomous action by the EU Commission would have been detrimental to the EU's reputation.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this regulation because I believe that real competition among ports is fundamental in order to achieve real and sustainable economic growth. Only if every region is able to compete will Europe regain its lost economic strength. The state monopolies from the south like Puertos del Estado in Spain and their centralised management are a drag on the economic growth of Europe.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Although positive, the efforts of the TRAN Committee are insufficient to vote favourably on the text, since once again States are forced, as with all transport concerns, to be forced to further liberalisation.  This proposal for a regulation is certainly only the first step towards a much wider liberalisation which will benefit only multinationals and not employees in the port and maritime sector, nor European employees and consumers as a whole. The European Union is dangerously exposing the European port sector to the terrible example of the port of Piraeus, the latest victim of ultra-liberalisation, sold last January to COSCOCS, a giant Chinese shipowner. I therefore vote against this text.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposal aims to contribute to a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable operation of TEN-T by developing a framework that improves port operations and helps them adapt to changed transport and logistical requirements. The main objectives of the proposal include the modernisation of port services and operations and the setting of framework conditions for port investment. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Fleckenstein report. The Commission's original proposal (2013), widely rejected by trade unions and port managers, was substantially amended in this parliamentary term, given Commissioner Bulc's position not to include the opening up of port services to the market. In this regard, the rapporteur made a report which differed significantly from the original proposal in meeting the demands of the different sectors involved. The commitment negotiations included aspects that, while not meeting all of our objectives, represent significant progress in social and labour matters, as well as improvements in the efficiency and transparency of port management, which could be lost in future legislative initiatives if the report is reversed. It is also a good basis for further negotiation with the Council.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I abstained in the final vote on this report. The report in general terms is very negative in terms of the environmental regulation of ports and certain social criteria. But it contained an important and very positive element for decentralised port management, such as the decentralised tariff system, introduced through an amendment from the Committee on Transport which I voted in favour of in plenary. Precisely because of this positive element, I abstained from the vote because, because of the joint content from a left-wing and environmentalist perspective, the report is negative and we hope that it will be improved in the tripartite dialogues.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – A clear framework of State aid rules is an important criterion for fair competition between ports on an equal footing. This Regulation will apply to all seaports covered by the TEN-T guidelines and, according to the Commission, will help to eliminate the additional administrative burden faced by already well-functioning ports, while at the same time helping other ports to meet their structural challenges.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: Writing. – I believe that, in the third step, the European Parliament has succeeded in preparing a proposal for a regulation on market access to port services and port financial transparency systems acceptable to all parties.  It is unequivocally clear that there is a need to improve transparency in the European Union, including Latvia, with regard to the setting of port service charges and the public funding received. If the port authority receives public funding, it must be transparent and keep separate records of operations financed from public funds. The establishment of a single port system in the EU would not be appropriate, as there are large differences between member states' port systems, including many different models for the organisation of port services and port management.  I also do not consider the introduction of free competition between EU ports to be right. Such a system would put shipping companies in a privileged position, threatening especially small ports, including Latvia. Needless to say, a large proportion of shipping companies are not at all European Union companies. For example, the charging of port infrastructure is necessarily left to the port authority. Needless to say, it is important for Latvia to ensure the development of ports, including the bureaucratic burden as much as possible.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report that regulates market access to port services and financial transparency of ports. The report is designed to support the increase in their efficiency and the reduction in costs of services supplied at the ports. It underlines the prevention of price abuse and market distortions while boosting maritime trade flows and allows for ports to keep their current service arrangements, provided they meet minimum requirements. I voted in favour of this report as it aims for more transparent and fairly priced EU maritime port facilities.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. We abstain in the final vote on the third attempt to liberalise port services because, despite improving social aspects and, in particular, the surrogacy of staff, the approved text still makes a number of reservations to us.  We welcome the socialist proposal in favour of greater transparency in port funding sources, which will help to verify the State aid that ports in central and northern Europe receive, with more reason in matching this adoption with the Commission's new proposal to exempt aid to port infrastructure from ex ante control of competition. Likewise, in the face of the Commission's interest in deregulation of port tariffs, the Spanish Socialists are in charge of the mandate of the current Spanish Constitution adopting these tariffs by congress, as it maintains in solidarity the current network of our ports, which would otherwise reduce their presence in the territory, without improving competition with European ports. Nevertheless, we prefer to abstain in the mandate from the rapporteur, who has recognised the Spanish peculiarity in working during the tripartite dialogues with the Council.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. I felt that it failed to add much for UK ports, while also representing a very cumbersome sledgehammer with which to achieve the required policy goals. Many unions and other organisations have raised deep concerns with me about this legislation which I do not feel have been adequately addressed. The Commission’s ‘one-size-fits-all’ proposal for a new Port Services Regulation failed to recognise the complexity and diversity of the EU’s port sector. Although Parliament has managed to secure some limited improvements to the Commission’s proposal, not least greater social aspects, this draft legislation remains a blunt instrument with very little added value for port operators, users or workers. For this reason, I voted against the Parliament’s Port Services report and will continue to work with UK ports and unions to oppose this regulation.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation on access to the port services market and the financial transparency of ports. This measure will connect European ports to a trans-European network, which will lead to more innovation and a more effective functioning of the relevant port services.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This report focuses on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council establishing a framework for market access for port services and financial transparency of ports.  First, of course, the Commission was aimed at liberalising port services and operations. The aim was to create conditions to attract investors and combat the "low competition" of the sector to "improve the quality of port services".  Following the mobilization of trade unions and the work of the TRAN Committee, the directive was revised in the direction of protecting social rights and workers. The focus has been on social and environmental standards, including safety and health. The possibility of a national flag has been amended, which obliges compliance with national and local standards as well as collective agreements of each port in order to combat social dumping and cabotage.  Although we must remain very attentive to the changes that still can be made, I voted in favour of the directive amended by the European Parliament to give a mandate in favour of the rights of employees in agreement with trade union organisations in the sector.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 It should be noted that the amendments introduced by the European Parliament, in its specialised transport committee, to the initial proposal of the European Commission greatly improve the initial text, with direct implications in Portugal: they exclude piloting, introduce relevant labour issues and reduce the degree of liberalisation imposed. However, we do not subscribe to the final version because it is completely based on the logic of liberalisation. It is interesting, for example, the concern expressed with the "users" of ports. Irony of the ironies, while public transport users are made to customers, port client companies become users. Our sense of voting is therefore explained by what has been voted on: we voted in favour of the amendments to the European Commission's proposal, which make it less bad, and we voted against the original proposal and the final amended document.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The benefits of such a regulation would be a more efficient, better connected and sustainable functioning of the trans-European transport network, but a new regulation would also mean more harmonised EU law, and even more. Due to the large number of amendments, it was not possible to assess what this proposal looks like at the end of the vote.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on access to the market for port services and financial transparency of ports. There is no reason to subject all EU ports to uniform regulation. Moreover, it is superfluous to subject ports and port services to special regulation. We are not dealing with a general law in the sense of Hayek in this regulation. As a result, this is a bad law, which also violates the principles of subsidiarity.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission’s ‘one-size-fits-all’ proposal for a new port services regulation failed to recognise the complexity and diversity of the EU’s port sector. Although Parliament has managed to secure some limited improvements to the Commission’s proposal, this draft legislation remains a blunt instrument with very little added value for port operators, users or workers. For this reason Labour MEPs will continue to work with UK ports and unions to oppose this regulation.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports aimed at increasing efficiency and lowering costs for services provided in EU seaports. The rapporteur considers that unfair prices and market distortions, as well as the encouragement of trade, can be achieved through greater transparency in the setting of fees for the use of port services and infrastructures, as well as in the public financing of ports. The adoption of this report by the EP does not affect national rules on labour and social protection in ports.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Regulation on "access to the port services market" paves the way for the "liberalisation of port services" in monopolies. The EU for the interests of European business groups does not establish a uniform way of delivering port services to capital, leaving it to governments to define in each country its manner and form, depending on the interests and aspirations of each bourgeoisie, amid fierce competition to expand their activity and increase their profitability. With the implementation of the regulation, the ground is laid for the further damage to the rights of port workers. In voting against the regulation, the European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece stresses that ports and their services, either in various forms of direct delivery to the capital or with an operator of the urban state, serve the profits of monopolies, destroying labour rights, imposing galleon conditions.  The JRC contributes to the development of the popular struggle in opposition to monopolies, their power, capital associations such as the EU, because only in this way can the country's ports and infrastructure become popular property and be exploited by labour-popular power, integrated into a nationwide scientific project based on meeting social needs.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: Writing. \u2012 In the vote on improving the efficiency of port operations, I supported the European Parliament's position on the Port Services Regulation and its way forward.
