Although this is already the third attempt to push for a regulation of port services at European level and a number of things remain controversial, the Commission's proposal this time has been greatly improved by the European Parliament, so I thank the European Parliament's rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for long-term compromises. From a content point of view, I would like to stress that parliament's position has made important improvements, for example by not supporting the regulation of the principle of free competition in the regulation of port services, thereby recognising the diversity of ports and allowing the existing different models for port management and the organisation of services established at national level to be maintained in the Member States.  I also welcome the fact that port infrastructure charges can be set autonomously by the managing body of the port. As regards port service charges, a number of guiding principles of transparency and non-discrimination will have to be respected. In the case of public funding, I believe that transparency and the determination of transparency in the use of funds by listing separately actions carried out using public funds are proportionate and will not constitute a significant obstacle to port development.  The position adopted today by the European Parliament is a good basis for negotiations with the Council with a view to adopting the regulation in its final form.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Ports are an extremely important part of the transport sector in the European Union and their proper functioning is of great importance for the economic development of the Member States. Existing regulations leave a significant part of port infrastructure management competences in the hands of governments, allowing for a coherent policy, stimulating investment and defending the interests of national port operators.  The Commission's proposal will adversely affect the situation of ports in many countries, increasing bureaucracy and limiting the influence of Member States in shaping their own policies in this area. It is particularly dangerous for Polish ports to actually limit the possibility of supporting public modernisation and investment in port infrastructure, which could lead to a decrease in their competitiveness.  In western Europe, for many years ports have benefited from generous public support and thus built their strong position on the European market. Now, through regulation at EU level, similar actions are being attempted by the Polish Government, among others, which will consolidate the competitive advantage of Western European ports, especially German ones. We have seen before how a similar mechanism has worked for the shipbuilding industry.  We must bear in mind that the right slogans about the need to open up the market, simplify procedures and reduce costs often hide particular national interests. Given the possible negative effects of the Commission's proposal on Polish ports, I voted against this report.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Feckenstein report because I believe that it increases efficiency and strengthens the competitiveness of trans-European transport hubports, without jeopardising the social and labour rules in force in the Member States. I would point out that the report ensures the right to strike, as collective labour actions taken in accordance with the national legislation of the respective Member State and/or the agreements applicable between the social partners are not considered interruptions of port services for which emergency measures can be taken. The report also provides for financial transparency provisions that ensure fair competition and prevent price abuse, in particular where port services are not subject to effective competition.  Finally, I would stress that the report also takes into account the specific situation of ports located in outermost regions.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 There are over 300 ports in the European network, providing more than three million jobs directly or indirectly. They are characterised by diversity in size, management mode and organisation. As I support the idea of advanced and balanced joint European measures on ports, which will, inter alia, improve the financial transparency of the operations of ports and maintain their competitiveness, I supported the opening of tripartite negotiations between the Commission, the Council and the committee responsible.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The harmonisation of consumer price indices is an extremely sensitive issue, as it is linked to the issue of inflation, on which decisions on European economic and monetary policy are based. The improvements made are a long way from making these manoeuvres acceptable. Moreover, by including house prices and taxation, the new index will better reflect reality, on the one hand, but, on the other, it will inflate the inflation figure by making the ECB's unconventional policies appear more positive than they actually are. That is why I have chosen to vote against.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. – This proposed legislation seeks to harmonise indices across the EU, but doing so will not reflect the various cultural differences in economic activity between different Member States, and accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation which updates the statistical methodology for the development of a harmonised consumer price index, as this is essential for accurate inflation rate data, both in the EU and in the Eurozone.  The Regulation also recognises, at the initiative of the Spanish Socialists, that consumer price statistics are a public good.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – This proposed legislation seeks to harmonise indices across the EU, but doing so will not reflect the various cultural differences in economic activity between different Member States, and accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against this report. This file is concerned with the Harmonised Index of Consumer Prices (HCIP) The HCIP deals with price stability. The problematic aspects of the text relates to the fact that there is a provision within the text which permits the possibility of allowing for future indexes in the following areas: narcotics, games of chance, prostitution, life insurance, which of course raises a number of issues. Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I have decided to vote against this report because it leaves it to the European Commission many powers to define central details in relation to the definition of this price index which is fundamental to the living conditions of workers in the European Union. The report gives the Commission the ability to change the list of products considered when developing this index, without limiting the possibility of including products such as certain types of drugs or activities such as prostitution. Taking into account the effects that such inclusions can have, and above all the legitimacy effect on such activities that would have decisions like these, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report harmonising consumer price indices, because the report provides statistical information on price stability, which is vital for correcting macroeconomic imbalances in the EU. Rationalisation must be achieved in a clearer scope, maintaining separate treatment for health, education and other specific areas, reducing the scope for interpretation of the rules, ensuring uniform treatment of similar product groups in all Member States, removing unnecessary parts of legislation, and clarifying previously misinterpreted provisions. In addition, incomplete statistics were partly responsible for the economic crisis that began in 2008. This new legislation improves the quality of consumer price indices, which are important for correcting macroeconomic imbalances in the EU.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted against the report and against the motion for a resolution on the grounds that the amendments it makes to the original regulation, although essentially technical, can be used for political purposes. Indeed, the economic indices discussed here are often a means of better controlling Member States by imposing targets on them or a means to decree an imaginary growth. It is remembered that in 2014, reforms to the methods of calculating GDP had allowed the integration of prostitution and other illegal activities, the thus inflating the growth by 0.5%. With the package adopted by Parliament giving the Commission a lot of power, I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ As a UKIP MEP, it is consistent for me to vote against harmonisation in all forms. In this particular case, I note that there are challenges in regard to consumer pricing indices; in the UK, the index is vastly impacted by house prices and mortgage interest rates. Given that private home ownership is at much higher levels there than in most of continental Europe, this leads to a discrepancy. There is no real requirement for harmonisation or for a further EU Regulation on this subject.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. Harmonized Consumer Price Indexes (CHIS) are a measure of inflation that provides valuable information on the deflation of economic values such as wages, rents and interest rates. They are therefore the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. I voted in favour of this resolution because it allows harmonised, and therefore comparable statistics to be put in place between the Member States and thus to better coordinate economic and monetary measures within the Union.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation which updates the statistical methodology for the development of a harmonised consumer price index, as this is essential for accurate inflation rate data, both in the EU and in the Eurozone.  The Regulation also recognises, at the initiative of the Spanish Socialists, that consumer price statistics are a public good.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to harmonise consumer price indices. This proposal establishes a uniform legal framework for the development, compilation and dissemination of harmonised consumer price indices (HICP) and house price indices (CCI) data at Union, national and sub-national level. The HICP is a measure of inflation used as valuable data to recalculate economic value (e.g. wages, rents, interest rates) in line with inflation and is therefore the basis for economic and monetary policy decision-making. It is therefore necessary that these statistics be objective, impartial and comparable for all Member States and for all product categories. The current HICP Regulation was drawn up as early as 1995, but new developments in consumer price statistics require a revision of the existing norms in order to ensure the highest possible comparability for key users of the HICP.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The Harmonized Consumer Price Index (CHPI) is a consumer price index (CPI) calculated for each of the European Union countries and a few other European countries. To calculate the level of inflation, it is used by the ECB as an indicator of price stability and as a means of verifying compliance with the convergence criterion in terms of inflation. The amendments would establish a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of the harmonized consumer price index, the harmonised consumer price index at constant tax rates (IPCH-TC), the owner-occupied housing price index (LOP) and the EU-level real estate price index (IPI) as well as at the national and sub-national level. It is essentially a technical modification of the regulation to better take into account price changes across the Member States. However, these indices can be used as political tools to better control Member States by imposing targets on them... or in order to regain imaginary growth by changing the calculation formulas. That's why I abstained.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of a uniform legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonized consumer price indices (CHPI) and harmonised house price indices (IPIs) at EU level as well as at national and sub-national level.   Wrong statistics were partly responsible for the financial crisis in 2008. This new legislation will improve the quality of consumer price indices that are important for correcting macroeconomic imbalances in the European Union.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Regulation because of the existing need to update the reference period for price indices so that they are comparable and relevant. The Harmonised Consumer Price Indexes are a key tool for achieving the price stability objective of the European System of Central Banks and, therefore, for defining the monetary policy of euro area countries.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Harmonised consumer price indices (HICPs) measure inflation in a harmonised way in all Member States. The ECB and the Commission, in accordance with Article 140 TFEI, use these instruments to assess price stability in different countries and national competitiveness in the context of macroeconomic imbalance procedures. The HIERC regulation currently in force dates back to 1995 and caused many problems at the time of the outbreak of the economic crisis in 2008. The wide proliferation of flawed and poor quality statistics, combined with the development of new instruments in the field of consumer price statistics, has made it necessary to revise the whole structure in order to ensure maximum comparability of data between the different users. The Gualtieri report, which I supported with my vote, has made some changes to the proposal for a regulation presented by the Commission. The text approved by Parliament further improves the draft by presenting more up-to-date and efficient legislation on statistical methodology.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted against this report amending the criteria used to monitor the prices of consumer products in the EU. These indices are a fundamental tool for the adoption of certain macroeconomic decisions. We find the Commission's high discretion to amend these criteria problematic through delegated acts, and also the open door for concepts such as prostitution, gambling, narcotics and others to be included in the indexes.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his work in reaching agreement in this Regulation on harmonised consumer price indices. It establishes a uniform legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on consumer price indices and house prices at Union, national and subnational level. There will be pilot studies funded by the Commission where appropriate and in addition every five years the Commission shall submit a report to the co-legislators assessing the main results of those studies.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report moves towards excessive harmonisation of the categories of expenditure to which the choices of consumers in economically too heterogenic countries converge. In addition, the proposed evaluation criteria will be interpreted and used by the Commission and the ECB to develop crazy new austerity policies. For all these reasons, I did not intend to support this text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report. This document aims to update the statistical methodology for the development of a harmonised consumer price index in the European Union; the current Regulation dates back to 1995 and the latest statistical developments on consumer prices required a revision of the current framework to ensure maximum compatibility for major IPCA users. This update is also important for the purposes of the Stability and Growth Pact, as early interim information on inflation, especially for monetary policy management, is essential.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which aims to adopt a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on harmonised indices of consumer prices. The Commission's proposal for a regulation establishes a uniform legal framework for the development, compilation and dissemination of harmonised consumer price indices (HICP) and house price indices (CCI) data at Union, national and sub-national level. The HICP is a measure of inflation used, inter alia, as valuable data that recalculate economic value (e.g. wages, rents, interest rates) in line with inflation and is therefore the basis for economic and monetary policy decision-making. It is therefore essential that these statistics are objective, impartial and comparable for all Member States and for all product categories. The current HICP Regulation was drawn up back in 1995. New developments in consumer price statistics require a review of existing rates in order to ensure the highest possible comparability for key users of the HICP. The Regulation also takes into account the innovations in EU decision-making introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, which empowers the Commission (Eurostat) to adopt implementing measures (implementing acts) or legislative measures (delegated acts) which may amend non-essential elements of the Regulations. For this reason, a number of actions in the Commission's proposal need to be set out by means of delegated acts, for example by establishing a methodology suitable for compiling harmonised indices for country-comparable indices or updating the weightings of the HICP sub-indices.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. -u2012 I welcome and support the proposed regulation. It is an important update of the obsolete system for the setting of criteria for the dissemination of harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP) and residential property price indices (HPI) at EU and Member State level. The HICP forms the basis for determining inflation on which all major economic and monetary decisions are based. It is therefore all the more important that the system is objective and the statistics must clearly show the facts. The proposed regulation updates the 1995 Regulation and takes into account in particular the innovations in EU decision-making brought about by the Treaty of Lisbon – the competence of the Commission or the Commission. eurostat when adopting implementing and delegated acts. The important thing raised by the rapporteur seems to me to be the requirement for monthly preparation of HICP estimates by the Member States, which will improve the quality of provisional inflation data.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Flawed statistics and inhomogeneity of calculation between Member States contributed, among many other factors, to the delay in responses to the 2008 economic crisis. The optimisation of legislation on harmonised consumer price indices makes it possible to simplify legislation, reducing the room for possible divergent interpretations at national level. The aim of the report is to create a favourable environment for the effective implementation of monetary policies developed within the European framework, reducing response times by Member States for the production and dissemination of relevant statistical data. I therefore support the changes that have been made, in the hope that the European Union will be able to respond promptly to future macroeconomic imbalances, thanks in part to more homogeneous and objective information for a key sector such as price stability.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒u2012 I support this Report, which updates existing statistical methodologies and simplifies its elements into a single HICP regulation. The key is to correct the macroeconomic imbalance in the EU.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report presents some very interesting findings regarding the increase in fraud concerning, in particular, the management of the rural development fund or, in Turkey, the funds relating to the "pre-accession instrument" or the collection of VAT. It also raises violations of public procurement rules by the refugee fund on the pretext of an emergency. On the other hand, the report calls for a series of measures aimed at strengthening the EU's judicial powers over Member States and creating new super-structures such as, for example, the granting of a specific procedural right to OLAF or the establishment of a European prosecutor's office with broad judicial powers, particularly in the area of VAT fraud. I am deeply committed to the sovereignty of The Member States in judicial matters and therefore strongly opposed to these provisions. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that an update of the instruments for measuring inflation is necessary to enable decision-makers to take the most appropriate monetary policy decisions, especially in a turbulent period such as the current one.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Harmonised consumer price indices (HICPs) are aimed at measuring inflation in a harmonised way in all Member States. The Commission and the European Central Bank shall make use of the HIERAs when assessing price stability in the Member States in accordance with Article 140 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The European Parliament must support the Commission's proposal for a regulation establishing a uniform legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonised consumer price indices (HICPs) and house prices (IPAB) at Union level and at national and subnational level. The HIIC provides an instrument for measuring inflation used, among other things, as useful information on the deflation of economic values such as wages, rents and interest rates and thus forms the basis for decisions on economic and monetary policy. It is therefore essential that these statistics are objective, impartial and comparable in all Member States and for all product categories.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report is a proposal to amend the consumer price index regulations. As a reminder, the Harmonized Consumer Price Index (CHPI) is an index that calculates the level of inflation and is used by the European Central Bank as an indicator of price stability. The rapporteur recommends that above all technical changes be made in the calculation of the IPCH in order to better assess national inflation rates. Nevertheless, it is essential to remain vigilant in the face of these changes, which can be used as political tools in order to better control Member States by imposing specific objectives on them or in order to regain imaginary growth. It was in this context that the integration of prostitution and other illegal activities into the calculation of GDP had inflated the economic growth of the Member States of the European Union. I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Harmonised Consumer Price Indices (HICPs) are designed to measure inflation in a harmonised way and are of fundamental importance as they are used to assess national competitiveness. They are also essential tools for achieving the price stability objective. The current IACP regulation dates back to 1995 and is not adapted to new realities, taking into account recent developments in consumer price statistics. This resolution provides for a review of the impact of tax changes in inflation through a separately calculated price index, as well as the determination of price indices for dwellings and, in particular, for owner-occupied dwellings.  This is an important step towards improving the relevance and comparability of the HICP and would also allow the identification of real estate bubbles at an early stage. The report also provides the legal framework for implementing rapid HICP estimates, which are essential for monetary policy in the euro area. Moreover, it advocates the launch of pilot studies in order to strengthen the progressive harmonisation of consumer price indices by assessing the feasibility of using additional basic information or applying new approaches, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. It is an instrument that will be used to assess the competitiveness of the different Member States according to criteria that we believe are often interpreted arbitrarily and instrumentally by the Central Bank and the European Commission. At a time when, within the EU in particular, we are witnessing an ideological dispute over what the rate of inflation should be compatible with real growth conditions, there is a risk that an excessive level of harmonisation of the categories that enclose the choices of consumers in such different Member States and in economic conditions so in opposition to each other risks being an exercise that leads to results that are not easily interpreted. In any case, this is a measure which strips the Member States of an assessment of the substance which we think it is right that they should maintain.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European System of Central Banks (ESCB) is one of the main factors in our economy, without which the value system could not function. Thus, the use of harmonised consumer price indices by it helps to harmonise inflation in the Member States of the European Union. The introduction of harmonised consumer price indices at a constant value of tax rates (HICP-CT) will improve the European economic system, creating a better possibility of analysis and control.  I encourage Member States to contribute to the start of pilot studies, the verification of current information and the design of new methodological approaches in order to achieve a gradual strengthening of consumer price indices. I also support the idea of improving Europe's economy by implementing ECOICOP (European Classification of Individual Consumption According to Purpose) and thus gaining a broader look at current and future problems, statistics, visions, possibilities and ambitions. With the new proposed system, a uniform legal framework will be established for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonised indices. Thus, Member States will undertake to submit provisional inflation information and estimates of these indices on a monthly basis.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation which updates the statistical methodology for the development of a harmonised consumer price index, as this is essential for accurate inflation rate data, both in the EU and in the Eurozone.  The Regulation also recognises, at the initiative of the Spanish Socialists, that consumer price statistics are a public good.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on harmonised consumer price indices and the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 2494/95, on the basis of the following considerations in my report: the quality of statistics and their comparability are a public good of fundamental importance for all citizens of the Union, researchers and public policy-makers in the Union; in 2003, the Governing Council of the ECB decided that, in pursuit of price stability, it would aim to keep inflation rates below but close to 2% over a medium-term horizon; this legal framework must be adapted to current technical needs and progress, including by improving the relevance and comparability of HIICPs, as well as by monitoring a wider set of additional indicators necessary for measuring, analyzing and forecasting inflation, which must be made available on a harmonised basis.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. This file is concerned with the Harmonised Index of Consumer Prices (HCIP) The HCIP deals with price stability.  The problematic aspects of the text relates to the fact that there is a provision within the text which permits the possibility of allowing for future indexes in the following areas: narcotics, games of chance, prostitution, life insurance, which of course raises a number of issues. Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ This proposed legislation seeks to harmonise indices across the EU, but doing so will not reflect the various cultural differences in economic activity between different Member States, and accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the establishment of a common legal framework for the production of harmonised indices by Member States. This will involve collecting, compiling, processing and submitting of harmonised consumer price indices (HICPs) which will allow us to measure inflation in a harmonised way across the EU. The indices are also to be collected in a more simplified manner. This should allow us to measure convergence more effectively. The report also underlines the need for common definitions of different terms in order to avoid their broad and differing interpretations.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The changes made improve the consumer price index. However, given the link between this index and monetary policy decisions, it may be thought that the change in the inflation index will have implications for the monetary policy decisions taken by the ECB. By including house prices and taxation, the new index will better reflect reality, on the one hand, but, on the other, it will inflate the inflation figure by making the ECB's unconventional policies appear more positive than they actually are. This raised the legitimate doubt that the revision of the regulation was necessary at a time when the ECB needed objective data to better justify unconventional policies and to better sponsor their policy at a difficult time when the EU bank was losing more and more credibility in a low-growth environment threatened by deflation. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Harmonised consumer price indices (HICPs) allow for a harmonised assessment of inflation between all Member States. These indices in particular provide information on price stability, as well as assessing national competitiveness under the Commission's MIP.  The proposed regulation clarifies the scope of HIICPs by ensuring that indices are objective, impartial and comparable in all Member States and for all product categories, thus avoiding possible manipulation. As a result of the innovations in consumer price statistics, it was necessary to revise the Regulation, which has been in force since 1995, in order to ensure maximum comparability of data. I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation because it defines an up-to-date and uniform system of the indices underlying decisions on economic and monetary policy.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, which establishes a single legal framework for the development, compilation and dissemination of data on harmonised consumer price indices (HSIs) and residential prices (HSIs) at Union, national and sub-national level. CSOs provide an indicator of inflation, which is used, inter alia, as a valuable source of information on deflation of economic aggregates, such as wages, rents and interest rates, and which is therefore the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. It is therefore crucial that these statistics are objective, non-discriminatory and comparable in all Member States and in all product sectors.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because it establishes a common legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of harmonised consumer price indices (HICPs) and a housing price index (IPAB) at Union level and at national and subnational level. A uniform framework which, in my opinion, is necessary if these statistics are objective, impartial and comparable in all States and for all product categories, and which therefore forms the basis for future decisions on economic and monetary policy. Indeed, I believe that the quality of statistics, their uniformity within European territory and therefore their comparability are a public good of fundamental importance to all EU citizens.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Quality statistics and their comparability are fundamentally important for all Union citizens, researchers and those directing public policy in the Union. The development, production and dissemination of data on Harmonised Indices of Consumer Prices (HICP) at national and subnational level must be done within a uniform legal framework. The HICP can be crucial in providing a measurement of inflation used as input for deflating economic values. This affects rents, interest rates, and salaries which form the basis for monetary and economic decisions. Statistics of this nature must be comparable across all Member States and must be of an objective, unbiased nature. Regulations on HICP must be updated to include decisions introduced by the Lisbon Treaty which allows the Commission to create implementing or legislative measures which can amend unnecessary parts of a regulation. The HICP can be an essential tool in the analysis of causes of inflation. It can also be used to predict the effect of future tax changes on inflation. HICP flash estimates provided monthly by Member States would be crucial to analyse the conduct of monetary policy.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ This proposed legislation seeks to harmonise indices across the EU, but doing so will not reflect the various cultural differences in economic activity between different Member States, and accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Regulation establishes a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of harmonised indices of consumer prices and house prices at Union level, at national and sub-national level. HICP provides a measure of inflation which, together with other sources, are valuable inputs to deflate economic indicators such as wages, rents, interest rates and therefore serve as the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions.  I support the Gualtieri report because It considers it crucial that these statistics are objective, impartial and comparable in all Member States and for all product categories, thus enabling a review of the current regulatory framework and maximum comparability for key users of these indices.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – This proposed legislation seeks to harmonise indices across the EU, but doing so will not reflect the various cultural differences in economic activity between different Member States, and accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal for a regulation establishes a uniform legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonised consumer price indices (HICPs) and house prices (IPAB) at Union level and at national and subnational level. The HIIC provides an instrument for measuring inflation used, among other things, as useful information on the deflation of economic values such as wages, rents and interest rates and thus forms the basis for decisions on economic and monetary policy. In addition, the regulation takes account of innovations in the EU decision-making process introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, which give the Commission the right to enact implementing or legislative measures that may amend non-essential elements of a regulation. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that these updates are necessary and that these statistics are objective, impartial and comparable in all Member States and for all product categories.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ It is of cross-border benefit, that indices of consumer prices are harmonised across Member States. This will also help with quality statistics and their comparability towards a public good of fundamental importance for all European Union citizens, researchers and those responsible for public policy in the EU. By improving the relevance and comparability of the HICP as well as by monitoring a broader set of supplementary indicators, further developments in favour of European consumers can be registered.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Consumer Price Index (HICP) provides an instrument for measuring inflation and thus forms the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. It is therefore necessary for the methods of calculating the index to be objective, impartial and comparable in all Member States and for all product categories. The EU Regulation on the production and dissemination of data relating to the 1995 HICP must establish a uniform legal framework at Union and national level for the development, production and dissemination of data. The changes made improve the consumer price index. However, given the link between this index and monetary policy decisions, it may be thought that the change in the inflation index will have implications for the monetary policy decisions taken by the ECB. By including house prices and taxation, the new index will better reflect reality, on the one hand, but, on the other, it will inflate the inflation figure by making the ECB's unconventional policies appear more positive than they actually are. For these reasons, I preferred to vote against during the vote in plenary.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I have decided to vote against this report because it leaves it to the European Commission many powers to define central details in relation to the definition of this price index which is fundamental to the living conditions of workers in the European Union. The report gives the Commission the ability to change the list of products considered when developing this index, without limiting the possibility of including products such as certain types of drugs or activities such as prostitution. Taking into account the effects that such inclusions can have, and above all the legitimacy effect on such activities that would have decisions like these, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution approves the regulation on harmonised consumer price indices, the aim of which is to establish a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of harmonised consumer price indices and the housing price index at national and Union level. With my vote, I wanted to support this regulation, because I believe that the harmonisation of these indices is essential in order to have comparable data that will allow inflation levels and other economic aspects to be calculated uniformly in all Member States and, consequently, to take the appropriate economic policy measures.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation establishes a uniform legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonised consumer price indices (HICPs) and house prices (IPL) at Union, national and sub-national level. The HICP is an element of measuring inflation used, inter alia, as a valuable contribution to the deflation of economic values such as wages, rents, interest rates and therefore forms the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. It is therefore essential that these statistics are objective, impartial and allow comparisons to be made between all Member States and all product categories. Harmonised consumer price indices are an important tool for analysing the causes of inflation and predicting the impact of future tax changes on inflation.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Inflation is measured in a harmonised manner in the Member States by means of harmonised indexes of consumer prices (HICP). The current REGULATION on the HICP originates from 1995: changes in consumer price statistics require a revision of the framework in order to ensure maximum comparability for the main users of the HICP. The Commission's proposal for a regulation sets out a single framework for the development, production and publication at EU, national and subnational level of harmonised indices of consumer prices and house prices (HICP and HPI).  The HICP makes it possible to measure inflation, which is, inter alia, valuable information when deflating economic values such as wages, pensions, interest rates and thus forms the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. It is therefore important that those statistics are objective and comparable across all Member States and product categories. Quality statistics are a key public good for all EU citizens, researchers and those responsible for EU public policy. The draft report proposes that euro area Member States submit HICP rapid estimates on a monthly basis and that the breakdown of the hicp, home price index (OOH index) and HPI estimates be adopted through implementing acts.  In addition, the Commission should report every five years to the European Parliament and the Council assessing the results of the pilot studies. I supported this report in order to improve the functioning of the single internal market.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The aim of the Regulation is to examine changes in the prices of services and consumer goods purchased by households over time. The Regulation provides comparable inflation rates in the euro area, the EU, the European Economic Area and other countries, including acceding and candidate countries, calculated on the basis of a harmonised approach and a single set of definitions. The Commission's proposal for a regulation establishes a single legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP) and house prices (HPI) at Union, national and non-national level.  The current HICP Regulation dates back to 1995. New trends in consumer price statistics therefore require a review of the legal framework in order to ensure the greatest possible comparability for the main users of the HICP. This Regulation takes account of changes in the EU decision-making process introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, which gives the Commission (in this case Eurostat) the right to issue implementing measures (implementing acts) or legislative measures that may amend non-essential elements of the Regulation (delegated acts). I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The framework for providing harmonised indices of consumer prices is fundamental to the European Union’s economic governance. The current framework is outdated, and therefore the Commission’s proposal seeks to modernise the framework into a single new regulation. The harmonisation of the EU’s inflation measures is an important tool in order to have an effective monitoring mechanism on the impact that the European Central Bank’s monetary policy has, as well as to ensure the correct implementation of the macroeconomic imbalances procedure. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that streamlining would result in a clarified framework.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which reflects the new developments in consumer price statistics since 1995. Getting these statistics right is an important tool in managing inflation and the wider economy. Sensibly this regulation also prevents the UK from having to produce statistical data relevant only to euro area countries and ensures that national statistical authorities maintain control of statistical details and development.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to establish a common legal framework between Member States for the definition of consumer price indices. These data are essential in order to assess and measure the performance of monetary policies in the euro area and the evolution of price stability within the Union. The text introduces common definitions between Member States. We also call on the European Commission to prepare a report on property ownership with the aim of better protecting the Union from the risk of a housing bubble. In support of these objectives, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The aim of this text was to provide a common framework for the production of price indices, whether on consumption, housing or house prices. These statistical tools should thus enable a better understanding at European level of the deflation of certain economic values (wages, rents, interest rates). If we want common economic and monetary policies, we must have common tools. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a regulation is of particular importance during one of the most complex historical moments for the management of monetary policies by central banks. In fact, the dramatic problem of deflation, having hit Japan over the past decade, also seems to be afflicting Europe, and many economists are beginning to believe that this may be a non-transitory phenomenon. This Regulation therefore establishes a coherent legal framework for the management of data on harmonised consumer price indices and house prices at both European and national level. This is a decisive step forward in harmonizing statistical studies within the scope of statistical studies, but this is decisive once these data are used within the European institutions for economic policy decisions. This text also takes account of institutional developments within the Commission in the Treaty of Lisbon. In particular, the new framework for action of national institutions is important, since they have to provide lightning estimates on a monthly basis in order to then compose the indices used in monetary policies. For this reason, the text appears to be an important step in the better management of statistical data in the European institutions.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The proposed amendments amended the consumer price index regulations to improve it. At the same time, however, it gives considerable power to the Commission through delegated acts, for example for the integration of sectors such as prostitution and illegal trafficking in the calculation of the price index. For these reasons, I objected to these changes.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Outdated regulations need to be upgraded. I fully support initiatives to update the applicable provisions. Only this Regulation dates back to 1995.  Taking into account consumer price statistics and market developments, as well as other factors involved, it is imperative to regularly review the effectiveness of the existing regulatory framework. Moreover, the text does not undermine national power and while Eurostat will mainly focus on specific details for the euro area, national statistical authorities will retain control through implementing acts.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Decisions on EU economic and monetary policy should be based, inter alia, on statistics that are as objective, non-discriminatory and comparable as possible in all Member States and in all product sectors. New developments in consumer price statistics require a revision of the framework in order to ensure maximum comparability for key HST users.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The commission proposal for a regulation establishes a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of harmonised consumer price indexes (HICP) and house prices at Union level, at national and sub-national level. HICP provides a measure of inflation which, together with other sources, are valuable inputs to deflate economic indicators such as wages, rents, interest rates and therefore serve as the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. It is therefore crucial that these statistics are objective, impartial and comparable in all Member States and for all product categories. I am in favour of the proposal, in particular because it includes information on the impact that tax changes have on inflation.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation which updates the statistical methodology for the development of a harmonised consumer price index, as this is essential for accurate inflation rate data, both in the EU and in the Eurozone.  The Regulation also recognises, at the initiative of the Spanish Socialists, that consumer price statistics are a public good.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I abstained on this deliberation because I question the consideration of illicit sectors in the calculation of indices.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The commission proposal for a regulation establishes a uniform legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonised consumer price indices (HICP). The HICP provides a measure of inflation and provides a basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. It is important that these statistics are objective and comparable between Member States, covering all product areas, not forgetting the diversity that characterises consumption structures in the different Member States. The current HICP Regulation dates back to 1995 and therefore requires a revision. The current proposal also takes into account the amendments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, which gives the Commission (in this case Eurostat) the power to adopt implementing acts or legislative measures that may amend non-essential parts of a regulation – delegated acts. In the Commission's proposal many activities are being defined through delegated acts, as well as the definition of the appropriate methodology for producing harmonised indices between countries, or to update the weights of HICP sub-indices. Our opposition to this proposal in committee, which we maintain, is the possibility of not excluding integration into future rates of illicit goods and activities such as narcotics, gambling, prostitution, among others. This fact that we consider unacceptable.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report given the importance of the quality of statistics and their comparability for citizens, researchers and policy-makers in the Union. I welcome the Commission's proposal to create a uniform legal framework for the processing of data on consumer price indices. The use of uniform and comparable data is also essential for a more effective monetary policy in the euro area, as it would make it possible to respond more quickly and concretely to the different critical issues that may arise.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the legislative proposal because it leads to unnecessary interference in Member States.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ The current regulation on harmonised indices of consumer prices in force has been in force since 1995 and it is therefore essential that it be thoroughly revised, as we must be able to ensure maximum comparability for the main users, as there have been new developments in statistics and, last but not least, a change in the decision-making processes of the European Union following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon. I therefore support the European Commission's proposal in question.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because, in my opinion, the competitiveness of the Member States is not assessed on the basis of the criteria considered.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Decisions on EU economic and monetary policy should be based, inter alia, on statistics that are as objective, non-discriminatory and comparable as possible in all Member States and in all product sectors. New developments in consumer price statistics require a revision of the framework in order to ensure maximum comparability for key HST users. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of the report on harmonised consumer price indices and the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. 2494/95.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the inclusion of our main achievement, which is to ensure sufficient implementation power for the Commission to make the statistical methodology evolve on HICP (the Council sought to strengthen the national level during the trilogue negotiations) and to better integrate into HICP indices both owner-occupied housing indices and house-price indices, which are crucial in addressing macroeconomic imbalances in the EU. Flawed statistics were partly responsible for the financial crisis in 2008. This new legislation improves the quality of indices of consumer prices which are important to correct macroeconomic imbalances in the EU.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Commission Regulation for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonised consumer price indices (IPCA) and house prices (IPV) at Union, national and subnational level. It is of particular importance that these statistics are objective, impartial and comparable in all Member States, and a review of the current framework is therefore necessary in order to ensure maximum compatibility.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation which updates the statistical methodology for the development of a harmonised consumer price index, as this is essential for accurate inflation rate data, both in the EU and in the Eurozone.  The Regulation also recognises, at the initiative of the Spanish Socialists, that consumer price statistics are a public good.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I would like to thank my colleagues in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs for this important legislative report. Improving the quality of consumer price indices is indeed a very important measure in verifying and correcting macroeconomic imbalances within the EU.  Indeed, there were many cases of inaccurate statistics that were at the root of the explosion of the financial crisis in 2008. Creating a common procedure and a more integrated methodology between the different Member States will certainly help in this respect.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement reached between the EP and the Council on the proposal for a regulation establishing a uniform framework for the development, dissemination of data on harmonised consumer price indices (HICPs) and house prices (IPAB) at EU level, as it is an important instrument for harmonising and simplifying existing legislation, and also contributes to the functioning of European economic governance. , particularly in the context of the procedure for monitoring macroeconomic imbalances. With regard to the analysis of inflation, the EP strongly insisted on the inclusion in the Regulation of information having an impact on inflation as a result of tax changes. This was reflected in the introduction of the HICP-TA. In addition, in order to promote eurozone monetary policy, the EP strongly supported the need to introduce an obligation for eurozone states to provide lightning estimates on a monthly IPCA basis. The Regulation will be implemented through a series of delegated acts to be adopted by the Ec on a proposal from Eurostat, taking into account the essential support of the ECB, where such acts implied prerogatives in the field of monetary policy, and in accordance with the EP's opinion. Finally, I welcome the EP's decision to include pilot projects in the regulation.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on harmonised indices of consumer prices. These indicators allow for a better and guaranteed comparable value for determining inflation in different EU Member States.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. In order to ensure the objective comparability of the consumer price index (HICP) between Member States, I voted in favour of repealing the outdated regulation. The HICP makes an important contribution to the recording of inflation and is used as a basis for monetary and economic policy decisions.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ This proposed legislation seeks to harmonise indices across the EU, but doing so will not reflect the various cultural differences in economic activity between different Member States, and accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ The current regulations regarding the Harmonised Indices of Consumer Prices (HICP) date back to 1995, and despite almost 20 amendments over the course of the past two decades, a new framework is long overdue. Measuring inflation accurately is a key component of the macroeconomic imbalances procedure. HICP indices can have a major impact on economic variables such as wages, rents and interest rates – and can form the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. Clearly then, the streamlining of the existing framework as set out by the Commission and my S&D colleague Mr Gualtieri is badly needed. Therefore I supported this proposal.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report amending the criteria used to monitor the prices of consumer products in the EU. These indices are a fundamental tool for the adoption of certain macroeconomic decisions. We find the Commission's high discretion to amend these criteria problematic through delegated acts, and also the open door for concepts such as prostitution, gambling, narcotics and others to be included in the indexes.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I support these revisions because having one uniform measure for calculating inflation will provide Member States with greater clarity and make administration of our economy easier and more effective. This could be a very important step towards our goal of achieving price stability.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation which updates the statistical methodology for the development of a harmonised consumer price index, as this is essential for accurate inflation rate data, both in the EU and in the Eurozone.  The Regulation also recognises, at the initiative of the Spanish Socialists, that consumer price statistics are a public good.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 The report concerns indicators that determine the economic policies of each State, since they can degrade or increase the value of Member States' wages and social rights. Their harmonizing automatically means that one of the most important instruments of the State's fiscal policy is transferred into the hands of the Commission. That is why we consider this vote to be appropriate since we oppose the harmonisation of consumer indicators.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I along with ALDE voted in favour of this regulation on harmonised indices of consumer prices. This regulation lays down a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP) and of housing prices (HPI) at Union, national and sub-national level. Harmonised indices of consumer prices are destroyed by massive inflation in a harmonised manner across Member States. They are essential for assessing and measuring convergence in terms of price liability within the EU. The regulation consolidates revisions to the original 1995 regulation, simplifies and clarifies the requirements for the compilation of these indices and takes account of new technical aspects of data collection. In this regard the regulation will allow National Statistical Institutes (CSO) to collect statistical unit data in an electronic form, e.g. scanner data from retailers, for the purposes of compiling the indices. This proposal ensures the principles of the European Statistics Code of Practice relating to commitment to quality, sound methodology, cost effectiveness, relevance, accuracy, reliability and compatibility.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because this regulation consolidates revisions to the original 1995 Regulation, it simplifies and clarifies the requirements for the compilation of harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP) and takes account of new technical aspects of data collection. It is important that we update legislation regularly and make it fit for purpose; this is exactly what this regulation does.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal for a regulation sets a legal framework at European Union, national and sub-national level for the development, production and dissemination of data on Harmonised Indices of Consumer Prices, which measure the way prices of goods and services change over time, and on housing prices. Since the last applicable regulation dates back to 1995, and given the fact that national statistical authorities will retain control of the details through implementing acts while Eurostat will take care of euro area details through delegated acts, I voted in favour of this report. In addition, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ This proposed legislation seeks to harmonise indices across the EU, but doing so will not reflect the various cultural differences in economic activity between different Member States, and accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it improves the quality of indices of consumer prices which are very important in the rectification of macroeconomic imbalances.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on harmonised consumer price indices and the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013; 2494/95 as it is necessary to enable efficient assessment and measurement of price coherence within the Union and to address a concrete analysis of the eurozone's monetary policy results in terms of reaching price stability.  Given that certain parameters change over time, it is necessary to adapt legislation in this area to ensure, in line with current needs, flexibility of methodology, improve equity housing indices and ensure better integration of the housing indices.  I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report is a proposal to amend the regulations on consumer price indices. The Harmonized Consumer Price Index (CHPI) is a consumer price index (CPI) calculated for each of the European Union countries and a few other European countries; it calculates the level of inflation as comparablely as possible for all countries and is used by the European Central Bank as an indicator of price stability and as a means of verifying compliance with the convergence criterion for inflation.  However, we must remain cautious because these indices can be used as political tools to better control Member States by imposing targets on them or in order to regain imaginary growth by changing the calculation formulas. Reforms to GDP calculation methods imposed in 2014, for example, had allowed prostitution and other illegal activities to be integrated, thus inflating growth by about 0.5%.  For the time being, the calculation of CPIs does not take into account these types of activities, but the proposed delegated actions will therefore have to be monitored. That is why I have decided to abstain on this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – This proposed legislation seeks to harmonise indices across the EU; doing so will not reflect the various cultural differences in economic activity between different Member States and accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ The Harmonised Index of Consumer Prices is an important tool to ensure that consumer prices across Europe are equally reflected in calculations which can determine inflation rates within the EU. This updated framework will take into account new developments in statistics as well as new decision-making processes in the EU which have come into effect since the adoption of the Treaty of Lisbon. Therefore, I believe the regulation is useful and will contribute to greater accuracy in the calculation and publication of inflation rates.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Roberto Gualtieri's report on the European Parliament and Council's proposal for a regulation on consumer price indices and repealing Regulation (EC) 2494/95. This is to replace a 1995 regulation on how consumer price indices are calculated. These allow inflation to be measured in the same way in all the countries of the European Union. This new regulation takes into account statistical developments and technical improvements in data collection. I therefore agree with this new regulation which will allow a better assessment of the results of monetary policy in the euro area. This regulation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which adapts and creates a common framework for different price indices (consumer, occupied housing and real estate) in light of statistical, technological and legislative developments. This will allow for better calculation of inflation in the various EuDS and a more accurate estimate of the convergence of price stability within the Union, which are essential figures for the policies of the European Commission and the European Central Bank.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Harmonized indices of consumer prices are intended to measure inflation in a comparable way in all Member States. This requires a common framework for the development, compilation and dissemination of harmonised indices of consumer prices and the house price index at Union and national level. I am abstaining on this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Flawed statistics were partly responsible for the financial crisis in 2008. Therefore, I voted in favour of the report as it improves the quality of indices of consumer prices, which are important to correct macroeconomic imbalances in the EU.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 On 8 March 2016, a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on harmonised consumer price indices was voted on in the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg. In order to ensure the proper functioning of the European Union and to implement an effective monetary policy, inflation indicators in the EU are most likely to be harmonised, including consumer price indices. It is probably even reasonable for consumer price indices to be comparable in all EU Member States and in all product areas. The aim of the present proposal was to establish a common legal framework for the creation of such harmonised indices by The Member States. However, given that the proposal also contains extensive possibilities to create indices for items such as narcotics, gambling and prostitution, I could not support the text submitted and I had to vote against it.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The report deals with the improvement of the existing framework on Harmonised Indices of Consumer Prices (HICP) and of Housing Prices (HPI) at Union, national and sub-national level. It is important to highlight the necessity for these indices to be objective and easily comparable across all Member States. Additionally, the new developments in the field of consumer prices statistics make it necessary for the existing framework to be revised in order to ensure maximum comparability for the users of HICP. I welcome the Commission’s proposal for a regulation as it lays down a uniform legal framework for the development and dissemination of data on HICP. However, it is deplorable that the proposed regulation could constitute, in the future, a legal basis for the production of indices for some controversial items such as narcotics, prostitution, games of chance, etc., in case their degree of methodological harmonisation improves sufficiently. In order to express my concern about the aforementioned fact, I decided to abstain.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ The Harmonised Indices of Consumer Prices (HICP) are designed to measure inflation in a harmonised manner across Member States. The Commission and the European Central Bank use the HICP in their assessment of price stability in Member States. As we all well know, maintaining price stability is a very crucial task since it makes a significant contribution to general welfare, including levels of economic activity and employment. In this regard, it is more than necessary for Member States in the euro area to provide early provisional information on the monthly harmonised indices of consumer price. By doing this Member States will have the opportunity to conduct monetary policy in the euro area that is needed and right.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The proposal for a regulation outlines a uniform legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of harmonised consumer price index (HIIC) and house price (IPAB) data at European, national and subnational level. With regard to the HIERC, it is a means of measuring inflation and also useful because it provides information on the deflation of wages, rents and interest rates. That is why it is essential that statistical data are certain, impartial and comparable in all Member States. In addition to these data, it is necessary to have timely provisional information on inflation. I decided to give a positive opinion because the current HICA regulation dates back to 1995 and it was important to carry out a review of its structure and its subsequent updating.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it gives too much power to the Commission, in particular to integrate prostitution and drug trafficking into the calculation of the price index.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on consumer price indices. The aim of this report is to amend the regulation on consumer price indices. It wants to establish a common framework on three levels - European, national and sub-national - for the development, production and dissemination of several price indices: the IPCH (harmonized consumer price index), the IPCH-TC (the harmonized consumer price index at constant tax rates), the LOP (price index on owner-occupied dwellings) and the IPI (real estate price index). This major change could make it possible to better take into account price changes across the Member States but also to create a political tool capable of better controlling them, by imposing targets on them or by falsifying the figures. I do not want to allow the European Commission to ever control us more and more.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation which updates the statistical methodology for the development of a harmonised consumer price index, as this is essential for accurate inflation rate data, both in the EU and in the Eurozone.  The Regulation also recognises, at the initiative of the Spanish Socialists, that consumer price statistics are a public good.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I have decided to vote against this report because it leaves it to the European Commission many powers to define central details in relation to the definition of this price index which is fundamental to the living conditions of workers in the European Union. The report gives the Commission the ability to change the list of products considered when developing this index, without limiting the possibility of including products such as certain types of drugs or activities such as prostitution. Taking into account the effects that such inclusions can have, and above all the legitimacy effect on such activities that would have decisions like these, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This report was born due to the need to revise the 1995 Regulation on Harmonized Consumer Price Indexes (IPCA) in order to achieve maximum harmonization among the main users of THE IPCA.  It is worth noting the fundamental role of IPCA, as they provide more than relevant information to deflate economic values such as wages, rents or interest rates. In addition, they are very useful for making economic and monetary policy decisions.  Among other measures, the report calls for Member States belonging to the euro area to provide monthly advanced INDICATORS of the IPCA so that the European Union has early interim information and can be guided by it to carry out adequate monetary policy management.  In my view, this report should be adopted to establish a legal framework to promote the production, development and dissemination of data on IPCEs and house prices (IPV) at Union level.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The harmonised index of consumer prices is inherently inaccurate because each country has a different culture, a different level of income and therefore a different structure of household expenditure. Harmonised indices thus always give a conived picture of price level developments. Constant changes in methodology reduce the comparability of price levels over time. The new creation requirements will place a weight on national statistical authorities and the EU budget.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Harmonised consumer price indices are used to assess national competitiveness under the Commission's macroeconomic imbalances process. The regulation applicable to the consumer price index dates back to 1995. The European Commission's proposal for a Regulation lays down a single legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonised consumer price indices (HICP) and housing prices (HPI) at national, supranational and EU level. The HICP is essential for assessing and measuring convergence in terms of EU price stability and eurozone results. The Harmonised Consumer Price Index at Constant Tax Rates (HICP-CT) is an important tool for analyzing the causes of inflation and forecasting the impact of future tax changes on inflation.  I supported this Report because I think it is important that there is a single legal framework.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The current system for calculating the harmonised index of consumer prices is in place in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 2494/95 of 1995. The aim of the new regulation is therefore to replace the old one through its modernisation, including Union decision-making innovations introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, which will enable the European Commission to adopt implementing acts and delegated acts through 2007. The latter will, by the way, help to define an appropriate methodology for the production of harmonised indices between Member States, as well as to modernise the weights of harmonised sub-indices in the consumer price index. Due to the specificnaity of Member States in cases such as drugs, scratch-drawers, prostitution, life insurance and indirectly measured financial intermediation services, it will not be necessary to prepare sub-indices. On the other hand, this will be necessary in the sampling and representativeness, price collection and analysis, substitution and quality adjustment, index production, revision, specific indexes and products processed in specific areas. To put it mildly, one of the main tasks of the new regulation, through its effective adaptation to member states' practices, will be to guarantee a policy of making prices as fair as possible, so as not to suffer consumers – especially those least well-off, such as pensioners or needy families.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: In writing \ u2012 The proposal for a Regulation presented establishes a common framework for the development, development and publication of harmonised indices of consumer prices and the house price index at Union, national and regional level. These single comparable indices, which are statistically recorded, will serve as a basis for the development of forecasts and concrete measures necessary for further development as a matter of priority.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on harmonised consumer price indices and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be made in the first half of the year.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against it. The purpose of this report is to amend the consumer price index regulations. The Harmonized Consumer Price Index (CHPI) is a consumer price index (CPI) calculated for each EU country: it calculates the level of inflation in the most comparable way possible for all countries and is used by the European Central Bank as an indicator of price stability and as a means of verifying compliance with the convergence criterion for inflation. We oppose this because these indices can also be used as political tools to better control Member States by imposing targets on them or in order to return to imaginary growth by changing the formulas for calculation.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report. Quality statistics and their comparability are a public good of fundamental importance for all European Union citizens, researchers and those responsible for public policy in the European Union.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on harmonised consumer price indices. The dossier, which I have edited as shadow rapporteur, contains the definitions necessary to clarify the cases described, such as 'house prices', 'price reference period' and also 'Laspayres-type index'. As the PPE Group, we have stressed the importance of cost-effectiveness, which has been reintroduced.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 In order for the European Union to be able to conduct a unified monetary policy effectively, statistical data such as the HICA are needed. I support this report because in this way the EU can improve its monetary policy by supporting skills and growth.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on harmonised consumer price indices. I hope that the new regulation will be a step forward in measuring prices, vital information and that it is necessary to measure evenly across Europe, to ensure that it has the effects we are looking for.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
