text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution upgrades the existing single European system for providing information on harmonised consumer price indices (HSIs) and house prices (HSIs). These indicators are an important means of information on inflation and related issues which are very important for the Union's economic and monetary policy. This Regulation has been in force since 1995 and needs to be modernised in order to comply with the new market conditions in order to achieve more effective price comparability with the ultimate aim of achieving equal treatment of similar product categories. I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution, because I consider it necessary to establish a new legal framework with regard to CSTs reflecting new developments in this area to unify systems and prevent divergent national practices that circumvent the provision of reliable statistical results. The EP resolution calls on the Commission to submit a proposal for amendments or replacement of the current Regulation 2494/95 including the impact of tax changes on inflation and the provision of preliminary estimates by Member States on a monthly basis with a view to better analysing them for more accurate results.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to harmonise consumer price indices. I believe that it is very important that these statistics are objective, impartial and comparable for all Member States and for all product categories, because on the basis of these data economists, politicians, analysts make decisions on monetary and economic policy.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report to harmonise indices for the HICP. This will facilitate the comparison of inflation and determine price stability in all Member States.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Harmonized Consumer Price Indexes (CHPI) are designed to measure inflation in a harmonised manner across Member States for international comparison. The current regulations date back to 1995. The Commission proposes the revision to take account of the innovations introduced by the Lisbon Treaty, which gives it the right to issue measures (acts of implementation), or legislative measures that can change the non-essential parts of a regulation (delegated acts).  Under the new regulation, the Commission will be free to decide whether to introduce narcotics, gambling or prostitution into the calculation of this index, even though they are currently excluded. I am opposed to this new takeover by the Commission, whose absurd ideology and methodological fanaticism I know. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on harmonised indexes of consumer prices and repealing Regulation (EC) No 2494/95. It is essential to establish a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of harmonised indexes of consumer prices and house prices at Union level, at national and sub-national level. Statistics should be objective, impartial and comparable in all Member States and for all product categories. The current HICP Regulation dates back to 1995, so it is very important that this Regulation be updated.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as the current regulation that has been in place since 1995 needs to be updated to reflect the developments in consumer prices statistics.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. An economic and monetary zone requires common tools. As such, I am pleased that we have adopted a report establishing a common legal framework for the production of harmonized indices. This is a fundamental tool for measuring inflation in all Member States and ensuring the unity of the euro area. This report has the merit of simplifying and clarifying the provisions by bringing together all the existing provisions into a single act.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The existence of a harmonised index of consumer prices at EU level is essential as consumer price indices are one of the main indicators of the overall price stability of countries. The purpose of their harmonisation is to ensure comparability of indices within the Member States of the Union, comparability of price stability, inflation and the state of monetary policy in euro area countries. The Harmonised Index of Consumer Prices is an important tool for the functioning of economic and monetary union, since measuring the inflation rate consequently affects the level of wages, interest rates or rents. By monitoring the causes of inflation, indices can predict the impact of future tax changes on inflation, an important aspect for European households. The legislative proposal presented aims at establishing a single framework for the development, production and publication of data on harmonised indices of consumer prices and house price indices, thus establishing a sound information basis for economic and monetary policy decision-making at union, national and regional level. I therefore express my support for the proposal tabled.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposed the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on harmonised indices of consumer prices and repealing Regulation (EC) No 2494/95. In its report, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs proposes that Parliament adopt the draft regulation with a text significantly amended at first reading.  The amendment would take two issues out of their remnant where the Commission could decide under the authority of the Regulation and proposes that they be established directly by the Regulation. The first is the definition of sub-indices of harmonised indices of consumer prices whose share of the total basket is negligible, and the second is the designation of sub-indices whose production may be suspended, since some of them do not relate to final consumption expenditure of households or because the degree of methodological harmonisation is not yet satisfactory. I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The Harmonized Consumer Price Index (CHPI) is an index that calculates the level of inflation in the most comparable way possible for all countries. It is used by the European Central Bank as an indicator of price stability and as a means of verifying compliance with the convergence criterion on inflation. The amendments would establish a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of the harmonized consumer price index, the harmonised consumer price index at constant tax rates (IPCH-TC), the owner-occupied housing price index (LOP), and the EU-level real estate price index (IPI) and the national and sub-national level.  We must remain cautious because these indices can therefore be used as political tools in order to better control Member States by imposing targets on them or in order to regain imaginary growth by changing the calculation formulas.  For this reason it is appropriate to vote against this text.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The protection of the financial interests of the European Union, as well as the effectiveness of public expenditure, should be key elements of EU policy, so that citizens' confidence is increasing, ensuring that their money is used correctly, efficiently and effectively. The multiplicity of the legal systems of each Member State makes it difficult to combat fraud and the EU should make efforts to step up the fight against fraud, so that it is effective and with tangible and satisfactory results. I support the rapporteur's position that the Commission should address the problem of divergence of approaches by Member States with regard to the design of irregularities and heterogeneous interpretations in the implementation of the EU legal framework. I believe it is essential that we develop a mechanism for exchanging information between the competent authorities in order to allow cross-check of accounting records between Member States with the aim of preventing transnational fraud.  I share the rapporteur's concern about the increase in smuggling, trafficking and other forms of illegal and illegal trade, which have an impact on member states' collection of customs duties and, consequently, on the EU budget.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This proposal aims to improve the calculation of the CHPI but significantly enhances the Commission's powers for delegated acts. Moreover, these technical changes could enable the Commission to define the criteria for the economic performance of the Member States and to further increase its control over policies that are the responsibility of national parliaments and European peoples. That is why I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which lays down a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of Harmonised Indices of Consumer Prices (HICP) and of Housing Prices (HPI) at European Union and national level.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. The Consumer Price Index is an economic indicator that measures the price evolution of a basket of goods and services from year to year. This indicator therefore allows an estimate of price increases as well as inflation. The new regulation will repeal the 1995 regulation and allow for a fairer calculation of harmonized consumer price indices and house price indices, as it takes into account all statistical, technological and legislative developments that have taken place since 1995.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I was not able, for medical reasons, to attend the plenary session from 7 to 10 March 2016. Nevertheless, I would like to express my support for the adoption of the harmonized consumer price indices replacing the 1995 regulation. The adoption of this measure strengthens the ECB's role and will, among other things, help identify housing bubbles at an early stage through the price index for owner-occupied dwellings.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report on harmonised consumer price indices, the primary objective of which is to set up a common European legal framework for the development, production and publication of harmonised indices in consumer and house prices. This would work not only at EU level, but also at national and subnational level. The introduction of this system could also have an impact on important policy decisions, as it would allow inflation to be measured in each Member State in such a way as to ultimately produce objective, unbiased and, above all, comparable results.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ This report presents a uniform legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on Harmonised Indices of Consumer Prices (HICP) and of Housing Prices (HPI) at Union, national and sub-national level. The HICP measures consumer price inflation in the euro area. I voted for this report that will bring a revision of the above-mentioned framework in order to ensure maximum compatibility for the main users of the HICP. I consider it worth mentioning that the HICP is also used in assessing whether a country is ready to join the euro area.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of this Regulation is to establish a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of harmonised consumer price indices (HICPs) and the house price index (IPL) at Union and national level. Price statistics with a high level of quality and comparability are essential for those responsible for public policy in the Union, for researchers and for all European citizens. The Commission and the European Central Bank (ECB) use the dissemination of harmonised consumer price indices (HICPs) to assess price stability in the Member States. By 31 December 2018, the Commission will have to prepare a report addressing the appropriateness of the OOH (owner-occupied house price index) price index for inclusion in the HICP coverage. Depending on the results of the report, the Commission shall, where appropriate, submit within a reasonable period of time a proposal to amend this Regulation as regards the integration of the OOH price index into the HICP coverage.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ At national, sub-national, and EU levels, the Commission’s proposal for a regulation establishes a uniform legal framework for the development and dissemination of data on Harmonised Indices of Consumer Prices (HICP) and of Housing Prices (HPI). The HICP provides a measure of inflation used as valuable data for deflating economic values and shapes the basis for economic and monetary policy. Therefore, it is important that statistics are objectively comparable across all product areas and member states. For the power of the Commission to alter elements with delegated acts, two issues are excluded and decided directly in the regulation. First is the determination of the sub-indices of the HICP, secondly the selection of sub-indices. Furthermore, since early conditional information on inflation is crucial for the conduct of monetary policy, euro Member States must provide HICP flash estimates monthly. The breakdown of the estimates of the HICP, Owner-Occupied Housing (OOH) price index and the HPI must also be adopted by means of implementing acts. Lastly, with the influential pilot studies, the Commission shall appropriately contribute to their financing and report to the European Parliament and the Council assessing the main findings of the studies. For these reasons, I have voted for this regulation.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on harmonised consumer price indices (HICP) and housing prices (ICBN) at Union, national and sub-national level. The HICP provides inflation measurements, which are used, inter alia, for salaries, rents, interest rates and therefore form the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. It is therefore essential that these statistics are objective, error-based and comparable in all Member States and in all product areas. I agree that Member States will not have to create or provide HICP sub-indices whose weight represents less than one permile of the total expenditure included in the HICP. Given the importance of monetary policy implementation, I consider it beneficial that Member States in the euro area will submit flash HICP estimates at monthly intervals.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The harmonised indices of consumer prices are aimed at making inflation more measurable in all Member States. This is understandable from the idea, but not urgently necessary, as parameters already exist to measure price stability. I abstained from voting.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to establish a uniform legal framework for the development, compilation and dissemination of data on harmonised indices of consumer prices (TTHI) and housing price indices at Union, national and regional level. The TTHI allows inflation to be measured and is used, inter alia, as a valuable input to deflate economic values such as wages, rents and interest rates, which is why it is the basis for decisions in economic and monetary policy. It is therefore important that these statistics be objective, impartial and comparable across all Member States and product categories.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the draft report submitted. The harmonised index of consumer prices is a very important tool for ensuring the stability of Member States' prices and monitoring inflation. These are important indicators in the context of monetary policy.  In this context, it is necessary to ensure that these statistics are objective, impartial and comparable for all Member States and for all product categories. A uniform legal framework should therefore apply across the EU to the development, compilation and dissemination of harmonised data on consumer price indices and house price indices at Union, national and sub-national level.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ This proposed legislation seeks to harmonise indices across the EU; doing so will not reflect the various cultural differences in economic activity between different Member States and accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a regulation defines a uniform legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonised consumer price indices (HICPs) and house prices (IPAB) at Union level and at national and subnational level.  A very important point is also the request to euro area Member States to provide lightning estimates on a monthly basis, and for the unbundling of lightning estimates of the HICA, the owner's occupied house price index (OOH) and the IPAB to be adopted by implementing acts. I therefore vote in favour of this draft resolution.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. I support the proposal for a regulation. It sets out a single framework for the design, preparation and dissemination of harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP) and residential real estate price indices (HPI) at Union, national and sub-national level. The HICP provides a measure of inflation, which is used, inter alia, as an important figure in deflationary economic values such as wages, rents and interest rates, and is therefore based on economic and monetary decisions. It is therefore extremely important that these statistics are objective, impartial and comparable across member states and in all product areas. The hicp regulation currently in force was adopted in 1995. In view of developments in the field of statistics on consumer prices, this framework should be revised to ensure maximum comparability for the main users of the HICP.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒I welcome this Regulation with a view to setting common frameworks for the development, development and dissemination of harmonised consumer price indices and property price indices at EU, but also national and sub-national level. She would stress the importance of harmonised consumer price indices (HIPC) for assessing national competitiveness when we talk about the macroeconomic imbalance procedure. Better, more orderly EU legislation is a fundamental precondition for smart regulation. I am pleased to put statistics in the Commission's priority area, as simplification and improvement of the regulatory environment is announced. More efficient monetary policy action requires early interim information on monthly HIPCs in the form of estimates.  I welcome pilot research as the basis for constructive and relevant data based on the on-going process. She would stress that it is crucial to find sufficient funding to establish pilot projects.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report is a proposal to amend the consumer price index regulations. The amendments would establish a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of the Harmonized Consumer Price Index (CHPI), the Harmonised Consumer Price Index at Constant Taxation Rates (IPCH-TC), the Owner-Occupied Housing Price Index (LOP), and the Eu-national and National Housing Price Index (IPI).  It is essentially a technical modification of the regulation to better take into account price changes across the Member States. However, we must remain cautious because these indices can be used as political tools to better control Member States by imposing targets on them, or in order to return to imaginary growth by changing the calculation formulas. Reforms to GDP calculation methods imposed in 2014, for example, had allowed prostitution and other illegal activities to be integrated, thus inflating growth by about 0.5%. With the amendments adopted giving far too much power to the Commission, I prefer to vote against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒Harmonised Consumer Price Indices (HIPC) are designed to measure inflation in a harmonised manner across Member States and are used by the European Central Bank to assess price stability in the Member States. I would like to stress the importance of harmonised consumer price indices in the event of a macroeconomic imbalance, such as the 2008 financial crisis, the scale of which we can say are partly responsible and flawed statistics. Quality statistics and their comparability fall within the public good of fundamental importance for all Union citizens, researchers and those in charge of public policymaking and monetary policy implementation in the Union.  For this reason, I support the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on harmonised consumer price indices, which improves the existing statistical methodology through a clearer scope of application, the removal of redundant pieces of legislation and clarification of provisions that have previously been misinterpreted. This new law improves the quality of the consumer price index, which is important for correcting macroeconomic imbalances in the EU.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The commission proposal for a regulation establishes a uniform legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonised consumer price indices (HICP). The HICP provides a measure of inflation and provides a basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. It is important that these statistics are objective and comparable between Member States, covering all product areas, not forgetting the diversity that characterises consumption structures in the different Member States. The proposal to revise the current CPI Regulation, which dates back to 1995, takes into account the amendments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, which gives the Commission (in this case Eurostat) the power to adopt implementing acts or legislative measures that may alter non-essential parts of a regulation – delegated acts. In the Commission proposal, many activities are being defined through delegated acts, as well as the definition of the appropriate methodology for producing harmonised indices between countries, or to update the weights of HICP sub-indices. We have expressed our opposition to the proposal in committee and in plenary, since integration into future rates of illicit goods and activities such as narcotics, gambling, prostitution, among others is not excluded. We find this unacceptable.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 Statistics are extremely important in the development of any policy. The economic one is no exception. That is why I supported the report on harmonised consumer price indices, on the basis of which inflation can be measured. A common framework for the development, development and dissemination of harmonised indices at Union and national level needs to be established and complemented by possible other relevant indicators, including better in-house price indices. As we have been able to see for ourselves in the past few years, it is highly desirable that information, even if only provisional, be provided in a timely manner and that rapid estimates of price stability developments can be made. It is therefore more than logical for the Commission to take measures to allow it to consider possible changes in the collection of that relevant information.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, this is a very important issue as it deals with key economic and monetary policy decisions. The proposal for a regulation submitted by the Commission establishes a single legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data relating to harmonised consumer price indices (HICP) and housing prices (ICBN) at Union, national and sub-national level. Since the current HICP Regulation in force dates back to 1995, it needs to be reviewed in order to achieve the maximum possible comparability for the main users of the HICP. We must not forget that timely regular information on inflation is essential, in particular, for the conduct of monetary policy. If appropriate, the Commission will contribute to the financing of pilot studies and then prepare a report every five years on the evaluation of the main findings for the European Parliament and the Council, which will certainly contribute to raising awareness among us MEMBERS of the European Parliament.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal for a regulation establishes a uniform legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonised consumer price indices (HICPs) and house prices (IPAB) at Union, national and subnational level. The Regulation also takes into account innovations in the EU decision-making process introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, giving the European Commission the right to enact implementing measures (implementing acts) or legislative measures that may amend non-essential elements of a regulation (delegated acts). I voted in favour of this draft report, which proposes that both the HICA and the HIIC-CT are broken down according to the categories of the European Classification of Individual Consumption by Function (ECOICOP) and calls on the Member States of the euro area to provide estimates on a monthly basis.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The HICP Regulation measures changes in the price of services and consumer goods purchased by households over time. The HICP Regulation provides comparable inflation rates in the euro area, the EU, the European Economic Area and other countries, including acceding and candidate countries, calculated on the basis of a harmonised approach and a single set of definitions.  The Commission's proposal for a regulation establishes a single legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP) and house prices (HPI) at Union, national and non-national level. The current HICP Regulation dates back to 1995, and new trends in consumer price statistics therefore require a review of the legal framework in order to ensure the greatest possible comparability for the main users of the HICP. This Regulation also takes into account changes in the EU decision-making process introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, which gives the Commission the right to adopt implementing measures or legislative measures which may amend non-essential elements of the Regulation.  The final agreement stipulates that the OOH can be covered by the Regulation if there is a uniform way of collecting these indicators in each Member State that does not currently exist. National statistical authorities will maintain control over the details through implementing acts and Eurostat will focus on specific details of the euro area through delegated acts. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I wanted to vote in favour of this report in order to accompany the adaptation of the regulation on consumer price indices, which dates back to 1995, to statistical developments, marked in particular by the creation of a European statistical system, technological developments, data collection, or legislative developments, linked to new committee procedures.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ This proposed legislation seeks to harmonise indices across the EU; doing so will not reflect the various cultural differences in economic activity between different Member States and accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report establishes a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of harmonised consumer price (HICP) and house price (IPH) indices at Union level, at national and sub-national level. The report aims to include information on the impact that physical changes on inflation have in the inflation analysis. HICP-CT are an important tool for analysing the causes of inflation and predicting the impact of future fiscal changes on inflation - hence this draft report proposing that HICP and HICP-TC be divided into categories according to the European Classification of Individual Consumption by Objective. The report also calls for euro area Member States to provide rapid monthly estimates and for the breakdown of rapid HICP estimates, the owner-occupied house price index (PCA) and the IPH to be adopted through implementing acts. Finally, it has been determined that the Commission should, every five years, submit to the European Parliament and the Council a report assessing the main results of pilot studies. In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Commission Regulation updates the existing statistical methodology and establishes a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of harmonised consumer price indexes (HICP) and house prices (IPH) at Union level, at national and sub-national level. HICP-TC are an important tool for analysing the causes of inflation and predicting the impact of future fiscal changes on inflation and correcting macroeconomic imbalances.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report. This document aims to update the statistical methodology for the development of a harmonised consumer price index in the European Union; the current Regulation dates back to 1995 and the latest statistical developments on consumer prices required a revision of the current framework to ensure maximum compatibility for major IPCA users. This update is also important for the purposes of the Stability and Growth Pact, as early interim information on inflation, especially for monetary policy management, is essential.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on a commission proposal for a regulation that establishes a uniform legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonised consumer price indices (CHIS) and harmonised house price indices (IPIs) at EU level as well as at national and sub-national level. The IPCH is an element of inflation measurement, providing valuable information on the deflation of economic values such as wages, rents and interest rates; it is therefore the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. That is why it is extremely important, in this context, to be able to rely on objective, unbiased and comparable statistics across all Member States and product categories. The current HLP Regulation dates back to 1995, and recent statistical developments in consumer prices therefore required a revision of the current framework to ensure maximum comparability for the main users of THE CHPI.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the harmonised index of consumer prices.  The document establishes a uniform framework for harmonised consumer price indices (HICP) and house price indices (CCI) data at Union, national and sub-national level. These indices and a measure of inflation that allow the economic value of wages, rents, interest rates, etc. to be recalculated.  The proposal updates the regulation adopted as early as 1995. Changes in price statistics have long led to a long-term revision of the existing norms, thus ensuring objective comparability .

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this report amending the criteria used for monitoring consumer product prices in the EU. These indices are a fundamental tool for the adoption of certain macroeconomic decisions. We find the Commission's high discretion in changing these criteria problematic through delegated acts, and also the opening door for concepts such as prostitution, gambling, narcotics and others to be included in the indexes.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The Consumer Price Index measures price changes, including the year-to-year price increase.  I supported this text on the new consumer price index regulation that will repeal the 1995 regulation. It will thus be adapted to the statistical, technological and legislative changes of recent years. Parliament had also asked to add and clarify certain definitions as well as to determine the categories of sub-indexes whose production is not required by the Member States. The ECB's role is also strengthened in index production.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. (u2012 Legislation improves the quality of consumer price indices (HICP), which is important if macroeconomic imbalances in the EU are to be rectified. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I have decided to vote against this report because it leaves it to the European Commission many powers to define central details in relation to the definition of this price index which is fundamental to the living conditions of workers in the European Union. The report gives the Commission the ability to change the list of products considered when developing this index, without limiting the possibility of including products such as certain types of drugs or activities such as prostitution. Taking into account the effects that such inclusions can have, and above all the legitimacy effect on such activities that would have decisions like these, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The HIPO, the harmonised consumer price index measures changes over time in the prices of consumer goods and services purchased by households. It is essential that this index is constantly measured accurately, as many of the monetary and economic decisions taken by the EU depend on it. Following the latest developments in consumer price statistics, a revision of the REGULATION on which the HICA is based, dated 1995, was necessary. I therefore voted in favour of this report, because it provides for the introduction of a single simplified regulation that will make it possible to improve the definition of the categories of products to be taken over and the scope of the regulation, to reduce the scope for interpretation of the rules, to remove redundant parts of the legislation and to ensure uniform treatment of similar product groups in all Member States. In addition, in order to have timely information on inflation in order to implement monetary policy, euro area Member States will be asked to provide lightning estimates on a monthly basis.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ This proposed legislation seeks to harmonise indices across the EU; doing so will not reflect the various cultural differences in economic activity between different Member States and accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ One of the many factors that exacerbated the financial crisis in 2008 was that statistics on consumer prices were not consistent across the EU. I voted in favour of this legislative proposal because I believe that it will improve the quality of the indices used in measuring consumer prices – something which is important to get right when trying to correct macroeconomic imbalances across the EU.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported the establishment of a new framework on harmonised consumer price indices, as it introduces order in previous outdated updates and amendments to regulations adopted in the past, namely 20 of them over the past 17 years. The Harmonised Consumer Price Index is an important tool for analyzing the causes of inflation and forecasting the impact of future tax changes on inflation. This Regulation lays down a clearer scope for its application, leaving out for example transactions between households, while definitions of categories and product groups have been significantly clarified. The Regulation covers harmonised indices at constant tax rates, indices for owner-made housing and property price indices, both at Union and national and sub-national level. Its breadth also covers health, education and other specific areas separately, while reducing the scope for interpretation of the rules and ensuring uniform treatment of similar product groups in the Member States.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I agreed with the new harmonised consumer price adjustment, as this is mainly an update of the statistical methodology. The regulation currently in force on harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP) dates back to 1995 and the revision also required the need to take account of changes in the EU decision-making process following the adoption of the Treaty of Lisbon.  This Regulation will establish a single legal framework for the development, production and publication of hicp data as well as on house price indices. The HICP serves as a measure of inflation used, inter alia, as an important input for deflationary economic values, which includes wages, rents or interest rates. This means that this index forms the basis for the Economic and Monetary Policy Decisions of the Union and it is therefore desirable that statistics be objective, impartial and comparable. In addition, this statistical index provides information on price stability and is therefore essential to offset macroeconomic inequalities across the EU. I believe that this measure will make it possible to obtain more accurate, undistorted statistics in the future, thus avoiding financial crises similar to the one of 2008.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 Harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP) are designed to measure inflation in a harmonised manner in all Member States. The Commission and the European Central Bank shall use the HICP in their assessment of price stability in the Member States. Regulation (EC) No 2494/95 on the HICP was adopted in 1995 and circumstances have changed since then and it is therefore necessary to adapt this legislation. The Commission has proposed to have a single framework for the development, preparation and dissemination of harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP) and residential real estate price indices (HPI) at Union, national and sub-national level. Following the negotiations in the trialogue, the regulation also contains an indication of the owner-owned house price index (OOH), since the proportion of owner-owned residential properties varies greatly between Member States. The Commission will carry out a study on OOH and there is a possibility that this index will be included in the HICP context. The Regulation also recommends a study on the cost of living index by supplementing the HICP with additional inflation-related information. Provisional inflation data are very important for the implementation of monetary policy, so I believe that it is essential to provide objective and impartial statistics with the best possible comparability for HICP users. For the sake of the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the Harmonised Consumer Price Index (HIP), which modifies the existing statistical methodology, synthesizing its principles in a single regulation. This index measures inflation in all Member States in a harmonised manner and is used by the Commission and the European Central Bank to assess price stability in the Member States. The report emphasises the importance of dealing independently and separately with certain areas such as health, education and other specific sectors, in order to reduce the area of interpretation of the rules, ensuring uniform treatment of categories of similar products in all Member States.  I also believe that, for monetary policy in the euro area in the context of the correction of macroeconomic imbalances, it is essential to have preliminary provisional information in the form of a rapid estimate. Moreover, the HICA was designed to assess price stability and should not be understood as an index of the cost of living. From this point of view, I believe that pilot studies should be initiated on harmonised indices relating to the cost of living, as the report itself proposes.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 The primary purpose of harmonised consumer prices is to measure inflation in all Member States. However, their legislation contained in Regulation No 2494/95 does not sufficiently respond to technical progress and current needs. I therefore welcome the Union's action in the form of a new regulation that will ensure consistency between harmonisation and the latest knowledge in the area.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 Harmonised Consumer Price Indices (HIPC) are designed to measure inflation in a harmonised manner across Member States. The Commission and the European Central Bank shall use the HIPC in their assessment of price stability in the Member States in accordance with Article 140. treaty on the functioning of the European Union. Harmonised Consumer Price Indices (HIPC) are used to assess national competitiveness under the Commission's macroeconomic imbalance procedure.  This Regulation also lays down a common framework for the development, development and dissemination of harmonised consumer price indices (HIPC, harmonised consumer price indices at constant tax rates, price indices for owner-in-house housing) and property price indices at Union, national and sub-national level, and I have therefore supported it.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which lays down a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of Harmonised Indices of Consumer Prices (HICP) and of Housing Prices (HPI) at European Union and national level. HICP can have a major impact by deflating economic variables such as wages, rents and interest rates – and can form the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on harmonised indices of consumer prices and repealing the Regulation. More than 20 years old is the last regulation in force, and it is therefore necessary to adopt a new regulation which, in line with the new eu decision-making principles brought about by the Treaty of Lisbon, must be adopted. We need objective, impartial and accurate data that we will be able to compare between Member States. I support the Commission's contribution, if necessary, to the financing of pilot studies and to produce a report for the European Parliament and the Council once every five years to assess the main results of the pilot studies.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ As ECR shadow rapporteur for this file, I sought to protect the UK from having to produce statistical data only relevant for eurozone countries and also to ensure that national statistical authorities maintain control of statistical detail and development. This was successfully achieved, and I was therefore able to support this agreement at today’s vote.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the report on the ground that it promotes the harmonisation of consumer indicators. These are the indicators that determine the economic policies of each State since they can degrade or increase the value of the salaries and social rights of the Member States. Their harmonizing automatically means that one of the most important instruments of the State's fiscal policy is transferred into the hands of the Commission.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Decisions on EU economic and monetary policy should be based, inter alia, on statistics that are as objective, non-discriminatory and comparable as possible in all Member States and in all product sectors. New developments in consumer price statistics require a revision of the framework in order to ensure maximum comparability for key HST users.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the harmonised index of consumer prices. Without quality, reliable statistics and their comparability, there can be no responsible economic policy management. In this way, up-to-date, comparable statistical methods are in the interest of all EU citizens. As the existing Regulation on harmonised consumer price indices (HICP) originates in 1995, its amendment was indeed timely. I agree with the amendment which emphasises that the single framework for harmonised CPI should be adapted to current needs, inter alia, by improving the relevance and comparability of the HICP. Furthermore, I also share the view that the legal framework should ensure the monitoring of more comprehensive additional indicators, which will enable inflation to be measured, analysed and predicted. I also think it is right to make an amendment to the hicp's rapid estimates, since early information does indeed play a major role in the monetary policy of the euro area. Finally, I also support the promotion of pilot studies on harmonised cost of living indices.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – The change in prices for the various products and services on the European market is an element of uncertainty for consumers in the Member States. Significant differences, both between different states and between different regions, contribute to maintaining significant disparities at European level, creating the prerequisites for unfair discrimination between consumers. In order to counter these problems, the Commission has developed a unified statistical methodology, which can at this time be achieved through harmonised consumer price indices (HICPs). These indices aim to establish uniform treatment of similar product groups in the Member States in order to reduce the possibility of interpretation or violation of the rules, which contributed to the 2008 crisis. Treatment also concerns the area of real estate indices, which represent a significant part of the European economy, but does not relate to areas of public interest, such as education, health, etc. I believe that supporting this document and its application as soon as possible will help to reduce the existing development gaps at Union level. That is why I support its adoption in its current form.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The Commission's proposed regulation establishes a uniform legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on harmonised consumer price indices (CHPI) and harmonised house price indices (IPIs) at EU, national and sub-national level. The IPCH is an element of inflation measurement, providing valuable information on the deflation of economic values such as wages, rents and interest rates; it is therefore the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. That is why it is extremely important, in this context, to be able to rely on objective, unbiased and comparable statistics across all Member States and product categories.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of developing, collecting and disseminating harmonised indices of consumer prices that will allow us to measure and compare inflation across Member States. I believe that this is an essential tool to help us assess the competitiveness of our national economies more effectively, understand their shortcomings and subsequently be able to plan and formulate better economic and monetary regulations in a comparative perspective. Objective, smart and reliable statistics about our economies are a valuable public good, which every citizen should be able to have access to.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the Regulation touches on an important issue relating to a uniform legal framework for the development, compilation and dissemination of harmonised data on consumer price indices and house price indices at Union and national level. In this context, the Commission should ensure that these delegated acts do not impose a greater additional burden on Member States. It is essential that the statistics referred to in the Regulation are impartial and comparable for all Member States and for all product categories. As a result, new statistical trends require new legal norms.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Harmonised consumer price indices are designed to measure inflation in a harmonised manner across Member States and are used to assess national competitiveness under the Commission's macroeconomic imbalance procedure. As the current example of the Regulation on the Harmonised Index of Consumer Prices dates back to 1995, I have accepted a new proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on harmonised consumer price indices and the repeal of the old Regulation.  I believe that the proposal contains a single legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of data on the harmonised consumer price index and housing prices at Union, national and subnational level.   In addition, comparable and reliable consumer price indices, together with other sources, are valuable data for deflation of economic sizes such as wages, rents, interest rates and data from national accounts. These estimated quantities show the development of a particular phenomenon in an economy without the impact of inflation and are key data for political and economic decision-making.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on harmonised indices of consumer prices and repealing Regulation (EC) No 2494/95, as the new regulation provides a single European framework for harmonised indices of consumer prices both at Union and national level. I believe that the HICP provides an relevant criterion that allows statistics on consumer prices to be objective, impartial and comparable across member states. I believe that the regulation is urgently needed, not only to revify the 1995 HICP framework and to take account of the innovations in EU decision-making set out in the Treaty of Lisbon, but also to provide a criterion for inflation, which is used, inter alia, as an important figure in the deflation of economic values. It is precisely the latter that economic and monetary decisions are based on.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this report amending the criteria used for monitoring consumer product prices in the EU. These indices are a fundamental tool for the adoption of certain macroeconomic decisions. We find the Commission's high discretion to amend these criteria problematic through delegated acts, and also the opening door for concepts such as prostitution, gambling, narcotics and other

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this legislation as it is my belief that harmonisation in the way we calculate inflation is basic to achieving a clear picture of the state of our economies.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This report is a proposal to amend the consumer price index regulations. This price index allows the level of inflation to be calculated as comparablely as possible for all countries and is used by the European Central Bank as an indicator of price stability and as a means of verifying compliance with the convergence criterion for inflation. The amendments would establish a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of the Harmonized Consumer Price Index (CHPI), the Harmonised Consumer Price Index at Constant Taxation Rates (IPCH-TC), the Owner-Occupied Housing Price Index (LOP), and the Eu-national and National Housing Price Index (IPI). However, we must remain cautious because these indices can be used as political tools to better control Member States by imposing targets on them, or in order to return to imaginary growth by changing the calculation formulas. One of the two packages of proposed amendments has been adopted giving far too much power to the European Commission. So I voted against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal for a regulation sets out a single framework for the development, production and publication of harmonised indices of consumer prices and house prices (HICP and HPI) at EU, national and subnational level. The HICP makes it possible to measure inflation, which is, inter alia, valuable information when deflating economic values such as wages, pensions, interest rates and thus forms the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. It is therefore crucial that these statistics are objective, unbiased and comparable across all Member States and product categories. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against this report amending the criteria used for monitoring consumer product prices in the EU. These indices are a fundamental tool for the adoption of certain macroeconomic decisions. We find the Commission's high discretion in changing these criteria problematic through delegated acts, and also the opening door for concepts such as prostitution, gambling, narcotics and others to be included in the indexes.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this first reading agreement because the regulation includes two key proposals suggested by the Greens, namely: 1) The Commission shall prepare a report by the end of 2018, which shall address the suitability of the OOH price index for integration into HICP coverage. Depending on the results of the report, within a reasonable timeframe, the Commission shall submit, if appropriate, a proposal for amending this Regulation with regard to integrating the OOH price index within the HICP framework. If the report establishes that further methodological developments are required for the integration of the OOH price index within the HICP framework, the Commission will pursue the methodological work and report back to Parliament and the Council as appropriate; 2) In addition to the HICP, research on a harmonised cost of living index should be initiated, although no specific details were provided on how such research will be carried on.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report concerning the harmonisation of consumer price indices. The report suggests modernising existing rules to enable objective informing on price stability within the EU and monitor the effects of the European Central Bank’s monetary policy. It formulates a uniform legal framework for the creation, improvement and diffusion of Harmonised Indices of Consumer Prices (HICP) and of Housing Prices Indices (HPI) data at the national and sub-national EU level. HICP are particularly significant as they provide the inflation measure used for deflating economic values serving as the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. It is essential that these statistics are objective and comparable across all Member States and all product areas, as quality statistics and their comparability are of fundamental importance for all EU citizens, researchers and those responsible for public policy.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The objective of this legislation is to establish a common legal framework for the production of harmonised indices for Member States, which means collecting, compiling and processing harmonised consumer price indices. In this way we will be able to observe the results of the EU's monetary policies and advance price stability. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation which updates the statistical methodology for the development of a harmonised consumer price index, as this is essential for accurate inflation rate data, both in the EU and in the Eurozone.  The Regulation also recognises, at the initiative of the Spanish Socialists, that consumer price statistics are a public good.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. \u2012 The revision of the Consumer Price Index Regulation was voted on at the last plenary session. This index provides an instrument for measuring inflation and thus forms the basis for monetary policy decisions. The regulation dates back to 1995 and had to be revised. With the review, a number of steps have been taken, both in terms of harmonisation and through the inclusion of house prices and the inclusion of taxation data. Goods that do not cover household final consumption expenditure, such as narcotics, games, prostitution and certain types of insurance, have also been excluded from the basket. However, the timing of the review itself seems rather strange. As these changes will inevitably increase the inflation figure, this has raised the legitimate doubt that the revision of the regulation was necessary at a time when the ECB needed objective data to better justify unconventional policies and to better sponsor their policy at a difficult time when the EU bank was losing more and more credibility in a low-growth environment threatened by deflation. For these reasons, we voted against.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I support this review of harmonised consumer price indices, because having a uniform measure will help Member States calculate inflation and thus make the management of our economy easier and more effective.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 We do not follow the possibility of including in the price indices certain products derived from illicit activity such as prostitution or drug trafficking. Assuming some economic reasoning, we think that this is totally incomprehensible on the part of the citizens and constitutes a message of relative passivity, if not tolerance, with activities that should not be express, whether monetary, social or economic, in our society.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Harmonized Indices of Consumer Prices (HICPs) are intended to measure inflation in a harmonised manner in all Member States. A common framework for the development, compilation and dissemination of harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICPs) and the House Price Index (HPI) will be established at Union and national level. The PURPOSE of the HICP is to assess price stability. The effects are not foreseeable. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to regulate harmonised price indices by the European Parliament and the European Council. The wrong statistical indices were partly responsible for the 2008 financial crisis.  I am convinced that this legislation, which will improve and regularize statistical methodologies for the formulation of these indices, will improve the quality of the means available to the EU to correct macroeconomic imbalances.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the Harmonised Indices of Consumer Prices. The Harmonised Index of Consumer Prices (HICP) measures changes in consumer goods prices and services purchased by households. The HICP provides a comparable measure of inflation in the euro area, the EU, the European Economic Area and other countries, including acceding and candidate countries. The report mainly binds the national statistical offices in the EU. The resolution makes it possible to present these indices in a uniform manner.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted 'in favour' of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament on harmonised consumer price indices. These indicators are used to measure inflation adequately in all European Union countries. In addition, they are used to assess national competitiveness under the Commission's mi macroeconomic imbalances procedure.  It is therefore crucial that statistics based on harmonised consumer indicators are objective, impartial and comparable in all Member States and in all product categories. In order to ensure comparability of indicators, a level playing field is needed for the division of THE HICP into categories. Furthermore, in order to help Member States prepare comparable consumer price indices, it is extremely important that methodological instructions are drawn up and regularly updated by the European Commission in close cooperation with The Member States within the European Statistical System.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, which I supported, lays down the necessary conditions for the revision of the existing regulation since 1995, as is also necessary in view of new developments in consumer price statistics.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The consumer price index provides an instrument for measuring inflation and forms the basis for economic and monetary policy decisions. It is therefore necessary for its calculation methods to be objective, impartial and comparable in all Member States and for all product categories. A number of steps have been taken, both in terms of harmonisation and through the inclusion of house prices and taxation data, but it may be thought that the change in the inflation index will have implications for the monetary policy decisions taken by the ECB. The new index will better reflect reality, on the one hand, but, on the other, it will inflate the inflation figure by making the ECB's unconventional policies appear more positive than they actually are. This raised the legitimate doubt that the revision of the Regulation was necessary at a time when the ECB needed objective data to justify its unconventional policies at a time of difficulty when it is increasingly losing its credibility, in a context characterised by low growth and threatened by deflation. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation on harmonised indices of consumer prices. Harmonised indices of consumer prices are important for several reasons. First of all, they provide important information on price stability within the European Union, monitor the effects of monetary policy and are able to measure inflation with high accuracy. That is why it is important that these statistics are objective, impartial and comparable across the European Union. Given that the current legislation on consumer price indices could rather be described as complex and, in a sense , as it did not reflect the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, it was widely supported for simplification and updating.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 The existing framework for the provision of harmonised index consumer prices consists of the 1995 Regulation and the 20 implementing regulations and is as such opaque and in some cases obsolete. Legislation should therefore be adapted and harmonised for a number of reasons, in particular with a view to providing accurate information on price stability within the Union and monitoring the monetary policy effects of the European Central Bank. In view of the above, I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on harmonised indices of consumer prices and repealing Regulation (EC) No 2494/95.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Dear Fellow Members, Increased action against corruption and the fraud of public funds, I believe, is a positive, promising, great thing for everyone but economic criminals. But we know from our recent experience in Szeklerland that this noble purpose and intention can be re-used. The Romanian Corruption Prosecutor's Office and the Romanian authorities are clearly using these bodies for political purposes. In the vicinity of political elections, to terrorize the mayors of Miercurea Ciuc and other mayors and to make their political activities impossible. In the light of this experience, I did not know this from olaf's present... (Part of the opposition was not recorded due to a technical problem.) Thus, while it gives you a chance to prevent the theft of money, it also gives you the chance to be abused for political purposes, for example, against my country, Hungary.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, the fight against fraud has been a top priority for the EU for all the time I have been here, and before. What I welcome about this report is that it outlines the challenges in how we protect the EU’s financial interests, but by fighting fraud we can also retain the confidence of our citizens. This report highlights that there are some areas where a number of Member States have to do more – including my own, the United Kingdom. I think that it is important to recognise that a vast number of cases of fraud that the EU has to address are in fact in Member States. The Commission’s commitment in this report to publishing a regular EU anti—corruption report is welcome, as are the calls to harmonise the methodology behind the calculation of error rates at both EU and Member State levels. However, a meaningful fight against fraud means that there must be legislation regarding the minimum level of protection for whistle—blowers.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I welcome the report which addresses the issue of the protection of the European Union's financial interests. The report describes very well the problems that we encounter when infringements occur, whether negligently or intentionally, that is, fraud is committed directly here.  However, I did not support the report as such in the end, I abstained, which is why I am taking the opportunity to explain it here now. I personally do not consider it an appropriate means of combating this imperiousness to establish a new office, namely to establish a European Prosecutor's Office. I am convinced that this new office will not improve the state of the fight against financial fraud, that financial fraud must be combated by judicial authorities in individual national states, and that the judiciary as such can criminally and legally recognise and condemn the infringements of those who abuse subsidies, for example.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Compared to 2013, the overall impact of non-fraud offences increased by 36 % in 2014. And in turn, the number of known irregularities increased by 48% to more than sixteen thousand cases. Adding to this fact is that, according to a recent report published by the European Court of Auditors, the error rate estimated in the expenditure part of the Community budget for 2014 amounts to 4.4% or more than 6.3 billion of the total expenditure. This is a huge sum and it was used very inefficiently.  Losses due to corruption at Union level now amount to EUR 120 billion, and these are only official data. Unofficial, colleagues, we know nothing. Consequently, the Commission's offer, according to which it is mandatory to publish all documents, is welcome, and I support it. Thank you!

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 In implementing the Union's policies, justice must be guaranteed. That is why there are offices dedicated to combating fraud in the management of European funds. In 2014 alone, 1649 irregularities were reported in the allocation of funds, for a total of €538 million. The most critical areas are expenditure on public goods or services (public procurement) and procurement. I voted in favour of this report because it provides a clear and comprehensive view of the various points of interest and possible improvements in the fight against fraud.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. – This report admits that the overall financial impact of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported in 2014 is 36% greater than in 2013, while the number of such irregularities increased by 48%, and that 1 649 irregularities were fraudulent. It recognises that fraud in TOR is up by 196% from 2013 to 2014, and that just 24% of the money is recovered. Such honesty is commendable. However, it fundamentally fails to grasp that the causes of the problem are the systems themselves – particularly around the bureaucratic nature of VAT – and its proposed solutions involve more action by the Commission and further harmonisation. One-size-fits-all has been a proven failure; this report calls for more of it.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – This report admits that the overall financial impact of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported in 2014 is 36% greater than in 2013, while the number of such irregularities increased by 48%, and that 1 649 irregularities were fraudulent. It recognises that fraud in TOR is up by 196% from 2013 to 2014, and that just 24% of the money is recovered. Such honesty is commendable. However, it fundamentally fails to grasp that the causes of the problem are the systems themselves – particularly around the bureaucratic nature of VAT – and its proposed solutions involve more action by the Commission and further harmonisation. One-size-fits-all has been a proven failure; this report calls for more of it.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The report contains a number of proposals to improve the fight against fraud and corruption in EU budgets, so I voted in favour.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 This annual report of the European Parliament on the protection of the EU's financial interests for 2014 specifically mentions the fight against corruption. The report makes it clear that in 2014 there was an increase compared to last year in the overall impact of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities. The European Parliament therefore encourages the European Commission to maintain its strict policy and to provide, inter alia, full transparency on the relationship between national law enforcement authorities and the European Anti-Corruption Office. According to the Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats, this report provides a clearer picture of the main challenges relating to the protection of financial interests in the EU, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. As with the 2013 Annual Report, I once again worked in 2014 to ensure that every penny we have at our disposal for European projects is used wisely. Reports of waste and misspent taxpayers' money are damaging the reputation of the European Union and politics itself. In addition, there must continue to be less room for criminal energy to develop.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Under the pretext of the fight against fraud, the European Union is acquiring new superstructures and confiscating even more sovereignty from the Member States. I obviously voted against this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report. The report tells us that corruption in the EEA is in the region of €120 billion. The same report says that the fraudulent use of UK taxpayers’ money is ‘often linked to insufficient knowledge of complex rules and requirements’. Most interestingly with regard to what the EU refers to as ‘own resources’, which is another phrase for ‘what UK citizens pay via VAT’, fraud has increased 191% between 2013 and 2014. The European Ombudsman in the report tells us that the ‘European Commission’s credibility and seriousness have been endangered’ as it does not follow its own suggested guidelines. This report also calls for the implementation of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. I am vehemently opposed to the EPPO as I am not in favour of the EU having a ‘justice system’ that would stand above the UK justice system.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. While a process of consolidation and budgetary restraint is underway in Europe, it is essential to use all available resources to boost investment and growth within the Union. I voted for this report because fraud now costs the EU EUR 120 billion a year, compared to its annual budget of EUR 150 billion.  It is important to combat fraud and to ensure that the eu's budget is properly used for projects that contribute to growth and employment. In addition, all necessary measures must be taken to prevent or stop fraudulent policy activity. Illegal and illegal trade has an impact on member states' collection of tariffs and therefore directly penalises the EU budget.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ Fraud receives much public attention and severely damages the reputation of the European Union. Therefore, we need decent financial management to prevent irregular and illegal expenditure and irregularities relating to revenue. The Commission and the Member States should work closely together and fight irregularities and corruption. Moreover, I support the ideas from the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) to develop a system of indicators to measure the level of corruption in the Member States, to amend the EU Staff Regulations in order to enhance the protection of whistle-blowers and to improve transparency in the lobbying sector. It could play a positive role in increasing the trustworthiness and public image of the European Union institutions.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on "Protecting the European Union's financial interests and combating fraud". I was the rapporteur for the 2010 report on the protection of the EU's financial interests, and I am therefore aware of this issue. However, since then, fraud and irregularities have increased, and already in 2014 the EU lost more than EUR 3 billion. Euro. However, so far, a small proportion of illegally diseducated cash has still been recovered from Member States. As I have said many times, the main problem remains that Member States are not obliged to provide comprehensive and comparable data on their use when receiving the huge funds allocated by the EU. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to harmonise the principles for reporting fraud and to establish a clear reporting system to determine how Member States implement the recommendations of investigations carried out by OLAF and to provide for penalties for non-compliance. This situation must not be tolerated, and I therefore reiterate my calls on the Commission to take full responsibility for the recovery of EU funds unduly paid.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report has a number of forces and makes correct, eligible proposals for abuses of EU funds and VAT fraud. The proposal urges the Commission, in line with the relevant legal basis, to maintain its strict policy of interrupting and suspending payments. This is ineligible because it does not meet the requirements of the standard and thus may lead to arbitrary application of the law, which may result in the discipline of Member States acting in the interests of the protection of sovereignty. A concrete example of this is the recent threat by the Italian Prime Minister to withdraw aid to states opposed to migrant infractions. The report calls for the establishment of an EU Public Prosecutor's Office, which may also be capable of limiting sovereignty in the Member States. On this basis, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This report takes the pretext of fraud and other "irregularities" found in EU accounts to call for more control over Member States. Thus, under the guise of anti-fraud, it proposes to create new superstructures, to strengthen the powers of the Commission or its substitutes: all additional steps to the dilution of the sovereignty of our nations.  That is why I voted against it.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this report, which worryingly underlines that all irregularities reported in 2014 amount to EUR 3.24 billion, an increase of 36% over 2013. Of these irregularities, 16,473 were fraudulent (VAT fraud, smuggling, counterfeiting, etc.) amounting to 538 million euros.  In response to these findings, the report recommends, in particular, that the Commission should harmonize the reporting framework for alleged fraud and the rules for reporting all legal actions taken in Member States concerning the potentially fraudulent use of EU resources. The report also calls for the European Commission to develop a system of reliable indicators and easily applicable uniform criteria to measure the level of corruption in Member States that would cost the EU economy EUR 120 billion a year! With regard to non-fraudulent irregularities, the report calls for administrative measures, in particular by establishing more transparent and simpler requirements and by strengthening technical assistance to Member States.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. 80% of the Union budget is implemented by the Member States and by the Commission. In addition to legislative and budgetary powers, MEPs have important oversight work.  The report is critical of the expenditure and revenue management of the Union budget. Of the total of 16 473 irregularities notified to the Commission in 2014, 1 649 were fraudulent, i.e. EUR 538.2 million.  Although I believe that the Union budget is spent efficiently, there are still too many irregularities and therefore, as we ask in the report, the Commission and the Member States have to assume their responsibilities. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. 12012 Corruption is a serious problem affecting all Member States and is a factor that undermines citizens' confidence in democratic institutions and processes. Every year, as a result of this phenomenon, the European economy suffers substantial losses, estimated at around EUR 120 billion; Resources that can be linked more generally to increased funding opportunities for organised crime networks and terrorism-related networks. The Jávor report, which I supported with my vote, correctly highlighted the main challenges concerning the protection of the Union's financial interests. The current existence of significant differences in the number of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported by each State gives a distorted picture of the real situation which prevents the problem from being clearly represented. The definition and harmonisation of the framework for reporting suspected cases must therefore be a priority, which can be pursued through the systematic implementation of the recommendations of the European Anti-Fraud Office. The fight against corruption and money laundering offences must increasingly be seen, within an overall framework, as a key tool for ensuring the effective functioning of EU institutions.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The greens report includes interesting elements in the control of european institutions' expenditure, such as the development of results-based budgets including multiple indicators (also based on environmental issues). Also the promotion of the European Prosecutor, EPPO, to fill the shortcomings of the current agencies. But the report also includes measures to require harmonisation of the calculation of irregularities or fraud, with the aim of making a ranking of countries according to the irregularity and fraud ratio they achieve. The solution he seems to propose is to demand the paralysis of payments from European programmes to the countries concerned without making distinctions between the beneficiary, civil service, business and government populations. It also sided with the Supervisory Committee of OLAF, under the Council, which has had uns professional and interested control behaviour.
