On this balance sheet we shuffle abstention if it withdraws the punishment from the countries or these sesamos considerations against OLAF. The vote was not barned in favour because they are also not the measures that we would have put forward, apart from mentions according to neoliberal elements of the model. To this end, separate votes were proposed. However, these points were not withdrawn and eventually voted against.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this report on the protection of the Union's financial interests and the fight against fraud. There are sections relating to the detection and reporting of irregularities, income and own resources, expenditure, need for improved information and controls, among other things. The Commission is requested to develop rigorous indicator systems and uniform criteria that are easily applicable on the basis of the stockholm programme requirements for measuring the level of corruption of Member States and assessing anti-corruption policies.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report presents anti-fraud recommendations to which national authorities, the Council and the Commission must pay attention. It makes an observation on the irregularities or frauds reported in the EU's accounts, whether in terms of revenue or expenditure. Justifying the anti-fraud, he proposes the creation of new superstructures and strengthening the powers of the Commission. Once again the dilution of the sovereignty of nations takes precedence. This report regrets the reduction in VAT revenues or tariffs, while welcoming the existing trade agreements and calling for a strengthening of the single market, which leads me to vote against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report regularly analyses fraud and irregularities reported to the Commission in 2014 and proposes measures to be put in place to improve both controls and alerts by increasing prevention. Although I broadly support it, I have chosen to abstain in voting on this text because some of the proposals go in the direction of asking the Member States for new transfers of sovereign prerogatives which I certainly cannot support.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. Investing European taxpayers' money well is a requirement. That is why we must properly protect the EU's financial interests by combating fraud and irregularities with every possible means. In the light of the data from this report, we must remain vigilant and redouble our efforts in this area, as the total sum of EU funds that have been splattered with some irregularity amounts to EUR 3 240 million. The report stresses that procedures by States and the Commission should be simplified and citizens should be better available to alleviate non-fraudulent irregularities.  In addition, the Commission undertakes to submit a biannual report on anti-corruption and to the establishment of a strict policy on suspension and interruption of payments if the interests of the Union are at risk. For all this, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which contains the 2014 Annual Report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests. Fight against fraud'. In this report, the European Parliament stresses that irregularities not considered to be fraud often involve insufficient knowledge of complex rules and requirements. It considers that simplifying the rules and procedures between the Member States and the Commission would reduce the number of such infringements. In addition, the fight against irregularities, including fraud, requires the awareness of all institutional bodies at European, national, regional and local level and the general public. The creation of a culture promoting fraud prevention and combating fraud is essential for all institutions and bodies involved in the use of funds, and Member States are therefore encouraged to promote the exchange of good practices. The European Parliament reiterates its call on the Commission to establish a system for the exchange of information between competent authorities, enabling cross-checking of accounting records between two or more Member States in order to prevent cross-border fraud through the Structural and Investment Funds, thereby ensuring a horizontal approach to the protection of the EU's financial interests.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I supported the proposed annual report on the protection of the EU's financial interests and the fight against fraud by thoroughly analysing the situation in the field of combating irregularities and proposing an appropriate set of measures to tackle fraud more intensively. Financial fraud is unfortunately ing in all areas, and the EU budget is no exception either. Irregularities in 2014 amounted to as much as EUR 3.24 billion, which is 36% more than in 2013. This suggests that, despite the many efforts made to combat irregularities, there are still a number of reserves. It is also important to distinguish between irregularities and fraud, as the former can occur unintentionally, while others are consciously targeted at damaging public funds. In order to prevent both, enhanced cooperation between The Member States and the European institutions, in particular the Commission, is therefore necessary, and on the other hand, it is necessary to simplify the system of rules defining the implementation of the disbursement system from the EU budget.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this Report on the Protection of the EU's Financial Interests, and I also take this opportunity to welcome the Commission's commitment to publish the EU anti-corruption report twice a year and to call for the swift promotion of the Eu Minimum Level of Whistleblower Protection Act.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The report presents anti-fraud recommendations to which national authorities, the Council and the Commission must pay attention. This report is a pretext for inducing more control over the Member States by creating new superstructures, strengthening the Powers of the Commission, which would lead to a further step towards diluting the sovereignty of nations. In addition, it calls for a strengthening of the single market. For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the fight against fraud against the EU budget must be a priority for the Commission and that it is essential to implement a uniform and uniform system of rules that will make it possible to prevent, as well as react, fraud and to minimise possible errors on the part of users of European funds.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Corruption affects all Member States and costs the EU economy around €120 billion a year, as indicated in the Commission's first report on EU anti-corruption policy, published in February 2014. Sound public spending and the protection of the European Union's financial interests are key elements of EU policy in order to increase citizens' confidence by ensuring that their money is used correctly, efficiently and effectively. The European Parliament must contribute to the fight against fraud and corruption, which can help finance the activities of organised crime networks or terrorism in Europe, undermining citizens' confidence in democratic institutions and processes. Parliament must take note of the 2014 annual report on the 'Protection of the European Union's financial interests in the fight against fraud' and urge the Commission to further increase its efforts to ensure that the fight against fraud and corruption is effectively implemented and leads to more tangible and satisfactory results.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report makes anti-fraud recommendations, including in the management of the Rural Development Fund or in the awarding of public contracts. The rapporteur proposes a dematerialisation of procedures, a simplification of financial rules and better training of local administrations in order to put an end to these irregularities. It also wants to encourage greater transparency, notably through the more regular publication of compliance audits.  Nevertheless, under the guise of anti-fraud, this report calls for the creation of new structures, which are costly to the taxpayer, and to strengthen the control of the Member States, thereby undermining our national sovereignty. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The protection of the Union's financial interests must be a central element of the EU's political programme. Both the European Union and the Member States must protect financial interests against crimes that cause significant financial damage. Unfortunately, corruption affects all Member States and creates costs of around EUR 120 billion for the EU economy. The effects of corruption are also felt in terms of diminished citizens' confidence in the European institutions and in democratic processes. I consider it beneficial for the Commission to implement a new anti-fraud policy, in line with the principle of sound financial management and in order to ensure the proper protection of the EU's financial interests, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Final vote: abstention. There are a number of key passages in the report which, for us, foreshadow unacceptable transfers of sovereignty in the field of the judiciary. However, an explicit vote against on the 'fight against fraud' would expose us to instrumental attacks.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on the 2014 annual report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests – Combating fraud, as I believe that stimulating sustainable economic growth is a priority objective to be achieved through a work of budgetary consolidation and rigour that also includes the fight against fraud , in every manifestation. As I have also pointed out in my other speeches and as is evident from the report that I approve, the combination of possible policy instruments must be accompanied by the effective application of existing legislation and effective compliance with international commitments, including anti-fraud and anti-corruption clauses. I therefore welcome the annual report, which shows that the strategy on international fiscal policies must not be separated from coordinated action at EU level. The benefits of the internal market must also be enhanced by relentless pressure on tax fraud and evasion.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ This report admits that the overall financial impact of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported in 2014 is 36% greater than in 2013, while the number of such irregularities increased by 48%, and that 1 649 irregularities were fraudulent. It recognises that fraud in TOR is up by 196% from 2013 to 2014, and that just 24% of the money is recovered. Such honesty is commendable. However, it fundamentally fails to grasp that the causes of the problem are the systems themselves – particularly around the bureaucratic nature of VAT – and its proposed solutions involve more action by the Commission and further harmonisation. One-size-fits-all has been a proven failure; this report calls for more of it.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because just like its author, I am concerned about the continuously high number of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities, particularly in public procurement, all of which have a negative impact on our economy. The report lays out a number of measures which could help address this problem, for example on better detection and reporting of the irregularities, better controls and harmonisation of  methods used for calculating the error rates. Most importantly, the Commission needs to make full use of its powers regarding VAT fraud and work closely with the Member States on the subject. The European Investment Bank, on the other hand, should strengthen its transparency and governance.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Reported irregularities amounted to around 3.24 billion in 2014 and have a 36% greater overall financial impact than in 2013. The report points out that non-fraudulent irregularities are often due to insufficient knowledge of complex rules and requirements, and a simplification of rules and procedures is therefore required. With regard to fraudulent activities, however, the report highlights the estimated loss in VAT collection, which, in 2013, amounted to 168 billion. There is also a high level of irregularities in public procurement and calls for greater vigilance on the part of the Commission. The report is based on a constructively critical approach which I support and have therefore voted in favour of.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The figures in the European Commission's report clearly show us that we cannot lower our guard and that the protection of financial interests and the fight against fraud must be placed at the heart of European policy. In 2014, Member States reported 1 649 irregularities as fraud against European funds, amounting to EUR 538 million. Ensuring the correct use of the financial resources of the European budget is our duty. In this respect, it is becoming increasingly necessary to ensure transnational coordination and to encourage Member States to turn to Europol, Eurojust and OLAF for ever-increasing cooperation. Indeed, the diversity of the legal and administrative systems of the Member States makes it even more difficult to combat fraud and corruption, just as the absence of uniform reporting principles in all Member States increases the difficulty of collecting comparable and accurate data. The extent of the damage that fraud causes to the financial interests of the Union should also convince us of the need to resume the debate in order to adopt the PIF Directive and the Regulation establishing the European Public Prosecutor's Office in order to create a regulatory and institutional framework for an effective and coordinated defence of the Union's financial interests. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report taking into account that Member States have the main responsibility for collecting own resources, while also stressing that rationalising public spending and protecting the EU's financial interests should be central elements of EU policy to strengthen citizens' confidence by ensuring the proper, efficient and efficient use of their money.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the 2014 annual report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests and the fight against fraud. Such procedures concern issues vital to the present and future of the Union and it is particularly important that we take them seriously. In view of the particularly strong implications of corruption issues in political, economic and social areas, we understand that reports which address the issue in depth, such as this one, contribute to the defence of legality and I have therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because this report, which focuses on the EIB's investment programme, represents a clear commitment to greater transparency and accountability. The document also underlines the Commission's competences, believing that the Commission should take full responsibility for the recovery of amounts unduly paid by the EU. In its report, OLAF undertakes to work more closely with Member States to combat fraud by collecting accurate data and maintaining its strict policy on interruptions and suspensions of payments. It is important for Parliament to be in favour of transparency and accountability, because it is Parliament that represents those citizens with whom the Member States finance the EU.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Corruption is a concern for all Member States, costing the EU economy around €120 billion per year. The EU’s policy should include the protection of the EU’s financial interests amongst its main elements. The average VAT loss for Member States in 2014 exceeded 15.2%. It is necessary for the Commission to create a mechanism that would encourage companies to pay regular tax rather than committing tax avoidance. The time between the appearance of an irregularity, its discovery and the final Commission report is now three years four months. The Commission should engage with the Member States to ensure there is an improvement in the efficiency of discovery and reporting. The Commission is called upon to ameliorate the diverging approaches that exist between Member States in the detection of irregularities. A system of uniform criteria should be developed by the Commission that would measure the levels of corruption in each Member State whilst evaluating their anti-corruption policies. Member States must transpose Directive 2014/24/EU, making e-procurement mandatory whilst introducing monitoring requirements.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ This report admits that the overall financial impact of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported in 2014 is 36% greater than in 2013, while the number of such irregularities increased by 48%, and that 1 649 irregularities were fraudulent. It recognises that fraud in TOR is up by 196% from 2013 to 2014, and that just 24% of the money is recovered. Such honesty is commendable. However, it fundamentally fails to grasp that the causes of the problem are the systems themselves – particularly around the bureaucratic nature of VAT – and its proposed solutions involve more action by the Commission and further harmonisation. One-size-fits-all has been a proven failure; this report calls for more of it.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The financial interests of the Union relate not only to the allocation of funds, but also to the collection of taxes, such as VAT. Thus, control is essentially done at national level. True knowledge of this reality is also dependent on national authorities and, therefore, as the report rightly points out, the transmission of information must be exemplary. Something that still does not happen, although it is possible to already have a good photograph.  The known data remain worrying at almost all levels, especially in the negative for member states' recovery of funds after their return has been declared. In view of this scenario, the report also recommends, quite rightly, that the institutional and legal framework be strengthened. The importance of completing the legislative process of the so-called Financial Interests Protection Directive should be underlined. I therefore support this report.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – This report admits that the overall financial impact of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported in 2014 is 36% greater than in 2013, while the number of such irregularities increased by 48%, and that 1 649 irregularities were fraudulent. It recognises that fraud in TOR is up by 196% from 2013 to 2014, and that just 24% of the money is recovered. Such honesty is commendable. However, it fundamentally fails to grasp that the causes of the problem are the systems themselves – particularly around the bureaucratic nature of VAT – and its proposed solutions involve more action by the Commission and further harmonisation. One-size-fits-all has been a proven failure; this report calls for more of it.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report focuses mainly on the EIB's investment programme, as well as identifying and notifying fraudulent irregularities. Parliament noted that the total number of reported irregularities amounted to approximately EUR 3.24 billion and pointed out that the overall financial impact of the fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported in 2014 was 36% greater than in 2013, while the number of such irregularities increased by 48%. I agree with the report and vote in favour because it is a strengthening of the EIB's governance, transparency and control framework, supporting a shift towards full parliamentary accountability.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The EU institutions are continuously trying to ensure that fraudulent use of EU funds is wiped out. Full transparency through collecting appropriate, comparable and accurate data as well as establishing uniform reporting principles are important tools. Often non-fraudulent irregularities occur due to insufficient knowledge of complex rules and heavy bureaucratic procedures. Simplification of rules and procedures may also help reduce irregularities.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The annual report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests in 2014 is presented by the Commission in cooperation with the Member States and sets out the measures taken by the Commission and the Member States in the fight against fraud and the results achieved. In 2014, the total number of reported irregularities amounted to approximately €3.24 billion and the overall financial impact of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported in 2014 was 36% higher than in 2013, while the number of such irregularities increased by 48%. All Member States are asked to participate in Eurofisc in all its areas of activity in order to facilitate the exchange of information in order to help combat so-called 'carousel' fraud. It is found that the level of irregularities resulting from non-compliance with public procurement rules continues to be high and the Commission is required to ensure and apply the rules, giving priority to maximum transparency in order to prevent fraud.  In general, the report provides a good critical apparatus, and I therefore believe that we should vote in favour of it.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The report contains a number of proposals to improve the fight against fraud and corruption in EU budgets, so I voted in favour.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Public spending and the protection of the EU's financial interests must be essential elements of the EU's policy of increasing citizens' trust by ensuring the correct, efficient and effective use of their money. Corruption affects all Member States and creates costs of around EUR 120 billion annually for the EU economy. I voted for the European Executive to take full responsibility for recovering funds wrongly paid from the EU budget, as well as for improving the collection of own resources, and to establish uniform reporting principles in all Member States with a view to collecting adequate, comparable and accurate data. Through the Commission's ex-ante and ex-post controls, more and more irregularities have been detected and it is therefore necessary to promote these controls further. The competent authorities of the Member States must also improve controls and use all available information to avoid errors and irregular payments related to the use of EU funds.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The draft report submitted is based on OLAF's 2014 annual report and the Commission's report. Your rapporteur supports the implementation of the anti-fraud strategy by all Commission services and recommends that EU agencies, executive agencies and joint ventures do the same. It also asks the Commission to include a chapter on results in the report on combating corruption in the EU, to be published shortly. The document calls on the EC to take full responsibility for recovering funds unduly paid from the EU budget and to maintain a strict policy of withholding and suspending payments. Member States must take the same measures to combat fraud affecting the financial interests of the European Union as they undertake to combat fraud affecting their own financial interests. Nevertheless, since compromise amendment 9 (paragraph 52, paragraph 53) was adopted by a vote in the Commission, I decided to abstain.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The fight against fraud is fundamental if we want to ensure the sound management of European Union funds. The report published annually by the Commission outlines that in 2014, the EU Member States reported 1 649 fraudulent irregularities which involved EUR 538 million of EU funds. There was an increase in fraudulent irregularities on the revenue side; however, there was a decrease on the expenditure side, with the Commission interrupting 193 payments in the cohesion policy and rural development areas. This report urges the Commission to maintain its strict policy on interrupting and suspending payments in accordance with the relevant legal basis, as well as harmonising the methodology for calculating error rates at EU and Member State level, which would lead to enhanced cooperation among EU institutions. We need to have a clear and fair picture of the main challenges that exist when protecting the financial interests of the EU and for these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report responds to the annual reports of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) in July 2015 and the European Commission in September 2015 on the protection of the EU's financial interests and the fight against fraud in 2014.  In this report, we call for greater transparency and governance of the European Investment Bank (EIB), by advocating for greater parliamentary control. We also recommend improving the detection of irregularities and developing a value-for-money strategy to prevent fraud. These objectives cannot be achieved without a stronger commitment from the Member States. Considering that fraud undermines the financial interests of the Union, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The report on the fight against fraud in 2014 reminds us that Member States must take the same measures, whether it is to combat fraud that harms the Union's financial interests or to combat fraud against their own financial interests.  I voted in favour of this text because I think it is important to follow OLAF's recommendations and to ensure better coordination between OLAF, customs authorities and market supervisors. Better coordination will help to solve the growing problems of international organised crime, such as smuggling, illegal and illegal trade, which is thus an incident to the EU budget.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the JAVOR report on the 2014 annual report on the protection of the financial interests of the European Union. This text calls on Member States to take the same measures to combat fraud that harms the Union's financial interests as those taken at national level. Through this vote we call for greater parliamentary scrutiny and more transparency, particularly with regard to tobacco agreements.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. In the case of a better fight against fraud, this report aims to strengthen the powers of the Commission or its substitutes, thereby undermining the sovereignty of nations.  It suggests that the Commission audit Member States, and repeats its proposal to establish a European public prosecutor's office with broad judicial powers, including the fight against fraud. It goes so far as to require a public report on the use of European funds from the courts of state accounts.  Finally, it is alarmed by a decline in VAT revenues or tariffs (traditional own resources) while welcoming existing trade agreements and calling for a strengthening of the single market.  For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to abstain on this report because every year we adopt many resolutions and reports on the fight against fraud of all kinds and finally we are constantly witnessing large-size fraud. Of course, we are also achieving great successes, but there is still much to be desired. We need to be stricter in prosecuting and detecting financial crimes, because this is not only the Community budget, but also the Member States.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important to have and operate independent anti-fraud services and mechanisms in the European Union. The funds available to the EU in the Member States as well as in third countries should be subject to scrutiny as to their sound management, in order to reduce their exploitation by the governments of the Member States for the benefit of their micro-party objectives, but also to avoid illegal agreements with large companies to the detriment of citizens.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Member States and the Commission share responsibility for the implementation of 80 % of the Union budget and are responsible for the collection of own resources, in particular in the form of VAT and customs duties. The efficiency of public spending and the protection of the EU's financial interests should be key elements of EU policy in order to increase citizens' confidence by ensuring that their money is used correctly, efficiently and effectively. According to the present report, the irregularities reported involve a total amount of around EUR 3.24 billion with an overall financial impact of 36 % higher than in 2013, while the number of such irregularities increased by 48 %. Of the 16 473 irregularities reported to the Commission in 2014, EUR 1 649 was fraudulent, involving EUR 538.2 billion.  I agree that the Commission should take full responsibility for the recovery of funds unduly paid from the EU budget and for the collection of own resources more effectively.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it aims to frame the sovereignty of states in the fight against fraud.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 The worrying increase in fraudulent irregularities that emerges from the 2014 Annual Report on the Protection of the European Union's Financial Interests confirms the need to complete and consolidate the legal framework and actions to combat fraud, which is currently deficient in the non-adoption of the PIF Directive and the regulation establishing the European Public Prosecutor's Office. A significant vulnus is found in the field of procurement for major works where it is essential to improve controls, the exchange of information, mechanisms to facilitate reporting and the adoption of measures on the transparency of procedures. Priority is given to the prosecution of crimes and illegal activities such as smuggling, counterfeiting of goods, trafficking in human beings and other forms of illegal trade. These phenomena, as well as corruption, money laundering (with Luxembourg and Germany at the earliest in Europe) and organised crime, have taken on a worrying transnational character and should be countered by appropriate instruments of equal level.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee on Budgetary Control draws up each year an own-initiative report on the protection of the "union's financial interests", which also includes information on irregularities and cases of fraud transmitted by Member States, which has been growing in percentage and upstream. This report regrets that Member States use "different definitions for similar types of crime and that not all [collect] identical and detailed statistical data according to common criteria, making it difficult to collect reliable and comparable statistics at EU level". It calls for the criteria for assessing irregularities and fraud to be standardised in the Member States by linking them to their sanctioning measures for non-compliance. Also asking the Commission to present guidelines to "assist" in harmonisation in fraud assessment. It calls for the Commission to play a more active role in monitoring control and supervisory systems in the Member States and to recover unduly unpaid funds for the EU budget. The report regrets that criminal law systems are only partially harmonised, citing the need for a regulation to establish the European Public Prosecutor's Office. Accepting and defending the need to improve the fight against fraud, we do not follow up on some of the considerations and proposals made in the report.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it was positive overall.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The 2014 Annual Report on the Protection of the European Union's Financial Interests in the Fight against Fraud reveals a number of failures. In the area of detection and reporting of irregularities, all reported irregularities correspond to approximately EUR 3.24 billion. The European Commission must take full responsibility for recovering the funds unduly paid from the European Union budget and put more pressure on the Member States in collecting data and information. Information on the VAT gap and estimated vat collection losses is also worrying. The European Commission will have to find a way and create a mechanism to motivate businesses to pay their taxes regularly and not avoid obligations. I consider it very bad news that public procurement rules continue to be breached. Member States must swiftly transpose into national law the Public Procurement Directive, which makes e-procurement compulsory and introduces a monitoring and reporting obligation in order to reduce procurement fraud and other serious irregularities.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report because, although I agree with the tough fight against fraud, there are still serious doubts about the transfer of sovereignty in the area of the judiciary.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important to have and operate independent anti-fraud services and mechanisms in the European Union. The funds available to the EU in the Member States as well as in third countries should be subject to scrutiny as to their sound management, in order to reduce the phenomena of their exploitation by the governments of the Member States for the benefit of their micro-party objectives and to avoid illegal agreements with large companies to the detriment of citizens. For these reasons I am voting in favour of the report on the protection of the EU's financial interests - Combating fraud.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ There are a number of positive elements in this report that I can support, although these are overshadowed by references to the harmonisation of VAT and, in particular, the call for a swift adoption of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office regulation. As a result of these negative aspects I abstained in the vote.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Concerning the Annual Report 2014 on the protection of the EU’s financial interests, I believe that the methodology for calculating error rates must be harmonised at EU and Member State level and that the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) regulation should be adopted swiftly. Moreover, I would like to welcome the Commission’s commitment to publish an EU anti-corruption report biannually. I support the call on the Commission to swiftly promote legislation on the minimum level of protection for whistle-blowers in the EU, and I urge the Commission to maintain its strict policy on interruption and suspension of payments in accordance with the relevant legal basis. I believe that, through this report, the goal of expressing a clearer and fair picture of the main challenges in the protection of the financial interests in the EU was accomplished.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, bearing in mind that fraud and corruption are an obstacle to the EU's competitiveness in the world economy and put the well-being of all citizens at risk. The Commission should continue to work to recover funds unduly paid from the EU budget, as well as for the sake of better perception of own resources. Similarly, the Commission should support member States' actions in the fight against fraud and corruption.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the Committee on Budgetary Control for the important work of monitoring and analysis in the use of European funds: for 2014 alone, more than EUR 3 billion of irregularities have been established.  This trend is constantly increasing: the increase (36 percent) in such fraud compared to 2013, when the increase was 48 percent, is worrying.  I agree with the report in particular for its willingness to insist that the Commission take very tough measures (interruption and suspension of payments) in the event of irregularities.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the 2014 Annual Report on the Protection of the EU's Financial Interests - Combating Fraud. Of course, I welcome the EU's efforts to stop the misuse of EU funds – EUR 3.24 billion, almost 50% more than in the previous year. In principle, however, the report does not go far enough for me. The aim must be to reduce the abuse to zero.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The proper, economic and effective use of funds strengthens citizens' confidence in the Union. The fight against fraud and corruption is therefore very important. They also contribute to the Union's competitiveness in the global economy.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ This report admits that the overall financial impact of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported in 2014 is 36% greater than in 2013, while the number of such irregularities increased by 48%, and that 1 649 irregularities were fraudulent. It recognises that fraud in TOR is up by 196% from 2013 to 2014, and that just 24% of the money is recovered. Such honesty is commendable. However, it fundamentally fails to grasp that the causes of the problem are the systems themselves – particularly around the bureaucratic nature of VAT – and its proposed solutions involve more action by the Commission and further harmonisation. One-size-fits-all has been a proven failure; this report calls for more of it.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. I voted against Mr Javor's report on protecting the financial interests of the European Union. Firstly, because I believe that there are no financial interests of the European Union, there is only the financial interests of European states and taxpayers. Indeed, the budget of the Brussels monster is fuelled by a direct budgetary contribution from the Member States - the so-called GNI resource - a part of the VAT they collect and the ever-decreasing tariffs levied at Europe's borders. In the event of fraud, it is therefore directly the budgets of the States that are impacted and harmed. Secondly, because this notion of the EU's financial interests serves political purposes: to strengthen the powers of OLAF, the European anti-fraud office, the Commission's pseudopode, and to push for the creation of a European prosecutor's office. But OLAF's internal dysfunctions have worried this Parliament for years, cast doubt on its methods, and thus undermine its legitimacy. Its director general, Mr Kessler, is even in the crosshairs of the Belgian justice system for the murky role he allegedly played in the Dalli case. His diplomatic immunity would have even been lifted. Nothing to build trust!

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The greens report includes interesting elements in the control of european institutions' expenditure, such as the development of results-based budgets including multiple indicators (also based on environmental issues). Also the promotion of the European Prosecutor, EPPO, to fill the shortcomings of the current agencies. But the report also includes measures to require harmonisation of the calculation of irregularities or fraud, with the aim of making a ranking of countries according to the irregularity and fraud ratio they achieve. The solution he seems to propose is to demand the paralysis of payments from European programmes to the countries concerned without making distinctions between the beneficiary, civil service, business and government populations. It also sided with the Supervisory Committee of OLAF, under the Council, which has had uns professional and interested control behaviour. On this balance sheet we shuffle abstention if it withdraws the punishment from the countries or these sesamos considerations against OLAF. The vote was not barned in favour because they are also not the measures that we would have put forward, apart from mentions according to neoliberal elements of the model. To this end, separate votes were proposed. However, these points were not withdrawn and eventually voted against.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is very important if we think about the level of fraud and the effects of fraud for citizens. Fraud leads to corruption and corruption leads to the polarisation of society.  I appreciate the fact that the report also states that many of the mistakes found by OLAF are not fraud, and that is why I believe that prevention, simplification and transparency are needed in spending money.  I voted for the report although I do not believe that the establishment of new institutions solves the problem, just as I do not agree that citizens should be penalised for the mistakes of national institutions or legal persons by suspending or interrupting payments to European funds.  I appreciate that the report refers to the simplification of procedures, but the Commission must also check over-regulation at national level.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this very comprehensive report because I believe that it will lead to a strengthening of the legal framework, reinforcement of the fight against fraud, and better harmonisation of criminal law. It is very important that everyone be held accountable when important financial interests are at stake, so it is important that we use the best systems to check if there is any fraud taking place.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States and the Commission share responsibility for the implementation of around 80% of the Union budget and Member States are mainly responsible for the collection of own resources, inter alia, in the form of VAT and customs duties. The diversity of the legal and administrative systems of the Member States presents a complexity which sometimes hinders efforts to combat irregularities and fraud. Although with shortcomings, however, the report moves in the right context and proposes ways and tools to strengthen this effort, so we voted in favour of it.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Annual Report by the Commission on the Protection of the EU’s Financial Interests. One of the main conclusions of this year’s report stresses the urgent need of including VAT in the scope of an adopted PIF directive, and it asks the Council to explain its reasons for delaying the negotiations in view of the adoption of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office regulation (EPPO regulation) and calls for better harmonisation of criminal law when EU funds are at stake. I am glad to see that we recognise the proven effectiveness of OLAF’s investigations into the Commission’s Report where at the same time we criticise Member States’ failure to follow up on its recommendations. It is good to see that fraudulent irregularities dropped by 4% last year but this follows a sharp increase in the previous year. A new biannual EU Anti-Corruption report will also be produced by the Commission this year, with the first edition expected to be published in the coming months.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe this report demonstrates a good benchmark by which Member States can put in place policies of sound and transparent spending procedures in their budgets. The report also comprehensively addresses the issue of corruption, which is estimated to cost the EU economy around EUR 120 billion per year. Member States and the EU institutions need to step up their action to ensure that this figure is drastically reduced.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ This report admits that the overall financial impact of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported in 2014 is 36% greater than in 2013, while the number of such irregularities increased by 48%, and that 1 649 irregularities were fraudulent. It recognises that fraud in TOR is up by 196% from 2013 to 2014, and that just 24% of the money is recovered. Such honesty is commendable. However, it fundamentally fails to grasp that the causes of the problem are the systems themselves – particularly around the bureaucratic nature of VAT – and its proposed solutions involve more action by the Commission and further harmonisation. One-size-fits-all has been a proven failure; this report calls for more of it.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ The scale and complexity of the EU’s financial interests are such that fraud is inevitable – the number of UKIP MEPs to have faced criminal trials over the years is testament to that. This House must continue to take these matters seriously and I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ There are several points that should be highlighted. Fraud and errors are two different things; both must be fought and not confused. The methods for calculating error rates at the European and Member State level should be harmonised. Prevention is important and should involve constant training and support for staff responsible.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the 2014 Annual Report on protecting the EU's financial interests – the fight against fraud, as this is a topic that is also important in the area of protecting the EU's financial interests as an element of the fight against corruption and for creating and preserving citizens' trust in the EU institutions. EU money should be spent in a transparent manner in accordance with the rules. The total amount of all reported irregularities for 2014 was around €3.24 billion. A clear distinction should be made between irregularities that can be considered fraudulent and those resulting from errors.  In addition to procedures in the process of spending Union funds, it is good that fraud in the field of acquiring EU revenues such as VAT fraud, where particular attention should be paid and a more effective system to deal with cross-border fraud is also being addressed. When spending Union funds, an important part concerning the area of European funds, where unfortunately the number of fraudulent irregularities is impermissibly high. Transparency needs to be improved and the reporting system improved and data comparability improved. It is important to continue the process of creating national anti-fraud strategies. In addition to combating the consequences of fraud, prevention should be addressed.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report takes the pretext of fraud and irregularities found in the EU's accounts to induce more control over Member States.  Under the guise of anti-fraud, it proposes to create new superstructures, to strengthen the powers of the Commission or its substitutes: all additional steps to the dilution of the sovereignty of nations. It is alarmed by a decline in VAT revenues or tariffs (traditional own resources) while welcoming existing trade agreements and calling for a strengthening of the single market. I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – This report admits that the overall financial impact of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported in 2014 is 36% greater than in 2013, while the number of such irregularities increased by 48%, and that 1 649 irregularities were fraudulent. It recognises that fraud in TOR is up by 196% from 2013 to 2014, and that just 24% of the money is recovered. Such honesty is commendable. However, it fundamentally fails to grasp that the causes of the problem are the systems themselves – particularly around the bureaucratic nature of VAT – and its proposed solutions involve more action by the Commission and further harmonisation. One-size-fits-all has been a proven failure; this report calls for more of it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the 2014 annual report on the protection of the financial interests of the European Union, a subject which I have closely followed and has been appointed rapporteur for my political group in the Committee on Regional Development.  In 2014, the amount of fraud spent on EU funds was estimated at 538 million euros in the EU. It is unacceptable that European taxpayers' money is being diverted by fraud and corruption, while projects that bring growth and jobs need this money more than ever. The EU and Member States must ensure that every euro is spent better, by firmly combating irregularities in public procurement but also by adapting to new forms of fraud, particularly transnational ones.  I am also pleased that the necessary distinction between fraud and simple errors, which I had defended in the REGI opinion, is reflected in the final report. This distinction is indeed essential and the simplification of procedures in regional policy, defended by the EPP Group, will reduce the error rate by reducing confusion for project owners.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. Effective, transparent and rational management of European funds is a prerequisite for European citizens' confidence in their institutions. It is therefore particularly important to avoid waste and fraudulent activity and to strengthen cooperation between the Member States, the European Commission and the various European authorities or agencies responsible for these controls. This report particularly urges the European Commission to be very vigilant about fraud and also urges it to issue a bi-annual report on the fight against corruption. I was obviously in line with these proposals and I voted in favour of this report.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. In principle, the report is balanced and supports the position that the use of funds should be better monitored and used and that fraud should be better combated at EU level. An adjustment of definitions is very welcome, as is a restructuring of the OLAF Supervisory Committee. However, the improved fight against fraud must not be a back door to the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office. I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, which expresses a clear and fair picture of the main challenges in the protection of EU financial interests. I welcome the Commission’s commitment to publishing a regular EU anti-corruption report and reiterate our call for the promotion of legislation on the minimum level of protection for whistle-blowers in the EU.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Managing EU funds and protecting the EU's financial interests are key elements of EU policies. The legal and administrative systems of the EU Member States excel in their diversity, which also makes it difficult to eliminate irregularities and combat fraud. For these reasons, not only the Commission but also the Member States need to increase efficiency in the fight against fraud and corruption. The report proposes steps to obtain better monitoring and control of the management of public procurement, while stressing the importance of access to information and transparency. The importance of the Commission's role and its application of a strict policy of interruption and suspension of payments in specific cases of fraud is also mentioned. It is therefore appropriate to agree to the proposal and thus commit to a common solution to corruption and fraud that distort the EU's financial interests.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission and the Member States implement together almost all of the EU budget. They have then the duty to overcome corruption and irregularities. The report by the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) suggests how to avoid non-fraudulent irregularities. I voted in favour of this report, since I believe we should develop a system to measure corruption and to measure the effectiveness of the anti-corruption policies of the Member States.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. – In the Commission's report 'Protection of the European Union's financial interests - Fight against fraud - Annual Report 2014', it has been certified that the total number of reported irregularities amounts to approximately EUR 3.24 billion. I believe it is essential to take strong action to combat as many fraudulent practices as possible effectively. I supported Mr Javor's report because the fight against illicit trade and illicit financial flows must continue to be a top priority for the Eu ropean Union and the Member States. There is therefore a need for a greater level of cooperation between the countries of the euro area with regard to criminal investigations and the exchange of information between authorities. In addition, it is important to emphasise the support of agencies such as Europol, Eurojust and OLAF. I will conclude by pointing out that, within this context, third countries play a key role and, for this reason, the Commission must continue to include anti-fraud and anti-corruption provisions in all EU international agreements.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it takes the pretext of fraud in the EU accounts to strengthen the Commission's supervisory powers over the Member States. The amendments of the ENF group that were fighting this interference were rejected.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The report on the protection of the Financial Interests of the European Union was drawn up as part of the fight against fraud and corruption. It highlights irregularities and frauds reported in EU accounts, such as relations with lobbies and NGOs. Calling for greater transparency, he suggested the creation of new bodies, such as a European Public Prosecutor's Office with extensive judicial powers, to combat these abuses.  However, the report, under the guise of fine concepts such as ethics, equality and respect for European citizens, tends to restrict the sovereignty of The Member States and strengthen the powers of the Commission. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The report contains a number of proposals to improve the fight against fraud and corruption in EU budgets, so I voted in favour.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. In 2013, expenditure irregularities considered fraudulent increased by 76%. In 2014, this figure was only reduced by 4%. That is why we believe that we have made efforts that are paying off, but we still have a long way to go.   This report urges the Commission to develop a system of easily applicable uniform criteria on the basis of the requirements set out in the Stockholm Programme to measure the level of corruption in Member States in order to assess policies to be developed against corruption.   Another of the proposed measures is to simplify the rules, as many non-fraudulent irregularities are linked to insufficient knowledge of them. The rapporteur also calls on Member States to promote the exchange of good practices and welcomes the increasing detection of cases of fraudulent irregularities by community ex ante and ex post checks.  On the basis of the great importance of the subject we are dealing with, I believe that it is essential to adopt this report in order to achieve a more transparent and more homogeneous European Union.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The proposal calls on the Commission to develop a system for measuring corruption in the Member States. Let's leave this to Transparency International and similar organizations. Let the EU look for ways to prevent corruption in its institutions. I do not agree that the EU, as stated in the proposal, should pass legislation to protect whistleblowers.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Committee on Regional Development called for a database on irregularities in cohesion policy, as this is the only way to analyse the frequency and patterns of irregularities and identify quality prevention mechanisms. The Committee also calls for enhanced education and information on irregularities. I supported the 2014 annual report on the protection of the EU's financial interests, as it highlights the importance of working on data transparency, and that without analysis and education, there will be no major developments in combating irregularities and corruption.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 Protection of financial interests and effective fight against fraud are directly related to the trust of the population in the EU and its institutions. Corruption alone amounts to EUR 120 billion a year in the EU. The financial statement of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported to the Commission in 2014 increased by 36% compared to 2013.  Out of a total of 16 473 irregularities reported to the Commission in 2014, there were 1 649 frauds, corresponding to EUR 538.2 million. These figures are too high to talk about an effective fight against corruption. I consider it necessary to adopt simplified rules in the area of resource management. Complicated rules lead to misinterpretation and unnecessary inconsistencies and damages. All rules aimed at increasing transparency in the management of public finances must be clear, comprehensible and cannot be interpreted speculatively. Control should also be increased and streamlined, responsibilities should be consistently inferd and the public regularly informed of these findings and measures. This will also have a positive effect in the area of prevention.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the 2014 annual report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests – combating fraud, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/3/2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. Under the pretext that fraud and irregularities have been found in the Union's accounts, this report takes the opportunity to induce more control over the Member States. It uses anti-fraud as a reason to create new superstructures and to strengthen the Powers of the Commission. In addition, this report is concerned about the decline in VAT revenues or tariffs, while welcoming existing trade agreements and calling for a strengthening of the single market! In the end, this is just one more step towards the total dissolution of state sovereignty.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which calls on the relevant authorities in the Member States to perform better controls and to use all available information to avoid errors and irregular payments involving EU funds.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2014 Annual Report on the Protection of the EU's Financial Interests - Combating Fraud sees me in favour. It is very important to give citizens a guarantee that their money invested in taxes is spent in a way that is fair, transparent and consistent with needs. It is precisely for this reason that sound financial management is and must remain a priority, to be monitored periodically. Of course, the diversity of legal and administrative systems is an obstacle, but the problem of corruption, which affects all Member States and costs billions of euros a year, must be eliminated.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on the draft annual report for 2014 on the protection of the EU's financial interests, the fight against fraud. The report draws attention, for example, to tax evasion related to insufficient VAT collection, the problem of corruption and financial fraud. What is alarming is that all fraudulent and non-fraudulent financial irregularities reported to the Commission increased by 36% in 2014 compared to 2013 and their financial impact represented a 47% increase compared to 2013. In the report, we call on both the Member States and the Commission to fight financial fraud and corruption more vigorously, as well as to better exchange information. Although the emphasis on the role of the new European Public Prosecutor's Office bothers me in the text, I do not agree with the creation of this institution, which I consider to be redundant, but otherwise I am aware of the importance of the present report and the whole issue of combating financial fraud, which is why I supported the text in the final vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Fraud in the Eu ropean Union budget is a phenomenon that must not be tolerated. There are too many types of fraud and irregularities at different levels. It is worth investing in the fight against fraud because only in this way can we recover the money that would otherwise be lost. I supported this report because I agree that the EU must do more to recover our taxpayers' money.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The 2014 annual report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests – combating fraud reminds us that corruption affects all Member States and costs around EUR 120 billion per year to the EU economy. To combat fraud, it proposes measures such as improving information and controls, better regulating government procurement, budgeting on the basis of performance and profitability, or strengthening the fight against tobacco smuggling and counterfeiting of products, which I fully share and therefore vote in favour of the proposal.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 A key issue is the protection of the confidence of European citizens through a clean and efficient system of use of their money. As a condition, it is necessary to rationalise public expenditure which can be achieved through regular checks on the performance of national systems which, unfortunately, often present divergent practices, creating difficulties in identifying irregularities and abuses. Protecting the EU's financial interests is a direct objective, as is the fight against fraud, given that corruption exists in all Member States by hindering the smooth functioning of the system and reducing the EU's competitiveness in the global economy and market. The cultural implications and the violation of the principles of the rule of law, values that are the cornerstone of the EU, are equally remarkable.  The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) plays an important role in strengthening action to combat corruption and fraud. I am voting in favour of the findings and changes proposed in the annual report since I consider it an obligation on the Member States to protect the Union's financial interests from criminal offences which have economic and moral consequences. This requires the direct cooperation of the Member States with OLAF and the granting of further procedural rights to it to ensure the effective implementation of its recommendations.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the 2014 Annual Report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests. Fight against fraud'.  The resolution highlights the problems that lead to various cases of fraud and irregularities amounting to more than EUR 3 billion. damage to the EU budget in 2014. I support the measures proposed in the report to strengthen control over the use of EU funds, to apply more responsiblely the requirements of EU directives in the field of public procurement, and to better coordinate olaf, customs and market surveillance authorities in the fight against tobacco smuggling and the trade in counterfeit goods.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report to take measures to counter fraud that have a negative impact on the financial interests of the EU.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Member States and the Commission share responsibility for the implementation of around 80% of the EU budget and Member States are primarily responsible for the collection of own resources, particularly in the form of VAT and customs duties. But corruption affecting all Member States costs the EU economy around 120 billion euros a year. The reported irregularities relate to a total amount of around 3.24 billion euros for 2014, with an overall financial impact of 36% higher than in 2013. The report denounces this state of events. To remedy this, it highlights the problems of the Union's functioning that can lead to fraud and calls on the Commission to regulate lobbying activities much more strictly. The report also encourages the Commission to "develop a mechanism that would encourage companies to pay normal tax instead of tax evasion". Finally, it proposes the establishment of a whistleblower protection system and improved access to information and transparency. However, this report contains real progress and forgets that it is the free movement of capital promoted by the Union that contributes most widely to the development of fraud.  I am voting for this text, however.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. With loud noise and loud bang, a financial balance sheet lands in Parliament. Everyone was horrified in front of him, the pretext followed in his footsteps. The European governance, under the banners of anti-fraud, is ready to create new superstructures and to further arrogate itself from the sovereignty of the member nations that stand in its way. If bad faith is limited, it is not within the European cenacle. The report, welcoming trade agreements and calling for a strengthening of the single market, cannot simultaneously lament the declines in tariff revenues. As a result, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering, i.e. the protection of the Union's financial interests, should be placed as a priority on the Union's agenda. This is an obligation of the European Union to protect taxpayers' rights against criminal offences which cause significant damage to the Union budget. I would stress that the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office in coordination with national authorities is of fundamental importance for the protection of the Union's financial interests. I voted in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the European Union and its Member States must do their utmost to tackle fraud, corruption and practices that breach good governance rules and jeopardise our collective economic recovery. The report calls for better reporting, better controls and adherence to public procurement rules.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Protecting the EU's financial interests is a priority. The fight against fraud is above all an ethical issue aimed at strengthening the rule of law and ending situations of impunity. European taxpayers' money must be used to the best of the public interest. While more than 3 billion euros of EU funds are threatened by fraud, only 10% have been reported and prosecuted by the States concerned. It is up to the European Union to seek, prosecute and bring to justice those who commit offences that harm its financial interests.  That is why I strongly support the European Commission's proposal to create a European Public Prosecutor's Office. The first step is to establish a coherent system in this area.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – Protecting the EU's financial interests is one of the guiding principles for the functioning of the Union. The efficient, transparent and orderly management of European finances is an essential prerequisite for eu citizens' trust in the European institutions, as well as their share of the idea of European integration. At a time when all Member States must necessarily participate in the consolidation of national budgets in order to sustainability finances, it is particularly important to avoid any waste and fraudulent activities (illicit and unauthorised trafficking, smuggling, money laundering, corruption, opaque public procurement, etc.) with EU funds, and all necessary measures must be taken in this regard. The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF), EUROPOL, EUROJUST, customs and market surveillance authorities have a key role to play in this area, so better coordination of their activities must be ensured, as must strengthening Member States' cooperation with the Commission in preventing, detecting and combating fraud. A clear distinction must be made between fraud and non-fraudulent irregularities in the management of European finances, so it is essential to harmonise the definition of irregularities at Member State level, as well as to harmonise the processes for detecting and reporting them. I therefore fully agree with the motion for a resolution on the annual report in this form.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because this new legislation will improve the quality of indices of consumer prices which are important to correct macroeconomic imbalances in the EU.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission presented its report entitled 'Protecting the European Union's financial interests — combating fraud — Annual Report 2014". In its report, the Committee on Budgetary Control recommends that Parliament take note of the report. On this basis, it should state that the total value of irregularities reported in 2014 amounted to around EUR 3.24 billion, which was 36% higher than in 2013, while the number of irregularities increased by 48%. It also recommends that around 10% of the irregularities reported were fraudulent, amounting to EUR 538.2 million, while the total financial impact of non-fraudulent irregularities was 47% greater than in 2013, but their number decreased by 5%.  It urges the Commission to take full responsibility for the recovery of funds unduly paid out of the EU budget. It proposes that Parliament point out that non-fraudulent irregularities are often linked to a lack of knowledge of complex rules and requirements and that simplification of rules and procedures by Member States and the Commission could reduce the number of such irregularities. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This report takes the pretext of combating fraud and irregularities found in the EU's accounts in order to impose more controls on Member States. Under the guise of anti-fraud, it proposes to create new superstructures, to strengthen the powers of the Commission or its substitutes: all additional steps to the dilution of the sovereignty of nations. So he calls for a vote against.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The protection of the financial interests of the European Union, as well as the effectiveness of public expenditure, should be key elements of EU policy, so that citizens' confidence is increasing, ensuring that their money is used correctly, efficiently and effectively.  The multiplicity of the legal systems of each Member State makes it difficult to combat fraud and the EU should make efforts to step up the fight against fraud, so that it is effective and with tangible and satisfactory results. I endorse the rapporteur's position on the Commission to address the problem of divergence of approaches by Member States with regard to irregularities and heterogeneous interpretations in the implementation of the EU legal framework. I believe it is essential that we develop a mechanism for exchanging information between the competent authorities in order to allow cross-check of accounting records between Member States with the aim of preventing transnational fraud.  I share the rapporteur's concern about the increase in smuggling, trafficking and other forms of illicit and illegal trade, which not only have an impact on member states' collection of customs duties but also on the EU budget.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report refers to fraud and irregularities in the EU's accounts to impose more control on Member States. Under the guise of anti-fraud, it proposes to create new superstructures, to strengthen the powers of the Commission or its substitutes: all additional steps to the dilution of the sovereignty of the nations. That is why I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which expresses a clear and fair picture of the main challenges in the protection of EU financial interests. I welcome the Commission’s commitment to publishing a regular EU anti-corruption report and reiterate our call for the promotion of legislation on the minimum level of protection for whistle-blowers in the EU.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which strengthens measures to combat tax evasion in all EU states. In particular, I supported the provisions which called for greater parliamentary control and transparency for the tobacco agreements between the European Commission and the tobacco industries, to which I am opposed. The Commission will need to quickly publish an assessment of these agreements and an analysis of their impact on the implementation of the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I was not able, for medical reasons, to attend the plenary session from 7 to 10 March 2016. Nevertheless, I would like to express my support for the annual report on the protection of the EU's financial interests, calling in particular on Member States to give the fight against fraud that is detrimental to European financial interests as much as to the fight against fraud affecting their own financial interests. In addition, the report rightly argues the need for more governance and transparency in the ECB's activities.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Fraud, corruption and other irregularities have serious consequences for the European Union. These include facilitating the financing of organised crime and terrorist networks and a financial loss of around EUR 3.24 billion per year. The situation is deteriorating year on year, so I consider it particularly important to report on the 2014 report on the financial protection of the European Union – the fight against fraud, which was adopted today by a large majority in Parliament. We have been talking for years about the creation of a joint European Public Prosecutor's Office, and I believe that it is high time that concrete steps were taken. I also consider it essential to improve the exchange of information between Member States, and for this we need common definitions and rules on key issues such as the reporting of corruption or the protection of whistleblowers.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) has the responsibility of protecting the European Union’s financial interests by investigating fraud, corruption and any other illegal activities. I voted for this Annual Report that emphasises OLAF’s role and presents the areas that need improving.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report, which I have also supervised as rapporteur in the shadows, as I believe that the issue of fraud and corruption affects all the Member States of the European Union, not only Romania. It is clear that, by combating fraud and ensuring a transparent environment, it is ensured that organised crime activities are reduced and citizens' confidence in public institutions are increased and that the EU's financial interests are protected, at the same time, by increasing its competitiveness on the world market. In this respect, as the document suggests, the European Commission, together with OLAF and the Member States, must improve customs controls, as well as of public institutions empowered to obtain and spend European funds in the Member States. Furthermore, the development of the budget on the basis of performance and not the formalistic evaluation of the programmes will allow and create a framework conducive to the economic development of each Member State.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report, which maps the situation very comprehensively and clearly on both the revenue and expenditure ad than the European budget. In this context, it can be stressed that the Czech Republic has participated in cooperation with law enforcement and judicial authorities from Germany, Poland, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Belgium, Spain and Switzerland to defuse criminal networks responsible for tax revenue fraud worth around EUR 320 million, and it would be good if we followed up on this cooperation with other activities, including those at EU level. I agree with the need to improve controls and to improve practice in the area of public procurement, where there are a large number of irregularities and frauds.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: in writing. \u2012 The report states that approximately 10% of irregularities at EU level are identified as fraud worth EUR 538 million. In the same year, 193 eu payments related to cohesion and agricultural policy amounted to more than EUR 7.7 billion were suspended. European. The report summarises that for 2014 the financial statement of irregularities in the EU increased compared to the previous year. The report in the European Parliament on the protection of financial interests is based on the Commission's Annual Report 2014. This is the first annual report on the subject of the Ec, which is prepared with the assistance of the Member States. It presents a detailed analysis and recommendations to achieve concrete results in the fight against financial fraud in the EU. I support the proposed resolution.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report calls for a stronger fight against fraud at all levels of the EU and for stricter controls on the use of funds. All in all, a very critical report, which I support and which I voted in favour of.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The relevant Commission report is essential to ensure the transparent functioning of the EU and to prevent cases of corruption in the Member States.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. U2012 Corruption costs us $120 billion a year and is related to the financing of organized crime. This initiative report shows data on irregularities reported to the European Commission highlighting the need for urgent and effective measures to help us in the fight against fraud. Hence the importance of supporting this text. These measures call on the Council to give new impetus to the negotiations on the PIF Directive in order to strengthen the existing legal framework by establishing common minimum standards for the definition of offences affecting the Union's financial interests. The Commission is also urged to harmonise and simplify the framework for notifications of suspected fraud and to develop a system of rigorous indicators and uniform criteria, among other measures.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report submitted.
