In order to improve the protection of the Union's financial interests, decisive action is necessary to establish a common and proportionate level of protection by means of dissuasive measures and to prevent irregularities and fraud. The EU must strictly respect the principles of sound financial management: transparency and responsibility. A better mechanism for reporting and controlling infringements must also be applied.  The EU must have a comprehensive and coherent enforcement framework. In addition, greater attention must be paid to ensuring full transparency in the financing of major infrastructure projects.  I believe that the Commission should establish a system of strict indicators and easily adaptable uniform criteria based on the requirements set out in the Stockholm Programme and establish a corruption index. It should be noted that the protection of the EU's financial interests and the fight against fraud crosses Europe's borders, and international cooperation must therefore continue to develop.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ This report admits that the overall financial impact of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported in 2014 is 36% greater than in 2013, while the number of such irregularities increased by 48%, and that 1 649 irregularities were fraudulent. It recognises that fraud in TOR is up by 196% from 2013 to 2014, and that just 24% of the money is recovered. Such honesty is commendable. However, it fundamentally fails to grasp that the causes of the problem are the systems themselves – particularly around the bureaucratic nature of VAT – and its proposed solutions involve more action by the Commission and further harmonisation. One-size-fits-all has been a proven failure; this report calls for more of it.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to ensure that EU funds are protected from the risk of fraud, through a series of measures the Commission and the Member States have increased their effectiveness in combating the overall rate of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularity. Of course, EU funds must be managed properly and used as efficiently as possible. In view of the success of the results obtained, I am voting in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Fighting fraud and corruption by all means is a key element of the EU policy agenda to strengthen and increase the confidence of citizens and ensure that their money is used properly. The overall financial impact, based on the reported irregularities, on the EU budget was 36% greater than in 2013. That is why I welcome the report by the Committee on Budgetary Control and especially the importance of enhanced cooperation among EU institutions to tackle fraudulent behaviour in the use of EU funds.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. I support the report because, in my opinion, the topic of the European Investment Bank, which seeks to adapt its policy to EU policies, is well covered. I support the efforts enshrined in the report with regard to the increasing power and role of the EIB, but at the same time also necessarily its transparent functioning, which leads to even greater accountability towards the European Parliament. Transparency and accountability to parliament is essential, as the development of the bank will also increase the complexity of its operation.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The amount of all reported irregularities in 2014 of around €3.24 billion is very high. Comparing 2014 with 2013, the trend of the increase in the number of reported irregularities, the increase in the overall financial impact of reported irregularities and the increase in the amount of traditional own resources related to fraud is worrying. I call on the Commission to urgently take measures that will lead to the elimination of irregularities, both those considered and those not considered fraudulent. I welcome the proposals in the report, which require better reporting, better controls, more transparent public procurement, results-based budgeting and preventing tobacco smuggling and illicit trade in counterfeit goods.  Corruption is a major problem, especially in newer Member States. Due to its significant impact on the Union economy, we need to make further efforts to prevent it in all Member States. Situations where whistleblowers are punished for their selfless contribution to society and pointing out criminal acts are also common. We need to change this because only through legislatively regulated whistleblower protection can we influence the reduction of corruption levels.  I support this report because it indicates the need to apply measures to address irregularities and protect the EU's financial interests, and asks the Commission for a swift response.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report takes the pretext of fraud and irregularities in the EU's accounts to induce more control over the Member States. Under the guise of anti-fraud, it proposes to create new superstructures, to strengthen the powers of the Commission or its substitutes: all additional steps to the dilution of the sovereignty of nations. It is alarmed by a decline in VAT revenues or tariffs (traditional own resources) while welcoming existing trade agreements and calling for a strengthening of the single market.  As these positions are contrary to those which I defend and which I am elected to defend, I obviously vote against this text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that as Members of the European Parliament, and therefore representatives of the citizens of the Union, it is essential to commit ourselves to transparency and financial regularity. In the situation in which we find ourselves today, with stagnant economic growth and with populist and demagogic movements blowing on the fire of anti-Europeanism, we must be able to convey the image of a responsible Europe, working for the well-being of its citizens and not wasting a single euro of the resources it has at its disposal. This report by Parliament, for the year 2014, provides a precise picture of the situation and the main issues to be addressed and resolved with regard to the protection of financial interests in the European Union. The growing number of financial irregularities detected indicates that important progress is being made on the investigative front (and let me remind you of the good work done in Italy by the COLAF in this regard). However, the legislative and judicial framework is still very fragmented. Only state authorities can investigate and prosecute fraud and other financial crimes that harm the interests of the Union. And the rules that these authorities follow vary widely from state to state. The Commission should therefore commit itself to harmonising the methodology for calculating error rates and to establishing the European Public Prosecutor's Office as quickly as possible.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The 2014 Annual Report on the Protection of eu financial interests and the fight against fraud paints a clear and objective picture of the main challenges of protecting financial interests. The reported irregularities in the report amount to around EUR 3.24 billion. I am concerned that the overall financial impact of false and non-false reported irregularities in 2014 increased by 36% compared to 2013, with the number of irregularities increasing by 48% in 2014. On the other hand, I welcome the reduction of irregularities by 5% in 2014 under cohesion policy, compared to 2013. I also welcome the Commission's commitment to publish the report twice a year, as it is essential to promote transparency and harmonisation.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the 2014 Annual Report on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Union. I did so because it is necessary to combat corruption, which costs Europeans up to EUR 120 billion a year. In 2014, irregularities of fraudulent and non-fraudulent origin increased by up to 42% within the European budget. We must not tolerate these irregularities, which amount to up to EUR 3.24 billion. I therefore voted in favour of a provision encouraging the Commission to take a more active stance in regaining funds unduly paid out of the European budget. Fraudulent irregularities are most common in agricultural policy, rural development and fisheries. It is therefore appropriate to establish a transparent control mechanism in these areas and to guarantee the protection of whistle-blowers. Furthermore, given that 80 % of the budget is under shared management, the European Commission should develop a system for exchanging information between the relevant authorities of the Member States. I also voted in favour of strengthening the role of the European Commission in carrying out audits and inspections and the obligation on Member States to step up their efforts to detect errors before the European Commission is wrongly asked to reimburse costs. Citizens themselves are actors who can largely help detect unfair activities and irregularities. In the end, I also supported the creation of an electronic counter, which could easily and quickly draw attention to fraud.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 325 of the Treaty of Lisbon requires the Commission to submit an annual report on the protection of the Union's financial interests, indicateing of measures taken to combat fraud in connection with the use of EU funds. According to the 2014 Annual Report, Member States will need to step up their efforts to prevent, detect and report fraud affecting EU funds and make greater efforts at national level in the fight against fraud. The Annual Report on the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests therefore recommends that Member States review their controls to ensure that they are targeted and based on risk analysis. Another positive aspect, highlighted in the report, is the emphasis on the satisfactory progress made at national level in implementing new rules and policies aimed at strengthening the fight against fraud, and on the successes achieved by OLAF's investigative activities. Finally, I would like to stress the importance of promoting a proper administrative culture that prevents the dispersion of important public resources, all of which should be spent on the benefit of European citizens. For this reason, I voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report supports the implementation of anti-fraud strategies by all Commission services and recommends that EU agencies, executive agencies and joint ventures do the same. It also asks the Commission to include a chapter on results in the report on combating corruption in the EU, to be published shortly. The EC has been called upon to take full responsibility for recovering funds unduly paid from the EU budget and to maintain a strict policy of withholding and suspending payments.  The rapporteur points out that Member States must take the same measures to combat fraud affecting the Financial Interests of the European Union as they do to combat fraud affecting their own financial interests. Nevertheless, the report supports the Regulation on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and calls for the adoption of a directive on the protection of financial interests covering VAT-related matters. I have hereby abstained.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I am in favour of the 2014 annual report on the protection of the EU's financial interests and the fight against fraud, in particular because it calls on Member States to take measures identical to those taken at the national level to combat fraud that harms the UNION's financial interests.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ This report admits that the overall financial impact of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported in 2014 is 36% greater than in 2013, while the number of such irregularities increased by 48%, and that 1 649 irregularities were fraudulent. It recognises that fraud in TOR is up by 196% from 2013 to 2014, and that just 24% of the money is recovered. Such honesty is commendable. However, it fundamentally fails to grasp that the causes of the problem are the systems themselves – particularly around the bureaucratic nature of VAT – and its proposed solutions involve more action by the Commission and further harmonisation. One-size-fits-all has been a proven failure; this report calls for more of it.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. I welcome the presentation of this report, the main basis for making the Commission clarify the main reasons why Member States are not monitoring cases of alleged fraud by EU financial stakeholders, as presented to them by the European Anti-Fraud Office. This report found that the irregularities reported involve a total amount of around EUR 3.24 billion, considering that the simplification of rules and procedures by the Member States and the Commission will reduce the number of such irregularities. It therefore calls for the awareness of all institutional bodies at European, national, regional and local level, as well as of the general public. There is still concern about the improvements in the communication, saying that, despite Parliament's numerous calls for the establishment of uniform principles of communication in all Member States, the situation remains very unsatisfactory.  It also considers that this problem creates a distorted picture of reality in relation to the level of infringements and the protection of the EU's financial interests and therefore calls on the Commission to make firm efforts to address the problem of divergence of approaches by Member States.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The total irregularities reported in 2014 involve €3.4 billion. The impact of these irregularities increased by 36% compared to 2013. The number of irregularities increased by 48 %. In 2014, it was the rural development sector that reported the most irregularities. It is a priority to reverse this trend. A two-year anti-corruption report by the European Union, the protection of whistleblowers, the interruption or suspension of payments on a relevant legal basis and the harmonisation of the methodology for calculating error rates, among other measures, are proposed.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. Investing European taxpayers' money well is one of our priorities. That is why we must properly protect the EU's financial interests by fighting with every possible means against fraud and irregularities that occur. In the light of the data from this report, we must remain vigilant and redouble our efforts in this area, as the total sum of EU funds that have been splattered with some irregularity amounts to EUR 3 240 million. The report stresses that procedures by States and the Commission should be simplified and citizens should be better available to alleviate non-fraudulent irregularities.  In addition, the Commission undertakes to submit a biannual report on anti-corruption and to the establishment of a strict policy on suspension and interruption of payments if the interests of the Union are at risk. For all this, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Considering that corruption affects all Member States and costs the European economy around EUR 120 billion a year, I supported this text which calls on the Commission and the Member States to develop, at their respective levels, interconnected databases on irregularities in the field of cohesion policy, including those a result of procurement. The adopted text also calls on all Member States to hold national public statements accountable for the use of EU funds and for the EU executive and Member States to take firm action against fraudulent irregularities. Finally, the text calls on the competent authorities of the Member States to carry out better checks and to use all available information to avoid errors and irregular payments linked to European funds.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support the report by my colleague, Mr Benedek, 2012 2012 , "Protecting the European Union's financial interests. Fight against fraud'. The fight against fraud and the waste of EU support funds must be a critical task for all EU institutions and Member States.  It rightly emphasises that the current definition of fraud unnecessarily covers cases of insufficient knowledge of complex rules and requirements. I agree with the statement that simplifying the rules between The Member States and the EU would also reduce the number of what is now sometimes completely unjustifiably attributed to infringements.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. The proper management of EU expenditure and public revenue is essential to citizens' confidence. The protection of the EU's financial interests must therefore be at the heart of its political objectives. The report by Benedek J-vor highlights the central role of Member States and the Commission in the collection and implementation of the EU budget and proposes solutions to combat fraud.  Parliament calls for improved declarations to harmonize still too different approaches between Member States, the design of reliable indicators of the level of corruption and the adoption of legislation protecting whistleblowers. It also wants control procedures to be strengthened with firm measures against fraud. MEPs want the regulation on the European public prosecutor's office to be adopted quickly and therefore ask the Council to explain itself on the blocking of this dossier. Finally, the report calls for better supervision of public procurement, in particular by calling on Member States to rapidly transpose the 2014/24 Public Procurement Directive.  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Investment Programme of the European Investment Bank (EIB), which supports the EU's policy objectives.  The text stresses the importance of strengthening the governance, transparency and supervisory framework of the European Investment Bank and also calls for greater parliamentary oversight.  The fight against fraud must remain a priority for the European Union and, for this, closer work with Member States to collect more accurate data is needed. It is also important that Member States take the same measures to combat fraud that harms the Union's financial interests as they do to combat fraud that harms their own financial interests. In this sense, the EU and the Member States must follow the recommendations made by OLAF.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The greens report includes interesting elements in the control of european institutions' expenditure, such as the development of results-based budgets including multiple indicators (also based on environmental issues). Also the promotion of the European Prosecutor, EPPO, to fill the shortcomings of the current agencies. But the report also includes measures to require harmonisation of the calculation of irregularities or fraud, with the aim of making a ranking of countries according to the irregularity and fraud ratio they achieve. The solution he seems to propose is to demand the paralysis of payments from European programmes to the countries concerned without making distinctions between the beneficiary, civil service, business and government populations. It also sided with the Supervisory Committee of OLAF, under the Council, which has had uns professional and interested control behaviour. On this balance sheet we shuffle abstention if it withdraws the punishment from the countries or these sesamos considerations against OLAF. The vote was not barned in favour because they are also not the measures that we would have put forward, apart from mentions according to neoliberal elements of the model. To this end, separate votes were proposed. However, these points were not withdrawn and eventually voted against.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 2014 Annual Report on the Protection of the EU's Financial Interests – Anti-Fraud, because it is important that Member States take the same measures to combat fraud that is directed against the Union's financial interests, which they also take to combat fraud that is directed against their own financial interests. These include the detection and reporting of irregularities, results-oriented financial management, optimal use of funds and tobacco smuggling. I continue to support the European Investment Bank's investment programme, which significantly promotes the EU's policy objectives, and the call for full parliamentary control in improving the governance, transparency and control framework.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The report contains a number of proposals to improve the fight against fraud and corruption in EU budgets, so I voted in favour.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ There is a clear and fair picture of the principle challenges on the protection of EU financial interests in this report. Hence, I welcome the Commission’s commitment to publishing regular reports on corruption in the EU, ‘EU Anti-Corruption Reports’ and furthermore I reiterate, along with my EPLP and Socialist colleagues, a call for the promotion of legislation which presents protection for whistle-blowers.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ Proper public spending and the protection of the EU's financial interests should be key elements of EU policies aimed at strengthening citizens' trust by ensuring the proper, efficient and efficient use of their money; Whereas sound financial management should be combined with the so-called 'maximum utilisation rate' approach of each euro; I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ The financial interests of the European Union must be preserved for the benefit of all citizens. The number of reported financial irregularities in the form of fraud has been worryingly high in recent years, most notably in the area of EU funds. I supported the implementation of this Report, as it opens up new ways to improve reporting and control in member states, amend and complement rules for EU staff, and focuses on the importance of lobbying transparency. The great success of this Report is to call on the Commission to create a corruption index to increase control over countries where the risk of corruption is high and to submit an EU anti-corruption report twice a year. Success has also been achieved in facilitating cooperation between the European Anti-Fraud Office and its supervisory board, which has so far been limited. The report represents a major step forward in the fight against fraud and corruption in the Member States of the Union and highlights the necessity of adopting additional regulations and directives that should reduce fraud and ensure smooth economic growth and development. Member States of the Union depend on a fair distribution of EU funds as well as their successful implementation, and this report ensures continued good practice.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ Despite the fact that the Commission and the Member States are coming up with new anti-corruption instruments, the Commission's report states that corruption costs the EU up to EUR 120 billion a year in all Member States. The fight against fraud is one of the biggest challenges for the EU, both to increase its competitiveness and, above all, to increase citizens' trust. I supported the resolution on the Commission's annual report on the Union's financial interests in 2014, as it contains warnings that have long been overlooked by the competent authorities.  As this report is also the first report evaluating the use of Structural Funds for the period 2014-2020, we are receiving information on trends that should be a warning to all links in the chain. It is worrying to note that the rural development sector was responsible for the largest number of fraudulent irregularities reported, as the report suggests. Cohesion policy, and therefore regional development instruments, are thus under obvious pressure. However, it should not be forgotten that cohesion policy is more concerned with irregularities caused by administrative claims than as if they were intentional fraud. Local and regional authorities should therefore put more pressure on increasing their administrative capacity and continuously training staff. At the same time, the Commission needs to continue its corrective actions and suspend payments in fraudulent proceedings, as it has already done for 193 payments.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the Commission's report entitled 'Protecting the European Union's financial interests — combating fraud — annual report 2014'. Two areas at risk are highlighted, tobacco smuggling and public procurement. Illicit tobacco trafficking is a global problem that is why EU Member States lose large sums of public revenue annually. Estimates suggest they lose up to €37 billion. In this way, the welfare of European taxpayers is being damaged and the functioning of the internal market is also adversely affected, as there is a distortion of competition and a deterioration in the conditions for SMEs. The second problem is the area of public procurement. I am aware that there are many errors and irregularities in this area. However, we could get calculations of the effects of these irregularities on the European budget and also how to act as a result. We'd need a General Prosecutor. Reporting and control should be improved and cooperation between the institutions should be increased as regards the necessary anti-fraud measures. For this very part, I voted in plenary and voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2014 annual report on the protection of the EU's financial interests and the fight against fraud. According to the report, the irregularities detected in 2014 amount to a value of 3.24 billion euros (+ 36% compared to 2013) with an increase of 48% in the number of irregularities themselves. At a time when there is a serious crisis of confidence of European citizens in the Union's institutions and their adherence to the project of European integration, it is necessary to act on all fronts in order to restore and maintain that confidence. On the financial front dealt with in this report, I believe it is essential to pursue the fight against fraud more strongly and to support the policy of protecting the Union's financial interests which the Commission is pursuing. In my opinion, while it is appropriate for the Commission to strengthen its monitoring and monitoring role by giving full assistance to the Member States, they must also commit themselves to implementing the recommendations in this area. It is essential that the Member States ensure that the resources deriving from the Union budget are used correctly for projects that actually contribute to growth and employment in Europe.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: In writing \ u2012 It is mainly the diversity of the legal and administrative systems of the Member States of the Union that creates the space for fraud to arise. Corruption remains a major problem affecting all Member States and costing the Union's economy almost EUR 120 billion a year. Not only does corruption threaten citizens' trust in institutions, but it makes it possible to facilitate the financing of organised crime and terrorism. I therefore support the adoption of a multiannual anti-fraud strategy.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. —Member States and the Commission have a shared responsibility for implementing around 80 % of the Union budget, and Member States are primarily responsible for raising their own resources, including in the form of VAT and customs duties. Sensible public spending and the protection of the EU's financial interests should be key elements of EU policy aimed at increasing citizens' trust by ensuring that their money is used properly, efficiently and effectively. Such good financial management should be implemented using an approach that entails the most effective spending of each euro.  The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) has a responsibility to protect the Financial Interests of the Union by investigating fraud, corruption and other illegal activities, and its supervisory board was set up to consolidate and guarantee OLAF's independence by regularly monitoring the implementation of its investigative role. I therefore welcome the commission's adopt of a multiannual anti-fraud strategy that will serve to correct significant discrepancies in the number of irregularities reported by each Member State, and I supported the report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which expresses a clear and fair picture of the main challenges in the protection of EU financial interests. I welcome the Commission’s commitment to publishing a regular EU anti-corruption report and reiterate our call for the promotion of legislation on the minimum level of protection for whistle-blowers in the EU.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the 2014 Annual Report on the Protection of the European Union's Financial Interests – The Fight against Fraud. The fight against fraud and corruption is important both in terms of ethical-moral principles and in terms of increasing the European Union's competitiveness in the global economy. By spending taxpayers' money transparently, in line with the objectives of the European Union and the interests of EU citizens, we make an important contribution to strengthening citizens' confidence in the EU institutions, which has been gradually declining in recent years. It is important to distinguish between fraud and irregularities. Not all irregularities are fraud. In order to combat irregularities more effectively and to implement regulations and requirements, we need transparent and simple rules, enhanced cooperation between Member States and the European Commission, timely transmission of accurate data and a unified approach by Member States to detect and report irregularities. We need strong political will to combat fraud, both at national and European Union level.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report calls for the creation of common indications of fraud, so that it can be defined and recognised in all Member States in the same way, at the same time as minimum protection for whistleblowers is promoted. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important to have and operate independent anti-fraud services and mechanisms in the European Union. The funds available to the EU in the Member States as well as in third countries should be subject to scrutiny as to their sound management, in order to reduce the phenomena of their exploitation by the governments of the Member States for the benefit of their micro-party objectives and to avoid illegal agreements with large companies to the detriment of citizens.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because I have treated the promotion of joint European action against financial fraud, tax evasion and other financial abuses as one of the central issues of my work as a Member. The report details the possible causes, organisational, professional and political problems that cause significant social losses in this field in the Member States and at European level. The particular importance of this issue is underlined to me by the fact that my own country is particularly affected, so that the system of financial abuse reaches the political-governmental sphere; for this reason, I specifically welcomed the fact that the report provides a separate analysis of the forms and causes of abuse and fraud in public procurement in the Member States. In my work as a Member, I will pay particular attention to how the experience and suggestions expressed here are applied in the practice of the Hungarian authorities and the European institutions, in particular OLAF.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Safeguarding the EU's financial interests, together with increasing citizens' trust by ensuring that their money is properly, efficiently and effectively used, is the cornerstone of Community action. One of the most important issues raised in the EP report on the protection of the Union's financial interests is the European Commission's call for a corruption index to assess Member States' policies. According to this index, countries with the highest risk of corruption will be subject to special controls on the spending of EU money. The document also draws attention to the adoption by Member States of a regulation on the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office to combat fraud more effectively and faster across Europe. Every year, up to 10-15% of EU funds are misused or illegally used at a loss for both the European Union and its citizens. In recent months, the Court of Auditors' report has also indicated that the Union is not sufficiently effective in controlling and combating cross-border fraud, particularly in the area of tax policy.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Combating European money fraud has become one of the European Union's priorities in recent years. In this way, the efforts of taxpayers in each Member State are protected and ensure that funds are reached in areas that really need them and not in the pockets of people who seek only easy enrichment of public money. The annual report of the Committee on Budgetary Control for 2014 highlights the total amount of EUR 3.24 billion affected by irregularities. Overall, the amount defrauded increased by 36% compared to 2013, while the number of irregularities increased by 48 %, thus significantly. The main sector affected is rural development, i.e. exactly where funding is most needed.  The European Parliament supports the Commission's initiative to publish a biannual report on the fight against corruption at EU level, as well as civil society activities in this regard, as well as the interruption of payments where deemed necessary. However, this last measure should not affect the actual development of those sectors. Furthermore, the EU's European supervisory bodies in this regard (OLAF) should not have immunity from control by national structures in order to avoid system flaws. I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. I would like to stress the importance of distinguishing between legitimate generic medicines and fraudulent counterfeit medicines in order not to interrupt the production or legitimate trade in generic medicines, and I again call on the Member States that have signed, but not ratified, the UN Protocol to eliminate the illicit trade in tobacco products to complete the ratification process as soon as possible.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Annual Report 2014 on the Protection of the EU’s Financial Interests as I find it unacceptable that our citizens’ money is wasted on fraud, corruption or even on irregular use of funds due to insufficient knowledge about the rules and requirements for their use. I believe it is key that we achieve sound public spending to ensure that every euro is used properly and to be able to use all available resources to stimulate growth and create jobs. Anti-fraud strategies such as simplification of regulations, transparency in lobbying, stricter inspection, better coordination between Member States, but also efforts to develop uniform reporting among Member States, are needed to achieve this goal.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 The correct, effective and efficient management of common financial resources is an absolute necessity and a clear duty for all institutions. We need coordination, effectiveness and equal measures throughout the Union. Member States must take the same measures to combat fraud affecting the EU's financial interests as they normally do to combat fraud affecting their national financial interests. There is a need for coordination of anti-fraud action between the EU and the different national authorities, and measures must be able to ensure equivalent protection in all Member States.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I emphasise the necessity of combating fraud and actions detrimental to national budgets, especially in times of economic recovery and fiscal consolidation. I would also like to point out that detecting and reporting irregularities remains not uniform between Member States and that the level of irregularities caused by non-compliance with public procurement rules remains high. But it's not just non-compliance with the rules and laws that are the problem. I believe that states must find a good trade-off between the necessity of generating revenues and the dangers that too high VAT rates pose as a kind of incentive to move into a grey economy. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. -u2012 Report on the 2014 Annual Report on the Protection of the European Union's Financial Interests – The fight against fraud, as I consider it extremely important that EU funding be managed in accordance with the rules and principles of sound financial management. It is important to be aware that the protection of the EU's financial interests is a central element of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU and that we, both in the EU and in individual Member States, are jointly responsible for protecting the Union's financial interests. I believe that such measures are an important step in greater protection of the Union's financial interests against crime, while increasing efficiency in the fight against financial irregularities and fraud. I believe that such action will preserve the confidence of European citizens in the European institutions.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The greens report includes interesting elements in the control of european institutions' expenditure, such as the development of results-based budgets including multiple indicators (also based on environmental issues). Also the promotion of the European Prosecutor, EPPO, to fill the shortcomings of the current agencies. But the report also includes measures to require harmonisation of the calculation of irregularities or fraud, with the aim of making a ranking of countries according to the irregularity and fraud ratio they achieve. The solution he seems to propose is to demand the paralysis of payments from European programmes to the countries concerned without making distinctions between the beneficiary, civil service, business and government populations. It also sided with the Supervisory Committee of OLAF, under the Council, which has had uns professional and interested control behaviour. On this balance sheet we shuffle abstention if it withdraws the punishment from the countries or these sesamos considerations against OLAF. The vote was not barned in favour because they are also not the measures that we would have put forward, apart from mentions according to neoliberal elements of the model. To this end, separate votes were proposed. However, these points were not withdrawn and eventually voted against.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report. It is of great importance that taxpayers’ money is not lost due to fraudulent practices.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The report takes the pretext of fraud and irregularities in the accounts of the European Union to impose more control over the Member States.  Under the guise of anti-fraud, it proposes to create new superstructures and strengthen the powers of the Commission or its substitutes: all additional steps to the dilution of sovereignty. It is alarmed by a decline in VAT revenues or tariffs (traditional own resources), while welcoming existing trade agreements and calling for a strengthening of the single market. I voted against it.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's Financial Protection Report points out that the financial irregularities reported in 2014 have increased by 36% since 2013, and that corruption affects all Member States. Every year, the European Union's economy suffers costs of around EUR 120 billion caused by corruption. Moreover, corruption is a phenomenon with extremely negative effects, affecting the image of institutions and participating in the financing of organised crime or terrorist actions in Europe. In this respect, there is a need to further strengthen the role of the European Anti-Fraud Office, as well as other actions, such as establishing uniform principles for reporting fraudulent or non-fraudulent irregularities at Member State level, in order to have a real picture of the situation in the European Union, but also to be able to find solutions to these problems. I also believe that more transparency is needed in the management of European funds. I appreciate that the report for which I voted underlines the need to strengthen the role of the Commission by introducing control and monitoring activities, through action plans and warning letters, and by providing technical assistance to the Member States by the Commission.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The EP's own-initiative report summarises the most important results of the EU institutions' anti-fraud policy in 2014 and examines, reviews and complements the report prepared by the European Commission. One of the many – regrettable – Hungarian aspects of the document is that in 2014 the rural development sector accounted for the largest number of reported irregularities. Most of these occurred in Hungary, Poland, Italy and Romania. I voted in favour of Benedict Jávor's report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 Voted against even though there are positive elements for monitoring the way European institutions spend (results-based budgeting including multiple indicators being able to measure environmental impacts). Also the promotion of The European Prosecutor EPPO. However, the report aims to make a ranking of countries based on the irregularity and fraud ratio they achieve and proposes to demand the paralysis of payments from European programmes without making distinctions between the beneficiary population, civil servicer, business and government. It also sided with the Supervisory Committee of OLAF, under the Council, which has had uns professional control behaviour and guided to try to interfere with OLAF's independence in favour of particular cases. We shuffle abstention if it withdraws the punishment from countries or these sesained considerations against OLAF. The vote was not barned in favour because they are also not the measures that we would have put forward. To this end, separate votes were proposed. However, these points were not withdrawn and eventually voted against.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this file because it is a very ambitious report as the text calls for the establishment of a corruption index and it recalls strongly Parliament’s position regarding the PIF Directive and the EPPO regulation, which are two key elements in the protection of the EU’s financial interests.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the Commission's commitment to publish the EU anti-corruption report twice a year and look forward to receiving another report in early 2016.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Annual Report 2014 on the Protection of the EU’s financial interests – Fight against fraud, which targets prevention of financial fraud and strengthening of financial transparency. According to Article 325(5) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) the Commission is mandated to report each year on its work with Member States to combat fraud and ensure sound management of EU funds. In 2014, Member States reported 1 649 irregularities as fraudulent (both suspected and established fraud), involving EUR 538 million in EU funds. The report urges Member States to make greater efforts in fraud detection and combat, ensuring that their controls are risk-based and well-targeted. It equally acclaims the progress made at national level to implement new rules and policies aimed at strengthening the fight against fraud in the near future.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The report calls for strengthening the governance, transparency and control of the European Bank and Investments and recalls the European Commission's responsibility for the recovery of funds unduly paid for by the Community budget. In this context, the report also calls on the Commission to make full use of its executive powers in areas such as VAT fraud, to work closer with Member States in collecting accurate data and to maintain a strict policy on interruptions and suspension of payments. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in your favour.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2014 Annual Report on the Protection of the EU's Financial Interests sets out the measures taken by the Commission and the Member States in the fight against fraud and the results achieved. In 2014, the total number of irregularities amounted to approximately € 3.24 billion and out of a total of 16 473 irregularities, 1 649 were of a fraudulent nature, amounting to € 538.2 billion.  The report also points out that the level of irregularities in public procurement continues to be high, which is why the Commission is required to vigilant and apply the rules, giving priority to maximum transparency in order to prevent fraud. A number of amendments have also been adopted on behalf of the EFDD Group, in particular those in which I express concern at the lack of absolute transparency regarding the financing of major infrastructure works, so I call on the Commission to consider a proposal making it compulsory to publish all accounting and design documents relating to major projects, including documentation relating to subcontractors; and, above all, the one in which I call on the Commission to make public all the documentation relating to the project and its financing of the Lyon-Turin high-speed line. That is why I thought it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which expresses a clear and fair picture of the main challenges on the protection of EU financial interests. I welcome the Commission’s commitment to publishing a regular EU Anti-Corruption report and reiterate our call for the promotion of legislation on the minimum level of protection for whistle-blowers in the EU. It is absolutely vital that we maintain, and where possible improve, our rigour in full financial transparency.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'Fraud is rightly getting a lot of attention from public opinion and damages the reputation of the European Union. It is only logical that we should therefore do everything in our way to prevent irregular expenditure and illegal income. I believe that the Commission and the Member States must work more closely together in the fight against corruption. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this annual report.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This report provides an annual EU-wide anti-fraud assessment for 2014. VAT fraud, irregular CAP payments, abusive public procurement, smuggling and counterfeiting, etc. The cost of these irregularities and frauds is estimated at 120 billion euros per year, an increase of 36% compared to 2013. However, it is probably in its part relating to the problems of the functioning of the Union that can lead to fraud that this report is most interesting. In particular, it calls on the Commission to provide much stricter supervision of lobbying activities, such as those carried out by the tobacco industry, and to make the registration register of these lobbying activities, currently optional, compulsory for all EU institutions. In addition, amendments have been adopted to increase transparency in the financing of major infrastructure projects, including Lyon—Turin. I voted for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an own-initiative report on the protection of the 'financial interests of the Union', which also includes information on irregularities and cases of fraud transmitted by member states, which have been growing in percentage and upstream. The report regrets that Member States 'use different definitions for similar types of crime and that not all collect identical and detailed statistical data in accordance with common criteria, which makes it difficult to collect reliable and comparable statistics at EU level', and calls for uniformity in member states to assess irregularities and fraud, linking them to their sanctioning measures for innators. It calls for the Commission to play a more active role in monitoring control and supervisory systems in the Member States and to recover unduly unpaid funds for the EU budget. The report regrets that criminal law systems are only partially harmonised, citing the need for a regulation to establish the European Public Prosecutor's Office, creating one more institution and an extension of the EU's powers over national states.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. In principle, the report is very balanced and supports the position that funds should be better monitored and used and that fraud at EU level must be better combated. In this respect, I support this report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 Thank you President. I voted in favour of the Annual Report 2014 on the protection of the EU's financial interests. The objective of expressing a clear and fair picture of the main challenges for protecting the EU's financial interests from the risk of fraud has been achieved.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the 2014 Annual Report on the Protection of the EU's Financial Interests - Combating Fraud. The protection of the EU's financial interests must be a central element of the EU's strategy in order to increase citizens' confidence. It is therefore necessary to ensure that EU funds are used properly, economically and effectively. I strongly support combining the principle of sound financial management by 'optimal use of every euro'. Even after this report, however, much remains to be done for the EU on the road to better prevention of corruption. Ultimately, however, it must also be a question of significantly curtailing the EU's budget and reshaping the EU through fundamental reform.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it provides a clear overview of the main challenges in the protection of EU financial interests. I welcome the Commission’s commitment to publishing a regular EU anti-corruption report and reiterate our call for the promotion of legislation on the minimum level of protection for whistle-blowers in the EU. Transparency is of the utmost importance for citizens.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the own-initiative report on the 2014 annual report on the protection of the EU's financial interests – combating fraud, which also introduces suggestions from the Committee on International Trade (INTA). INTA's suggestions focus on anti-fraud measures that should be introduced into EU trade policy. INTA recalls that the fight against illicit trade and illicit financial flows should remain a top priority for both the EU and the Member States. Also, in the same text, INTA welcomes the key role played by the EU's macro-financial assistance programme in promoting reforms in the countries that are the EU's closest trading partners, one of its aims being to fight corruption and fraud in the beneficiary countries.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The text of the report focuses on the EU's political objectives through better governance, transparency and the implementation of effective control rules, and proposes to upgrade the role of the European Parliament in it.  The main points of the report are the detection and reporting of irregularities, and it examines individual issues relating to the budget, tobacco smuggling and the investigations of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF), the annual report of which it certainly takes into account . I voted in favour of this initiative.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The annual report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests in 2014, which we voted on today, is presented by the Commission in cooperation with the Member States and sets out the measures taken in the fight against fraud and the results achieved. In 2014, the total number of reported irregularities amounted to approximately €3.24 billion and the overall financial impact of fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported in 2014 was 36% greater than in 2013. It notes that fraud in traditional own resources is increasing and is concerned about the VAT gap and the estimated loss in its collection, which amounted to EUR 168 billion in 2013; All Member States are therefore required to participate in Eurofisc in all its areas of activity. As far as expenditure is concerned, there has been a steady increase in the number of reported fraudulent irregularities, which has quadrupled compared with the previous year: it is the rural development sector that has recorded the negative record of fraudulent irregularities, followed by cohesion policy and public procurement. In general, the report offers a good critical apparatus, which is why I thought it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. The report, which is presented annually by the Commission and the Member States, sets out the measures taken by the institutions themselves in the fight against fraud against the EU and shows what has been achieved. In 2014, the total number of reported irregularities amounted to around €3.24 billion, an increase of 48% on 2013. The report distinguishes between fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities. Out of a total of 16,473 irregularities reported to the Commission in 2014, 1,649 were fraudulent in nature. The sector with the highest number of fraudulent irregularities is rural development. Almost 71% of the irregularities notified in the field of natural resources (agriculture, rural development and fisheries) are attributable to Hungary, Italy, Poland and Romania. Non-fraudulent irregularities are often due to insufficient knowledge of complex rules and requirements, and the simplification of these rules and procedures is seen as the way to reduce these irregularities. With the resolution, which I voted in favour of, the EP, with the contribution of us in the M5S, responds to the Commission by calling for more effective action to be taken and put in place in the fight against fraud.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: Written. \u2012 The 2014 annual report on the protection of the EU's financial interests, voted on tuesday 8 March 2016 in the European Parliament, is misleading. At the heart of the report is the Commission's desire, supported by the European Parliament, to be able to decide for itself whether Member States are corrupt and, if so, to what extent. This is a task that has so far been excellently fulfilled by independent journalists. But independent investigations show time and time again that a number of Member States are extremely corrupt. And so the European Commission, itself previously expelled for corruption, wants to come up with new rules. That's like asking the mafia to rewrite the criminal law. The PVV has therefore voted against.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. The 2014 Annual Report on the Protection of the European Union's Financial Interests – The Fight against Fraud, which I supported, notes that the number of irregularities reported to the Commission in 2014 compared to 2013 is particularly critical. I believe that all necessary measures must be taken to prevent irregularities to the detriment of budgetary resources, which either result from ignorance of complex regulations and requirements or fraud. The report proposes, inter alia, the establishment of a system of strict indicators for measuring corruption in the Member States, a change in the rules to increase the protection of whistleblowers and greater transparency in lobbying.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – It hardly needs further explanation as to why I did not vote for this report if I read a typical small detail from it: 'since all internal and external EU policies should be designed in such a way as to benefit boys and girls, men and women, as well as all other persons with gender identities'. This is, of course, an approach to gender equality in the specific values of the European Union. I'd love to have someone explain that it's okay to have men and women and other gender identities. But how can we make decisions with special attention to people of unknown identities? Question one. Question two: when will hungarian nurses and other workers earning €300, vulnerable foreign currency creditors living in disenfranchisehood, finally be so curious?

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, Happy International Women’s Day to you and to all the other women here. It is good that we have had an opportunity to vote on so many reports today and debate women’s issues, and I think that it is important for us to address gender mainstreaming. But, given that it is 2016, it is, to my mind, high time that we dealt with this and put the issue to bed. The reason that this has not happened is that the Member States have been quite slow to implement many of our recommendations. When we look at the gender pay gap, the figures in the UK show that we still have something like a 9.4% pay gap and over the course of their working lives women are likely to earn GBP 300 000 less than their male counterparts. We need greater action if we are to make progress that enables women to fulfil their potential. I am particularly concerned at the lack of female representation in science and engineering and especially, as I have witnessed myself, in the ever-growing IT sector.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: I too would like to thank the rapporteur for handing us this report and for allowing us to vote on it on 8 March. March 8th has a long tradition, a tradition of women fighting for their rights. We know how far this fight comes from, at least from that of Olympe de Gouges. I think it is important that we have marked another step in this direction today.  I hope that, as the report calls for, we can also move towards full recognition of the rights of LGBTQI people, a recognition of the full rights that unfortunately is still a long way from being achieved in Italy.  It seems to me, however, that this report gives very clear and very determined indications in this direction too, and that is why I voted with conviction in favour of it.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr In fact, it is a very regrettable fact that, in principle, we had to draw up such a report, because, as much as we do not accept any text, a resolution here and so on, we are not really ideal, especially on the issue of gender equality. Gender equality is a very important aspect of political action and, if all the guidance is adopted in the functioning of the European Parliament, it can reasonably be hoped that it will be effective, and these changes will also be a good example for other national and local organisations and institutions to also implement in life all the principles that we are talking about here in this document. So I have to say that I voted in favour and am proud of it.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – I strongly reject the request that the Committee on Gender Equality be given powers to make it a kind of supercommittee superior to the other standing committees. I also believe that no one at all, including women working in this institution, needs the introduction of a new role as the so-called permanent rapporteur on gender mainstreaming. The text tabled by the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality is nothing more than a hijacking of parliamentaryism through the back door of bureaucracy. Moreover, the report reaffirmed the dangers of the word gender. I could not support the report.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – The deletion from the report on gender aspects of the European Parliament's family policy is an act of disregard for the rights of millions of families in Europe who want to devote themselves to raising children and millions of women in Europe who often, when they have to work, aspire to devote themselves to working from home and raising children. These women bring great value to the lives of their children, above all, their peoples and europe as a whole. It is a great pity that, once again, the European Parliament has referred with such disdain to the rights of the family, although of course Parliament has those it supports – support for the claims of the political homosexual movement, of course, in this report has not been lacking.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on a report on gender mainstreaming of Parliament's work. Like all workplaces, the European Parliament needs to work actively on gender equality. Women and men should be treated equally and given the same conditions in the internal work of Parliament. It is also important that the gender perspective is included when Parliament deals with various proposals. I voted on this basis in favour of the report. On the other hand, there are parts of the report i am critical of, it concerns proposals for excessive bureaucracy linked to this work, as well as various forms of internal quotas. I marked against these parts in separate votes.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender equality between men and women is recognised by the EU as a fundamental right, a common and founding value, as well as an indispensable condition for achieving Europe's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. Gender mainstreaming is generally defined as all the measures and policies adopted by the institutions to promote and ensure gender equality within the Member States in the various areas of European competence. Despite the importance of the issue, some committees are still delaying the implementation of the measures taken in this regard. For these reasons, I voted in favour, trusting in a future improvement in inter-institutional cooperation with a view to the early achievement of gender equality.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report called for 40% gender quotas, more gender programmes, changes to rules of procedure and gender budgeting internally within the EU Parliament. UKIP voted against the EU Parliament spending any more money on internal administration.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to integrate the gender perspective into the work of the European Parliament and in all aspects of EU intervention, as well as in the preparation, design, implementation, control and evaluation of policies, legal provisions and expenditure programming, in order to achieve equality between women and men.  I also believe that the achievement of this objective effectively contributes to the usual practice of each parliamentary committee appointing one of its members as responsible for gender mainly, the creation of a "gender mains integration network" that meets several times a year, and the High-Level Group on Gender Equality , which also meets on a regular basis. Both agencies are supported by the report, which also stresses the need to make 'amendments for gender mains integration', amendments which the FEMM Commission draws up to incorporate the gender perspective into the reports of other parliamentary committees.  The report also defends gender impact assessments and gender budgeting budgets.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report called for 40% gender quotas, more gender programmes, changes to rules of procedure and gender budgeting internally within the EU Parliament. UKIP voted against the EU Parliament spending any more money on internal administration.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes the integration of the gender perspective into all policies and, therefore, to continue to take steps forward in favour of gender equality, through specific measures to eliminate, prevent or remedy gender inequalities. The Resolution emphasizes the need for gender mainstreaming amendments, a gender assessment and a gender budget to integrate the gender perspective into all policies. It also stresses that greater cooperation between the committees is necessary. The report calls for a roadmap on gender equality, indicating how to increase female representation in middle and high command positions by up to 40% by 2020. It also urges the Commission to assess the gender perspective in the new policy or legislative proposals in order to ensure that the European Union supports women's rights.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. It is important that the concept of gender mainstreaming is incorporated into the working procedures and policy work of the European Parliament and its MEPs. More attention should be paid to the issues of gender equality in all parliament committees, not just the Women’s Rights and Employment Committees. MEPs should consider carefully how all policy measures can have impacts, both direct and indirect, impacts on women. Equality between women and men is recognised by the EU as a fundamental right – MEPs must take efforts to integrate gender aspects into their work in all committees.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as I believe in the importance of gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. To make this a reality, gender mainstreaming needs to be an ongoing and integrated process by integrating gender equality at all stages and in all policy areas.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. A resolution aimed at improving gender equality in the work of the European Parliament was voted in favour by a large majority. Gender mainstreaming is aimed at equality between men and women and the fight against discrimination. It has also been decided that Parliament will regularly adopt and implement a strategic plan for gender mainstreaming within Parliament, with the overall objective of promoting gender equality.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The FEMM Commission is never short of crazy ideas that would be laughable if they were unfortunately not the consequence of this deadly ideology of abolishing all borders: civilizational, cultural, religious, national, and now sexual. Simply put: this ideology leads to the indifferentiation of everything and everyone, in the name of of course the "right to difference". In this case, this report, for which the equality of women and men goes far beyond equality before the law or that of remuneration. The idea of the report is to give the FEMM committee a say in all other committees through a permanent rapporteur charged with ensuring compliance with the ideology of the kind of texts voted on. It must thus take into account "equal parts" (sic!) the benefits for women, men, LGTBIQ and "all other gender identities"! In short, a kind of LGBTIQ Commissioner, charged with looking after the interests of the community.  This report is totally delusional and testifies to the harmful nature of this institution, which is the European Parliament.  I therefore voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. I strongly believe in the principle of equality and that everyone should be treated equally irrespective of gender. I am opposed to gender quotas because I believe they are discriminatory and demeaning to women.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. This report, the result of a long work by my colleague Angelika Milnar, calls for the integration of gender in the preparation, design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of EU policies, with the aim of promoting gender equality. I voted in favour of this resolution, because the integration of gender equality policies is a principle enshrined in the treaties. The European institutions must be the best example of gender equality.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Angelika Mlinar’s report on gender mainstreaming. It is astounding that gender inequality still remains an issue in 2016. Gender mainstreaming is a tool to effectively address this problem and empower more women by fairly including them in decision making processes. Thus, we need to incorporate gender mainstreaming in the preparation, design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of policies at the European Parliament. Analysis shows that our system regarding gender equality is still fragmented and inefficient – I believe that European Parliament has the obligation to set a good example in this regard.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to integrate the gender perspective into the work of the European Parliament and in all aspects of EU intervention, as well as in the preparation, design, implementation, control and evaluation of policies, legal provisions and expenditure programming, in order to achieve equality between women and men.  I also believe that the achievement of this objective effectively contributes to the usual practice of each parliamentary committee appointing one of its members as responsible for gender mainly, the creation of a "gender mains integration network" that meets several times a year, and the High-Level Group on Gender Equality , which also meets on a regular basis. Both agencies are supported by the report, which also stresses the need to make 'amendments for gender mains integration', amendments which the FEMM Commission draws up to incorporate the gender perspective into the reports of other parliamentary committees.  The report also defends gender impact assessments and gender budgeting budgets.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. Gender mainstreaming means gender mainstreaming in the design, development, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of policies, regulatory measures and spending programmes in order to promote equality between women and men and to combat discrimination. In 2009, a network of MEPs responsible for gender mainstreaming in EP committees and an additional staff-level network were set up. Members of this network shall organise regular meetings and exchange information on documents of interest to members of the network, as well as share best practices. The European Parliament has gradually established a gender mainstreaming structure. The assessment of the work of each individual body is positive, but the overall picture is different. I support the proposals aimed at strengthening the current gender mainstreaming structure and making it more effective and effective, including by creating a strong interinstitutional network. It is also important to promote closer cooperation with national parliaments and to exchange views regularly in order to further develop best practices for progress in gender mainstreaming.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I have of course voted against this text, which stems from the crazy ideology of the genre. On the other hand, I supported the alternative motion for a resolution which reminds us that gender equality should be understood only as equality between men and women, and not as the official recognition of other types of 'genders'. It should be noted that this alternative text could only be tabled with the support of 12 Members of my group, Europe of Nations and Freedoms.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Article 2 of the Treaty on the European Union guarantees equality between women and men. Furthermore, following a resolution adopted in 2003 by the European Parliament, each parliamentary committee appoints one of its members to be responsible for the integration of the genre. However, this is a fight that must be constantly recalled. I have therefore, of course, supported this resolution, which stresses in particular the need for amendments on gender integration, on gender impact assessments and on its budgeting in order to integrate the gender dimension into all political sectors.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Mlinar report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. The EP's organisational structure currently includes various bodies dedicated to the development and implementation of gender mainstreaming at both political and working life levels. All these realities, however, lack coordination which is capable of establishing cooperation on the basis of specific mechanisms for monitoring and monitoring the results obtained. In this context, political parties must also play a role by committing themselves to promoting women in the recruitment, selection and nomination of candidates. The presence of many structural barriers remains, in different dimensions, a problem to be addressed in order to create a truly favourable environment for participation in decision-making positions at all levels. We need measures to reconcile work and private and family life, combined with positive action to ensure an increase in people of this under-represented gender in positions where women or men preponderance. Integration is not a political objective in itself but a fundamental means, which combined with other specific actions and policies, can guarantee the true achievement of gender equality.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution because it is essential to promote the main translating of the gender perspective into all of Parliament's policies, as well as the momentum and promotion of women in the decision-making spaces in which they are underrepresented. This report raises the need to implement a strategy for the development of gender mains mains, through tools such as "gender mains mains integration amendments", gender impact assessment reports and gender-sensitive budgets. To improve the integration of the gender perspective into all policies, the report proposes further developing gender mains tools and also calls on the Commission to make gender impact assessments in new legislative proposals to ensure that the EU is active in defending women's rights.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. This report deals with "gender ideology." I am sure that if we ask ten people to define this concept, we will not have a single common definition. In fact, there is no such thing, and that is the whole problem with this report.  What are we talking about? Equality between men and women? To erase the differences between these two categories? The introduction of quotas? The inclusion of specific rights for LGBT people? From the implementation of training policies for recalcitrant minds to the principle of equality? In fact, all these issues can be found in this catch-all report, which does not even have the merit of giving a clear vision of what should or should be done in terms of gender equality. We believe that this fight is essential and must be fought with courage and tenacity. Unfortunately, feminist and LGBT up-and-comers, whose ideologies destroy all our existing social, educational and family models, do not advance the cause of women, quite the contrary. Let's make no mistake about the fight. It is the one for equality between men and women that we want and not that of the enforced disappearance of the sexes.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to congratulate rapporteur and group colleague Angelika Mlinar on her excellent work in this report which I have supported. Gender mainly, gender mainly, has been welcomed at the international level as a strategy for achieving gender equality. And Parliament cannot be left behind in it. Equality between men and women is recognised by the Union as a fundamental right and a common value, as well as a necessary condition for achieving the objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The dimension of "gender" does not only imply sexual orientations that must only remain in the private sphere. A person's identity is not determined based on their sexual orientation. Defining a policy based on the sexual behaviour of individuals or promoting rights based on particular sexual behaviour is the basis of communitarianism, which I oppose. Gender equality should be understood only as equality between men and women, not as official recognition of other types of "gender".  I am voting against this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the content of this report, which I find contradictory in several passages and decidedly unbalanced, which is why I did not support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to integrate the gender perspective into the work of the European Parliament and in all aspects of EU intervention, as well as in the preparation, design, implementation, control and evaluation of policies, legal provisions and expenditure programming, in order to achieve equality between women and men.  I also believe that the achievement of this objective effectively contributes to the usual practice of each parliamentary committee appointing one of its members as responsible for gender mainly, the creation of a "gender mains integration network" that meets several times a year, and the High-Level Group on Gender Equality , which also meets on a regular basis. Both agencies are supported by the report, which also stresses the need to make 'amendments for gender mains integration', amendments which the FEMM Commission draws up to incorporate the gender perspective into the reports of other parliamentary committees.  The report also defends gender impact assessments and gender budgeting budgets.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which examines how the gender dimension is included in the work of the European Parliament. Gender mainstreaming has been adopted at international level as a strategy for the implementation of gender equality. In practice, gender mainstreaming means gender mainstreaming in the design, development, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of policies, regulatory measures and spending programmes in order to promote equality between women and men and to combat discrimination.
