Gender mainstreaming has a dual dimension: it requires both gender mainstreaming in different policies and addressing the issue of representation of women and men in a particular policy area. Both aspects of gender representation and gender-based content must be taken into account at all stages of policy-making. While the figures are important, it is also important to consider how the gender dimension relates to the content of policies in order to better understand how women and men can better reap the benefits they bring. Gender-based policies ensure that the needs of all citizens, women and men, are equally met. However, structural gender inequalities remain entrenched in our society. Even if the laws treat women and men equally, women still do not have equal opportunities to have resources and assets and to manage them. The current situation therefore shows that gender-based policy content is an essential part of an appropriate gender equality strategy.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report examines how gender equality applies in the work of the European Parliament. Equality between women and men is a fundamental right recognised by the EU, a common value of the EU and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. On the line of values represented by the People's Party, I consider it extremely important to promote equality between men and women and to combat discrimination, and for this reason I support the realistic measures proposed to prevent or remedy gender inequalities. It is very important for me to support policies aimed at better compatibility between work and family life. Unfortunately, the report also contains a number of demands which conflict with the principle of subsidiarity and therefore become unacceptable. I couldn't support them.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also supported the proposed report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament by my colleague Mlinar. On 8 March each year we celebrate International Women's Day, or as we say in Slovenia, Women's Day, which gives recognition to the struggle of women for their equality. Unfortunately, there are still no guarantee in many areas. I am aware that women must be respected every day and in all areas, both in social, professional and everyday life. In addition to professional or professional work and social and public engagement, many women also play an important role in motherhood and child-rearing. While the proposed report concerns the proper mainstreaming of gender equality in the work of the European Parliament, the proposals it advocates should be transposed to all areas of social life. Despite significant progress in the fight for equality in Europe, there are still significant gender differences in many areas, and efforts must be made, both at EU and national level, to reduce such anomalies.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. Thank you, Mrs. Miller, for this report. I believe that gender equality should be achieved through all EP committees, not just through the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM), and that is why I support the GMAs proposals.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the integration of the gender dimension into the work of Parliament. This dimension of gender is often centered on sexual orientations; however, a policy is not defined based on the sexual behaviour of individuals.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the integration of the gender dimension into the work of the European Parliament is an becoming objective that must be achieved as quickly as possible and that, although the situation has improved considerably, much still needs to be done in this regard.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Equality between women and men is recognised by the European Union as a fundamental right, a common EU value and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. At present, women's representation in the european Parliament's top positions is still low. The European Parliament must regularly adopt and implement a political plan for gender mainstreaming in Parliament's work, with the overall aim of promoting equality between men and women through the effective inclusion of the gender perspective in policies and activities, including decision-making structures and administration. A gender-sensitive Parliament can play an important role in correcting gender imbalances, facilitating equal participation for women and men and creating the conditions for the development of a policy framework for gender equality. Only through cooperation between the Committee on Women's Rights (FEMM) and the other committees can gender mainstreaming be ensured in the various policy areas.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This indigestible report puts the dimension of gender before, in all its proposals, focusing solely on the sexual orientations of individuals. The rapporteur the rapporteur thereby proposes to incorporate this gender dimension into the work of the European institutions and to put in place statistics on respect for gender equality. Worse, it even provides for the creation of a gender integration network in the European Parliament and the Commission with the appointment of a permanent rapporteur on the gender dimension.  It is absolutely outrageous to define a policy based on the sexual behaviour of individuals. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the Report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. I declare myself against favoring one gender over another. Qualification and not gender should be the deciding factor in an individual's profession. I also oppose the idea of establishing a permanent rapporteur on gender mainstreaming who examines the work of all committees. This would be an additional element that would contribute to the administrative burden, without having any effect. On the other hand, I support the preservation of the practice of the main gender changes, which have been shown to have beneficial effects. Gender equality should be guaranteed through equal opportunities. We could achieve our goal in achieving gender equality through other means, for example, by promoting education among both women and men, and by eradicating gender discrimination. I want to stress that I support gender equality, but I do not believe that this report is a step forward on this issue.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. Whereas gender mainstreaming must include the rights, perspectives and well-being of LGBTIQ people and people of any gender identity, the report calls for the establishment of the Permanent Rapporteur on gender mainstreaming.  This figure would work with the High Level Group to ensure that the gender mainstreaming objectives for both the Secretariat and Parliament's staff were achieved. The report calls on the Commission to carry out a systematic gender impact assessment of each new legislative or intervention proposal on the basis of its in-depth assessment of its impact on fundamental rights, including for LBGTIQ people.  It stresses that gender-neutral language is used in parliamentary work and calls for a procedure to be incorporated into the EP regulation leading to gender equality in each committee and delegation.  In short, meaningless proposals which I cannot but vote against.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to integrate the gender perspective into the work of the European Parliament and in all aspects of EU intervention, as well as in the preparation, design, implementation, control and evaluation of policies, legal provisions and expenditure programming, in order to achieve equality between women and men.  I also believe that the achievement of this objective effectively contributes to the usual practice of each parliamentary committee appointing one of its members as responsible for gender mainly, the creation of a "gender mains integration network" that meets several times a year, and the High-Level Group on Gender Equality , which also meets on a regular basis. Both agencies are supported by the report, which also stresses the need to make 'amendments for gender mains integration', amendments which the FEMM Commission draws up to incorporate the gender perspective into the reports of other parliamentary committees.  The report also defends gender impact assessments and gender budgeting budgets.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. As part of Women's Day on Tuesday 8 March 2016, the European Parliament wanted to send a strong message for gender equality by publishing a report on the integration of gender in the work of the European Parliament. This report provides an overview of the inclusion of the gender dimension in Parliament, but also in EU policies.  Equality between men and women must become a reality within the European Union and also outside the borders of the European Union. Our institution must set an example for the rest of the European Union. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to strengthen the Community strategy for a more balanced representation of women in political life and in particular in the work of the European Parliament. More than half of Europe's voters are electricians. However, women continue to be largely under-represented in the posts of responsibility in all the countries of the European Union. In the European Union, the average presence of women in national governments and parliaments is 25%. We therefore need more entrenched and incisive equal opportunities policies. With regard to the integration of the gender dimension into the work of the European Parliament, I believe that qualitative research is needed to determine the scope and impact of gender policies on the results of resolutions and legislative texts. In addition, the High Level Group on Gender Equality and Diversity, which is responsible for adopting an action plan to promote gender equality and diversity in Parliament, should present a roadmap on gender equality indicating how to bring women's representation in leadership positions to a higher and intermediate level to 40% by 2020.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was concerned with the efforts made by the European Parliament’s internal structures to integrate a gender perspective and gender representation into its work and policies. Gender mainstreaming is both important and necessary. On a separate but much related point, my party, Sinn Féin has proposed practical solutions for addressing the gender pay gap in Ireland. We have agreed with the National Women’s Council of Ireland that if we wish to bridge the divide between men and women’s pay we need to increase the incomes of low paid workers, increase the supply of affordable and quality childcare, and advocate a fairer sharing of caring work between women and men. Gender discrimination is far from buried. Only this week, the Nevin Economic Institute reported that 60% of all low paid workers are women. Almost three in every ten female workers are low paid, compared to a factor of two in ten male workers. The majority of low paid women work in three employment sectors: wholesale and retail, accommodation and food, and health and social work. Sinn Féin will continue to use our mandate in Brussels and Leinster House to continue campaigning for fairness and equality at work.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report called for 40% gender quotas, more gender programmes, changes to rules of procedure and gender budgeting internally within the EU Parliament. UKIP voted against the EU Parliament spending any more money on internal administration.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ In support of International Women’s Day and my personal belief in equal representation of men and women in both the European and national parliaments, I voted in favour of this report. I strongly encourage all committees in the European Parliament to integrate the gender perspective in their activities. I believe that gender balance is needed in all forms of employment, but particularly in managerial positions. Although many domains of life are currently dominated by men, women also have a lot to contribute and their perspective could be invaluable in particularly in business, science and politics.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution is concerned with monitoring the situation on the implementation of measures and policies aimed at ensuring gender equality between men and women in the Legislative Processes of the European Parliament. The text points out that there is still a lot of work to be done to achieve satisfactory objectives and, moreover, notes that only a few parliamentary committees are active in this regard, while others have not yet implemented the necessary measures. Finally, greater interinstitutional cooperation is required to support gender mainstreaming and specific budget lines to support it. In agreement with this position and considering it essential that the European Parliament should be an example to civil society in the field of gender equality, I supported the resolution with my vote in favour.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament as I believe there are things to be improved in this House. The European Parliament is a vocal defender of gender mainstreaming and it should be in the forefront of it, serve as a positive reference and good example also for other relevant institutions. In order to be a credible stakeholder in this area, we have to address the shortcomings highlighted in the report such as candidates for chairs of committees and delegations. Having said that, I had one reserve on the proposal for a standing rapporteur on gender mainstreaming, as I think we do not need a newly created position for these issues. The structures and instruments already exist in the European Parliament; it is only up to us to use them adequately.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Women's rights policy is being improperly identified with gender mainstreaming and gender policy, which is not about defending women but about a broader concept that wants to integrate the gender perspective, that is, of men and women, into all both European and national policies. So who better than the European Union can act as a stimulus, becoming a model for the Member States. Although gender equality is recognised by the Union as a fundamental right, a common value and a necessary condition for achieving the development and growth objectives, it is unfortunately regrettable that the principle is not fully implemented, including at the level of the European institutions. This lack is not just about fair distribution in decision-making posts; But there are also no impact assessments of European policies that should better guide policy-makers in making choices. The report we are voting on today can be a useful tool for raising awareness of the subject at all levels and guiding us in our parliamentary work. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, stressing that gender mainstreaming has been accepted internationally as a strategy to achieve gender equality. Gender mainstreaming has a dual dimension: it provides both for gender mainstreaming into the content of different policies and for covering the issue of the representation of women and men in the policy area concerned. Both dimensions – gender representation and gender-based content – must be taken into account at all stages of the policy-making process. Structural inequalities between the sexes persist in our society and therefore gender-based policies are a crucial element in a proper strategy for gender equality.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's motion for a resolution on gender mainstreaming in its work, on which we voted today, is part of a multifaceted effort to maintain conditions of equality and equal opportunities in Europe and its institutions. It is therefore understandable that this effort is a key tool for improving the functioning of Parliament and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree with its basic political objectives: these are effective and far-reaching measures to achieve equality both throughout the EU and within European policies themselves as soon as possible. The report calls on the parliamentary groups in future to propose a man and a woman for the presidencies of European parties, the same groups and committees, a measure which will help to show how much gender does not make a difference but personal characteristics. I believe that this document represents a clear and targeted response to the social inequalities that still affect Europe today, and that is why I could only support it.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Gender mainstreaming can be used as a tool in achieving gender equality. It allows for the integration of a gender perspective into preparation, function, implementation and evaluation of policies with the goal of promoting equality between genders and avoiding discrimination. All EU policies, both internal and external, should be created to benefit males and females equally. The representation of females in key decision-making positions both at political and administrative levels are low, even within the Parliament’s political groups. When women do chair committees they tend to be less connected to economic decision-making. The Parliament must make sure that the decision making process is shared evenly amongst genders to ensure equality. Gender mainstreaming first necessitates the integration of a gender perspective to the content of policies. It also engages with the issue of representation of women and men in a particular policy area. This ensures that the needs of all citizens, regardless of gender, are met.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report called for 40% gender quotas, more gender programmes, changes to rules of procedure and gender budgeting internally within the EU Parliament. UKIP voted against the EU Parliament spending any more money on internal administration.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Taking advantage of International Women's Day, the European Parliament has adopted a set of reports, in which it is part, underlining the much that remains to be done in the defence of women and, more than that, for gender equality. Discrimination between men and women is unacceptable. But it is not enough just to promote inequality outside the doors. Parliament in the exercise of its legislative powers, but also in its functioning, must also ensure gender equality. However, without devt what is the independence of their elected officials, nor the will of the voters they represent, nor an administration that is intended to be meritocratic. Thus, all without exception should have the same opportunities, but this does not translate into parity by decree of the governing positions, in the constitution of the committees, of the presidencies of the groups. I still support this report but I reiterate the importance of continuing to promote a change of mentality through equal opportunities, not results.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report called for 40% gender quotas, more gender programmes, changes to rules of procedure and gender budgeting internally within the EU Parliament. UKIP voted against the EU Parliament spending any more money on internal administration.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is the goal of the gender mainstreaming strategy. This strategy has a twofold dimension: integrating a gender perspective into the content of the various policies and addressing the issue of the representation of women and men in the various policy areas. Both dimensions (gender representation and gender-responsive content) must be taken into account at all stages of the policy-making process. The European Parliament has gradually established a structure for gender mainstreaming and I therefore agree with the rapporteur's proposals to strengthen and make more effective the current structure for gender mainstreaming, including the creation of a solid interinstitutional network. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ It is worthless speaking of gender equality without then ensuring compliance with a gender mainstreaming policy.  This will entail a critical review and analysis of all the work of the European Parliament vis-à-vis gender equality standards. It will require a strong strategic engagement that will affect every aspect of EU policy, from preparation to spending programmes. Its implementation will require a strong assurance that each action or measure takes into consideration its effects on women and men.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report highlights the situation regarding the implementation of gender mainstreaming within the work of the European Parliament. Gender mainstreaming has a twofold dimension: integrating a gender perspective into the content of the various policies and addressing the issue of the representation of women and men in the various policy areas. Both dimensions must be taken into account at all stages of the policy-making process. Although numbers are important, it is also necessary to take into account how gender refers to the content of policy measures, in order to better understand how women and men would benefit. A gender-responsive policy ensures that the needs of all citizens, both women and men, are taken into account in the same way. In our society, however, there are still structural gender inequalities. Although laws treat women and men in the same way, women still do not have equal access and control over resources and resources. The current situation therefore shows that gender-responsive policy content is an essential element of a proper gender equality strategy. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes the integration of the gender perspective into all policies and, therefore, to continue to take steps forward in favour of gender equality, through specific measures to eliminate, prevent or remedy gender inequalities. The Resolution emphasizes the need for gender mainstreaming amendments, a gender assessment and a gender budget to integrate the gender perspective into all policies. It also stresses that greater cooperation between the committees is necessary. The report calls for a roadmap on gender equality, indicating how to increase female representation in middle and high command positions by up to 40% by 2020. It also urges the Commission to assess the gender perspective in the new policy or legislative proposals in order to ensure that the European Union supports women's rights.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Integrating a gender perspective is essential in the preparation, development, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of policies, regulatory measures and spending programmes, with the aim of promoting gender equality and combating discrimination. This integration requires both the integration of a gender perspective into the content of different policies and the resolution of the problem of the representation of women and men in those policies. Balanced representation of women and men and the existence of gender-sensitive content must be taken into account at all stages of the policy-making process. Even though laws treat women and men equally, women still do not have the same access and control over resources and property, and gender mainstreaming is an essential element for an appropriate gender equality strategy.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Equality between women and men is a fundamental right recognised by the EU, a common value of the EU and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. Structural gender inequalities still affect our society. Even if the law treats women and men as equals, women still do not have equal access to or control over resources and assets. Since 2009, a network of representatives responsible for gender mainstreaming in EP committees has been established, as well as a similar network at staff level. Members of the Network shall meet and share information on ongoing matters of interest to network members and best practices. During the last parliamentary term, delegations also appointed representatives responsible for gender mainstreaming. The report voted on today was about the main conclusions of the questionnaires answered by the members of the network.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The idea of gender in the document is unsu convincing, as there is no evidence that it actually improves the situation of women. For example, the main instrument of gender-sensitive amendments in most cases is to add a single word to an existing text, which is 'gender', 'women' or 'female/female'. This is a small help for women. Given that the change itself does not change literally, I believe that solutions should be sought that have a clear impact on gender relations. I voted against.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Assessing the different implications of any planned policy action and legislation for both women and men is an important tool to ensure effective decision-making. Parliament adopted a resolution on gender mainstreaming in 2003. This resolution outlines the need for gender mainstreaming amendments and the different aspects that should be considered. Enhanced cooperation is needed between the institutions, in order to integrate gender equality at all levels and into all stages of policymaking. I voted in favour of this report, as I strongly believe that tools such as gender mainstreaming and gender budgeting as well as key decision-making issues at political and administrative level will help us induce further gender perspective in all policy areas.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report looks at the integration of the principle of gender equality into the work of the European Parliament. He advocates for a balance within the staff of Parliament, particularly for positions of responsibility.  I regret, however, that, more ideologically motivated, the rapporteur has proposed to introduce complex and costly internal procedures, the effectiveness of which is considered questionable. Together with my colleagues in the EPP Group, we have tabled a number of amendments aimed at restoring a balance between supporting the integration of women and maintaining the quality of parliamentary work.  Supporting the purpose of this report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. This initiative report wants greater gender equality in the European Parliament, particularly in its internal organisational chart. I naturally supported it, as parity was one of my long-standing political struggles. This text defines the various tools that should enable women to better represent the institution. In particular, it calls for a quota system for more women in management positions.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 In her report, Mrs Angelika Mlinar examines how gender equality applies in the work of the European Parliament. Equality between women and men is a fundamental right recognised by the EU, a common value of the EU and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. On the line of values represented by the People's Party, I consider it extremely important to promote equality between men and women and to combat discrimination, and for this reason I support the realistic measures proposed to prevent or remedy gender inequalities. It is very important for me to support policies aimed at better compatibility between work and family life. Unfortunately, the report also contains a number of demands which conflict with the principle of subsidiarity and therefore become unacceptable. I couldn't support them.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report aims to decline gender ideology at all levels of the European institutions, by de facto ending the traditional gender distinction. "Gender" is based on personal considerations, particularly sexual ones, which must be reserved for the private sphere. They cannot determine social relationships under any circumstances. Refusing that our fundamental principles be used for the benefit of a dangerous ideology, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report in the first place because I think we have much more important issues to address in the European Parliament that affect society as a whole. Initially, the report included a proposal for gender-neutral sanitary installations. Yes, this has been rejected in committee, but what remains is also quite problematic – the imposition of quotas for female committee chairs. In this case, we must also impose quotas in which regions to vote for men and in which for women, in order to have a level playing field among representatives in the European Parliament.  Yes, I think there should be representation from different genders and a woman should not be discriminated against on pay when she does the same job as a man, but there are professions suitable for women and those suitable for men and quotas cannot be the solution.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote against. The report essentially discriminates on the basis of sex, does not promote meritocracy but instead introduces quotas, a measure that has proven to be counterproductive over time. A proper report would instead promote equal opportunities, the only real equality.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 In her report, Mrs Angelika Mlinar examines how gender equality applies in the work of the European Parliament. Equality between women and men is a fundamental right recognised by the EU, a common value of the EU and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. On the line of values represented by the People's Party, I consider it extremely important to promote equality between men and women and to combat discrimination, and for this reason I support the realistic measures proposed to prevent or remedy gender inequalities.  It is very important for me to support policies aimed at better compatibility between work and family life. Unfortunately, the report also contains a number of demands that conflict with the principle of subsidiarity and thus become unacceptable (e.g. mandatory female quota, LGBTQ rights). I couldn't support them.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. The report broadly develops the implementation of a horizontal approach to gender mainly at different levels of administrations, proposing a number of specific objectives for their achievement, also within the scope of the various EU institutions. At the same time, it believes that this integration of the gender perspective into different EU policies should also be carried out through the work of the various parliamentary committees. Therefore, in a general consideration, the adoption of the report is positive, as it progresses in integrating the gender perspective and in the full participation of women in political and administrative life.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender mainstreaming involves integrating this perspective into the preparation, design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of policies, regulatory measures and spending programmes to promote equality between women and men and combat discrimination. It has a twofold aspect: it requires both the integration of the gender perspective into the content of the different policies and the approach to the issue of the representation of women and men in these policy areas.  The report proposes a set of measures to strengthen and make the current gender mainstreaming structure more effective and more efficient, including the creation of a sound interinstitutional network, the appointment of a permanent rapporteur for gender mainstreaming or the strengthening of the influence of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality on aspects of the budget related to gender issues.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against it during this deliberation because I am totally opposed to gender theory.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report analyses the level of gender mainstreaming in parliamentary committees and other activities of the European Parliament. It advocates gender mainstreaming in all aspects of EU policy and points to a number of measures to achieve it. It also argues that such integration must include the rights, prospects and well-being of LGBTIQ people. It recalls that Parliament's organisational structure has different bodies responsible for the development and effective integration of gender, both at policy level and at professional level.  It notes that, among Parliament's officials, the majority of women remain in the group of assistant sits and that, regrettably, the objectives of gender balance at head level, intermediate and higher grade, adopted in 2006, have not been achieved by the end of the deadline (2009), not even until this year. The report calls for interinstitutional cooperation in favour of gender mainstreaming, stressing the need for continuous dialogue with national parliaments with a view to knowing good practices, new techniques and information gathering. We agree with the general concern expressed in the report and with some of the measures recommended, even if not accompanying all of them.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, because if we don’t have equality in this institution, then what hope is there for society?

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: writing \ u2012 Gender equality and the related emphasis on the equality of women with men must be a strong theme in the individual Member States of the European Union. Each of the women represents a unique contribution to modern society and it is therefore essential to systematically create conditions improving their quality of life. In addition to superficial statements, many EU Member States and the Commission itself are making only a pre-fic9/2013 strategy for a real improvement in the situation of women in society. I am therefore very happy that since 2009 a network of Members responsible for gender mainstreaming within committees has been set up in the European Parliament, as well as another staff-level network. However, I find it regrettable that most committees have not adopted or discussed the Gender Action Plan. The adoption of the action plan in question would be a positive step towards gender equality.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report, which is totally unnecessary and to which we have always been opposed.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. The report essentially discriminates on the basis of sex, does not promote meritocracy but instead introduces quotas, a measure that has proved counterproductive over time. A proper report would instead promote equal opportunities, the only real equality.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I totally support this resolution, which stresses for the need for gender mainstreaming amendments, gender impact assessment and gender budgeting in order to integrate a gender perspective in all policy areas. It is fundamental that we call on the Commission to make gender impact assessments on new legislative or policy proposals in order to guarantee that the EU is upholding women’s rights. As female representation in key decision-making positions at political and administrative level – including political groups in Parliament – remains low, I support the proposals to increase gender equality at staff level. On 8 March, I therefore support the call on Parliament, its institutional partners and NGOs to closely work together with a view to making gender mainstreaming a continuous process, and integrate gender equality at all levels, in all areas and into all stages of policy-making.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the integration of the gender dimension in the work of the European Parliament, because I am convinced that progress on gender equality and respect for women's rights depends on a cross-cutting approach in addition to specific measures, and that we must regularly assess the relevance and performance of our parliamentary work in this area.  In particular, I welcome the invitations to political groups and the administration to ensure a gender balance in parliamentary committees and at different levels of the hierarchy. Indeed, I believe that the European institutions can make a difference also by example and by creating role models for young European women.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In her report, Mrs Angelika Mlinar examines how gender equality applies in the work of the European Parliament. Equality between women and men is a fundamental right recognised by the EU, a common value of the EU and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. On the line of values represented by the People's Party, I consider it extremely important to promote equality between men and women and to combat discrimination, and for this reason I support the realistic measures proposed to prevent or remedy gender inequalities.  It is very important for me to support policies aimed at better compatibility between work and family life. Unfortunately, the report also contains a number of demands that conflict with the principle of subsidiarity and therefore become unacceptable (e.g. mandatory female quota, LGBTQ rights). I couldn't support them.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the firm intention that in a few years real equality between the two genders will be achieved, in line with the fundamental EU rights and objectives contained in the treaties. It is vital to lead by example and to eradicate any kind of inequality in the institution that represents all European citizens.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to integrate the gender perspective into the work of the European Parliament and in all aspects of EU intervention, as well as in the preparation, design, implementation, control and evaluation of policies, legal provisions and expenditure programming, in order to achieve equality between women and men.  I also believe that the achievement of this objective effectively contributes to the usual practice of each parliamentary committee appointing one of its members as responsible for gender mainly, the creation of a "gender mains integration network" that meets several times a year, and the High-Level Group on Gender Equality , which also meets on a regular basis. Both agencies are supported by the report, which also stresses the need to make 'amendments for gender mains integration', amendments which the FEMM Commission draws up to incorporate the gender perspective into the reports of other parliamentary committees.  The report also defends gender impact assessments and gender budgeting budgets.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to integrate the gender perspective into the work of the European Parliament and in all aspects of EU intervention, as well as in the preparation, design, implementation, control and evaluation of policies, legal provisions and expenditure programming, in order to achieve equality between women and men.  I also believe that the achievement of this objective effectively contributes to the usual practice of each parliamentary committee appointing one of its members as responsible for gender mainly, the creation of a "gender mains integration network" that meets several times a year, and the High-Level Group on Gender Equality , which also meets on a regular basis. Both agencies are supported by the report, which also stresses the need to make 'amendments for gender mains integration', amendments which the FEMM Commission draws up to incorporate the gender perspective into the reports of other parliamentary committees.  The report also defends gender impact assessments and gender budgeting budgets.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. Among the major challenges facing Europe with economic investment and action plans, gender equality is one of the most important. The strategy for equality between women and men demonstrates the Commission's concrete commitment to this issue.  The European Parliament, in turn, has launched a questionnaire among the members of the gender mainstreaming network which, in addition to registering a desire for gender mainstreaming, regardless of an action plan and a concrete balance between men and women, has also highlighted some unresolved issues. I therefore support the work done with this report, considering in particular the monitoring of culture and education in gender mainstreaming and equality, as a factor of economic growth and cohesion and social inclusion, to be continued to be promoted both inside and outside our institutions.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament because it is an important starting point for implementing a strategy that achieves the conditions for equality between men and women, especially within the European Parliament, which is the beating heart of the European Union.  I firmly believe in the need to implement gender policies that promote and promote women's views in an area such as Politics, which is very often difficult for women to access and is partly anchored in sexist and discriminatory logic.  The aim of integrating the gender dimension into Parliament's work is not only to raise public awareness and the institutions of issues relating to discrimination between men and women, but also to integrate women fully into the various social spheres and particularly into political representation.  I agree with the importance of a more integrated and shared approach with national parliaments in the field of good practice and of seeking best practices of gender mainstreaming at national and regional level in the Member States.  It is also essential to insist on the European Commission establishing an effective and efficient regulatory framework for equality between men and women within the European institutions.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against the report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament because I proposed an alternative resolution in Amendment No 4. The report itself represents an incredible amount of unnecessary bureaucracy and deeply interferes with the structures of the European Parliament. I say: the Committee on Women's Women's Committee is not a superman! I strongly reject any special right to other committees!

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the European Union, equality between women and men is a fundamental right and a prerequisite for achieving the Community's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. Structural differences in the treatment of women and men are still entrenched in our society. Despite the efforts of the Commission and the Member States, the rate of increase in female employment is still unsatisfactory. It has changed from just 58.1% to 62.8% since 2002. If the current trend continues, the Europe 2020 target of 75% will not be achieved until 2038.  Gender mainstreaming, as the report points out, must be two-dimensional, both by including it in the content of different policies and by addressing the unequal representation of women and men in the policy areas in question. I welcome the outcome of today's vote and the set of measures proposed by the rapporteur to increase the effectiveness and efficiency of the current gender mainstreaming structure. In this context, the most important aspects are strengthening cooperation with national parliaments in order to increase the exchange of information and contacts for the further development of strategies and to increase the impact of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality on gender-related budgetary issues.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report called for 40% gender quotas, more gender programmes, changes to rules of procedure and gender budgeting internally within the EU Parliament. UKIP voted against the EU Parliament spending any more money on internal administration.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ Julie Girling on behalf of the UK delegation. The UK delegation firmly supports the principle of gender mainstreaming, recognising and subsequently welcoming its potential to equalise the current disparities between genders. Within the European Parliament itself, changes can and should be made and so we welcome those paragraphs that call for more women in senior positions, help women to juggle work-life balance, highlight the need for better training on LGBTIQ issues and encourage EU policymaking that is more mindful of a gender perspective. However, while being supportive of efforts to ensure greater equality, there are a number of elements of this report that the UK delegation cannot support. Rather than focusing on tangible results, this report is more concerned with bolstering the FEMM committee’s position within the European Parliament. Instead of using this opportunity to implement a more long-term and meaningful strategy to help and support women, this report seeks to instil gender budgeting which poses the risk of diverting funds from other, much needed activity. As a result of this, the UK delegation abstained overall, for this report.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. Another report by the FEMM commission is a delusion. Because, as is the custom of this commission, the acceptance of equality between women and men goes far beyond legitimate equality of opportunity or wages. In fact, the aim of this report is to give the FEMM Committee, which is of little use, an illegitimate right of review in all areas, by imposing a reading systematically in line with the ideology of "gender" and to take into account "equal parts" (sic!) the benefits for women, men, LGTBIQ and "all other gender identities"! This promises to be a great headache for texts on the protection of long-term investors, for example. While most of the time, the analysis of respect for the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality of European laws is sloppy, that impact studies are more a matter of incantation than analysis, and that real evaluations of the effectiveness of European policies are lacking or censored, Mrs (Miss? Ms?) Mlinar, and the parliament with her, focus on nonsense. I voted against this report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution because it is essential to promote the main translating of the gender perspective into all of Parliament's policies, as well as the momentum and promotion of women in the decision-making spaces in which they are underrepresented. This report raises the need to implement a strategy for the development of gender mains mains, through tools such as "gender mains mains integration amendments", gender impact assessment reports and gender-sensitive budgets. To improve the integration of the gender perspective into all policies, the report proposes further developing gender mains tools and also calls on the Commission to make gender impact assessments in new legislative proposals to ensure that the EU is active in defending women's rights.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the promotion of gender mainstreaming in the EU, because achieving gender equality is central to the protection of human rights, the functioning of democracy, respect for the rule of law, and economic growth, social inclusion and sustainability. Unfortunately, we have not made as much progress on this front as we should have, and that needs to change. There should be more gender equality regarding decision-making positions and committee influence, and gender equality should be emphasised in all policies that the EU adopts.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to integrate the gender perspective into the work of the European Parliament and in all aspects of EU intervention, as well as in the preparation, design, implementation, control and evaluation of policies, legal provisions and expenditure programming, in order to achieve equality between women and men.  I also believe that the achievement of this objective effectively contributes to the usual practice of each parliamentary committee appointing one of its members as responsible for gender mainly, the creation of a "gender mains integration network" that meets several times a year, and the High-Level Group on Gender Equality , which also meets on a regular basis. Both agencies are supported by the report, which also stresses the need to make 'amendments for gender mains integration', amendments which the FEMM Commission draws up to incorporate the gender perspective into the reports of other parliamentary committees.  The report also defends gender impact assessments and gender budgeting budgets.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 In her report, Mrs Angelika Mlinar examines how gender equality applies in the work of the European Parliament. Equality between women and men is a fundamental right recognised by the EU, a common value of the EU and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. On the line of values represented by the People's Party, I consider it extremely important to stand up for equality between men and women and to promote the fight against discrimination. For this reason, I support the realistic measures proposed to prevent or remedy gender inequalities.  Furthermore, it is of paramount importance for the Hungarian delegation of the People's Party to support policies aimed at better compatibility of work and family life. Unfortunately, the report also contains a number of demands that conflict with the principle of subsidiarity, so I could not support them.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 The report stresses the need for gender changes, gender impact assessment and gender budgeting in order to integrate the gender dimension into all policy areas.  It stresses the need for more cooperation between the various committees, which is necessary, and calls on the High Level Group to present a roadmap of gender equality showing how to increase the representation of women in middle and senior management positions to 40% by 2020. In a better gender mainstreaming in all policy areas, the report proposed the further development of gender mainstreaming tools, such as gender mainstreaming. It also calls on the Commission to make gender impact assessments on new legislative or political proposals in order to ensure the defence of women's rights. Bearing in mind that equality between men and women is recognised by the EU as a fundamental right, a common value of the EU and a prerequisite for achieving the eu's growth, employment and social cohesion objectives, we believe that the report has made a positive contribution in this direction and we have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support my colleague Angelika Mlinar who was rapporteur on this report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. Equality between women and men is one of the fundamental principles of EU law, a common value and a necessary condition for the achievement of the EU objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. For 20 years now, the Commission committed itself to a ‘dual approach’ towards realising gender equality. This means mainstreaming a gender perspective into all policies, while also implementing specific measures to eliminate, prevent or remedy gender inequalities. This report supports that commitment by the Commission by calling for a rotating co-chair for the Gender Mainstreaming Network, a strong and stable relationship between the EP high-level group for gender equality and diversity, targeted trainings for staff and MEPs, and a standing rapporteur on gender mainstreaming to ensure better and more effective cooperation.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe Parliament has the organisational structure and capacity to promote gender mainstreaming in its activities. This report manages to highlight the key areas where Parliament needs to improve the gender balance in its decision-making.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Angelika Mlinar, member of the FEMM Committee, aims to introduce the concept of gender mainstreaming in all European Parliament policies and actions, both at political and working level. This includes a strict quota system for the filling of posts, the inclusion of the so-called gender perspective in all the activities of parliamentary staff, the creation of a separate 'network for gender mainstreaming', a permanent rapporteur on the subject and the elimination of alleged disadvantages for women in the day-to-day work of the European Parliament. This report is superfluous, speaks out against an excessive bureaucracy and seeks to replace the principle of performance with a technocratically arranged filling of posts. It is to be assumed that the proposals contained in the report by the FEMM Committee aim to compensate for its lack of practical legitimacy by introducing gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament. That is why I did not vote in favour of this report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In her report, Mrs Angelika Mlinar examines how gender equality applies in the work of the European Parliament. Equality between women and men is a fundamental right recognised by the EU, a common value of the EU and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. On the line of values represented by the People's Party, I consider it extremely important to promote equality between men and women and to combat discrimination, and for this reason I support the realistic measures proposed to prevent or remedy gender inequalities.  It is very important for me to support policies aimed at better compatibility between work and family life. Unfortunately, the report also contains a number of demands that conflict with the principle of subsidiarity and therefore become unacceptable (e.g. mandatory female quota, LGBTQ rights). I couldn't support them.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report called for 40% gender quotas, more gender programmes, changes to rules of procedure and gender budgeting internally within the EU Parliament.  UKIP voted against the EU Parliament spending any more money on internal administration.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ It is appropriate that we are voting on this report on what is International Women’s Day and, whilst Parliament has done important work in this area, we should continue to ensure that this report’s recommendations are adhered to.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union must guarantee equal opportunities and treatment between men and women. The European Parliament and its institutional partners should step up their efforts to integrate gender equality at all levels, in all areas and at every stage of the policy-making process.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the proposal for a resolution by the European Parliament on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament because I believe that the gender dimension in the European Parliament should be more visible when it comes to the content of EP policies, but also in the administration itself, i.e. in the decision-making process. I also support inclusion in the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, gender-conscious elements, and the objective of gender balance in higher and medium management levels.  Equality between men and women is one of the fundamental principles of European legislation, and a necessary condition to achieve social cohesion, employment and growth. However, there are still some shortcomings and shortcomings within the other EU institutions and parliament itself in order to fully achieve gender equality.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The implementation of the 2016-2019 "Gender" strategy is presented in this text as the capital for the protection of man, for economic growth and the defence of democracy. This dimension of "gender" focuses only on sexual orientations. An area that should remain only in the private sphere and should not be subject to special treatment.  The identity of human beings is not determined by sexual practices. A policy is even less defined based on the sexual behaviour of individuals. Promoting rights based on particular sexual behaviour is the starting point of communitarianism that the National Front rejects. It is only natural that I voted against this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report called for 40% gender quotas, more gender programmes, changes to rules of procedure and gender budgeting internally within the EU Parliament. UKIP voted against the EU Parliament spending any more money on internal administration.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to integrate the gender perspective into the work of the European Parliament and in all aspects of EU intervention, as well as in the preparation, design, implementation, control and evaluation of policies, legal provisions and expenditure programming, in order to achieve equality between women and men.  I also believe that the achievement of this objective effectively contributes to the usual practice of each parliamentary committee appointing one of its members as responsible for gender mainly, the creation of a "gender mains integration network" that meets several times a year, and the High-Level Group on Gender Equality , which also meets on a regular basis. Both agencies are supported by the report, which also stresses the need to make 'amendments for gender mains integration', amendments which the FEMM Commission draws up to incorporate the gender perspective into the reports of other parliamentary committees.  The report also defends gender impact assessments and gender budgeting budgets.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 Gender equality is one of the fundamental principles of European law, a common value and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's growth, employment and social cohesion objectives. Unfortunately, women still don't have the same rights and options as men. Angelica Mlinar's report calls for the swift integration of the gender perspective into the preparation, design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of EU policies. I believe that raising awareness of the persistent problem of gender inequality and strengthening cooperation with the Commission, national parliaments and international organisations is essential – not only in the context of International Women's Day celebrations – which is why I have unequivocally supported the proposal.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I abstained on my colleague Angelika Mlinar's report on the integration of gender in the work of the European Parliament. Gender equality is a key issue and many steps need to be taken to address the unacceptable inequalities that still plague today. However, the introduction of the gender perspective in all Parliament's documents does not seem to me to be adequate to achieve gender equality. I support the objectives of the report, but the measures it advocates do not seem to me to be the best way to achieve it.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. This report concerned the integration of gender perspectives into the work of the European Parliament, including the work of parliamentary committees, the selection of Parliament's staff and the allocation of civil servants' positions within the Institution. Voted on Women's Rights Day, it was important to reaffirm equality in women's rights in our chamber.  However, while the report contains good things, others are much less so. Moreover, as this report has no legislative scope and is in addition to the many texts that the European Parliament too often collects on the gender dimension, I abstained.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report calls for the introduction and implementation of gender mainstreaming in all policy areas, committee work and delegations in the European Parliament. I do not see in the report the training opportunities for Members and assistants and I reject this report.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I abstained when i voted on the report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. I support the promotion of equality between women and men and believe that significant steps are being taken more and more and progress is being made. However, as regards the disproportionate requirements for the provision of a female quota at all levels in the European Parliament, I believe that binding rules will only make efficiency more difficult and disproportionate. I also believe that the rights of women and men in Parliament are already respected and taken into account. There is equality between women and men in Parliament, and rights and opportunities are the same for all. I support gender mainstreaming, but I believe that the report places too much burden on and can harm the effectiveness of work in Parliament.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it calls for gender mainstreaming to be made a continuous process, and gender equality to be integrated at all levels, in all areas and into all stages of policymaking.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Angelika Mlinar, member of the FEMM Committee, aims to introduce the concept of gender mainstreaming in all European Parliament policies and actions, both at political and working level. This includes a strict quota system for the filling of posts, the inclusion of the so-called gender perspective in all the activities of Parliamentary staff, the creation of a separate 'network for gender mainstreaming', a permanent rapporteur on the subject and the elimination of alleged disadvantages for women in the day-to-day work of the European Parliament. This report is superfluous, speaks out against an excessive bureaucracy and seeks to replace the principle of performance with a technocratically arranged filling of posts. It is to be assumed that the proposals contained in the report by the FEMM Committee aim to compensate for its lack of practical legitimacy by introducing gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament. That is why I did not vote in favour of this report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union recognises gender equality as a fundamental right. This is the general value of the European Union, which is essential to achieve the European Union's objectives in terms of growth, employment and social cohesion. Yet there are still structural inequalities between women and men in society, and women no longer have equal access to, or control over, resources and resources. The current situation therefore shows that the content of gender-based policies is essential for a proper strategy for gender equality. The resolution stresses the need to integrate gender into all policy areas, which is why I also support this proposal. In order to further improve gender equality, two different aspects need to be taken into account: policy content and gender representation, and gender equality at decision-making level.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 In her report, Mrs Angelika Mlinar examines how gender equality applies in the work of the European Parliament. Equality between women and men is a fundamental right recognised by the EU, a common value of the EU and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. On the line of values represented by the People's Party, I consider it extremely important to promote equality between men and women and to combat discrimination, and for this reason I support the realistic measures proposed to prevent or remedy gender inequalities.  It is very important for me to support policies aimed at better compatibility between work and family life. Unfortunately, the report also contains a number of demands that conflict with the principle of subsidiarity and therefore become unacceptable (e.g. mandatory female quota, LGBTQ rights). I couldn't support them.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: Writing. \u2012 This report provides an overview of gender mainstreaming in the various policies, an internationally accepted strategy for achieving gender equality. It is a fact that since 1996 the Union has committed itself to taking the so-called two-way approach, which aims not only at the theoretical integration of this strategy, but also at taking concrete measures to prevent and eliminate inequalities. However, it is regrettable that not all objectives have been achieved and that administrative barriers continue to exist in this context. As can be said from questionnaires addressed to Members of the bodies responsible for gender mainstreaming within Parliament, there is a manifest lack of coordination of their activities. Measures are therefore proposed for established cooperation both between the European institutions and the relevant committees and with the national parliaments, in order to ensure the stability of this strategy. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report 'Gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament' was set up to ensure that the institution which co-makes equality law in the European Union applies the principles of equal treatment to itself. Unfortunately, the report goes well beyond the function of evaluation, which was the first motivation for the document, and contains a number of proposals which, in my opinion, will not improve the situation of women, are counter-effective and, above all, do not arise from any apparent demand, such as quotas for women and men in individual committees.  I voted against many specific solutions, which I consider unnecessary or even harmful, but I supported the report in the final vote because it is, admittedly, an imperfect but necessary step towards a systematic evaluation of Parliament in terms of compliance with EU law – in principle, that the order must always start with itself.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Gender equality is a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. The achievement of gender equality is possible through the inclusion of the gender dimension in all parliament's political and legislative processes. The structural nature of gender inequalities must be combated through the definition and implementation of specific measures that eliminate, prevent or remedy gender inequalities. I am aware that much still needs to be done, despite the progress of recent years, and I am sure that the European Union, together with the Member States, will do everything in its power to reduce and eliminate the inequalities that still exist between men and women.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it is a hymn to gender theory. Amendment No. 4, in which several MPs, including those of the FN, tried to replace gender equality with equality between men and women, was unfortunately rejected. This report also darkens into ridicule by stating that the gender dimension must integrate "LGBTIQ" people (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transsexual, Intersexual, and - latest in trendy sexual orientations - "Queers" ...).

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The report is part of the 2016-2019 gender strategy. It proposes, in particular, to introduce the concept of 'gender' into the work of the European institutions and at all levels. To do this, a major communication and awareness campaign would be carried out to train MPs, political advisors... to the practice of neutral language, respectful of all genres. Indeed, the concept of "gender" includes "men, women and all other genders in general".   Not only do I consider that gender equality is only about equality between men and women, but also that the sexual orientations of persons are in the private sphere and should not be debated in the public sphere. In addition, I would like to remind you that politicians must defend the integrity of the human person, which is not limited to his sexual practices. It is therefore absurd to want to impose a unique way of thinking through the "gender", which sells human dignity and respect for privacy. This text is part of the desire for communitarianism on these subjects, initiated by the Commission and supported by LGBT lobbies. I voted against it.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to integrate the gender perspective into the work of the European Parliament and in all aspects of EU intervention, as well as in the preparation, design, implementation, control and evaluation of policies, legal provisions and expenditure programming, in order to achieve equality between women and men.  I also believe that the achievement of this objective effectively contributes to the usual practice of each parliamentary committee appointing one of its members as responsible for gender mainly, the creation of a "gender mains integration network" that meets several times a year, and the High-Level Group on Gender Equality , which also meets on a regular basis. Both agencies are supported by the report, which also stresses the need to make 'amendments for gender mains integration', amendments which the FEMM Commission draws up to incorporate the gender perspective into the reports of other parliamentary committees.  The report also defends gender impact assessments and gender budgeting budgets.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes the integration of the gender perspective into all policies and, therefore, to continue to take steps forward in favour of gender equality, through specific measures to eliminate, prevent or remedy gender inequalities. The Resolution emphasizes the need for gender mainstreaming amendments, a gender assessment and a gender budget to integrate the gender perspective into all policies. It also stresses that greater cooperation between the committees is necessary. The report calls for a roadmap on gender equality, indicating how to increase female representation in middle and high command positions by up to 40% by 2020. It also urges the Commission to assess the gender perspective in the new policy or legislative proposals in order to ensure that the European Union supports women's rights.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Angelika Mlinar, member of the FEMM Committee, aims to introduce the concept of gender mainstreaming in all European Parliament policies and actions, both at political and working level. This includes a strict quota system for the filling of posts, the inclusion of the so-called gender perspective in all the activities of parliamentary staff, the creation of a separate 'network for gender mainstreaming', a permanent rapporteur on the subject and the elimination of alleged disadvantages for women in the day-to-day work of the European Parliament. This report is superfluous, speaks out against an excessive bureaucracy and seeks to replace the principle of performance with a technocratically arranged filling of posts. It is to be assumed that the proposals contained in the report by the FEMM Committee aim to compensate for its lack of practical legitimacy by introducing gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament. That is why I did not vote in favour of this report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the creation of additional commissions and committees to ensure gender equality in Parliament. It is foolish to ask for absolute equality in the number of men and women hired to work in the EP. I do not agree that special commissions should work to ensure that there are more women in Parliament and that there is absolute gender equality in admission to the EP. I am also against the 'Commission taking into account the experiences of LGBTIQ people' when analysing the impact of the proposed legislation on gender equality. The only fair admission criterion for applicants is their experience and knowledge, not gender or sexual orientation.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. ‒ Even though I support Article 23 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and Article 8 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, I voted against this report for the sole reason that I have not found any gender discrimination in Parliament, therefore I consider this report useless.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Equality between women and men is recognised by the EU as a fundamental right and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives. Gender inequality persists in our society despite laws applying to both women and men as equals. On the other hand, all the measures outlined in the report have already been implemented and are part of the EU legal framework, so I voted against this report.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ I take gender equality for granted in all EU policies. The EU formally respects the principle of gender equality as a fundamental right and value. In many areas, however, this principle remains more and more on paper than in practice. In addition to fulfilling it, it is necessary to create real conditions, taking into account and at the same time removing gender gaps, and to take practical steps.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted strongly against text. The report envisages the inclusion of the gender dimension in all the work of the European institutions, at all levels, in all internal and external policies. It also calls for the establishment of monitoring the work of parliamentary committees through a "responsible" who will ensure that this report is properly implemented.  This dimension of "gender" focuses only on sexual orientations, an area that must remain in the private sphere and should not be treated in particular: the identity of human beings is not limited to their sexual practices!

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report which points out that gender mainstreaming is not a policy goal in itself, but a key means of achieving gender equality, always in combination with other specific actions and policies targeted at advancing gender equality.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is a fundamental principle for the European Union. We must therefore show that the European Parliament is also at the forefront of ensuring equal opportunities for men and women. That is why I supported this report.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. Equality between men and women is a fundamental right recognised by the European Union, as well as a common value and a necessary condition for the full implementation of the EU's objectives for growth, employment and social cohesion to be achieved.  Since 1996, the European Commission has committed itself to the adoption of a gender equality policy involving the gender perspective in the implementation of legislative measures and policies.   This resolution aims to continue this process by promoting greater integration of the gender perspective into all measures adopted by the European institutions, whether in the drafting of legislative texts, in budgetary policies or in promoting the representativeness of women occupying middle and top positions within the administration.  I voted for it.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. Progress is needed in integrating the gender perspective into the work of the European Parliament. To do this, we must evaluate the current institutional framework and propose tools that will allow us to move forward in this area, integrating the gender perspective into the work we do in a comprehensive way, as proposed by the motion for a Resolution to which I have added my vote.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution concerns the integration of the gender dimension into the various policies and the representation of men and women in the field of policy to promote gender equality in the European Parliament. Although gender equality is now an undeniable right and value of the EU, it must be achieved not only by prohibition but also by positive measures to eliminate gender discrimination. Parliament's Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) is responsible for gender mainstreaming in EP political and legislative processes. There is also the network of Members responsible for promoting gender equality in the EP Committees. Despite the existence of these mobilisations, research has shown the lack of an action plan for the practical implementation of gender equality. At the same time, the existing practice of amendments in favour of gender mainstreaming needs to be improved.
