I am voting in favour of this resolution by welcoming the proposals it contains, for example, strengthening cooperation with national parliaments, more effective cooperation between FEMM and the network of Members and establishing an appropriate framework for the effective integration of the gender dimension into EP policies.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In the European Parliament, no less than four bodies are responsible for promoting gender equality both on the merits and internally of the institution. This report makes a number of concrete proposals, including reaching 40% of women in key management positions by 2020. Women MPs are still too confined to committee chairs whose budget or political weight is more minor. The text therefore invites political parties to take responsibility, for example by proposing joint pairs at the head of their political group or parliamentary committees.  My GUE/NGL group is particularly exemplary in this regard, being the only group with more women elected than men. I am voting in the face of the Conservatives' outcry against this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The definition of gender in the text is based on forced egalitarianism. I consider that giving that meaning to the word gender is arbitrary and contributes to distorting the debate. In my opinion, it is a well-built Trojan horse that enters the debate and will come to establish assumptions that will distort the texts. Is it not said that what is private, namely sexual practices, must remain in the private sector? And I don't know that these practices in any way affect a person's identity. Therefore, I find it illegitimate to base a policy on these bases. We are in favour of national unity, and these policies would pave the way for communitarianism. As a result, I have spoken out against the motion for a resolution. There was an alternative text that gave the word gender the common definition. It was a way of countering the staggering text of the S and D. As a result, I have spoken in favour of the alternative text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the integration of the gender perspective into the activities of the European Parliament. I believe that the rapporteur has deviated from the essential objective of the report.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it is important for Parliament’s policies and programmes to be pluralistic and include a gender perspective when they are being drafted, implemented and monitored.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: writing – Gender equality is a frequently discussed topic in our society, not including the European Parliament. It is one of the guiding principles of EU primary law and a condition for achieving growth, employment or social cohesion. The Union sees equality of access to needs for both sexes behind the promotion of gender equality and has long integrated this issue into the content of its policies. The European Parliament has already taken a number of concrete measures to combat discrimination on grounds of sex. However, the Mlinar report is based on the traditional promotion of gender equality and clearly pursues a different objective, namely to significantly increase the powers of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) by including gender issues in all other aspects of EU work. In addition to amending the European Parliament's procedural rules and increasing financial and human resources, the report presented calls for the establishment of a rapporteur for Gender Mainstreaming at Parliament level. However, such a function does not feature in the founding treaties and will cause a substantial increase in the workload and complicate procedures for both the European Parliament and the various committees. From the point of view of European citizens, Parliament's work will seem even less comprehensible, thereby increasing the already generally high level of Euroscepticism. This report uses gender ideology as a backslid to give the FEMM more influence over other EU policies, which is at the forempor of my beliefs, which is why I have chosen not to support it.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament, which calls on the Parliament, its institutional partners and NGOs to closely work together with a view to making gender mainstreaming a continuous process, and integrate gender equality at all levels, in all areas and into all stages of policymaking, which is essential.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Equality between women and men is a fundamental right recognised by the EU, a common value of the EU and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. The report of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality examines the implementation of this principle in the work of the European Parliament. Since 2009, a network of meps responsible for gender mainstreaming in EP committees has been established. Each member of the Network was asked to complete a questionnaire aimed at examining the activities and policy instruments for gender mainstreaming in each committee.  The report is based on an evaluation of the responses. These responses have revealed a number of best practices, but also problematic cases which call into question the effectiveness of the current gender validation framework. On this basis, the report proposes a series of measures that would strengthen and improve the current structure for gender mainstreaming. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This text is a new concession to the fashionable theme of "gender" in order to force the European Parliament to integrate this new religion into its practices, with the sole aim of making good thanks to LGBT lobbies.  The mere mention of this theory is sufficient to reject in principle the obligations that one wishes to derive from it. It is not clear how Parliament should modulate its work according to each other's sexual practices or each person's conception of one's or the other.  Promoting rights based on particular sexual behaviour is the starting point of communitarianism that the National Front rejects.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 8 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) establishes gender mainstreaming as a horizontal principle and Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union (WEU) establishes the principle of equality between men and women as a fundamental value of the Union. I have decided to abstain from this report because certain prerogatives are considered in the report which must respect the principle of subsidiarity, since quota issues are, for example, a competence of the Member States.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This dimension of "gender" focuses only on sexual orientation, an area that should remain only in the private sphere. A policy is not defined by the sexual behaviour of individuals, at the risk of categorizing individuals and undermining equality. That is why I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Gender inequality can only be overcome if it is tackled holistically in all areas of life, and in all areas of decision-making. Gender mainstreaming is one of the great policy innovations of the European Union, and it seeks to include a gender perspective in policy-making at all levels, and also ensure that women, and persons of all gender identities, are equally represented in decision-making. As a co-legislator of European laws, effective gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament is key.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to better integrate the gender dimension into the work of the European Parliament. On the agenda for Women's Day, this text reminds us that in many areas equality between men and women is far from perfect. I support all initiatives that will strengthen women's position.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 "Tous les jours La Journée des Femmes." That's what I read this morning on my way to work at a florist in Strasbourg. That's the way it is for us, for a man who's got something, every day of the year is Women's Day. Only this one, March 8th, will be officially recognized. The joke aside – some of them have now been elected to the Slovak Parliament (and others have been rejected for this reason) who are questioning natural women's equality and equal opportunities by misinterpreting Christian values. All forms of intolerance are reprehensible and all minority groups have the right to protection, as their rights cannot be enforced on the basis of the principles of majority democracy because of their numerical disadvantage. If we do not want politics to be defined between women and men, women's rights must also be protected.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that should integrate a gender perspective in the content of different policies, and should address the issue of representation of women and men in the given policy area. Gender mainstreaming has been embraced internationally as a strategy towards achieving gender equality.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ To this day, even though gender equality is recognised by the EU as a fundamental right, structural gender inequality persists to exist in our society. Sadly, the report highlights that activities of bodies responsible for gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament and with other institutions are not yet effectively coordinated or integrated and that 2009 gender balance targets at senior and middle management level have still not been met. I voted in favour of this report because integration of a gendered perspective is a necessary component of all areas of policy-making and a prerequisite for creating equal opportunities for women and men. The European Parliament should therefore continue to work on embracing and implementing gender mainstreaming in all aspects of its work. The report is a necessary step in the right direction.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report calls for the implementation of gender mainstreaming at all levels of the EU and its policies. Special training and instruction for the employees will be offered. I consider this to be a waste of money and I have spoken out against this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Progress in ensuring gender equality in all EU policies has been very slow, so gender equality must also be better ensured in the work of the European Parliament.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. The integration of the gender perspective implies its incorporation into all aspects of European Union policy – preparation, design and implementation – in order to achieve equality between men and women. Hence the importance of supporting this report. It takes stock of the current situation from a dual perspective: the content of women's policies and representation in the administration and decision-making positions in the European Parliament. The outcome of this evaluation is clear. We have made very little progress, confirming the lack of coordination and gender integration. In the face of this critical situation, more commitments are certainly needed, but above all measures and actions.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that both men and women in the political, professional and family life need to be equally active. First of all, it is necessary to ensure an adequate work-life balance. It is necessary to prevent any discrimination and to remove all obstacles that lead to inequalities between women and men. EU policies must be designed and implemented in a way that benefits everyone equally. In addition, there is no need to identify new measures until the existing gender mainstreaming measures have been properly implemented.  I do not think it is appropriate to establish a permanent rapporteur on gender mainstreaming and to legitimise the use of gender-neutral language. There are also doubts about the usefulness of regular gender mainstreaming training and the potential financial costs.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report called for 40% gender quotas, more gender programmes, changes to rules of procedure and gender budgeting internally within the EU Parliament. UKIP voted against the EU Parliament spending any more money on internal administration.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender mainstreaming has been welcomed internationally as a strategy for achieving gender equality. Although numbers are important, it is also necessary to take into account how gender refers to the content of policy measures, in order to better understand how women and men would benefit.  We all know that a gender-responsive policy ensures that the needs of all citizens, both women and men, are taken into account in the same way.  I therefore vote in favour of this report because equality between women and men is a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I find this report extremely problematic for several reasons. First, it tries to impose gender ideology and completely contain natural differences between the sexes by redefining the notion of gender. The European Commission points out that gender-focused policies find their source in the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, which clearly states that one of the founding principles of the European Union is to achieve equality between women and men. But this is what we're used to - the paper is that this report is trying to give the Women's Rights Committee some powers that don't belong to it. The measures proposed are pre-intesic. They directly request amendments to the European Parliament's Rules of Regulations and the granting of powers to one committee over all other committees, and thus over all eu policies. This is against the legal and democratic procedures and regulations of the European Parliament. Abolishing the independence of the functioning of parliamentary committees and placing the FEMM committee above all is not the key to achieving genuine equality between women and men. On the contrary - it will harm this ultimate goal to which we aspire. Because of all this, I was unable to support the Report on Gender-Based Policy in the Work of the European Parliament. It does not contribute to improving women's rights, but brings with it a burden in the work of the European Parliament, increasing bureaucracy and reducing transparency, which will also undermine citizens' trust in the European institutions.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report claims to defend equality between men and women but merely communitizes and classifies individuals according to their gender or gender. Equality cannot be ensured by spending its time designating so-called communities to defend. That's the obvious thing. On the other hand, I believe that public institutions should interfere as little as possible with what belongs to the private sphere of individuals. I therefore vote against this motion for a resolution.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Integrating the gender perspective into EU sectoral policies is a key step towards achieving equality between men and women and achieving an inclusive and sustainable society. This is a crucial dimension for the protection of human rights and the functioning of democracy. However, progress remains slow and uncertain, and the evaluation of the Commission's 2010-2015 strategy notes a number of shortcomings, although the commission's proposals have been renewed for the three-year period 2016-2019. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that introducing gender perspectives at all stages of the political cycle is the only real action to be taken to achieve our aims of equality and cohesion, the founding aims of the Union itself. I also believe that this is a crucial issue for the European Parliament, which already has an organisational structure to promote the integration of the gender dimension into all its activities, but for this structure to be fully effective, it must be strengthened through greater cooperation with the Council and the Commission, facilitating the work of the various bodies responsible for gender mainstreaming within Parliament itself.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Gender mainstreaming means "integrating a gender perspective into all aspects of EU policy, i.e. gender perspectives in all aspects of EU policy. preparation, draft, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of policies, in legal measures and in spending programmes, in order to achieve equality between women and men". It is not a policy objective in itself, but a key tool for achieving gender equality, always combined with other concrete measures and policies aimed at promoting gender equality. Since 1996, the Commission has committed to a dual approach to achieving gender equality. This approach includes integrating a gender perspective into all policies and implementing specific measures to address, prevent or address gender inequality.  Since the EP adopted a resolution on gender equality in 2003, each parliamentary committee appoints one of its members responsible for gender equality. However, in order to reduce women's non-representation in key decision-making positions at political and administrative level, gender equality at staff level needs to be implemented equally. I therefore welcome the conclusions of the resolution and the emphasised need for gender-conscious amendments, gender impact assessments and gender budgeting to include a gender perspective at all levels, in all areas and at all stages of politics.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The report analyses the level of gender mainstreaming both at staff level and at Member level, in the work carried out in parliament committees and in ep activities.  The report notes that in the EP too, despite a broad set of recommendations, there are significant inequalities between men and women, with them representing the majority in the lower working group and being less represented at the level of intermediate and higher-grade managers. The report recommends gender mainstreaming in all aspects of EU policy and suggests measures to achieve it. Many of the recitals and proposals in the report are positive. Others refer to administrative measures that do not solve the deep problems of the identified inequalities. Moreover, the whole report sees the real causes that are at the root of inequalities between men and women. In addition, it omits the reality of another level of EP workers and the impact of the inequalities that occur there - cleaning, security, catering and other workers. We abstained.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ I commend the Parliament for the support that the report on Gender Mainstreaming in the Work of the Parliament was given today and am happy to be one amongst many voting favourably on the measures. Gender mainstreaming is an important tool for this institution to use in the movement towards better gender equality. Gender mainstreaming is the concept of assessing the different implications for women and men of any planned policy action, including legislation and programmes, in all areas and levels. Women have an important voice in Parliament and these measures, like stronger interinstitutional relations, will improve the gender balance in EU policy-making. The exchange with other institutions and organisations such as UN Women will assist the European Parliament in creating more tailor-made gender mainstreaming programs. The European Parliament is making great strides to gender equality and setting a high bar for other international institutions.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Equality between women and men is recognised by the EU as a fundamental right, a common value of the Union and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. In the European Parliament, the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) is the main body responsible for promoting gender equality and gender mainstreaming in all political and legislative processes in Parliament. Gender mainstreaming has a twofold dimension: integrating a gender perspective into the content of the various policies and addressing the issue of the representation of women and men in the various policy areas. Unfortunately, once again, the text presented to the plenary is affected by certain ideological visions that prevent the adoption of a balanced report. Therefore, despite the fact that I remain committed to the affirmation of real equality between men and women, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal on the inclusion of gender equality in the work of the European Parliament and consider this to be one of the priorities of the European Union. Achieving gender equality is not only one of the pillars of the protection of human rights, but it is also a fundamental issue for me, linked to the functioning of democracy and respect for the rule of law and social inclusion. The fight against gender discrimination for equal treatment in the labour market should continue to be an objective of the European Union as a whole, and my position towards the European Parliament in its efforts to integrate the gender perspective into all its committees is unequivocally positive. I believe that the principle of gender equality within the European Union should continue to be strengthened by legislation and treaty amendments, as should the European Parliament on equality issues in the future. Gender equality is also a key international objective for me, which should promote European integration. Measures must continue to be taken to close the gap and jointly combat gender segregation in the labour market.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report provides an opportunity to assess the results achieved and to propose new solutions to the gender mainstreaming policy plan for a period of three years, as mentioned in parliament's earlier resolutions on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. The report contains a number of controversial proposals, including the application of parity to the functions of ep committee chairs; gender budgeting; systematically assess the gender impact of new legislative proposals or Commission policy proposals; gender mainstreaming training for all EP staff (mandatory), as well as for Members, political group staff and parliamentary assistants (where available); guidelines for gender-neutral language and training for interpretation and translation services; numerous references to the situation of LGTBIQ persons. The whole plan for gender mainstreaming is not convincing, as there is no evidence that it actually improves the situation of women. For example, the main instrument of gender-sensitive amendments in most cases is to add a single word to an existing text, which is 'gender', 'women' or 'female/female'. This is a small help for women. I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. Unfortunately, I could not support this report. I am in favour of gender equality and support measures that will really improve the position of women in society. Unfortunately, what this proposal contains is not part of such measures. Moreover, for example, quotas for the representation of men and women in the Parliamentary Committees of the European Parliament go against democratic principles, where voters decide who to elect to the EP.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the topic regularly mentioned of the gender dimension in the work of the European Parliament. It is important to remember here that this issue should not only be dealt with in Parliament, but also in the Member States, following the principle of subsidiarity. Working for gender equality is an everyday struggle, in all places and all areas. Above all, however, measures must be adopted and the means implemented at the most appropriate levels, namely, the national level.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report called for 40% gender quotas, more gender programmes, changes to rules of procedure and gender budgeting internally within the EU Parliament. UKIP voted against the EU Parliament spending any more money on internal administration.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report reaffirming the integration of the gender perspective, adopted at international level, as a strategy leading to the achievement of equality between men and women. In practical terms, gender mainstreaming involves integrating it into the preparation, design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of policies, regulatory measures and spending programmes to promote equality between women and men and combat discrimination. This report states that, however, structural inequalities between men and women in society are still entrenched – even when legislation treats women and men on an equal footing, women still do not have the same access or control over resources and assets. Therefore, the current situation shows that it is essential that the content of policies is gender-sensitive for a good equality strategy.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. I have more than once advocated the need for gender mainstreaming, gender impact assessment and a gender budget in all policy areas and at all levels of the European Union. This is the only way to combat the many inequalities that persist and it is up to us to set an example.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to integrate the gender perspective into the work of the European Parliament and in all aspects of EU intervention, as well as in the preparation, design, implementation, control and evaluation of policies, legal provisions and expenditure programming, in order to achieve equality between women and men.  I also believe that the achievement of this objective effectively contributes to the usual practice of each parliamentary committee appointing one of its members as responsible for gender mainly, the creation of a "gender mains integration network" that meets several times a year, and the High-Level Group on Gender Equality , which also meets on a regular basis. Both agencies are supported by the report, which also stresses the need to make 'amendments for gender mains integration', amendments which the FEMM Commission draws up to incorporate the gender perspective into the reports of other parliamentary committees.  The report also defends gender impact assessments and gender budgeting budgets.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Asylum policies and procedures, including the assessment of asylum claims, must take gender equality into account. Gender-based forms of violence, including rape, sexual violence, female genital mutilation, forced marriage and domestic violence, should be a valid reason for seeking asylum in the EU, says the text of the report we voted on yesterday in plenary session.  The text also recommends various measures to ensure that women's specific needs are respected throughout the asylum procedure and in reception centres, including: separate housing and sanitation facilities for men and women; female translators and interpreters; specialized trauma counselling services for women who have experienced gender-based violence; child care during selection and asylum interviews; providing information to women about their right to apply for asylum independent of their spouse's and to have legal status independent of that of their spouse; training that takes into account the specifics of women and men for staff and legal aid for women in reception centres.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. Gender mainstreaming brings double benefits: this not only guarantees equal opportunities, but also demonstrates an example of good practice for other institutions and Member States.  It is true that, although participation statistics are one, it would always be without prejudice to the fact how the gender dimension relates to the content of policies, how it can be used best, while at the same time not folding the stick towards the implementation of the equality criteria.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this report, which takes stock and looks at the perspectives on the integration of gender equality into the various policies of the European Union, through the work of the Parliamentary Committees of the European Parliament. The text also provides an update on the representation of women in Parliament's teams.  In the end, the text encourages Parliament to take into account the dimension of gender equality in the work of all parliamentary committees and to continue its actions.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution because it is essential to promote the main translating of the gender perspective into all of Parliament's policies, as well as the momentum and promotion of women in the decision-making spaces in which they are underrepresented. This report raises the need to implement a strategy for the development of gender mains mains, through tools such as "gender mains mains integration amendments", gender impact assessment reports and gender-sensitive budgets. To improve the integration of the gender perspective into all policies, the report proposes further developing gender mains tools and also calls on the Commission to make gender impact assessments in new legislative proposals to ensure that the EU is active in defending women's rights.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. We in the European Parliament have introduced a strategy to achieve equality between men and women in parliament. Equality between peoples is a fundamental right, which is why I support the agreement.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I abstained from the report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament because, on the one hand, I believe that this issue is important, but on the other hand I do not fully agree with the content of the report.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes the integration of the gender perspective into all policies and, therefore, to continue to take steps forward in favour of gender equality, through specific measures to eliminate, prevent or remedy gender inequalities. The Resolution emphasizes the need for gender mainstreaming amendments, a gender assessment and a gender budget to integrate the gender perspective into all policies. It also stresses that greater cooperation between the committees is necessary. The report calls for a roadmap on gender equality, indicating how to increase female representation in middle and high command positions by up to 40% by 2020. It also urges the Commission to assess the gender perspective in the new policy or legislative proposals in order to ensure that the European Union supports women's rights.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report called for 40% gender quotas, more gender programmes, changes to rules of procedure and gender budgeting internally within the EU Parliament. UKIP voted against the EU Parliament spending any more money on internal administration.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today is International Women’s Day and I could not think of a more appropriate time to have this report placed in front of the chamber. Gender inequality, in my view – a view that is shared by many of my colleagues in the S&D and in the EPLP, as well as across the chamber – can only be overcome if it is tackled in a holistic way: addressing every aspect of our lives. This innovation of gender-mainstreaming is a great tool which seeks to include a gender perspective in policy-making at all levels. It will ensure that women, and persons of all gender identities, are equally represented in decision-making. As a co-legislator of European laws, effective gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament is key.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ The adopted non-legislative resolution on gender mainstreaming in the work of the EP aims to promote, according to the literal text, 'the rights, perspectives and well-being of LGBTIQ people as well as persons of all gender identities'. Also, 'all eu internal and external policies should be designed to equally support boys and girls, men and women, as well as other gender identities'. What gender identities do the authors of the proposal have in mind? Existing or some new one that anyone can come up with at any time? The resolution also calls for the strengthening of current and new gender access instruments to be introduced in all areas of work of the EP, committees, political factions and delegations. Including the senseless establishment of an internal monitoring body. According to the approved report, funding for regular gender equality training should be allocated to MEPs, assistants and political group staff. It also calls for the use of 'gender-neutral expression' and calls for 'specific training courses on the use of gender-neutral language for translation and interpretation services'. How much money will be wasted to implement and control compliance with all these nonsensical proposals and also to the unnecessary bureaucratic burden associated with it? I find it completely pointless to promote such absurd proposals and undemocratic measures. I voted against.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒I supported this proposal for a regulation as gender mainstreaming is a means to achieve gender equality. This policy should include the rights, perspectives and well-being of LGBTIQ people and people of all gender identities. The Regulation calls for the continued development of the gender mainstreaming network, from committees to each Member and their alternates individually, in order to improve cooperation and gender mainstreaming development. Interinstitutional cooperation on this issue plays a major role, as the involvement of several institutions would ensure the inclusion of gender policies in all phases of the political cycle. Research into the progress of the development of this policy is an important segment of this Regulation, which has identified a certificate for the allocation of additional resources for the purpose of drawing up assessments of the impact of policies on genders and gender-based analysis. Regular training of Parliament's staff is also the objective of this regulation, designed to cover employees in medium and senior management positions. By coordinated work, both political groups and committees, the European Parliament can demonstrate its role as an institution acting when it comes to gender equality in decision-makers.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ The EU's progress on gender equality is stagnating and at the current rate it will take some time for gender equality to be achieved. We can say the same in the application of gender equality in the work of the European Parliament. The EU recognises equality between women and men as a fundamental right, a common EU value and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. Within the EP, the committee on women's rights and gender equality is the main body responsible for promoting gender equality and gender mainstreaming in all EP policies and legislative procedures. Since 2009, the EP has established a network of Members responsible for gender mainstreaming within committees, as well as another staff-level network. Network members meet regularly, share information on up-to-date files and propose best practices for gender mainstreaming.  However, it has to be said that structural gender differences are still entrenched in our society. Although laws treat women and men equally, women still do not have equal access to or control over resources and property. The current situation therefore shows that the content of gender-sensitive policies is an essential element of a proper gender equality strategy.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has adopted a report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. I did not vote in favour of this report because I consider some of the provisions adopted to be unacceptable, particularly in terms of expanding unnecessary bureaucracy. I supported amendments to ensure a balanced representation of women and men in the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, a higher representation of women in the leadership positions of the EP administration (objective 40%). I also supported the provisions under which the European Parliament is to create better conditions for reconciling work and family life. I voted in favour of the deletion of the provisions on the accreditation of gender courses and gender-neutral language, which were eventually deleted. Since the vote in plenary did not delete such nonsensical proposals as the establishment of a 'permanent rapporteur' function for gender equality or the monitoring of the gender aspect in all committees, including the development of action plans, the network of rapporteurs and the gender training of all staff and Members, I could not vote in favour of this resolution. It will now be interesting to see the implementation of this resolution. A visible step should be to achieve gender parity in the FEMM Committee, which I am very much in support of and will be happy to give my seat to one of my male colleagues for the second half of the parliamentary term.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Union recognises equality between women and men as a fundamental right and a common value of the EU. At international level, gender mainstreaming is adopted as a strategy for the realisation of gender equality. In practice, this means taking into account the gender perspective when preparing, implementing and evaluating policies, regulatory measures and programmes with the aim of supporting equality between women and men and promoting the fight against discrimination. In 1996, the Commission introduced a dual approach: integrating the gender perspective into all policies while implementing measures to tackle gender inequalities. Since 2009, a gender mainstreaming network has been established in the European Parliament, involving some Members and some of the staff of the European Parliament. All members of the Network were able to reply to a questionnaire, which then produced a report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. They found that there are some examples of good practices, but could improve coordination, either within Parliament or cooperation with other institutions. On the basis of the replies, it is proposed that a procedure for gender mainstreaming should be entered in the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. I believe it is important to promote activities for gender mainstreaming, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Angelika Mlinar, member of the FEMM Committee, aims to introduce the concept of gender mainstreaming in all European Parliament policies and actions, both at political and working level. This includes a strict quota system for the filling of posts, the inclusion of the so-called gender perspective in all the activities of parliamentary staff, the creation of a separate 'network for gender mainstreaming', a permanent rapporteur on the subject and the elimination of alleged disadvantages for women in the day-to-day work of the European Parliament. This report is superfluous, speaks out against an excessive bureaucracy and seeks to replace the principle of performance with a technocratically arranged filling of posts. It is to be assumed that the proposals contained in the report by the FEMM Committee aim to compensate for its lack of practical legitimacy by introducing gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament.  That is why I did not vote in favour of this report.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. The N-VA delegation abstained in voting on this report.  The N-VA stands for an inclusive society with equal rights and obligations for all, as well as an equal opportunities policy tailored to and with attention to all diverse target groups. This applies to all genders, especially women and girls, but also to people with disabilities, older people, LGBTIQ's, etc. Infringements of this equality, both at work and in private, are not acceptable to us, including within the European Parliament. .  At the same time, the N-VA delegation is concerned that some of the measures proposed in the report could lead to even more bureaucracy and an increase in the budget. They do not address the causes of discrimination and inequality.  The N-VA believes that a structural solution must be found and that, for example, the appointment of a permanent rapporteur on gender mainstreaming is not the answer to a more woman-friendly European legislation.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of this report. Gender inequality can only be overcome if it is tackled holistically in all areas of life, and in all areas of decision-making. Gender mainstreaming is one of the great policy innovations of the European Union, and it seeks to include a gender perspective in policy-making at all levels, and also ensure that women, and persons of all gender identities are equally represented in decision-making. As a co-legislator of European laws, effective gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament is key.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. The definition of gender equality is broader than equality, namely formal-legal equality and real equality in everyday life. Little progress has been made in recent years, but there are still many shortcomings. Research shows that in October 2013, 17.8 per cent of board members in europe's leading companies were women. If there were no activity at European Union level, such as the European Strategy for Gender Equality and the legislative initiative on women's quotas on boards, there would be less than 14 per cent. Reducing the gender gap is an area where the EU needs to play a prominent and important role, as there is too little action at the end of the chain.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the draft report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament, as I believe that there is still no need to create new instruments or institutions to address the issue of gender equality. The issue of gender equality has existing institutions in their content of work, and the fulfilment of this principle is the task of all institutions incoerition, not just those responsible for its implementation. As before in similar cases, the principle of subsidiarity, which must be respected in this area, should be recalled in this context.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Gender mainstreaming in the preparation, planning, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of policies, regulatory measures and expenditure programmes, with a view to promoting equality between women and men and combating discrimination, is a positive thing. The report proposes measures aimed at enhancing and increasing the effectiveness and efficiency of the existing structure of gender mainstreaming. However, what is overlooked in the report is that gender parity cannot be conceived in the context of policies promoted daily by the EU.  The report does propose measures which may improve the question of parity to some extent, but unfortunately these proposals cannot coexist and improve further over time because of the other measures promoted by the EU. So there is no point in talking about equal treatment between men and women if we do not fight at the same time to strengthen the rights of all people. However, the text contains many positive references which we cannot ignore. That is why we voted in favour.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report essentially discriminates on the basis of sex, does not promote meritocracy but instead introduces quotas, a measure that has proved counterproductive over time. A proper report would instead promote equal opportunities, the only real equality.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, since equality between women and men is a fundamental right recognised by the EU, a common value and a necessary condition for achieving the EU's objectives. Gender equality is key to the protection of human rights, the functioning of democracy, respect for the rule of law and economic growth, social inclusion and sustainability. The principle of gender mainstreaming and the desire to eliminate all forms of discrimination against women are already internationally accepted strategies. Nevertheless, the enforcement of equality between women and men is one of the main weaknesses listed in the European Commission's assessment of the Gender Equality Strategy for the period 2010-2015. In my opinion, the European Parliament has a key role to play in addressing gender inequalities. On a practical level, this means promoting equal economic, social and political participation of women and men and extending the gender equality policy framework. The proposal strengthens and improves the current structure for gender mainstreaming, including through the establishment of a robust interinstitutional network, both for enhanced cooperation with national parliaments, regular exchanges and contacts, and for establishing a stable link with the EP High Level Group on Gender Equality and Diversity.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Equality between women and men is a fundamental right, a common value of the European Union and a prerequisite for achieving the EU's objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. There is no doubt that for centuries women have been discriminated against and treated much worse than men. Moreover, unfortunately, ladies still face problems, barriers and obvious inequality in many areas.  Promoting gender equality is more than a ban on discrimination on grounds of sex. Positive actions in support of women are the basis for women's full inclusion in the labour market, social life and political or economic decisions. However, the fight for equality must not be conducted mindlessly and at any cost. It cannot be imposed that the question of competence or ordinary human trust should be less important than arithmetic proportions, as would be the case with the mandatory introduction of quotas in the average and high management posts in the European Parliament. It would also be a bad idea for political groups to present candidates not in terms of knowledge, experience (and therefore competence) but gender as chair chairs in parliamentary committees, groups or delegations. An even less understandable demand is the assessment of the Union budget in terms of the implementation of gender equality. That is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report describes the implementation situation of measures to ensure gender mainstreaming within the work of the European Parliament. Gender mainstreaming is the set of measures and policies adopted to ensure gender equality between men and women in legislative processes. The resolution shows that there is still a situation of inequality between men and women in Parliament. There is still a lot of work to be done to achieve satisfactory objectives. In fact, it is noted that only some committees are more active in this regard, while others have not yet implemented the necessary measures. The report called for greater efforts between the institutions to achieve the objectives set, such as greater inter-institutional cooperation to support gender mainstreaming, as well as more funds and specific budget lines. I therefore vote in favour of the report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for this text, the content of which should be self-evident... The Charter of Fundamental Rights contains specific provisions on the cross-cutting principle of gender equality and Article 6 of the EU Treaty gives this charter the same legal value as treaties. Attitudes need to change, we need to push for this change that will not happen on its own.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament, as I believe it is an essential step towards achieving real equality between men and women. This report has the ambition of integrating a gender perspective into the content of the laws and promoting gender equality in the administration and the decision-making process surrounding the law. While I believe that the European Parliament should set an example for other European and national institutions to follow, I decided to vote against the creation of a post of standing rapporteur on gender mainstreaming as I do not see the added value and it would create more bureaucracy.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament, as I believe that the principle promotes the fight against discrimination on the basis of sex. There are still gender inequalities, particularly in leadership positions. We must abandon the stereotypes that arise in politics, entrepreneurship and society and allow women to participate more in decision-making. Gender equality, and thus greater women's involvement, is, in my view, a path to a more competitive and fairer Europe.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution because it is essential to promote the main translating of the gender perspective into all of Parliament's policies, as well as the momentum and promotion of women in the decision-making spaces in which they are underrepresented. This report raises the need to implement a strategy for the development of gender mains mains, through tools such as "gender mains mains integration amendments", gender impact assessment reports and gender-sensitive budgets. To improve the integration of the gender perspective into all policies, the report proposes further developing gender mains tools and also calls on the Commission to make gender impact assessments in new legislative proposals to ensure that the EU is active in defending women's rights.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Angelika Mlinar, member of the FEMM Committee, aims to introduce the concept of gender mainstreaming in all European Parliament policies and actions, both at political and working level. This includes a strict quota system for the filling of posts, the inclusion of the so-called gender perspective in all the activities of parliamentary staff, the creation of a separate 'network for gender mainstreaming', a permanent rapporteur on the subject and the elimination of alleged disadvantages for women in the day-to-day work of the European Parliament. This report is superfluous, speaks out against an excessive bureaucracy and seeks to replace the principle of performance with a technocratically arranged filling of posts. It is to be assumed that the proposals contained in the report by the FEMM Committee aim to compensate for its lack of practical legitimacy by introducing gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament.  That is why I did not vote in favour of this report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Today is a good day to vindicate the equality of gender, also in the European Parliament. Not only in the civil service organisation but also in the political groups, since the prospect of the integration of gender equality has two dimensions: integrate the gender perspective in the different political decisions as well as the deal with the representation of women and men in the political arena. Unfortunately, no plan of action on this subject has been discussed or adopted and there remains much work to be done. I desire that we can be an example and demonstrate that there is no distance between the proposals and the facts.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The "gender" dimension focuses only on sexual orientation. An area that should remain only in the private sphere and should not be subject to special treatment.  The identity of human beings is not determined by their sexual practices.  A policy is even less defined based on the sexual behaviour of individuals. Promoting rights based on particular sexual behaviour is the starting point of communitarianism that the National Front rejects.   So I'm voting against it.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the integration of the gender perspective into the work of the European Parliament, as achieving gender equality is essential for the protection of human rights, the functioning of democracy and social inclusion. Currently, the presence of women in key administrative and political decision-making positions, as well as in political groups in the European Parliament, remains low.  Within the European Parliament, the Committee on Human Rights and Gender Equality is the central body responsible for the promotion and integration of gender equality in the political and legislative processes of the European Parliament. However, all committees should actively participate in this process, and in this respect should adopt their own action plan. From this point of view, the establishment of a permanent rapporteur for gender mainstreaming is particularly important for achieving the objectives of gender mainstreaming. Moreover, the action should not be limited to the European Parliament. In this respect, I believe that there should be an ongoing dialogue with national parliaments in order to ensure an exchange of views and practices with a view to promoting the integration of the gender perspective into the - better coordinated - work of European legislative for a.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The principle of gender mainstreaming is already an internationally accepted strategy for achieving gender equality. Gender generalisation means, in practice, integrating the gender dimension into the process of designing, developing, implementing, monitoring and evaluating policies, regulatory measures and spending programmes, with a aim of promoting equality between men and women and the fight against discrimination. In order to promote this, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution because it is essential to promote the main translating of the gender perspective into all of Parliament's policies, as well as the momentum and promotion of women in the decision-making spaces in which they are underrepresented. This report raises the need to implement a strategy for the development of gender mains mains, through tools such as "gender mains mains integration amendments", gender impact assessment reports and gender-sensitive budgets. To improve the integration of the gender perspective into all policies, the report proposes further developing gender mains tools and also calls on the Commission to make gender impact assessments in new legislative proposals to ensure that the EU is active in defending women's rights.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it calls for the inclusion of gender mainstreaming in the Rules of Procedure as the process of Gender mainstreaming has to be formalised in order to comply with Article 8 TFEU that makes this process a legal obligation: ‘In all its activities, the Union shall aim to eliminate inequalities, and to promote equality , between men and women.’

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I believe that stronger interinstitutional relations will improve gender balance in EU policy-making; I recommend that the European Ombudsman provide data on complaints about maladministration to parliament's High Level Group on Gender Equality and Diversity once a year.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on Gender Mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. Gender mainstreaming represents the integration of a gender viewpoint into the preparation, design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of policies, regulatory measures and spending programmes. The goal is to promote equality between women and men, and combat discrimination. The report calls for continuing expansion of the gender mainstreaming system and its regular monitoring across policy areas. It appeals for the creation of a supporting environment for women to take part in decision-making positions at all levels and underlines the importance of measures for the reconciliation of work and private and family life. Particular emphasis is placed on the importance of a constant struggle and continuing work towards gender equality.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a report seeking the integration of the gender perspective into the various Union policies through parliamentary committees, Staff of the European Parliament and gender equality in management positions. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to integrate the gender perspective into the work of the European Parliament and in all aspects of EU intervention, as well as in the preparation, design, implementation, control and evaluation of policies, legal provisions and expenditure programming, in order to achieve equality between women and men.  I also believe that the achievement of this objective effectively contributes to the usual practice of each parliamentary committee appointing one of its members as responsible for gender mainly, the creation of a "gender mains integration network" that meets several times a year, and the High-Level Group on Gender Equality , which also meets on a regular basis. Both agencies are supported by the report, which also stresses the need to make 'amendments for gender mains integration', amendments which the FEMM Commission draws up to incorporate the gender perspective into the reports of other parliamentary committees.  The report also defends gender impact assessments and gender budgeting budgets.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'Gender equality may be recognised in our European Union as a fundamental right, gender inequality still exists in our society today.  I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the integration of a gender perspective must be a necessary part of all forms of policy-making and an absolute prerequisite for creating equal opportunities between men and women. The European Parliament must therefore implement the principle of gender mainstreaming in its work. In this respect, this report is therefore a necessary step in the right direction.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This report is part of one of two reports voted symbolically on 8 March, International Women's Law Day. Even though equality between women and men is recognised by the EU as a fundamental right, much remains to be done even in the European Parliament to truly guarantee this right.  The report highlights the need to integrate a gender perspective into all policies, while also implementing "gender tools" and specific measures to eliminate, prevent or compensate for gender inequalities. The report calls for more cooperation between parliamentary committees and calls for the establishment of a high-level group to propose an action plan to strengthen women's representation by 40% by 2020, particularly in management positions. It also calls on the Commission to conduct gender impact studies on new legislative or political proposals to ensure that the EU is truly working towards gender equality. I am pleased that all the amendments that my group has tabled with the Greens and the Socialists to improve the text have been adopted. I voted for this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The level of gender mainstreaming in parliamentary committees, as well as at staff level in EP activities, is examined in this report. The aim is to mainstream the gender perspective in all aspects of EU policy. Several measures are pointed out for their implementation. The EP's organisational structure has different bodies responsible for the development and effective integration of gender, both at policy level and at professional level. However, it is clear that, among EP officials, the majority of women remain in the group of assistant roles, and that, regrettably, the objectives of gender balance at head level, intermediate and higher grade, adopted in 2006, have not been achieved by the end of the term (2009), not even until this year. That is, there will still be much to do.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The argument that an expansion of gender mainstreaming in the EU institutions has a positive impact on gender mainstreaming in the Member States is more than questionable. I am also opposed to gender mainstreaming, and so I voted against it.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament because I believe that the institutions must be an example to follow. With this text, we are calling on the Commission, when it presents a new legislative proposal, to conduct a gender-based impact assessment. Furthermore, as co-chairman of the LGBTI Intergroup, I can only welcome the part of the text relating to the suggestion, in the field of human resources management, to draw up guidelines sensitive to LGBTQI issues, in order to improve well-being in the workplace. LGBTI women and people are fighting the same fight to end discrimination.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. I voted against this motion because it is not only about gender equality, but also involves bisexuals and transsexuals. From an ethical point of view, the report is also incompatible, because a 'normal' woman should not be treated as a lesbian.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted against the Mlinar report. The best part is that gender mainstreaming ideologues have now laid down their strategy of social management of values and norms in the internal processes of the EU Parliament in black and white. As of today, the countless eu-romantic pan-Europeans of the old parties can no longer dismiss the gender mainstreaming measures of the EU institutions as malicious anti-EU rumours. Thanks to the Mlinar report, these measures can be substantiated. The report adopted by the Committee on Women's Affairs and Women's Policy illustrates with a graph how the various elements of control interact. The EU Parliament outperforms itself in internal gender regulation frenzy. The Women's Committee is not responsible for internal processes. That is the responsibility of the Bureau, that is to say President Schulz and its Vice-Presidents. Finally, even the EU Commission is taking a position in plenary on how the EU Parliament intends to take internal gender measures. It is so incomprehensible that it must be recalled before the next elections. An alternative motion for a resolution was tabled by the soloist of the Family Party. Nobody took note of this motion, not even the members of their own group, and it was lost abruptly. But that is the way it is, if you are more concerned with setting the mood against the AfD in your own group before the state elections, and obviously do not have the necessary support in civil society.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Gender inequality can only be overcome if it is tackled holistically in all areas of life, and in all areas of decision-making. Gender mainstreaming is one of the great policy innovations of the European Union, and it seeks to include a gender perspective in policy-making at all levels, and also ensure that women, and persons of all gender identities are equally represented in decision-making.  As a co-legislator of European laws, effective gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament is key, and I hope it will have far-reaching effects on the EU’s promotion of gender equality in Europe. I worked on this report and am therefore delighted it has been adopted by a large majority. I look forward to working with my colleagues across political groups and with Parliament’s secretariats to implement the proposals we have now committed to, and hope to encourage Member States to follow suit.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 On International Women's Day, I particularly appreciated the reports on the subject of gender: the road to full equality between men and women is still very long and we still have to work on a daily basis in order to achieve the objectives we have set ourselves. The gender issue is not exclusive to women: it concerns the quality of life of all citizens, the need to develop a labour market that protects the rights of families and leisure, and sustainable economic growth. That is why I voted in favour of the report on gender work in Parliament. In essence, the European institutions are being asked to step up their attention to this issue by defining a legislative process that increasingly takes into account the opinion of the FEMM Committee on equality between women and men. This step is necessary because, despite many statements, the European Union is still struggling to use gender perspective in its day-to-day activities.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I did not support the report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. Although, as Vice-Chair of the FEMM Committee, I support gender equality in all sensible ways, I do not think that it was this report that contained effective solutions. In my opinion, it is necessary to look for real measures and activities that will help women to achieve equality, rather than mindlessly promoting ideological proposals of the type of gender training for Parliament's staff, or gender quotas, not to mention other proposals that went all the way to absurdities.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The problem of gender inequality is one of many that cannot be solved by creating absurd regulations that contradict common sense. The report on which we voted today is an example of the activity of our House, which contributes to perpetuating the opinion of the European Union, as the source of many nonsensical ideas. Gender ideology is not conducive to solving existing problems, but it creates a climate of absurdity and ridicules the efforts of those communities that really fight discrimination against women.  As a Member of Polish I am familiar with this climate of legal absurdities from the era of real socialism, when the Communist government sought manifestos or special resolutions to regulate matters that did not require such regulation. This has ridiculed both decision-makers and public institutions, and I am afraid that a similar fate may also be encountered by the European Parliament. Gender mainstreaming in every element of parliamentary work, document or regulation in literally every element of parliamentary work is ridiculous, which will undoubtedly increase bureaucracy but will not produce real results.  But should we not pursue the opposite situation, in which the gender aspect ceases to be the subject of quarrels and disputes? Tracking down discrimination in every legal act and organising ideological training for MEPs and MEPs will not improve the fate of women, but it will certainly improve the well-being of some of my colleagues on the left side of the chamber. I voted against this ridiculous report.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. The report notes that the representation of women in key decision-making positions at political and administrative level, including in Parliament's political groups, remains low and calls for the removal of structural barriers to gender mainstreaming. As I support efforts to create an environment in which women can compete for decision-making positions at all levels, I supported the report.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I think that this report is very important and I would like to explain briefly why I voted in favour. Today we have also seen a debate in this House which shows how serious the risks of racism and xenophobia are in this fortress Europe, which repels people with barbed walls and wire and new fences.  We know that we are talking about a migratory phenomenon in which we cannot distinguish between asylum seekers, political refugees, economic migrants: we are talking about women and men seeking a worthy life. Precisely, women and men. A very different migratory phenomenon from previous ones in which the prevalence of male migration was usually a very significant factor.  Today we see entire families: women, men, boys and girls who cross borders and risk their lives on a daily basis. That is why it is important – and this report does so appropriately – to analyse and respond to this phenomenon also from a gender perspective.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Madam President, let me quote section 13 of this extremely scary Honeyball report: ‘gendered forms of violence and discrimination constitute persecution and should be valid reasons for seeking asylum in the EU.’ There is the trick. In all the countries of origin of the present invasion of Europe, there is obviously significant discrimination against women. This discrimination is a basis for asylum, as Ms Honeyball wants us to accept, so basically every woman has the right to come to the EU and then she has a similarly enforceable right to family reunification. So, all the doors are open. Europe is open. Anybody can come to Europe. Watch out for this very scary report.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, I am proud that the European Parliament is speaking up for one of the most vulnerable groups in our society, female refugees, and I congratulate my colleague Mary Honeyball, who has steered this report through  Parliament. Girl and women refugees arriving on European shores now outnumber men and, as if having to flee the horrors of war was not bad enough, they have additional risk and hardships to face just because they are women: sexual abuse, violence and discrimination. The measures needed to protect these mothers, daughters and sisters are clear: asylum procedures that take their vulnerability into account, better cooperation between EU Member States to tackle human traffickers, and organising reception facilities in a way that allows women to sleep and shower separately. I am shocked by some on the Right who have attempted to thwart action to protect these women on account of events elsewhere.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Madam President, Donald Tusk's words still ring in my ears last Thursday, when I recommended to what he called 'illegal economic migrants' that they stay in their countries and not come to the European Union. These words are a death sentence for thousands of people fleeing war, horror and deprivation of rights, but people are also not illegal. On the contrary, they are eded by international law. Since January, 55% of people fleeing are refugees, facing risks in their countries of origin, during transit and in the country of destination, such as violence, trafficking, exploitation, health risks, among others, which are aggravated in the case of women. Humanitarian corridors need to be opened and legally and safely easier to access these risks.  I voted in favour of this report because it is another step to incorporate a human rights approach and protect women in the light of their specific needs, but it is also essential to put in place measures to ensure the integration of refugees.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr These are just official data that, between the beginning of 2015 and November 2015, 38% of all refugees who applied for asylum in the European Union are women and children, and from January this year only more than 55% of women and children in Greece. Clearly, women, children, old men are the most vulnerable in society, especially in situations of military conflict. Consequently, we must show and create all the conditions for all human rights to be exercised and respected against this category as well, because it is the most discriminated against– women and children. I welcome the objectives proposed in the report, which are precisely the subject of this aspect, and it is clear that we in the European Union must do everything in order for the high human rights standards that are within our Union to be applied absolutely to all people. Thank you!

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – I share the fact that women who find themselves in the situation of refugees seeking asylum are particularly vulnerable. Especially if they are also mothers. I admire these women and agree that they deserve special attention and protection. However, I could not support the resolution tabled, because these women have once again become hostages in an ideological struggle for the value of every human life, even one that has not yet been born. Offering women a 100% discount on abortion instead of help and support is a sign of cynicism. To those who propose it, it is not about freeing a woman, but about enslaving them. And I'll never be involved in that.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: – Madam President, we voted in favour of this report because today, 8 March, and with thousands of women trapped at the borders, we must remember that the Europe of walls, the Europe of fences, the Europe which condemns migrants illegality is the Europe complicit in the labour and sexual exploitation of these women.  Women struggling to survive bombs, poverty, misery; women who stop evictions in Spain, such as PAH partners; women fighting the occupation of their territories, such as Palestinians and Saharawis; women fighting the Dáesh, such as Kurdish militiamen; or all those that in Latin America fight against the criminal practices of multinationals, such as indigenous leader Berta Cáceres, murdered in Honduras.  Rebels and feminists, because without equality there is no emancipation.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on a report on the situation of women refugees in the EU. It goes without saying that women migrants are particularly vulnerable, and it is also obvious that migration policy needs to be analysed from a gender perspective. I therefore voted in favour of the report. Furthermore, I agree with the report's call for legal routes for migrants and for a redistribution mechanism between EU Member States. With regard to the report's wordingon migrants' access to sexual and reproductive health in the Member States, I maintain my view that the EU should respect the fact that responsibility for health policy belongs at national level.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 All refugees unfortunately face great difficulties and hardships, but women, often victims of gender-based violence and discrimination, are certainly the most vulnerable. Creating secure access routes to combat illegal trafficking in human beings must, in view of recent events at Europe's borders, be a priority. The EU must commit itself not only to defining and extending cases justifying asylum applications, such as rape, forced marriages or honour killings, but also to setting up a system of reception and medical care, in accordance with respect for human rights. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this report, trusting in the power and willingness of the institutions to work to improve the plight of refugee women and asylum seekers.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. While we absolutely sympathise the sentiments of the report regarding those who have suffered abuse and persecution and the need to make sure that decent care and facilities are available, the report also called for legal routes for asylum in to the EU, an expansion of the EU migration and asylum policies and more burden sharing of refugees between all Member States. The EU has caused this crisis and is putting everyone at risk, so UKIP voted against further expansion of EU control.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is important that asylum policies and procedures are gender sensitive. 55% of refugees arriving in Europe are women, girls and children. To ensure that women's specific needs are addressed, gender-specific training, including gender-based violence, needs to be promoted for staff; sanitary facilities and gender-segregated rooms; guarantee the right to request female interviewers and interpreters; ensure access to women's health services; provide childcare services during exams and interviews; inform women of their right to file an independent asylum application, etc.  It is also urgent that there be no further internment of children, pregnant women and survivors of rape, sexual assault and trafficking. And, of course, measures are needed for the integration of refugee women and asylum seekers into the labour market. The solution to the refugee crisis is not to return them to Turkey, but to create legal avenues of immigration and implement integration policies. The dignity of the European project based on the principles of solidarity, justice and equality is at stake.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. While we absolutely sympathise the sentiments of the report regarding those who have suffered abuse and persecution and the need to make sure that decent care and facilities are available, the report also called for legal routes for asylum in to the EU, an expansion of the EU migration and asylum policies and more burden sharing of refugees between all Member States. The EU has caused this crisis and is putting everyone at risk, so UKIP voted against further expansion of EU control.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this progressive report which was concerned with the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers. Recent research conducted by Amnesty International shows that women and girl refugees face violence, assault, exploitation and sexual harassment at every stage of their journey, including on European soil.
