The organisation interviewed 40 refugee women and girls in northern Europe in December 2015 who travelled from Turkey to Greece and then across the Balkans. All the women described feeling threatened and unsafe during the journey. Many reported that in almost all of the countries they passed through they experienced physical abuse and financial exploitation, being groped or pressured to have sex by smugglers, security staff or other refugees. It is absolutely unacceptable that after living through the horrors of the war in Iraq and Syria these women have risked everything to find safety for themselves and their children, but from the moment they begin this journey they are again exposed to violence and exploitation, with little support or protection.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 This report from the European Parliament refers to the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU. During 2015, around 1 million people crossed the Mediterranean, 35% of whom were women and children. In January 2016, women made up 55%. This report I voted for highlightes the extremely precarious situation in which women refugees and asylum seekers find themselves and calls for an acceleration of political processes to take more account of the risks faced by women (trafficking in human beings, sexual violence, female genital mutilation, etc.) and their needs (access to medical services, prenatal and postnatal care) , provision of a security service during interviews, etc.).  The Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats calls through the report for measures to ensure gender sensitivity in the asylum process.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. With this resolution, Parliament voted in favour of reforming migration and refugee policies with regard to gender-based measures. It was particularly important to guarantee the safety of female asylum seekers, who often travel with young children. In view of the difficult situation of female refugees, I believe that the procedures and examination of asylum applications must take into account gender-specific elements, such as .B the provision of female interlocutors and interpreters. That is why I supported this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Mrs Honeyball's report on the "situation of refugee and asylum-seeking women in the EU" is a new call for mass immigration of "refugees" who are in fact the vast majority of economic immigrants. In the end, there is little talk about women. A highlight for a report voted on Women's Day! The report further states that there can be no smugglers, no human trafficking, no abuse if immigration is totally legal and without hindrance... which is to say that there would be no thieves if the theft was allowed!  The report does not forget to focus on LGBTI rights. Of course, the report does not seek to understand why only 15% of immigrants who arrived in Europe in 2015 are women. As for European women who were attacked by immigrants at the beginning of the year, this is not a single question in the text. The rapporteur also forgets to point out that as many as 10,000 immigrant minors have vanished into the wild.  I therefore naturally voted against this very strongly oriented and ideologized report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I have the greatest possible concern for the plight of all those fleeing war and persecution, primarily from Syria, I feel that this report spectacularly misses the point. Women and children are often left behind, both in Syria and in refugee camps, whilst those who undertake dangerous journeys across Europe from safe country to safe country at the hands of smugglers are predominantly male. This leaves women at far greater risk in their country of origin and in refugee camps, and therefore any report on the situation of women refugees should consider what steps can be taken to tackle this situation. Instead, it focuses on other issues and neglects those who have not arrived within Europe. Once again this is a ‘little European’ report which fails to understand the global issue.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. \u2012 On the issue of refugees and asylum seekers in the EU from the point of view of women, this report contributes to the progress of this discussion, which is so important at the moment, and shows particular care when it highlights the problems that a certain "gender blindness" can mean for women who, by fleeing societies that discriminate against them in such a cruel and inhumane way , they deserve special precautions from those who welcome them so that they are not victims of other forms of discrimination. I will vote in favour because it not only draws attention to specific problems that lead women to apply for asylum, in the case of those fleeing to not be victims of genital mutilation, but also contains recommendations to facilitate a set of inclusive conditions for them by the host countries and to show that they understand the diversity of problems and needs that afflict people arriving in the EU in this situation. I conclude by highlighting my agreement with the rapporteur when she says that the current humanitarian crisis causes gender inequalities to be intensified and that we must do even more to harmonise good practices in the treatment of women asylum seekers and refugees.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Mary Honeyball’s report on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU. Unfortunately, we are not close to resolving the migrant crisis, nor will the recent agreement with Turkey be a lasting solution. In the meanwhile, there has been a concerning development in the migrant crisis: the majority of those fleeing to Europe are now women and children. They are particularly vulnerable. Children are disappearing by the thousands and women face discrimination, violence and are sexually harassed. Moreover, women are being coerced into sexual acts or they have to resort to prostitution to pay for their travels. Childcare is another issue to consider. Furthermore, integration might be more difficult for women. Some did not have access to a proper education and have little or no experience on the labour market. Thus, I support this resolution, because it reflects those additional problems and underlines that women need safer alternatives.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is important that asylum policies and procedures are gender sensitive. 55% of refugees arriving in Europe are women, girls and children. To ensure that women's specific needs are addressed, gender-specific training, including gender-based violence, needs to be promoted for staff; sanitary facilities and gender-segregated rooms; guarantee the right to request female interviewers and interpreters; ensure access to women's health services; provide childcare services during exams and interviews; inform women of their right to file an independent asylum application, etc.  It is also urgent that there be no further internment of children, pregnant women and survivors of rape, sexual assault and trafficking. And, of course, measures are needed for the integration of refugee women and asylum seekers into the labour market. The solution to the refugee crisis is not to return them to Turkey, but to create legal avenues of immigration and implement integration policies. The dignity of the European project based on the principles of solidarity, justice and equality is at stake.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to ˗ to ensure the safety of female refugees. January 2016 According to the data, women and children make up 55% of those who have arrived in Greece to apply for EU asylum. The reform of EU migration and asylum policy aims to provide for measures to protect women and children seeking refugee status. The draft resolution stresses that various forms of violence and discrimination based on sex, including rape, sexual violence or forced marriage, are persecution and should therefore be recognised as an appropriate basis for seeking asylum in the EU. I support the specific measures putd out to facilitate the situation of women seeking asylum: separate sleeping places for women; translation, counselling and childcare services; as well as training for reception centre staff on sexual violence or smuggling.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is entirely unsustainable as it seeks to extend refugee status to all women and their families living in third world states who are discriminated against on grounds of sex. In doing so, they want to further strengthen the immigration invasion that is stifling Europe, hiding under the guise of concern about violence against women. And by supporting family reunification, they would allow for more legal immigration. This report demonstrates once again that the majority of the European Parliament is still unable to face up to the dangers of European identity and European culture. On this basis, I voted against the report, of course.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. What a folly this catalogue of proposals that will only aggravate the migratory tsunami that is overwhelming our Old Continent... I have of course voted against this text because all its proposals aim to facilitate the entry and stay in Europe of the 'Migrants', by leading to excessive expenditure.  Decidedly, the EU confirms to us every day that "Hell is paved with good intentions"...

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Of the one million migrants who arrived in the EU in 2015, 35% were women and children and today 55% of the refugees arriving in Greece are women. I have obviously supported this report which aims to respond to the specific needs of protection of women who are attempting a perilous journey in search of a better life or simply protection. This requires a new comprehensive set of gender dimension guidelines for asylum and migration.  But it also requires that migrant women receive accurate information about the asylum procedure, their rights and their specific benefits. They must have protection during their stay in refugee camps and, as part of the asylum application, have the right to request an investigator and an interpreter and to conduct an individual interview away from any third party,...

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it sets out the policies necessary to meet the needs of asylum seekers and refugees. It envisages various measures to ensure specific care for women during the asylum process and in reception centres.  As Unicef reported last month, 60% of refugees and migrants arriving are now women and children, while by mid-2015, men made up 73% of all displaced persons. The gender dimension of this massive displacement of people is therefore an essential factor that must be taken into account in order to provide an adequate and effective response.   The report calls for, inter alia, special protection for the LGBTI collective and urges Member States and the EU to sign and ratify the Istanbul Convention. It also calls for irregular migration not to impede access to EU asylum procedures and expresses deep concern about forced returns.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 From the beginning of 2015 to November of the same year, some 900 000 people reached the coasts of Europe crossing the Mediterranean Sea. 38% of these were women and children. Girls, who have fled conflict and persecution, represent a particular group within the large category of refugees, more exposed to the risks of early and forced marriages, sexual, physical violence and prostitution. I voted in favour of the Honeyball report because I believe that it effectively delinees the problems and possible responses linked to the difficult conditions facing refugee and asylum seeker women in the EU. The report presents several measures to ensure that their specific needs are met both within reception centres and during the asylum application process. Among the main provisions are those that provide for the construction of night zones and toilets separated by gender, the presence of female staff and interpreters, the provision of advice for traumas related to gender-related violence and the care of children during screening. Particularly important for women's emancipation is the decision to increase information in order to explain to women the right to apply for asylum independently of their spouse.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report dealing with the situation of refugee women and asylum seekers in the EU. The report is positive in that it believes that asylum policies and procedures and application assessments should include a gender approach. It includes gender-based violence, rape, sexual violence, female mutilation, forced marriage or sexist violence as grounds for asylum applications in the EU. It also includes persecution and violence against LGBTI groups. The report calls for measures to ensure that women's needs are met during the asylum process. Safe and legal routes are requested to ensure the safety of women on their way to the EU to prevent human trafficking and mafias. It stresses that immigration policies and legislation should not prevent access to the EU asylum procedure. It stresses the importance of labour insertion measures. It calls for solidarity between EU countries and that responsibility should not be based solely on the countries of first destination, which we believe is necessary.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and welcome the adoption of this report today on the international day of working women. Parliament, with this, asks women for special attention in asylum policy. Reform of Community policies and procedures on migration and asylum needs to include measures to ensure the safety of women asylum seekers, who often travel with young children and other dependents. Asylum policies and procedures, including the assessment of asylum applications, need to take gender into account, while gender-based violence – such as rape, sexual violence, genital mutilation, forced marriages and domestic violence – should be recognised as a valid reason for seeking asylum in the EU. I have supported this resolution as necessary as it is urgent.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. All the points proposed in this report are intended only to exacerbate the migrant crisis by giving them even more facilities to return to Europe. This report would result in enormous additional costs. The report makes no mention of Christians, Shiites, Yezidi and Kurds who experience a great deal of violence, whether in their country of origin or in refugee centres. The report makes no difference between war refugees and economic refugees. The report also does not mention the risks of insecurity or terrorism associated with the reception of migrants. All these points lead me to vote against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is unbalanced and in some passages i do not agree with it. That is why I did not intend to support you with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is important that asylum policies and procedures are gender sensitive. 55% of refugees arriving in Europe are women, girls and children. To ensure that women's specific needs are addressed, gender-specific training, including gender-based violence, needs to be promoted for staff; sanitary facilities and gender-segregated rooms; guarantee the right to request female interviewers and interpreters; ensure access to women's health services; provide childcare services during exams and interviews; inform women of their right to file an independent asylum application, etc.  It is also urgent that there be no further internment of children, pregnant women and survivors of rape, sexual assault and trafficking. And, of course, measures are needed for the integration of refugee women and asylum seekers into the labour market. The solution to the refugee crisis is not to return them to Turkey, but to create legal avenues of immigration and implement integration policies. The dignity of the European project based on the principles of solidarity, justice and equality is at stake.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the situation of female refugees and asylum seekers in the European Union. In 2014, half of the refugees in the world were women and girls. Historically, international conventions and national asylum policies have tended not to take into account the specific situation of women seeking asylum and the gender dimension of the refugee situation. Asylum systems were mainly viewed from a male perspective. Although a common European Asylum System (BEPS) has been established, member states' law, policies and practices remain very different and there are clear gaps in the protection of women seeking asylum in the EU. It is difficult to generate statistics on the demographic diversity of refugees trying to reach Europe, due to their nature. However, all modern research mentions that more single men than women and children come to the EU to apply for international protection. This is mainly due to gender barriers that prevent women from receiving the protection faced by women throughout their journey. The traditional unequal distribution of work means that women often remain in the country to care for children and older family members. Most of them lack, in particular, financial and administrative independence in order to leave their country. Fleeing women, who are increasingly vulnerable, are vulnerable at all stages of their journey: in their countries of origin, transit and arrival. Gender-based violence, which usually makes women decide to flee, is a common feature of the whole journey to the EU and the EU itself.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 It is undeniable that women and children fleeing war and persecution are victims of various forms of violence in the countries of origin, but also, unfortunately, on the difficult road to Europe. The migration crisis is intertwined with a crisis of violence rooted in the area of origin and accompanies women and children along their journey. We are all sensitive to the problems of women and young girls. Europe has important things to do, such as providing accommodation and facilities for women and children, protecting expectant and nursing mothers. Unfortunately, the report has entered into the competences of other committees and member states, behind which there is no financial commitment, behind which there is no financial resources.  As long as we fill pages and meetings with promising-sounding proposals that are not applicable in reality, until we respect the powers until we protect our borders, it will be difficult to properly deal with either the migration crisis or the crisis of violence. Although I considered it important to draw attention to the particularly vulnerable situation of women refugees and asylum seekers on the line of values represented by the People's Party, and for this reason I supported some of the proposals made to remedy the problem as a compromise, I abstained in the final vote of the report, as I believe that many of the paragraphs in the report concern a subsidiarity issue and would remove powers from national Member States, including our country. , in particular in the management of asylum.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. - Although I fully agree with the many findings of the proposed report on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU, I abstained in the vote. This does not mean that I am not aware of the difficulties faced by refugee women fleeing war zones of the Middle East or North Africa with their children. I strongly condemn the inhumane methods used by smugglers who lead desperate people into Europe, from physical to psychological abuse, violence, etc. The best way to help refugees is to make peace in war zones, everything else is just patches on the open wound. Migration is the biggest challenge for Europe, and we need to be realistic in tackling this and tell people what to expect and how Europe will accept them. I would like to stress once again that all efforts must be directed towards peace-building so that refugees can return to their homelands. However, we must ensure that others who are already with us are properly treating, which must comply with international humanitarian law.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 In the face of the spread of the refugee crisis emergency that is before us every day, we cannot ignore the needs of some particularly vulnerable groups and the fact that they require specific protections. Women asylum seekers and refugees arriving in the European Union are fleeing discrimination, persecution and conflict in their countries of origin, which force them to embark on a dangerous and uncertain journey. When they arrive, these women, who are already vulnerable and often severely tried, face in many cases further harassment, violence and the unfortunately not uncommon risk of becoming the subject of trafficking, exploitation and other unacceptable crimes. As stated in the report voted on today, which I support, these risks should be duly taken into account in the management of reception and asylum procedures, and addressed with due sensitivity. In reforming the Union's migration and asylum policies, therefore, measures must be provided to take account of the gender dimension in order to guarantee the safety of women seeking asylum, many of whom are often, moreover, single mothers or people who are already severely debilitated.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ Croatia is coping well with the problem of refugee flows through its territory, but it is important to stress that women very rarely stay in hospitals even when their health is at risk. It is important to enable migrant women to feel safe and to provide them with quality health assistance.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report on the situation of refugees and asylum seekers in the European Union calls for legal, material and financial facilities for women, children and LGBTI refugees and asylum seekers, as they are victims of violence in their home countries but also in Europe. These provisions will exacerbate the migrant crisis by facilitating their entry and stay in Europe and by incurring excessive expenditure. Of course, I voted against this report.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that it is Europe's task, understood as a system of values that puts human rights and their protection first, to create safe and legal access routes to the continent to avoid the exploitation by merchants of men of women who are refugees and asylum seekers in the EU.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Fleeing women are on the rise and vulnerable at all stages of their journey to their countries of origin, transit and destination. Gender-based violence is not only an essential element of the reasons for fleeing, but also a common feature on their journey to and within the EU. The European Parliament, in a resolution of 13 April 1984 taken up by successive conclusions and guidelines of the UNHCR, was the first international body to recognize the need for gender-conscious interpretation of refugee status. Many EU Member States have adopted their own gender guidelines, but these have not been binding and have been partially and unevenly effective. Member States must ensure that asylum procedures at borders comply with unhcr guidelines on international protection, in particular with regard to gender-based persecution. Parliament must therefore adopt a comprehensive set of gender guidelines at EU level, implementing, in the field of asylum and migration, a comprehensive policy reform, attentive to the social, cultural and political dimension of persecution and also including reception and integration measures.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. Based on the fact that refugee women, children and the LGBTI community are victims of violence and discrimination in their home countries, this report calls for legal facilities on their behalf, particularly on asylum applications. Indeed, the rapporteur wants to facilitate the integration of these illegal migrants by offering them language courses and childcare services but also by guaranteeing them quality care. It is also recommended that accommodation centres be provided specifically designed or adapted to them.  At a time when the peoples of Europe are facing mass unemployment, precariousness and an unprecedented increase in social inequalities, it is absolutely scandalous to welcome and facilitate the arrival of these illegal migrants, the extreme majority of whom do not flee war. It is essential to put an end to the Schengen area, to put an end to the spread of illegal migrants in the Member States and to block the reprogramming of structural funds to finance reception infrastructure. So I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The wave of refugees coming to Europe is also causing problems with the situation of refugees and asylum seekers in the EU. It is indeed a difficult and, at the same time, problematic situation, and their rights must be respected without any doubt.  On the other hand, respect for the rights and freedoms of individuals, regardless of gender, is an essential condition of a rule of law. To mention only women as receiving ill-treatment is discrimination. The preferential treatment discussed in this report concerns only girls, but not refugee boys. In view of the recent incidents in the elais refugee camp, where rapes have taken place among 14-16 year oldboys, I believe that boys should also be entitled to equal protection. At the same time, the report provides facilities for the LGBTI community, but does not propose facilities for Christians persecuted by Muslims in camps. This should be foreseen. In view of the above arguments, as well as the fact that most of the measures mentioned in the report involve difficulties for the volunteers in the camps and for the local officials, I am against this report.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. According to the report, the rise of extremism and populism from the extreme right in Europe exposes refugee women and asylum seekers to a further risk of racist abuse, discrimination and violence.  Member States would be obliged to promote safe and welcoming environments for applicants for international protection and to combat all forms of discrimination. On the subject of refugees, the Commission should ensure that these changes take into account the situation of women, LGBTI people and other vulnerable groups, providing for specific derogations, where appropriate.  The Commission and the Member States should ensure full access to sexual and reproductive health and rights, including access to safe abortion, and additional resources must be allocated as a matter of urgency. Women asylum seekers and refugees should have a greater say and LGBTI people should be more focused.  In short, there is surplus to vote strongly against.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is important that asylum policies and procedures are gender sensitive. 55% of refugees arriving in Europe are women, girls and children. To ensure that women's specific needs are addressed, gender-specific training, including gender-based violence, needs to be promoted for staff; sanitary facilities and gender-segregated rooms; guarantee the right to request female interviewers and interpreters; ensure access to women's health services; provide childcare services during exams and interviews; inform women of their right to file an independent asylum application, etc.  It is also urgent that there be no further internment of children, pregnant women and survivors of rape, sexual assault and trafficking. And, of course, measures are needed for the integration of refugee women and asylum seekers into the labour market. The solution to the refugee crisis is not to return them to Turkey, but to create legal avenues of immigration and implement integration policies. The dignity of the European project based on the principles of solidarity, justice and equality is at stake.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European Parliament adopted a report on refugee women and asylum seekers in the EU as part of Women's Day on Tuesday 8 March 2016. It was important for the European Parliament to send a strong message in support of migrant women and girls fleeing their country in atrocious conditions. These women are too often victims of violence during their journey. It is important to ensure their safety. We need to adapt refugee centres to the particularity of women and to ensure that sanitary conditions within these camps are improved. I voted in favour of this report

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the situation of refugee women and asylum seekers in the EU. The terrible reception conditions for refugees, who are on the doorstep of Europe in recent weeks, are in the eyes of all. Children and women, who account for an average of one third of asylum seekers, are the first to suffer from this difficult situation. Refugee women and asylum seekers are the most vulnerable to all kinds of violence, victims of discrimination of all kinds, including sexual discrimination. Europe cannot remain impassive or, worse, think only of erecting barbed-wire walls. Action must be taken quickly and resolutely to alleviate the suffering of refugee women and asylum seekers, safeguarding their health and promoting their integration.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this progressive report which was concerned with the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers.  Recent research conducted by Amnesty International shows that women and girl refugees face violence, assault, exploitation and sexual harassment at every stage of their journey, including on European soil. The organisation interviewed 40 refugee women and girls in northern Europe in December 2015 who travelled from Turkey to Greece and then across the Balkans. All the women described feeling threatened and unsafe during the journey. Many reported that in almost all of the countries they passed through they experienced physical abuse and financial exploitation, being groped or pressured to have sex by smugglers, security staff or other refugees. It is absolutely unacceptable that after living through the horrors of the war in Iraq and Syria these women have risked everything to find safety for themselves and their children. But from the moment they begin this journey they are again exposed to violence and exploitation, with little support or protection.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. While we absolutely sympathise the sentiments of the report regarding those who have suffered abuse and persecution and the need to make sure that decent care and facilities are available, the report also called for legal routes for asylum in to the EU, an expansion of the EU migration and asylum policies and more burden sharing of refugees between all Member States. The EU has caused this crisis and is putting everyone at risk, so UKIP voted against further expansion of EU control.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the need for the rights of female refugees to be addressed, but I was unable to vote in favour of this report because of the unacceptable references to abortion. I do not believe in extreme liberalisation of reproductive rights and I will never accept legalisation of abortion. Nobody should be punished by death for the actions of others and no arguments can justify the killing of innocent, unborn children.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 All refugees face great difficulties, but women and girls are more vulnerable and need special attention because they are often subjected to gender-based violence and discrimination. I voted without hesitation in favour of this report calling for the individual registration of refugee women and specialist advice for women victims of gender-based violence. It is also stated that rape, sexual violence, forced marriages, domestic violence, so-called honour killings authorised by a state represent a form of persecution and must be considered a reason for seeking asylum in the EU. Finally, all the health and reception needs and needs of women are highlighted and specific measures are being developed to ensure and improve the social inclusion and integration of refugee and asylum seeker women.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe there has to be special attention paid to women refugees, especially those fleeing their countries of origin together with their children, as they are more vulnerable and they face many challenges throughout their very risky journey.  It has to be said that cases of physical violence, abuse or other forms of discrimination were registered. Our goal should be to point out such cases and make sure women refugees get the appropriate level of protection they need. On the other hand, I could not support some of the proposals of the rapporteur concerning reserves on lack of solidarity between the Member States when it comes to their approach to refugees and asylum seekers. Those statements are not objective, fact-based and, above all, are not within the scope of the report. Also, I do not fully share the report’s call for full access of asylum seekers to public services with regard to education or employment services during the asylum process. These should be granted, but only to those whose asylum procedure has been concluded successfully.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ On this International Women’s Day, we are sending a very clear message that action must be taken to protect women and girls seeking protection in the EU. Violence is an everyday reality for women and girls fleeing conflict. But pressure on asylum systems should never excuse failure to protect women from violence; they should have the same rights as other victims of gender-based violence. Every measure and policy to improve the situation of refugees seeking entry to Europe must take women into account. These measures must acknowledge the trauma of their journey from their country of origin to Europe. The assistance provided to these refugees must be medical and psychological and should last throughout the asylum procedure. Women refugees must also have access, as soon as they arrive, to complete information about their rights, whether they concern the asylum procedure or reproductive health.  Europe must improve the quality of entry offered to refugees, in particular to women and children. The arbitrary retention of women and children is unacceptable. One must also pay attention to the vulnerability of women when deciding to send a refugee back to a so-called safe country. A safe country for a man is not always a safe country for a woman.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation of refugee women is one of the most tragic issues of the serious migration crisis that is testing some of Europe's founding values: respect, equality, tolerance. Values that take on even greater significance when we consider refugee or migrant women: women who come from war zones or the place of multi-year conflicts, where they have sometimes already suffered deprivation and violence, indifference and harassment that are still repeated all too often during the journey to Europe. These are particularly vulnerable people with specific needs who, in addition to taking responsibility for their own survival, often also have to take care of their children, their families. Unfortunately, there are still no uniform procedures in the various Member States for the proper reception of refugee women. That is why the report identifies guidelines to ensure consistent treatment for women arriving in Europe with the hope of finding help and protection. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Written. Europe faces a huge humanitarian challenge. Hundreds of thousands of refugees have come to Europe because of war and persecution in their home country. We have a responsibility to protect them and to deal with vulnerable groups such as women and children in particular.  Today, each country alone faces the challenge. It's unsustainable. A pan-European solution, agreed between eu member states, is needed. However, what the solution should look like in practice must be up to the Member States that will take part in it. Denmark has, and will continue to have, a clear exception in the area of refugee and asylum policy. Therefore, we cannot vote for all 28 Member States to be responsible for all refugees arriving in the EU, stressing that the Danish asylum and refugee policy is determined only in Denmark. Nor are we voting in favour of establishing safe and legal asylum routes, as the proposal is not detailed.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 This proposal contains important positive elements, but also contains several negative points. It is therefore considered appropriate to abstain from the vote.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the European Union, in an effort not only to demonstrate the growing problems brought about by the sharp rise in the number of refugees, but also the inequalities faced by many women in this situation. In this light, I believe that the need to support and promote the rights of these women and girls who are forced to suffer many hardships from a position of weakness is evident. That is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Recent research shows that more single men manage to reach the EU to pursue international protection than women and children. Women and girls escaping conflicts encounter many forms of gender-based violence whilst traveling towards a host country. It is important to engage in a gender-specific analysis of this issue. The wording of the alternative resolution on ‘the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU’ would ensure adequate protection for female refugees. Whilst working on a dignified and reasonable migration policy it must be recognised that women should benefit from specific aid when they apply for asylum. Refugee centres must be adjusted to respect the privacy of women. Pregnant women in particular should have easy access to adequate medical care. Fighting against human smugglers must be a main priority. It is recognised that some female refugees are sexually abused as payment for illegal smuggling services. The European institutions and Member States are called upon to take immediate action against human trafficking.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. While we absolutely sympathise the sentiments of the report regarding those who have suffered abuse and persecution and the need to make sure that decent care and facilities are available, the report also called for legal routes for asylum in to the EU, an expansion of the EU migration and asylum policies and more burden sharing of refugees between all Member States. The EU has caused this crisis and is putting everyone at risk, so UKIP voted against further expansion of EU control.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Taking advantage of International Women's Day, the European Parliament has adopted a set of reports, in which it is integrated, underlining what remains to be done for gender equality. This in particular wanted to highlight a particular reality in this area and for which much work still needs to be done in Europe: women asylum seekers and refugees.  The report paints an impressive picture of the horrors these women are subjected to and lists a set of recommendations to Member States, which still remain primarily responsible for reception, application analysis and integration. The need to inform these women is, in particular, that their request may be independent of the husband - often aggressor.  However, the report also extends beyond what should be its fundamental object, including areas where there is no community competence, such as abortion. I can only abstain.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I abstained and voted in favour of the alternative resolution, because I cannot agree with the rapporteur's overly far-reaching calls for parts of the current right of asylum to be amended 'through the back door'. It is precisely today, on International Women's Day, that we must send out a signal and work for full social, economic, cultural and political equality for women. However, we do not achieve this by making statements on family reunification and setting out new rules on asylum procedures. On the contrary, we need to look more closely at the issue of gender-based violence against women and girls who come to Europe. Our asylum policy must be implemented in a gender-sensitive manner. In my view, this includes the demand for gender-segregated accommodation and sanitation facilities, but also more commitment to the fight against trafficking in human beings and people smugglers and a more efficient implementation of resettlement programmes.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. While we absolutely sympathise the sentiments of the report regarding those who have suffered abuse and persecution and the need to make sure that decent care and facilities are available, the report also called for legal routes for asylum in to the EU, an expansion of the EU migration and asylum policies and more burden sharing of refugees between all Member States. The EU has caused this crisis and is putting everyone at risk, so UKIP voted against further expansion of EU control.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 On such a sensitive issue as the situation of refugee women and asylum seekers in the EU, there is unanimous agreement on the need to devote the utmost attention to it. The latest figures show that 38% of asylum seekers in Europe are women, and according to Filippo Grandi's speech in plenary, 20% of refugees are women travelling alone with children still in swathes. There is therefore no doubt that the situation is dramatic and that it must be dealt with in the best possible way, firstly by inviting all those Member States that have not yet done so to sign the Istanbul Convention.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with several aspects brought forward in this report, in particular the call for asylum seekers to be provided in due time with all the relevant information, including all specific services available to women applying for asylum, as this leads to informed decisions. I strongly support the statement that, despite the challenges Member States face in dealing with the migration flow, women migrants are exposed throughout the perilous journey to threats which are different to those of men, and that this requires different services to be provided to them.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Written. "The Moderates in the European Parliament voted in favour of the report on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU. We think it is important to recognise that women and girls fleeing conflict are particularly vulnerable. Often they travel alone with their children and are particularly vulnerable to violence, even when they reach Europe. The report draws attention to the need for separate sleeping places, toilets and shower areas. It also calls for the guarantee of care, including sexual and reproductive health care, and safe spaces for women to leave their children during interviews for asylum applications. It also calls for officers and police to be trained in gender-based violence so that they can identify victims of trafficking and sexual exploitation early, and prevent them. calls on the Member States to implement the common rules on asylum and the rules to combat trafficking; However, the Conservatives do not support the report's attempts to change the rules of the asylum package, for example by proposing mutual approval of asylum decisions in the EU, and attempts to make family reunification a human right.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, drafted by fellow Labour MEP, Mary Honeyball.  Women refugees and asylum seekers often face violence, assault, exploitation and sexual harassment at every stage of their journey, including on European soil. Women – and indeed children – who are entitled to claim asylum are being coerced into transactional sex and forced into prostitution to pay for travel documents or a place in a boat or lorry. They need safer alternatives, as this report sets out. The specific protection and integration needs of women refugees and asylum seekers have too often been overlooked. To meet the needs of everyone entitled to protection, our asylum laws and policies must be fully gender sensitive at every stage.  On International Women’s Day Labour MEPs are sending a very clear message that action must be taken.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report highlights the situation of women in the migration processes of refugees and asylum seekers in the European Union. It highlights the violation of human rights, including gender-based violence and rape as a weapon of war. In order to improve the safety and protection of refugee women and girls, it expresses the need for safe and legal access routes to the EU, taking gender issues into account. Stresses, in particular, that more Member States should participate in EU resettlement programmes; considers that legislation and policies on irregular migration should not hinder access to EU asylum procedures; stresses that the right of asylum is enshrined in Article 18 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union; stresses all the health and reception needs and needs that women have, including full access to health and sexual and reproductive rights. It also calls for specific measures to be developed to ensure and improve the inclusion and social integration of refugee women and asylum seekers. This seems to me to be a good report, so I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it aims to correct the situation of extreme vulnerability of refugee women within the European Union. Women fleeing persecution in their home states face an extremely dangerous journey, facing risks such as attacks, rapes, scams, human trafficking and even death. These women, who in themselves are tremendously vulnerable in their home country, face additional obstacles to their arrival in the European Union, increasing their vulnerability. The report proposes that asylum procedures and policies, including the assessment of applications, should be gender sensitive, and calls for all issues relating to gender-based violence, such as rape, sexual violence, female genital mutilation, forced marriage or domestic violence, to be considered as valid reasons for receiving asylum in the European Union. It also focuses on the protection of LGBTI's collective and calls for an end to the detentions of children, pregnant women seeking asylum, or survivors of rape, sexual violence and human trafficking. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution puts refugee women and asylum seekers at the centre in order to improve their safety and protection against all types of violence and abuse. By voting in favour, I intend to support the European Parliament's position that greater attention should be paid to women and their children throughout the reception phase from their stay in refugee camps, as well as at border controls and, of course, after accession to the EU. All measures and policies to improve the situation of refugees must take women into account and adequate funds must be made available to launch programmes for greater inclusion and integration of women in the EU.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 A reform of EU migration and asylum policies and procedures must include gender-sensitive measures to ensure the safety of women seeking asylum, many of whom travel with young children, and other dependants. This report highlights the particularly vulnerable situation of refugee women in the European Union. Upon arrival at reception centres, these already vulnerable women, who could be victims of sexual violence, trafficking or other violent crimes, face additional barriers that exacerbate their already vulnerable positions. Member States should guarantee the right to require that interviewees and interpretations be women, provide appropriate training to interviewees and interpretations in the field of sexual violence, trauma, provide trauma advice to women who have suffered gender-related violence, provide information on asylum procedures and the specific rights of women seeking asylum , provide childcare services during asylum checks and interviews, inform women of their right to apply for asylum independently of their partner and have a legal status independent of that of their spouses.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the eu report on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers. The subject itself is very important and deserves attention, as an unprecedented and growing number of women and children are seeking international protection in the EU due to ongoing conflicts and human rights violations, including the use of gender-based and rape as weapons of war. Refugee and asylum-seeking women often suffer cumulative discrimination and are more at the fore to sexual and gender-based violence in countries of origin, transit and destination. Girls fleeing conflict and persecution are more at risk of child, early and forced marriage, as well as sexual violence, assault and forced prostitution.  On the other hand, the report focused more on asylum and asylum procedures than on specific issues affecting migrant women. It also intervenes on issues that fall within the competence of the Member States.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The content of the document calls on Member States to immediately establish safe and legal asylum routes, reform Frontex, establish Community-wide guidelines for women as part of a broader migration and asylum reform, guarantee special accommodation for LGTBI persons, review EU policy on safe countries of origin, pay particular attention to asylum applications made by women and avoid detaining asylum seekers. The report pays particular attention to: – the gender dimension in determining refugee status (preferential treatment for refugees, both women and girls, but nothing about young boys); – the needs of women asylum seekers (specially trained for the sex of counsellors); – trafficking and smuggling of people and sexual violence, and in this context free access to abortion; – detention policy; – social inclusion and integration. Due to the nature of the document, I voted against. We need unequivocal action with the aim of equal treatment not only on gender issues, but also on origin.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Women and children accounted for around 35% of all refugees in the EU until 2015. In January alone the percentage rose to 55%. Most of these women asylum seekers and refugees in the EU face an exceptionally challenging situation which needs to be highlighted. Sometimes the situation for them gets worse once they arrive at certain reception centres where they end up as victims of sexual violence, trafficking or violent crimes. I voted in favour of this report where it called for gender sensitive asylum procedures and measures. I voted against all amendments relating to access to abortion and sexual and reproductive rights.

name: Seb DANCE
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was drafted by Labour MEP Mary Honeyball.  Women refugees and asylum seekers have specific protection and integration needs which have too often been overlooked. To meet the needs of everyone seeking protection, our asylum laws and policies must be fully gender sensitive at every stage.  Research shows that women and girls face violence, assault, exploitation and sexual harassment at every stage of their journey, including on European soil. Women – and indeed children – who are entitled to claim asylum are being coerced into transactional sex and forced into prostitution to pay for travel documents or a place in a boat or lorry. They need safer alternatives, as this report sets out.  On International Women’s Day Labour MEPs are sending a very clear message that action must be taken to protect women and girls seeking asylum in the EU.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, on International Women's Day, the European Parliament is paying particular attention to the situation of refugee women and asylum seekers in the EU, also thanks to the adoption of the resolution by the rapporteur, Mrs Honeyball, on this subject. In 2015 and early 2016, more than a million refugees arrived in Europe. International conventions and Member States' asylum policies have shown that they do not take sufficient account of the specific position of women asylum seekers and gender aspects. In this regard, I would also like to point out that many EU Member States have not yet signed and ratified the 'Istanbul Convention' on preventing and combating violence against women. Today's resolution reminds us of the importance of the EU's resettlement programmes, in which all Member States should participate, and reiterates that responsibility, costs and benefits must be shared between all 28 Member States and not just among the countries of first arrival, putting into practice the principle of European solidarity. For all these reasons, I voted 'yes' to the resolution.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report looks at the situation of refugee women and girls who face different forms of gender-based violence during their journey. Being more vulnerable than men on the migration route, I am in favour of an in-depth analysis of the specific needs of refugee or asylum-seeking women.  I regret, however, that more ideological than political considerations have led the rapporteur to go beyond the scope of the report by adding parts on asylum procedures and detention. In order to put the focus back on the refugee situation, we have tabled an alternative resolution to present the recommendations of the EPP Group.  Considering, however, that in view of the exceptional nature of the migration phenomenon in Europe and the vulnerability of refugee women, I have decided to support this report which makes proposals to improve access to specific health and support services for women.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report on the status of refugee women and asylum seekers in the European Union. They are very often victims of gender-based violence and persecution during their journey to a host country.  Despite many paragraphs which I have rejected because they went too far in their recommendations, which is not the responsibility of the Committee on Women but of the Committee on Civil Liberties to which I belong, I could not reject such a text.  By voting on this text, we wanted the European Parliament to send a signal that it is mobilised and attentive to the condition of women in the current migration issues.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: in writing. In my own name and right, and representing the Spanish delegation of the PPE Group as Secretary General, I would like to record the reason for our final positive vote on the Honeyball Report Resolution. On the one hand, we have rejected, unequivocally, the proposals for abortion and its euphemisms on sexual and reproductive health, but we could not and should not vote against a report supporting proposals that we make our own. Family reunification in armed conflict, as set out in Article 74 of Protocol I to the 1949 Geneva Conventions, is of particular interest in protection for women and children at a time when the tragedy of refugees forces us to be supportive.  In addition, the drama of women and girls, fleeing rape in their countries, is recognized. Solutions are sought for refugee women and means for integration into host countries are needed.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The dramatic situation of refugees has been the focus of public attention for months, but little has been done about the measures to be taken to help these people and to address the national dynamics that are opposed to the full implementation of the Commission's plan. In this scenario, it is necessary to remember that women among refugees face a situation of particular humanitarian and economic emergency that must be addressed at European and international level. A dramatic fact concerns the greater number of obstacles that women face in order to reach Europe than men. Furthermore, a labour market which still discriminates between the sexes does not allow women to be fully included and, above all, reduces the chances of economic independence for the livelihoods of children and their dependent elderly. Finally, sexual violence has been underestimated in recent years and psychological and legal protection measures should be encouraged so that we can build a system for defending women's rights from the earliest moments of relief. I voted in favour of this text in order to make the European Union at the forefront of the defence of women's rights.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. According to the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, 55% of refugees arriving in Greece since the beginning of 2016 are children and women, 20% of whom are alone with their children, making them vulnerable during their journey. This situation must be taken into account.  Legislation on refugees and asylum seekers in the EU therefore proposes measures to address this issue. Introduce non-mixed dormitories, toilets and showers; employing female translators and counsellors, creating appropriate facilities for mothers who have arrived with their children: all measures that will improve the reception of refugees in the EU.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 It is undeniable that women and children fleeing war and persecution are victims of various forms of violence in the countries of origin, but also, unfortunately, on the difficult road to Europe. We are all sensitive to the problems of women and young girls, and Europe has important things to do, such as providing accommodation and facilities for women and children, protecting expectant and nursing mothers. Unfortunately, the Socialist reporter did not write about this, but made proposals by entering into the competences of other committees and the Member States, behind which there was no financial commitment, behind which there is no financial resources.  As long as we are satuous in meetings with humanitarianly promising proposals that are not applicable in reality, we do not respect the powers, we do not defend our borders, it will be difficult to properly deal with either the migration crisis or the crisis of violence. Although I considered it important to draw attention to the vulnerable situation of women refugees and asylum seekers on the line of values represented by the People's Party, and for this reason I supported some of the proposals made to remedy the problem, I abstained in the final vote of the report, as I believe that many paragraphs of the report concern subsidiarity issues and would remove powers from national Member States, including our country, in particular in the management of asylum.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. On 8 March, International Women's Day, the European Parliament adopted a highly symbolic resolution, despite opposition from some on the right and the far right, to take gender into account in asylum policies and procedures. Through this vote, we want to draw attention to the particular plight of women and girls in the paths of exile.  They are vulnerable targets, particularly in the face of gender-based violence and sexual abuse, female genital mutilation and the use of rape as a weapon of war, which many of them have experienced. Moreover, like unaccompanied minors, they risk falling into the hands of criminal networks to become victims of human trafficking.  A whole range of specific measures should be put in place: training staff, separate accommodation, access to appropriate care, stopping the detention of minors, pregnant women, rape victims...

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. In the unprecedented influx of migrants arriving in Europe, the share of women and children has doubled, from a quarter to more than half of refugees since the beginning of 2016. I supported this report because it highlights the vulnerable situation of these refugee women who have fled persecution in their country of origin and who continue to be exposed, during their journey, to terrible physical and psychological attacks, sexual violence and human trafficking.  When they arrive at reception centres, these women often face new obstacles that further weaken them, especially as some EU member states voluntarily degrade their reception conditions to deter migrants from coming to their borders.  For this reason, I support calls for the adoption of all measures to ensure that women's specific needs are respected throughout the asylum process and in reception centres. More broadly, I renew my call to open safe and legal routes to the EU, in order to increase the safety of refugee women and to discourage the trafficking and exploitation of migrants by smugglers.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. While the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union already imposes the absence of internal border control, this report risks worsening the migrant crisis. The consequence of this is to facilitate their entry and stay in Europe, while at the same time incurring excessive expenses. The weakness of this report is that it does not distinguish the reasons for the arrival of migrants, which is essential, especially in the context of asylum policy. Considering that the issue of migrants at its origin must be addressed, I voted against this report, which deals only with the consequences.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote against. The report is vague, does not propose any substantive measures, discriminates in favour of women, as if underage boys do not need protection. Moreover, it does not distinguish between so-called refugees and illegal immigrants, while at the same time ignoring the Christian populations of the region, which are perhaps the biggest and first victims of attacks.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are all sensitive to the problems of women and young girls, and Europe has important things to do, such as providing accommodation and facilities for women and children, and protecting expectant and nursing mothers. Unfortunately, the Socialist reporter did not write about this, but made proposals by entering into the competences of other committees and the Member States, behind which there was no financial commitment, behind which there is no financial resources.  As long as we are satuous in pages and meetings with humanitarianly promising proposals, which are not applicable in reality, until we respect the powers until we protect our borders, it will be difficult to properly deal with either the migration crisis or the crisis of violence. Although I considered it important to draw attention to the particularly vulnerable situation of women refugees and asylum seekers on the line of values represented by the People's Party, and for this reason I supported some of the proposals made to remedy the problem as a compromise, I abstained in the final vote of the report, as I believe that many of the paragraphs in the report concern a subsidiarity issue and would remove powers from national Member States, including our country. , in particular in the management of asylum.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. In 2014, half of the world's refugee population was made up of women and girls. Historically, there has been a tendency for international conventions and national asylum policies to ignore the specific situation of women asylum seekers and the gender dimension of refugee situations. Given its nature, it is difficult to obtain accurate statistics on the demographic diversity of refugees trying to reach Europe. The European Union's asylum policy must take into account women's experiences at all stages. I therefore agree that this moment of uncertainty and instability is also an opportunity to harmonise good practice in the treatment of women asylum seekers and refugees in Europe.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation, because it is part of a logic of total permissiveness of migratory flows and fails to mention the persecution of Christian populations.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report addresses existing and to be taken measures for women asylum seekers. According to the UNHCR, in January 2016, women and children accounted for 55% of people who arrived in Greece seeking asylum. The report calls that forms of gender-based violence and discrimination, including but not only rape, sexual violence, female genital mutilation, forced marriage, domestic violence, so-called honour crimes, should be valid grounds for seeking asylum. The report calls for measures that respond to the needs of women during the asylum application process, which are positive and relevant. It advocates safe and legal means of access to the EU and considers that responsibilities and costs should be shared among the 28 Member States It considers that, even in countries considered safe, women may be victims of gender-based persecution and LGBTI people may also be subject to abuse, which makes their application for protection legitimate. It advocates the establishment of a complaints handling mechanism within FRONTEX following abuses and violations committed. Regrettably, the report does not express any critical position on the causes that drive thousands of refugees to flee their countries.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in  favour because it is positive for women and asylum seekers.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ several migration analyses show that single men come to Europe rather than women staying in their country of origin to care for their family, exassing them to even greater danger. The fact is that the situation of women who choose to flee is very daunting on the roads and they are often subjected to attacks. The fact that women fleeing after arriving in Europe often have to live on incomes that are well below the poverty line is also problematic, and this poor financial situation then has an impact on their immediate decision-making. Even after refugee status has been granted, women face quite serious obstacles on the road to employment and social assistance, including a lack of access to childcare. However, the rise of far-right extremism in the Member States of the European Union also poses a very great danger to these women.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because it is certainly not 'right-wing populism' that endangers refugee women and asylum seekers.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the situation of female refugees and asylum seekers in the EU. The report is vague, does not propose any substantive measures, discriminates in favour of women, as if underage boys do not need protection. Moreover, it does not distinguish between so-called refugees and illegal immigrants, while at the same time ignoring the Christian populations of the region, which are perhaps the biggest and first victims of attacks.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I condemn all forms of violence towards women and girls, wherever it takes place. This report rightly highlights the vulnerable situation in which female asylum seekers, often fleeing sexual violence, find themselves.   However, I cannot support the view that the responsibility and cost for asylum procedures be shared by all 28 Member States. Nor should Member States be forced to take part in resettlement programmes. I therefore abstained in the vote on this matter.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ In 2015, about 1 million people crossed the Mediterranean. Women and children account around 35% of refugees. In January 2016, women accounted for 55%. I strongly believe we need to highlight the exceptionally vulnerable situation of women asylum seekers and refugees in the European Union. They have fled persecution in their home countries only to undertake a perilous journey in order to reach a place of safety. On arrival at reception centres these already vulnerable women, who may be victims of sexual violence, trafficking or other violent crimes, face additional barriers which further increases their already vulnerable positions. I therefore support the call for gender sensitive asylum procedure through a number of measures, such as gender-specific training for staff, gender-segregated sleeping and sanitation facilities, the right to request female interviewers and interpreters, access to gender-sensitive health services including prenatal and postnatal care.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the situation of refugees and asylum seekers in the Union because women are particularly vulnerable in the context of migration and asylum. This is a reality that we cannot deny, especially not at a time when flows to the EU are the most important.  Women fleeing war in their countries should not experience physical and gender-like violence in host countries. In this resolution, we stress the need to adopt measures that take into account the particular vulnerability of women and ensure that their rights are respected at all stages of the procedure.  I support the emphasis in particular on exposure to the exploitation of smugglers and the need to redouble efforts in police and judicial cooperation. We also stress the importance of giving women individual rights and legal status independent of that of their spouses, as well as appropriate legal assistance.  Finally, with regard to the social integration of refugees in the host country, we call on Member States to pay special attention to women here as well.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 We are all sensitive to the problems of women and young girls, and Europe has important things to do, such as providing accommodation and facilities for women and children, and protecting expectant and breastfeeding mothers. Unfortunately, the Socialist reporter did not write about this, but made proposals by entering into the competences of other committees and the Member States, behind which there was no financial commitment, behind which there is no financial resources.  As long as we are satuous in pages and meetings with humanitarian and promising-sounding proposals that do not apply in reality, until we respect the powers, until we protect our borders, it will be difficult to properly deal with either the migration crisis or the crisis of violence. Although I considered it important to draw attention to the particularly vulnerable situation of women refugees and asylum seekers on the line of values represented by the People's Party, and for this reason I supported some of the proposals made to remedy the problem as a compromise, I abstained in the final vote of the report, as I believe that many of the paragraphs in the report concern a subsidiarity issue and would remove powers from national Member States, including our country. , in particular in the management of asylum.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report bearing in mind that in 2014 half of the world's refugees were women and girls. It is widely recognized that acts of violence against women asylum seekers are often committed by persons outside the state level, in particular members of their families, and it is therefore particularly important that the State ensures protection for women in such cases. States should interpret the Convention on the Status of Refugees in the light of gender considerations and should provide for reception conditions, support services and asylum procedures that take account of such considerations.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is important that asylum policies and procedures are gender sensitive. 55% of refugees arriving in Europe are women, girls and children. To ensure that women's specific needs are addressed, gender-specific training, including gender-based violence, needs to be promoted for staff; sanitary facilities and gender-segregated rooms; guarantee the right to request female interviewers and interpreters; ensure access to women's health services; provide childcare services during exams and interviews; inform women of their right to file an independent asylum application, etc.  It is also urgent that there be no further internment of children, pregnant women and survivors of rape, sexual assault and trafficking. And, of course, measures are needed for the integration of refugee women and asylum seekers into the labour market.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is important that asylum policies and procedures are gender sensitive. 38% of refugees arriving in Europe are women, girls and children. To ensure that women's specific needs are addressed, gender-specific training, including gender-based violence, needs to be promoted for staff; sanitary facilities and gender-segregated rooms; guarantee the right to request female interviewers and interpreters; ensure access to women's health services; provide childcare services during exams and interviews; inform women of their right to file an independent asylum application, etc.  It is also urgent that there be no further internment of children, pregnant women and survivors of rape, sexual assault and trafficking. And, of course, measures are needed for the integration of refugee women and asylum seekers into the labour market. The solution to the refugee crisis is not to return them to Turkey, but to create legal avenues of immigration and implement integration policies. The dignity of the European project based on the principles of solidarity, justice and equality is at stake.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I strongly support this report, because I am deeply convinced that vulnerable people have the right as much and more than others to a strong physical and social protection network. And I believe that the EU has this vocation by its very nature: to welcome and protect those who risk seeing their rights mortified, those who risk losing them, those who have never even seen them recognised.  The Europe of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, of accession to the Convention on the Rights of the Child, of promoting gender equality, cannot allow refugee women who have fled violence that is inconceivable and monstrous to us not be able to count on guaranteed minimum measures that will enable them to finally feel safe and free to start again.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the EP resolution on the situation of refugee women and asylum seekers in the EU because I believe there is an urgent need to safeguard their psychophysical safety and protect them from violence, abuse and any other form of exploitation. It is important to emphasise gender in the dramatic issue of asylum seekers. The UN High Commissioner for Refugees estimates that in January of this year alone, women and children accounted for 55% of the total number of people on the Balkan route through Turkey. It is extremely tragic to note the conditions under which women are subject in order to leave and continue their journey to Europe, accepting as the last resort to prostitute themselves in order to pay the traffickers and suffering all kinds of violence and discrimination. I therefore believe that it is a humanitarian and civilised issue to guarantee women victims of persecution, rape, female genital mutilation and any kind of discrimination 'authorised' by their states to obtain refugee status in the European Union while providing all the necessary information on the procedures to be followed for seeking asylum. Finally, it is essential to assess a whole range of issues relating to the reception and policies of social inclusion and integration of refugee women in the EU.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against the report on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU today as I support the EPP's compromise amendment. Mrs Honeyball's report, on the other hand, sets the wrong priorities and priorities in many areas. As a German MEP in particular, I say that our many local volunteers are doing everything possible to meet the demands of women, especially mothers with children, with 1.2 million refugees at the moment. The last thing they need is wise sayings from Brussels. They need concrete help and support only in this way can we manage this crisis situation together. In Germany and all the other countries affected by the high number of refugees.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. There is a loophole in legislation regarding the protection of female asylum seekers, despite the Common European Asylum System (CEAS). Nevertheless, given the current situation, we should look at the refugee problem as a whole. We must promote a uniform solution, taking into account the situation of all refugees.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. While we absolutely sympathise the sentiments of the report regarding those who have suffered abuse and persecution and the need to make sure that decent care and facilities are available, the report also called for legal routes for asylum in to the EU, an expansion of the EU migration and asylum policies and more burden sharing of refugees between all Member States. The EU has caused this crisis and is putting everyone at risk, so UKIP voted against further expansion of EU control.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ The UK delegation is fully committed to the protection and advancement of women’s rights and we endeavour to ensure that equality for all is fully achieved. Significant numbers of women, however, continue to be subjected to gross mistreatment and violence, and consequently remain in a state of immense vulnerability.
