Women refugees and asylum seekers are particularly susceptible to such conditions, and it has become abundantly clear that these issues need to be addressed. We firmly support efforts to protect women from sexual exploitation and abuse, including human trafficking and FGM. We also welcome moves to ensure that women are legally recognised as individuals in their own right. There are nevertheless a few paragraphs of this report which raise concern and have consequently resulted in split votes. For example, we cannot support action that interferes with the legal competency of Member States or the attempts to dictate the terms of asylum at the national level. It is not that we do not agree with such points. Rather, we believe that these demands go beyond the scope of the FEMM committee and infringe upon the principle of subsidiarity. For these reasons we abstained on this report.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. Ms Honeyball's report on the "situation of refugee women and asylum seekers in the EU" is less concerned with women than with calling for the mass immigration of those who are called refugees when their majority is made up of economic migrants. We had to think about it: there can no longer be smugglers, human trafficking and abuse if immigration is totally legal and without brakes! Of course, the mention of women also serves as a pretext to dissertation on so-called LGBTI groups, who have lost a Q in the process. Honeyball would do better to ask why only 15% of migrants who arrived in Europe in 2015 are women and what this reveals, or why Eastern Christians, who are the main victims of ongoing conflicts, are so poorly represented. As moved as she is by the plight of women and children, Honeyball does not honour with her compassion the European women who are massively attacked by migrant groups in Germany and Sweden. Nor does it concern itself with the fate of the 10,000 minors who have been lost, even though it refuses to allow minors to be placed in detention centres. In short, I voted against this partial, one-sided and ideological report.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: In writing. Among the subjects that are often forgotten or ignored when it comes to migration, gender is an important aspect to consider.  Women currently account for about 1/3 of asylum applications in the European Union, and they are often victims of discrimination and various forms of sexual or gender-based violence in their country of origin, transit or destination. Refugees and asylum seekers are also at risk of forced and early marriage or even prostitution and are still very often forced to accept unreported jobs to remain in the destination countries.  I voted in favour of this resolution because it recognises the highly vulnerable situation of these refugees and asylum seekers and has the merit of calling on the States and the European Commission. The proposed measures represent a first step towards better protection of the fundamental rights of refugees and asylum seekers in EU member states.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. In the face of violence, rape, discrimination, human trafficking and genital mutilation that women may have suffered during their journey to Europe, a specific approach is needed to deal with their reception and integration into Europe.  This approach involves staff training, including modules on sexual violence, the provision of rooms and sanitary facilities for the separation of women and men, access to health care tailored to women's needs, including access to contraception and abortion, or information to women detailing their right to apply for asylum separate from that of their husbands.  Another important consideration is the question of the integration of these women, their access to the labour market and family reunification. For all these reasons I voted in favour of My Colleague Honeyball's report. Europe's honour also depends on mutual respect, gender equality and solidarity.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of giving stronger support to women refugees, because the rise of far-right populism and extremism in Europe puts women refugees and asylum seekers at further risk of racist abuse, discrimination and violence. Member States have an obligation to promote safe and welcoming environments for those seeking international protection and to combat all forms of discrimination. Additionally, legal and safe routes into the EU must be made available for those fleeing conflict and persecution, and legislation and policies relating to irregular migration should never prevent access to EU asylum procedures, because the right to asylum is enshrined in Article 18 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is important that asylum policies and procedures are gender sensitive. 55% of refugees arriving in Europe are women, girls and children. To ensure that women's specific needs are addressed, gender-specific training, including gender-based violence, needs to be promoted for staff; sanitary facilities and gender-segregated rooms; guarantee the right to request female interviewers and interpreters; ensure access to women's health services; provide childcare services during exams and interviews; inform women of their right to file an independent asylum application, etc.  It is also urgent that there be no further internment of children, pregnant women and survivors of rape, sexual assault and trafficking. And, of course, measures are needed for the integration of refugee women and asylum seekers into the labour market. The solution to the refugee crisis is not to return them to Turkey, but to create legal avenues of immigration and implement integration policies. The dignity of the European project based on the principles of solidarity, justice and equality is at stake.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 It is undeniable that women and children fleeing war and persecution are victims of various forms of violence in the countries of origin, but also, unfortunately, on the road to Europe. The migration crisis is also intertwined with a crisis of violence rooted in the areas of origin and accompanies women and children. We are all sensitive to the difficult situation of women and young girls. Europe has important things to do, such as providing accommodation and facilities for women and children, protecting expectant and nursing mothers. Unfortunately, the Socialist reporter did not write about this, but intervened in the competences of other committees or Member States, behind which there is no financial commitment or financial resources.  As long as we are satuous in pages with empty promises, until we respect the powers, until we protect our borders, the migration and violence crisis cannot be properly addressed. Although I considered it important to draw attention to the particularly vulnerable situation of women refugees and asylum seekers on the line of values represented by the People's Party, and for this reason I supported some of the proposals made to remedy the problem as a compromise, I abstained in the final vote of the report, as I believe that many of the paragraphs in the report concern a subsidiarity issue.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Writing. \u2012 The report argues that asylum policies and procedures, including the assessment of asylum requests, should be gender sensitive and is of the opinion that gender-based violence, such as rape, sexual violence, FGM, forced marriage, domestic violence, should be a valid reason to seek asylum in the EU. It stresses the need to set up facilities to take into account LGBTI people in all Member States and stresses that violence against LGBTI people is a common occurrence in reception facilities. It therefore calls for a number of measures to be taken to ensure that women's needs are met throughout the asylum process. In view of the increasing number of women/refugees seeking asylum and protection, we voted in favour of the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which contains many positive proposals e.g. safe and legal routes to the EU for those fleeing conflicts with gender taken into consideration, and that more Member States should participate in the EU Resettlement Programmes. It also reminds us that LGBTI people may be subjected to further abuse, that family re-unification is systematically delayed and often violated and that women asylum seekers in detention have been subjected to sexual abuse. However, it then goes too far where e.g. in paragraph 61 it states that employment and housing that matches the needs and abilities of refugee women and girls should be guaranteed by host countries. Yes, that is what we would want for everybody, our children as well as refugees, but no Member State can guarantee it. The word food appears in one paragraph out of 62 and over 200 recitals and only in the context of food distribution – totally ignoring the fact that in some instances there is no food. Yes, we wish for and vote for the good things – as I did, but I am left with a slightly sour taste in my mouth that we ignored certain realties in an effort to deliver a political message.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The report by Mary Honeyball deals with the situation of female refugees and asylum seekers and addresses some important aspects. These include taking into account the specific needs of girls and women in the implementation of asylum procedures and accommodation in asylum seeker homes, the fight against trafficking in human beings and people smuggling, and protection against sexual exploitation and violence. The alternative proposal tabled by the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats included precisely these points, which is why I supported it. The Honeyball report, on the other hand, contains demands in its final version that go far beyond the target. This concerns, for example, calls for the establishment of a continuous structure for so-called LGBTI people in all Member States or for universal, unrestricted access to free, high-quality public education, health services and employment and housing. I therefore did not vote in favour of the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 We are all sensitive to the problems of women and young girls fleeing war and persecution. Europe also has important things to do, such as providing accommodation and facilities for women and children, protecting expectant and nursing mothers. Unfortunately, the Socialist reporter did not write about this, but made proposals by entering into the competences of other committees and the Member States, behind which there was no financial commitment, behind which there is no financial resources.  As long as we are satuous in pages and meetings with humanitarian and promising-sounding proposals that do not apply in reality, until we respect the powers, until we protect our borders, it will be difficult to properly deal with either the migration crisis or the crisis of violence. Although I considered it important to draw attention to the particularly vulnerable situation of women refugees and asylum seekers on the line of values represented by the People's Party, and for this reason I supported some of the proposals made to remedy the problem as a compromise, I abstained in the final vote of the report, as I believe that many of the paragraphs in the report concern a subsidiarity issue and would remove powers from national Member States, including our country. , in particular in the management of asylum.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. While we absolutely sympathise the sentiments of the report regarding those who have suffered abuse and persecution and the need to make sure that decent care and facilities are available, the report also called for legal routes for asylum in to the EU, an expansion of the EU migration and asylum policies and more burden sharing of refugees between all Member States. The EU has caused this crisis and is putting everyone at risk, so UKIP voted against further expansion of EU control.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. We are well aware of the danger posed by migrants who flock to Europe every day in their thousands. However, we are less aware of the vulnerability of women and children in this population who are subjected to sometimes sexual violence and intolerable abuse. The collective mismanagement of the migration crisis has made traffickers happy with them who use migrants as a financial windfall. We have a moral responsibility to these women and children, especially in refugee reception centres. On the other hand, with regard to asylum procedures, I believe that if special precautions are to be taken for the most vulnerable persons, they must remain subject, as do any other claimant, to the procedures in force. I believe that the best protection of these women and children is above all through a resolute and determined struggle against all those who exploit misery, strip them of their property and deprive them of their dignity.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ Europe is currently facing an unprecedented human tragedy as ever-increasing numbers flee war and oppression to seek asylum in the EU. In the asylum process it is clear that women refugees and asylum seekers experience certain unique hardships – sometimes through officialdom whose systems are geared towards men, sometimes through criminality in the form of sexual abuse and rape. This is an important report, which I supported.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that calls for gender sensitive asylum procedures through a number of measures. The EU has played an important role in highlighting the issue of gender equality and placed it at the heart of the values on which European Union is based. The report calls for support for vulnerable women refugees and asylum seekers who may be victims of sexual violence, trafficking or other violent crimes, or discrimination, and to ensure the women’s needs throughout the asylum process.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the situation of refugee women and asylum seekers in the EU because asylum seekers have specific protection needs and different problems than men, and it is therefore necessary not to treat them as passive victims and inert aid recipients. I believe that the European Parliament should continue to be vocal and raise awareness of the needs of refugee women and asylum seekers. Safe routes can certainly help solve this problem, prevent cases of violence and abuse, and improve the conditions and condition of the facilities in which they are located, especially when it comes to pregnant and nursing women. I also believe that a common and coordinated approach by Member States is needed to ensure safe environments for women seeking international protection and to counter all forms of discrimination.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution is based on the observation that women, children and LGBTI refugees and asylum seekers are often victims of violence, both in their home countries but also in Europe, and calls for legal, material and financial facilities on their behalf. All the provisions of the text are finally aimed at further exacerbating the migrant crisis by facilitating their entry and stay in Europe, resulting in excessive expenditure.  The report does not mention persecution of Christians, who are exposed to violence, either in their country of origin or in asylum-seeker centres (the same case for Shiites, Yezidi, Kurds). The relationship does not distinguish between refugees fleeing war and economic refugees and does not address the dangerousness of some migrants, either in terms of terrorism or in terms of ordinary violence. So I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. While we absolutely sympathise the sentiments of the report regarding those who have suffered abuse and persecution and the need to make sure that decent care and facilities are available, the report also called for legal routes for asylum in to the EU, an expansion of the EU migration and asylum policies and more burden sharing of refugees between all Member States. The EU has caused this crisis and is putting everyone at risk, so UKIP voted against further expansion of EU control.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ Although I do not support the EU’s general approach towards the refugee crisis, I voted in favour of this report. This report calls for the new EU migration and asylum policies and procedures to include gender-sensitive measures to ensure the safety of women seeking asylum, many of whom travel with young children. The text rightly highlights the vulnerable situation women refugees are facing. These women often fled gendered forms of persecution – including rape, sexual violence, female genital mutilation, forced marriage in their country of origin, undertaking a perilous journey during which they may be victims of sexual violence, trafficking or other violent crimes.  Concretely, the report calls for Member States to ensure women’s and children’s specific needs are met throughout the asylum process and in reception centres.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I abstained on my colleague Mary Honeyball's report on the situation of refugees and asylum seekers in the European Union. I support improving the living conditions of refugee women, who are very problematic and who are often very vulnerable. But the report presented had shortcomings and inadequacies, and the measures recommended were impossible to implement as such. I regret that the alternative resolution proposed by my political group, the EPP, which was realistic, was not accepted.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. As with the Milnar report, there are some positive and far more critical things in this Report. Parliament should reduce these many repetitive reports that do not have legislative implications, particularly on important and serious issues such as the situation of refugee women. The requirements proposed in the text go far beyond the competences of the FEMM committee, which proposes this report and largely encroaches on the principle of subsidiarity.  I therefore abstained on this report while remaining firmly committed to the protection, promotion and equality of women's rights.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In 2015, around one million people came to Europe. 38% of this number are women and children, representing one third of the total number of immigrants seeking asylum in the European Union. Women and girls are driven by different needs than men. Their treatment is different from country to country. They are often subject to discrimination and are exposed to physical violence, including sexual violence. Improving the safety of women and girls in exile, including asylum-seeking procedures, are not the only changes contained in the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the situation of refugees and women seeking asylum in the EU.  Asylum policy and its procedures should take into account the gender aspect and assume an individual approach. The creation of safe and legal routes for obtaining asylum will reduce the operation of smuggling networks and make it possible to find shelter without endangering life. It is also important to protect refugees and women seeking asylum from any form of exploitation, abuse, violence or trafficking in human beings. The Common European Asylum System (CEAS) established between Member States is not uniform. Legal, political and practical differences contribute to the unequal treatment of women seeking protection in Europe, and security and respect for women's rights must not be contradictory political objectives.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report calls for the implementation of accelerated administrative procedures for refugees. The special protection for female migrants and opportunities for sexual health protection are welcome, but I reject undifferentiated immigration through shortened administrative procedures and have therefore voted against the report.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 During the migration crisis, the issue of refugee women and their situation is becoming topical, seeking refuge and fleeing war-ravaged areas. The facts speak for themselves: since January 2016, of all the asylum seekers reaching Greece, 55% were women and children.  We need to address this issue in order to understand what are the possible ways in which these women and children are best served, because it is this group that is most vulnerable and can be the weakest in terms of overcoming difficulties in seeking safe haven. It is clear that gender-related aspects of refugees are also an important issue in shaping migration policy. I believe that women with children are the main group to be assisted.  However, given that this report, in my opinion, concerned not only the subject matter of the issue, but also the issue of migration policy, which changes the nature of the report, I abstained in the vote on this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it calls for measures to ensure that the basic needs and human rights of women seeking asylum are addressed, including their protection from violence. The resolution sets out new comprehensive EU-wide gender guidelines as part of wider reforms to migration and asylum policy, and urgent action to improve safety and security.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was drafted by Labour MEP Mary Honeyball. Women refugees and asylum seekers have specific protection and integration needs which have too often been overlooked. To meet the needs of everyone seeking protection, our asylum laws and policies must be fully gender-sensitive at every stage. Research shows that women and girls face violence, assault, exploitation and sexual harassment at every stage of their journey, including on European soil. Women – and indeed children – who are entitled to claim asylum are being coerced into transactional sex and forced into prostitution to pay for travel documents or a place in a boat or lorry. They need safer alternatives, as this report sets out. On International Women’s Day, Labour MEPs are sending a very clear message that action must be taken to protect women and girls seeking asylum in the EU.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Written. Europe faces a huge humanitarian challenge. Hundreds of thousands of refugees have come to Europe because of war and persecution in their home country. We have a responsibility to protect them and to deal with vulnerable groups such as women and children in particular.  Today, each country alone faces the challenge. It's unsustainable. A pan-European solution, agreed between eu member states, is needed. However, what the solution should look like in practice must be up to the Member States that will take part in it. Denmark has, and will continue to have, a clear exception in the area of refugee and asylum policy. Therefore, we cannot vote for all 28 Member States to be responsible for all refugees arriving in the EU, stressing that the Danish asylum and refugee policy is determined only in Denmark. Nor are we voting in favour of establishing safe and legal asylum routes, as the proposal is not detailed.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The report by Mary Honeyball deals with the situation of female refugees and asylum seekers and addresses some important aspects. These include taking into account the specific needs of girls and women in the implementation of asylum procedures and accommodation in asylum seeker homes, the fight against trafficking in human beings and people smuggling, and protection against sexual exploitation and violence. The alternative proposal tabled by the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats included precisely these points, which is why I supported it. The Honeyball report, on the other hand, contains demands in its final version that go far beyond the target. This concerns, for example, calls for the establishment of a continuous structure for so-called LGBTI people in all Member States or for universal, unrestricted access to free, high-quality public education, health services and employment and housing.  I therefore did not vote in favour of the report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: Writing. \u2012 This report tends to highlight the extremely vulnerable position of refugee girls and women and asylum seekers, given the various forms of gender-based persecution suffered by a large part of them in their countries of origin and their already burdened situation in trying to reach Europe. The aim is to avoid secondary victimisation of these individuals during the asylum process, even in countries considered safe. It is therefore imperative to ensure a gender-sensitive asylum policy that looks forward to the material and psychological support of these individuals. In particular, it is proposed, inter alia, to diversify the stage of asylum application and distribution in reception centres between men and women, to provide compulsory training of staff in matters of sexual and psychological violence, and subsequent promotion on the labour market. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Mrs Honeyball's report calls on Member States to adequately safeguard the rights of refugees, provide them with separate accommodation, toilets and showers in reception centres, basic medical care, including for pregnant women, as well as legal advice. It condemns the sexual violence against refugees, which occurs both in the country of origin, during the journey to Europe, but also in reception centres already within the EU. condemns the forced prostitution of refugees (to pay for travel), undeclared work, their desperation and the need to raise funds for themselves and their children; calls for support in search and family reunification programmes.  In addition to these undoubtedly legitimate content, the report has many points of contention. The reservations relate to the unauthorised encroachment of the content of the report into the remit of the LIBE Committee, the competent asylum law, but also ideological political themes, such as free access to abortion or too wide a range of budget-guaranteed goods and services that even the richest EU countries cannot afford.  However, the main theme of the report – the situation of refugee women – is extremely important and urgent. I have had the opportunity to visit both reception centres and offices and organisations working for migrants, and I believe that women's problems are addressed in a legitimate and appropriate way in the report. That is why, despite the negative vote on the articles with which I disagree, I supported the report in the final vote.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, 8 March, Parliament strongly supported the resolution on refugee women and asylum seekers. Responding to the refugee crisis means above all preserving the human dignity of hundreds of thousands of girls, women and children seeking international protection in our Member States.  Women asylum seekers have specific and different protection needs than men. Until now, asylum systems have been largely assessed from a male perspective. Thanks to this important vote, we call for the development and implementation of our immigration and asylum policies to take gender issues into account.  Both in the first phase of reception, guaranteeing them not only adequate services and accommodation, but also psychological help and above all abolishing all forms of detention of women or pregnant women or who have suffered trauma or violations; both in the process of carrying out the procedures, guaranteeing them women's assistance; and especially in the phase of social inclusion and integration, facilitating them in access to education and the labour market. We have also reiterated the need to make safe and legal access routes to the European Union available, in order to improve the safety of refugee women and discourage the trafficking of migrants.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ There is no doubt that we are facing the worst ever refugee crisis in the history of Europe. In fact, the level of migration to Europe is very high which means that the scale of human tragedy is unmeasurable. It is not a secret that in this critical humanitarian situation, human trafficking is on the rise. Smugglers from Sub-Saharan Africa to Scandinavia indiscriminately abuse refugees’ human rights, disappear with families’ life savings, leave boats on purpose to stop anyone returning to shore, or sell the most desperate people to organised crime groups that which are involved in drug and organ trafficking. Unfortunately, all along the migration routes, the most vulnerable victims are women and children. Therefore, the EU should do whatever it takes to protect the most vulnerable. We cannot allow women and children to be treated and exchanged like slaves. We should provide all along the migration routes to Europe safe spaces for women and children, vital services, family tracing and protection. We should save lives rather than facilitate violence, exploitation and trafficking.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The subject of the Honeyball report is a very sensitive one and acquires greater symbolism because it is voted on Women's Day. Unfortunately, several Member States have not yet signed the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence (Istanbul Convention), and this is unacceptable to me. Despite the creation of the common European asylum system, policy and practice in the Member States continue to vary considerably. It is therefore clear that there is a gap in the protection of women asylum seekers in the EU. I therefore believe that the Union has a duty to act forcefully in this area, and the European Parliament is and will continue to be the spokesman for this body with common objectives, albeit with different political positions, as is normal when it comes to highly sensitive issues, such as the rights of refugee women and asylum seekers.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. With regard to the protection of refugee women and children on European soil, we, members of the EPP Group, did not wish to vote in favour of the Honeyball report, which is too broad, beyond the scope of the Committee on Women's Rights, and proposing a comprehensive vision of asylum, immigration and family reunification that we cannot endorse.  That is why we have tabled and voted on an alternative motion for resolution focused on concrete, realistic, reasonable and responsible proposals, based on real demands, to improve the situation of women asylum seekers and refugees, the children accompanying them, as well as the isolated minors. I believe that women should be able to receive specific assistance in the asylum application process, medical assistance for pregnant women and accommodations that respect women's right to privacy in refugee reception centres.  At the other end of the day, the fight against people smugglers and sexual abuse is one of our priorities. As part of this alternative motion for resolution, we call on the Member States and the EU institutions to take strong measures to combat human trafficking and to sign the Istanbul Convention on the subject.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. For International Women's Rights Day, Parliament adopted a series of recommendations to help refugee women.  These include: the demand to create safe migration channels, particularly for asylum seekers; the request to take women's rights into account in the definition of a "safe" country (i.e. a country that will be considered to be safe in the event of repatriation and therefore does not justify an asylum application); Better information for migrant women about their rights; an end to the detention of minors and pregnant women; improved reception conditions. I have, of course, supported the adoption of this report.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because, under the pretext of helping women seeking asylum, it will exacerbate the migrant crisis by facilitating their entry into Europe. It also guarantees them rights (housing, health, employment) that are often denied to European women.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The report documents the violence suffered by women, children and LGTBI refugees and asylum seekers in their countries of origin and in Europe. In order to alleviate the problem, the text proposes to create, among other things, reception and transit centres adapted for these people, to facilitate their asylum applications, to promote their integration into the labour market...  However, all these provisions only increase the arrival of migrants in Europe, without the authorities making the necessary distinctions between war refugees and economic refugees. Nor do they take into account the dangerousness of certain migrants (terrorists or common criminals). Moreover, the persecution of Christians in these war-fighting countries is not mentioned. I logically voted against this text.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is important that asylum policies and procedures are gender sensitive. 55% of refugees arriving in Europe are women, girls and children. To ensure that women's specific needs are addressed, gender-specific training, including gender-based violence, needs to be promoted for staff; sanitary facilities and gender-segregated rooms; guarantee the right to request female interviewers and interpreters; ensure access to women's health services; provide childcare services during exams and interviews; inform women of their right to file an independent asylum application, etc.  It is also urgent that there be no further internment of children, pregnant women and survivors of rape, sexual assault and trafficking. And, of course, measures are needed for the integration of refugee women and asylum seekers into the labour market. The solution to the refugee crisis is not to return them to Turkey, but to create legal avenues of immigration and implement integration policies. The dignity of the European project based on the principles of solidarity, justice and equality is at stake.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it aims to correct the situation of extreme vulnerability of refugee women within the European Union. Women fleeing persecution in their home states face an extremely dangerous journey, facing risks such as attacks, rapes, scams, human trafficking and even death. These women, who in themselves are tremendously vulnerable in their home country, face additional obstacles to their arrival in the European Union, increasing their vulnerability. The report proposes that asylum procedures and policies, including the assessment of applications, should be gender sensitive, and calls for all issues relating to gender-based violence, such as rape, sexual violence, female genital mutilation, forced marriage or domestic violence, to be considered as valid reasons for receiving asylum in the European Union. It also focuses on the protection of LGBTI's collective and calls for an end to the detentions of children, pregnant women seeking asylum, or survivors of rape, sexual violence and human trafficking. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The report by Mary Honeyball deals with the situation of female refugees and asylum seekers and addresses some important aspects. These include taking into account the specific needs of girls and women in the implementation of asylum procedures and accommodation in asylum seeker homes, the fight against trafficking in human beings and people smuggling, and protection against sexual exploitation and violence. The alternative proposal tabled by the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats included precisely these points, which is why I supported it. The Honeyball report, on the other hand, contains demands in its final version that go far beyond the target. This concerns, for example, calls for the establishment of a continuous structure for so-called LGBTI people in all Member States or for universal, unrestricted access to free, high-quality public education, health services and employment and housing.  I therefore did not vote in favour of the report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree that sexual minorities should be taken into account in asylum proceedings. This will only lead to asylum seekers opting out of sexual minorities in order to have a better chance of obtaining asylum.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. In 2014, more than half of the refugees were women. Given the growing number of refugees arriving in the EU, it is necessary to take into account the situation of refugee women and asylum seekers. Women are unprotected during refuge and often be victims of sexual assault and/or human trafficking. As recent surveys show that there are currently more male asylum seekers, the report notes the need to provide additional support to asylum seekers and the necessity of identifying their needs during refugee work. I consider the report insufficient because it excludes certain issues related to asylum seekers and to the extent of changes to the current asylum system that goes beyond this type of report. That's why I didn't support my colleague Mary Honeyball's report.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Women, who are among the most vulnerable groups in the event of conflict and instability, currently make up one third of the total number of asylum seekers. In their countries, but also on their way to the EU, they are victims of gender violence, discrimination, trafficking, physical and psychological abuse. In addition, 20 000 women from countries where women are still being mutilation in the 21st century are also applying for asylum in the EU every year.  I support the application of conventions, regulations and humanitarian aid in the field of refugee and asylum, taking into account the gender aspect. As a matter of priority, assistance and support must be given to women and children, while strict respect for safety rules. Cooperation between all forces, the police, the judiciary and other security and investigative forces needs to be stepped up, both at Member State and EU level. This process must be special for women, from asylum policy to social integration, and must sensitively take into account the physical and psychological suffering that women have endured.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the situation of female refugees and asylum seekers in the EU because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is based on the simple observation that women, children and LGBTI refugees and asylum seekers are often victims of violence, not only in their countries of origin but also in Europe. It therefore calls for appropriate reception and transit centres, facilitating asylum applications, guaranteeing care, stopping all detentions of minors, providing childcare during selection and asylum interviews, facilitating the integration of refugees into the labour market, providing training and language courses and encouraging Member States to use the Structural and Investment Funds.  This report completely forgets to distinguish between refugees fleeing war and economic refugees, it does not even address the subject of the dangerousness of some migrants (and yet the events in Cologne have proved that these concerns are legitimate), it does not mention the persecution of Christians, yet exposed to violence... These provisions, thus adopted by the well-meaning MEPs, will further exacerbate the migrant crisis, since they will facilitate their entry and stay in Europe, resulting in excessive spending.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Report which: emphasises the urgent need to immediately open safe and legal asylum routes, in order to counter smuggling networks and to increasingly enable women, children, the elderly and people with disabilities to seek refuge without risking their lives; is deeply concerned about deaths, pushbacks and grave human rights violations at the EU external borders; takes the view that responsibilities and costs and benefits should be shared by all 28 Member States and not just by the countries of first arrival; regrets the lack of solidarity among Member States.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a draft report on the situation of refugees and asylum seekers in the EU. It's a very sensitive and complex subject. I am fully aware of the complexity of the position of women, and especially women with children, in a situation where they find themselves unasprotested and living in precarious conditions while waiting for their asylum application to be processed in one of the EU Member States. However, I think the report lacks the basic themes and these are solutions to the situation in places of conflict so that even women do not have to flee their homes, the fight against illegal smugglers, who are responsible for a number of lives, as well as the protection of the EU's external borders and the fight against illegal migration. We are only dealing with the consequences, but we are neglecting to focus on the causes and prevention of problems, which is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on this report. Together with my political group, we recognise the humanitarian side and the plight of the thousands of migrants who see women and girls as particularly at risk on their journey to the European Union. We are aware that women are often trafficn for prostitution-related human beings, that many girls flee countries where genital mutilation is practised or that they essentially escape from war zones where hunger and misery are everyday life. There is no doubt that it is necessary to adopt a gender perspective in the management of migration. To my regret, the draft report includes references to asylum procedures in general, family reunification, reception and detention policies without focusing on the gender perspective. All these issues are beyond the competence of the FEMM Committee.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. Women and children account for around 35% of refugees. This group is in a highly vulnerable situation, fleeing persecution and violence in its country of origin, subjecting itself to dangerous routes to Europe in search of a safe place.  Unfortunately, when they arrive here, their situation of vulnerability is not taken in particular attention. This report draws attention to the need for asylum policies and procedures to be sensitive to gender issues, gender-based violence such as rape, forced genital mutilation, forced marriages, domestic violence, among others, which should be valid arguments in the asylum application.   However, refugee reception centres should be prepared for their reception by providing the indicated medical care, health facilities and dormitories separated by gender where necessary, legal and psychological advice, as well as promoting measures facilitating their integration into the host country.  I voted for it.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 The right to asylum is enshrined in Article 18 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The increased flows of refugees arriving at our borders demonstrate our duty to offer protection to these tortured people. In this number of people there are also women and children, who are undoubtedly a more vulnerable group of people, who need supporting measures to protect it. The increased need to protect refugee women is also evident from the fact that the minority of asylum seekers are women and underage girls who are more at risk than men, such as their abduction and sexual abuse on their way to the EU. Also, the death rates of women along the way are higher compared to those of men. This manifest injustice must be taken into account and dealt with in a timely manner by ensuring safe and legal path to the EU, as this resolution rightly points out; Finally, the provision of psychosocial assistance to women victims of traumatic experiences is considered necessary.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. More and more women and children fleeing war and persecution in their country are arriving in Europe, taking the risk of dying at sea, falling into the hands of criminal networks, but also being subjected to discrimination and violence in reception centres once they arrive. Without providing lasting solutions to the migration crisis, Parliament seeks here to ensure dignified and safe reception conditions, or psychological support for women victims of sexual violence. It calls for such violence (genital mutilation, forced marriage) to be recognized as valid grounds for applying for asylum. He denounces the detention of children and pregnant women. It calls on states to open a humanitarian corridor to allow refugees to apply for asylum safely but also not to place the responsibility for the reception solely on Greece.   I am voting for this very concrete report on the needs of refugee women but lacking in hindsight on the overall responsibility of the Union in these population displacements.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The measures I have seen in this report are good intentions, and how would they not be, when we see the extent of this migration wave? But it is clear that all these measures will facilitate the entry and residence of foreigners in Europe, especially if the report does not distinguish between political refugees and economic migrants. Moreover, the report does not mention the risks to the influx of foreigners. This translates into a potential terrorist threat. It is not serious, we have to react. Finally, I deplore the fact that violence against Christians in asylum centres as well as in their own countries is not mentioned.  As a result, I voted against this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU. I believe that the rapporteur has deviated from the essential objective of the report.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I could not support this resolution as despite many positive elements, the final version of the text included unacceptable references to the right and access to sexual and reproductive health services and the right to abortion.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. There is a real need to protect women and children. According to the United Nations Refugee Agency, women and children accounted for up to 55% of refugees in January 2016. It is now women who are arriving in greater numbers in Europe. Their vulnerability requires special attention To combat sexual exploitation, trafficking and prostitution.  We need to promote trafficking detection, identify loverboys, train people who can detect trafficking, especially in NGOs. We will not get out of this if we all work together. Only a comprehensive long-term strategy can overcome this crisis. We can only regret that our memory of the past is not long enough to respond to the universal values we stand for, to the ethics we advocate.  This crisis must not destroy the Europe of solidarity, justice and equality. It is about the dignity of women, the dignity of man and the dignity of the EU. If Europe does nothing, history will remember that it has turned away from its values.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – According to a report by the Office of the United Nations High Representative for Refugees, around half of the total number of refugees are women and girls. At EU level, however, mostly adult men apply for asylum. This also puts women refugees in a vulnerable position, as they often face threats and sexual violence from smugglers during their journey to international protection. It is essential for the EU to recognise the seriousness of this problem and to combat it by introducing effective measures to provide women and young girls with protection that prevents threats to health and lives. The European Parliament also takes into account the gender aspect in the interpretation of the International Convention on Refugees. Conditions must be created for women in asylum homes to avoid the risks of sexual violence (separate sleeping area, separate sanitary facilities, psychological counselling, etc.). The humanitarian crisis plaguing Europe presents a number of challenges that can only be overcome by the joint efforts of all the Member States. However, I believe that the motion for a resolution on the situation of refugees and asylum seekers in the EU contains parts interfering with asylum procedures which are not within the competence of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, but of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Constitutional Affairs, or within the competence of the Member States. I am voting against the proposal as it stands.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU because it stresses the vulnerable situation of women asylum seekers and refugees in the European Union. In 2015, about one million people crossed Mediterranean. Women and children accounted for around 35% of refugees. In January 2016, women accounted for 55%. They have fled persecution in their home countries only to undertake a perilous journey in order to reach a place of safety.  However, I voted against the paragraphs calling on Member States to implement measures on abortion, sexual and reproductive rights. The EU has no competences on abortion policy at national level and, therefore, cannot interfere in Member States’ policies in this area, which we should fully respect.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Women refugees have shown great strength to risk everything and flee their war-torn home country, cross the seas in dreadful conditions facing physical assault, abuse and violence and look now for protection in the EU. During the asylum process, on European soil, they are still exposed to gender-based harm and remain a particularly vulnerable category. Europe needs to stand together and give a humanitarian response, and as policy makers we need to address their basic social, medical and economic needs. It is the week we celebrate International Women’s Day; following our European values, I hereby support and respect the right of these women, who have been through enough already, to seek asylum in proper conditions.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. In 2014, half of the world's refugee population consisted of women and girls. International conventions and national asylum policies have generally ignored the specific situation of female asylum seekers and the gender-related aspects of refugee situations. The report by the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality points out that female refugees are vulnerable throughout their journey. Gender-based violence, as well as being one of the main causes of women's escape, is always a feature of their journey to and from the EU. It notes, however, that the legislation constituting the Common European Asylum System has not so long guaranteed uniform and gender-relevant treatment of women seeking protection in Europe. It advocates that EU refugee policy must be sensitive at all stages to what women are experiencing.  The report states that the scale of the humanitarian crisis facing Europe is of grave concern. Such crises also magnify unequal relations between the sexes. At the same time, the current period of uncertainty and confusion is also an opportunity to coordinate best practices on the treatment of female asylum seekers and refugees. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution is based on the observation that women, children and LGBTI refugees and asylum seekers are often victims of violence, both in their countries of origin but also in Europe, and calls for legal, material and financial facilities on their behalf.  All these provisions aim to further exacerbate the migrant crisis by facilitating their entry and stay in Europe, resulting in excessive expenditure.  The report does not mention persecution of Christians, who are exposed to violence, either in their countries of origin or in asylum-seeker centres (idem for Shiites, Yezidi, Kurds). It does not distinguish refugees fleeing the war from economic refugees and, of course, it does not mention the dangerousness of some migrants, either in terms of terrorism or in terms of ordinary violence, as at Cologne train station. Once again, it is a question of blaming the host countries and the Europeans, who are always suspected of racism, and not doing enough to accommodate all the misery of the world. The vote is resolutely against.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Women account for, on average, one third of asylum seekers. Between the beginning of 2015 and November of the same year, some 900,000 people crossed the Mediterranean and reached the coast of Europe, representing about 38% of the total for women and children. I have decided to abstain in this report because I believe that all refugees should be welcomed and treated well on the territory of the European Union and there should be no gender discrimination. Knowing that many of these refugees still do not have decent living conditions, I understand that everyone, regardless of whether they are men or women, should have the best living conditions.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. All these provisions are ultimately aimed at further exacerbating the migrant crisis by facilitating their entry and stay in Europe, and by driving excessive expenditure. Moreover, the report makes no distinction between political refugees and economic migrants. That is why I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was drafted by Labour MEP Mary Honeyball. Women refugees and asylum seekers have specific protection and integration needs which have too often been overlooked. To meet the needs of everyone seeking protection, our asylum laws and policies must be fully gender sensitive at every stage. Research shows that women and girls face violence, assault, exploitation and sexual harassment at every stage of their journey, including on European soil. Women – and indeed children – who are entitled to claim asylum are being coerced into transactional sex and forced into prostitution to pay for travel documents or a place in a boat or lorry. They need safer alternatives, as this report sets out. On International Women’s Day Labour MEPs are sending a very clear message that action must be taken to protect women and girls seeking asylum in the EU

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on this text. While women and girls are people more vulnerable to violence and persecution than men, the presence in this text of provisions that facilitate family reunification or limit the length of detention of people who have not been granted refugee status at a time when the European Union is experiencing a migration tragedy is irresponsible.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. ‒Surveys for 2014 show that half of the world's refugee population is made up of women and girls. This means that one in two refugees is affected by the report on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers that we voted on today. Because of their vulnerability, refugee women are very often victims of violence on an already dangerous journey to Europe. By developing an infrastructure in our refugee camps that allows women to meet their basic hygiene needs separately from male refugees, we can greatly reduce the risk of gender-based violence. This will make refugee women feel safer staying in Europe while they wait for their refugee status to be assessed.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Half of the world's refugee population in 2014 were represented by women and girls.  The European Parliament was the first international body to acknowledge the need for a gender-sensitive interpretation of the Refugee Convention, in a resolution of 13 April 1984. I have voted for this report that reiterates the need to guarantee a consistent and gender-sensitive treatment for women seeking protection in Europe.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – The EU is undoubtedly going through the most serious crisis since its inception.  Thousands of people are coming to the Old Continent in the hope of finding international protection. However, we cannot put them under a common denominator. Women and men who leave their homes to escape war face different risks and are vulnerable differently. It is important to clarify that, according to the latest figures, women and refugee children accounted for more than half of asylum seekers in the EU in 2016. I don't think we can turn a blind eye to their suffering and grief. Driven by this conviction, I supported the draft EP resolution calling for European measures to protect refugee women. I firmly stand by the position that EU migration and asylum policy must have a mechanism in place to ensure their safety and protection. The fight against people smuggling will only be successful if we provide safe and secure routes to the EU.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ In 2014, half of the world’s refugee population were women and girls. Laws and policies, despite the establishment of the Common European Asylum System (CEAS), differ significantly across Member States. Additionally, there continues to be a discernible gap in the protection of women seeking asylum in the EU. As a result, a new all-inclusive set of EU-wide gender guidelines should be adopted as part of wider reforms to migration and asylum policy. The acts making up the CEAS have so far not assured consistent and gender-sensitive treatment for women seeking asylum. Although there is currently legislation and policy designed in a gender-sensitive way, significant shortcomings persist. While some policies are gender-sensitive, this does not always ensure their effective implementation. This policy must be sensitive and responsive to women’s experiences at every stage. Women asylum seekers and refugees must be given a greater voice for policy makers to comprehend how gendered relations of power yield forced displacement and specific gendered needs. Unequal gender relations have intensified during this humanitarian crisis. However, this time also allows for the possibility to harmonise best practice in the treatment of women asylum seekers. For these reasons, I have voted in favour of the above proposal.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report includes not only the special protection of female refugees but also the implementation of accelerated administrative procedures for refugees. The former is to be welcomed, but I am opposed to the shortened administrative procedures, as they do not guarantee a thorough examination. I voted against the report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Member States must pay attention to creating a safe and non-discriminatory environment for female refugees and asylum seekers, as women are more likely to be victims of violence.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. The European Parliament was the first international body, in its Resolution of 13 April 1984, to recognise the need for an interpretation of the Convention on the Status of Refugees based on gender considerations. Considerations that have subsequently been taken into account by organizations such as UNHCR and many countries. About half of the world's refugees are women and girls. These groups are the most vulnerable and face specific risky situations such as trafficking or sexual violence.  This report is of crucial importance as it echoes the specific situation faced by women and girls and because it calls for a broader reform of migration and asylum policies that takes into account the gender dimension. These proposals include some as important as the signing and ratification of the Istanbul Convention, improving the security and reception conditions of refugees, and providing additional resources to deal with trafficking and trafficking in women and girls and sexual violence.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 It should be noted that there is a clear link between the current migration crisis and the increase in smuggling and trafficking in human beings. In order to save lives and increase the credibility of legal routes to the EU, it is necessary to prevent irregular migration and to develop safe and sustainable migration routes to Europe as soon as possible. Particular attention must be paid to strengthening the control of the EU's external borders and improving the management of migratory flows.  All counter-measures to the migration crisis should be global in view of the particular situation of refugees and asylum seekers for women and girls. A common EU list of safe countries of origin should be established. In addition, an integrated approach to legal humanitarian migration should be applied and asylum procedures should be strengthened, which takes due account of the special needs of women and girls.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 At a time when thousands of refugees, the majority of them women and children, are facing repression and the barbaric policy of the EU and the Member States putting their lives at risk, the European Parliament's report on "female refugees" legitimises and promotes reactionary EU regulations. In particular, it premiums the detention of refugees by effectively cancelling the Geneva Convention on Refugees and Asylum Seekers. Empty expressions of sympathy for female refugees make no secret of the fact that the report supports the eu's entire anti-immigration policy; calling for: making full use of Dublin for the entrapment of refugees in the host countries, increasing Member States' cooperation with Europol, Eurojust, FRONTEX, the Asylum Service, in the name of combating slave traders, which portends an intensity of repression, acceptance of the "common list of safe host countries" for mass deportations in the fire of war. The report's wish list does not meet their urgent demands for: direct transfer to the countries of final destination, abolition of detention centres, open decent reception and temporary accommodation areas with adequate health care infrastructure, rapid and fair asylum, the granting of travel documents, the abolition of Dublin, Schengen and FRONTEX.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. While we absolutely sympathise the sentiments of the report regarding those who have suffered abuse and persecution and the need to make sure that decent care and facilities are available, the report also called for legal routes for asylum in to the EU, an expansion of the EU migration and asylum policies and more burden sharing of refugees between all Member States. The EU has caused this crisis and is putting everyone at risk, so UKIP voted against further expansion of EU control.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 National asylum policies have always tended to ignore the specific position of women and the gender aspects of refugee situations. In fact, in 2014, half of the world's refugee population was made up of women and girls, and unfortunately the asylum systems had been largely assessed from a male perspective.  Despite the creation of the common European asylum system, law, policy and practice in the Member States continue to vary considerably and there is a clear gap in the protection granted by axis. Fleeing women are on the rise and vulnerable at all stages of their journey to their countries of origin, transit and destination. In addition to being an essential factor behind women's decisions to flee, gender-based violence is a common feature during their journey to and within the EU.  A new comprehensive set of gender guidelines at EU level should be adopted as part of the wider reforms of asylum and migration policy.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. It is true that refugee women, migrant women and children are a particularly vulnerable group that therefore requires special attention and access and we must persistently combat the violence and exploitation that women face on the migrant route and ensure that they are adequately protected and cared for. However, we cannot induce into the regulation of asylum rights and undermine the principle of subsidiarity on which the EU is founded.  This report goes beyond the scope of both the Committee in which it was created and the EU, so I could not support it. I agree that women and children need to be given special care and access, that particular attention should be paid to pregnant women and mothers who have given birth on their migrant route, starting from adequate housing and medical assistance to preventing human trafficking to which women and children are particularly exposed, but I think that the measures proposed by this report are simply not appropriate, and many of them are completely unacceptable and contrary to fundamental rights. I reiterate that the EU must do everything in its power to help counterappression of the very source that led to this crisis, as our ultimate goal must be peace in restless areas, returning people to their homes and allowing peaceful coexistence.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report proposes an extremely generous policy for refugees. While I am not insensitive to the situation of individuals who are victims of conflict, I do not forget that the European Union imposes on the citizens of the Member States a policy of austerity that impoverishes and makes them vulnerable.  Such generosity towards migrants while the situation in their countries of origin remains dramatic can only increase flows and attract even more people to the territory of a European Union that can no longer even treat its own inhabitants with dignity. Citizens are hostile to it and the phenomenon can only continue to cause various tensions and disturbances. I therefore find this report particularly irresponsible and I therefore vote against it.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I strongly support the need to adopt new gender guidelines on asylum and migration to be taken into account when designing, implementing and evaluating European policies. I also support the idea that gender-based violence and discrimination should be interpreted as a form of persecution and therefore be a valid reason for seeking asylum in the EU. Member States must ensure satisfactory and binding gender guidelines and ensure that their practices comply with UNCHR guidelines on international protection. The Commission must establish a list of safe countries of origin while maintaining the principle of non-refoulement for women and girls arriving from countries where there is a high rate of crimes and gender-based violence, and we need to ensure that specialist staff are welcomed in order to allow the sharing of experiences. It should be remembered that women are not vulnerable in themselves but become vulnerable because of the conditions in which they travel and the complications they face during transit. EU countries cannot help but take high regard for the issue of women in addressing the impact of the arrival of refugees.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ From the beginning of 2015 to the month of November of the same year, around 900 000 people arrived on European shores via the Mediterranean, with around 38% of the total number of women and children. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) reported that as of January 2016, women and children have made up 55% of people arriving in Greece seeking asylum in the European Union. In general, women on average make up a third of asylum seekers and need special protection that takes into account the fact that they have different problems than men, and that their rights are at risk when their legal status depends on their spouse, which is why it is necessary to ensure that all asylum policies and procedures are implemented, including in the assessment of asylum applications , take into account the gender issue and be decided on a case-by-case basis. Refugee women are often subject to multiple discrimination and are most vulnerable to sexual violence and human trafficking. For this reason, I welcome this important resolution, which calls for a number of measures to ensure that the needs of refugee women are met so that their already vulnerable situation does not deteriorate further upon arrival at the reception centre and in the asylum process itself.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. This report focuses on the measures to be taken in response to the so-called refugee crisis, with particular relevance to women and children seeking asylum. The number of women and children arriving in Europe has been increasing, with around 55% of all refugees.  The report advocates safe and legal ways of accessing the EU and seeks to frame a broad set of situations that are valid grounds for applying for asylum. It is positive, but it does not depart from the logic of creating restrictions on those fleeing hunger, misery, war, seeking to be helped on European soil, aiming at the distinction between refugees and migrants. The report calls for measures that meet the specific needs of women and children during the asylum application process, around the registration process, psychological support, access to health care, including sexual and reproductive care, non-detention of children, the establishment of appropriate facilities for maternal care, labour market integration measures and access to language courses and public education , free and quality. Despite the absence of any critical position on the causes and responsibilities of the EU at the origin of this exodus, we voted in favour of the report.

name: Kati PIRI
text: in writing. – Human dignity, respect and a safe place to stay! Let us not forget this when we talk about women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU and their vulnerable situation. Let us talk about people and not only about numbers. We are talking about women who are too afraid to close their eyes in the mixed sleeping areas of reception centres. We are talking about victims of sexual violence. We are talking about people whom we are failing to protect, whose multiple victimisation we are not able to prevent. Women suffer disproportionately on their way to the EU and while staying in reception centres. We fail to protect them sufficiently and need to take appropriate measures to change this degrading situation. We need to prioritise these measures: first, make available safe and legal routes to the EU, by cooperating with third countries such as Turkey and by unravelling criminal networks. Second, we need to improve our internal cooperation; stop talking about numbers – take action! Third, we need to ensure that gender budgeting is applied while funding facilities for refugees: practical measures to make separate sleeping arrangements and bathrooms, and to organise gender sensitivity training for coast guards, police, interviewers and interpreters.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ I am proud to say that, on International Women’s Day, there was such a favourable response in the European Parliament for this report which will not only protect but support women refugees and asylum seekers in the European Union. The enormity of the humanitarian crisis currently facing Europe is a cause for grave concern and has unfairly left women in a less favourable position. Women seeking asylum should have access to high quality specialised services at the earliest possible opportunity and Parliament promotes in its report their access to these services. I believe that the European Union will move in the right direction to end gender-based discrimination and violence when the refugees enter European Union territory. During this crisis an opportunity presents itself to create better practices in the treatment of women asylum seekers and refugees in Europe.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 According to this report, gender measures to ensure the safety of women seeking asylum, many of whom travel with young children and other dependents, should be part of the EU's migration and asylum policy reform proposals. According to this report, asylum policies and procedures, including the assessment of asylum applications, should take gender issues into account, while gender-based forms of violence should be recognised as valid reasons for seeking asylum in the European Union, to ensure that women's specific needs are respected throughout the asylum process and in reception centres. I believe that some of these measures are perfectly legitimate and acceptable but, here too, the text dismissed by the FEMM Committee suffers from certain ideological forcings, distant from reality and a source of misunderstanding. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report is extremely controversial. The FEMM Commission has proposed measures to improve the situation of immigrant women and girls, which should be adopted by the Member States. One third of the report exceeds the remit of the FEMM Committee and enters into the remit of the LIBE Committee. The LIBE paragraphs call on Member States to immediately establish safe and legal asylum routes, reform Frontex, establish Community-wide guidelines for women as part of a broader migration and asylum reform, guarantee special accommodation for LGBTI people, review EU policies on safe countries of origin, pay particular attention to women's asylum applications and avoid detaining asylum seekers.  The report pays particular attention to: the gender dimension in determining refugee status (preferential treatment for refugees, both women and girls, but nothing about young boys); the needs of women asylum seekers (specially trained for the sex of counsellor); trafficking and smuggling of people and sexual violence, and in this context free access to abortion. That is why I could not support the report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, I had to abstain from voting on the draft, which deals with the situation of refugees and asylum seekers, because, unfortunately, the provisions blaming countries with different views on the migration crisis and quotas for a lack of solidarity have been repackached for rational proposals that call for improving the situation of the groups of women described. Let us not give Member States the right to decide their positions.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I abstained on this report for several reasons. The issue of the situation of refugees and asylum seekers is complex, particularly at a time when migration flows to Europe are increasing. As part of the review of the report, my political group decided to draft an alternative resolution emphasizing the humanitarian aspect of the situation and recalling the need to adapt our reception structures and procedures to the specific needs of refugee and asylum-seeking women, often accompanied by children.  I would like to remind you that it is children and women who are the first victims of the migration crisis as a whole, including being the target of human trafficking, which we must fight with force. But above all, as the principle of subsidiarity is fundamental, it is necessary for Member States to take responsibility for the management of refugees and asylum seekers.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. While we absolutely sympathise the sentiments of the report regarding those who have suffered abuse and persecution and the need to make sure that decent care and facilities are available, the report also called for legal routes for asylum in to the EU, an expansion of the EU migration and asylum policies and more burden sharing of refugees between all Member States. The EU has caused this crisis and is putting everyone at risk, so UKIP voted against further expansion of EU control.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. It is difficult to obtain accurate statistics on the demographic diversity of refugees trying to reach Europe. However, current studies suggest that more men are coming to the EU looking for international protection than women and children. This is mainly due to the lack of protection that women face during the journey.  Women are often left behind to care for children and elderly family members and there are many who do not have the independence to leave their country of origin. Those who manage to escape are vulnerable at all stages of travel – in countries of origin, transit and destination – and one of the concerns of the report is that the European Union's asylum policy will take into account the experiences of women at all these stages. The acts of violence of which they are victims are often committed by non-state actors, including family members. Persecution occurs when the state cannot or does not want to grant protection to women. The report therefore states that a new comprehensive package of EU gender guidelines should be adopted in the wider context of migration and asylum policy reforms, and I therefore voted positively.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. In 2014, half of the world's refugee population was made up of women and girls. Historically, there has been a tendency for international conventions and national asylum policies to ignore the specific situation of women asylum seekers and the gender dimension in refugee situations. Asylum systems have largely been examined on the basis of male experience. Despite the creation of the Common European Asylum System (CEAS), laws, policies and practices in the Member States continue to vary significantly and there are notorious gaps in the protection of women seeking asylum in the EU. This report suggests a number of measures to ensure that the specific needs of asylum-seeking women and girls are taken into account by Member States.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is important that asylum policies and procedures are gender sensitive. 55% of refugees arriving in Europe are women, girls and children.
