To ensure that women's specific needs are addressed, gender-specific training, including gender-based violence, needs to be promoted for staff; sanitary facilities and gender-segregated rooms; guarantee the right to request female interviewers and interpreters; ensure access to women's health services; provide childcare services during exams and interviews; inform women of their right to file an independent asylum application, etc.  It is also urgent that there be no further internment of children, pregnant women and survivors of rape, sexual assault and trafficking. And, of course, measures are needed for the integration of refugee women and asylum seekers into the labour market. The solution to the refugee crisis is not to return them to Turkey, but to create legal avenues of immigration and implement integration policies. The dignity of the European project based on the principles of solidarity, justice and equality is at stake.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Asylum policies and procedures, including the assessment of asylum claims, must take gender equality into account. Gender-based forms of violence, including rape, sexual violence, female genital mutilation, forced marriage and domestic violence, should be a valid reason to seek asylum in the EU, says the text of the report we voted on yesterday in plenary session.  The text also recommends various measures to ensure that women's specific needs are respected throughout the asylum procedure and in reception centres, including: separate housing and sanitation facilities for men and women; female translators and interpreters; specialized trauma counselling services for women who have experienced gender-based violence; child care during selection and asylum interviews; information provided to women about their right to apply for asylum independent of their spouse's and to have legal status independent of that of their spouse; training that takes into account the specifics of women and men for staff and legal aid for women in reception centres.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 The current situation in the Middle East does not suggest that we will be able to successfully resolve the refugee crisis in the near future. So far, we can only help alleviate the misery of refugees from this region. The report by my colleague Mary Honeyball on the situation of female refugees is a valuable document defining where and how the EU can do its best on the latter issue. And that is why he deserves full support. At the same time, I would like to stress that the EU is not a charity for the whole world and we must therefore pay more attention to what needs to be done to bring the flow of refugees to an end ˗ namely the resolution of the Syrian and other bloody conflicts.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. Worldwide, half of the displaced and refugees in 2015 were women. In Europe today, this figure is around one third. As these women flee war and the violence they are specifically subjected to in their country of origin (forced marriages, rape, mutilation), they face the same difficulties on the road to Europe and refugee camps.  Mary Honeyball's resolution clearly calls for consideration of the gender dimension in asylum policy. It calls for the specific needs of women to be taken into account: separate sanitary facilities, specific housing, the use of female staff, the establishment of appropriate psychological and legal counselling services, and staff training.  Beyond the situation in the camps, the EU must open supervised and secure access routes to ensure the safety of migrant women and to stop the administrative detention of women and their children. Finally, the resolution also votes on the integration of these women into our societies, through access to the labour market and education. So I supported that report.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Written. \u2012 Mr President, I am in favour of the rights of women, children and sexual minorities. These are human rights, values that the EU should always promote – raining or shining. Honeyball's report comes true on a rainy day. Among other things, it calls for the opening of new legal entry routes for refugees. This would further increase the EU's attractiveness and increase the number of leavers.  I cannot support such a policy. And should LGBTI people be better taken into account in the refugee crisis? I'm sure I should. But is this the main concern? Dead children are washed up on European shores and we are here for equal treatment of LGBTI people. Let's focus on what's going on.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. This year, the European Parliament dedicated International Women's Rights Day to refugee and asylum-seeking women. On this occasion, I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation of refugee women. It should be remembered that, since the beginning of 2015, 900,000 people have reached European shores, of whom 38% are women and children.  As this resolution reminds us, it is a question of taking into account the needs of women in asylum procedures, such as the right to be registered individually, to be granted legal status independent of that of their spouse, or the right to request an interpreter and conduct an individual interview away from any third party. I supported this resolution which calls for an end to all childcare in the EU, but also to respond to an alarming health situation by setting up reception facilities and health services tailored to the specific needs of refugee women.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report dealing with the situation of refugee women and asylum seekers in the EU. The report is positive in that it believes that asylum policies and procedures and application assessments should include a gender approach. It includes gender-based violence, rape, sexual violence, female mutilation, forced marriage or sexist violence as grounds for asylum applications in the EU. It also includes persecution and violence against LGBTI groups. The report calls for measures to ensure that women's needs are met during the asylum process. Safe and legal routes are requested to ensure the safety of women on their way to the EU to prevent human trafficking and mafias. It stresses that immigration policies and legislation should not prevent access to the EU asylum procedure. It stresses the importance of labour insertion measures. It calls for solidarity between EU countries and that responsibility should not be based solely on the countries of first destination, which we believe is necessary.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. Europe faces a huge humanitarian challenge. Hundreds of thousands of refugees have come to Europe because of war and persecution in their home country. We have a responsibility to protect them and to deal with vulnerable groups such as women and children in particular.  Today, each country alone faces the challenge. It's unsustainable. A pan-European solution, agreed between eu member states, is needed. However, what the solution should look like in practice must be up to the Member States that will take part in it. Denmark has, and will continue to have, a clear exception in the area of refugee and asylum policy. Therefore, we cannot vote for all 28 Member States to be responsible for all refugees arriving in the EU, stressing that the Danish asylum and refugee policy is determined only in Denmark. Nor are we voting in favour of establishing safe and legal asylum routes, as the proposal is not detailed.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I abstained on the report on the situation of female refugees and asylum seekers in the EU, as I believe it contains too many aspects that affect the asylum procedure in general and are not focused on gender issues. This overstates the competences of the FEMM Committee (Women's Rights and Gender Equality) and interferes with the LIBE Committee (Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs).  Although I am well aware of the difficult situation of women and girls fleeing conflict and war zones, I think that the gender perspective needs to be examined in more detail and less generally. However, this has not happened with this report.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it aims to correct the situation of extreme vulnerability of refugee women within the European Union. Women fleeing persecution in their home states face an extremely dangerous journey, facing risks such as attacks, rapes, scams, human trafficking and even death. These women, who in themselves are tremendously vulnerable in their home country, face additional obstacles to their arrival in the European Union, increasing their vulnerability. The report proposes that asylum procedures and policies, including the assessment of applications, should be gender sensitive, and calls for all issues relating to gender-based violence, such as rape, sexual violence, female genital mutilation, forced marriage or domestic violence, to be considered as valid reasons for receiving asylum in the European Union. It also focuses on the protection of LGBTI's collective and calls for an end to the detentions of children, pregnant women seeking asylum, or survivors of rape, sexual violence and human trafficking. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. While we absolutely sympathise the sentiments of the report regarding those who have suffered abuse and persecution and the need to make sure that decent care and facilities are available, the report also called for legal routes for asylum in to the EU, an expansion of the EU migration and asylum policies and more burden sharing of refugees between all Member States. The EU has caused this crisis and is putting everyone at risk, so UKIP voted against further expansion of EU control.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to congratulate my colleague and fellow Labour Member Mary Honeyball on this report and all the work that she has put into it. The report that was put in front of the chamber today calls for a number of measures to ensure that women’s needs are met throughout the asylum process, allowing for gender-specific training for staff, including comprehensive training on sexual violence, trafficking and Female Genital Mutilation (FGM). Indeed, in 2015, about one million people crossed the Mediterranean into Europe, with women and children making up around 35% of the refugees. We need to highlight the exceptionally vulnerable situation that female asylum seekers and refugees in the European Union face. Having fled persecution in their home countries, seeking a place of safety, many become victims of sexual violence, trafficking and other violent crimes, which disproportionately affect women. I want to see a more gender sensitive asylum procedure through the measures outlines in this report.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ the report highlights the specific situation of women who very often flee with their children against the horrors of conflict raging in their homes. Many of the motions for a resolution adopted focus precisely on the needs and concrete assistance of this vulnerable group. Both women and girls are often subjected to violence, including sexual violence, along the way and in refugee centres. Many of them then come to EU countries at an advanced stage of pregnancy, and the EP also wants to ensure/impose the right to abortion as part of their assistance. Yes, these women must be protected from any form of violence and safe havens must be ensured. However, even such a very painful situation cannot be an excuse for killing unborn children. Children of raped mothers also have a right to life. What's more, abortion will further traumatize a raped woman. I therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ Despite long-term efforts, the common European asylum system does not yet guarantee a coherent and gender-sensitive approach to women seeking protection in Europe. As a woman, I am also concerned that refugees (women and girls) are often victims of abuse and gross human rights violations. I am particularly concerned to hear of the shocking conditions and attacks that refugees and asylum seekers face at all stages of the journey, be it the country of origin, transit or destination. I am opposed to any human rights violations, and I therefore expect all bodies representing refugees to respect the principle of gender equality more consistently, thereby ensuring respect for rights and meeting the needs of refugees and asylum seekers. I believe that by working together, we will prevent refugees and asylum seekers from being subjected to constant sexual and financial abuse, and we will do everything we can to ensure that they do not become easy victims of smugglers and various criminal groups. In this way, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the report presented and to express my conviction that such attention should not only be paid to the most vulnerable, women and girls, not only at a time when we are commemorating the celebrations of the ICJ, but also during the next period.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation of women in the context of the current migration crisis: I believe that action is urgently needed, especially given the high percentage of women and children who crossed the Mediterranean in 2015, equal to 35% of the total, and the presence of women among asylum seekers, which increased sharply in the first months of this year. The situation of refugee women and women seeking protection in Europe is particularly alarming because of their vulnerability both during their dangerous journey to the countries of destination and on their arrival, for example within reception centres, as they are exposed to risks of violence and abuse, trafficking or exploitation for sexual purposes or other violent and heinous crimes. We therefore call in this resolution for gender issues and the dangers of refugee women to be taken into account in the implementation of asylum policies and procedures, providing instruments to improve the security and protection of asylum seekers, including through the opening of safe and legal access routes to the European Union to improve their security and discourage illegal trafficking in migrants.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The situation of female refugees deserves our attention, we must take into account their vulnerability, threat of violence and their obligations towards children. I therefore supported the PPE resolution, which takes a view to the situation of refugees with the necessary understanding. We want to be in solidarity, but we cannot guarantee them more care and rights than women and children have in the European Union. That is why I did not support Mrs Honeyball's report. I am very sorry that MEPs and Members of the European Parliament have used the situation of the migration crisis to promote a 'gender' ideology in asylum and integration policy. The report contains provisions encouraging Frontex to take into account a 'gender' approach in its activities, encouraging Member States to guarantee women unhindered access to quality education, health services, employment and accommodation, to guarantee women broad access to sexual and reproductive health and other rights that go beyond EU competences. I believe that refugees should be treated with the utmost regard to the protection of the dignity of human life and, as far as possible, to help them. But it is not possible to abuse this situation and promote a "gendered" ideology through the resolution. After all, the resolution has only proved to have received relatively close majority support.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. According to data for January 2016 of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, 55% of asylum seekers who arrived in Greece were women and children. There are worrying reports that women and children are prostitution to survive so they can pay smugglers to continue their journey into the EU and apply for asylum there. It is therefore necessary to open safe and legal asylum routes immediately, in order to counter smuggling networks, so that women, children and people with disabilities can get refuge without risking their lives. On several occasions, women and girls seeking refuge in the EU come from countries where the regime does not recognise them with the same rights as men, but oppresses them. At present, gender-based violence cannot be prevented in reception and transit centres in the European Union, as there is no supply of separate sleeping quarters and toilets. Women need to be provided with suitable living and hygiene conditions. In addition, they should be given access to gynaecological health services if they need them. The European Union's asylum policy must take into account the experience and needs of women at every stage. I believe that the voice of asylum seekers and refugees needs to be strengthened, which is why I voted in plenary.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The report by Mary Honeyball deals with the situation of female refugees and asylum seekers and addresses some important aspects. These include taking into account the specific needs of girls and women in the implementation of asylum procedures and accommodation in asylum seeker homes, the fight against trafficking in human beings and people smuggling, and protection against sexual exploitation and violence. The alternative proposal tabled by the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats included precisely these points, which is why I supported it. The Honeyball report, on the other hand, contains demands in its final version that go far beyond the target. This concerns, for example, calls for the establishment of a continuous structure for so-called LGBTI people in all Member States or for universal, unrestricted access to free, high-quality public education, health services and employment and housing. I therefore did not vote in favour of the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ despite the fact that more and more women are on the run, the European asylum system does not sufficiently guarantee gender-sensitive access to women. In fact, women and girls on the run represent a special group in need of increased protection. Especially at a time of humanitarian crisis facing Europe, it is more than necessary to establish harmonisation of the most effective procedures for the treatment of asylum seekers and refugees in Europe.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report.  Women refugees and asylum seekers have specific protection and integration needs which have too often been overlooked. To meet the needs of everyone seeking protection, our asylum laws and policies must be fully gender sensitive at every stage. Research shows that women and girls face violence, assault, exploitation and sexual harassment at every stage of their journey, including on European soil. On International Women’s Day Labour MEPs are sending a very clear message that action must be taken to protect women and girls seeking asylum in the EU.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the report on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU. I regret that we have failed to bridge some of the differences that have ariset in the preparation of this report. I support the special care and special treatment of vulnerable groups: pregnant women, elderly women and children. I cannot support the resolution because it contains some arguments with which I do not agree. We need a human and dignified but at the same time responsible treatment of women and asylum seekers. I would like to see a more realistic and sensible proposal that will deal more with specific needs and procedures that take into account women's needs.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the draft report on the situation of refugees and asylum seekers in the EU, as I believe that this serious issue needs to be addressed comprehensively and in the context of the debate on the reform of the asylum system in the European Union. Although I do not dispute that the situation of women, especially in refugee camps, needs to be given particular attention and, above all, to ensure the safety of women and children, I believe that this can be achieved within the framework of 'routine' humanitarian aid, which is provided to a sufficient extent and, above all, in a targeted or asylum procedure that takes into account the individual situation of each applicant. I am of the opinion that some of the wording in the draft report has unfortunately been worded unhappily and could thus seem counterproductive in the current situation. This does not change the need to provide humanitarian aid, to ensure decent conditions for all refugees and to respect the legal framework of international, Union and national.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report calls for ensuring that asylum policies take account of the particular problems faced by women and the double exploitation they suffer. It also urges the Member States to sign and ratify the Council of Europe Convention on the Prevention and Combating of Violence against Women and Domestic Violence. Equally important is the need to create a common asylum system and to establish a new, comprehensive set of gender equality guidelines in the context of wider immigration and asylum policy reforms. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is vague, does not propose any substantive measures, discriminates in favour of women, as if underage boys do not need protection. Moreover, it does not distinguish between so-called refugees and illegal immigrants, while at the same time ignoring the Christian populations of the region, which are perhaps the biggest and first victims of attacks.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to take into account new, comprehensive and EU-wide, cross-border guidelines as part of a wide-ranging reform of migration and asylum policy. I think it is important to help the needs of women in the asylum process. Due to current conflicts, regional instability and human rights violations, an increasing number of men, women and children are seeking international protection in the EU. In 2014, half of the world's refugee population consisted of women and girls who were vulnerable throughout their journey, both in countries of origin, transit and destination. The problem is that, in a crisis situation, there are huge differences in the treatment of women and girls seeking asylum between Member States, and there are still very significant shortcomings. Unfortunately, international conventions and national asylum policies have generally ignored the special situation of female asylum seekers and gender issues in the refugee situation. I consider it necessary that the legislation constituting the common European asylum system guarantees uniform and gender-relevant treatment of women seeking protection in Europe. In my opinion, the European Union's refugee policy must also be sensitive at all stages to the situation of women seeking asylum.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Data on migrant women in these years of strong migratory pressure are alarming. The report highlights the situation of those forced to emigrate and seek political asylum in Europe as a result of the war in their country. The report emphasises the violation of human rights, especially gender-based violence and mass rape, which are increasingly being used as an improper weapon. In order to improve the safety and protection of refugee women, there is a need, as M5S colleagues have repeatedly called for in the relevant committees, to create safe and legal access routes to the EU. In particular, it should be noted that more Member States should participate in EU resettlement programmes, activities that Member States are not currently carrying out. We believe that legislation and policies on irregular migration should not hinder access to European political asylum procedures. The report emphasises all women's health and reception needs, such as full access to health care and sexual and reproductive rights. This seems to me to be a good report, so I can only vote in favour of it.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for my colleague Honeyball's text, considering that women make up an average of one third of asylum seekers; whereas, from the beginning of 2015 to November of the same year, some 900,000 people reached European shores via the Mediterranean and that women and children account for about 38% of this number; Whereas the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) reported that in January 2016, women and children made up 55% of those arriving in Greece to apply for asylum in the EU. There are significant inequalities between women and men who apply for asylum throughout the European Union. Too many people, including many women, have already lost their lives on their hopeful journey!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the European Union. If I do not share all the provisions of the resolution, it recalls important facts. Indeed women account on average for one third of people who apply for asylum. Between the start of 2015 and November of the same year, some 900 000 people crossed the Mediterranean to reach Europe’s coasts, and women and children accounted for around 38% of the total. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) reported that, as of January 2016, women and children account for 55% of those reaching Greece to seek asylum in the EU.  Even in countries deemed safe, women may suffer gender-based persecution and thus have a legitimate request for protection. Gendered forms of violence and discrimination constitute persecution and should be valid reasons for seeking asylum in the EU and that this should be reflected in new gender guidelines.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. Since the beginning of the migration crisis we are experiencing, the European Parliament has been working to address the humanitarian emergency and provide international protection to the millions of people affected by war and oppression in the Middle East.  But much remains to be done. And we need to improve our policies. Experience teaches us that there is an urgent need to take into account the specific situation of women seeking asylum. These women, after fleeing the war, find themselves in a situation of unacceptable insecurity once they arrive in Europe. Many of them are raped, others disappear salvaged by networks and condemned to prostitution.  The European Parliament had to sound the alarm. We are sending a clear request to the European Commission: from now on, the gender dimension will have to be fully included in our reception arrangements. That's the meaning of our comrade Honeyball's report.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 We are witnessing one of the most serious migration crises in history, we must demonstrate our firm intention to manage this phenomenon and our commitment to ensure that images of children and women covered in mud and cold are no longer seen. In this crisis, we seem to forget women, who are abandoned or victims of violence, who suffer help and conditions as a result of their forced choice to flee war and hunger. That is why I wholely supported this report, because I believe that, within the framework of a reform of the EU's migration and asylum policies, which is urgently needed, we must ensure the safety of women seeking asylum, many of whom travel with young children and other dependents. Rape, sexual violence, female genital mutilation, forced marriages and domestic violence must be recognised as valid grounds for seeking asylum in the European Union. It is also necessary to ensure that the specific needs of women are respected throughout the asylum process and in reception centres by guaranteeing night areas and toilets separated by gender, female staff and interpreters and childcare during screening and interviewing for asylum applications.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I abstained from the proposal for a report on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU, as I believe that the report is well designed but contains a certain gender ideology, which I unfortunately could not support. The area addressed in the report is important, but requires thorough reflection and appropriate amendments.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report dealing with the situation of refugee women and asylum seekers in the EU. The report is positive in that it believes that asylum policies and procedures and application assessments should include a gender approach. It includes gender-based violence, rape, sexual violence, female mutilation, forced marriage or sexist violence as grounds for asylum applications in the EU. It also includes persecution and violence against LGBTI groups. The report calls for measures to ensure that women's needs are met during the asylum process. Safe and legal routes are requested to ensure the safety of women on their way to the EU to prevent human trafficking and mafias. It stresses that immigration policies and legislation should not prevent access to the EU asylum procedure. It stresses the importance of labour insertion measures. It calls for solidarity between EU countries and that responsibility should not be based solely on the countries of first destination, which we believe is necessary.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The report by Mary Honeyball deals with the situation of female refugees and asylum seekers and addresses some important aspects. These include taking into account the specific needs of girls and women in the implementation of asylum procedures and accommodation in asylum seeker homes, the fight against trafficking in human beings and people smuggling, and protection against sexual exploitation and violence. The alternative proposal tabled by the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats included precisely these points, which is why I supported it. The Honeyball report, on the other hand, contains demands in its final version that go far beyond the target. This concerns, for example, calls for the establishment of a continuous structure for so-called LGBTI people in all Member States or for universal, unrestricted access to free, high-quality public education, health services and employment and housing. I therefore did not vote in favour of the report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The refugee situation is worrying in itself. It is no longer only a political issue but an issue of humanity with people who are on European territory with unacceptable conditions. If you are a woman, the situation is even more complex, both in countries of origin and the host, as specified very clearly and in detail in this report.  I think that things related to this issue can be done in a better way, and that is why I support this proposal.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. All the provisions of the report are ultimately aimed at further exacerbating the migrant crisis by facilitating their entry and stay in Europe, resulting in excessive expenditure.  The report does not mention persecution of Christians, who are exposed to violence, either in their countries of origin or in asylum-seeker centres (idem for Shiites, Yezidi, Kurds).  It makes no distinction between refugees fleeing war and economic refugees.  The report does not address the dangerousness of some migrants, either in terms of terrorism or in terms of ordinary violence. So I voted against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. In 2014, half of the world's refugee population consisted of women and girls. Historically, international conventions and national asylum policies have generally ignored the specific situation of female asylum seekers and gender-related aspects of refugee situations. Despite the establishment of a common European asylum system, the laws, policies and practices of each Member State remain significantly different and the lack of protection for women seeking asylum in the Union is striking. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report dealing with the situation of refugee women and asylum seekers in the EU. The report is positive in that it believes that asylum policies and procedures and application assessments should include a gender approach. It includes gender-based violence, rape, sexual violence, female mutilation, forced marriage or sexist violence as grounds for asylum applications in the EU. It also includes persecution and violence against LGBTI groups. The report calls for measures to ensure that women's needs are met during the asylum process. Safe and legal routes are requested to ensure the safety of women on their way to the EU to prevent human trafficking and mafias. It stresses that immigration policies and legislation should not prevent access to the EU asylum procedure. It stresses the importance of labour insertion measures. It calls for solidarity between EU countries and that responsibility should not be based solely on the countries of first destination, which we believe is necessary.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that focuses on the specific situation of women refugees and asylum seekers because it highlights the acute and particular way in which women fleeing desperate situations are affected and because it calls for a set of specific measures to protect these women, among them the necessity to open safe and legal passage.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I stress that the majority of women and refugees seeking asylum have suffered violent violence and that their detention can exacerbate trauma; I stress that the detention of asylum seekers for reasons of administrative convenience alone violates the right to freedom enshrined in Article 6 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. I call on the Member States, in order to prevent violence against women and children in the country of entry, to introduce and strengthen the control mechanisms for overcrowded refugee reception centres in the Union, which do not always meet the minimum requirements to reduce gender-based violence.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU. The resolution supports a reform of EU migration and asylum policies and procedures appealing for the inclusion of gender-sensitive measures for the safety of women seeking asylum, given their particularly vulnerable position. It is further stated that all forms of gender-related violence, such as rape, sexual violence, female genital mutilation, forced marriage or domestic violence, as well as violence against LGBTI, should be considered as valid reasons for seeking asylum in the EU. The importance of making available safe and legal routes for women refugees is equally stressed in the resolution, with the general aim of improving the security and safety of women refugees.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is important that asylum policies and procedures are gender sensitive. 55% of refugees arriving in Europe are women, girls and children. To ensure that women's specific needs are addressed, gender-specific training, including gender-based violence, needs to be promoted for staff; sanitary facilities and gender-segregated rooms; guarantee the right to request female interviewers and interpreters; ensure access to women's health services; provide childcare services during exams and interviews; inform women of their right to file an independent asylum application, etc.  It is also urgent that there be no further internment of children, pregnant women and survivors of rape, sexual assault and trafficking. And, of course, measures are needed for the integration of refugee women and asylum seekers into the labour market. The solution to the refugee crisis is not to return them to Turkey, but to create legal avenues of immigration and implement integration policies. The dignity of the European project based on the principles of solidarity, justice and equality is at stake.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ On International Women's Day, myself and other Labour MEPs are sending a very clear message that action must be taken to protect women and girls seeking asylum in the EU. I was very proud to vote in favour of this report.  Women refugees and asylum seekers have specific needs that can be overlooked by an asylum policy that does not take into account their gender. To meet the needs of everyone seeking protection, our asylum laws and policies must be fully gender—sensitive throughout the process from arrival to integration. Research has shown that women and girls face violence, assault, exploitation and sexual harassment at every stage of their journey, including on European soil. Gender based violence is often aimed at the most vulnerable, this leads to women – and indeed children – who are entitled to claim asylum finding their indeterminate legal status being exploited to coerce them into transactional sex and forced into prostitution to pay for travel documents or a place in a boat or lorry. To prevent this kind of gendered violence there needs to be adequate processes and safe passage for them to be able to claim asylum without facing this kind of degradation.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'Today, the Report of Mary Honneybal was voted in favour of the Report of Mary Honneybal in Strasbourg. An important step towards upgrading the plight of the many female refugees who often face sexual exploitation as they make their way to and from Europe. Five measures are absolutely necessary, namely: safe routes, safe sleeping places, the right to be assisted in the asylum procedure by female interpreters and to be questioned by female interviewers.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This report looks at the situation of refugee women and asylum seekers in the EU.  Refugees can also flee their countries in cases of rape, forced marriage, or domestic violence and should therefore be given specific protection. Upon arrival in reception centres: they may also be exposed to sexual violence, human trafficking and the violation of their rights.  However, all this is not taken into account either as a valid reason for obtaining asylum or in the reception conditions. Measures must be taken: better reception of refugee women and their children with real training of reception workers, the cessation of their detentions, the establishment of separate housing and sanitation, and the better inclusion and social integration of these women.  I have doubts about the closer coordination of the police and judicial bodies in view of the risks inherent in the use of the files and I regret that neither the overwhelming reception conditions in Turkey nor the confiscation of the property of the refugees have been denounced!  However, this report is a good move, it is imperative to ensure the safety of refugee women.   I voted for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The report calls for measures that meet the needs of women during the asylum application process, such as individual registration of women, the granting of documents ensuring individual safety, regardless of their spouse and other family members, specialised traumatic counselling and psychosocial care, counselling provided by professionals with valences in all aspects related to the different violence to which women are targeted Etc.. It argues that the detention of children in the EU should be put to an end and that parents should be able to live with their children in appropriate facilities while awaiting the asylum decision, applying the same principle to pregnant and lactating women, as well as to survivors of rape, sexual violence and trafficking, and that psychological support is provided. However, the report makes no critical allusion to the true causes of these waves of refugees and does not condemn the EU for its involvement in the wars from which refugees flee. In this sense, it does not point to the basic solutions that are needed to resolve the fundamental issue and which have to do with a policy of peace and cooperation that the EU is not able to implement.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Of course, the protection of women is of the utmost importance, but the rapporteur is trying to facilitate family reunification under this pretext. These family reunifications would further exacerbate the situation in the EU. I therefore reject this report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Honeyball's resolution on refugee women and asylum seekers in the EU. The report, which was adopted just today, sends a strong message to the governments of the Member States to take measures to meet the needs of women arriving on our shores.  In 2016 alone, 55% of those who reached Europe by sea and applied for reception were women and children. Women forced to leave their country in search of a better future in Europe all too often face various kinds of violence.  We must ensure that 8 March is much more than a very useful anniversary.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. I voted against the motion because, in the end, refugee women and refugee children will receive enormous benefits and the measures proposed here will facilitate the ability to catch up with their husbands/families under relieved conditions. In addition, they are to be better placed in many ways than indigenous women in EU countries. I consider this unequal treatment to be totally unacceptable.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the EUROPEAN Parliament's resolution on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU. A third of the report exceeds the powers of the EU and the EU Parliament. The report also addresses issues such as the reform of Frontex, calls on Member States to open their borders and calls for an EU-wide gender reform of asylum policy. The report calls for unequal treatment in the determination of refugee status, a privilege for women and girls – but not boys. The report also calls for preferential treatment of female and LGBTI refugees by qualified gender-sensitive legal advisers. All this not only exceeds the competences of the EU, but is also simply indefensible in terms of content. I categorically reject all this and have therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. \u2012 Female refugees are a particularly vulnerable group of displaced populations, in need of special care and treatment at all levels. The report on the situation of refugee women/girls seeking asylum within the EU is moving in the right direction.  It has, however, once again been the subject of ideological positions by leftists and socialists, which concern the more general issue of managing the refugee crisis, without having any added value in analysing the problems of refugee women and in providing specialised protection to them. That is why, far from populist interventions and amendments, I supported the alternative proposal of the European People's Party, which focuses purely on the problems faced in particular by female refugees, in the wake of their forced displacement, such as violence, exploitation and persecution on grounds of sex, including trafficking in human beings on grounds of sexual and labour exploitation.  Recognition of women's rights at all levels, let alone women refugees, who are unprotected, possibly with children in their arms, are at risk of becoming victims of all kinds of violent behaviour, is a priority for our political group. Political pressure from the European Parliament in this direction must be serious, responsible and find a way to escape the moods of serving micro-political purposes.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this important report which was drafted by Labour MEP Mary Honeyball. Women refugees and asylum seekers have specific protection and integration needs which have too often been overlooked. To meet the needs of everyone seeking protection, our asylum laws and policies must be fully gender sensitive at every stage.  Research shows that women and girls face violence, assault, exploitation and sexual harassment at every stage of their journey, including on European soil. Women – and indeed children – who are entitled to claim asylum are being coerced into transactional sex and forced into prostitution to pay for travel documents or a place in a boat or lorry. They need safer alternatives, as this report sets out. This also includes the situation of women refugees in appalling makeshift conditions across the EU and on our borders, as in the Calais and Dunkirk ‘Jungles’. Member States have not provided the humanitarian response that these refugees require, and they must do so urgently.  On International Women’s Day we are sending a very clear message that action must be taken to protect women and girls seeking asylum in the EU.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Writing. Women and children are extremely threatened on the run: physical violence, abuse, sexual exploitation are just some of the additional dangers that women have to endure. For me, the protection of refugees and, above all, the protection of women on the run is non-negotiable. This applies not only to the countries of origin, but above all to the escape routes and countries of arrival. Legal escape securitises could prevent thousands of women and children from being driven into the hands of unscrupulous smugglers. In addition, the conditions must be created in the countries of arrival in refugee camps and communities in order to respond to the needs of possibly traumatised women. For me, the demands made in the report are a good basis.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was drafted by my Labour colleague Mary Honeyball.  Women refugees and asylum seekers have specific protection and integration needs which have too often been overlooked. Research shows that women and girls face violence, assault, exploitation and sexual harassment at every stage of their journey, including on European soil. Women – and indeed children – who are entitled to claim asylum need safer alternatives, as this report sets out.  On International Women’s Day Labour MEPs are sending a very clear message that action must be taken to protect women and girls seeking asylum in the EU.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a report that has particularly interested me. In my home town of Padua, the Leghista administration successfully prevents family reunification through a series of deplorable expedients such as the delay in granting citizenship to resident immigrants and forced checks on their homes in order to assess their habitability with excessively strict criteria. However, the League is lag behind and I have received further confirmation of this today: we have in fact voted on a text which provides for greater and more specific protection for refugee women, as a sensitive objective of the wars and tragedies that are upsetting so much of the world. Women, and with them the LGBT community, escape not only from the widespread violence of war, but also from the fear of war rape, the practice of genital mutilation, domestic violence. For this reason, they must be given a careful reception, specific places of protection and psychological support. It is necessary to avoid their repatriation by recognising the specific nature of the tragedies they live in and, last but not least, to encourage the practice of family reunification not only for their own salvation but also as a safeguard of legality and well-being in the host countries (important studies show that the presence of women cushions the aggression of migrant men and generates a positive climate of integration and tolerance).

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. \u2012 At a time when thousands of refugees, the majority of them women and children, are facing repression and the barbaric policy of the EU and the Member States putting their lives at risk, the European Parliament's report on "female refugees" legitimises and promotes reactionary EU regulations. In particular, it premiums the detention of refugees by effectively cancelling the Geneva Convention on Refugees and Asylum Seekers. Empty expressions of sympathy for female refugees make no secret of the fact that the report supports the eu's entire anti-immigration policy; calling for: making full use of Dublin for the entrapment of refugees in the host countries, increasing Member States' cooperation with Europol, Eurojust, FRONTEX, the Asylum Service, in the name of combating slave traders, which portends an intensity of repression, acceptance of the "common list of safe host countries" for mass deportations in the fire of war. The report's wish list does not meet their urgent demands for: direct transfer to the countries of final destination, abolition of detention centres, open decent reception and temporary accommodation areas with adequate health care infrastructure, rapid and fair asylum, the granting of travel documents, the abolition of Dublin, Schengen and FRONTEX.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ honeyball's report sought to resolve the alarming situation of women refugees and asylum seekers. The most shocking information was undoubtedly that these women are subjected to violence not only in the countries of origin, where their level of violence often leads to the decision to leave the country and flee to Europe, but unfortunately their scares do not end there. According to the latest reports, they also encounter violence during transit and even in the countries that make up their destination. The report therefore contained proposals for solutions such as separate accommodation for mothers with children, separate social facilities and so on. And while it is extremely important to prevent situations in which women are subjected to violence, I fear that some of the proposals contained in the report were very difficult to implement and some of them were all too controversial. Unfortunately, although I support the improvement in the situation of women and children in general, I could not support the report.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the situation of women refugees and asylum seekers in the EU highlights the issue of the situation of women refugees in the European Union. They are many times, because of their vulnerable situation, victims of sexual violence, trafficking or other violent crimes. I agree that asylum policies and procedures, including the assessment of asylum applications, should take account of those circumstances. However, since the report in some places is too ideologically and generally interfering with the area of asylum policy, which is primarily the responsibility of the LIBE Committee and violates the principle of subsidiarity, I abstained from voting.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Syria.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me start by saying that we discussed this issue – the situation in Syria and our work to try and put an end to the war – on 19 January, so less than two months ago. Many different things have happened since then so I would like to thank you for this debate and for the opportunity that this offers us all to check and double check the steps taken, the sense of direction and also the difficulties we still have ahead of us. First of all let me remind us all again what has happened in this one and a half months. First of all we had the London conference on Syria. I start with this because this was not only a pledging conference where the European Union and the Member States represented two-thirds of the contributions to support Syrians inside Syria and in the neighbouring countries, but this was also a way of showing the unity of the international community and solidarity and a sense of hope for the Syrians in their own country.  We have pledged EUR 3 billion in support for the refugees and the internally displaced people inside Syria and for the humanitarian aid. I will go back to the role of the humanitarian aid in a moment from a political and also from a security point of view, but we also prepared two packages, two compacts as we call them, one for Jordan and one for Lebanon, which comprise not only financial support, but also some measures that can support these countries in the effort of integrating Syrian refugees into the host communities, giving children education, giving young women and men job opportunities, and also making it sustainable for the communities in Jordan and in Lebanon to sustain this effort in the mid-term period.  The second thing that has happened since 19 January is that the first round of talks among Syrians took place in Geneva – almost immediately suspended because of clear problems that were coming up in the first talks that Staffan de Mistura was holding at the time – and a subsequent meeting of the International Support Group in Munich.  Here we met at length for many hours together with John Kerry, Lavrov and all the other Foreign Ministers represented there from some 20 countries, the European Union and the Arab League, all around the table, trying to check exactly whether the suspension of the talks in Geneva was due to difficulties that were impossible to overcome – not only locally, internally, nationally, among the Syrians but also in the bigger regional framework – or if it would be possible, through the International Support Group, to move forward and revitalise a process in which all of us have invested so much in the last months.  Out of this meeting in Munich we established two task forces: one on the modalities of the cessation of hostilities, co-chaired by the US and Russia, these being the two actors that needed to coordinate the most, especially in military coordination, to identify in concrete terms the maps, the groupings and the areas for the entry into force of the ceasefire or the cessation of hostilities.  And a task force on humanitarian aid, because we identified very clearly the need to have a second round of talks in Geneva, which Staffan de Mistura has now announced for tomorrow and the coming days, to make sure that these talks happen with a completely different, or very substantially different, atmosphere on the ground, rather than the one that we experienced on the previous occasion, meaning to try and reduce the gap between Syrians talking in Geneva about a very difficult political transition and process, while on the ground Syrians are dying in besieged areas and cities with no access to humanitarian aid.  So we know that delivering in an effective way humanitarian aid, food and medicines to the Syrians inside Syria would give credibility. It would create conditions for a credible process in Geneva and would also open up some channels for political discussions among different parties. We then has, as you know, the task force on cessation of hostilities producing very advanced work – the humanitarian task force as well, I will come back with details in a moment – and the adoption of UN Security Council Resolution 2268 on cessation of hostilities that started on 29 February.  Since then, I have to say – not only myself but also the UN Special Envoy Staffan de Mistura and the two Co-Chairs of the taskforce, the US and Russia – that the cessation of hostilities, the ceasefire, is substantially holding even if we are seeing several breaches throughout Syria, in different parts of Syria.  However, the overall assessment is that the ceasefire is holding and that the situation on the ground for this whole week has been significantly improved compared to all the previous weeks of the conflict. That is to say that this is probably the first time in five years of conflict that we see in many parts of Syria no major armed intervention even if, as I said, breaches are happening continuously but with an intensity and a magnitude that is definitely on a different scale from in the past. On the humanitarian task force: we have managed in these weeks to deliver aid through 180 trucks to 150 000 Syrians inside Syria in different besieged areas and we are working – the EU in particular and together with the UN – I will come back to that as I said, to reach areas further beyond the ones we have managed to reach so far.  As I said, Staffan de Mistura has announced that talks will restart from tomorrow onwards. We do not expect this to be an easy process, on the contrary, but the fact that we managed to somehow recreate, or create rather, the conditions for the talks to be taking place is definitely good. I met Riad Hijab in Paris a few days ago and we discussed at length not the conditions that anyone places on going back to Geneva but how the international community, the regional actors and the participants to the talks managed to create the conditions for the talks to be significant and substantial.  And let me say that one strong message that we, all of the European Union, together with the rest of the international community but here I talk for the European Union, are passing on united is to encourage all the parties, starting from the regime obviously but also the opposition, not only to go to Geneva and take part in the talks but also to do this in a spirit of engagement and compromise. Obviously we are also working as the European Union to support the opposition in this very difficult task of entering these difficult negotiations.  This is the first time after five years of war that we have this combination of cessation of hostilities holding overall, even if with significant breaches but holding overall, and humanitarian aid being delivered in besieged areas. So this is indeed not creating a rosy picture from one day to the next or from one week to the next, but there are some steps that are finally going in the right direction.  One of these is the coordination that I mentioned before that the US and Russia have developed, especially on the military-to-military level, a close coordination with regard to first the establishment and then the monitoring of the ceasefire, and the work to defuse tensions that could endanger this very fragile truce. This is why I believe that those who talk about a new Cold War definitely need a reality check when it comes to this level of coordination and messaging.  Now, the role of the European Union. The European Union is part of both the task forces, with different roles. On the ceasefire, on the cessation of hostilities task force we have a presence, together with other countries or organisations that are part of the international support group. We have our military experts present there and we are also working out ways in which we can contribute to monitoring the cessation of hostilities, together with other friends. On the humanitarian assistance task force our role is definitely a much bigger, relevant one, not because we are the ones who are the good ones and not the ones that get implicated in military things, but simply because in specific terms, the role of the European Union in Syria has not been – this was a political decision and I think it was right – it has not been and it is not a military player on the ground in Syria.  Some Member States are, but nonetheless, the leading role here is for the two main countries that have a military presence and activity, knowledge and control of the military activities that can be done, leading to negotiations on the establishment of cessation of hostilities. This does not mean, as I said, that we are not part also of this very crucial work with our active presence there and that, as I said, might increase in future days. On humanitarian assistance: there is here a very strong link between humanitarian aid and the political process that needs to restart. The last time we met, I remember that many of you mentioned the need for a Marshall Plan for Syria. If we consider the numbers, the money we are putting into this inside Syria, in the neighbouring countries and elsewhere, I can say that the Marshall Plan has already started in a very significant way.  The humanitarian task force in which, as I said, we have a leading role has already met four times and, as I said, has succeeded in delivering 180 trucks of aid to seven besieged areas and we reached out to more than 150 000 Syrians in cities like Madaya, Mouadimiya, al-Sham, Kafr Batna, Foua, Kafraya, Zabadani and Deir Ezzor. This is not an exhaustive list. On the contrary, we are working on further cities all over Syria that need to be reached – and could be reached – in terms of priorities in the coming days and weeks.  The plan is to deliver assistance to more than 1.7 million Syrians inside Syria during the first quarter of this year, so in the next couple of months. To provide direct help for the humanitarian deliveries and work hand in hand with the UN agencies on the ground we have reactivated our ECHO office in Damascus. Among international actors, let me say that the European Union is probably the only one that is considered trustworthy by all sides – inside Syria and in the region. Somehow we have privileged access to many of the interlocutors that then have to work on the steps that are needed to allow humanitarian aid inside the difficult-to-reach areas. Our major role on humanitarian aid gives us also a major political role to play and we are doing this. We are helping to create windows of trust between different parties in the conflict. Our role is to open wide such windows for meaningful and comprehensive negotiations towards a political transition. We have to keep in mind, even with these positive steps that have taken place in recent weeks, that a new escalation might still happen anytime. The regional situation remains very tense. Every day we see news that is extremely worrying – even this morning – and that the proxy war among regional and international powers could still turn into a direct war.  This is something we must always keep in mind all through our work, keeping the hope that moves are going forwards on the diplomatic track, on humanitarian assistance and also on the work on the cessation of hostilities and the monitoring of the ceasefire; keeping in mind the risk that this could still degenerate and go backwards if we do not show consistency and if we do not encourage enough the players on the ground – the military groups, the political actors – to engage, the regime first and foremost, to engage in meaningful political process. We have had talks. I have had direct talks in recent days with all our partners, friends, interlocutors – not friends – both inside Syria and outside Syria in the region, to pass on the same message: to engage in the political process, to allow humanitarian access to improve and to work significantly to have the cessation of hostilities hold and improve day by day. Just yesterday, we discussed this with our Turkish partners and, if you look at the communiqué that came out of the Council yesterday night, you will also find a reference to the need to work together – Turkey and the European Union – to improve humanitarian conditions in more and more areas inside Syria. This is a common commitment we discussed with the Turkish yesterday. Everyone must do their best at this time. We have opened a window – a very small one – and we have to make sure that it does not close but that it opens further on the three levels – humanitarian, military ceasefire and the political one. Let me take this opportunity here to thank Staffan de Mistura for the excellent coordination work that he is doing. We are in daily contact and the way in which we are working together with the United Nations in all these three aspects is really, I think, an example for our work also in other fields. I think we have seen that diplomacy can work in recent experiences last year. We know that Daesh can be defeated and that it can be defeated only through a process that puts an end to the war in Syria and guarantees a transition in Damascus. We know that the war inside Syria can be over and forces can merge to fight terrorism – Daesh and al-Nusra – in the country. We have today the first steps in the right direction which are the result of the very determined – I would say stubborn – work we have done, coordinated with many others, starting with the USA. After five years of war diplomacy, including European diplomacy, is starting to bring some first results that, as I said, could turn back at any single moment if we do not have all the actors pushing in the same direction with the same stubbornness we have shown in recent months. We need to continue to build on this to try to have a new Syria. Most likely the one that has been destroyed in five years of war will not come back with all its beauties, but maybe we can allow the Syrians to build their country again beyond ethnicity, religion or political creed, to be united, democratic, non—sectarian, not governed by the same men who presided over so many years of civil war, but with an inclusive governance guaranteeing all different Syrians to be part of the same country , with no space in it for Daesh and al-Nusra which have nothing to do with the history of the country and will have nothing to do with its future if we manage to work well together as we have done in recent weeks.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Madam High Representative, I am pleased to hear you stress that the conflict has already been going on for five years. Indeed, during this long period, Syrians have not had much reason to hope. When they went out on the street five years ago, that is not what they expected. That is why, I believe, the ceasefire that came into force on 27 February is a very important element, and it is , again, I agree with you - because it allows access to humanitarian aid that the Syrian people desperately need. I remember we talked about it recently when you came before our committee. The ceasefire is also important, as it is a glimmer of hope that must be held up from this political perspective. While the ceasefire is not perfect - there are still casualties - it does exist. It is generally respected, and it is up to us to seize this opportunity and turn it into a credible political transition. "Credible political transition" does not mean, of course, "immediate elections" as Assad or Putin have suggested. This is, of course, unacceptable. We need to focus our efforts on the peace process, and it is when stability is fully restored that elections can be held.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, first please allow me to congratulate the Vice-President/High Representative for launching this fundamentally important initiative and for the very wise way in which to coordinate us, as Europe, with other major international and regional actors in order to try to fix this long-lasting conflict. The last ten days have been the quietest for most Syrians in the last five years, but this could help to build up a momentum behind the peace talks in this war-torn country and allow the international talks set to start tomorrow to resume soon. There is no real alternative but the political solution and we need a strong political will and commitment to make it.  A political solution in Syria will allow the international community to concentrate on what is most important: fighting Daesh and all other terrorist groups and stopping them from spreading and bringing more war and suffering to the entire region. Finding a solution for Syria will allow Syrians to stay in their homes and not further risk their lives in coming to Europe or elsewhere. The participation of the moderate Syrian opposition in the international talks is essential and should be guaranteed. Therefore we condemn any actions against moderate Syrian opposition forces and against the town of Aleppo that could undermine the ceasefire and equally the international talks. The reduction in violence also allowed the dispatch of humanitarian aid and convoys to the population in need. Nevertheless, this has to continue and the Syrian Government has to cooperate and further facilitate the aid. It goes without saying that unless the talks bring results the humanitarian crisis will continue. The boundaries between these various conflicts in Syria are often vague and belong to different actors. It is so important for all sides, including Turkey and Russia, to stick to UN resolution 2254. Objectives: combating terrorist groups and allowing a solution for Syria.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the Munich-agreed fragile ceasefire prevailing now in Syria offers the international community the political opportunity to press strongly and implement the original UN Geneva peace agreements. It is an important step forward, establishing a lasting settlement based on an inclusive government in Damascus that can represent all Syrians. However, attaining detente between Syria’s warring factions, and ultimately the cessation of the brutal proxy civil war, hinges on Russia’s political and military interventions. We share with Russia the common objective of eliminating the evil scourge of ISIS and other extreme radical Islamist groups in Syria. Yet, under the bargain, Russia must also honour its obligations, demonstrate its compliance and avoid further provocation by ceasing attacks against all anti-Assad Syrian civilians and moderate opposition groups and desist from helping to create a greater refugee exodus in order to destabilise Europe and get payback against Chancellor Merkel and the EU sanctions. As the peace process gathers momentum, Moscow must realize that its behaviour will be closely scrutinised. Only with Russia playing its role as a responsible international interlocutor and actor can peace be brought to this blighted country.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, every effort to stop the war in Syria through negotiation must be supported, but not every outcome can be accepted. The cessation of hostilities is very fragile but it must be a step towards a ceasefire because the appalling violence, death, destruction, starvation and the extraordinary human suffering has gone on for far too long. The Syrian people deserve more support from us and we must strengthen our negotiating and leadership position. Had we developed a strong common and comprehensive EU strategy towards Syria earlier, we would have played a role of leadership and not merely be first in facing the consequences of inaction. The EU is most noticeable in its divisions and its struggle to offer humane shelter to those fleeing the war, many of whom are Syrians. Yes, we are key for humanitarian aid but we need more efforts to stop this suffering at its source. Meanwhile, Russia continues to help Assad and create new realities on the ground and then negotiates for humanitarian aid. Putin jumped into the vacuum using the most cynical and brutal violence of bombing hospitals, civilians and rebels that share our agenda in fighting the so-called Islamic State – or Daesh – and this kind of behaviour led by Putin’s Russia must have a price. I believe we need EU sanctions for the violence used in Syria. I have a few brief questions for the High Representative. After we heard that the continuation of talks has been delayed and will not start tomorrow but on Monday, independent and credible monitoring of the cessation agreement and of aid delivery becomes even more important. How was this organised, and are food drops being considered for those suffering the most? You mentioned the packages on Lebanon and Jordan. Is this enough? I worry a great deal about the situation in Lebanon, while so much attention goes to Turkey. We cannot afford Lebanon to collapse. Lastly, how will you use your leverage and contacts with the Iranian leaders to ensure they play a more responsible role and stop supporting the brutal Assad regime?

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. "Thank you, Mrs Mogherini, for the clarifications you have brought here. In fact, we are at a different stage of ceasefire, but it is fragile, and not only fragile, but it is a very complex situation and it did not take much time to start seeing more interference and interference, namely Saudi Arabia, which wants to impose conditions which i think is one of the reasons why the round of negotiations is once again deduring. Conditions that want to impose exclusivity, for example, of the oppositions that are represented, excluding, for example, a fundamental part, such as kurdish Syrians. That said, there have been positions on all sides, the United States, Russia.  I want to reinforce what was the position of Staffan de Mistura, the Mediator of the United Nations, which seems to me to be the most reasonable of all. That is to say, this is a Syrian issue and any solution that is found depends solely and exclusively on the Syrian people and I ask you, Mrs Mogherini, when will the European Union have an autonomous position that does not depend on the will of the United States, does not depend on the will of Saudi Arabia, does not depend on the will or conditions of the other parties other parties that are not only the only one solely of the Syrian people, because that, yes, will determine whether or not there is success in these negotiations.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the The ceasefire agreement in Syria holds, but it is fragile, and it is to be hoped that the peace talks scheduled for the end of the week in Geneva will also take place. It will be very important for the peace negotiations that they are inclusive and that this applies to all population groups, including the Kurds.  During the preparations for the peace talks so far, women have only taken on the role of extras, including on the opposition side. Today, on International Women's Day, I would like to draw attention to the women who oppose both the terror of the Assad regime and that of the jihadist groups. The journalist Zaina Erhaim from Aleppo has placed a monument to these women with her film "Rebels". The film tells the story of courageous women who work as paramedics in the combat area or organise self-help for women. I would like to remind you of the many women who have paid for their courage with their lives, such as the Kurdish blogger Rukia Hassan, who reported and was murdered about her life under the rule of the Islamic State in Raqqa. I hope that in the peace negotiations women will be promoted by the EU side, that they will also have a say in the political process.  In view of the countless crimes committed and committed in Syria against women, men and children, the EU's position must be clear and decisive. There can be lasting peace in Syria only if those responsible for these crimes are held accountable.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear High Representative, we are seeing some tentative signs. The truce appears, although violated several times, globally it seems to be holding up and more and more rebel factions are also negotiating. And the new climate of cooperation between Russia and the United States is certainly very positive, as is the victory of the reformists in Iran, which can further push for a negotiated solution. Perhaps the biggest problem remains the very un cooperative attitude of other allies to these factions, in particular the Turks and Saudi Arabia. In fact, in particular the Turkish agenda, I see it as very little aligned with our foreign policy, given the priority objective of having direct control over Syrian Kurdistan and which is also carried out with intense bombing, precisely against those Kurdish militias that are fighting Daesh. By the way, I still see too few serious and credible efforts to stop the illegal oil trade, which is one of the main sources of income for Daesh.  The risk of our complacency with the Turkish demands, with a new agreement for a further EUR 3 billion and further concessions, including the opening of the negotiating chapters, would not be misunderstood as a sign of weakness, with which we seem to be giving Turkey a little contract for the management of the migration crisis that we are not managing to achieve internally, perhaps passing over in silence what is happening in south-east Turkey itself and in Syrian Kurdistan.  I think that we should further strengthen the two packages that you mentioned earlier with regard to Lebanon and Jordan, which are making considerable efforts, and above all the role of the Union must be even more fundamental, not only for humanitarian aid and for future reconstruction, but also for a Roadmap for a definitive truce and a political process. , which is why these main allies of ours must therefore be part of the solution and not part of the problem.  We must make a great deal of pushes in this direction.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Commissioner, I will make two points. The first is Turkey. This is a country that is against democracy, as we see with recent events, that supports Islamism - now everyone recognizes it - that is against international law in Iraq, in Syria, and also supports organized crime. However, you want to subject Europe - perhaps because it is in the interest of Germany or that of a chancellor who has betrayed her people and Europe - to agreements with a country that does not meet european criteria. Do you think that is normal? Are you not afraid that the countries will revolt and break up Europe? The second point is about our moralism. He failed in the face of truth and reality. Our moralism has been that of submission to the master, the United States, to those who pay - Qatar, Saudi Arabia - or to blackmail and dhimmitude.
