It is a bit normal that, in these conditions, we play the role of strapontin. That's the price you have to pay when you refuse reality.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Mrs Mogherini, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. A few words of truth, a man's word of truth: Russia has entered Syria and so we now have a ceasefire. Let us hope that Russia does not withdraw. Let us also hope that the Americans have already learned how to overthrow dictators in Libya, Iraq, how many hundreds of thousands or millions have died as a result of the overthrow of dictators. Only a dictator can keep in his hands a country where there are Alawi, Christians, Baha'i, Druyuz, Shiites. The thought of an election in a situation where an armed Daish stands at the gates where al Nusra is fighting is a complete absurdity – the introduction of democracy at such a moment. As there is war, it must be a dictator.  Speaking to the Kurds who came here, I explained to them that they had to come to an agreement with Assad. They said no. Then I went to Damascus and there I explained to the Assad people that they should talk to the Kurds. They said no. And now they're getting along with each other. And that's where the hope is. But the problem lies in Turkey: the only thing the European Union can do is bribe the Turks somehow so that they do not destroy this fragile agreement that is being made there in Syria.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, yes, progress has been made in Syria. Humanitarian access and the cessation of hostilities are important steps forward. But beware, the situation remains fragile, as you said, which requires all our mobilization. I have two points and one question. My first point: on this International Women's Day, the UN Special Envoy, Staffan de Mistura, reminded us that Syrian women are an integral part of a lasting solution. They have the right to participate and we have a duty to ensure their participation in the peace process. In general, we know how crucial it is for the inter-Syrian dialogue to be as inclusive as possible. The second point is that if the lack of direct military involvement by the European Union has excluded us from the negotiations on the cessation of hostilities, in terms of political negotiations, that must be our strength. In the case of Syria, as in the Middle East more generally, the European Union must have the ambition to be a balancing force and we thank you, High Representative, for all your efforts in this direction. My question is not urgent, but I think our strength must be anticipation. Our common ambition is to hold elections. How can we anticipate the difficulties of holding such a vote, with more than 11 million people displaced in Syria and neighbouring countries? Do host countries fully support this objective? (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – Madam Representative, I think you have outlined the situation quite correctly. I would like to move on a little bit from my question: do you not see that the Russians have a responsibility here, with the parties involved in Syria, or with all the Member States of the European Union? After all, russian bombing is now, unfortunately, more refugees than there ever would have been from internal problems. So I ask you, how do you feel about involving the Russian part in this whole settlement?

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, I think that, in this situation, we must remember the message that the High Representative sent us: beware, the situation can deteriorate very quickly. So let us be very vigilant about the accusations, and the judgments. One of the great lessons to be learned from what is happening in Syria is that it is only if we, together, together - the entire international community - assume our responsibilities with a very concrete vision, that we will be able to restore lasting peace and stability in this region.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Mr President, for too long, when we debate Syria in this Chamber, there has been only despair. Before last week, once again, sceptics said that the ceasefire in Syria would not hold and humanitarian assistance would remain undelivered. Thankfully, although there have been incidents to the contrary, the sceptics have been proved wrong. Civilian deaths have fallen by 90% since the truce came into force, according to media reports just this morning. Our task politically this week and in the weeks to follow is to keep trying to turn despair into hope. The High Representative should have the European Parliament’s full support to use the international collaboration that we have achieved to make tentative moves which could turn a temporary ceasefire into a permanent peace. In the remainder of this speech I apologise both to colleagues and perhaps most of all to those who are suffering in Syria, because I have to refer to a different type of sceptic: those who, I am disgusted to say, are from my own country and are seeking to exploit the tragic flow of refugees from Syria by turning it into a cynical political argument to inflame opposition to my country’s membership of the European Union. Like Boris Johnson, who referred to the sincere compassion for Syrian refugees as ‘Britain-bashers’ moral outrage’ and then repeated the deliberate myth that ‘many of them are arriving in Europe as economic migrants’. Or the leader of UKIP, who by saying that ISIS is using this route to put jihadists on European soil is giving publicity and encouragement to the very people he says he wants to deter. These people are contemptible. They will fail on Syria, just as sceptics about Syria will fail. There is genuine compassion in the European Parliament in the matter of solving this refugee crisis. They will not win. My country will remain a member of the European Union, and European efforts, rather than those of any one country on its own, are needed to respond to the humanitarian crisis that is the tragedy of Syria and to contribute to the peace which is necessary to end this conflict. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card questions under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: blue-card question. – Well, maybe Mr Howitt knows something that we do not, but is he disagreeing with the First Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Timmermans, who has said that most of the people who are entering Europe are from Syria? Does he also disagree with official asylum figures in the UK, which say that the most of the people who came to the UK and claimed asylum last year actually came from Eritrea and not Syria? Mr Howitt, you are scaremongering and you are playing a political game. So please answer. Do you disagree with Mr Timmermans and are you disagreeing with official British asylum figures?

name: Richard HOWITT
text: blue-card answer. – Whether it is the Commission or the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the major country of origin for a million refugees who have come to Europe is Syria. The majority are genuine refugees fleeing war, death and persecution. They are victims of a six-year bloody civil war and this European Union will contribute to international diplomacy to deal with peace and conflict resolution. We reject the arguments on the other side. (Applause)

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, a ‘partial ceasefire’ was the best description I have heard of the deal: ‘partial’ in terms of the stakeholders included, as well as in the territorial scope. Allow me to mention the firm results: increasing the role of al—Assad, reinstating Russia in international salons and bringing Iran to the region. Other effects are less obvious. Unfortunately, Daesh is going to operate beyond state borders and we were not notified about the organisation’s will to quit atrocities. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – As you mentioned the atrocities which took place in Syria and Iraq, do you not think that the European Union – through its two members of the Security Council, the UK and France – should call for an international criminal tribunal for Syria and Iraq to be set up in order to hold the leaders of Daesh accountable, in the near future, for their atrocities and genocide , especially against national minorities like the Azeris and Christians?

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you, colleague, yes I share your view.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, five years of our confusion and inaction have led us to where we are now: a situation where a sort of ceasefire – on whatever conditions – is in place. Frankly, to me the situation looks like a Syrian puzzle being made by Putin’s hands. He is the one acting on both sides by not stopping Russian citizens joining ISIS and then coming to back Assad; who bombs opposition, civilians and hospitals; who intentionally pushes massive flows of refugees; who feeds radical parties inside the EU; who creates fake propaganda stories.  Let us be frank, Moscow has given the West a very good lesson as regards our claims that there is no military solution in Syria, as completely the opposite has been proven so far. Clearly, any ceasefire is better than a war. The question remains: what is the price for it and at whose expense?

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, the cessation of hostilities is good news, especially since it leads to what we want, which is a political settlement that gives way to lasting peace that guarantees the existence of the Syrian State and does not break like other precedents. We have always supported Mr. mistura, but we must remember who does not. We should look at the session diary two or three years ago or the statements of some leaders who said how well Al-Nusra was doing, that is, al-Qaeda, or the anti-Dáesh coalition—65 countries that changed nothing. Now they have turned the tide and we are seeing that an independent role from the European Union would be needed and the best way is to tell our partners in quotes, the Government of Saudi Arabia and the Turkish Government, to stop funding, to tolerate and, above all, to break the truce, as it did yesterday. We must go to Geneva, we have always said so, with the presence of the government and the non-terrorist opposition.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: – Mr President, I say to Ms Mogherini: thank you for a very impressive update on the situation in Syria and I echo your comments and praise for Mr de Mistura. If anything, you were rather modest about your own role in this, and the role of your services and the European Union in cohering the international community into values-based cooperation. The EU does not do guns and tanks and bombs, thank goodness, but we can play a role acting together to facilitate a dialogue which goes somewhere. I very strongly endorse Mr Howitt’s position, from my party, the Scottish National Party, in making sure that we as the United Kingdom continue to remain part of that framework.  You are right: the cooperation is starting to deliver. That is the best description of it. There is an immediate humanitarian crisis, and I entirely support your efforts on that. I am also very keen to stress the support for Lebanon and Jordan; these are fragile states that need our total support. My question would be about accountability: there can be no peace without accountability on all sides, for all crimes in this conflict. I am glad to hear of the reopening of the Damascus office of ECHO. But my question would be: to what extent are your services assisting NGOs – or indeed individuals – domestically and internationally in gathering the evidence that we will need to ensure that accountability is part of Syria’s eventual solution?

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: – Mr President, as we know, Syria is probably the most serious issue that the world faces today. We have seen the evilness of Islamic State. We have seen the televised burnings, we have seen the drownings, the beheadings, and the throwing of people off roofs for simply being homosexual and, if they do not die, kicking them to death on the ground. It is these extremists who want to take over control, not just of Syria, but the whole region. But let us not forget that back in 2013 we had all Western politicians, including John McCain and our own foreign policy genius, Guy Verhofstadt, telling us that we must arm these rebels – these nice cuddly rebels – who included the al-Nusra Front and the Syrian Mujahideen. Thank God that did not happen. I would simply like to ask Ms Mogherini why we continue to do nothing about Saudi Arabia and why we are continuing to throw money at Turkey and are inviting Turkey to join the European Union when they are the funders of terrorism.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Union is now trying to buy Turkey's favour with billions in payments, and is succumbing to a major error. Turkey is not a desirable partner in the Syrian peace process, either politically, militarily, and certainly not by religion. Turkey's fight against the Kurdish independence movement was extended to Syrian territory months ago, with the help of pro-Turkish militias operating freely in the border area. In violation of international law, Turkey began shelling Syrian territory in mid-February. Washington sent a note of protest to Ankara and called for an immediate halt to the attacks. But I wonder: where is the Union's response? Instead of taking measures according to the Erdogan regime because of the repression of minorities and the weakening of a military partner, they continue to take action here. This is duplicitous, wrong and certainly not a way to peace in Syria.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, the ceasefire agreement in Syria is a hopeful step and I am confident that it will be strengthened by the forthcoming talks in Geneva.  The ceasefire is not absolute—as has been said—but violence has been greatly reduced. Anyway, that's good news.  It is true that the ceasefire is not the solution of the conflict either. We need the forthcoming negotiations to allow progress towards a political solution as agreed in the 2012 Geneva Communiqué and Security Council Resolution 2254.  The lack of progress in the political arena would encourage the consolidation of groups such as the Dáesh and the worsening humanitarian crisis, which has had such a negative impact on the European Union.  We are at a crucial moment and I welcome, Mrs Mogherini, your commitment to the support and impetus of the Geneva talks and to the relief of the serious humanitarian situation that is affecting the Syrian people. But we also know that the Wary Syrian parties and international and regional actors need to live up to the circumstances for the conflict in Syria to finally move towards a stable solution and end five years of confrontation.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Since 2011 we have seen the Syrian people's uprising against dictator Assad turned into civil war by sectarian war and proxy between Saudi Arabia and Iran, for Turkey's support for the infiltration of terrorist groups, resulting in the destruction of the country, unbearable human suffering, in the greatest humanitarian catastrophe since World War II. All at the gates of Europe but with Europe to the east. The Russian intervention exposed the emptiness and the European disconcert.  Five years in which Member States have been unable to act coordinatedly and strategically, either through the common foreign and security policy for the negotiated resolution of the conflict, a common security and defence policy that would help Kurds, Iraqis and Syrians in the fight against terrorist occupiers and to secure liberated areas for displaced populations or even a humanitarian emergency policy capable of creating living conditions in refugee camps , including education for children and young people.  We do not just feed the reasons why thousands of fugitives every day seek refuge in Europe. We are offering more lost generations to extremist and terrorist recruitment. This conflict has opened doors to the terrorist hydra, in addition to Syria and Iraq, also already in Libya, where it directly threatens our own security. The European Union cannot continue to deny and fuel the illusion that it can contain the border conflict and outsource refugees fleeing it to Turkey and other neighbours. I greet Ms Mogherini for finally putting the European Union into a ceasefire agreement, but Munich will not last without sitting the Kurds at the table as well. It is not enough to manage the crisis, it is necessary to deal with the underlying causes. For this we need a Europe of solidarity and strong political leadership.  The immoral deal that the European Council seems to have made yesterday with Erdogan's Turkey, unfortunately, does not foresee this leadership we need so much.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Madam High Representative, in your introduction to this debate, you referred to conversations you had yesterday with your Turkish partners. There are three recent events that concern me, so what is my question: what do you actually indicate the Turkish role in the regional war currently raging in Syria?  Twice, hundreds of heavily armed jihadists, whether from Jabhat Al-Nusra or The Islamic State, have carried out attacks on Kurdish units from Turkish territory. One time near the city of Azaz, the second time near the city of Tel Abyad. Turkish territory is therefore used as a base for jihadists in that war. Finally, a third event: on 28 February, the Greek authorities stopped a ship en route to Lebanon from Turkey laden with heavy weapons.  Mrs Mogherini, I have the feeling that Turkey is more the problem than the solution to the crisis situation surrounding the whole of this Syrian regional war.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – After many years, we have come to the point where we are saving a humanitarian catastrophe, or at least trying to resolve it in parallel with the political process that should lead to peace in Syria. The humanitarian catastrophe is the result of a wrong policy, including ours, in relation to the complexity of Syria. We didn't understand where the start of the escalation in Syria was going. We certainly have, as you said, three positive things at the moment. One is a ceasefire, the other is coordination between the United States and Russia and a third inclusiveness in the negotiations, which also involves Russians, including Assad. You said we weren't in the Cold War. I fear that, according to the rhetoric of some colleagues who cannot focus on Syria but are polarising with Putin - completely unnecessary in this situation that we are actually in this Cold War. I think the ultimate goal that we need to set ourselves is a democratic Syria. Perhaps it would be right that we in Europe are already starting to think about what happens after the war in Syria, namely the process of reconciliation.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am convinced that in Syria, albeit with the fragile truce, an extraordinary opportunity has been created for the European Union and, after five very difficult years of conflict and humanitarian emergencies, the temporary freezing of violence allows much broader and more targeted humanitarian intervention, but also the relaunch of a political process that must put the side of , so to speak, preconceptions and giving syrians the opportunity to start thinking about a future built primarily by themselves.  I think that the European Union has been carrying out extraordinary work in the UN for months. Now he has to prove that he is up to a renewed leading role. It must therefore take on the crucial responsibility of leading a humanitarian response that is equal to the conditions created, although it must be stressed that the European Union, with more than EUR 5 billion earmarked for humanitarian assistance, is the main regional donor, but also to continue to act diplomatically to build bridges between the international and regional and local actors involved in the conflict. As you rightly pointed out here, there is a strong demand for a European political presence in Syria, in a context where our credibility has tangible specific weight. These opportunities, and the hope that they represent a momentum for Syria towards national peace, are part of a regional framework where the European Union has already shown that it can play an important role, as in the case of the Iranian nuclear power.  However, what has been done so far is not enough. Indeed, I fear that the European Union is increasingly turning in on itself, as demonstrated by the management of the refugee crisis. We must give real direction to the whole of European foreign policy which, while maintaining its basic values, must finally take a clear direction and show consistency. If we as Europeans want to play a decisive role in Syria, we must be prepared to renounce national self-interest, the ambiguities of certain countries and start thinking big, favouring the peace process that is more indispensable than ever.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: " The war in Syria has been going on for five years and has killed more than a quarter of a million people. That is why we welcomed the agreement in this country on terms agreed by the US and Russia. Negotiations on a complete resolution of the conflict are conducted under the auspices of the UN. We have a strong interest in stabilisation in the region, as it is, among other things, the key to solving the most serious migration crisis facing the European Union. Lasting peace in Syria means, above all, stopping the murders of civilians, including Christians, as well as a real halt to the flow of migrants and the concrete possibility of their return to their own country. We are therefore very concerned that, despite the agreement, 135 people have been killed again in a short period of time and more than 550 in terrorist-controlled territory. Therefore, the Union must continue to actively support the UN in its peace efforts and provide the humanitarian assistance that Mrs Mogherini referred to today.

name: Javier NART
text: – Mr President, our inaction has in this case caused a collapse in Syria. We have prolonged the war, there has been no solution to the problems that exist and we find today something that none of us like, but that is the reality. In a war, the protagonists are not the ones we desire, but the real ones. And today the protagonists are, on the one hand, the regime of Al-Asad, which is simultaneously, contradictoryly, the guarantee of its own security for the Sunni middle classes, for the Alawites indeed, and also for Christians, confronted with the Wahhabi, either terrorists of Yabhat al-Nusra or, let's say, the allies of the West, Ahrar al-Sham, who are exactly the same , with more Yaish al-Islam.  We absolutely need to go to a peace process and the need, therefore, to recognise that it was Russian intervention that led, in the end, to agree.  To raise a primary anti-Russian position is to deny evidence: five years of war have ended with a ceasefire within a few months of Russian action, which meant the strengthening of a criminal regime but which exists, which is that of Al-Asad.  Let us promote peace negotiations, have a proactive presence on the part of Europe and fight terrorism effectively, which we strategically do not do.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Mr President, hundreds of Syrians nationwide used the cessation of hostilities to resume anti-government protests calling for the overthrow of Assad in favour of a free, democratic and united Syria. It was a reminder of how the conflict emerged in the spring of 2011. However, the reality is that this is not a cessation, but merely a reduction, of hostilities. During the first week of the agreement, 135 people were killed in areas covered by the deal, and 32 of them were civilians. The violations must stop in order to create a favourable environment for the start of negotiations. The intra-Syrian negotiations have to resume in order to move forward into a comprehensive ceasefire and a long—overdue political transition as outlined in the Vienna Peace Agreement. It must be a Syrian-led and a Syrian-owned resolution.  The international community must work in good faith to implement the agreement alongside the agreement reached in Munich. Russia and Iran need to exert their influence over Syria’s regime and other parties to respect the truce. We need to seize this opportunity to make it work on all fronts – military, diplomatic and humanitarian. Progress in getting aid to besieged areas of Syria is welcome. There must be no obstruction of humanitarian aid, and full access must be allowed throughout Syria. The international community has to be much bolder in this approach.  We must not waste this chance; this needs to be the year in which the bloodshed in Syria comes to an end. It is our common goal to defeat Daesh and solve the refugee crisis. Therefore, it is in all our interests to support the Syrian peace process, which can lead to a stable, inclusive government and has the support of all Syrians.  (The speaker refused a blue-card question from Mr Buonnano)

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, I wish to thank the High Representative for her statement. We all agree that it is time for peace now in Syria, peace for everyone. Therefore, I call on you, High Representative, to make sure that a genuine delegation of Syrian Christians will be added to the Syrian Democratic Council delegation in peace talks. Several times I asked for attention for the democratic self-administration in north-eastern Syria in the Rojava canton. People are living peacefully in this region they have maintained by themselves. However, this peace is under threat not only from Daesh but also others. Turkey has to stop the shelling of DSA territory, otherwise we would see another massive wave of refugees floating to neighbouring countries and Europe. The Kurdish regional government in Iraq has to open the Faysh Khabur border crossing to the DSA area and end all restrictions. I therefore call on you to use all your diplomatic influence in the discussions with our Middle East partners. Last but not least, I would ask you to start cooperation with the DSA for aid to internally displaced people. We need to have them. They are the keepers of future stability in the region.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, the civil war in Syria has many implications for the EU: the refugee crisis, terrorism, negative impact on the regional situation, complicating relations with Russia, potential for escalation. The two recent ceasefire agreements have not yet been able to completely stop the fighting between the regime and the opposition and between the various factions forming that opposition. That is so primarily because there is no agreement among the intervening powers, both regional and extra-regional, on the future of the Assad regime and the ensuing betting on rival factions. The solution, exclusively political, would have to be reached after a real ceasefire which would be motivated by humanitarian intervention to help the population caught in the fighting. In sum: from simple to complex and from humanitarian through the military to the political level seems to be the logical path, promising eventually a solution to this complicated and important conflict on our doorstep.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Mr President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has I support the current ceasefire, which has so far been largely observed by all the main parties to the conflict. The next step is the resumption of the Geneva talks, which are intended to lay the foundations for a longer-term pacification of the country. In addition, however, the war crimes committed must be punished by the application of international criminal law. I warmly welcome the initiatives, such as the Commission for International Justice and Accountability. It is supported by Germany, the United States and the European Union, among others. Its employees collect and document evidence of human rights violations in the Syrian civil war.  The organization has already gathered enough evidence to charge Assad for crimes against humanity.  Should a procedure arise, however, it is still unclear which legal authority is competent or whether a new body needs to be created. The EU should call on all the powers involved, notably the US and Russia, to take international criminal law issues into account in the Geneva negotiations.  In general, international law should become an essential part of the EU's foreign policy toolbox. Dictators need to know that they pay a heavy price if they violate the human rights of their citizens. The European Union should systematically call on third countries to join the International Criminal Court. (The speaker refused to answer a question from Mr Buonanno under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: While the Syrian conflict has so far been associated with immeasurable suffering, the near-total annihilation of a country and the destruction of millions of people, it seems increasingly difficult to end the war. To outside observers, it seems that not only have we come closer to a solution, but we are moving further and further away from peace. Indeed, if one of the parties, if it can be put this way, gains military supremacy, foreign supporters of the losing forces will immediately arrive and give new impetus to the fighting. All we see here in Europe is that everyone is fighting terrorism in Syria and people are fleeing, slowly losing hope that they will be able to rebuild their country one day. And if that hope is lost, it's almost no matter who wins, because there will be no population. And on International Women's Day, allow us to welcome, alongside our wives, our daughters, the ladies present, the women who today are protecting their families and their country with guns somewhere near the Syrian border.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, with regard to Syria, I would first like to point out that there were Western powers, and of course Turkey and Saudi Arabia supported Daesh, that is to say, they supported extreme Shiite Islam in order to strike the Shiites, especially Assad, and that is why Daesh was strengthened. We must take this seriously. The situation in Syria, of course, is critical. Daesh must be defeated. There must be peace. And without peace, Mrs Mogherini, of course thousands of refugees will continue to come to Greece. We currently have 40,000. If this situation continues, 150,000 refugees will be stranded by the end of the month.  Here comes the question: Skopje and Albania have closed the borders. Mr Ban Ki-moon said that this was an illegal act, that it violates international law. For your part, as the European Union, as High Representative, what will you do? You must take action to open the borders. It's illegal what's going on. Thousands of refugees cannot be trapped in Greece. Greece cannot have turned into a refugee Dachau.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, the fragile truce we are witnessing in Syria is certainly better than war, and it needs to be maintained. And that is why it is good that you are involved in this process respected High Commissioners, but it is also good that both the US and Russia have found a solution. However, the future cannot be in their hands. The future must be in the hands of the Syrians and we must make it clear that Syria belongs to them and not to someone else. And we need to make it clear that our enemies are primarily Daesh and terrorist groups that have shown how much they are willing to commit crimes in this world. Everything else, in my deep belief, should be left to the Syrians. If we want to establish an international criminal court for war crimes in Syria, let's do it, because it can also be a legal path that can resolve the situation. But, in any case, let us leave Syria to those who live there.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the ceasefire in Syria is the first encouraging signal since the war in that country began that there is a hope of normal lysing the situation in this very difficult region. Civilian casualties have already reportedly fallen by 90% and casualties in the fighting have been reduced by 80%. What is causing concern is the reluctance of the Syrian opposition to participate in the peace talks in Geneva.  As far as the European Union is concerned, despite the fact that it is actively involved in both the provision of humanitarian aid and the ceasefire, it has nevertheless missed an important opportunity to be a great and important player on the world chessboard, because – let us be honest – if Russia had not intervened militarily, Syria would have been occupied by ISIS forces and transformed into yet another Islamic country that would be hostile to the West and dangerous for its interests in the sensitive region of the Middle East.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, it would be good if this ceasefire agreement in Syria represented the end of the deadly five-year war, but the foundations on which it stands are fragile. News of an alliance of hawks is coming from the United States, advocating a military escalation against the Syrian government and Russia, making more weapons on the ground. Let us be clear, this ceasefire agreement is the result of the dramatic situation in which terrorist gangs are on the ground, the result of military collaboration between the Syrian government and its Russian and Iranian allies and Hezbollah. Terrorists, it is good to remind you, at the service of the United States and its allies, a kind of American foreign legion, as someone has already suggested.  As for the waves of refugees arriving in Europe every day, they are like stones thrown in the face of the European Union, reminding them of their own responsibilities in the operation of destabilisation, interference and war in Syria. Apart from the shame that was yesterday's summit, when I heard you here today talking about things that only the Syrian people have to decide, we fear, Madam Vice-President, that nothing has been learned from all this.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the High Representative, thank you for your important report. Thank you also for your great commitment to the peace negotiations and to improving humanitarian aid. But what the Commission is doing is far from enough here. As long as there is still hunger in the refugee camps and as long as the people there are not sufficiently protected from the cold, we must also give more money – we as the EU and as the Commission. We should not give money to Turkey to build a wall to protect itself from the refugees. Isn't it much more sensible to put the money into the camps so that people have no reason to flee so that they can survive there? I therefore urge you to work to ensure that at least the most necessary needs of the people in the refugee camps on the ground are met.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to start by saying to Members very sincerely that sometimes I have the impression that it is relatively easy to sit here and highlight all the shortcomings of a situation that I described myself as being very far from being – not even perfect – but good. It is as if we were complaining that this glass is half-full. It is actually much less than half-full. The point is that two weeks ago it was empty. So our task is to try to build, drop by drop, a glass that is full and becomes a little bit fuller every day because every single drop is a life we save and every single life we save has a value, whether it is here in Europe, in the Aegean, inside Syria, in Lebanon or Jordan. So my job – I do not know about yours – is not to argue about whether this is perfect or not enough. My job is to try to make it better every day with what we can put at the disposal of an international community that needs to come together – finally –because five years of war are also the result of five years of international divisions and regional clashes on Syria, in Syria and around Syria.  So I really believe that the European Union’s role here is this: to try – as many of you have said – to bridge different agendas.  We have so many actors here – inside Syria and outside Syria – that have completely different agendas. We would disagree on almost everything but as our vital interests – political and, I would say, even moral – and also our interest as Europeans in security – because the longer the war lasts, the more Daesh spreads – and also in the refugee crisis – I know Frans Timmermans is having a debate on migration after me so I will not spoil his exercise and I will leave this aspect to him – but also our interest in relation to management of the flows, but first of all our humanitarian and political interest, is to try to identify the common ground among very different agendas. These are going to stay different, but maybe we can enlarge, step by step, the common ground that allows the international community and the regional players to facilitate, rather than make it impossible, for the Syrians to try to build peace instead of having five years of civil war.  So war is not over. We cannot even call it a ceasefire; we call it a cessation of hostilities and we had hours of discussion about the words here, just to let you understand how sensitive these things are. So it is clear that war is still there. It is not going to disappear next week and, as I said very clearly at the beginning, things can return to being very bad at any time if we do not continue to align all the possible elements that push in the right direction, which is a very complicated job to do every single day. So what is still there? We have a cessation of hostilities. We are trying to open the spaces we have to have more and more humanitarian access, to have more and more delivery of humanitarian aid, and to have more hope for the Syrians.  One of you said that our task is to turn despair into hope. That is true and also to try to build bridges among the different actors, identifying common grounds – that is diplomacy and that is the European spirit.  Sometimes we have difficulty in doing this inside the EU; outside we still have a little bit of credibility in doing this and I will try to keep it – the inside might help, I have to say; sometimes that is not always the case.  We are trying to build the road towards peace, political transition inside Syria and a Syrian-led and a Syrian-owned future for the country. When we say Syrian-led and Syrian-owned, we are not referring only to the Syrians who are still inside Syria, but also those who have left Syria because they also have to have a say in the future – and the present – of their country.  So indeed, as Mr Preda was saying, we need to try to stick – and to push all the actors to stick – to the roadmap that we decided together, that was endorsed by a Security Council resolution, unanimously adopted for the first time. This is the precious result of the difficult work we have managed to build.  I heard some words about the lack of unity among the Europeans here. Let me tell you very clearly: I chair and participate in five different formations of the European Council, I take part in the European Commission College every week, I am very often here in Parliament – that it is quite clear and obviously you have divisions and different views – but on this the European Union is not only united in words and in thoughts, but is also acting united. Every single week, every three to four days, we coordinate actions, messages and we coordinate our work every day in the task forces we are in. Do not portray the European Union as divided even if you do not really see the division here. There are fields where we are divided – plenty of them – but at least in the fields where we act together and we think together and we are politically on the same page, let us also try to highlight the positive that we have. We should at least do this ourselves because, if we do not do it ourselves, it is difficult for others to see this. But in this field – on our actions in Syria – we are indeed united and acting as Europe. On three things, firstly Lebanon and Jordan, I agree one hundred percent – and even more – on the need to stress not only the financial support we can give them, but also the work we can do together to increase the resilience of societies and of their systems and to work together for this. I will visit Lebanon and Jordan in a couple of weeks’ time, 10 days, and this will be one of the elements of our common work. They sit, together with us, in the International Support Group. We work extremely well together with both Jordan and Lebanon because I believe we share the same objective, namely that of trying to find a solution to the war and for the country to move forward and find peace. One other thing that was mentioned was accountability. This is something on which we are already starting to work, in particular with the NGOs that are working on the ground every single day. This is an issue which we can perhaps come back to in more detail at a later stage, either in plenary or in one of the committees. I would be glad to do so. Let me finish with one element. Some of you referred to the role of women, especially on this particular day. I like to do it especially on the other days too, but it true that 8 March is somehow a very significant day. When we say that the future of Syria has to belong to all the citizens of Syria – all the Syrians inside and outside the country – we always also refer to women. When we say that we are thinking – not only thinking but trying to build a perspective – of a secular country in Syria, we also refer to the fact that so many women in Syria have expectations of the role they can play in their country. The work that we do with the NGOs in supporting their daily work, inside and outside Syria, with the Syrians, is partially, but significantly, going towards the work of NGOs that work on empowering women.  But let me also say something that I find really sad. I am sorry to finish on a sad note. Around the table of the International Support Group for Syria, I am the only woman sitting there. This perhaps gives the European Union a special role but it tells us a lot about the state of play of the role of women in international diplomacy still in such a large part of our international community – and not only in certain parts of the world but in many parts of the world, including the European Union. To finish on a positive note, I will tell you that indeed, when women are not only at the table, but also in negotiating teams, as was the case for the Iranian deal, I think that we sometimes have better chances to build something, maybe pragmatic, maybe, as I said at the beginning, stubborn, but that at the end of the day might work.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – On Saturday, 27 February, the first ceasefire entered into force in five years of war in Syria, following the unanimous adoption of UN Security Council resolution 2268. It is essential that it is fulfilled to enable unhindered access and distribution of humanitarian aid throughout Syria. This truce will allow the United Nations to reconfide the talks between Syrians in Geneva and begin to create the conditions for the political transition agreed by the Security Council. The international community and the parties to the conflict have a responsibility to comply with the minimum life-saving agreements, and to lead Syria to a peaceful solution. The war has already produced more than five million refugees, which must be taken into account. The EU, together with the US and Russia, must share information to monitor compliance with the truce and cooperate with the Syrian parties, excluding terrorist organizations, to focus on the reform roadmap to a new Syria. We join and support the United Nations in declaring the need for a "Marshall plan" for Syria.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – 13 million people in need of humanitarian aid, 5 million of them children, more than 250 000 people killed, more than 4 million refugees and 9 million IDPs. In 2015, MSF medical facilities faced 94 aerial and shelling attacks. MSF also has recorded 74 mass casualty incidents, noting the increase from October last year. Observers state that all forces opposed to Assad are indiscriminately attacked, without making a difference between civilians and militants. Both governments also use cluster bombs, confirmed by numerous reports on the ground. Russia is not a solution: siding with Assad has made it a contributor to one of the biggest humanitarian catastrophes since WWII. One should not forget that Russia’s strategic aim is destabilising Europe and NATO. Further, it lies within the responsibility of the EU not only to receive refugees, but also to create conditions in Syria, in the form of safe areas where people could live until they could return to their homes. Also, the EU and other states need to adequately finance the World Food Programme, which supports Syrian refugees in neighbouring states.

text: in writing. – On Saturday, 27 February, the first ceasefire entered into force in five years of war in Syria, following the unanimous adoption of UN Security Council resolution 2268. name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the joint debate on the Commission statement on the implementation of the European Agenda on Migration.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, in the past six months unprecedented numbers of people have arrived at the EU’s borders. The push factors driving the flows are unlikely to be reversed in the foreseeable future. Tens of thousands of people are still fleeing war in Syria and Europe will remain attractive to those who are looking for a better life. As Europeans, we cannot and will not turn our backs on our moral and international legal obligation to provide protection for those who need it. But nor can we continue to have uncontrolled irregular flows of migrants passing swiftly north through one border after another, in fundamental contradiction with the principles of the Common European Asylum System and the Schengen rules. The crisis has exposed serious deficiencies at parts of the external borders. This, and the ‘wave-through’ policy adopted by some countries, has led several Member States to resort to reintroducing temporary internal border controls, putting into question the Schengen area of free movement and its huge benefits for our economy and our citizens. We estimate the cost of ‘non-Schengen’ to be in the range of EUR 5-18 billion a year. So we need to get our systems into order to be prepared to deal effectively with the challenge of people on the move. That means more managed and legal means of entry for those in need of protection, and quick and effective identification and return of those who have no right to be in the EU. In line with the objectives we presented on 10 February, and which were endorsed by the European Council, last week the Commission put forward a roadmap to bring the Schengen area back to normality by the end of this year. I am glad that this roadmap was fully endorsed by the Heads of State and Governments yesterday. In our roadmap, we identify three key priorities: first, Greece needs to address the serious deficiencies in its border management, with the assistance of the Commission, EU agencies and other Member States. In the meantime, we must also quickly agree on the European Border and Coast Guard to restore confidence in the effectiveness of the management of our external borders. I count on this House to play its part here. Second, the ‘wave-through’ approach has to stop now and consequentially we need to urgently step up help for Greece in dealing with those present on its territory. We are working closely with the Greek authorities and international organisations to increase the reception capacity. We have also proposed a new EU humanitarian support instrument in order to be able to help better and quicker and, finally, getting the relocation decisions really working will also help alleviate the pressure in Greece. In this regard, I welcome the fact that we have been able to accelerate the pace of relocations over the last days. Third, we need to apply the Schengen rules to ensure the future of Schengen. The roadmap makes clear that the Commission is ready, if needed, to propose a coordinated European approach for temporary internal border controls in May. Such controls would be targeted at the parts of the border where they are necessary and would be limited in time, with the aim of phasing them out by December. Let me make clear that the aim is not to sanction any Member State. It is about a concerted approach in which we can work in an orderly way whilst the underlying problems are resolved. In this crisis everything is linked to everything, and we need to work on all tracks in parallel. First of all, we need to see the numbers of arrivals into Greece come down. For this reason, it is essential that we continue to work with Turkey to fully implement the Joint Action Plan, to break the business model of the smugglers, end the tragic loss of life and make clear that the only viable way to come to Europe is through legal channels. In this regard, the European Commission stands ready to support the further work in the coming days on the basis of the principles identified by the Heads of State or Government in its statement last night. As agreed by leaders, this work will respect European and international law. In parallel, we need to see Greece return to the Dublin system, in line with the recommendation we made on 10 February. For the longer run, we need to take a fresh look at Dublin in order to make sure that we build a sustainable European Asylum system. Last but not least, I have talked about the need to ensure safe alternative routes for those in need of protection. This is particularly important in order to ensure the protection of vulnerable persons, including women and children. This was also highlighted in this morning’s debate on women refugees, and I really want to thank Parliament for raising this important issue especially on 8 March, International Women’s Day. What is essential is that we keep working on all these fronts and stick to the agreed plans. This is what Member States have committed to in successive European Council meetings. Now they need to deliver. We have a plan, and we need to show that slowly but surely this plan is starting to show results.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, thank you very much for the overview. It is indeed the case that we are making small steps, but unfortunately the steps are still too small to actually make progress, given the scale of the problem. Although the registration data in Greece is now given in percentages, it has now increased visibly. But it is still not clear what the percentages are actually based on, because the actual figures are still not 100% clear, because we do not know how many people – as you yourself have said – actually cross the borders in concrete terms. I am also pleased that, at the EU-Turkey Summit, we have now taken another step forward in our cooperation with Turkey. I hope that action can be taken here by the middle of the month, and I would also like to thank the Commission for clearly rejecting the so-called wave-through policy. For this reason, however, I also believe it is necessary for us to tackle the issue of trafficking in human beings with an even more intensive approach. I see that both Europol and Frontex are still not sufficiently staffed, that we still do not have a full staffing of Frontex, including EASO, because the Member States do not provide the necessary experts accordingly, which I think is disgraceful. Normally, the EU should work together, not stop each other. I would like to draw attention to a particular problem and ask for your help: in 2014, 4 000 children who were sexually abused were identified. There were 8,000 children in 2015, and more children in 2016, in January only, than in the whole of 2015. In other words, the unrecognised refugee children have clearly reached the criminals. I would like us to give a more coherent and better european response and to provide staff to better protect these children.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her What are we talking about? The Commission wants to reapply Dublin to Greece – a system that has never worked and which attributes all responsibility for refugees to states with an external border alone. If the Balkan route is closed or if it remains closed, then the situation in Greece will finally become a humanitarian disaster – there can be no question of transfers back to Dublin. The other Member States must finally take responsibility.  Instead, Turkey should now take over and solve our problems. But is Turkey really a safe state, a reliable partner? The peace process with the Kurds has ended, lawyers and journalists cannot work freely, media are occupied, and after China, Turkey is the country with the most imprisoned journalists. Yes, we commend Turkey for taking in almost three million refugees and at the same time declare that we, as a continent of 500 million people, are overwhelmed with such a number – that is embarrassing! Europe is losing its value not only as a place of relative prosperity, but as a place of freedom, democracy and respect for fundamental and human rights. This affects the refugees, and it is also a fatal signal for our own citizens. The Commission and the Council must finally take political leadership and promote distribution within the EU. Yes, combating the causes of flight and smugglers, including ensuring better living conditions for refugees in third countries, remains important, but only by taking responsibility for our own responsibilities do we have a strong negotiating position and, on our part, we are a reliable and credible partner. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Madam President, thank you very much for accepting my blue card. You mentioned the Western Balkans route and you said it couldn't be shut down. I'm of the opinion, as you do, that the Western Balkans route must be open. But do you agree with me that we need to know who is passing along this Western Balkan route? And it is certain that Greece cannot establish the Dublin regulation because the Dublin regulation has long since failed, but we need to know, I am convinced of, who is coming to us in Europe. Do you agree with me?

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I agree with you that the registration of all arriving refugees must be ensured where they arrive. Mrs Hohlmeier has just pointed out that this cannot be left to Greece alone, for example, but that we also need the support, the staff support, of all the Member States. If that is assured, we will certainly be one step further together.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, today we are here, surely, to speak about implementation of rules. It is not an exciting subject, but rules are what will save us in the end. And if we do not play by the rules then why are we here in the first place? Rules and implementation do not always allow for flashy announcements, claims of big victories or headlines about vital breakthroughs, but they do matter. It was, therefore, disappointing following yesterday’s summit with Turkey to hear that once again, for the second time in 12 months during this crisis, our rule book has been torn up and thrown in the bin.  We must first make the rules we have in place work, or at least give them a chance to work and to make them work better, rather than always producing new policies based on desperation. I am supportive of a lot of the proposals the Commission has come forward with, building upon and enhancing the mechanisms we already have in place. And they will help us protect the external borders, help make returns more efficient and offer solidarity and assistance through EASO and Frontex. Vice-President Timmermans has offered us assurances today in all those respects. But nowhere in the current established rules does it say that we should take actions in contradiction to our own asylum laws, hand over huge sums of money with no proper guarantees in return and abandon the Copenhagen criteria in exchange for nothing more than a promise.  Silver-bullet solutions do not exist, relocation does not yet work and I fear any deal we make with Turkey and its current proposed form without a proper legal framework and a system of incremental payments, targets and benchmarks will create nothing more than another failure, at a time when we really need success. I fear that George Bernard Shaw was too right when he said ‘we learn from history that we learn nothing from history’.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 149(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting this blue—card question. Would you not agree with me that the situation with immigration is the biggest single factor where the EU is totally out of touch with its constituents and one of the biggest reasons why there is such a backlash against this organisation? Would you also agree with me that the very fact that the desperate measure which the EU takes to try to deal with this crisis, which is to go cap-in-hand and grovel to Turkey to deal with this situation, just illustrates the weakness of this organisation?

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for those very interesting questions, which I will have to reflect on for a while, but in the meantime perhaps I could just say to you that if you had listened to what I just said in my speech, you would realise the way forward is a positive way forward, with the UK fully participating in putting more sense into the decisions of the European Union. If we were to leave the European Union – and I know this gentleman would like us to – we would no longer be an influence for good, doing what we can with the experience of people like myself, former immigration ministers and others to help Europe to solve a crisis which frankly needs to be solved.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, during the last few months this continent has been faced with an unprecedented number of refugees fleeing from conflicts and oppression. The response from national leaders has frankly been quite pathetic. We have seen calls for systematic mass refoulement of refugees at our borders, in obvious contravention of international humanitarian laws and the Treaties and laws of the Union. We have seen the reintroduction of internal border controls despite calculations from the Bertelsmann Institute indicating that only the financial cost of the collapse of Schengen could be as high as EUR 1.4 trillion over a 10-year period. We have seen Member States engaging in a race to the bottom with regard to the reception standards for refugees, hoping that this would push them elsewhere. But what we have not witnessed, however, is European leadership and a willingness to move towards the only solution that can in the long-term return sovereignty and control of the situation to the peoples of Europe. In other words, joint action with the Community method to ensure a fair, reasonable division of the responsibilities for the people fleeing. What we need is for us to manage our borders together, to share the responsibility for receiving refugees together, to find ways to repatriate those that do not meet the criteria for international protection, and that we do this together under dignified conditions. Commissioner Avramopoulos and First Vice-President Timmermans, keep up the good work within the Commission and propose now a true European solution, not least in the upcoming Dublin reforms. It is high time for the Commission and this Parliament to take the lead, together with a few courageous leaders we still can count on in Council. Why? Because Europe simply deserves it today.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her What is happening with the refugees at the moment can only be considered cynical: because the EU Member States are unwilling to take in refugees themselves, perhaps this should now be done in a horse-trading – as is currently being discussed – on the principle: if you give me an illegal refugee from Greece back to Turkey, then you will get a legal refugee – whatever that is – back to Europe, where he should be resettled.  I would like to make it clear that deporting refugees back to Turkey would be contrary to international law, because Turkey has so far only signed the Geneva Convention on Refugees with a regional reservation. The strategy of a genuine reception policy in the EU has failed. The migration agenda has become a repressive agenda. If we are now perhaps thinking about granting protection only to Syrians, and even in their case discussing safe zones in Syria, then that is really a farce, and it is pathetic. We are also tying itself up to Turkey, which is itself flouting human rights, which not only destroys media freedom, but also shoots at its own people. What is happening here is the erosion of the individual right to asylum. The Geneva Convention on Refugees is being thrown overboard, and this is a post-World War II civilisational achievement. We on the left will never accept this, and I call on you to protest against it and to use all the means that we, as Members of the European Parliament, as civil society, have.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr Timmermans, Mr Avramopoulos, this would have been the opportunity you could have seized to explain to us what you actually think of the Council's proposals last night. But when I listen to you, I actually hear a kind of "loyal cooperation." I also hear you say as a form of disclaimer 'within the law' and 'within the international treaties', but I hear you suggest that we are going to cooperate loyally with a Council proposal that is not aimed at giving refugees a home and taking them in properly, but that the primary aim is to limit the influx of refugees into Europe. I think we are already at the very first fault in our analyses: refugees are fleeing from somewhere, not necessarily somewhere. We have to see that and we have to deal with it. We do not do that when we say, 'Here you have a used refugee, I would like a fresh refugee back'. It's not trading in empty bottles for full bottles. They're people looking for a safe place. So if you're talking about legal access, I'd like to know how we organize that legal access. When you talk about border controls, we have to share the analysis that people are not allowed to use a legal border crossing, they come irregularly. That's why we have a control problem. I believe that it is not just the Council that lacks leadership, but you now, and that is a pity, because you were on the right track.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, even today we are still forced to talk about small steps forward, unfortunately. Small steps forward and as a follow-up to the migration agenda.  We are still forced to talk about 10 000 unaccompanied minors who have disappeared on European territory, the traces of which have been lost. We are still forced to talk about the lack of reliable data on dismantled criminal networks and I hope that europol's European Centre against Trafficking in Migrants will soon come and tell us about the results of their operations. We are forced to talk about an agreement with Turkey to deal with the migration crisis, but we cannot give in to Turkish blackmail: we cannot trade the management of migratory flows for Turkey's accession to the European Union.  Is Turkey really a safe country? Do you protect fundamental rights? No, it's not! It is not, but we are forced to think that it is; we want to convince ourselves that it is, because there is a lack of will, at European level, to deal with the migration crisis. There are certain Member States that refuse to tackle the management of migratory flows in a united manner. So, as long as there is a lack of willingness on the part of certain Member States to cooperate, nothing will ever change. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: "blue card" question. I am pleased to note that you are also talking about the 10 000 missing children. We submitted a written question about this with more than 40 ALDE members last week and asked for this to be put on the agenda here as well. What does your group propose to find those 10,000 missing children? I went to speak to Europol, I went to speak to Missing Children Europe. In 2016, we cannot afford to see 10 000 children lost on our territory.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Answer to a blue card question. It absolutely finds the support of our group in clarifying the disappearance of unaccompanied minors. I myself, along with other colleagues, have put questions to the European Commission to try to clarify matters and to call for a greater protection programme for this extremely vulnerable group of people.  It is unacceptable that even today there are thousands and thousands of unaccompanied minors disappearing into nowhere, without anyone demanding their protection; So absolutely there will be our support in this regard.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – If anything has been shown by this self-inflicted asylum crisis, it is the general incompetence of the European Union. Hundreds of pages of proposals have already been presented, but no asylum seeker has arrived yet.  Yesterday, European leaders, with Prime Minister Mark Rutte as the current President of the European Union, put the national interests of the sovereign states in the lap of turkish dictator Erdogan. Turkey demands and the EU bows. That is the conclusion of yesterday's shameful display. Turkey wants 6 billion euros, the European Union bends. Turkey wants to lift the visa requirement, the European Union bends, Turkey wants accelerated accession to the European Union and the EU bends. The European Union has made itself dependent on the unreliable Turkey, playing a dangerous game with our freedom, all under the guise of resolving the asylum tsunami. These were not negotiations and this is not a deal. This is a historic mistake.  These plans should therefore be taken off the table immediately. I therefore call on my own Prime Minister Mark Rutte to show courage. Close the Dutch borders. No money to Turkey and asylum claimants, but to our own people and our own security.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, both the so-called road map for Schengen and the joint statement of yesterday's session reward the entrapment of thousands of desperate refugees and migrants in Greece, taking it for granted. They confirm that closed borders and controls, expulsions through sorting are not only a policy of Austria or the Visegrad countries but a single policy of the European Union to close the faucet, signed by the Greek government. Contrary to the Geneva Convention, the European Union not only does not recognise Afghans, who are also victims of imperialist wars, as refugees, but now even Syrians are taking economic migrants for deportation to Turkey.  As for Dublin, it is coming back reinforced along with new restrictions on asylum, like those that Germany has just passed and other states are trying to encourage fascist hordes;  Solidarity with refugees means being transferred directly to their countries of final destination, it means temporary places of human decent hospitality; solidarity means an intensity of the fight against the policy of repression of the European Union and its governments and Member States, against imperialist war and in its womb, the capitalist system.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: – It is a point of order, Madam President, I would ask that the speeches be slower, because else the interpreters do not interpret and do not hear, it is not understood. Therefore, I ask you to ask the speakers to speak more slowly so that the interpreters can make a correct interpretation so that those who do not speak the same language can understand what they are saying.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Madam President, let me start by thanking the Commission for its consistent and clear commitment in trying to find a way forward to manage this crisis and to examine the tools we have at a European level in order to do so in the best possible way. I will focus on Schengen. Our celebrated Schengen zone has become a cornerstone of modern-day Europe. We must do what we can to ensure that it remains so. But at the same time, we must understand that the only reason that we do not have internal borders in Europe is because our citizens were promised that our external borders would be more secure and that sharing of information would be improved. One simply cannot happen without the other. Schengen is crucial in terms of Europe’s overall security, but it is also economically and politically necessary. We have seen that the cost of reintroducing border controls would be EUR 5-18 billion every single year. So we need to do much more to ensure our external borders are secure and that security standards remain high. In this respect, the proposal for a European Border and Coast Guard is an essential part of the picture. We need to ensure that we do this quickly while looking at all the sovereignty implications. We also need to ensure that the commitments and the EU-Turkey joint action plan are implemented and how this can be squared together with what was agreed last night. Every Member State must follow its obligations at the external borders, and this is true also for Greece. We all appreciate the difficulties that Greece in particular is going through, and therefore it is essential that solidarity and mutual trust between Member States is the principle upon which action in this area is based. I will conclude by saying our citizens demand action from Europe. It is no longer about finding emergency responses to emergency situations. We need to move past a piecemeal approach. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 149(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. It's also good for me to answer slowly in two or three words. My question is: do you see any way to solve many, many problems? For example, by finding a tool against reluctant or even blocking Member States. Because not only do problems exist on their own, but several Member States are trying to block this.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for this question. I am currently working on a report, which I hope will be adopted in plenary next month, that precisely identifies a division of this institution that can finally, after many years of discussion, particularly in other institutions, help us accept that migration and its challenges are something that have to be shared by all of the European Union and all of its 28 Member States. Any solution requires a proportional sharing of responsibility by everybody.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Madam President, as Mr Timmermans said, I think: we have a plan. To be fair to the Commission, they have had many plans, and many with integrity. When EUR 700 million was pumped into Greece recently, it proved that something can happen, something valuable can happen with the humanitarian instrument. But clearly it is not enough and we know that many of the Members who are engaged in this crisis, who are actually doing something in this crisis, know that the Commission has had plans for more than two years. The problem is the Council; the problem is the incoherent, often aggressive, reaction to established plans on a number of fields. So we now have two pillars to this solution: we have a set of plans from the Commission, dealing with what is most difficult from Dublin, from revising our agencies to do things that they were never expected to do so that we now have a Border Agency, we have a revamping of our Asylum Support Office – major revisions within months which we will all have to do our work on in this Chamber.  Then we have the plan on Turkey and in the few seconds that I have, I just want to caution that we do not breach international law when we deal with the Turkey plan, that we stick to our principles and international law in all that we do. But let us just remember that we do not have the luxury in this House of not doing our work in this Parliament where some of the major issues that the Commission will be dealing with were set out earlier, because we do not have the luxury to leave people to die or to leave people to be injured or to leave young unaccompanied children to go missing in the interior of Europe. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – You are criticising the European Council, but ten months ago it was our governments that proposed the only logical mechanism that could stop this drama and allow it to be resolved on point. I am talking about the fight against illegal people smuggling. Is this fight not a necessary mechanism to finally focus on helping those who can be helped, without resonate with this problem, which is really becoming increasingly unsolvable every day?

name: Claude MORAES
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for the question. The issue concerning the Council is not to blame the Council on generalities, and we should not deal in generalities. It is the extremes in the Council and that some countries can try and mop up the responsibilities of other countries, and that is not acceptable in a European Union that wants an organised and compassionate response. It is just unacceptable that some countries can try and do everything and some countries can sit and watch as other countries do something. The Commission has plans; those plans would have matured over two years, and we would now be in a position of activity. But we are not, because some Members of the Council have been aggressive and done nothing.  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Helga STEVENS
text: – In the past, European leaders and governments have not paid enough attention to European border policy. As a result, we have become dependent on Turkey. We can no longer control even our own borders alone. The European Union has become blackmailable. The Turks are, of course, taking full advantage of this now. The EU has been following the lax Merkel line for too long and is therefore in bad trouble today.  The structural solution is clear to the NVA: what is happening today is particularly painful for the European Union. This is not subject to repetition. We must do everything in our part to ensure that the EU can return its own beans completely and does not remain dependent on countries such as Turkey. So we have to close the routes to Western Europe, we have to focus fully on accommodating in our own region and introduce a strong push-back policy. We also need to introduce strict limits and therefore impose strict quotas on the influx.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: – Madam President, I would like to hear an honest debate. In the communication we are still discussing the implementation of the measures foreseen in the relocation decisions. It did not work. We cannot ask a country like Greece to build hotspots and make them operational if refugees are not redistributed. 536 persons out of the foreseen 66 400; this is next to nothing. I am convinced of two things. Firstly, we should stop trying to outsource EU problems and instead tackle the refugee crisis by delivering a genuine European approach. Secondly, we need concrete measures on how to establish solidarity and share responsibilities, starting now.  The Commission proposal to fully restore the functioning of Schengen has been endorsed by the heads of state and government, but my fear is that this is just a vague engagement and the deadline is too far off. We need a holistic approach, not only on paper. Schengen could be saved by defining common border management but also legal and safe ways of working. I am looking forward to a blue card proposal that will allow a concrete discussion on legal economic migration.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Schengen can and should only be restored by ensuring that EU countries share responsibility for accepting refugees. But instead of putting all the powder on shared responsibility for reception and putting together a sufficiently grand coalition to enforce this, the Commission is merely pursuing an agenda to stop people fleeing from reaching Europe. You are throwing out your hasty and bad proposals for a new super-Frontex. You accept bilateral action, you want to pursue unacceptable deals with the authoritarian regime in Turkey to detain refugees and you want to send NATO forces to the Aegean Sea. The UNHCR condemned your Turkey plan earlier in plenary. Colleagues, this is not a way forward, it is not the path of the future. The future path for Europe, in terms of dealing with the refugee situation, can only be based on our taking joint responsibility, but it seems that the Commission has given up. Is that it? If that is the case then we are doomed. Trapped in a Europe that no longer stands up for human rights and the right of asylum.

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Madam President, the Commissioners in their communication of 10 February 2016 outline what their interpretation is of a safe third country. As I read that communication it says that pretty much all the safeguards and provisions that we have managed to put into EU law can be interpreted in a way that basically covers everyone. I am not sure that that is very smart and sensible. Why did we put the safeguards in? In order to have them, in order to have very clear provisions.
