And we are passing all these laws right now in order to stick to them and not later on say that it was basically irrelevant what we put there. So my question to the Commission is this: do you actually really think that Turkey – a country that is sending the military against its own people, a country that is sending refugees back to Syria, where we even hear reports that people have been killed, Syrian refugees have been shot at by border guards or other Turkish police – do you think that this country can be qualified as a safe third country , as provided for under the EU Procedures Directive? That would be very interesting to hear.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Major shortcomings at our external borders," timmermans says. Yes, I can't help but agree. We're talking about a new coast guard here. I thought that Frontex, with its triple budget contribution, would guard our borders, our external borders above all. But with hindsight, we know that Frontex's biggest mission is search and rescue, so now I wonder what this new Coast Guard is going to do that is different from Frontex?  There is also talk of the need to redistribute refugees between The Member States. Yes, last year they even managed .m. to redistribute 400 pieces. There was talk of redistributing 160,000. What happens now this year? Should we multiply 160,000 times two and reallocate 320,000 or how do you think there? And when the quota is full, what do you do? Sweden has, of course.m. Avramopoulos, when is this going to happen?

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, EUR 700 million is the sum that the Commission wants to squander in what I call the 'Danaïdes' barrel of migrant reception policies. So, in view of this figure, let me have a special thought for the people of Calais and Grande-Synthe, who are suffering the direct consequences of this disastrous policy of migratory submersion, as well as for those families who can no longer live in safety, for the shopkeepers who are putting the key under the door and, above all, for those women who have been victims , as in Cologne, multiple sexual assaults by migrants with no respect for the laws of the host country. That is why, rather than financing and taking on the costs of the migration invasion, this money - our money - must be used to dismantle wild camps and finance the immediate expulsion of illegal migrants, but also to help Hungary, Bulgaria and Greece secure their borders and dry up the flow of migrants.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Madam President, the least that can be said is that the European migration agenda, presented 20 months ago, is ineffective and ineffective. It's a complete failure. How could it be otherwise when the bulk of this agenda is based, in fact, on the more or less good will of the government of a third country, in this case Turkey, with which the European Union has ambiguous and even schizophrenic relations. This government is playing a role in that. He understood the weakness of this Europe, stuck in its dogmas of eradicating internal borders and its desire to welcome hundreds of thousands of immigrants, despite the hostility of the European peoples. This paves the way for increasingly demanding haggling. You have just handed over a nuclear weapon in Mr Erdogan's hands by entrusting him with the custody of an external border of the Union, and thus the ability to open or close the taps of mass immigration. The "one-for-one" system supported by Mrs Merkel, which consists of promising to accept a legal refugee in Europe for any illegal immigrant intercepted or readmitted to Turkey, is not only sordid, but doomed to fail. On the one hand, the problem of the final destination of these legal refugees is not solved, with the majority of Member States refusing to participate in your resettlement quota system. In addition, I guarantee that candidates for illegal immigration and especially traffickers have already imagined how to take advantage of it. Albert Einstein said that you don't change a system with the same ideas that created it. I think he was right. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Dear Colleague, do you not consider this agreement to be an inadmissible collaboration in favour of Turkey and that, in fact, European bureaucrats in Brussels agree to pay a racketeering, a ransom to Mr Erdogan, and that, in fact, the European Union recognises that it cannot protect its borders on its own and gives Turkey that weapon in its hands? Indeed, this is an expression of enormous hypocrisy, since Turkey is clearly not a European country and has no place in the European Union.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, my dear colleague, I share your sentiment in this regard. I believe that this is an unacceptable haggling that will reinforce already considerable migratory flows, in particular, with the abolition of visas in particular, migration flows coming from Turkey itself. There are many candidates in Cappadocia for economic immigration to the European Union.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has said. I would like to thank the Commission for keeping its nerve in its proposals last week, but also in recent months, in an exceptional situation, in a pressure that no one was prepared for, an event of the century, this migration of peoples, and for ensuring that Europe's internal freedom of movement – freedom of movement, the abolition of border controls in Europe – is maintained and Schengen is saved. , that it has a clear roadmap for this, which must be maintained, which also ensures that a source of our prosperity and our social security systems – the internal market – emerges from this crisis undamaged. I also believe that it is important to restore internal order and to reconcile the objectives of the fulfilment of the Geneva Convention and internal order within Europe, which is currently not succeeding, and that these two objectives are reconnected. That is why it is right that a demand that we have made from Parliament for a long time should now be implemented, namely a European border control and coastguard, so that we can do justice to our possibilities here. We must see, for example, that in more than fifteen or twenty years Schengen and Dublin, we Germans have made a slender foot and said that Malta, Italy and Greece are doing this, and that we have been able to abolish our border management. We must also support this with our money, with our staff, that common border controls, that is, as a European body, be carried out in order to make progress in this way. And we must realise that this is also in the sense of a proper procedure for the refugees, and this must also be done with Turkey. It is also important that, at the same time, we also have the aid for these refugees and for these countries, so that people have reasonable living conditions where they are. Bringing all this into a single concept is, I believe, also the good way forward for the European Council last Monday.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The current crisis has also arisen because our instruments have not worked at European level, because we did not have a European migration policy and because Dublin never worked. It is positive that there is now a comprehensive package of legislative measures to discuss. I am convinced that the European Parliament will support the Commission in discussing these matters constructively and critically and also swiftly. But it will take time, and the problem is that we have to act now.  I was in Idomeni a week ago today. I can't get these pictures out of my head. It was horrible what I saw. People are desperate, many have no roof over their heads, especially women and children suffer.  This week, the situation has worsened: heavy rains have added to the site. Today, once again, I received a cry for help from Idomeni: there are now 15 000 people, the situation is chaotic, it can explode at any time. Commissioner Avramopoulos, I pointed out to you back in September that I wrote you letters – and far too little has happened in this respect. If the local population did not exist, the situation would have exploded long ago. Now we finally have a Council regulation with which we have a legal framework.  I urge you to act because we cannot waste time. Action is needed, as the Portuguese Government has done, which wants to double its quota. Since yesterday, refugees from Greece have been brought to Portugal. That is the right answer to this difficult crisis.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: blue-card question. – Actually it was a blue card for Mr Brok, before he leaves. On Sunday, while Mrs Merkel was appeasing Mr Erdoğan, did she protest about the closure and raid on the Zaman newspaper? Was she respecting human rights? Did she raise the human rights of those journalists that were abused the other day?

name: Elmar BROK
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – (The speaker speaks without a microphone) ... She has done so in the talks with Mr Davutoglu, and she has discussed these events countless times with Mr Erdogan. Mrs Merkel has always been attacked for taking turkey to court too harshly for denouncing human rights violations, violations of freedom of religion and expression. I believe that Mrs Merkel is a champion on this issue of criticism of Turkey, and she has made it clear that it would now be good to open the chapters – I believe it are the numbers – 22, 23, so that we can discuss with Turkey on freedom of the media, freedom of expression and freedom of religion – conditions for membership, which Turkey is far from fulfilling and through the measures that has gripped them is further away than ever. And that is also Mrs Merkel's position.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: – Madam President, the European Union has not been very successful in dealing with the migration catastrophe. The failed relocation mechanism is just one example of the Union trying to impose something that neither the Member States nor the migrants are interested in. The most urgent thing is to stop asylum shopping. People come to Greece and Italy because from there they have been able to travel unhindered to a handful of northern European welfare states. That flow has now slowed down a bit, not because of what the EU is doing, but thanks to the Member States that have re-established internal border controls. The Schengen system should be suspended until the situation is under control, otherwise we risk losing it piece by piece. The asylum rules should be adjusted in such a way that it is not possible to apply for asylum in one Member State if you arrive from another.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: Madam President, you are a little bit like Sisyphus. Indeed, the Commission has taken stock of the scale of the crisis and, after three packages of actions, after evaluations, after successive summits, the implementation today remains very stifling, even despairing, since the States, every night, undo what you have set up in the morning. We have been calling here in Parliament for four years for the protection of external borders to preserve Schengen, legal routes of migration and solidarity between states. The more time passes, the more states seem unable to take responsibility, apart from Germany and Greece. They are slipping away, they are getting bogged down in a double death paralysis on two fronts: first, because thousands of people die every day and millions of families are demolished by wars and, secondly, because we are witnessing, in a way, the dangling arms, the sinking of the values that presided over the construction of Europe. Then from Sisyphus, gentlemen, turn into Prometheus and put the States at the foot of the wall.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Madam President, yesterday's summit showed once again that there are certain Member States in the European Union that do not want to participate in common responsibilities and do not show solidarity with Member States facing a major pan-European problem such as refugee-migration. We must realise that unilateral actions and selfish national policies not only do not work, but in the long run will have disastrous results for everyone.  I note, however, with satisfaction the summit's commitment to return to Turkey those who arbitrarily enter Greek territory and to distribute an equal number of Syrian refugees to all Member States. I also welcome the promise of immediate financial and organisational assistance to Greece in order to meet the needs of stranded refugees, as well as to implement their relocation programme from Greece to the other Member States. But words must be made work immediately.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I am very concerned about the future of the EUROPEAN Union and the Schengen system. I fear that it will collapse completely, because one country after another adopts so-called own border controls or temporary border controls. Among other things, my own country, Sweden, has done so. I see it as my task to work towards making these border controls as short as possible, but there will be no change unless all Member States take responsibility. As long as not all Member States do so, different countries will introduce temporary controls, and I find that extremely tragic. Another issue that is also on the agenda is to send back those who do not have protection grounds. I have nothing against it in itself, but it is also the case that there are a number, hundreds or perhaps thousands, of people who have been living in Europe for years and who have been rejected, but it has been impossible to send them back. Now there is an extra intensive hunt to really get these people back to Gaza, to Afghanistan and to many other countries that are extremely problematic. I would like to know what the Commissioners think about it.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: "Ladies and ladies and cede," he said. Each of us is sometimes a patient, and some are doctors, and we know exactly that for the sake of health, we need to fight the causes of the disease, not the effects. And we here for many, many months have been trying to combat the effects, and we close our eyes to the causes of the disease. By continuing in this way, we will lead to the inevitable collapse of the European Union, to the dismantling of this project at all. If we care about the Schengen project and the European Union project, then we need to define what is Europe and what Europe is no longer, and close the borders. And begin to defend ourself against the influx, against this huge infection that we are just infected with, and not to nurture the disease. The disease is not to care for it in our body, because this disease will destroy us. Let's take care of health. Turkey can still use us and a heap of billions of us to implement some of its own policies, and we cannot protect ourself and close our external borders. We just need more radicalism.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Madam President, Commissioner, thank you first of all for this review of the implementation of the European migration agenda. I welcome the mobilization of President Juncker's team since the beginning of his mandate. Nevertheless, we know that much remains to be done, inside and out. I would like to start with two questions. First, on setting up hotspots. We know that the eleven hotspots are not operational. What are the main obstacles to moving faster? If the blockages are political, should we give even more time for national decisions to be taken? To postpone to tomorrow what we need to do today is to make what is important today an emergency tomorrow. Secondly, in May 2015, the Commission announced the establishment of a pilot centre in Niger. Since then, we have very little news about the establishment of the centre, which is nevertheless a concrete element of the external dimension of our migration policy. We need to use this project as a way to work with third countries, especially in Africa. I also have two points on the external dimension of our migration policy. I look at it because I think that if we do more on the causes outside, we will not have to deal with the consequences inside. First, readmission agreements: what timetable, which country? Secondly, Lebanon and Jordan: we must continue to support these two countries, which are key elements for the sustainable management of the migration issue. Today, more than ever, it is necessary for financial promises to be turned into concrete projects, and we must listen to them.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Madam President, we appreciate the Commission’s efforts, but the Greek solution and the Turkish solution will show their limits quite soon. So we really need stronger European solutions to regain control of the situation: in order to safeguard Schengen, to respond to refugees according to European values. We also need a real European border, not a kind of wired wall, but rather a new concept of a border system which should be advanced infrastructure, with the proper information and logistic capacity and providing useful services. A border control, managing the refugee flow and also assisting the refugees with human standards. We believe this should be organised, promoted and financed as a strategic public investment, which should be there to prepare Europe for the 21st century and to reorganise its relationship with the neighbourhood in more positive terms.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for I would like to raise a key point in the European agenda on migration so far: the relocation mechanism. Millions of people are coming to Europe: German Development Minister Müller said earlier this year that eight to ten million people are from the Middle East and are already on their way. And many more millions come from the African continent. That is the real problem. And the EU has been talking for months about the distribution of 160,000 people from Italy and Greece. 873 of them have already been distributed, and since yesterday it has been said that this distribution is now to be significantly accelerated. Maybe you can do it in just 15 years. But what does the redistribution of 160 000 people who are there solve with regard to the problem of ten, twenty or even more millions of people coming to us? What does one have to do with the other in the first place? We cannot help all of these people with us; we must help on the ground, and immediately.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: – Madam President, the European Union's migration policies have evolved as was the case with our economy or, rather, the economy of some, and always outside of human rights. They began by separating migrants into two groups: legal and illegal. The illegals were fenced, locked in the IDS, taken away from their health, expelled, even the law was broken with the hot returns. Then, with the wars, in Iraq, Syria or Afghanistan, they have used refugees in a disgusting way to separate refugees from migrants. They named them "economic." Simply put, refugees could have some right, but migrants could have none. All outside the European Union. Now not even that: refugees are also being gassed on the borders or evicted from the Calais camp, without any respect for their dignity. But the truth is that everyone, all refugees, migrants, are victims of their cruel and criminal policies.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, Commissioner, your starting criterion seems to be to reduce, contain, avoid. Next, deny, return, repatriate. The third, to agree with the devil, to accept all the impositions, to pay the price that suits so as not to face the issue directly. That's what we did yesterday with the European Union-Turkey agreement. We are still acting within the framework established by the Dublin Commission, but the European oasis and the individualised treatment of asylum applications have gone down in history. And we continue to tell Greece, the same Greece to which we have pushed to the brink of the economic and social abyss, that it does not fulfil its obligations, that it must act as a general container or as an immense prison, to prevent other European countries from having to assume their responsibilities. We close the door of the Balkans and are unable to prevent the 'save yourself who can' of almost all Member States. Meanwhile, men, women and children live in Idomeni or die near Lesbos. We're denying ourselves. We are returning Europe to the hell of national interests. Have we forgotten our own history? The answer is not to punish Greece, the answer is to change its judgment.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Madam President, the EU is not very good at haggling at the Turkish bazaar. They seemingly agreed to EUR 6 billion, but Turkey asked for EUR 20 billion. What is the top limit you are prepared to do with taxpayers’ money? Then Mr Tusk got on the plane, after agreeing a roadmap, minutes later the newspaper Zaman was shut down and the riot police moved in. On Sunday, Mrs Merkel was trying to appease. The same weekend saw the Alternative für Deutschland see election success.  Elections are an indication of how the people feel. She is not listening to her people. Have you asked the European peoples whether they are prepared to accept visa liberalisation for 75 million Turks? I thought not. Has David Cameron asked the British people whether they accept an extra GBP 500 million bill on top of the 12 billion we already pay in foreign aid, and an extra billion to the EU in the coming year? I thought not too. So what have you gained from haggling at the Turkish bizarre? Cheap tat at price you should not have paid. We all know that feeling of being taken for a fool, and that is why the British will Brexit.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Madam President, I emphasize the importance of figures, arrivals. We are facing a huge humanitarian crisis and a management crisis as well. Unilateral measures, quotas and border closures must be put to an end in the Union. I want Open Balkans, like Filippo Grandi. Only together and in solidarity can we cope with this difficult situation. We need to restore and protect Schengen with more control over external borders. I support the Commission's urgent measures and the humanitarian aid mechanism, also urgent, for Greece and the urgency in sending the committed quantities, in combination with those from the other two Funds. Turkey, compromised issue. But Turkey, yes, now and for what? To improve the humanitarian conditions of refugees on their territory and also in Syria. And Turkey also to slow flows that do not require international protection. We don't have too many alternatives. We have to meet internal and external commitments: relocation, resettlement, hotspots and Funds, comply with the Funds. And the key to the international arc: complying with Resolution 2268 on cessation of hostilities; Geneva talks and the work of the two working groups, mainly humanitarian groups, where we are very important and very credible.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: – Dear Commissioners, we will continue to support you in the future in resolving the crisis, but I admit that the previous debate on Syria and now does not give me much hope. The successful policy of the European Union is a construction on two main pillars – the leadership role in resolving conflicts and managing the refugee crisis. Lately, our policy has focused only on the second pillar.  Do we have a holistic migration policy today? The answer is no. Moreover, the commission's latest proposals regionalise the problem of tackling refugee flows. Now in your proposals on the agenda is Greece, and then? The new emergency. At the same time, double standards are manifested. All your proposals are for the protection of Schengen. Today, Schengen is the magic word, and what about the other countries on the external border? Their fate is a buffer zone and a huge refugee camp. I assure you, europe will not become more secure from this.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. This is the return of realism – not selfishness, but realism. Last year we were bidding, there was talk of an open-door policy, we were ready to accept everyone. It was an iliability error. I fully support this turn towards realism. The European Union's external borders must be protected, help must be helped, but at the same time a responsible policy must be required of Greece. Finally, it is necessary to ensure that the agreement with Turkey is actually done. Finally, it is necessary to help humanely, above all, refugees, Christians and followers of other religions who suffer from war in the Middle East. Let us not return to the relocation mechanism as an arbitrary mechanism. It is risky and, in my opinion, also incompatible with the rules of international law, because people cannot be placed contrary to their will where they do not want to ride. Realism is not selfishness. Only a secure Europe will be able to help others.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Madam President, anyone who wants to understand the slump of a united Europe and its leaders only has to read the conclusions of yesterday's summit. The United Europe of principles and values in its tough negotiations with Turkey, the state that violates European borders, holds european territory with an army, violates fundamental rights and freedoms, bombs Kurdish citizens inside and outside its borders, and its president blackmails thousands of refugees with despair, has succeeded in visa waiver, opening accession funds, disbursement of three billion and additional funding and... the top, which is shameful even to be written: the exchange one to one refugee! At the same time, it has already succeeded in closing borders as they see fit, turning Greece into a camp for the unhappy and cashing in the unsolyment of its peace with per capita amounts for each refugee, in practice abolishing asylum and violating international treaties. And they are proud of the German, Austrian and Greek leadership. Unfortunately, ladies and gentlemen, developments will be rapid and tragic.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: – The European Commission has repeatedly stated that immigration has been placed at the heart of its priorities, but it has focused in particular on the principle of solidarity laid down in Article 80 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the Union, offering truly concrete proposals only in this regard. It is imperative that the Commission's attention be focused on establishing a migration policy, on developing a robust common policy, on revising the Dublin Regulation and the 'Blue Card'. These must be the priorities of the utmost importance. They are listed at every meeting of European leaders, but they continue to exist only at utopian level. We have to act! Too little has been done in this regard, and the effects of this delay have all been felt strongly, but paradoxically, this lethargy, the lack of an overall vision, together with a concrete lack of action, continues to be a pressing reality for the whole of Europe.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – (The microphone did not work properly in the first part of the speech.) ... You could say she bought what she needed. Firstly, the assurance that the migrant wave that has splashed along the so-called Balkan route forward is finally being entregadded and, secondly, that a 100-pronged Regime of The Shennese regime is being restored soon. The price for this deal is high, especially if Turkey will not be a credible partner. If the next regular summit also delivers an agreement on the member states' concrete commitments, things will gradually normalise. In the meantime, some European countries will continue to face the exceptional situation caused by illegal migrants. Yesterday we not only provided Turkey with a great deal of extra money and other assistance, but we opened the door to it helplessly in its integration into the European Union, even though this has nothing to do with the migrant crisis. Turkish politics has felt the plight of the European Union and blackmailed it. He is exploiting the refugee crisis to improve his negotiating position. It's not credible, and that's not how the partner behaves. This burdens this agreement and its credibility and sincerity and calls into question our future cooperation between the European Union and Turkey. When a reporter asked me today: 'What about the human rights and freedoms of refugees, you are not interested in this story?', I replied that I and that they can only protect themselves in orderly environments that are only being established now, after yesterday's summit.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are playing into the future of the European Union on this migration crisis. On our ability to respond we will be judged by future generations. Instead, we continue to talk and make summits without ever arriving at a genuine common European solution. In 2015, again, 6 out of 28 Member States dealt with 80% of asylum applications arriving in Europe on their own. If everyone did their part, these numbers would be manageable. Greece cannot and must not be left alone, as can Italy and the other countries that are making the greatest efforts.  Outsourcing borders is not a solution and our governments would not be blackmailed by Turkey if they had already found common solutions, based on solidarity and a holistic approach. Today, however, we are talking about the implementation of the European agenda on immigration: well, how is it possible that the relocations were only a few hundred, compared to the 160 000 promised? This is an unacceptable delay! A few weeks ago I was in Lampedusa, where people are stuck on the island even weeks, without even shoes on their feet. They are there to pay for the inability of European governments to implement the decisions of the Council, in which they themselves sit.  Until a clear perspective is given on the future of these people, the whole hot spot system will not work, because they are afraid of getting caught up in the hypocrisy of Dublin. We need an ambitious and courageous reform of Dublin, with a permanent redistribution mechanism and a strengthening of the ASO: we expect this from the Commission and that is the only way we are prepared to work, not cosmetic touch-ups!

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Madam President, the European Union has failed to manage the refugee crisis and continues to take wrong decisions that violate European and international law and the human rights of refugees. How many more refugees must die helplessly in order to stop the xenophobic racist approaches of some European leaders such as the Visegrad countries, who close borders, build fences and thus lock refugees in inhumane conditions in Greece. The Council has made it possible for the Council to discuss Turkey's unacceptable claims and blackmail, in order to avoid the Member States' responsibilities, even though the European Union has responsibility for the wars that have destroyed the refugee countries. The closure of the Balkan corridor, NATO in the Aegean, which tramples on the sovereign rights of states, and the repressive measures of FRODEX are killing solidarity and the values of the Union.  Stop the barbarity! Legal and safe roads and a binding legal system for the relocation of refugees must be created immediately. The refugee crisis must be addressed by strengthening the solidarity shown by the Greek people. (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on hearing today's debate, I want to tell you about my experience as mayor of an Italian city. Refugees or illegal immigrants have arrived, as you want to call them, even from me and there is not one fleeing the war. They come from countries where there is no war. That's to say there are so many situations.  However, I wanted to make a proposal, because there are two very important people who decide the fate of Europe. Every country in Europe has fought, with its fathers, its grandparents and great-grandparents, for its freedom. Here we see so many people, especially many men, fleeing the so-called war and coming to Europe.  So in the face of helping women and children – we would miss something else because it really seems right to me – why do we not quickly train these men and take them back to their countries of origin, so that they can fight for their land and really help get things back in their place? That is: let us train them and send them back to their country to fight for their territory and their freedom.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Madam President, the obvious was sought at yesterday's summit for 15 hours, and final decisions were postponed until the 18th. But if some 2,500 refugees and migrants continue to come to the Greek islands every day for 10 days, how will this already huge European problem – I stress – with an additional 25,000, 30,000 people?  The European Union has an obligation and a duty to take serious decisions for Member States that do not implement its decisions to relocate refugees to their territories, to implement, in cooperation with Turkey, to resettle refugees from Turkish territory directly proportionally in the countries of the European Union, to harden its attitude towards countries that arbitrarily close their borders and to force Turkey to accept irregular migrants hosted in Greece , finally following its signatures, past and recent, on readmission.  If, ladies and gentlemen, the solidarity of the countries of the European Union is finally called off once and for all, and if Turkey, as a strategic partner, continues to make new demands, exploiting thousands of desperate people, the Europe of values and humanism will have finally failed.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: "While we are debating here, who knows how many times, the children of refugees on the Macedonian border are playing in the sewage. I say this to you because today, on International Women's Day, we do not have to talk about limited politicians who allow themselves to be taken prisoner by populist and far-right politics and think that if they close the borders, they have also solved the problem. No, today we need to talk about the women, women and children who are stuck behind closed borders, who cannot go back or go any further. Today we must think of the mothers who made perhaps the most difficult decision of their lives when they decided to leave their homes in an attempt to save their children and their own lives. Mothers, who often carry their young children for thousands of kilometres, take care of them and keep them alive. And they hope that sooner or later they will find a country where they can be raised in good, human conditions. What is happening today on Europe's closed borders is a disgrace and a disgrace! Trampling on what was once called European humanism. We must not protect Europe from refugees, but from politicians who, above all else, have their own political careers, their own power, and are therefore willing to join forces with everything and everyone. We in the European Parliament must finally say that a country that does not participate in the common European immigration and asylum policy cannot be a member of the European Union.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, with what you have told us and with yesterday's conclusions of the summit you are proving that the refugee policy of the leadership of the European Union is a bargain with Turkey. Turkey is exploiting the refugee crisis to upgrade its role, violates international law, challenges national sovereign rights. From what was decided yesterday I isolate the agreement "one we send you, one you take", as if we are exchanging goods, which is the most vulgar and the most perverse that the human mind has thought of.  Otherwise, Mr Vice-President, you are currently haggling with Greece over the relaxation of the debate on commitments or even debt relief, in order for the country to become a vast hot spot. You destroyed the country with three memoranda and now you are trying to end it with the refugee crisis. Okay, there's going to be humanitarian aid. These agreements are a crime against refugees, especially those who are currently in Greece, and against the country. Unfortunately, these agreements are also signed by the current Tsipras government.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Officers, I'm sorry. Dear Colleagues, The fact that, for six months now, the Union has been unable to control the situation beyond words and in deeds at its external borders has destabilised the whole of Europe. But it destabilizes the Western Balkans with serious consequences. It is therefore necessary to put an end to the possibility of migrating along the Balkan route without revulsion, and there is time for any measures to restore order at the borders. Everyone here is talking about the growing refugee crisis, although we are well known that a fraction of the arrivals, although the number of arrivals is increasing, but a fraction, are indeed entitled to refugee status. Solidarity and concrete assistance can take many forms in their case. But the majority did not flee under international law. The larger, illegal immigrant population starts, fights and gets trapped by people smugglers in the hope of a better life, risking their own lives and that of their children – while no Member State can be obliged to accept them. It is therefore common sense for our citizens for the Union to prove that it can control the conditions prevailing at its borders and protect its external borders. Therefore, all clear messages and actions are desperately needed, and there is no time to waste.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, on the refugee crisis, many proposals have already been put forward, some of which have already been adopted by Parliament and the Council. Others are being prepared and I trust that you will be responsible for carrying out a system of amending the Dublin Regulation, which overcomes the unsustainable link between the asylum seeker and the country of first arrival. A genuine response to migration can only be based on the principle of solidarity, respect for human rights and the principles enshrined in international law.  However, the humanitarian response is only part of that strategy, based on a global approach that Parliament has been pressing for for so many months. Without a forward-looking vision on the part of Europe, we will be the victims of an unprecedented political failure.  I will end with the words of the High Commissioner for Refugees this morning: 'it is time to reaffirm the values on which Europe was built'.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. To begin with, I would like to note the call made by The President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, a few days ago to economic migrants: not come to Europe. This appeal is a breakthrough in the European Union's policy in the face of a growing migratory wave that is likely to exceed two million this year. The last two years have shown that there is no way to continue the policy of saving the world by resettling it in Europe. We cannot bear such a policy either financially or socially. The solution to the immigration crisis lies in foreign policy, in efforts to stabilise the situation in Africa and the Middle East – so that refugees have nowhere to go – and in the financial support of non-European countries that accept and rescue refugees from war-torn countries. Yesterday's summit with Turkey raises the hope that this shift from domestic policy to foreign policy will continue. At the same time, they draw a picture of the real costs we will incurred in stemming the flow of illegal immigrants. The cost is not only economic, because visa-free travel with Turkey, it is a very high price for dealing with only part of the problem. After all, Europe will continue to accept refugees, albeit legally and in a controlled manner. And this regaining of control is extremely important. Very important from a security perspective, but also important from the point of view of the effectiveness of helping refugees, because in order to help effectively, we must have real, reliable data. We have to plan everything, organize everything. This control is also needed in order to make a list of tasks and to count the costs and to identify the possibilities of the European Union, so that this lifeboat, which is the European Union, does not become too heavy.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: Madam President, in this Parliament we have always sought legal and safe ways of influxing refugees into Europe. At the moment, in yesterday's communication we see a nugget from this road, which is the mechanism of resettlement from Turkey directly to Europe. If this is combined with the relocation of those refugees who are in Greece to European countries and the absolute return of those who are economic migrants to Turkey and from there to their countries, we can say that we are seeing a solution to the problem.  But what is the cost we pay for it? Unfortunately, the cost is the discount we make on our values, the discount on our principles, especially those relating to human rights. That is the price we pay, because we are not moving towards European unification, we are not moving towards political unification, next to economic integration. This is the cost that the Commission, which Mr President told us, is paying us. Juncker that it is a last-chance Commission. We ask the Commissions to do their duty.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is certainly not responsible for the migration tragedy we are experiencing in Europe, but by its incoherent policy and the messages it has sent, it has contributed greatly to illegal immigration on its territory. It is clear that by extending the quota policy, we have encouraged migrants to come to our territory. The reality is that in France, the government has chosen to empty this incredible and indecent Calais jungle to distribute migrants in the villages of France, in respite centres. In the Schengen area, there are no borders, nor are these respite centres prisons. Nearly 25% of the migrants who were distributed in these villages left without leaving an address. In Germany, too, nearly 160,000 people are not geographically identifiable. Many of these people have come to our country, to our territory and to the European Union to have a destiny. Well, we lied to them! This is the reality and the inconsistency of European Union policy today. We must establish a policy of firmness and make this known by also putting in place a return policy that we do not have, because today the migration policy is totally misguided. I think we really have to take that into account in this Chamber.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, before the beginning of winter, most of us thought that the migration wave would allow due to the weather, and perhaps naïvely thought that it would gradually cease. However, this has not happened and Europe is facing an even greater disaster than it did a year ago. It's time to realize we have more problems than we thought.  As I could see for myself, Greece is not coping with the influx of refugees, and the situation, especially on the Macedonian-Greek border, has long been completely unbearable. If there is no rapid change, Greece will not be able to protect our common Schengen area in the future. No program would help.  So let's talk about concrete measures and how we will work. Cooperation with the Balkan states, the partnership with Turkey, the establishment of a common European border and coast guard are just some instruments that cannot, in their essence, save us.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for the umpteenth time we are in this House, debating the issue of immigration and discussing the various emergencies that arise before us. I hope, however, that once and for all these rivers of words that are regularly spent will be matched by concrete action. The most important of which is certainly the modification of Dublin III, which is the real anomaly of the European reception system. Only in this way can Greece, italy, tomorrow Malta or Spain be helped in practice today.  The European Commission undertook to submit an amendment to Dublin III by 31 March this year. I hope that this deadline will actually be met and, above all, I hope that the nation states in the Council will subsequently be effective, unlike what has happened in the recent past.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, the closed border and quota policy just dumps the problem on other Member States. There are no unilateral solutions and Member States have to work together. We have to move from uncontrolled influx to orderly reception and better control at the EU external border, to register people in a human way, and restore Schengen. Work for harmonising databases between Turkey and the EU is crucial, and I support the EU-Turkey action plan and the new monitoring facility for Greece. Funds for refugees in Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan have to be disbursed fast, including to the UN and NGOs. I do support NATO cooperation to combat traffickers in the Mediterranean. Resettlement is the safe highway to Europe. All Member States should increase their quotas and speed up procedures with the UNHCR. Relocation, repatriation and the revision of Dublin also must be accelerated. Stigmatising refugees is part of the problem, putting people against people. It is time for EU leaders to change the narrative. Refugees are neither a burden nor a danger. They are human beings, women and children in search and need of protection.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: – Madam President, Respected Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Timmermans, I would like to thank you for reviewing the implementation of the European Migration Agenda, during which around 800 000 people have entered the EU in the last practically ten months, of which 120 000 have entered the EU this year. Our key task is to try an uncontrolled, illegal influx of people fleeing the threat of their own lives to organize this reception in a solidarity, humane and real way.  That is why I welcome your initiative to revise the Dublin Regulation, to protect the Schengen acquis and to make the most of the dialogue with Turkey as it was yesterday to prevent smugglers from illegally transporting people across the Aegean Sea and leading to tragedies, while helping Greece and in particular this disastrous situation on the Macedonian-Greek border that later has consequences along the entire so-called Eastern Mediterranean and Balkan routes.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, I am very concerned about the situation in Schengen. Yesterday's policy with Turkey is important and important, but it is unrealistic to think that Turkey will solve Europe's refugee crisis. We ourselves need to get Europe's external borders in order now. Member States shall take the decisions already taken in the past on the establishment of hotspots, the identification, registration and more even distribution of migrants to different Member States.  Dozens of decisions and recommendations have been taken, but implementation at member state level is seriously dwindly. It has caused member states to be unable to trust each other and to launch temporary border controls within the Schengen area. As many as eight countries have resorted to these. It is clear that the measures proposed by the Commission last Friday in its own programme must be taken to ensure the Schengen area and the free movement of people in Europe in the future. It is important to us, both politically and economically, but it can only happen if the external borders hold.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, my country is showing that ‘European solidarity’ are not empty words, but the way to face this, the worst refugee crisis since World War II. It is an existential crisis for the EU as the UN High Commissioner for Refugees put it, here today. Portugal received this week 64 refugees by chartered plane from Greece, assisting EASO to relocate human beings undergoing inhuman treatment at the closed borders of FYROM, after Austria and other neighbours ganged up to violate the Schengen system, international law, EU Council decisions and sheer decency. More refugees are expected later this week, thanks to the proactive response of the government of Portugal.  But, what about other EU governments? Why are the European Commission and the European Council so prone to punishing Portugal and Greece for failing to meet deficit decimals and not acting against Hungary, Austria and other Members who gang up to bomb European solidarity and torture women and children who asked for protection in Europe? Could it be for the same reason that the European Council allowed itself to be blackmailed yesterday by President Erdoğan’s Turkey?

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Dear Commissioners, the European Union is in a critical situation and a large number of Member States continue to abdicate from the obligation of shared responsibility. We've been saying for a few months that we need to respond urgently. Unfortunately, we do not start applying the agreements thus made and as a result the division is getting bigger. The Commission's decision to set aside 700 million euro for the in order to meet europe's growing humanitarian needs during this refugee crisis, it will be key for Greece, and especially for the countries of the western Balkans. The implementation of an action plan with Turkey will also play its part.  It is necessary to establish without delay a European Border and Coast Guard, of which Bulgaria and Romania must be an integral part. Otherwise, they will become the Buffer Zone of the European Union. In addition to our efforts to restore peace in the Middle East, we must also move towards the immediate replacement of the Dublin Regulation and successfully implement a new, single European asylum procedure.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, the statements by the President of the Council last week in Greece, the conclusions of yesterday's summit and even his statements here today on the European Agenda on Migration are very revealing of the inhuman and criminal nature of the European Union's policies in this area. Those who promoted destabilisation, chaos and underdevelopment in the places of origin of the migration flow now tell the victims: "Forget it, do not come to Europe, if you do, you will be expelled, without appeal or harm".  This agenda violates international conventions, violates the right to international asylum protection and emphasises the repressive and selective nature of the European Union's immigration policy, now even supported by the NATO war machine. To persecute, criminalise and expel those who are looking for a better life in Europe, unless, in the case of a skilled workforce, they can take advantage of the great European capital.  This is also, and perhaps first of all, a sign of the profound crisis in which the European Union is plunged – a crisis that reveals its true face, lying down false principles and proclamations.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Commissioner, you have listed some measures to implement the plan for... in this case and as the last listed as a relocation measure... agreement on the relocation of refugees. I believe that this should be the first agreement between Member States as a precondition against all other measures, including before the closure or restriction of entry into the border. Instead of our agreement and therefore solidarity between Member States, we have found a subcontractor, that is Turkey. Which, of course, we are willing to pay a lot, in the end, six billion, and, moreover, of course, a huge amount of indulgence in terms of human rights violations, freedom of the media and the rest. And in fact, we know from history that Turkey is a trader with a lot of trade talent. Therefore, of course, this cannot be a long-term solution. And the answer to how we solve these issues must be found between ourselves and within the Member States.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – This is the second debate on immigration today – in the morning we listened to Commissioner Filippo Grandi, Commissioner of the United Nations. But neither Commissioner Grandi nor Vice-President Timmermans today said the most important thing – a fact that we should not hide from our societies – is that the growth rate of illegal immigration into Europe is 1000%. At the beginning of this year, there were ten times as many illegal immigrants as in the same period last year. In fact, these people are being put at risk because we are constantly hearing some declarations in this House about the opening up of legal immigration routes. They are under the illusion that before we solve the problems of those people we can help today, we are actually able to encourage everyone to come to Europe. This is completely irresponsible to these people. And it is important that those who make such declarations become aware of their consequences.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, I would like to ask Mr. Timmermans: Do you really think that the European Union wants to solve the refugee problem? You said earlier and accused Greece of not being able to protect its borders. Please ask Mr Avramopoulos, who sits next to you and was previously the country's defence minister, to tell you whether the Greek armed forces did not really have this capability or whether the Greek Government never entrusted them with this task, obeying outside orders, just to get to this unacceptable point.  You are talking about the coast guard and the border guard, at a time when Turkey does not accept to receive those illegally and illegally sent to Greece. Why do you insist that Greece implement the failed Dublin Treaty in order to turn this beautiful country and its impoverished people into a vast and unacceptable and wretched camp of gathering unhappy souls? And finally, why is this obsession with Turkey, which is constantly blackmailing us, threatening and demanding more and more benefits? In my opinion, commissioning Turkey to protect Europe's borders is like putting a rapist to sleep with a to help him get rid of his problem. If from a medical point of view this experiment can succeed I do not know; from a political point of view it certainly does not.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for today's presentation of the new legislative proposals, for which I assure you right now of his commitment to tackling the migration crisis.  We must make a clear distinction between refugees, who deserve international protection and economic migrants, which we can no longer accommodate. President Tusk also called last week for economic migrants to no longer make the journey, because they will not be able to be accommodated or even welcomed.  We must continue diplomatic work to resolve the various crises, especially the Syrian and Libyan crises. We must not underestimate the information from our intelligence services that there may be terrorists among migrants using the Balkan and Mediterranean routes.  We must therefore make the most of the specialised agencies at our disposal, first and then Europol and Eurojust, by pushing for a genuine exchange of information with and between the Member States in order to stem this phenomenon.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I express the desolation of millions of Europeans in the face of decisions which are at odds with other decisions previously taken, all in the short term, lacking vision and strategy, but above all unfulfilled. And I express desolation in the face of the clamorous absence of political will and, moreover, solidarity, because neither the problem is quotas, nor is the solution is to sub-order or outsource to Turkey the management of refugees and migrants, so that it may take them out of our sight, let alone offer promises of impossible fulfilment in a time of fatigue of enlargement. That is why, Commissioner, you make it clear to the Council that it is grotesque that Turkey should be promised what the Member States neither want nor can give, and that human rights problems are not solved without the Commission's utmost demand on the Member States on human rights.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, in general I would say that we all agree in this room, with only some exceptions, as far as the basic lines we follow in order to address this unprecedented situation. Yesterday’s summit was a necessary step, although not yet conclusive since next week’s summit is even more important. Everybody has now had their responsibilities put before them and everybody will be held accountable. What should prevail, as is our common understanding in this room, is tangible solidarity on all aspects of the issues discussed by the leaders yesterday. Solidarity is the basis, the main pillar of the Commission’s proposals.  The refugee crisis is a catalyst for the destiny of the European Union and I remind you here of the myth of Sisyphus, which you all know. Now put Europe in the place of Sisyphus. Yes, Europe is carrying a heavy rock on its shoulders, but it is absolutely necessary that all Member States help the EU to carry the rock to the top of the hill, and do not allow the myth to be confirmed and see the rock rolling down again. It is our duty not to let Europe backtrack. The tendency easily to adopt a populist and simplistic rhetoric is seen in the election results in various Member States. In this way, only extremism, nationalism and xenophobia gain ground. This is detrimental to the ideal and values of Europe. Let me repeat this: we will not change our strategy and we call on everybody to uphold it. We need large-scale relocations, effective return of those who have no right to stay and, of course, secure common external borders. For this all Member States share responsibility. As Member States share the responsibility together with the Commission to safeguard Schengen, and I hope that, even if some politicians do not realise the symbolic and political value of Schengen and their duty, they will nevertheless consider the economic cost of non-Schengen. I will not repeat by views and commitments as regards Schengen; you all know them. The migratory pressure is of such scale that no Member State could face it alone and we all know this. We need immediate support for the ongoing Frontex operations and also a swift agreement on the European borders and coastguard proposal, so that none can sit and wait until things get better on their own. They will not if we do not all engage. This is why I also welcome the engagement of our partners: of the UNHCR, as I stressed this morning, and of NATO, which will help us finally stop the activities of smugglers. I remind you, we have declared a war against smugglers, with key third countries, like Turkey. Yes, we need Turkey to face this global crisis. I know that there are second thoughts, maybe some doubts, but we should never forget that Turkey is a key player in the area and a partner of Europe in our efforts. But we will not act against our own rules and this will be clarified during the coming days that will lead us to the European Council.  Return can only happen in full accordance with the European Union’s and international laws. We also need to complete our strategy. Resettlement is our immediate priority. As I had said already in my hearing, we need to build legal ways for those who need to come to Europe. Very soon, as promised, we will reveal our plans on the Dublin reform. I share your views. We need a fair burden-sharing system, including on legal migration. In a world of mobility we cannot have an EU without a proper economic migration policy, taking into account global developments, and then cooperation with third countries and, of course, coordination with the economic sector.  Last, but very important, a more coordinated policy on integration is what will complete this picture.  I would like to say to the Members of this Parliament that your interventions were very useful to me and I thank you for that and, as I always do, I am taking them very seriously into consideration in view of the upcoming developments. It was in this very House that our policy was born. It is in this very House that our policy will be defended in the name of European values, in the name of European democracy.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. – The migration crisis in the Mediterranean has brought immediate needs to the fore, but at the same time has also highlighted many of the structural limitations of EU migration policy and the instruments at its disposal. The resolute fight against irregular migration, migrant smugglers and migrant traffickers, as well as securing Europe's external borders, must be combined with a sustainable common asylum policy and a sound European policy on legal migration. Clearly, this requires more coherence between the various sectors, such as development cooperation, trade, employment, foreign affairs and home affairs.  The EU must continue to provide protection to people in need. Migrants who have been lawfully accepted in the Member States should not face reluctance and obstacles – they should receive as much assistance as possible to integrate into their new communities. At the same time, the EU must continue to strengthen cooperation with its global partners, address root causes and promote legal migration arrangements that stimulate growth and development in countries of origin and destination.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. I am disappointed in several respects by the results of the EU-Turkey Summit: it is disappointing that no final, sustainable settlement has been reached on the refugee issue. It is disappointing that Europe has once again played out its weakness rather than its strength. And it is disappointing that there was so little talk about the fate of the refugees and a lot of "the end of the wave-through."  Unfortunately, I have to say that there has again been no decision on how asylum seekers can come to Europe legally. For months now, there has been talk of the use of so-called hotspots in Greece to register refugees and then spread them across Europe. Not only have these facilities been stuck in the sand; if we now want to prevent refugees from coming to Greece in the first place, these registration zones will be run ad absurdum – or should at least be built with greater vigour in Turkey.  As far as Turkey is concerned, in the light of recent events, there must be a strong demand for respect for the rule of law and freedom of the press. Especially if the EU accession negotiations are to continue.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – The implementation of the European Agenda on Migration does show progress, but ultimately the results are modest. I stand by the belief that the agreement with Turkey will allow the European Union to fulfil its humanitarian obligations.  On the other hand, however, I am firmly opposed to mixing two fundamentally different issues – the resolution of the refugee crisis and negotiations with Turkey on EU membership and the fall of visas. Effective cooperation with our neighbours is only part of the solution. Member States should pursue a common policy, not counter the refugee crisis through breakaway actions such as arbitrary border closures. Otherwise, Greece will become a huge refugee camp. This common policy should also include countries outside the Schengen area. It is unacceptable for Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia to remain outside the scope of the new border protection agency. In this way, the ideal of a solidarity and a united Europe, which we so hold so zealously defend, is completely emptied of content!

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. The European Union and its Member States have failed miserably to meet the challenge of welcoming refugees. They are even prepared to draw a line under their international obligations by deporting asylum seekers to Turkey. Yesterday's summit thus buried all hope of a europe of solidarity, humane and responsible. Humanitarian aid is urgently needed in Greece, but it must not be turned into a huge refugee camp. We expected strong positions on the implementation of relocation decisions on which Member States have already agreed, on safeguarding the Schengen area through a specific plan for the abolition of internal border controls or on the development of safe and legal routes for refugees and asylum seekers to Europe. We also called for a complete overhaul of the Dublin Regulation to replace it with a harmonised European asylum system, based on solidarity and the sharing of responsibilities between all Member States. None of this has been achieved: this summit, with its deplorable record, has resulted in an undignified haggling, marking the victory of national selfishness over the european general interest.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the report by Danuta Maria Hübner, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the interinstitutional agreement on Better law-making (COM(2015)0215 – 2016/2005(ACI)) (A8-0039/2016).

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to start by saying that under Rule 140 of Parliament’s Rules of Procedure, the President of the European Parliament may sign an interinstitutional agreement after examination by Parliament’s Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) and after approval by Parliament. It is my honour today to recommend to Parliament the approval of the new interinstitutional agreement on better law-making and its signature by the President.  The current agreement on better law-making dates back to 2003. It was concluded before the 2004 enlargement of the European Union when we still had a Union of 15 Member States, and well before the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty. Parliament repeatedly called for the 2003 agreement to be renegotiated to take account of the new legislative environment created by the Treaty of Lisbon, to consolidate best practices and to bring the agreement up to date in line with the modern understanding of the better law-making agenda. So we took it as good news when, in January 2015, the then newly-elected Juncker Commission committed to presenting a proposal for a new interinstitutional agreement between the three institutions: Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. AFCO provided its contribution to the position of the European Parliament in the negotiations, in April 2015, on the revision of the 2003 agreement. The Conference of Presidents then endorsed the President’s proposal that Mr Guy Verhofstadt would be Parliament’s lead negotiator, conducting the negotiations in close cooperation with AFCO and the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI), and also reporting to the Conference of Presidents.  Finally, in December 2016, the Conference of Presidents endorsed the new agreement. And the resolution on the conclusion of this agreement on better law-making adopted by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, to be voted on tomorrow, expresses, in general terms, its view on the outcome of the negotiations. It also calls for the impact of the new agreement on the framework agreement and other related interinstitutional agreements to be ascertained with a view to simplifying the architecture of the numerous arrangements. It also identifies a range of issues that need further follow-up at technical or political level. It recommends the approval of the agreement and contains a mandate for AFCO to examine the extent to which amendments to or interpretations of the Rules of Procedure are necessary for the implementation of the agreement. Let me mention just some elements of particular importance for the European Parliament of the content of the new agreement. These include multiannual and annual programing; the Commission’s follow-up to Parliament’s legislative initiative requests and justifications for and consultations on envisaged withdrawals of legislative proposals; better law-making tools – which are important for a well-informed, inclusive and transparent decision-making process –  and the impact assessment issue. We agreed that the impact assessment should be comprehensive and balanced and take into account the costs of not legislating.  The independence and objectiveness of the new regulatory scrutiny vote is also an issue of particular relevance for us. The impact assessment should not, however, replace the political decision-making. Gold-plating is also an important issue, in the context of avoiding over-regulation and administrative burden for citizens, administrations and businesses, especially small and medium-sized businesses. With regard to delegated and implementing acts, we have moved forward, but Parliament expects today a swift agreement between the three institutions on the appropriate criteria for delineating delegated acts and implementing acts and a prompt alignment of basic acts via the legal framework of the Lisbon Treaty.  To conclude, having examined the content of the new interinstitutional agreement, AFCO has identified a number of issues that need further follow-up. These issues will be subject to further analysis in a joint initiative report drafted by AFCO and JURI. We trust that the new interinstitutional agreement on better law-making will be an important tool in establishing and developing a more open, more transparent relationship between the institutions with a view to delivering better law-making in the interest of the Union’s citizens.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I am very happy to be back in this Chamber. The issue up for debate is one where we, as institutions, have come together and demonstrated our firm intent to strengthen our cooperation. I am pleased to mark this important step forward in our interinstitutional relations. With this new agreement we have jointly established a set of rules on how to ensure a better delivery for our citizens and businesses together. I will not repeat the content of the agreement, but let me mention a couple of points that demonstrate this. We will have a joint discussion on our legislative priorities and also select those that, according to the three institutions, should be at the top of the agenda for the upcoming year. And yes, at a time when the EU is perceived as fragmented, it is important to show unity, to send a signal of common purpose and to tackle the big challenges ahead of us in a joined-up way. Concerning impact assessments, we agree that EU legislation must be based on informed decisions, while acknowledging that the legislative process is political and not technocratic. As co-legislators, we have a responsibility and a duty to our citizens to ensure that when we decide we have all relevant information in front of us and we take that information into account. In this regard much emphasis has rightly been put on having a particular regard for our SMEs as they are key to fostering growth and jobs in Europe. We have committed to avoiding overregulation and administrative burdens. The Commission’s fitness and performance programme is firmly anchored within the agreement framework. This agenda should not be seen as being all about lowering standards for protection. Rather it is about thinking twice before we legislate and casting a critical eye on existing regulation. The annual burden survey that, on the suggestion of Parliament, found its way into the agreement will help us to focus our minds on this matter. It will be a common platform for a discussion on how we can better ensure that we have legislation fit for purpose but without unnecessary burdens being put on citizens, businesses and administrations. We have also agreed to enhance the transparency of our work for citizens, and here I would like to highlight that we will have a joint database on the state of play of legislative files. This may sound to some of you like a technical issue, although it is quite important. People have to be able to understand how we work, so more active joint communication is needed. Then – and this is highly significant – Parliament and Council have agreed on a number of points where we, as co-legislators, can strengthen our cooperation, such as being better at ensuring an efficient process, while safeguarding the quality of legislation and respecting each institution’s prerogatives, such as working closer together at an early stage to better understand each other’s points of view and thereby , hopefully, facilitating negotiations. In this context, I would like to express my appreciation for the constructive approach of both Parliament and the Commission in establishing measures to instil greater confidence in Member States in the use of delegated acts. I am confident that this agreement will contribute to ensuring a framework and an atmosphere for negotiations that are conducive to finding constructive solutions to our common problems. We are all aware that the agreement is the result of a compromise, and not all issues were settled to the full satisfaction of each institution. Some points were hard fought, touching on sensitive issues and the balance between institutions. However, I believe that the deal represents a fair balance. The Council has welcomed the agreement reached and next week, on 15 March, the General Affairs Council will formally adopt the agreement. We then have to turn swiftly to implementation. We have to seize the momentum to put all the good words into practice, to make a real difference in how we deliver to our citizens and businesses. The Presidency has therefore placed implementation and follow-up high on the agenda of the Council. Already next week we will kick off by deciding on how the Council will organise its work in relation to the Commission’s annual work programme, also paving the way for the three-way talks on the joint annual priorities. We are only at the start of our discussion within the Council on implementation, but the Presidency in particular intends to look at how the Council deals with impact assessments and how to take forward the overall ‘better regulation’ package presented by the European Commission. And yes, the Presidency also intends to put transparency on the agenda. In closing, I would like to underline that the Presidency and the Council will of course continue to work in close cooperation with both Parliament and Commission on ensuring an effective application and implementation of this important agreement.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, when we reached an agreement on this in December, I was in two minds about it. I was happy that we had an agreement which takes us quite a number of steps forward, but I would have liked to see a more ambitious agreement in many areas. But realism took over and it was impossible to convince people to go the extra mile, so we settled for an agreement that is still much better than what we had before. So for me the glass is still half full with this agreement.  Why is it important? Because we needed to look at the whole policy cycle. We needed to review everything we – the three institutions directly involved – do when we legislate. All three institutions were unhappy with the status quo, so we wanted to bring improvements. Let me a mention a few substantial and meaningful, and let me repeat that, from our three different perspectives, none of us got a hundred percent of what we wanted. On implementing acts and delegated acts, the proposed approach should facilitate future discussions between the co-legislators and unblock the current impasse on many individual files. The Commission will also provide greater transparency by allowing stakeholders to see the text of delegated acts and implementing acts before they are adopted. On annual and multiannual programming, the interinstitutional agreement provides for intensive collaboration between the institutions in setting priorities through annual and multiannual programming and on identifying the priority files for the legislative procedure. On regulatory fitness, each new act will set out how the legislation will be monitored and evaluated in the future so that we can check whether it is working as planned. The Commission’s regulatory fitness programme will also play a central role in simplifying the body of existing legislation and reducing unnecessary regulatory burdens, but without weakening any of our important social and environmental goals. One of the biggest fears when we started this exercise was that this was just cutting red tape at the expense of our standards. This is not what we are doing. We are maintaining, and even improving, our standards, while still cutting red tape. On transparency, in some cases working jointly across the institutions to build common IT platforms for delegated acts – and later perhaps for the codecision procedure – will help open up decision-making to public scrutiny. It is important to remember that the framework agreement between Parliament and the Commission continues to apply in full, and the Commission remains committed to it as the bedrock of the cooperation between our two institutions.  This is a balanced outcome. I repeat that, although not all my ambitions were realised, it is balanced for the institutions. I hope that Parliament can support the outcome agreed by its negotiators, as this is good for the public and for business. I would like to thank Mrs Hübner very much for her outstanding report on this. We have a strong political message from the three institutions that they take seriously better regulation and the concerns of small businesses and the man and woman in the street – how can I say ‘man in the street’ on 8 March? – about unnecessary regulation. We have support for better regulation from all the institutions as a means to deliver societal objectives in the most efficient way.  If Parliament approves the new agreement, the Commission is ready to start work immediately with Parliament and Council to ensure its timely and effective implementation so that together we can start delivering concretely for our citizens and our businesses.
