In particular, the Commission can start to deliver on its commitments on the alignment of existing empowerments with the Lisbon Treaty, and we can work together to deliver the new register for delegated acts, which is something Parliament also wants.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, I would first like to congratulate Mr Timmermans on this very important initiative he has carried out since the Commission. I would also like to congratulate Mrs Hubner on the report, which is a report, I think, difficult to carry because it demanded a lot of consensus and which she has brought to fruition. And to congratulate my colleague Markus Pieper because he has made an effort to ensure that small and medium-sized enterprises are well defended in the interinstitutional agreement and, although we are ultimately not entirely satisfied, we have a second report which this Parliament will be working on to clarify those points where we believe that small and medium-sized enterprises should have been better defended by this agreement. During the negotiations, many popular group priorities have been addressed and that is why we are pleased: with regard to impact assessments, which are indispensable tools for achieving quality legislation and which will reduce the bureaucratic burden on enterprises, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises; with regard to the subsidiarity examination, which will allow us to legislate only where and when necessary; delegated acts, and I am glad of the words I have just heard from Mr Timmermans, because it is time for parliament's difficulties in almost every negotiation of the last decade to be resolved. The Council's latest statement on the United Kingdom has already referred to this agreement as a key part of avoiding unnecessary laws and improving the competitiveness of our businesses and economic growth. It is important for Parliament to work on an equal footing. It is what makes us what we are: Parliament.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, let me begin by making very clear the position of the Socialist Group throughout these negotiations. We are, of course, in favour of an improved and better system for legislators to know the impact of what they are doing and the potential costs that they may place on others. That is essential. But, we have always said that this must be a comprehensive assessment. It is not just about cutting costs to small and medium-sized enterprises, important as that is. It is also about the costs and burdens of other kinds. Not just of legislating, but potentially of the cost of not legislating, costs on the consumer, costs on public health and therefore on public budgets, costs to the environment, costs to the way our competition policies work. All this must be taken into account. Impact assessment must be comprehensive; a real cost-benefit analysis, in other words. We must also bear in mind that we are talking about legislating at the European level. Now, when we get it right, when we bring in common rules for our common market we are replacing 28 divergent and contradictory sets of national rules. In other words we are simplifying things for businesses, we are cutting red tape. That must be part of the occasion. And our third concern was that the procedure for impact assessments must, of course, be advisory. There is no right of veto for an appointed official in a legislative procedure. As elected representatives we must have the final say. Imagine if, 30 years ago, since this is International Women’s Day, an impact assessment had said: ‘oh, equal pay for equal work, that will cost businesses, that will cost the exchequer, no we had better not do that.’ Of course, we would have overridden that advice and taken the political decision to legislate anyway. Since the agreement meets our concerns in these respects my Group will fully support it. We also support the other things in it – on programming, transparency, impact assessments – very good. We look forward to approving it and to working for the further implementation of this important agreement.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I welcome this agreement as a step in the right direction; but like the Commissioner, I wish it had been more ambitious.  Reform in the European Union must be an ongoing process and it cannot stop with this interinstitutional agreement. Cutting administrative burdens, cutting red tape, especially for small businesses, is absolutely vital for our competitiveness in the global economy. My Group established three key priorities for the IIA: the SME and competitiveness tests, burden reduction targets and the independence of the regulatory scrutiny board.  On the last priority, our report sees the establishment of the scrutiny board as a welcome first step in achieving the independence thereof. On the first two, I am very pleased that the IIA reflects the text of the Council conclusions from February, specifically the burden reduction target. This was a key part of my Prime Minister's negotiations. Simplifying regulation and setting targets for cutting red tape will be good for the whole EU, and that is just what he made clear: we should make things better for the whole of Europe, not just the UK.  So there are some important things in this agreement, including impact assessments on substantive amendments, sunset and review clauses and a strong commitment to regulatory simplification. I am particularly pleased to see the commitment to undertake an annual burden survey to review the efforts to simplify legislation, to avoid overregulation and to look at the stock of existing EU law. As someone who believes that Britain will be better off in a reformed EU, I see reform as vital and I see this agreement as another step in the right direction, in a continuing journey of reform.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Mrs Erner, President of the AFCO Commission, has put out in a great way what is the objective of the report which we will be able to vote on tomorrow and which, of course, from the ALDE Group we are advising to vote positively so that the Interinstitutional Agreement can be implemented. Legislating is not an easy job, but legislating for all 500 million Europeans in twenty-eight countries is certainly very difficult. Beyond the principle of subsidiarity, the principle of proportionality by which we govern, there is the objective that the legislation is of quality and that it is not impossible to understand and implement. This agreement has to do in particular with the understanding of the rules, with better collaboration between co-legislators, with the applicability of the legislation that we are going to pass, with the anticipation of the impact, on the one hand, and the cost of non-Europe on legislation, and with the account of SMEs, which are indeed eternal forgotten in many european regulations and policies. It is not easy to co-register, because the institutions have technically very sophisticated gears, and the truth is that many of the European citizens sometimes see us as if we are installed in a distant galaxy. For all of the above, this Parliament feels the need — and has collaborated to do so — to improve that participation and trust that we must earn from the citizens. With this agreement, Parliament has lowered some of the barriers we have identified and successfully negotiated a broader and balanced approach to better regulation.  In this context, these good results must be achieved, Mr Timmermans, with regard to these impact assessments, the transparency and implementation of Union legislation, as well as the reduction of bureaucratic requirements, which must allow for greater flexibility, and the fight against deregulation, which is not the same as over-legislating. Legislate the right, no more, no less, but legislate, moreover, well. However, there has been no lack of pressure from those who insist on national nearsightedness or blind populism. Well, in the face of that too, I believe that we have reached a pragmatic, realistic agreement. And, with this aim of giveing the European Union the strongest possible legal framework, we will work. Of course, we will support the report tomorrow.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, today we are discussing the agreement between the European Commission, the European Council and the European Parliament on improving internal legislative procedures with a view to the proper functioning of the institutions, better implementation of Union policies and saving time and money. After long negotiations we finally have a proposal with some positive elements.  But it is clear that economic rather than social issues are still at the centre of attention. Trade unions expressing the needs of workers seem to be sidelined. At the same time, questions arise as to whether Parliament's voice is indeed being strengthened in the legislative process or whether it is the Commission which is mainly strengthened by this agreement. As Europe experiences intense reflection on its future, we should have changed its focus and perceptions and focused on the problems of the many, not the interests of the few.  This can be achieved through truly democratic and transparent procedures and not by agreements that restrict the voice of citizens and the institutions that directly represent them. Facilities for the active participation of citizens must be a priority for the European Union in order to strengthen democracy and weaken bureaucracy.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Mr Timmermans, who could imagine that behind the word 'better regulation' lies the desire to legitimis less well? I fear that behind this word lies an ideology, that at least to legislate, not to the best of legislating; an ideology that is focused - and you have said, you have used that word, it is repeated and it is heard on the administrative burden, particularly on the right of this Chamber. I am telling you, Vice-President, Europe's burden is not administrative. It is democratic and social. It is the 27 million unemployed, the refugees who cannot be welcomed with dignity and the problems facing this Europe that are not administrative. So, behind the ideology of "less regulation" and the desire to free markets, we must ask ourselves the question of which Europe we want. I, Mr Vice-President, the Europe that regulates is the one I am defending, it is that of air quality, of water, it is the one that ensures that health is respected. This is not the Europe of bureaucracy, where we are going to pay civil servants to check what we will not have legislated on for almost a year. Kafka dreamed of it, Europe is doing it.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the agreement that we are about to dismiss is the result of a watered-down compromise and we, as the European Parliament, the only institution directly elected by the citizens, could and should have asked for more. The procedure followed, in order to reach a compromise text, was not the best.  We in the 5-star Movement would have called, for example, for greater transparency with regard to trilogues: it is not enough to know what was decided after the event – the citizens need to know what is being negotiated and by whom; greater involvement of citizens through specific instruments, such as electronic ones; maximum publicity and transparency for delegated and implementing acts – too much opacity in fact and lobbyist interests surround these acts, see the Volkswagen case; the immediate establishment of the register of delegated acts – in fact, it is not clear why it should take place only in 2017, if it happens. Finally, we would have called for the establishment of a compulsory and binding transparency register for all the European institutions. In short, we would have really protected the citizens.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, I must admit that reading this report has saddened me. This pensum as long as a day without bread contains nothing concrete or useful. Hollow words follow one another, repeat, loop in a hellish waltz that leads to nothing. The big statements on transparency could have made me laugh, but when I see the opacity around TAFTA and the influence of lobbies within institutions, it is not laughter that grabs me, but indignation. When I look at the monstrous cost of the Workers' Detachment Directive to the French social protection system and, above all, to the French themselves, I know that European legislation is not intended to serve the interests of peoples and peoples, but only its ultra-liberal dogmas and the interest of some powerful multinationals. There is only one way for the European Union to better legislate, and that is to stop legislating at all. Let each people regain their fundamental right to decide their own laws and that states cooperate in good intelligence. The freedom of the sovereign people within each nation is the only valid legislative principle in a democracy.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: – Madam President, this agreement is the first since 2003, and very timely it is too. Broadly, legislation should express a political will to regulate some area and to do it as effectively as possible, but legislation does not happen by chance, as it were. Its aims have to be formulated as thoughtfully as possible. That is the policy process. Legislation – and I think that has been clear from the debate so far – has to avoid the extremes of under-regulation and over-regulation. To that end, while legislation is being formulated there must be wide-ranging consultation with all stakeholders, not just with the ones that have the most effective lobbying capacity. Some stakeholders are smaller, but their interests too must be recognised. SMEs come to mind here, and not just mine. All law-making involves a political decision which is then converted into a legal outcome. This is where impact assessment and attention to implementing and delegated legislation assumes importance. This meeting of politics and law will always be a sensitive one, and politicians should be aware that it is impossible to make regulations for all contingencies. In an ideal world better legislation should be of benefit to all the citizens of Europe and to European citizenship itself.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the signing of this interinstitutional agreement is very good news for the European Union, at a time of crisis when the boundaries of competences between the various institutions are shifting and becoming increasingly evanescent. I would also like to thank our rapporteur, Mrs Hübner, our shadow rapporteur, Richard Corbett, and the three negotiators who have worked to achieve a positive agreement.  I believe that this is a good agreement: it makes changes that make the previous agreement of 2003 more topical; dialogue with the social partners and small and medium-sized enterprises will be preserved and developed; their input will be taken more into account during the legislative process; above all, the social and environmental impact of the acts will also be assessed during the procedures themselves. Furthermore, this new agreement guarantees greater transparency during the negotiations, and lastly, Parliament is given greater weight in the annual programming, which we have been asking for for a long time.  In the light of all this, I can say that this is a good agreement, which is an important step in the direction, if not of the ever closer union, certainly of an ever closer institution. We expect a great deal from the implementation work that will begin in the institutions from tomorrow, which must be shared.  I'm going to ask you for a minute, Mr President. Legislating better ...  (The speaker continued in French) veut dire avant tout retirer de sa table et de sa tête le drapeau de son propre pays et y mettre celui de l'Europe.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I'm not as enthusiastic as my predecessors. I am happy with the agreement, but my joy is limited. The opportunity to create cost-effective regulation has not been seized. I am convinced that the impact assessment should be carried out at every stage of the legislation, and that the competitiveness test should be more strongly exposed. Finally, there is this contradiction: either we want the principle of subsidiarity or we are still talking about something that I do not fully understand – the absence, the cost of the absence of the European Union. The latter, however, is usually an invitation to centralism and overproduction of the law. So let us focus on the principle of subsidiarity, including in the European Parliament itself. Parliament's Rules of Procedure are currently under way in the Rules of Procedure. I propose that the European Parliament itself apply the principle of subsidiarity more widely than before. So: yes to the agreement – but my assessment is not as enthusiastic as many of its predecessors.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, on the contrary, I was an enthusiast. In fact, for me, this was one of the top priorities with which I came to the European Parliament and I still remember my meeting with First Vice-President Timmermans in November 2014 where we exchanged views, and I can understand, Mr Timmermans, what you say today, that you had higher ambitions. So did I. I think that many of us did, but the reality too is that many of us had lower ambitions so what we stand in front of today is a compromise, a compromise which you called a glass half-full, maybe a bit more than half-full I would say, but I think it is a good agreement and I think that we can make it a full glass with implementation.  I had the privilege to work closely with our negotiator, Guy Verhofstadt. I would not say what I am going to say now if he were present, but I think that, likewise his colleagues and partners, he did a very good job and I think that we have an agreement that we can implement today, and we can implement it so that the glass is, as I say, full.  One example, very briefly, is the administrative burden. This is exactly what is a chance for us. If the Commission will have the ability and the courage to show who proposes what, what happens in each sector and how Member States behave, what is the difference between the proposal that was submitted and the legislation enacted, and what is in fact the act that was passed through the parliaments, the gold-plating, I think that for me this is satisfactory in comparison to what I was seeking and that was one in , one out. I think that is the tool with which we can deliver. Thank you and it is up to us how we are going to implement this agreement.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Madam President, Ms Hübner in her report has pointed out the need for more concrete provisions on transparency of the legislative procedures, especially the trilogues, and I fully agree. Just two weeks ago the Committee on Legal Affairs came exactly to the same conclusions. Transparency is a necessary component of legitimacy. The interinstitutional agreement lays a good foundation for a more open and transparent interaction between the EU institutions. But I do not think that this agreement in itself is enough. We should not stop now when we are only at the halfway point. Let me explain.  A natural follow up for better law-making is better administration. I have had a chance to prepare a draft regulation for an open, efficient and independent EU administration that will also soon be presented here in plenary, next month in fact. And the Minister actually knows this project very well because she is a former member of this House. Diligent and transparent administrative procedures could reduce the complexity and restore the credibility of the EU administration in the eyes of its citizens, and I will not spare my efforts when this Parliament starts taking concrete actions towards better law-making and better administration.

name: Tim AKER
text: – Madam President, the European Union controls fishing, it controls farming, it controls trade, it has legal supremacy, it has a foreign minister and a foreign service, it wants a police force, it gives the UK a complete and open border, it wants an EU army, it will not give up on its failing currency, it wants more tax powers and its economy is crumbling.  I will give the EU some free advice. If you want better lawmaking, stop. All of these powers I mentioned belong with sovereign democratic nation states. They do not belong in this place and the sooner the United Kingdom is free and taking back control of these powers outside of this Union, the better.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her If I may believe a few of the previous speakers, that is the big throw today.  However, I would like to remind you of the Commission's draft. Unfortunately, much has been negotiated away in the trialogue procedure. The glass is half full, Said Commissioner Timmermans, and it is also significant that our negotiator, Mr Verhofstadt, is not present today. On the positive side – after all – the agreement: the Council is there, small firms are the focus of cutting red tape, and there is a bit more independence in assessing the quality of impact assessments. Parliament's reading, which is now reflected in the Hübner report, is also positive. I would like to express my thanks to Mr Verhofstadt and Mrs Hübner for this. But the big throw isn't that. The Commission wanted a stronger reporting obligation for gold-plating. Why have Parliament and/or the Council softened this? The Commission wanted to make the Council and Parliament more responsible for its own impact assessments. Why have the Council and Parliament softened this? The Commission wanted to make a commitment to an annual list of acts to be taken back. Why have the Council and Parliament softened this? The Commission is now keeping the buck of the EU bureaucracy. In the nirvana of a trialogue negotiation without a parliamentary vote, important advances for greater transparency have disappeared. It is a pity, because we are squandering the opportunity for European citizens to know much more about who is really responsible for what at what stage of European legislation. This agreement deserved more than this half-full glass. But we're moving on.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The interinstitutional agreement on which we are voting tomorrow is a good agreement. It is a good basis for cooperation between the European institutions. But it is also good news for the citizens. Why? Because with this agreement we make it clear that we take criticism seriously. Together we want to improve our legislative action, we want to change it. We will improve legislation and focus on cutting red tape. I would also like to highlight a second aspect: better regulation is not, in essence, about the mere number of EU laws, about more or less. Rather, quality is crucial. Maintaining and strengthening high consumer protection and environmental standards, strengthening fundamental rights and workers' rights – that is what the citizens expect of us, and this will ultimately have to be measured by the Commission, Parliament and the Council.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: Tomorrow we will vote on something that should be self-evident: the European institutions are going for better legislation. Only European action where necessary, simple and easily applicable legislation and the avoidance of unnecessary administrative burdens. And what do we see? We see that the agreement does not reflect that. The way in which the agreement was reached therefore leaves much to be desired. If, of course, you allow the negotiations for the European Parliament to be conducted by Guy Verhofstadt, someone who stands for the old Europe, regardless of any reality, then you will find an unrepresentative situation. Today he is again the great absentee here, so that only confirms this. The lack of transparency throughout the process has only contributed to this. So let this be a lesson for the future. We need a new wind in Europe, the old Europe is no more!

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for This agreement is an agreement between the Council, the Commission and Parliament on how the EU will legislate in the future. It contains both good things and bad things, but the best thing is that the proposals presented by the Commission that had risked paralysing the EU legislative process are no longer there. We Greens are concerned about proposals to introduce too much impact assessments. Why would you do that? Is it not good to analyse the consequences before going to a decision? Yes, it is, but it is so much easier to see the costs of a policy proposal that affects an individual company – for example, a producer of a dangerous chemical – than to see the benefits of the policy proposal to ban the dangerous chemical, something that very many people benefit from. These diffuse profits and an abundance of impact assessments risk paralysing the decision-making process.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would like to join all those voices that say that we are not, however, entirely satisfied with the negotiations on the Interinstitutional Agreement that have been concluded. We expected more, we only managed to do as much as we could. Today, Parliament is in a situation where it can say yes or no to this agreement. Well, we can say, of course we will say so, because this is an absolutely necessary agreement. But we are also saying no to the possible conclusion of further negotiations, because they are necessary. We would also like to say that we will expect that, even what has already been concluded in the Interinstitutional Agreement will in fact be fully respected by all three institutions.  In this House, in this House, we are discussing every year the report prepared by the Committee on Legal JD on better regulation, creating better mechanisms, creating a good European legal area. But I want to make it clear that good cooperation between the institutions is not a sufficient element of good law-making. First of all, there must be a good design on the table, and of course a good end result. And here it happens differently. Therefore, I am very sorry that despite our efforts, the PPE Group, but also not only, in Impact Assessment we do not have an SME test. Although we have a salty assurance from the European Commission that it will carry out very broad consultations. By the way of this consultation, in the moment when we finish the debate on this subject, the European Commission will put forward a legislative proposal on the posting of workers. from what I know, the consultation has not been carried out at all, so we are either lying or we will work well together. I believe the latter is more certain

name: Vicky FORD
text: – Madam President, increasing competitiveness is key to delivering stronger economies, increasing prosperity and boosting jobs and growth. We need to rewind the red tape, remove the bureaucracy and reduce the costs faced by businesses and public services when they try to comply with European law. This new agreement, which will govern how the Parliament, the 28 countries of Europe, and the EU Commission work together on better regulation will help – but we can go further. Last month, European leaders and the Commission promised a sector-by-sector, year-by-year approach to eliminate the unnecessary costs faced by businesses and passed on to consumers. Our economies cannot afford for this to be an empty promise. Commissioner, Member States, Parliament: let us work together to deliver on those promises.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Madam President, I will speak as Chairman of the Committee on Legal Affairs, whose competence includes, inter alia, improving lawmaking.  It is certainly positive that we now have a new agreement. However, the European Parliament has already set out certain positions in this area in the past, which have only partially been contained in the resulting text. Therefore, a few notes on several aspects.  Firstly, impact assessment is an important tool for assessing the quality of legislation. Such an assessment includes that the new rules do not cause excessive administrative burdens for their users. The independence of impact assessments remains one of our top priorities, which has not yet been fully achieved.  Secondly, the new agreement requires further follow-up to, for example, delegated and implementing acts. Only then will the deal plus or minus be complete. Finally, we must also monitor the implementation of the agreement as a whole, because that is the only way we will have a truly functional instrument that fulfils its role.  That is why the Committee on Legal Affairs, together with the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, will monitor the interpretation and implementation of the new agreement, through own-initiative reports and also through a joint working group.

name: Emil RADEV
text: – Dear Colleagues, I think we could have achieved a better outcome with this agreement, because we need to make simpler and clearer laws, not flood citizens and businesses with red tape. In this regard, the agreed annual burden study is an important tool for identifying and monitoring the results of the European institutions' efforts to avoid and reduce over-regulation and administrative burdens with a focus on small and medium-sized enterprises. It is necessary to clearly distinguish the burden imposed by the various Commission proposals and the acts of individual Member States. Thus, brussels will no longer be to blame for the emergence of various problems due to measures taken by Member States.  Public consultation in legislative planning will help to pay more attention to the impact of the new laws on competitiveness. The annual burden review and impact assessments of draft legislation will establish control over the impact they have, in particular on small and medium-sized enterprises. I hope that the new rules and commitments adopted by this agreement will be properly implemented and will help to truly improve, modern and quality European legislation.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, I welcome the rapporteur's recommendations because I share his concerns about the neglect of the assessment of the effects of legislation on SMEs. These companies are the backbone of the European economy and employ more than 80% of employees in the private sector, so any responsible legislator would have to be guided by their interests, among others. While this house proposes to assess the effects of legislation on gender equality, we give small and medium-sized private companies employing members of both sexes at least partial equality in practice too little importance. When it comes to laws and other acts, quality is much more important than quantity. I hope, therefore, that we will finally welcome a comprehensive regulatory guillotine that will remove redundant rules and procedures both at European and national level, and ensure that our companies further profit from the single market and employ even more people.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome this interinstitutional agreement and see it as a good basis for establishing and developing transparent relations between the institutions, with the aim of better legislating in the interests of the citizens of the Union.  I am pleased that it has been decided to hold an interinstitutional exchange of views on changing the legal basis of an act. It is important to use all available instruments to better legislate (and therefore impact assessments, public and stakeholder consultations, analyses, specifications, etc.) in order to ensure informed, inclusive and transparent decision-making. I therefore recognise that the measures agreed to improve the exchange of views and information between Parliament and the Council as legislators are undoubtedly a step forward. However, I believe that there is a need for deepening, in particular with regard to mutual access to information and meetings, so that we can ensure real balance and equal treatment between legislators throughout the legislative process, ensuring respect for the principle of loyal cooperation between the institutions.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, eu legislative work has sometimes been compared to riding a bicycle: you have to pedal all the time, otherwise you will fall.  Well, pedalled is. According to some estimates, 40 000 different legal measures have been taken in the EU. No one seems to know the exact figure. There are plenty of pedals, too. The Commission alone currently employs some 33 000 officials. I welcome the Hübner report as a reminder of what was originally agreed on the European Union. It is only up to the EU to adopt legislation where necessary and only to the extent necessary. This is a good guideline that should be recalled from time to time, whatever one may think of the European Union.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, three key ideas on this programme which they have called Better Regulation and the interinstitutional agreement that supports it. First, legislate better. Second, what criteria and serving which interests? From what we can see, it will be the so-called competitiveness of enterprises – read the interests of the large European economic groups – to determine even more the opportunity and content of the legislation, further overriding this criterion with social and environmental criteria, which could still take advantage of improving the living conditions of peoples. Second, more serious limitations on the democraticity of the legislative and decision-making process are designed. The door is open to a greater concentration of power in the European Commission and to limit the capacity of co-legislators to intervene, especially members. Third, transparency. Declarations of good intentions in this regard do not match specific measures. Access to documents and meetings continues to face numerous obstacles, to the detriment of the transparency of the legislative process, and we know that it is in the shadow that the soft powers assert themselves. It is to them, fundamentally, that serves this program.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the question we asked ourselves at the beginning of this debate was 'better a glass half full or half empty?' In view, this agreement can be both. Unfortunately, I agree with those who see it as half empty. It is true that progress has been made, for example in the field of programming. There is also talk of impact assessment, but then we should actually see who will do it in the name and on behalf of the Commission.  And as far as SMEs are concerned, it is clear that this is a very dear point to the movement that I represent, but we would not like to see, in the guise of the watchful eye for legislation that diminishes their bureaucratic burden, a Trojan horse is being hid which is designed to dismantle the body of rights and principles for the citizens that the acquis communautaire represents and which are rather unseated by the large multinationals. We also have criticism of the procedural aspect. Choosing a single negotiator, who has not been mandated on individual issues by Parliament, was not the best choice. And then we also call for more transparency on trilogues. It is not enough to know ex post, but we need them to be more in keeping with the spirit of the Treaties.  The principle of transparency and political accountability is non-negotiable.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, the new interinstitutional agreement on better regulation is a letter of empty law. A freshman law student would talk about a legal loophole. Often the literal, historical, technological and systematic interpretation of EU law is in direct contradiction with the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity as well as legal certainty. The examples are many and we are all aware of them in this Chamber, when, for example, the Commission sends legislative acts or directives without taking into account the comments of the various parliamentary committees even after two readings. Many cases of non-transposition of Community law into their respective national ones. Legal science is not a positive science, because its findings cannot be verified by experiments. Unfortunately, the institutions have become the citizens of the Union to experiment with the wrong economic, in particular, policies and legislation.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Madam President, I wanted to join the agreement and I wanted to recall two issues which I think are important to this agreement. Firstly, for the first time, a procedure is established so that the Commission has to respond to proposals for acts coming from this Parliament. The agreement sets a three-month deadline for the Commission to respond, and even follow up on the initiative proposals emerging from this House. I think this is a very important achievement, because we all know that many times the initiative reports or legislative proposals emerging from Parliament sometimes sleep in the Commission's drawers. I think this response commitment is very important and I also think it is very important, secondly, that the commitment to greater access to information, documents and to join the Council's meetings on the part of Parliament, because improving the relationship between Council and Parliament will greatly favour the legislative process.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I have often criticised the Commission for the bureaucracy it has, for the conflict of interest it presents as a member of the troika and as guardian of the Treaties, but I would like to say something and address the House: Has the Bureau seen what new bureaucracy it has brought with the new way of recruiting local members' associates? Have you really dealt with what bureaucratic monster you've created? If someone wants to hire someone with teleworking, who does not live in Athens for example and lives in Thessaloniki, they cannot hire them on an open-ended contract, because they have to come to settle in Athens, and they tell you to hire them under a free service contract. Quite simply, Parliament itself, with the bureaucracy you have brought in, has thus made the situation that we cannot either hire local assistants or assign cases. Huge bureaucracy! A document that had five pages you made fifty pages! Well, before we criticise the Commission, let Parliament also decide to pick up the bureaucracy it has created.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, most Europeans already know that the European Union is not a democratic institution. It cannot be an institution that demands the payment of debt in the face of the maintenance of public services, which obliges workers to relinquish their labour rights or refuses to open their borders to refugees from the wars it itself fuels. Perhaps with other majority it would be different, with a Europe vertebrate by its working classes, conscious and organized to defend its rights against oligarchies. But, with proposals like today's, we are denied even this formal possibility, withdrawing Parliament's possibility of acting as a representative chamber of the popular will. What this Agreement contains is nothing more than a concentration of powers in an unelected bureaucracy, that of the Commission, a Weberian fantasy of neoliberal dominance. For us, the law is not a complement to market interests: it is, on the contrary, a weapon for the conquest of rights and freedoms to which this Parliament cannot renounce.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I will make just a few comments on what I have heard. First of all, I fail to understand how anyone can say that doing something for SMEs is neo-liberal policy. I just do not understand it. If we can help SMEs across the European Union so that people who run small businesses can run their business instead of being engaged in endless hours of administration, they can hire extra people – how is that neoliberal? If we are to create more jobs in this European Union, we will have to start with SMEs. That is the best bet we have and this programme, this agreement, gives us extra concentration on what it means for SMEs. Why? Because they cannot defend themselves as well as big corporations can in the Brussels bubble. That is why I strongly believe we should concentrate on helping SMEs be better at what they do. My second point is this: Mr Durand of the Greens got terribly excited – I was a bit afraid he might do himself some harm – but he was angry because we were lowering social standards and lowering environmental standards. I have challenged his group time and again to give me three examples of where this Commission has come up with proposals that led to lower social or environmental standards. Two would be fine. Even one. Nothing. So before he gets terribly excited he should perhaps talk to other members of his Group so that we know what we are talking about. Finally, let me repeat very clearly that to me this is the beginning of a process. The way we implement this will show whether we really are capable of better law-making or not. It is not just about having less regulation at European level. It is also, in a rational way – a socially, environmentally and economically sustainable way – about removing too much red tape because there are 28 different regulations, and trying to find a common European solution. That also is better regulation. So I am proud of the fact that we have got this agreement. I will repeat once again that I would have loved to go beyond what we have achieved, but still this represents the consensus between three institutions and different political angles to this. I believe it is the basis for truly better regulation, completely controlled by the outside world, because we are going to be much more transparent, engaging others much more. Especially by using the expertise in the REFIT platform, we will be able to create momentum so that in future our SMEs in particular will not be overburdened by unnecessary regulation.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, many Members have spoken about the importance of the impact assessments and yes, I am convinced that the impact assessment will strengthen the decision-making process in the Council and the European Parliament. I am also convinced that new impact assessments will allow the institutions to better assess the implication of legislation at a very early stage. It is important to note, though, that impact assessments will not or should not limit the roles of the co-legislators, whether in Parliament or in the Council. It will and should only serve as a very helpful tool so yes, I agree very much with you, Mr Howitt, on impact assessments. These are advisory because ultimately it is us, the co-legislators, who will take a political decision. But clearly, the better the impact assessment is, the more informed the political decision will be. Mr Pieper mentioned the issue of gold-plating. The current text in my view is clear and reflects the roles and responsibilities of the institutions and the Member States in a process of implementation and transposition of Union legislation. It is important that we all have a very clear picture about what aspects of national legislation are of a European nature and what aspects are the result of national considerations. It is clearly indicated in the agreement. With the current wording we were able to listen to the wishes of the European Parliament and the positions held by national parliaments with their specific role in the implementation process. I know that Mr Pieper wanted to go further when it comes to gold-plating, I understand, but I do hope that he will accept that a glass half-full, as the First Vice-President said, can still be enjoyable to drink. Ms Adinolfi and several others mentioned the importance of increased transparency. I stressed this as well earlier, and I would like to stress again that under the Netherlands Presidency we will also make a start with two important provisions in the agreement: the register for delegated acts and the database on the state of play of legislative files. I do hope that the European Parliament and the Commission will undertake similar steps thereby making it possible to strengthen transparency of the Union as a whole. On the SMEs I think the First Vice-President of the European Commission was very clear about that and yes, I do agree with Mrs Vicky Ford. She is right: we need to deliver on our promises, and I am convinced that we will act accordingly. Before closing, let me take the opportunity to thank the chief negotiators, Guy Verhofstadt and First Vice-President Frans Timmermans and Minister Nicolas Schmit for reaching this agreement, and I also wish to thank the rapporteur, Ms Hubner, and her colleagues in the AFCO Committee for their hard work. I look forward to cooperating closely with Parliament and the Commission on the agreement.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to use my two minutes to address the two institutions which are here with us today. I would like to thank the Council, represented by the Dutch Presidency, and the Commission, represented by First Vice-President Timmermans, for their commitment to the implementation of the Interinstitutional agreement on better law-making. I am sure that if we work on implementation in close cooperation, if we commit ourselves to smart implementation, it will allow us to make maybe not the full extra mile, as you said, First Vice-President, but as many colleagues have said today through implementation I think we can do more for better law-making. We can indeed, as you were trying to say, go beyond what is on the paper and the Parliament is committed to it. We have heard that the Council is starting the debate on implementation and will ensure the implementation of the agreement in close cooperation with the Parliament and with the Commission. And this is good news for us, but for us in the European Parliament it is also important that we move forward on better law-making, while respecting equality between legislators. In the agreement, steps have been taken to improve the mutual exchange of views and information between the Council and the European Parliament. We need to develop this cooperation further. Transparency of decision-making, although recognised in the agreement, requires further follow-up in the implementation phase. Indeed it is up to us, as somebody said, to implement this Interinstitutional agreement in a way that will multiply the value of this joint interinstitutional effort toward better law. So, once again thank you to all those who were involved in all the institutions, and I also have hope that tomorrow we will have a happy end to this exercise. And then, as you said First Vice-President, it is just the beginning of a strong, joint effort on implementation.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 9 March 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The three members of the Belgian PS elected in this Parliament voted against this agreement because they believe that, under the guise of simplifying European legislation, the REFIT programme poses a serious threat to many provisions relating to social protection, environmental protection and public health. However, even more than before this long period of austerity, Europe must protect its citizens and its workers.  We voted against this point because, in addition to this deep concern, the inter-institutional approach is unbalanced since it only provides for consultation with the European Parliament by the European Commission and the Council in the implementation of REFIT. This is clearly insufficient in view of the threats to the safety and health of workers or, more generally, European citizens.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. – One word about delegated acts: it is high time to solve this remaining stumbling block that the EP has been facing during almost all negotiations. Whether the concessions given to Council as regards Members States’ expert consultation will achieve this aim – only time can tell. It is only to be hoped. Since being the owner of several reports in this field, I will advise my Group to examine carefully how the commitments are followed up, especially on common criteria, full alignment and common register.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The agreement between the Commission, the Council and Parliament replaces the 2003 Agreement and aims to improve EU legislation. The aim is, inter alia, that EU rules achieve the desired effect at the lowest possible cost and with the least administrative burden. The new Interinstitutional Agreement assumes that the law--setting process will be open and transparent and based on the most accurate information with the relevant participation of stakeholders.  Improving the existing Interinstitutional Agreement is particularly important at a time when the functioning of the EU institutions is increasingly being questioned and distanced from the problems of European citizens. In Brussels, there is often a law that no one understands, and the benefits of it are challenged by many. The agreement improves the entire political cycle – planning, drafting, adopting, implementing, evaluating and modifying the new law. This is done m.in the european Commission's multi-annual and annual programming of work, an impact assessment of the introduction or non-implementation of the law at UNION level, or a public consultation with stakeholders.  I am very pleased that the final document also includes the need for the institutions to assess the consequences of new EU law, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, as they are the ones most sensitive to legal changes , both negative and positive.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I believe that an effective better regulation agreement between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission has a fundamental impact on every area of our lives in the European Union. Thanks to the newly proposed rules, we are on track not only to reduce costs and administrative burdens, but also to increase the transparency and transparency of the law.  An important element of the agreement is the fact that it concerns the entire political cycle, from the planning stage through implementation to evaluation and possible modifications. In my opinion, one of the most important tools that we should use is public consultation, which allows stakeholders to comment on a particular issue. The active participation of citizens in the process of creating EU law, even before the European Commission makes a new legislative proposal, significantly reduces the distance from the institutions and gives us practical guidance on the expectations and potential concerns of citizens, businesses and organisations.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission Declaration on The Posting of Workers [2016/2605(RSP)].

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is with pleasure that I present to you, the European Parliament, the Commission proposal for a targeted amendment of the Posting of Workers Directive that the College adopted here in Strasbourg this afternoon. I can tell you that the ink on the proposal is, almost literally, not dry yet. Free movement for workers and the free provision of services are two of the four fundamental freedoms of our internal market. Since I took office, I have hardly ever heard these fundamental freedoms questioned, but I have often heard concerns on four specific aspects: first the impact of mobility on sending and receiving countries; second, the actual enforcement of existing rules; third, specific imbalances perceived as unfair; and, fourth, the need to ensure a level playing field within the single market. I am deeply convinced that we should not ignore these concerns, but address them. What should be the key building blocks of our response? First, our response should not be to shy away from labour mobility. We must promote the values of free movement that the European Union stands for and underline the medium and long-term benefits for our citizens, labour markets and our societies. Second, we need rules that are clear, fair and enforced on the ground. This is not always the case today. There is room for improvement. In my opinion, we now have four instruments in place that already offer national authorities more and better tools to make sure that free movement is fair and well managed. We have EURES, we have the platform to fight undeclared work, we have the enforcement directive on free movement of workers, and we have the enforcement directive on posting of workers. All these four instruments should be implemented swiftly. My services are providing active assistance to Member States but, once the transposition deadlines for the directives have expired in June, the Commission will also not hesitate to take enforcement measures if needed. A fair European labour market will only exist if the measures that we have adopted are also implemented. Implementing the rules we have in place is, of course, one part of the answer. Going further, we also need to improve, update and strengthen rules where needed. With this objective in mind, we finalised the preparation of a labour mobility package at the end of last year but, as you know, we decided to postpone its adoption until after the European Council where the UK issue was to be settled in order to avoid any interference with ongoing political discussions. With the UK deal on the table now, it is clear that we cannot proceed with our proposal to amend the social security coordination rules in Europe until we know the outcome of the UK referendum, but there is another aspect of fair labour mobility, posting, on which we could proceed. The Commission has today adopted the legislative proposal that we announced in our work programme 2016. I want to be very clear about my political view. We need more posting in Europe, not less. There are now about 1.9 million postings per year, a steep increase but still less than 1% of our workforce. There is potential for more and the Commission will continue to push for removing barriers to cross-border service provision, as stated in our internal market strategy. But, whilst pushing for more cross-border service provision and for more posting, we should also make sure that the system is organised in a fair way – fair for workers and fair for businesses. Much has been said and written about the articulation between internal market rules and social rules in Europe. For some, market rules should prevail and for others, social protection, but the truth is that the essence of the European social model is that both can and should go hand in hand. That was the core objective of the 1996 Posting of Workers Directive and it remains the objective now: to promote cross-border services, whilst guaranteeing worker protection and a level playing field between local and cross-border service providers. In the 20 years that have passed since the adoption of the 1996 directive, the European labour market has of course changed. With 28 Member States the divergences in wage levels and wage systems between Member States have significantly increased. Instead of convergence we see more divergence, and this has an impact on posting. The gap in minimum wages has increased from a 1:3 ratio in 1996 to a 1:10 ratio today. The differences in the constituent elements of remuneration in each country have also increased. Is a worker entitled to a 13th-month bonus, a Christmas premium, bad weather or travelling time compensation? The current posting rules do not provide a clear answer to this and this gives rise to uncertainty and disputes on a daily basis. That is bad for the posted workers, who may find it difficult to have their rights respected. It is also bad for posting firms as it increases transaction costs, and some even give up on the idea of posting because it is simply too complicated. In a highly competitive internal market, competition is based on quality, productivity and innovation. Labour costs are only one element, but competition based solely on wages is not in the interest of workers or business, nor of the competitiveness of Europe in a globalised economy. Whilst the construction sector still accounts for around 43% of postings, postings have spread to other sectors as well. Journalists, bankers, health care providers and others are posted today. They too should be protected, which under the current directive is not always guaranteed. Finally, we see growing trends of outsourcing and sub-contracting in the labour market. While sub-contracting continues to make a lot of sense when it gives access to more specialised skills and more efficiency, it creates unfairness and market distortions when sub-contracting firms are not subject to the same rules on remuneration. When undercutting local wage norms is the main reason for outsourcing, it leads to unfairness, segmentation of the labour market and downward, instead of upward, convergence. That is not the internal market we want and it is not the internal market we promised our citizens. It is clear that we need a targeted revision of the 1996 Posting Directive to address those issues and to update the rules to today’s context. I know many of you recall the difficult discussions on the Enforcement Directive. I remember those as well, as a Member of this Parliament at that time, but I sincerely believe that, this time too, we can come to an agreement. Since my first day in office, I have listened very carefully to representatives of various political groups, Member States and stakeholders, and I have noted the following requests in particular: better protection for posted workers, a level playing field between domestic and cross-border service providers, the need for more transparency and more legal certainty, respect for the principles of proportionality and non-discrimination , and also of course respect for the subsidiarity principle and for national wage-setting systems. The proposal that the Commission adopted today addresses those concerns in a balanced way. We propose targeted adjustments to the provisions on remuneration, building on recent judgments of the Court of Justice, and with full respect for specificities and national circumstances. It will no longer be the minimum rate of pay only, but all provisions on remuneration in the host country that will apply to posting. We will align the directive with the rules on social security so that both for social security purposes and for labour law purposes workers posted for longer than 24 months will be considered as integrated in the labour market of the host country, and we will better align the Posting of Workers Directive with the directive on temporary agency work: rules applicable to local workers must be applied to posted workers as well. I hope you will study our proposal – the official one, not the unofficial ones which I have seen commented on in the press in recent days. I hope you will study our proposal with an open mind and with a constructive approach. As you know, I am ready to come back to Parliament and discuss it at any time. The Commission will continue to work constructively with the co-legislators and, of course, also with Parliament, with pleasure and with the aim of coming to a good agreement.

name: David CASA
text: – nixtieq nibda dan id-diskors tiegħi billi nirringrazzja flower-gumssar marianne thyssen għaliex naħseb irrid nirringrazzjaha għall-kuraġġ illi kellha biexġ tera' tibda diskusjoni dwar din id-direttiva, illi ma kinitx direttiva perfetta u naturalment kellna aspetti – anki aħna bħna partit Popolari – li frog naħsbu li għandhom bżonn jiġu rranġati.  Issa naturalment, direttiva importanti bħal din ħa ssib kontroversja u mhux kulħadd se jaqbel miegħek. Jiena wkoll kelli diskussjoni twila fi ħdan il-partit tiegħi u ma kienx faħli biex il-Partit Popolari Ewropew jasal għall-consensus li għandna llum il-proposta ġdida li qed tressaqddie qumna l-Gumssarju.  Naturalment l-appell tiegħi hawn illum huwa issa fuq il-group politi大i l-oħra kollha. Jiena naħse illi i nistgħux f'dal-mumenti nkunu popolisti. Hemm bżonn illi flimkien, dan il-Parlament iwassal messaġġ hemm barra illi aħna magħqudin, illi aħna rridu nsibu kompromess; u jiena nwiegħed lil din il-kamra li, flimkien mar-rapporteur li se jkolli fil-ftit tal-ġranet oħra, jien ħa nagħmel ħilti kollha biex naħdem flimkien ma' heads rapporteur u coordinatur tal-group collhaike politii biexsibu dan il-kompromess; għax hawnhekk għandna bażi biex insibu dan il-kompromess, u jekk insibu bażi għall-kompromess f'dan il-Parlament inkunu qegħdin nibgħatu messaġ bġ'saħħtu flower-Kunsill; għaliex aħna rridu li l-Kunsill ukoll jara li dan il-kompromess li jintlaħaq hawn jintlaħaq ukoll fil-Kunsill. (Il-kelliem qabel li jwieġeb għal mistoqsija "karta blu" skont l-Artikolu 162(8) tar-Regoli ta' Pro大edura).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I believe that when you have turned to the other factions, I must ask the Socialists a question in any case – although this is not just for you. How do you think it is feasible to pay at least the local minimum wage for outsourced workers, or where there is no minimum wage, at least try to find a European average? How can this even be achieved in your opinion?

name: David CASA
text: tweġiba karta blu. – Onestament ma fhimtx eżattament x'ried jgħid il-ħabib tiegħi min-naħa tal-S&D Group; però, li kont qiegħed nipprova ngħid jiena huwa li, naturalment, mhux kulħadd ħa jieħu dak kull ma jrid. Jiena naħseb li, fuq dan l-arranġament li waslet għalih il-Kummissarju, hemm bżonn li jkollna "a give and take situation". Hemm bżonn li nsibu kompromess dwar mhux kif se nirbaħ jien biss, imma kif se nagħti biħi minn tiegħi biex it-tnejn li aħna nirbħu. Dan hu l-mument, f'dan il-Parlament, li nsibu kompromess għaliex jekk inkunu popolisti, kulħadd se jitlef: aħna, il-Gumssjoni, il-Kunsill u, fl-aħħar mill-aħħħar, il-ħaddiema li għandhom bżonn liraw lilna naqblu biex ikunu jiġu jiġuggiwardwardjati d-drittijiet tagħhom.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We are not concerned with restricting postings, but with ensuring that postings within Europe are made fair. Mrs Thyssen, I am very pleased that the Commission has realised that the Enforcement Directive alone is not enough, but that it is really necessary to approach the actual directive. It was only under pressure from the trade unions and we Social Democrats that last week's draft was improved at the weekend. The Commission could have saved itself this if it had actually taken the social dialogue seriously. The principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place must apply to everyone, including posted workers. But this must also apply to all types of collective agreements. It must also be clear that minimum standards must not be interpreted as maximum standards, and that Member States must be able to continue to lay down stricter rules to protect workers. We welcome the fact that, for the first time, a limit on the duration of posting is to be established. However, 24 months is unrealistic. If we look at the construction industry, for example, half of the posted construction workers work there for less than half a year. A limit of six months must be the objective in order to actually improve the situation. In addition, the real problems must be addressed: chain postings, endless subcontractor chains without clear responsibility, letterbox companies, bogus self-employment, posting by temporary employment agencies, workers being bruised for wages and social benefits, distortion of competition through lower social security contributions. These points must be at the heart of the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive and the announced revision of the coordination of social security systems. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Steinruck, I would like to thank Mrs Steinruck for her work on this report. They come, like me, from Germany. You have just spoken of the principle of equal pay at the same place of work for the same work. I would be interested to know: How do you define the topic of "equal place of work" for Germany, for example? Is this a region, is it a federal state, is it the whole of Germany? As you know, we have very different wages for equal work, in relation to Germany. I'd be interested in that.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Yes, that was my concern. I have said that all regional, all sectoral collective agreements, including minimum wages, must form the basis of the Posting of Workers Directive. If two people work in one place and do the same work, then the same principle of pay and social security contributions must also apply. I think that's fair.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, we have just been speaking about better law-making in this Parliament. I have to say that this is not a good example. It is the opposite of better law-making. I think it is a really bad idea to reopen this file while we are still waiting for the implementation of the enforcement directive in the Member States. I know that this is a targeted revision but it is still not something I welcome. With regard to the detail, the principle of remuneration for the protection of workers is very much wider than the original directive, which refers to pay. This is likely to have an adverse impact on smaller businesses, on our SMEs, and while the proposal is not directly referring to equal pay for equal work in the same place, I suspect that this is an attempt by the Commission to push ahead with that ambition. We must be very careful that we do not create another law with unintended consequences. (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question)

name: David CASA
text: – Mr President, in response to what Mr Aker has just said with regard to my colleague declining to take his blue card question, I think that every Member has a right not to accept a blue card, and he should not have called her a chicken. I am sorry, but these words should not be used and cannot be used in this plenary.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: on the alde group. – Mr President, the proposal for a revision of the Posting of Workers Directive was a considerable surprise to us. After all, the same issue has already been addressed by the previous regulation, which is an acceptable and balanced compromise between the principle of the freedom to provide services and the need to ensure adequate protection for workers, including minimum wage rules. So I ask at the outset: What objective does the Commission see in revising the legal framework at a time when the time for implementing the rules in force has not even passed and their results are not known? Is such an approach not contrary to the principles of better regulation which the Commission has undertaken to comply with?  The Commission expects the new revision to create a better competitive environment and ensure better pay conditions. But will this be true across Europe? Is the Commission not worried about reducing the competitiveness of enterprises from economically less developed Member States and, by extension, jeopardising the jobs of posted workers? Has the Commission taken into account the real economy in the Member States, including different pay levels? I am afraid that the new proposal will lead to a dispute between the Member States and once again increase barriers to labour mobility. The new concept of rules is not legally defined at EU or Member State level and will have a negative impact on the cross-border business of SMEs, which are the backbone of the European economy. A Europe that is not competitive on the inside cannot succeed even globally. And I think right now we need that competitiveness as much as we can. So I can guarantee you that the ALDE Group will do its best to preserve Europe's competitiveness and its fundamental principles.

name: Thomas HÄNDEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the In the last four years, the deployment in Europe has exploded. That would not be a bad thing if the reports of abuse had not also exploded. The Commission has started – and the attempt is laudable – to put an end to this abuse. Moreover, Mr Juncker has announced that he will enforce the principle of 'equal pay for equal work in the same place'. When I now read the documents that I know, I have to say that what is in it is not equal pay for equal work in the same place. There is still a lack of back sand and back.  If posted workers are only treated on an equal footing with local workers after 24 months, that is not enough. We have not solved the problem of general contractor liability. Wage dumping is still en masse in the subcontracting chains. This also applies to public procurement.  We have not solved the problem of bogus self-employed people who are still being sent instead of posted workers, as workers who are not. We still have abuses of posting by temporary employment agencies in Europe, and we have one thing above all: we have not resolved the effective control of the Member States over posting, because information between Member States is not properly regulated. This proposal is not enough, Commissioner; we need to improve on that. If the Commission does not put forward anything better, Parliament is now called upon to achieve equal pay for equal work in the same place.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, my thanks to the Commissioner for the presentation. I think we all understand the need to ensure that workers are well protected wherever they are from and wherever they are working and that they are not exploited and that their companies operate within the law. We want to ensure that posting is not used as a mechanism to deliberately exert downward pressure on wages and standards. We are aware that there is concern around posted workers in a number of areas and sectors and we recognise that the implementation directive has yet to be transposed in all Member States and many of us have a concern that a lot of Member States do not actually have adequate resources in terms of labour inspection for that to be fully effective.  So we were asked to look at whether the proposals answer the concerns. I think some of us have yet to be convinced. I think we want to know whether we can have more than the limited nature of collective agreements that are, I admit, contained here – they are in line with the ECJ, but could we go further? Should we not be looking at including sectoral and company agreements, and if they are not in here, why not? In terms of remuneration packages it appears better than simply covering pay, especially when we see so many states with minimum wages rather than living wages, but while equal pay in the same place sounds like a good idea I think for some people we ought to consider that a drop in pay may not be so attractive for all workers. I think we need to look at this in the full range to make sure that we are really addressing the concerns we have.

name: Tim AKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the Posting of Workers Directive allows companies to ship in foreign workers to another country where there are still unemployed people desperate to find jobs. People will remember the Lindsey Oil Refinery strikes in 2009, which were a direct result of this legislation, and it is this relentless drive towards a single state, with no regard for national borders or standards of living, that angers people in the United Kingdom. Workers brought in on a temporary basis do not have rent or mortgages to pay, they are often housed and looked after by the company. My constituents do not have that luxury – working or not, they still have bills that need paying, and that is the fundamental problem of this Directive and the EU’s freedom of movement. It is a race to the bottom in terms of wages and standards of living. Big business gets away with paying the minimum wage and we end up having a wave of economic migration that drives down wages. It is becoming ever clearer that the European Union is out for big business. Its policies have driven down wages and that will be its downfall. On 23 June, every worker who has been undercut, every worker who has lost their job, every worker who has lost out through open-door immigration, they will have their say. The EU is about the few, but it is the many that will set Britain free.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to start by thanking the Commissioner for the fact that employment and social policy issues are at the heart of the current European Commission. These issues should be treated with special care and care by us. I wonder, however, why the Commission has so hastily decided to revise the Posting of Workers Directive. Less than two years ago, after lengthy and difficult negotiations, all political groups and Member States adopted an implementation directive which, together with the current rules on posting, provides an appropriate compromise between worker protection and the freedom to provide services. Personally, I regret that the Commission did not wait for the implementation of the implementation directive and has missed the position of many Member States and the social partners on this issue.  In the Commission's view, a change in the rules on posting is necessary in order to achieve greater social cohesion in the Union and to ensure fair conditions of competition for companies. However, when it comes to the need to equate the burden of labour costs, the Commission forgets that companies that delegate employees bear a number of costs that local companies do not have to cover. In this situation, we may face discrimination against foreign actors, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, which can effectively undermine the competitiveness of the single market. Let us remember that posted workers are the most likely to fill the shortfall in local labour markets, and the bulk of postings – more than 60% – are posted between workers of the Western European Union. Creating barriers to the provision of services can lead to a reduction in posting, an increase in the grey economy – we already have such cases – and, consequently, less social cohesion.  I very much hope that, during the work in the European Parliament and in the Council, we will be able to reach a compromise which, as the Commissioner said, will develop ... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – Last weekend in my own country, the main news was that hundreds of employees from Romania were working for one euro at Dutch shipyards, hired through a Dutch agency with a letterbox in Romania. Unfortunately, that wasn't an incident. There is nothing to blame for the Romanian workers, but the people who deliberately seek out the loopholes do. Some people say that you are too quick to review the Posting of Tax Directive. I am inclined to say that you are finally seeing that a Union of 28 different labour markets can only exist by guaranteeing fair labour mobility and protection of workers. Your proposal for the adaptation of the Posting of Posting of Work directive is a step in the right direction. I welcome the extension of chain responsibility and obligations for employment agencies to reward workers equally when they are in the host country. But that doesn't get the job done. There are still major differences in social contributions between Member States, as is the case with Romanian workers working in the Netherlands at the shipyards. In the Netherlands it is called 'premium shopping'. Again, there is still no level playing field and that is necessary. I therefore look forward to your proposals for the coordination of social security later this year, because it is only by setting equal pay for equal work in the same workplace that we can maintain support and solidarity in the Union, even in the future.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. I am surprised by the Commission that, at such a difficult time as the European Union is today, another front of the fight is being opened, which may further divide the Member States. The restriction on the free movement of services – because this is the actual effect of the proposed amendments to the Posting of Workers Directive – will lead, above all, to an increase in unemployment in the European Union, including to a large extent a decrease in employment in Poland. Consumers, too, whose increase in the price of services will be affected in the first place, will also be victims of the Commission's proposals. So who will benefit from these changes? Supporters of protectionism and restrictions of competition by administrative methods, which, especially in Western Europe, have recently been arriving, as we can see, for example by observing the European car transport market. Economic integration must not be limited to the most aised countries and create artificial barriers to cross-border entrepreneurship. These changes are a step that will perpetuation of the division into poor and rich countries in the European Union, a step that we must firmly oppose.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, so finally we have it, the proposal to amend the Posting of Workers Directive. President Juncker and the Commissioner promised us the same pay for the same work in the same place, and this is it. I for one am happy to see it.  The Directive is 20 years old and during that time there have been many cases before the ECJ – the Rüffert case, the Laval case, the Viking case. There has been uncertainty surrounding the provisions of the directive and certain abuses, and while I believe the Enforcement Directive will deal with some of them, it cannot deal with all.
