There is still a core issue between Article 45 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which guarantees equal treatment and Article 56, which guarantees employers’ rights to provide services across borders. Article 45 guarantees equal treatment for seasonal and temporary agency workers, for fixed and part-time workers and for men and women, but not for posted workers. In some sectors, such as construction for example, there are wage gaps of 30% and more between local and posted workers, and in countries where posted workers make up a reasonable amount of that sector, posting can and does exercise a downward trend on wages. Yes, we need competition between companies, but as the Commissioner herself said, that must be based on many different elements. It must be based on productivity and expertise and innovation, on the type and quality of service and not just exclusively on wages. I, like Mr Casa, Commissioner, thank you for your courage in bringing forward this proposal. It is a start.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: Mr President, justice and the creation of a common area between European workers do not need a semblance of a revision of the 'detached workers' directive. The one you are proposing, Commissioner, maintains the competition of employees within the European Union. We therefore ask you to draw up a new directive based on a consultation with trade union organisations, with the aim of ensuring that seconded workers have a real level of equal treatment in terms of pay, social protection and working conditions. It should be complemented by the creation of a European body of labour inspectors to enforce a high level of labour law. The European institutions should become the source of new economic, social and democratic rights for all workers, otherwise it will be increasingly rejected, as is currently the case.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Mr President, the future of the European Union is under threat. Many citizens are no longer convinced that the EU can actually live up to the promises it has made. Sometimes even I ask myself whether we are doing enough to create a fair labour market that protect workers from exploitation, makes our societies more just and is also resilient in times of crisis. With this proposal on amending the Posting Directive we can say quite clearly that we are not going far enough. We are not delivering on the promise to protect workers from exploitation, especially those workers who are most dependent on a socially sound European legislation: posted workers. In this debate we would actually need a Commission that is specifically defending the rights of those workers who cross borders and thus very often become more vulnerable, and we would need Member States that take their task of the enforcement of existing legislation seriously.  It is a shame that we live in one of the richest regions in the world and we are still not capable of protecting workers from unlawful, and sometimes dangerous, working conditions and sanctioning employers who are abusing the system. We need to work on this and I hope that with this proposal we will move forward to come to such a situation.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in 2014, the European Commission issued an implementing directive to prevent social dumping against workers temporarily sent to another Member State and to expose the fraud committed by the so-called 'letterbox' companies. Unfortunately, however, discussions in Parliament and between the Member States have held back and prevented a serious assessment and a serious solution to the problem.  Unfortunately, the directive still leaves important vulnus uncovered, as Member States have too much freedom to apply or not apply control measures and related sanctions to punish blatantly uncovered cases of abuse. Furthermore, unfortunately, too much confidence is given to the ability and willingness of Member States to provide that assistance, that information to the host States to detect and punish irregularities and fraud, and, in addition, there is so much confusion about the principle of proportionality, and it will undermine, if not properly addressed, the effectiveness of the directive.  There are many points to analyze on which to work in an extremely correct, complete and effective way this time.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Mr President, Commissioner Thyssen, I would like to thank commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. I would like to start by thanking you for what you have presented today and for what you have also presented. I think that really is a very good basis for us to work with. It is important that we in Europe also look at this issue again. It is clear that not everything is going as we would like on this issue in Europe. I would warn, however, that we should be lump-sum-based, but I would say that we must look at the data and the facts. Not every posted worker in Europe is a problem. It is often discussed that there is only the posting of low-wage countries to high-wage countries and that wage dumping will then occur. But that is not the case everywhere. We have about 50 to 60% of the dispatches where this is the case. The other part, however, goes from high-wage to low-wage countries. With regard to workers where there are problems, of course that is the case, and we are abusing them, for example in the construction industry or in slaughterhouses or in the service sector, and we must counteract this. We are happy to do so as we mentioned in the PPE social paper: a targeted revision – I have no problem with that. What is important afterwards is the content that is in it. A second issue that I would like to raise again: the issue of equal pay for equal work in the same place of work. It sounds great, it sounds very good. But I think it's hard or impossible to implement. After all, what does "equal pay" mean? Is the gross wage, net wage, how long service, how does that play with? "Same work", how do you compare that? And the same place, the same country, the same state, the same region? This will be a long discussion. We are ready for that.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, you and, above all, President Juncker have repeatedly promised proposals that would provide equal pay for equal work and to be the defender of social dialogue, that is to say that it is employers and trade unions that should drive wage movements, not politics. A week ago, a Commission proposal was leaked which went completely in the opposite direction and aroused very strong feelings. Now we have a new proposal, I am grateful for that, it looks better, it is worth evaluating, then we will see what the analysis provides. What we do know, however, is that Europe will need more mobility in the labour market, and that makes it even more important to have equal pay for equal work, not pay according to where it comes from. You, Mrs Thyssen, have repeatedly pointed out the reasonable fact that we previously had some kind of biological salary, i.e. pay by sex. Women automatically had lower wages than men. What you are sticking to now is geographically justified wages, i.e. that where you come from is more important than what work you do. It's completely unreasonable, it's nineteenth century by my standards.  This must be changed, and this must be the result of the new survey you are making and the new proposals you are presenting. We are prepared in our Employment Committee to work with you, but then we cannot go in our own direction.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, twenty years ago trade unions demanded a directive to ensure the labour protection of posted workers. We do not achieve this because the European Union has placed the provision of services above labour rights. In other words, competition in the single market is competition between workers, is an erosion of their labour rights and wages for the benefit of employers.  The Commission is under pressure to implement changes, but we are a long way from Juncker's commitment to 'equal pay for equal work in the same place'. The introduction of 'necessary' remuneration is ambiguous and expressly excludes deferred wages from Social Security. Displaced workers remain outside sectoral agreements and must wait twenty-four months for the labour standard to be fully implemented, when the average displacement is four months.  We oppose minimum legislation consolidating an unprotected workforce, which is already almost two million, having grown by 45% as a result of forced mobility and widespread erosion of working conditions since the onset of the crisis. We need – and it is a pending challenge – deep labour harmonisation.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, finally the Commission is talking about a social Europe. Alas, your proposal remains half-hearted. Of course, you make some useful improvements, starting with ensuring equal pay for equal work in the same workplace. But, beware, let's stop the slogans! We must go further, we must go faster, with real safeguards to the abuses of detachment in Europe: to establish a real blacklist of fraudulent companies, to prohibit the continued detaching of workers in case of fraud. All this is crucial before it is too late, Commissioner. What for? Because social dumping is the symbol of the struggle between the proponents of Europe that protects and the proponents of Europe that is destroying. In the absence of agreement on strengthened controls and the implementation of genuine measures for social harmonisation from the top, it is the very destiny of our Union that is at stake. That is why we environmentalists continue to fight for a European body of labour inspectors, in order to carry out effective checks, but also for a European minimum wage, European unemployment insurance and universal European health coverage. The enduring union of Europeans is at this price.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: First of all, I am pleased that this proposal is now on the table and that we can get started. We all know that there are rather different opinions on the posting directive between the Member States, but also here in Parliament. That is why I would also like to congratulate Mrs Thyssen on her fortitude in this matter. This is an important proposal to improve the position of two million seconded people in Europe and to put an end to unfair competition in the labour market. The free movement of services and people is an extremely important foundation of the internal market, but it must be done in a fair way: not only free mobility, but also fair mobility, on a level playing field. The proposal is in response to two of the major priorities I have in this area. First of all, the duration of posting. Secondment is by definition temporary and should also be regulated as such. Exactly how long the secondment can and will take can and will still be debated in this House, but the proposal to limit the duration is very good. The same applies to the proposals for the remuneration of posted workers. This can be clearer, more transparent, better for the posted worker and better for the labour market, and a number of good proposals have been made there too. This proposal by Commissioner Thyssen is a balanced proposal, a good basis for starting our work here. I hope that here in the European Parliament, from left to right and from east to west, north and south, we will continue in the same balanced way.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Mr President, I was going to start by explaining to our UKIP colleague what this is about: that the whole point is that it is about preventing the freedom of movement from being abused to undercut terms and conditions in local markets. It does not have to be like that and we can prevent it being like that. I was going to explain that to him, but of course he is not here because he has done his 60 seconds for YouTube and then buggered off to the bar, as they always do. But while I have got 30 seconds left, let me just congratulate the Commissioner on actually listening and actually making a difference. Lots of colleagues have talked about how much work remains to be done on this. Universal collective bargaining is no use to us at all in the UK because we do not use that kind of system; we need sectoral- and company—level collective bargaining.  24 months is no use; we need 6 months. But on the principle of having listened and come back with a different proposal, I thank the Commissioner.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, you yourself said that the competition that takes place is usually unfair competition. It takes place on wages, non-wage labour costs and also the non-payment of social security contributions, so unfortunately not about the great ideas or innovations of companies.  I therefore have a specific question for you in this connection with the proposal, which is super important and which I think is a good thing that it is finally on the table. In Austria, orders are often awarded to companies that are ultimately the lowest bidders. These lowest-paid bidders do work with employees who are posted over two years. So, and now the following is happening: there is a Certificate A1 that social security contributions are paid in the country of origin. However, they are not being paid, and we are not getting a grip on it, because cooperation beyond borders does not work. Will these amendments, which you are proposing, finally make the interplay between the Posting of Workers Directive, the Enforcement Directive and the Social Security Directive work?

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we finally have the text of the long-awaited reform of the Posting of Workers Directive, a targeted reform, as defined by Commissioner Thyssen, which operates on three main fronts: the remuneration of posted workers, including in the case of subcontracting, the rules on temporary workers and long-term posting.  Of course, it will be necessary to analyse very carefully the scope of these provisions, in particular whether these few changes presented are capable of creating in reality the declared objective of an effective right to equal pay for equivalent work in the same place, which is a fundamental objective for our group.  My first hot impression is mixed. I am certainly pleased that the Commission has decided to get its hands on the Posting Directive rather than give in to pressure from those in this House too who would have preferred to await the results of the 2014 implementing directive, thus ignoring the seriousness of an already all-too-obvious problem.  However, I am sceptical that what has been proposed is sufficient, given the scale of the problem. I am convinced that, as a Parliament, we will be able to strengthen the text together.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: – No proposal is perfect. Even what Mrs Thyssen proposes will not be good for everyone. For some it goes too far and for others it does not go far enough. In any case, the proposal is balanced, and that is a very great credit. Attention is paid to the interests of workers and a level playing field for companies is created. Within the margin of competence between which the Commissioner can manoeuvre, she has succeeded in achieving her principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place, without directly intervening in national wage formation. This deserves our recognition. The Commission is making a good move with the proposal, but it is us as Parliament and the Member States who now have to take the ball in. In order to eliminate the abuses involved in secondment, these Member States must also focus on monitoring and information exchange. We all know that only effective control of legislation and thorough, preferably digital, cooperation between Member States provides the necessary guarantee to tackle the problem of social dumping. Here too, we urgently need to step up a notch if we are to restore the credibility of the European project to the citizens.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the effort made by the Commission is undoubtedly useful. The result is very disappointing. I, you see, have no ideological opposition to free movement, but I think that mobility can be an important tool in competitive models, in company systems or in individual companies. Provided, however, that there is equal pay, equal contributions and equal regulation.  Otherwise, mobility becomes an instrument for social dumping, with significant damage to competition as a whole and also, of course, to the people involved. Equality, in the proposal that you make, is not on any of these issues. We're going to have to start over. This will have to be done very carefully because the situation does not stand still in the meantime.  I want to say two very quick things about the time for stabilisation: 24 months is not just a long time; they are contrary to what is provided for, for example, in the legislation for seasonal work. In the same way, I would like to remind all of us that in the agreement between the European Union and the United Kingdom there are rules that alter the protection of people, and that is also a problem that we will have to address.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the directive really helps to prevent social dumping against workers, to be able to have mobility of workers, and that is very important. But there is a bilingualism, and bilingualism is this: In the agreement made by the Heads of State or Government to settle the Issue of Britain there are now provisions under which there will be discrimination on grounds of nationality for new entrants to the British labour market, so that they no longer have rights a source of industrial relations. They won't have housing benefit. They won't have tax breaks. They won't have any more benefits.  Does this have anything to do with the European Union? What are we talking about? Discrimination is made against workers on grounds of nationality. This is at the expense of four hundred thousand Greek scientists. The same goes for others. So how do we talk here about worker mobility? Stop bilingualism in this House at last!

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, the european Union's obsession with the Member States has been to reach greater levels of economic integration. Meanwhile, they left behind the most relevant convergence: social convergence.  When the needs of European citizenship pass through a truly social Europe, we cannot turn a deaf ear or look the other way. We must build a Europe where rights are equal, taking as a reference the most democratic and socially developed countries and not the other way around.  We need an administration that cares about reducing inequalities rather than increasing them. As long as this asymmetric model continues to operate, we will be generating a fraud to the values of the European Union. In this direction, all measures aimed at curbing social dumping must be supported.  We will therefore support a revision of the Displaced Workers Directive which actually captures the labour rights of those who do work outside their borders and unfair business practices are fought.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, by reopening this directive on seconded workers, you are tackling an issue used by populists who prefer to exacerbate the national retreat. You are brave to reopen this targeted review and to say your objective clearly: more mobility in Europe, because what we want is to facilitate job creation, to facilitate business dynamics and for everyone here to have a job and social protection at European level. Yes, we are working, through this text, for all European workers, for the dynamics of employment. We must mobilise the Member States to fight fraud, to implement these European texts, to build here, all together - and I see the beginnings of this evening, I have heard it , points of consensus that allow us all to move forward together. Please know, Commissioner, that we will be by your side!

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, today more than 8 million EU citizens are working or looking for work in another Member State. Most of them are well-trained professionals. In addition, there are 1.6 million frontier workers in Europe. They work in a different country than where they live. Finally, there are posted workers who carry out short seconds abroad. There's about 1.5 million of them. Whether the employee belongs to any of the above categories, this is essential: they are equally paid for equal work. A two-storey labour market in which foreigners earn significantly less than domestic workers simply does not work and causes a lot of problems. They also distort competition between companies and go against the fundamental values of the EU.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, I strongly agree with the viewpoint of the Commission, according to which the development of any legislation should be based upon well informed and evidence-based decisions. This is why I cannot find the logic in modifying the Posting of Workers Directive when the transposition deadline of the Enforcement Directive has not even lapsed yet and before its effects can be felt. New action should only be taken after it has been ensured that the existing – properly enforced and controlled – legislation is not enough. I believe that this is especially true for the case at hand, where we are dealing with basic principles of the single market: freedom of movement and freedom to provide services across borders. We should be extremely cautious that in our efforts to fight abuses, fraud and lack of enforcement, which I agree is needed, we do not run the risk of creating bureaucratic and other barriers to labour mobility and, ultimately, to European competitiveness.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: member of the Commission. √ I will be brief, because I have had a very long introduction, but I would like to thank you for the rich debate. As I expected, it is too much for one, for the other too little; for one we come up with proposals too quickly and for the other we do not come forward with proposals quickly enough. What I remember above all – and I am very positive and optimistic about this – is that I have heard a great deal of willingness among Members of Parliament, among many people, to listen to each other, to work together and to see how we can bring this exercise to a good conclusion. I have seen this in many groups, and I very much appreciate it.  I would like to say this: why are we now coming up with this proposal and why are we not waiting for the enforcement directive that we adopted in 2014 to be transposed? The reason is very clear: the enforcement directive has been put in place to ensure that the Member States have more instruments in their hands and would work better together to make the rules that are in place better apply. The Enforcement Directive is there to combat fraud and abuse and to ensure that the rules are ultimately better enforced. To do this, the Member States needed more instruments, and they got them through that enforcement directive. That's a good piece of legislation. We encourage the Member States to implement this directive in a timely and qualitative manner. We expect them to do that by June 18, because that's the limit date.  But that's not enough. We must also have the courage to look at the rules themselves, at the material rules we apply. We have seen that there are shortcomings there too, and that is why this Commission promised you when it took office that we would do the same and that we would move towards a focused review, focusing on the principle of equal pay for equal work. That is why we must act now and not wait for this enforcement directive to be implemented and for it to be evaluated. In the meantime, we cannot allow time to continue without looking at the basic rules themselves. I believe that we still have plenty of time and, above all, sufficient opportunity to discuss the technical details, but I would like to give a brief answer on a few things. The operation of the A1 form, which shows that people who pay social security are subject to social security in their country of origin. The questioner has since left, but I can assure you that with the social security coordination proposals we will ensure that that A1 form becomes a useful and reliable document. I would also like to point out - because this question has been asked by several people - that we are moving towards maximum equality, equal pay for equal work in the same place and that we also want to give maximum effect to the collective agreements, but we must do so within the legislative framework in which we work. We go so far as to include in this directive the collective agreements concluded at the level of a separate company in some circumstances – and I invite you to read the texts very thoroughly. We must, of course, respect the principle of non-discrimination, and that limits the scope that we can give to it. But please read the proposal very thoroughly and you will see that we are giving maximum effect to the collective agreements, out of respect also for the social partners. What I would like to emphasise, then, is what I said in the explanatory statement to this proposal. We are committed to promoting mobility in Europe. In order to do that, we need clear and fair rules that can be enforced and that are actually observed in practice. But what we also need is for the rules to be accepted by the citizens as being fair. They must not only be fair, they must also be socially accepted. This is what inspires us in this proposal. I look forward to the debate that we are going to have together, that we are also going to have a debate with the various Member States of the European Union, and after hearing what goodwill is here in this European Parliament, I am convinced that we can find solutions together here too. Thank you for this debate and thank you in advance for the constructive attitude.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: Mr President, I would like you to be able to respond to my concern, because I saw during this debate on the detached workers directive that no member of the far-right group to which the National Front, the ENF or the ENL belongs in French, attended the debate or asked to speak. So I wanted to know if it was you who forbade them to speak or if, quite simply, they were completely disinterested in this debate, which, however, every election campaign, they turn our ears to fight against Europe. While we are doing some real substantive work, I could see that they were not here tonight.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Thank you, thank you. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. The Commission is presenting its draft targeted revision of the 'detachment' directive today. The principle would be that a seconded worker should be paid the same as a local worker, including bonuses and other benefits. No doubt this is favourable to the seconded worker, if not for the national unemployed, but frankly, I do not see how this solves the problem of social dumping and unfair competition.  Because this competition also lies in a difference in cost. In France, even if their wages are the same, a Romanian or Polish seconded worker will always cost less than a French or immigrant worker. And this will always give foreign companies a competitive advantage over their French competitors to win contracts, such as the organization of the PS summer universities or COP21, for example. It would also mean limiting the duration of the secondment to two years, which is already enormous, with the automatic transformation of the seconded worker into an immigrant worker after this period. And there, frankly, the consequences seem dizzying to me.  I am waiting to see the exact text of your proposals. As you have said yourself, Commissioner: you want more seconded workers, more cross-border services. That's the problem!

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – With regard to the Commission's review of the Posted Workers Directive, which has been one of the priorities of the Dutch Presidency, it is important to note that, according to the latest analysis by the Bruegel Institute in Brussels, less than half of the 1.2 million posted workers come from eastern European countries that joined in 2004. The three largest emitting countries are PL (228 thousand), DE (227 thousand) and FR (144 thousand). Any legislation in the field of social and employment should only be balanced, well-founded and proportionate. A further amendment to the amendment to the legislation adopted only a year and a half ago, the deadline for its implementation in the Member States expires only this summer, is completely unreasonable and there is no adequate comprehensive data and impact assessment of the functioning of the legislation.  Let's look at the facts. Posted workers account for less than half (0.3) % of the EU labour market, so we cannot talk about a significant group. The mobility of the European workforce is much smaller than that of goods or services, but it is also far below the mobility of the American or Japanese workforce. This is a competitive disadvantage for Europe. Furthermore, the EU is gradually losing its competitive advantage at international level. In 2010, the EU produced nearly 30% of the world's GDP, and this is expected to be halved by 2050. Thus, any intervention in the EU must also mean maintaining the unity of competitiveness and the internal market.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: in writing. – We are faced with a moment in history when mobility, in all its aspects, is a constant that contributes to improving the functioning of the single market, increasing competitiveness or reducing unemployment. From the EU we are taking firm steps towards greater social and labour integration and, therefore, the free movement of workers, freedom of establishment or the freedom to provide services are fundamental principles of the internal market. I thank the Commissioner for opting for a specific review, as the Compliance Assurance Directive has not yet been implemented in all Member States and we will have to assess its results in order to assess its effectiveness. It is clear that we need to work to combat fraud and abuse, which is why this specific review should be directed only to those unresolved aspects, in order to ensure fair treatment for workers and common rules of play for companies, but more importantly, freedom of service delivery must be ensured.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. The European Commission today presented its proposal to revise the rules governing the secondment of workers within the Union. It was time, when we know that the current directive has reached the canonical age of 20 years.  While the 1996 directive was designed to protect employees, it was largely diverted from its objective, paving the way for widespread social and fiscal competition between workers, businesses and social protection systems.  At first glance, several proposals in this project are interesting: seconded workers should be entitled to the same pay conditions as their colleagues working for the same company with a contract from the host country. They should also be able to benefit from the thirteenth month, Christmas or seniority bonuses if they exist in the sector that employs them.  However, these proposals do not rule out all abuses. This is particularly the case with social security contributions and the portability of the rights acquired by the employee in the host country.  This revision, finally initiated, revives the debate on the fight against social dumping. Social Europe is the prerequisite for the future of the European project.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – Free service provision and posting of workers are fundamental principles for freedom of movement and the European internal market. The last European directive on this subject was in 2014 and its entry into force will take place in a few months' time. Surprisingly, however, the European Commission came up with a revision of this directive, before it could even analyse the results of the implementation of the previous rules on the posting of workers. The reason would be to discover gaps in cross-border services, the protection of workers and equal treatment with regard to remuneration provisions (equal pay in equivalent employment on equal terms). Firstly, the Commission does not take into account the position of several Member States when it comes up with such a proposal. In addition, the Commission must be an engine to stimulate the economy and competitiveness in the labour market, not to hinder. Last but not least, the Commission must defend the rights of cross-border workers, the development of SMEs, boost competitiveness and competition in the labour market based on productivity, expertise, innovation and cost-effectiveness. I believe that the Commission's proposal is against the fundamental principle of the EU - the free movement of labour.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – The European Commission proposes to amend Framework Directive 96/71/EC on the posting of workers by a company from one Member State to carry out work in another Member State. I believe that some proposals to amend this directive will have a negative impact on labour mobility. Thus, the current directive clearly states that a posted worker must be granted at least the minimum wage in the country where he was posted. It is a clear provision, without any doubt of interpretation. Another criterion, unclear, susceptible to different interpretations and therefore abuses in implementation is proposed: to ensure 'the necessary remuneration for the protection of posted workers'. In addition to the fact that such a criterion is unclear, it also does not take into account the competitiveness of companies that post workers. I am convinced that, in the European Parliament, we will be able to get the Commission to abandon such changes.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - Between 2010 and 2014, the number of posted workers increased by as much as 45%, and in 2014 1.9 million European workers were posted to other Member States. It is therefore essential that new instruments are provided to improve administrative cooperation between the national referral authorities. The European Commission thus presented a reform of the Posting of Workers Directive in the context of the provision of services aimed at creating a more connected and fairer European labour market, which will complement the Directive on the implementation of the 2014 Posting of Workers Directive. In order to reach such a labour market, it is necessary to ensure the principle that equal pay is obtained for the same job in the same place and that workers are more easily referred in a spirit of fair competition, a level playing field and respect for workers' rights. A revision of the rules on posting of workers would change the remuneration of posted workers, rules on people working through temporary employment agencies and long-term posting, and would also increase worker protection, transparency and legal certainty.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – First of all, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her courage in reopening this directive, which is not perfect. You have worked very hard to come up with a proposal that could ultimately be acceptable to everyone. It has been two decades since the adoption of this directive, during which time the labour market has changed greatly. That, too, is already reason enough to change. We must ask ourselves whether the equal pay rule for equal work in the same place is indeed the right formula for both parties, for workers and employers. Whether this rule will uphold basic values or will threaten them. There are still big questions to ask. I would like to make one more point. An employment relationship is a relationship between two parties. It is right that we pay close attention to the protection of employees' rights, but on the other hand, we must not forget about employers. In particular, small and medium-sized enterprises, which are also part of this story and may become uncompetitive as a result of the measures.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. – The freedom to provide services, a fundamental freedom of the single market of the European Union, confers on undertakings the right to provide services in another Member State, in which they may temporarily second their own workers to the provision of those services. In this respect, Directive 96/71/EC lays down a number of conditions to ensure minimum protection for posted workers, which has, for example, enabled the posting of some 1.9 million European workers to other Member States in 2014. However, there is a proposal to revise this directive, on the part of the Commission, which is likely to constitute an obstacle to the free service and labour mobility. The proposal establishes that posted workers will benefit from the same rules governing working and pay conditions for local workers. In addition to the fact that these new provisions may constitute a breach of the principle of subsidiarity, moreover, they will most likely lead to a decrease in the number of Romanian companies operating in the territory of other Member States. Thus, this proposal could have negative effects on the competitiveness of those companies, leading to a decrease in the number of service contracts and the loss of jobs.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission: What is the 'social triple A' rating? [2015/3024(RSP)]

name: Thomas HÄNDEL
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the The social situation in Europe urgently needs a triple-A social rating. This has undoubtedly and obviously also reached the Commission. Everyone knows that we are still insisting on very high unemployment in Europe, albeit slightly, but it is only the officially registered one. We have a totally unacceptable rate of youth unemployment, and not only in the so-called crisis states. We have a situation where poverty in Europe reaches such a scale that a quarter of the European population lives at or below the OECD poverty line. We sometimes cheer about new jobs being created, but it is essentially precarious jobs that are created where people are poor in work. All this, it seems, the Commission has now grasped and is turning an initiative into a social triple-A. In October 2014, Jean-Claude Juncker ambitiously announced this project in a speech to the EP. Even the Five Presidents' Report on the completion of the European Economic and Monetary Union aims to strengthen the focus on employment and social affairs. EPSCO 2015 defined the conclusion of a vision for a social triple-A rating for Europe. I quote: 'Social policy should use its full potential and address social and employment challenges for achieving the common social and employment objectives in the Europe 2020 strategy'. These are all words. I recognise – also for the Commission, there is, I believe, no discussion – for the social issue in Europe, there is no simple and no general solution. But since the first announcement, the Commission has not delivered. No concrete and structured information about the progress of a social triple-A. There is now a communication from the Commission, but, Commissioner Thyssen, I am not getting much smarter from today's structured information. I am missing too much, there are generalities that any of us in this Parliament could sign. But there is no clear announcement as to what is happening. Firstly, how does the Commission define a social triple-A for Europe? Secondly, what are the specific details about the concept, the components and the objectives? Thirdly, what are the existing and, above all, what are new mechanisms, procedures and indicators and measurable steps, both inside and outside the European semester, for achieving these objectives? Fourthly, how will the instruments be used? Fifthly, what is the Commission's detailed timetable for a social triple-A? Sixthly, how to promote better upward social convergence based on common high-level standards? These are all questions that arise. But I am not yet at the end of my committee's questionnaire. What reforms and legislation does the Commission intend to promote at European and national level so that we can achieve greater social convergence? Eighthly, how should progress in this direction be reviewed? Finally, how does the Commission intend to install a social triple-A rating for the whole of the EU and not just for economic and monetary union? Do we not want to create a core Europe and a peripheral Europe, a two-speed Europe in the social sphere? These are questions that arise. Finally, I would like to make it clear that I believe that the social situation is the key issue, the absolutely crucial key issue, for a common Europe based on solidarity. That is why we do not have time until March 2017, we do not have the time to wait for a White Paper. There is now an urgent need for clear steps towards a stronger social Europe.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, since its first day in office, a key goal of this Commission has been to create a Europe worthy of a social triple—A rating. For me there is no doubt that it is an ambition – indeed, a commitment – that the economic strengthening of our Union goes hand in hand with improving people’s lives. This is the core of the European social model and a vital component of our social market economy. In my view, a triple—A social Europe requires fair and balanced growth that leads to the creation of decent quality jobs, as well as chances and protection for all throughout their life cycle. The Commission has put fairness at the core of our agenda and I am convinced that it is only by ensuring that social considerations are better integrated in all European policy areas that we will truly achieve a social Europe. The Commission has already taken concrete steps to make sure Europe deserves a triple—A rating. Within the European Semester we have deepened the analysis of employment and social performance and we have strengthened the role of social partners at European and national level. We have done a social impact assessment in parallel with the negotiations of the new support programme for Greece. We have proposed a recommendation to the Member States on the reintegration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market, which was adopted in February. We proposed – and the Parliament and the Council quickly accepted – to increase the pre-finance for the Youth Employment Initiative from one percent to 30 percent, which represented an advance payment of around EUR 1 billion. This has allowed for the projects under the Youth Employment Initiative to really take off. We adopted the proposal for the Accessibility Act, which will give persons with disabilities more opportunities and choices in their everyday life. The newly established European Platform against Undeclared Work will help to combat undeclared work throughout the Union and contribute to better working conditions in the EU. A new EURES regulation will make it easier for jobseekers to expand their job search into other Member States and will facilitate free movement of workers. In addition, we have just adopted today a proposal for the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive, which we discussed earlier, and there is some work underway for 2016. We foresee a fresh start to promote work—life balance for working parents, both men and women. We are also preparing a European Skills Agenda to be launched during the spring and, moreover, a comprehensive evaluation of the 24 occupational health and safety directives is ongoing. I intend to come forward with a proposal on carcinogens before the summer. In parallel with these concrete initiatives, we today launched a broad consultation on a first concrete outline of the European Pillar of Social Rights. President Juncker announced this initiative in his State of the Union address in September last year and the consultation will collect stakeholders’ views, including national parliaments’ and, of course, the European Parliament’s. I invite all of you to participate in the debate and also to come with the position of the Parliament if possible. We invite social partners at European and national level and civil society to participate in this debate.  Why a Pillar of Social Rights? Well, the European social model is a success story. The European Union is today the largest economy in the world and most of its citizens enjoy very high living standards. European values have materialised over time in a whole set of social rights, which are enshrined in national and European law as well as fundamental rights. However, we need to assess whether the European social model is still fit for purpose. We are confronted with long-term challenges and we are also still confronted with the aftermath of the crisis. I would say that it is time for a reality check. Are our European Union and our Member States’ policies on social affairs, in the broad sense of the word, still up to date? Are they future-proofed for the 21st century? Those are the questions. This is particularly important for the euro area because we know that more convergence, including on social and labour market policy is essential for more resilience and for better stability of economic and monetary union. This is why the Pillar of Social Rights will, in the first instance, be there for the Member States of the euro area. But of course other Member States are welcome to join if they so wish. I am convinced that this double track is the right way to advance for a social triple—A: to take concrete initiatives that address people’s concerns and have a real impact on the ground – we have already launched more than ten – and, secondly, to initiate a joint reflection on how we want our European social model to develop in the 21st century so that it continues to work for people to deliver growth and opportunities for all. I cannot encourage you more to participate in this big debate. I think you really have something to say there and I looking forward to continuing that debate too.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Following the inaugural speech by President Juncker and also by yours, we had high expectations of you, Mrs Thyssen. We think far too little has happened so far. A little more social issues in the European Semester, a five-president report that does not turn away from austerity, and a non-binding communication on combating long-term unemployment. Well, today, after a year and a half, there were first initiatives. But with the announcements you have made now, that does little concrete to make a real, real triple-A for social that the people of Europe expect. A simple summary of all social rights in the social pillar does not help workers, nor does the restriction to the euro countries combat unfair competition, wage and social dumping. The Commission's clear focus must be on combating precarious employment, tackling unemployment, reducing poverty and reducing social exclusion. For this we need, for example, the definition of an employee concept, we need living wages, a minimum income and also the strengthening of collective bargaining partners. Take social dialogue more seriously than before! Child guarantee, too, is a measure to combat poverty. In order to achieve a real social triple-A for Europe, the principle of equal pay for equal work must be firmly established. We will be fighting in the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive, in the introduction of the social pillar and in the revision of the coordination of social systems!

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In banking, triple-A stands for the highest credit rating – often a pitfall of credit rating agencies for bankrupt states in the fight against the mountain of debt.  I welcome Jean-Claude Juncker's idea of turning this term into social. Social activities have a special value, our market a social side. In Germany, the social market economy: at first only a term, today a concept for the whole of Europe. Then, as now, the word must be filled with deeds, otherwise it will remain a worthless shell. I am therefore pleased that we in the European Parliament are now taking up the concept and discussing it seriously. What can such a social triple-A look like for Europe? What exactly do we need to do? Where does Europe need to change? I am open to this discussion and i would like to involve people more than before.  Within the framework of the German Family Party, I call for social justice between parents and the childless in the labour market. We need to pay particular attention to this there.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I believe that when the Commission launches to use new words, it must take into account the seriousness of the issues it will be dealing with, so it was very necessary for the Commission to define very clearly what it understood as 'triple A' when it launched it and that it was not a boutade, a symbol or a so-called Truth? And we have done, I believe, very well to put you at the foot of the wall, as they say, to define that will that you maintain. I hope that it will remain as that symbol of great will for the creation of a social Europe, which is what it can do right now until we rescue the principle of European Union, and that it will not fall — I think I see it from what you have set out - in the idea of making a baremation of 'triple A+ A2 C'... with a custom scale, because it is a perverse and unbearable dynamic that would take us fifty years and, in the end, which agency is going to say what the scale is? I think that is ruled out; don't get in there. On the other hand, I would like you to absolutely prioritize this path to a better social Europe. Since they don't want to talk about employment, even though the first thing for a "triple social A" is to get to full employment, we're just going to talk about social policies. Please talk about poverty and how to combat poverty. Today, now. Talk about student circulation and education: Erasmus+, etc. Today, now. And please don't forget that protecting workers is not establishing protectionism. One last thing: what credibility will the Commission have defending 'triple A' or a better social Europe when it has just given in, with Mr Tusk's document and in front of the United Kingdom, something as important as free movement and equal treatment, fundamental principles?

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Although we have had a positive economic development in Germany and some other Member States in recent years, the poverty rate in these countries has not changed. The latest reports presented show that there is no direct or exclusive link between economic development and the social situation of employees. I would therefore like to point out that the main task for us must still be what we, as the European Union, are actually doing in order to offer the 132 million people who are officially living in poverty a chance, a perspective.  There is simply too narrow a reduction, even in your communication on the labour market presented today. We need to be broader. What we need are specific criteria. We need concrete, tangible, measurable, qualitative criteria to combat poverty. There is no point in us working towards job creation only if we do not at the same time talk about the fact that we actually need minimum wages, minimum wages, poverty, preventing pensions that prevent poverty.  It is not simply a question of talking again about the balance between flexibility and security, when at the same time we know that it has been this flexicurity that has driven up precarious jobs in recent years, for example in Germany, and thus pushed poverty further forward despite work. We must fight against this. I therefore ask you not to talk about minimum rights! Talk about fundamental rights! Make it clear that everyone here in the European Union has the same fundamental rights to social security and to live without poverty.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I must admit that when we began to hear about the social triple—A some of us began to think: at last, here is something a bit more aspirational on social Europe. I really hope that we are also going to draw on the work that we have done in the past on issues beyond GDP, because I think that picks up on some of the points that were made about quite how we are really looking at this. As others have said, we certainly feel that social Europe has been very much under attack over the last few years. This Parliament has been extremely clear on that, as you will remember, and we recognise that if you cut too much you actually kill the plant that you were trying to grow. So, in terms of the social pillar, I, like you, really hope that there will be many, many responses to that consultation, not least from those experiencing poverty. I hope that part of the concentration in this is going to be about how we tackle growing inequalities, because they are there within our labour market, which we see hollowing out. They are there in terms of job opportunities, and we certainly do face a number of challenges. I would hope that all Member States will engage constructively in this, but I am British so I do not take that for granted. I think we are looking, however, at an issue of enforcement. When we are looking at future legislation, as others have said, we are looking at a core Europe and the ‘other’ Europe as well. So if we are looking at the extension of the Equalities Directive, the Carer’s Leave Directive, these sorts of things, I think we are faced with an issue here, if we really are looking at a one-speed Europe.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I am sorry, but we are not here! I was convinced that what was an indication and a chat, as usual, of Mr Juncker would never be achieved in practice. You talk about 'social triple A', as if a label were what is needed for a Europe that is hungry, that is really reduced to the exhaust of strength and where, not poverty and the risk of poverty, but poverty, absolute poverty are the condition in which millions of citizens find themselves.  We cannot speak of 'triple, quadruple, fivefold social A': we must talk about the problems and we must talk about concrete solutions which families, reduced to hunger, need. You say that concrete proposals have been made. Exact! Do you know what the last proposal is? That today the European Commission has requested the amendment of the 2016 budget to Italy, Spain, Finland, Romania and Belgium. Why? For serious and serious deviations from agreed austerity targets.  These are the triple A's that you're asking us for. Further structural reforms and adjustments, but I would remind you that these are not the measures that guarantee the livelihood and survival of millions of starving citizens.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Zimmer, to raise the social pillar to the same level as the economic pillar has become the new groundhog of Mr Juncker's Union, no doubt to restore the image of the European project to increasingly Eurosceptic citizens. This 180-degree shift even proposes to encourage the development of the welfare state in two directions: by supporting measures that ensure a better level of social protection within the Member States, while trying to define common objectives to ensure social convergence throughout the euro area. Even if the addition of a social touch to the European Semester is a pretext to impose on The Member States a new salvo of structural reforms, economic convergence remains the priority to save the euro area, a euro area undermined by a very hesitant recovery and by the development of a two-speed social Europe - this has been said and repeated. Raising social norms is especially likely to have a negative impact on the labour market, as the convergence of higher social norms remains difficult to combine with policies for better labour markets in a context, remember, of drastic budgetary constraints renewed every semester since 2007 and which have already led to endemic poverty.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, with triple A, rating agencies assess profitable banks, economies, investments. With social triple A, i.e. so-called social criteria in the labour rights slaughterhouse called the European Semester, the European Commission mocks and provokes, but also admits that cheap flexible working is the biggest investment in capital. Neither wishful speech nor supposed democratic accountability to reactionary bodies such as the European Parliament humanise the European Union. For example, listen to some of the Commission's answers to questions from the Communist Party of Greece: "The European Union," he says, "does not define a right to permanent employment contracts." I mean, rubber work for crumbs! Another: 'In Programmes of the European Social Fund workers do not receive a salary', nor, of course, insurance. Free and uninsured work, while the EURES system undermines permanent work by strengthening slave trade offices! For example, Greece, where by evaluating the third memorandum government and quartet misleading about the European Union more pro-grassroots than the International Monetary Fund and for interest in the weakest, divide poverty among the poor and impoverished, cut back wages, pensions, social benefits and spending, put a tombstone on social security and labour rights. No questions asked! Here Union officials and all governments shamelessly call for the hard work of refugees to be exploited if they escape the bombings, drownings, hot spots, deportation and entrapment in Greece. The one way for the people is to get rid of this policy and the power of capital.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, in 2014, when the President of the European Commission delivered this fine expression here in the European Parliament and announced his desire to make social Europe with a social triple A, this gave rise to immense hope, here, in these ranks, but also among the peoples of Europe. Your roadmap, which you detailed earlier, lets us see how much you work on this goal on a daily basis. The numbers are improving slightly, but we are still at 9% unemployed in Europe, on average, much more than in the United States; youth unemployment stands at 20%, which is still very worrying, and much more so in some countries, and 25% of our citizens are still at risk of falling into poverty. It is clear that social Europe obviously requires professional integration. I want to tell you here how the first lever of social integration, the first lever of social Europe, is the European Social Fund, it is the initiative for youth employment, it is the youth guarantee. I hope that, together, as part of the program you have described, we will be able to maintain and develop these tools. We need to mobilise the Member States, because they are the ones we have to train to really build a social Europe together. Social Europe is both the Europe of employment and the Europe of the social protection of each of the citizens. Thank you for working on it. Count on us!

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Thank you, Commissioner, and thank you to the Commission for this initiative.  It will, of course, take a great deal for Europe to become a social triple-A categorised part of the world. What are the conditions? We are living in a time of refugee crisis, right-wing extremism on the rise, questioning freedom of expression and media freedom – all this on top of an economic crisis that is by no time over. And at the same time, social partners who do not get involved in the way they should be in order for us to solve the problems. It simply cannot be done without them. Politics can't do it alone. I think that the experience of recent years is a clear example of this. Eurofound has made a very interesting report, which I would like you to read. It is about what has happened in the crisis countries that were treated harshly by the Troika and which were forced out of their collective bargaining systems. Those countries are still hurting more than other countries, and that is because the nerve fibers of the social partners have been destroyed by economic ism.  So, more of social power, let people free so that they can work together with politicians and others and trade unions to actually restore life courage. That's what it's all about.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, it has been quite a few months since President Juncker first told us about the 'triple A social' rating. It is true that when it was announced we thought it was an excellent idea, but I believe that it was not very clear to most Members what formalities were to be followed and, therefore, we need to have a clear definition and concepts.  European citizens have faced numerous sacrifices during the economic and financial crisis and, therefore, improving the economic situation and expected growth in the coming years must be reversed in society and, in particular, in the people most affected by the crisis.  If the 'triple A' rating means that the European Union, through the Member States, will work towards greater social confluence, more employment and more social justice, welcome it.  For the first time, the European Semester includes a set of social indicators, which shows greater sensitivity to social aspects. However, in order to achieve this classification, we need specific indicators capable of analysing the progress made and, more importantly, steering European policies towards this 'triple A' when we are still far from the objectives of the 2020 Strategy.  I thank Commissioner Thyssen for her explanations and I hope that this initiative will succeed.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – I have three questions. What good is a pan-European labour market if people need two jobs to pay the bills? What does a zero-hours contract help an educated young person in Spain who is desperate for work to start a family? And what does a skills approach help a worker in Bulgaria, who earns 95 euros a month in a clothing factory? As far as I am concerned, these are the questions that the social pillar should focus on.  Centrally, it should be: 1. How do we guarantee labour markets that can support our innovation ambitions and at the same time provide inclusive and support when needed? After all, you are not 21 and top fit every day of your life. 2. How do we adequately combat poverty and inequality, but do we also make work pay and stimulate purchasing power? 3. How can we really strengthen the social partners by turning their agreements into legislation instead of just paying lip service?  In short, Commissioner, no words but deeds and preferably the good deeds and a little quickly.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, I totally agree with the ambition of the Commission to accompany macro-economic and fiscal policies by social measures and I fully support the new focus from the European Semester on employment and social performance issues. After all, and I quote Commissioner Thyssen here, economic development and social progress are closely intertwined and mutually reinforcing. When it comes to definition of the social triple—A, I can also fully subscribe to the idea of an economically strong Europe with the balanced growth that provides jobs and improves people’s lives. At the same time, I believe that when working towards this goal, we should avoid any over-regulation hindering growth and we should make sure that when introducing any new legislation we take into consideration the situation of different Member States, the need to protect the freedoms offered by the single market to citizens and the safeguarding of European competitiveness.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Madam President, I think it is worthwhile remembering what President Juncker actually said at the outset of the Commission back in October 2014 and I quote: ‘I want Europe to be dedicated to being triple—A on social issues as much as it is to being triple—A in the financial and economic sense.’  Now my question to Madam Thyssen is this: does she really believe that this Commission over this period of work has been equally committed, dedicated, to social issues as compared to macroeconomic and financial issues. In your speech last June in Luxembourg, Madam Thyssen, you gave a resounding ‘yes’ to the question is there a new start for a Social Europe. Well, unfortunately, I feel that the actual answer is a no less definite ‘no’, for the simple reason that the main drive of the Commission, embedded in the European Semester, is austerity. There is a consistent pressure to arrive at so-called structural and budget equilibrium, and social aspects and consequences have taken a decidedly second place.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, when the President of the Commission announced his ambition to want a triple-A for the European Union, he sent a clear message: we must give as much importance to social issues as we attach to economic issues. It is the very foundation of a socially regulated market economy. This notion of "triple A" indicates direction and will, but it must now be given substance. What are the parameters that need to be taken into account? What are the indicators that assess progress and policies? In order to move in this direction, the Commission would be advised to rely on the existing arrangements. I am thinking of social rating bodies like Vigeo in France or EIRIS in the UK. Meriting the social triple A requires effective legislation, but it is not enough. As with the revision of the Worker Detachment Directive, it is essential to have high-performance inspection services that can monitor, but also advise and inform stakeholders. This is an essential issue for the credibility of the European Union, but above all to reconcile citizens with the European project. Thank you for your work, Commissioner.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, politics must offer meaningless answers to the overbearing demand for social justice. The deprivation of opportunity eliminates the demand for quality of life for women, children, the elderly and the unemployed of all ages. Poverty is narrowing the horizon for growth, and the Commission is therefore called upon to respond quickly, going beyond what is now being experienced by European citizens as unnecessary and even annoying propaganda.  A robust social pillar, for new policies on labour, rights, opportunities and for the audience of the most vulnerable, is needed without further time lay-offs. It will also help us to confront the hostile feeling not only of governments but also of the weakest citizens, towards the new poor who are knocking powerfully on our doorsteps, to whom we want and must give responses of civilisation, democracy and peace.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, in 2014 President Juncker declared that he wanted a social triple-A for Europe. This declaration has started the debate and I believe that, a little over a year later, many of us share the idea that it is essential to give the European Union a social face. That said, the question remains unanswered. What do we mean by a social face? For my part, I believe that the best social protection is to have a job, a dignified and remunerative job. That means two things. First, that we must arm our citizens by giving them all the tools to enter the labour market, namely skills, languages or even the means to be mobile. Arming our fellow citizens also means giving the same weapons to all, without unfair competition or race to the least social. At the same time, we must also allow our companies, whether industrial, artisanal or agricultural, to create jobs, which obviously requires a regulatory framework that is favourable to them and encourages them to invest and innovate. Behind the social triple A, behind the slogan, it must allow Europe to restore its image after a crisis that has shaken our continent, which has made our fellow citizens doubt and which has placed them in great precariousness. A Europe that reconciles itself with companies and employees is social convergence.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, indicators are needed. There are economics, we need them in the social sphere, so that we can assess. But I'd like to share a conviction with you. When we have a free internal market that allows the movement of workers, if there is not at the same time social convergence, it is that very internal market that is threatened. Worse still, I think that if there is no process of social convergence, then it is the European Union that can be threatened, because the anti-European, Europhobic voices, which advocate nationalist withdrawal, will then gain even more power than they have today. To do that, you need a method. This method is to propose things, even if, at first, to be a minority, not to be heard by the Council. Too bad! At least the proposals exist. Parliament can take it and we can support you and work with you. Finally, we have to start with priorities. If we can't advance to 28 at the beginning, then there's the Eurozone; that this Eurozone is driving others, if we can't act together right now! That, Mrs Thyssen, the social triple A must not be a word, it must now be a method.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – It is good that employment and social remain high on our agenda. That is why, of course, I also welcome the idea of a social triple A, because it brings together everything we are working towards in this area: promoting employment, improving the field of education, reducing dologorono unemployment and better coordination of social systems. I consider it very important that we also support the initiative to establish a European Pillar of Social Rights. Europe has always been and is a role model in terms of guaranteeing social rights, and of course it is right that this... and preserve this primate. However, for that to happen, we must constantly make sure that we are still improving this system, that we are working on a better and even more efficient system. And I believe that the European Pillar of Social Rights will also be the one who will contribute to this. Of course, many questions remain open about how this Triple A system will work, and i also welcome, of course, this issue, which we have addressed together to the Commission and, honourable Commissioner, we hope to get the right answers from you.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this debate is important in order to make it clear that any attempt to reduce the European Union to the pure economic dimension must be strongly rejected and that it is not possible to build a single market in the absence of a political and social Europe.  We must work together to achieve the adoption of binding social indicators, naturally in agreement with the trade unions and by strengthening the social dialogue, to combat dumping and to reaffirm that fundamental rights take precedence over economic freedoms. All workers must be given the same opportunities to improve working and living conditions wherever they live in the European Union. That is why it is urgent to define, where applicable, a minimum wage mechanism at European level, defined in agreement with the social partners, which will eliminate differences in treatment.  I also believe it is crucial that the Commission commits itself to addressing the issue of the impact of the digital single market on employment and social protection as soon as possible.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: Madam President, Madam European Commissioner, dear Marianne Thyssen, ladies and gentlemen, in calling for the triple A social in his October 2014 speech in this Chamber, President Juncker has launched a new social dynamic in Europe, a dynamic that is supposed to bring about convergence of European countries from the top. Indeed, in this area, Europe must lead by example. Social Europe must not remain a utopia. If, of course, we cannot have the same labour code for the 28 Member States, let us move together towards common rights and benchmarks for workers. This convergence would indeed be a means of effectively combating social dumping and a response to the dysfunctions of many of our directives. I know that, as such, Commissioner European Commissioner, you have effectively seized on the issue of the detachment of workers, which was the subject of the previous debate. I have full confidence in your ability to correct some of the shortcomings of the current text. In order to move towards this social Europe, we must go beyond the current framework known as the European Semester. We must relaunch the European social dialogue as conceived by Jacques Delors, our former President of the European Commission. In my country, France, social protection and workers' rights are not empty words. However, let us not make the mistake, at European level as in France, of adding up or even stacking rules, sometimes unenforceable and cumbersome for our companies. To be effective, let's be clear and precise on the essentials.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, a year and a half ago Juncker spoke here and inaugurated the concept of 'triple A social'. And I would like to remind you why you introduced this concept: because I needed to change the dynamics, to introduce a turning point, mainly to the citizens, in the face of the previous policy, especially by Mr Barroso who, on the basis of excessive austerity, had produced a social drama in the whole of the European Union. We introduced the concept of 'triple A social' precisely to say that we were entering a different time, when the citizen was once again at the heart of European politics. A year later, the 'triple A social' remains an empty concept that we have to fill and in which we cannot waste more time, and for this I ask three things fundamentally. First, a European minimum wage framework to end labour poverty in the European Union. Secondly, to also establish European unemployment insurance to share solidarity with the standing through the European Union as a whole. And, third, a minimum insertion income to eradicate social exclusion. These three basic concepts are essential to fill the 'triple A social' with content and to ultimately recover what is important, which is the European social model that millions of European citizens so expect throughout the European Union.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Commissioner, I have listened with interest to your explanation of the concept of social triple A rating, and I understand that this should be an expression of the high social standard that we have in the countries of the European Union and the use of current and new policies. You named some of them yourself.  I consider it very important here to emphasise precisely the promotion of the balance of professional and family life, which you have also mentioned. I now consider young families with children who invest in children instead of saving for a rich pension to be the most discriminated part of society. And I ask: How do we support these young parents?  I would remind all my colleagues here, who are calling for even greater protection of employees, for more posted workers at European level, that we need to have those employers to do this. We need to have competitive businesses. And this also requires transparent and stable legislative conditions. I would therefore also like to remind you that if you intend to proceed with the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive 1996, then the maintenance of a competitive business environment must be monitored.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Madam President, the Commission’s press release on the European social pillar originally described it as a reference document of a legal nature expressing key principles of the EU – but it is not going to apply in nine of the 28 Member States. That seems a bit odd: big important principles, but not going to apply to hundreds of millions of citizens.  I have to say to the Commissioner: it is lucky that you and President Juncker were not writing Exodus and Deuteronomy otherwise we might have had ‘thou shalt not kill, but you can in the United Kingdom’ and ‘thou shalt not steal, although the Swedes will have to opt into this’ and ‘thou shalt not commit adultery, but it is fine in Poland or , rather, optional in Poland’. Surely if this is important, then it should apply to everybody. Or if it is just a bit of blarney, a bit of soft soap to keep socialists happy while nothing actually changes, then in that case, let us not, any of us, bother wasting our time on it. If it is a real thing, by the way, then, at some point in the document, it should have made mention of quality jobs. There are 80 000 people in my constituency in the West Midlands on zero-hour contracts and similar exploitation. If this document means something then it should apply to us and it should talk about that.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: – As one of the youngest Members of Parliament and as coordinator of ppe young people here in Parliament, I would like to point out the need to put young people's problems at the heart of the Union's social policy. For my generation, the single market and the many benefits it offers are self-evident, but at the same time we are also the biggest losers from the recent financial and monetary crisis and we are inheriting an imperfect union in search of a new impetus. It is therefore extremely important for my generation to be given the signal that europe's identity is not only determined by free movement and the economy, but also, and above all, has a social heart. We can give that signal by actively working to activate, motivate and stimulate young people. Despite a recovering labour market, one figure remains the same: one in five young people is out of work and that is an absolute disgrace.  Through the Youth Employment Initiative, the Commissioner briefly played the ball. She quickly cleared more pennies, and successfully. For example, youth unemployment in Brussels is falling for the 33rd month in a row. But one swallow does not make spring: much work is still on the shelf, such as the agenda for new skills for Europe, which I will look at with great attention.
