Labour mobility must also be higher and, above all, fairer. A social Europe is a Europe where the rules are the same for everyone. My generation must never again be called "the lost generation." That is why Europe must and can be made much more social. We all have a responsibility to succeed.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. I am pleased that today we have the opportunity to talk about the triple A rating in the area of social policy. It is important for the Commissioner to explain what the triple A rating means, what it intends to achieve and what mechanisms it intends to achieve and what legislative changes it plans to introduce. This is a very ambitious plan, but without answers to these questions, we will not be able to implement it responsibly. We must bear in mind that social policy has a real impact on the quality of life of citizens and requires a responsible and precise approach on the part of the Member States and the EU institutions. Our priority in the Union should be to achieve the greatest possible social cohesion between The Member States. This will significantly improve the quality of life of citizens and allow unfetched competition through better work efficiency, innovation. This is what we will achieve by setting targets that take into account the diverse socio-economic development of countries. We all know how concrete action is needed to create jobs and incentives to pursue a social policy that is citizen-friendly and responding to their needs.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I urge the Commissioner to look out for two upcoming reports that will come to the floor of this House which are both very relevant: meeting anti-poverty targets in the light of household costs, for which I co-authored an opinion, and poverty from a woman’s perspective. We need strong impetus to meet these anti-poverty targets and that includes having serious social focus for the European Semester with a strong gender perspective, and I say this on the occasion of International Women’s Day. Women are disproportionately at risk of poverty and social exclusion and when we tackle the poverty that vulnerable women experience we lift up the rest with them.  The European Union has the potential to build a socially just and truly equal Europe, but we need to tackle gender inequalities if we are to make that vision a reality.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, Mr Juncker's triple social A has failed. We have armies of unemployed people in Europe. We have poverty in Europe. We have 9% unemployment. We have high unemployment among young people. We have 25% unemployment in Greece. If we really want to have a proper social policy, at least three things are needed: the European minimum social income, the minimum European wage, the European unemployment benefit. Instead of having these, we have a different direction.  As I said earlier, the latest agreement on Britain's stay actually dissolves all social policy in Europe, because there will not only be discrimination against those Europeans working in Britain but also those Britons who will work in the European Union, because Mrs Merkel said she likes this system. Therefore, it has not even been explained to British citizens that, when they are working in Europe, they can be discriminated against.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with this indefinition it gives the impression that Juncker's administration is trying to give us cat for hare. It seems that behind the "social triple A", which is presented as a firm plan, what there is is a firm improvisation on the fly. Hence new names are put to persevere in the same argument: austerity. We fear that the social dimension of economic and monetary union will have results that will equal working conditions downwards or, worse, that no policy is ever implemented or that those that are applied are ineffective, as in the case of the Youth Guarantee plan. It may have been a lapse, because the Commission was thinking about the results these measures would have for capital without thinking about what these measures could do for European citizens. The problem of quality in employment is, in the medium term, as serious as unemployment. If we fail to create jobs with rights, we will be incuring a recklessness that can jeopardize the support of our social and fiscal state.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Back in October 2014, I welcomed President Juncker's declaration that the idea of a triple A social rating first emerged. I am an ardent supporter of an approach in which harmonious economic development can only take place in parallel with measures aimed at improving the social situation and employment of the citizens of the European Union.  It should be noted, however, that such a social rating should be more than a general objective and an ideological declaration. I agree with the voters that we need a concrete plan on how to achieve this 'triple A'. First of all, there is a need for clear, comprehensive and easily measurable indicators to monitor progress. I hope that the Commission will present its proposal in this regard shortly. I would also like to point out that action towards a 'triple A' must cover the European Union from the outset, not just economic and monetary union.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Madam President, the Commission is highlighting this famous free and undistorted competition, considering that this is the basis of social progress. I think that today in Europe, competition is neither free nor undistorted, because social systems are too different from one country to another. The "detachment of workers" directive does not live up to social expectations. It now poses more problems than it solves. We see this, for example, in the agricultural sector, where it creates distortions of competition through the use of these famous seconded workers and exacerbates the agricultural crisis today. I believe today that it is necessary to harmonize social legislation in Europe very strongly and I would also add, in closing, that we must not forget to harmonize tax laws, because Europe is dying from these two problems: a lack of social harmonisation and a lack of tax harmonisation.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I originally wanted to talk about something else, but my colleague's previous contribution provoked me a little to change the content of my speech.  I think the exact opposite of my colleague. In my opinion, increasing competitiveness is currently increasing the social level of protection. It is not that europe will be strong economically and therefore social protection if we are to lag behind in competitiveness. This is indeed not the case in my view.  As far as the needs of the Member States are concerned, I think, unlike my previous spokesman, that it is important that some freedom for nation states is ensured. That the greatest threat to the social level of protection is if we tie too many regulations into legislation and if we do not provide space for the Member States.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. I would like to thank you for this rich debate. We have heard a lot of comments. I note that your support for a social triple A is very strong, but that there is no consensus here too on what exactly is needed. It is true that everything is needed and that we have to work on it. We do indeed have quite a few problems that we have to deal with at the same time. We are - and I hear we share this concern - with the aftermath of the crisis. We are facing increased poverty in Europe. While the aim was to reduce poverty, the crisis has increased poverty.  While we see that youth unemployment is falling every month, it remains far too high with 4.5 million young unemployed people who do not find a job. We know that half of our unemployed are long-term unemployed. We cannot accept that either. We see that our labour market is becoming more and more segmented and that we simply accept this as a given without acting against it. We are therefore trying to counter-gas.  We also need to look at the challenges we face. We have a aftermath of the crisis, but in the meantime the world has not stopped. We face long-term challenges, with long-term trends in society, in the economy and in our labour market. In society, we only have to look at demographic evolution, at the change of family structures, at the ageing population. But if we look at the economy and the labour market, we see globalisation, digitisation, new labour models. Then we have to deal with new business models, which we are not going to stop and that we should not stop. But we must give the right answer to this in order to ensure that we have a social policy and that the people who deserve our protection, who need protection at more times in their lives than before, can also count on that assistance, that activation.  We also need to look at what is needed to combat more inequality. More convergence is needed, because we know that more inequality in society is a barrier to economic growth and that does not help us in any way. Less inequality, more convergence, upward convergence, that's what we want to go for! Of course, this is not an easy matter. We need to look at what is needed for equal opportunities and equal access to the labour market. We will have to look at our skills agenda, at the education that is needed, not just when people are young. Lifelong learning, upskilling, reskilling, these are all issues that need to be reviewed in the future and that we will address in our skills agenda.  We also need to look at how we are going to improve social protection and social security. It is not just a matter of enert that the systems are sustainable and financially sustainable, but they must also be adequate. They have to cover the risks we want to cover. And we also need to look at fair working conditions. It is very clear - and this has been shown here by the various interventions - that this is not a matter that we can only tackle at European level. We also need the Member States. Together we need to develop an idea, a vision of where we want to go, and then implement it in mutual cooperation.  Nor is it a matter that will neither be inspired nor allowed by the minds of political leaders. We do indeed need - and you rightly pointed out - the social partners. They know the field. They can help us refine the right diagnosis, but they can also help us to work out the right solutions and, if we have solutions, to help implement them in concrete way. So it will be a work of all of us together. We will have to do it together at different levels of policy, with the social partners! I therefore again invite you to study in detail that package of documents that has been launched today, which consists of an explanation of what exactly we mean by that European pillar of social rights. In the annex to that document, we show a first outline of what it might look like. Questions and suggestions are asked. But there are also two working documents, one with an overview of the social acquis so far, primary and secondary law, international law, soft law, and one with the financial instruments at our disposal and with which we can strongly support the good things that the Member States should and want to do. We all need to take a very good look at that. The economic trends, the economic developments that are underway are also analysed. Also on this a document has been included in the package and I invite you, as well as the national parliaments, the governments, the social partners and the Economic and Social Committee, to really come up with input to work out a new plan on how we can ensure that - as Tom Vandekendelaere and others have said here - it also for the children , for today's young people is still good coexistence. How we can also ensure for them that we maintain a social market economy worthy of that name. And if we can draw out and realize that social market economy, then we will have earned our social triple A. Because what is at stake - and I will repeat it again - is that we need to ensure economic growth, that we make it possible and create it. An economic growth that gives rise to job creation, to quality jobs and to good social protection of the people. That's what we're doing! Not for nice words. It's a commitment. It is a commitment that we will have to make with many, that we must make good together with many. First, however, we need to clearly explain exactly how we see this. This is a good reason for this european pillar of social rights that we have launched today.  We call for a wide-ranging debate. There are those who say that there is no social Europe, that there is no work to be done. Well, in all the years I have been active in Europe and have also been active in this Parliament, I have not seen any previous calls for and so much preparatory work to be done for such a wide-ranging debate on the future of our social Europe.  So I'd say let's get to work. Let's work together. Let's draw that together. That is where we will be able to do good things for the people and that is where we will be able to ensure that even those who come after us find a Europe where life is good, where people have equal opportunities and where people who are less fortunate in their lives, who may have been given less talent or who have already committed a stupid act , can be kept on board. That people who need social protection, at any stage of their lives, can get it.  Thank you for this debate, Madam President, and I look forward to working with us, including in this dossier.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, Commissioner, for the strength of your statement here this evening. We will now allow a change of the guard for Commissioner Jourová to take her seat for the next report.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on Caterina Chinnici's report, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposed directive of the European Parliament and the Council on the establishment of procedural safeguards for children suspected or prosecuted in criminal proceedings (COM(2013)0822 - C7-0428/2013 - 2013/0408 (COD)) (A8-0020/2015).

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Jourová, allow me first of all to thank the Commission, the shadow rapporteurs and the rotating Presidencies, Latvian and Luxembourg, under which the negotiations for the constructive approach taken during the work took place. It has been about a year since I was given the negotiating mandate following the approval by the COMMITTEE on LibE of the text of the directive we are debating today.  The work carried out during this period was motivated by the desire to create a measure, which for the first time considered the specificity of the juvenile process at supranational level, accompanied by clear guarantees for the children involved. It took 9 trilogues, sometimes very difficult and numerous technical meetings before reaching a final agreement, which I very much welcome and on which I hope there will be broad consensus in this House. With more than one million children being prosecuted in Europe each year, there are still significant differences between member states' legal systems in the treatment of children at different stages of the procedure.  The directive is intended to bridge these gaps by defining and identifying clear rights for children suspected or accused through a body of minimum standards which, however, establish a high level of guarantees. In fact, the main focus was on the best interests of the child, a principle also enshrined in Article 24 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which is already known in civil and administrative matters and which thus enters the criminal process for the first time. I believe that the added value of the directive is that it has accompanied the juvenile procedure, as well as the fundamental safeguards provided for criminal proceedings involving adults, but also those required by the specific nature of minors, which must always be the recipients of specific adequate protection.  There are many aspects of the procedure involved in the directive, but I cannot dwell on them for reasons of time. I would, however, like to refer to Article 6 of the directive, which provides for the right of the child to be assisted by a lawyer. This is the most sensitive issue that has been addressed during the negotiations and I must say that I am satisfied with the compromise reached in the text which accurately describes the situations in which the presence of the defender is essential in order to ensure that the child is provided with technical assistance, the correct application of all the guarantees provided for and to help him understand the progress of the procedure involving him.  For this reason, while the directive provides for reasonable possibilities for derogation, in view of the lesser seriousness of the crime, the reduced complexity of the case and the measures that could be taken accordingly, the directive requires States to ensure the presence of the defender from the earliest stages of investigations and, in particular, when the child is questioned by the judicial police and, above all, in any case, in any case where he or she is deprived of his or her personal liberty. Another important provision is that which requires Member States to subject the child to an assessment carried out by qualified personnel, in order to support decisions on possible measures for the benefit of the child, on the adequacy of any precautionary measures and when the judgment is delivered.  In this connection, I would like to stress once again the importance of training those involved in the proceedings, starting with the police, magistrates and defenders. It is provided for in the directive that they have access to specific training so that they can ensure the best interests of the child. Finally, again in view of the specific needs of the child and his social reintegration at the end of criminal experience, detention is always considered as an extreme ratio, to be available when alternative measures are not effectively viable. And, where it is inevitable to deprive the child of personal freedom, he must do everything possible to safeguard his psychophysical development and his needs for re-education.  That is why I believe that one of the most significant aspects of the directive is that it has established for the first time at European level the principle of separate detention of children. For all these reasons, I am convinced that the directive is heading in the right direction for the definition of a common model of juvenile due process, also contributing in the criminal field, to the achievement of child justice.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Members ate to vote on the text of the Directive on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. This directive is particularly important as it gives specific rights to children involved in criminal proceedings in the European Union and provides for overarching protection at all stages of these proceedings. Children are particularly vulnerable in criminal proceedings due to their young age and immaturity. Around 1 million children in the EU are estimated to come into contact with the police and judiciary every year. They need therefore the highest possible protection. This directive is an important step forward in the construction of an area of justice in the European Union. Today there are large disparities in the level of protection offered in the European Union applicable to children in criminal proceedings in the Member States. In some cases, the level of protection is insufficient compared with the well-recognised international standards. The directive, once adopted, will significantly strengthen the procedural safeguards for children when confronted with criminal justice in the EU throughout all the proceedings. Moreover, the directive will also contribute to the development of an effective model of juvenile justice. The new rules will ensure the fair trial rights for children during criminal proceedings; they will also prevent children from re-offending and will foster their social integration. I would like to congratulate and thank the Parliament rapporteur, Mrs Chinnici, for her remarkable work and personal dedication on this file, which made an agreement on this directive possible after long and difficult negotiations.  The outcome of the negotiations is a very well balanced text which endorses the principle laid down in Article 24 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights that ‘the child’s best interests shall always be a primary consideration’.  Notably, children will benefit from assistance by a lawyer in serious and complex cases and every time they are in detention. Deprivation of liberty cannot be imposed as a sanction unless the child has been assisted by a lawyer, at least during the hearings before the court. Children will also benefit from other safeguards such as assistance by their parents or other appropriate persons. They will also have the right to protection of privacy, including the possibility of having court hearings held in the absence of the public. Furthermore, children will also have the right to an individual assessment to make sure that their specific needs concerning protection, education and social integration are fully taken into account.  Finally, the Commission is also very satisfied that the text foresees that children should be kept separately from adults in police custody and pre-trial detention, unless this is not in the best interests of the child. This directive will give a strong signal that the European Union strongly cares about children, the most vulnerable persons involved in criminal proceedings. Therefore, I strongly encourage you to vote in favour of this directive today.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – First and foremost, I congratulate Mrs Chinnici on her work and thank her for her excellent cooperation. As the people's party responsible for this report, I am very pleased that we have succeeded in creating a directive that is acceptable to Parliament as well as to the Member States. An important aspect of the negotiations was the transposition and feasibility of the Directive. I think that has been achieved and we are voting tomorrow on a text that will bring real assurances to the children of suspects and accused children. For me, it was important to create legislation that would stand up to the real world. Such a critical point in the negotiations was, for example, the right to legal assistance. Although, as a general principle, it is acceptable that every child has the right to help a lawyer, because they have even less understood what is happening to them than adults. However, there are also cases where this is impractical and ultimately we are punishing children if we expect it to be unconditionally ensured. It is also important that deprivation of liberty should only take place as a lasting event and for the shortest possible time and that children should be kept in isolation from adults. Involvement in criminal proceedings can stigmatise the child, reduce their chances of reintegration into society and affect their future professional and social lives. Therefore, caution should be exercised gradually. I trust that this directive will ensure adequate and child-friendly conditions for criminal proceedings.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, we are discussing in this Plenary of the European Parliament an agreement at first reading of a directive of the utmost importance, which is part of the package of procedural safeguards but addressed to a particularly vulnerable group, minors, who are not a minor collective: they are about 12% of persons suspected, investigated or prosecuted and , therefore, deserve the best attention from this European Parliament.  And, indeed, its legal assistance is strengthened, particularly ex officio, individualized treatment and individualised evaluation are ensured, the participation of persons exercising guardianship in proceedings is ensured and, above all, zeal is extreme so that pre-trial detention is the last resort, as well as strengthening guarantees of the medical examination of the suspected child, investigated or prosecuted criminally.  We are doing the right thing, but the most important thing is that we are complying with the completeness of this package of procedural safeguards in which very important steps have been taken on the legal basis of Article 82, but, more importantly, respecting the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which is the one that orders that only the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union can be influenced , especially restrictively, in the fundamental rights of individuals in accordance with the principle of proportionality and necessity, because, as a classic quote from the great Cesare Beccaria reminds us, 'any act of authority which one person exercises over another person and which is not strictly necessary is in itself a tyrannical act'.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – I congratulate my colleague Kinichi and the shadow rapporteurs who have worked on this dossier. The issue of procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings is extremely important due to the existence of varying degrees of protection in the Member States and even the lack thereof in some of them. Around 1 086 000 children a year face criminal proceedings, representing 12% of all Europeans facing criminal justice.  On behalf of the shadow rapporteur, honourable Colleague Kirkhope, I would like to stress that the protection of children must be a priority of society. They are his most vulnerable representatives and need special protection. We must be able to address legal gaps in systems, taking into account member states' legislative systems, while creating European standards to ensure the protection of children's rights within the Union.  I call on the Member States to ensure that the protection of children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings is implemented as a priority. It is a step in the right direction for Member States to adapt the legislative systems so that they comply with the requirements for better protection of accused and suspected children.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, at a time when democracy and the rule of law are under some assault within the Union itself, it was important to reach a good and solid agreement on this directive, especially since it is a directive on the most vulnerable among Europeans, children. Let us never forget — it is often an open door that is pushed, but I am happy to remind us this evening, even very late - that children are the future adults who make up our future and that giving them priority in a text is something refreshing. Failing to control the present in these times, working to preserve and protect our future is essential. I would particularly like to commend the hard work and determination of Caterina Chinnici during these long months and thank her for reaching this ambitious agreement with all of us and for enshrining these procedural rights which she has recalled and which we like to stress that they are essential because, despite the establishment of fundamental principles at European and international level. , justice is not always perfectly, if not at all, suitable for children and young people. I will not go back to the psychological environment that can be that of a minor in a courtroom. It was important that this text strongly enshrines the fact that they can benefit from additional guarantees, of justice that is adapted to their age as well as to their needs, of a justice which, of course, treats them with dignity, attention and fairness, and which is accessible, understandable and reliable. The directive enshrines these provisions by giving children the opportunity to be informed as well as to benefit from a personalised assessment and, above all, the right to access legal aid; it also guarantees the search, as much as possible, for alternatives to detention. We have yet to finalise, for the third part, legal aid, which we call for.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I also would like to add my thanks to the rapporteur on this directive for keeping a very clear and strong line in the negotiations. I think we have got something where the derogations are limited very much case by case and we have reduced some of the flexibility that the Council sought far too often. As people have said, it is another important part of the procedural rights package and here, I think, we have generally got an upward convergence. As so often, the toughest part has been around the actual access to a lawyer – surely a key part of justice –and my Group still has a lingering concern about the proportionality test in Article 6(6). We are concerned as to how that is actually going to be implemented in national law, in transposition and in practice. However, overall we believe this directive is a good legislative instrument which will improve the rights of children throughout the European Union.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the United Kingdom will not adopt this proposed legislation for two reasons. One, we have an opt-out and two, because we already have such safeguards under our own law.  It is shocking that some Member States lack basic safeguards for children under their own legal systems. For example, the right to be present at one’s own trial, the right to legal representation, the right of children held in custody to be kept separately from adults, and the right to be visited by a parent or guardian.  The question that springs to mind is how could the legal systems of Member States lacking such basic protections be considered equal to the legal systems that do? And of course they are, under the EU’s ideological doctrine of mutual recognition that says all Member States’ legal systems are equal. This is palpably not true but it is good to see the EU adopting some of the tried and tested principles of the English legal system.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, I believe that criminal justice must be a matter of state sovereignty. That is why I am opposed to this proposal for a directive, which wants to put in place European safeguards for children who are being criminally prosecuted. The European Union is, in any case, incapable of offering clear guarantees. In Article 6, the proposed directive, for example, recognises the right of children to a lawyer, but it is to dismiss that right immediately when, I quote, "the assistance of a lawyer is not proportionate in the circumstances of this case"; and, in Article 12, it gives them the right to be held separately from adults, but it is to depart from it immediately when, I quote, "it is not possible in practice to do so".  The Union has already ruined French industry and agriculture, it has dismantled our borders with the results we see in Calais. Let it not meddle in our criminal justice system, which does not need to be destabilized by the mediocrity of the guarantees it offers today.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Hekk kif qalu l-kollegi dan ma kienx pro大ess fa大li imma wara ħna laqgħat u negozjati iebsa huwa tajjeb li wasalna s'hawnhekk. Għanda bżonn din id-direttiva b'miżuri ta' ħarsien għal tfal li jkunu akkużati jew suspettati li wettqu xi reat. Dan hu każ sensittiv ħafna u rridu nagħmlu dak kollu li hemm bżonn biex inħarsu proprju lit-tfal fis-so大jetajiet tagħna. F'dan is-sens jiena nilqa' d-dritt għall-informazzjoni lit-tfal għaliex din hija garanzija biex it-tfal ikunu infurmati dwar id-drittijiet tagħhom. Hu importanti li t-tfal i jingħatawx il-ġenb. Irridu sistema legali li tagħti każ l-interessi ta' dawn it-tfal. Kull Membru tal-Unjoni Ewropea għandu jassigura li t-tfal, meta jkun meħtieġ, jingħataw assistenza legali. Inizjattiva oħra tajba ta' min ifaħħarha hi li tfal ikunu rjati waqt li qed isirulhom il-mistoqsijiet waqt l-interrogazzjoni. Jiena nisħaq li t-tfal għandhom jiġu trattati ta' tfal, u għalhekk huwa pożittiv li huma jingħataw il-protezzjonikollha li għandhom bżonn. Din l-inizjattivi hija xhieda tal-valuri Ewropej. Ewropa mibnija fuq id-drittijiet. Huwa għalhekk li għandna nagħtuha l-appoġġ sħiħ tagħna.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, there are numerous cases known where children, even below the age of criminal responsibility, commit terrible crimes going far beyond theft or vandalism: murder, rape, assault, kidnapping. Nonetheless, they have to be treated as underage which, however, applies to proceedings and not necessarily to verdicts.  In the case of charges brought against a person over the age of 18 for crimes allegedly committed when they were still under age, specific rules have to be followed, amongst them the right to mandatory assistance by a lawyer, to medical examination, to specific treatment, to individual assessment, and rules on questioning, are especially important. Moreover, those dealing with such persons have to be properly trained in order to effectively assess the situation at every stage of the proceedings and beyond.  In the end, however, it usually comes down to upbringing, education, relations with family members, a sense of belonging and many other things as well as a positive outside influence amongst other important factors. Without the quality of this there can regretfully be no happy childhood or youth, which creates a most fertile ground for unlawful behaviour during these periods of life.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – It is surprising, and even worrying, that there is no definition of a fair trial of children in the European Union. That is why courts have to give judgments on the basis of an incomplete and fragmented legal order. As the rapporteur points out, up to a whopping 12 per cent of the total number of people punished are children. The assistance of a solicitor not only in court, but also in police stations must be guaranteed for each child. Otherwise, they are losing their fundamental right. No child must fall victim to a complicated legal process. I very much welcome the Commission's proposal. I see it as a tool to strengthen justice, not as a way of avoiding it. At the same time, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for her efforts to ensure that special safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings do not hinder the objective atteming of criminal responsibility.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I welcome the report drafted by my colleague, Caterina Chinnici, with whom I co-founded the Parliamentary Children’s Rights Intergroup. Every citizen suspected of a crime must be able to understand and follow criminal proceedings and to exercise their right to a fair trial. All citizens must have their rights upheld in the course of the criminal process, but children are particularly vulnerable and we must address their specific situation. So I am happy to see that the report reaffirms that the child’s best interests must always be a primary consideration. As a member of the Committee on Culture and Education, I want to underline the role of prevention, as well as social reintegration of children suspected or convicted of criminal offences. Therefore, more consideration must be given to the power of informal learning, volunteering, sports and cultural participation for social inclusion and reintegration of children and young people who have gone through the criminal justice system. This applies especially to disadvantaged young people who may have failed in the compulsory education system.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I am known for having always supported, even as Minister of Justice, the unification of fundamental procedural rights in the event that there is a European arrest warrant. I also support the idea of this proposal to unify procedural rights that affect minors, but I am also asking myself one question whether the scope of those unified rights is too broad. The Commissioner may have noted the debate in the Czech Republic, which we are now having at both professional and parliamentary level, and that debate concerns how to adjust the right to the protection of the privacy of the child. This is if the child commits a particularly serious crime. In short, the Czech public does not want children who, for example, murder someone or intentionally harm someone physically, to be anonymous, so that the public cannot learn that someone has committed such a brutal crime.  So the idea is right, I just feel that the scope of unified rights is too broad.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, 1,086,000 children face justice every year. Yet only six Member States have a special prosecutor for minors. There is therefore a need for special juvenile courts. We need to shape the concept of a fair trial for children. The rights of the child must be respected, as the UN Convention specifies. This means, among other things, training of judges and lawyers themselves. It is therefore necessary for each Member State to ensure legal assistance with a lawyer for the minors themselves. The aim must be reintegration into society, it must be protection, not marginalisation. We don't want a modern-day Oliver Twist and his company, described by Charles Dickens in London in 1838. We must therefore take serious measures.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I also want to support this proposal for a directive and the opinion of the report. In my opinion, it is important to ensure that the criminal proceedings and equality of arms are truly adversarial. Equality of arms where necessary. That is, at a time when the child is clearly disadvantaged by his or her age in criminal proceedings, so we must undoubtedly balance this disadvantage to some extent.  I also wonder whether the extent of the rights granted or those to be uniformed in a kind of European robe is sufficient. In this respect, I agree with my colleague Mr Pospisil, who has spoken here before. On the other hand, I must point out, and although I understand that many who are affected by this crime, especially the intentional one, are calling for as much information as possible to be made public. But it is also a fact that the criminal activity of children, for example, is decreasing relatively as a result of the Czech legislation in the Czech Republic. So it is not entirely easy to assess this conflict between public law and the right of privacy of the child and its future development.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank the honourable Members for this discussion. I can only summarise that this directive is indeed another important contribution to strengthening the rights of suspects and accused persons by setting common minimum standards on fair trial rights. It is true that this arrangement on common minimum standards is something which is still missing in the Member States of the European Union and this is why we are coming with these harmonised rules.  This proposal provides for special safeguards for the most vulnerable persons, who are children. You know that recently we adopted here the Directive on the Presumption of Innocence and, among the three recently proposed directives on procedural safeguards, only the Directive on Legal Aid is to be adopted. What we see as the main added value of this proposal is that it introduces measures which are in the best interest of a child. It covers cases when a young person commits an act which society punishes by means of penal law; but the same society must not deprive him or her of the opportunity to start again, and this is in the best interest of society.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my fellow Members for their speeches and for their many appreciations for the agreement reached and I hope to be able to count on their support and that of their political groups. I would like to thank Commissioner Jourová once again for her attention to the directive, for her words here today and for the technical support she has given the Commission.  Tomorrow we will vote on a text that enshrines specific rights for children suspected and charged in criminal proceedings and we will vote in the knowledge that we have contributed to the creation of a European area for criminal justice. It will be legislation, which, together with others that have already been approved, forms part of the overall architecture of procedural rights but, above all, it will be a directive aimed at bridging the differences between the legal systems of the Member States, taking into account in the criminal process, the specificity of minors and their vulnerabilities, especially if they are minors in difficult situations, stating precisely, that the rights of the child must be protected in all circumstances. I would like to conclude, Mr President, with a personal comment. This year, in fact, I have twenty years of commitment in the field of juvenile justice and I must therefore say that I am particularly pleased to have been rapporteur for the report on this directive, which paves the way for the creation of a fair juvenile trial in the countries of the Union.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, March 9, 2016. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – This proposal for a directive on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings is a very important piece of legislation that will regulate the rules throughout the European Union on the rights of children in criminal proceedings. Despite the numerous international legal instruments in this area, there is no definition of what is the right trial for the child, so the courts must act on the basis of a partial and fragmented legal framework. The European Commission estimates that more than one million children are involved in criminal proceedings in the EU each year, representing 12% of all persons involved in criminal proceedings in the same territory. In addition to the large number, there are significant differences in the treatment of children in the Member States when faced with criminal proceedings. European studies show that children's rights are currently not sufficiently guaranteed within the Union at all stages of criminal proceedings and that the European Court of Human Rights has made decisions that are unfavourable to Member States on numerous occasions. In addition, this proposal for a directive is part of the EU Agenda on the Rights of the Child and aims to promote the rights of the child in the light of other measures, in particular the Guidelines of the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe on child-friendly justice, bearing in mind that such measures do not have binding force on EU legislation and therefore the guarantees provided for therein are not fully and uniformly applied in the Member States.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. – I would like to thank the rapporteur Ms Chinnici and the EPP Shadow Rapporteur Mr Csáky for the excellent work done on this important report. Children are the most vulnerable members of our society and they need and deserve our protection. Every year more than one million children are involved in criminal proceedings, and it is crucial that they are not left behind in our criminal law system. I am happy that Hungary is active and taking the lead in creating a child-friendly justice system, with child-friendly institutions during criminal proceedings. My own pilot project from 2013, which turned out to be quite successful, aimed to the same extent at child-friendly justice systems. I support this legislative text because it reconciles the discrepancies between Member States, creating a European standard on safeguards for children who are suspected or accused of having committed a criminal offence. As an EPP member I am in favour of the text agreed as it ensures that the best interest of minors will be protected at all stages of proceedings.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: writing – Criminal investigations in criminal proceedings are a complex and mentally demanding process for children and young people in particular. In its improper procedure, it can have a difficult and lasting impact on their psychological development and future life. I believe that minimum and uniform qualification requirements should be laid down for all member countries working with children, from the investigating authorities to the judiciary involved in this process. To this end, member states' governments need to prepare material, financial and formal preconditions for the education and acquisition of skills of these components when working with children and young people. An insensitive procedure that does not take into account the age and reason development of children without sufficient psychological support is traumatic for children and can produce a contrary to educational effect. This will affect the life of the child and the whole society in which he/she lives. It is inconceivable that in the 21st century, at a time of open market, borders and free movement in Europe, a minimum uniform level of protection and rights for children in the criminal proceedings should not be guaranteed. These are not things for long discussions. They need to be addressed operationally and promptly.

name: Emil RADEV
text: in writing. – According to European Commission data, 12% of all criminal proceedings in the EU relate to children; at the same time, there are different practices of proceedings in the Member States, such as the availability of specialised criminal departments, training of lawyers to work with children, as well as protections during interrogations.  I support the agreed directive on common minimum standards for the rights of children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings, because these measures will lead to clearer and harmonised standards of criminal proceedings against children. In particular, I find it an extremely important achievement that the right to an individual assessment, because no criminal proceedings are the same as another, especially where children are involved. The right to legal assistance is also extremely important - before the law everyone is equal, and children especially should have the opportunity for adequate protection and presentation to the police and court.  Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the agreed directive takes the best interests of the child into account. I also believe that it will facilitate mutual recognition of judgments as well as cross-border police cooperation. These are important steps towards a pan-European judicial area that will create common rules for all Member States.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – today's debate touches on a very important topic in relation to human rights, which concerns the legal protection of children. Their problems cannot lie solely on their shoulders, and institutional solutions must be found at Union level, which will unify a formal ˗ legal opinion in all Member States. This is an important topic, as the European Commission estimates that more than one million children are involved in criminal proceedings in the EU each year. There are worrying differences in the treatment of children in the Member States in the face of criminal proceedings, which just proves that the legal protection of underage eu citizens is not sufficient. In the case of a crime involving children, children must be subject to legal assistance and custody immediately after detention. All information provided to them should be transmitted in a manner adapted to their age and maturity. And, most importantly, the language they understand, regardless of their nationality, nor the place of accommodation, without any discrimination on the basis of language. Member States must ensure that all cases with children are handled with care and care. Criminal proceedings involving children should be dealt with without intimidation and should always, where possible, inform parents and their participation. Let us not forget that the proposed provisions should complement the directive on children's rights, because it has not yet defined what is the right trial for the child. This problem is therefore particularly important.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on Jens Geier's report, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget, Section III - Commission (2016/2004 (BUD)) (A8-0036/2016).

name: Jens GEIER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The European Parliament is struggling to take a stand to meet the political challenges facing the European Union. The European Parliament is taking the trouble to describe the current challenges and to deduce the financial consequences. And the Council of the European Union? He sends us a four-page paper, which is to its vast part copy and paste of the 2016 directive. Of course, the annual figures have been exchanged, here and there a formulation has been adapted – but that was it.  I know from the Council's deliberations that the German Government has made every effort to emphasise the challenges of the refugee crisis. However, it cannot have been very successful in this, because otherwise there could be no Council directives which do not in any way reflect the dramatic developments of the last twelve months. What is the situation? The 2016 budget mobilises more than €5 billion in the domestic and foreign policy categories to eliminate the causes of flight, feed, care for refugees in Syria's neighbouring countries, educate children and help EU Member States cope with the refugee crisis. As a result, the margins had to be fully exploited up to the upper limits of these categories. The Council agreed to renounce the margins it so cherished, which are to be held back for the unforeseen – so great was the need.  Has the situation since then eased? On the contrary. But the Council is taking the same position as we did in the spring of 2015, when we were still a long way from the peak of the migration movement. This borders on denial of reality.  We are preparing the 4th budget within the framework of the current multiannual financial framework. This year, too, it will become clear that the money will not be enough if the EU is to cope with the tasks assigned to it by the Member States. The first supplementary budget for 2016 will require an additional €250 million for the first Turkey facility, which has not yet been budgeted. In the budget for which I have political responsibility, that is another EUR 750 million. Since the weekend, we have known that there will most likely be a second Turkey facility. I am sure that the EU budget will once again have to contribute at least EUR 1 billion. We also need around €700 million to make the new humanitarian aid instrument within the EU effective.  I think all these measures make sense. Turkey has taken in more refugees than all EU countries combined. It is in the EU's well-understood self-interest to support Turkey in providing for the refugees. Humanitarian aid is also important and right, because this crisis is overburdening every Member State that is left alone. But if these are all priorities, then the Council must do one of two things: either explain what is no longer to be financed or adapt the financial resources to the increased challenges. He doesn't do either. He does business as usual. This will not work as it did last year, because the ceiling is simply too short.  Now we have a chance to respond to the new situation. That would be the revision of the medium-term financial framework, which is due to start at the end of the year. I therefore appeal once again to the Council: stop the denial of reality and make the European budget crisis-proof – this year, not 2020! This would also include applying the Stability Pact in such a way that Member States' contributions to the EU budget are not counted against their current budget deficit. The Committee on Budgets has decided to this, to my satisfaction. This is a decision which the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, to my displeasure, intends to withdraw in tomorrow's vote with Amendment No 21. Ladies and gentlemen of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, how can a state such as Greece at the same time fulfil the overwhelming conditions of the Troika, fulfil its tasks in protecting the EU's external border and provide for the refugees stranded at the border? How can Portugal show more solidarity in the refugee crisis if this country's budget is to be kept so rigid? No, we must be consistent here and allow flexibility. I would therefore ask colleagues to vote tomorrow with my group against the PPE-DE's Amendment No 21. I would also like to say a word to the friends of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance. I would like your group to be able to vote in favour of guidelines at the end, even if they contain positive wording on the ITER fusion reactor. The fight against nuclear energy is part of my political biography. I really thought about how I feel about ITER.  If I only click on the The exit will also cost money: at least EUR 4 billion. However, we are also renouncing major innovations that we urgently need, for example in the field of control technology or new active ingredients, if we were to dispense with ITER. I am in favour of ITER, together with my group.  But there is no contradiction in the fact that the development of the project will have to be closely monitored and look closely at whether the financial needs are set correctly and whether it is not so high. If we come to the conclusion that this financial need should be too high, then we should find a better benefit for these funds if they are not yet needed for ITER. My request is: strengthen the European Parliament in our debate for a sufficient budget! Don't weaken the house because of a dissent in a question! What could solve our budgetary problems as a whole would be a sufficient system of own resources. We have the Lamassoure report, which this House adopted in 2008: no additional burdens on the European taxpayer, but a system of own resources that allows the EU to finance its tasks. The High Expert Group, led by Mario Monti, is working on proposals for this. I expect the Council to engage constructively in this debate. Yes, that's what's working. But this work could be rewarded by the fact that in future the Council would have to do even less work with the budget as copy and paste, because the parliament would be solely responsible for the budget, as it should be in a democracy.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Geier, very much for recognising the important role of the EU budget to deal with crises and, at the same time, to continue to support the economic recovery, growth and jobs in Europe. This is what we foresee for 2017 as well. We will face another challenging year in budgetary terms: we will have to cope with the impact of the refugee crisis, people will need to be integrated, new arrivals will most likely continue, and we will have to continue to support investments in Europe. In that context we also very much welcome Parliament’s recognition that, with needs growing and pressures on the budget increasing, we ought to focus more on the results of our work. That budget focus on results will be a centrepiece in our work for 2017. Let me make four points. First, on the migration and refugee crisis, we have been stretching all flexibilities of the budget, for which we are very grateful to the Parliament. It is you that delivered it and we would have been lost if we did not have it. We will continue to do so. As you can see, we anticipate challenges, the most recent one being the necessity to create the new instrument to provide humanitarian assistance inside Europe. We will fund the Turkey facility in the budget for 2016. We already have projections. I am pleased to say that EUR 95 million, our first investment, is now already working there and of course we have an obligation to secure the funds in 2017 and most likely also in 2018. My second point is on another priority we should not forget. It is to continue to wipe out the unpaid bills that have accumulated from the previous financial period. We melted it down to EUR 8.2 billion and we will have a chance to present our analysis on the drivers for this more accelerated shrinkage of the unpaid bills and the consequences for future years when we have our first meeting of the interinstitutional dialogue on payments and outstanding commitments on 14 March, just before the discussion on our 2017 guidelines for the budget. My third point concerns what is ahead of us that is very important in 2017. In line with the MFF regulation, Article 7, we will have to review the cohesion policy envelopes, and that will lead to a revision of the commitment and the payment ceilings decided by the Commission on technical grounds. We will have the analysis of the Youth Employment Initiative and very important decisions to be taken on the basis of this analysis. We will have this in mid-April, in other words in about a month’s time. In 2017 we will have the obligation to complete the 5% reduction of staff and I take this opportunity to again urge all of us to do that with discipline. Since today is International Women’s Day, let me finish by recognising that the Parliament has placed in the guidelines encouragement for the Commission to work on gender mainstreaming in the budget. Last, but absolutely not least, in 2016 we are faced not only with the draft 2017 budget, but also with the review and revision of the multinannual financial framework. While these two events will not necessarily be combined, we will have to think of both as we work on the 2017 budget and it will of course have implications.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, firstly I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work which he has done, for the draft report which he put forward and for the good cooperation which we had throughout the process between our two political groups. The report which we are putting in front of this House and which will be adopted tomorrow stays true to the two most important priorities of our time in Europe: number one, continuation of economic recovery, and number two, managing the refugee crisis with the clear objective of reducing the influx of migration of illegal migrants into Europe. On the continuation of economic recovery we are going to allocate enough resources to research, innovation and infrastructure, all very important in order to improve the competitiveness of the European economy, to strengthen the European economy and to lead to the creation of more jobs.  As regards tackling the refugee crisis, Parliament’s position is very clear and it is also outlined in the guidelines which we will adopt with a very large majority tomorrow. Parliament sees the budget of the European Union as part of the solution. Parliament was always ready to act fast last year, as it is this year, when a crisis situation occurs, but likewise Member States of the European Union also have to fulfil their commitments in allocating enough financial resources to Africa, to the Madad Fund, to the Turkey Refugee Facility.  On this basis, I truly believe that we will be able to adopt this report with a wide majority tomorrow and respond to the concerns of the citizens of Europe.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and say that after a 2016 budget that we voted in charge, pushing the levers of flexibility to the limit, here comes 2017, a test of truth for the European Union. Indeed, our ability to respond to crises will determine our common future. We need political and solidarity responses. By that I mean that the coordination of national means is no longer enough. We must work to harmonize and put in place common tools where the stakes are common. An example: the question of borders is one of those trials of truth. We can no longer just coordinate the action of states. We need Community officers and a common border policy if we are to save free movement.  This much-needed political breakthrough will not happen without a financial effort. Today, however, the limits of the Union's budget do not allow this effort. I would therefore like to alert you to the paragraphs of our resolution on the revision of the 2014-2020 financial framework. This revision must respond to this unprecedented crisis. We will appreciate the 2017 budget in this renovated setting.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the rapporteur correctly identifies the problems facing Europe, but I am concerned that correct diagnosis does not always lead to correct treatment. I make three points. First, it is important that the EU operate within the budget which was agreed within the MFF and therefore, despite the immediate and pressing nature of many of the problems facing the Union, they should not be used as a reason to call for a bigger budget. Rather, the Commissioner is absolutely right to introduce performance-based budgeting, and would be right to pursue both value for money and European added value. Secondly, I understand and I do share the rapporteur’s concerns for the levels of youth unemployment. I fully accept that in times of crisis politicians will want to be seen to be responding. After all, who would not wish to see vastly improved employment prospects for young people? But a word of caution: experience has taught us that youth unemployment schemes have generally been strong on intent but disappointing in delivery. The one thing that would help young unemployed people more than anything else is a strong, vibrant and expanding economy. That brings me to my third point. I do understand that attention is likely to be focused on the immediate crises in agriculture, in security and the refugees. But I do urge colleagues not to lose sight of the fact that it is competitiveness, jobs and growth that is, and must remain, the number one priority for this budget.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, we are now, as has been said enough, facing formidable challenges. First, there is the far too low level of economic growth, especially investment, resulting in too high unemployment, which remains unbearable among young people. Then there is the scale of the migratory pressure, which undermines the cohesion of the Union, destroys solidarity and risks undermining the very foundations of the Union. There is still the terrorist threat, which, however latent it may be today, nevertheless remains fraught with threats of carnage and massacres. Finally, there is the catastrophic situation in the southern Mediterranean and the misery of Central Africa, two regions where horrors are daily and fight the sad record of intolerable things in misery. In the face of such challenges, the ALDE Group's budget priorities for 2017 are very clear: 1) promote innovation and investment and, therefore, growth for jobs; 2) support the development of SMEs, the backbone of the European economy; 3) relaunch the youth initiative; 4) manage and not just face migratory pressure, including by organizing humanitarian corridors, establishing safe zones and negotiating fair partnerships, not blackmail-based bargaining; 5) to live up to the geostrategic imbalances that occur throughout our neighbourhood and demand determined action by our Union against their causes. Madam President, Commissioner, rapporteur, it is on the basis of these priorities that we will actively participate in the discussions on the 2017 budget, which you are responsible for drawing up.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, tá buiséad bliantúil AE ag éirí dodhéanta. Gach mí bíonn ionadh orainn le ráiteas ón gCoimisiún agus gach mí cloisimid mar gheall ar ghealltanais nua, tosaíochtaí nua. Cuirtear ceist orainn ciorruithe a dhéanamh ar thosaíochtaí a bhí aontaithe cheana féin ar chláir riachtanacha.  An bhfuil déine anois ag rialú an Choiste um Buiséid mar aon le Ballstáit? Níl dóthain airgid ann chun na cuspóirí polaitiúla a bhaint amach. Agus le dúshláin nua atá práinneach ag teacht isteach anois, táimid ag cur moill orthu agus fiú ag cur na dtosaíochta seo ar ceal. D’aontaíomar ar fad go raibh infheistíocht riachtanach le haghaidh fhás an gheilleagair mar aon le poist a chruthú go háirithe tar éis na géarchéime airgeadais i 2007. Tá MFF 2014-2020 laghdaithe le EUR 85 billiún cé go bhfuil cuid de na cláir tar éis leathnú agus dul i méid. Tá na blianta, ar ndóigh, ag sleamhnú agus fad is atá cuid againn plódaithe le déine, tá na Ballstáit shaibhre ag seoltóireacht ar bharrachas.  Tá ár n-aos óg ag tógaint na rogha anois léim isteach san uisce nó léim ar eitleán, agus tá na tionscnaimh fostaíochta don ógra scriosta – an t-aon ábhar dóchais a bhí i ndán dóibh. An bréagchrábhadh atá ar bun ag an gCoimisiún agus an gComhairle ag rá go bhfuil ár n-aos óg ríthábhachtach agus iad ag an am ceánna ag gearradh a sciathán, tá sé scannalach. Tá ár dtionscal iascaireachta scriosta ar fad.  Gan dabht ár slánaitheoir mór, an EFSI, ní féidir iontaoibh a bheith againn as. Is iad na hinfheisteoirí príobháideacha atá ag baint an tairbhe ar fad as seo ar chostas seirbhisí poiblí. Tá na hionstraimí airgeadais ‘ad hoc’ atá á gcruthú ag laghdú aon chomhtháthú ó acmhainn Bhuiséad AE, agus caithfimid athbhreithniú réadúil a dhéanamh ar an gCreat Airgeadais Ilbhliantúil.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, this is a report, a good report, Mr Geier, Commissioner, which confirms that this Parliament is trying to be — and I think it succeeds once again — the best representation of the european general interest in the face of a national interest which is continually, and these days more, calls into question this European interest. It is a report that also admits a risk of obsolescence, because the evolution of events every day adds concerns and uncertainties to us. But I would like to point out the coincidences and values of the report: the connection with the revision of the multiannual financial framework, in the sense of a necessary increase in resources, the need to close the own resources report with the utmost ambition and, as mentioned, the risk of returning to the accumulation of outstanding payments. It also contains, in the positive, a claim for the recovery of Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility and a call to states wholly necessary on the Youth Employment Initiative, with a very positive climate change text and, on the other hand, a red line in relation to ITER that will prevent our group from being able to cast the favourable vote that the rest of the report certainly deserves.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European budget is in difficulty, as are many of the budgets of European countries, especially those in the eurozone, which are being forced to suffer the constraints of Brussels and the blackmail of a crazy single currency. If we do not start from this basic concept, it is very difficult to try to improve the current situation.  An increase in the Union's budget is utopian, although it is undeniable that some programmes probably need more resources. I believe, however, that there are very few programmes in which the Union can be more effective than the Member States in addressing the current challenges and critical issues. According to the Commission's triumphalist announcements, the Juncker Plan was supposed to be the example of a great European project, but it is only proving to be a different way for individual Member States to decide on projects that have been planned for some time, with no added value.  At this point, I wonder whether it does not make sense perhaps to let countries make freer use of their investment capacities, without having to comply with absurd constraints or European superstructures. The European states regard the EU budget as something alien to them, useful only for recovering funds for spot initiatives and measures, such as the Juncker Plan or the billion-dollar bill to be sent to Erdogan, in vain in the hope that the issue of immigration could be resolved.  Europe is ill and the Union's budget is the thermometer that certifies this disease. If we want to heal, we must take action, totally changing the care and approach adopted so far.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. I should say something about the idiotic sums promised to the wrong Turkey or about the immense sums that have been transferred to Greece in vain. But I want to talk about the flexibility instrument.  Parliament wants an extra amount of money for emergencies on top of the budget, which is a very bad idea. After all, when do you know if today's emergency is the worst thing that's going to happen this year? Because the EU is causing quite a bit. And before you know it, you've spent your emergency money too early and wrongly. And I predict what will happen: extra money will be spent on 1 January and on 2 January Parliament will be complaining that it is gone, like little boys who have eaten their sweets too quickly! Governments are notoriously incap of not being able to deal with money, not at national level and certainly not at European level, and therefore less, less, less money to the EU and no flexibility instrument.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the Budget of the European Union, corresponding only to about 1 % of gross domestic product, or rather gross national income, is an important budget for investment. It is a budget where administrative expenditure corresponds only to 6 % of that budget and has unquestionable added value, as evidenced by the provision of its guarantee for a plan, as is the Juncker plan, which will mobilise 315 billion investments, has already mobilised around EUR 50 billion, also an instrument, this budget which allows, in many Member States, to , the investment is more than 50 % only with revenue snares from this budget.  It contributes to growth, contributes to employment and, at the same time, to territorial cohesion and social cohesion. And to do so, regional operational programmes need to be at cruising speed in 2017. It is important to support SMEs, promote competitiveness and, to do so, we must pay special attention to Horizon 2020, Cosme, among other programmes. Erasmus+ and the Youth Employment Initiative are initiatives that must continue. Furthermore, the emergency that lies ahead of us, as is the case with this refugee crisis, cannot leave us indifferent and, in that sense, we must use all the resources available and all the solidarity, all the flexibility, to deal with this emergency.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: – There is an acute lack of investment in Europe for our economies to grow, to create new jobs. That is also why we have the European Investment Plan and the European Fund for Strategic Investments. The investment plan is, as a matter of principle, designed to finance investments that could not be made without anyone taking risks. If you look at the list of approved investments, you will also find projects that do not carry any risks. In my country, we make such investments without the help of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. The warming of apartments and houses is an excellent project. It saves energy, reduces emissions, creates employment. But if we provide EFSI funding for a risk-free project, it is not an economical use of European money. We will miss this money in the European Union budget. The Commission must therefore examine whether some investments can be made in a different way than through the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Speaking in this debate, I would like to support the rapporteur's view that the budgetary resources available in the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework are insufficient to deal with the growing immigration crisis, low economic growth and high levels of unemployment, especially among young people. Further commitments by the Union towards Turkey – now at EUR 6 billion, the creation of trust funds for Syria as well as Africa, additional appropriations for Greece, commitments to rebuild the Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe programmes, and finally the elimination of outstanding commitments – all of which, in my opinion, require a revision of the upper spending thresholds of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020.  At the same time, I would like to express my opposition to the rapporteur's position in favour of the introduction of an EU tax, which would be the main revenue of the European Union budget.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, this report talks a lot about how to get around the rules effectively; how to increase the budget without actually breaking the rules and ceilings of the multiannual financial framework. But what I want to focus on today is the text in the report which accuses the Member States of ‘duplicitous behaviour’ when they do not want to give the European Union more money. I am shocked. It is not a very nice thing to accuse the United Kingdom of, and David Cameron, as we all know, leads its government – the same David Cameron, of course, who gave us a cast-iron guarantee that if he became PM, he would not let matters rest there about the Lisbon Treaty. Well he did let matters rest there, but I am sure that was not really his fault, right? This is the Downing Street that recently promised us that they had nothing to do with John Longwood’s sacking as the head of the British Chamber of Commerce, when he backed Brexit. I am sure that phone call from an aide hours before the sacking was 100% coincidence. Right? The Prime Minister, who promised us he would have net migration down to the tens of thousands a year if he was elected. Well, okay, I cannot excuse that one at all. So we have this report in front of us which calls for finding ways to spend more taxpayers’ money in 2017. A report which calls for more spending in many areas and the one place where the report actually calls for cuts – I suppose the one area where it does that is to actually ask for more funding to be able to implement the cut. So whilst we are asking for more taxpayers’ money for 2017, I think this report had better think about who it actually calls ‘duplicitous’; if it is referring to Cameron then, who knows, it might actually be right for once.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: – I think it is important to maintain the main European directions for the 2017 budget: economic development and job creation. It is clear that the European budget is under pressure, especially because of the refugee crisis. Solutions need to be found to resolve this crisis. These solutions, however, must not jeopardise the implementation of other important European policies. There are increasing calls for the reallocation of funds for European policies, in particular cohesion policy. I think it is an error: refugees need to be integrated. To do this, we need to maintain economic development, which cohesion policy does. The reallocation of funds can improve the situation in the short term, but it jeopardises the economic situation, including long-term integration. New budgetary rules need to be identified, whereby the budget accepted by the Member States for 2014-2020 is fully spent without returning any more euros to the Member States. Without a realistic assessment of the requirements, see Turkey and Greece, and without appropriate proposals, the 2017 budget can be a failure. Let us not forget that 2017 must bring the correction required by the MFF. I also believe that the new approach is needed quickly: a budget based on own resources for food and on results and performance for spending.

name: Iris HOFFMANN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Sustainable development cooperation is currently the only functioning instrument that can help to combat the causes of refugees and migration. I therefore believe that it is completely incomprehensible that these European Development Fund funds should now be used for border security and the repatriation of refugees. For me, this is simply a misappropriation. These funds must come from the budget. This must be a place where room for manoeuvre must be created in the multiannual financial framework. The Council must finally recognise that the unforeseeable events have long since become a reality in Europe.  A few words about the trust funds for Syria and Africa: we are still waiting here for billions of dollars in funding from European capitals. If the Member States do not manage to distribute refugees fairly or to fulfil their financial responsibilities, I believe that there is no choice but to oblige them to show more solidarity on the basis of their contribution scale.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is indeed somewhat bizarre that the tax officials who are preparing for the Member States are completely unaffected somewhere by what their own heads of government are partly deciding, and that the whole thing is only slowly being corrected at a much belated stage – when the Heads of Government have noticed that the tax officials are deciding something different from their own heads of government. This ritual should be slowly changed by the Council. We really see that we are in a very serious crisis and that the Member States must learn to understand each other better or to have a little more understanding of the problems in each other and not to force the European budget into major corrective measures every few weeks simply because the Member States are partly unable to regulate things properly among themselves. I hope that, since the Turkey Summit, at least one or the other issue will be addressed between the Member States, that we will also begin to speak cautiously about the issue of quotas in the Member States. But it is still embarrassing when only 10% have been paid in in the Madad fund; the same applies to the Syria Fund.
