This is simply an embarrassing number for the Member States, because the whole thing has been decided long enough now, and the problems of the refugees are well known. I hope, Commissioner, that we will have some insight from the Member States in this negotiation. We do not want to be huge, but approaching this budget with a certain sense of reason would also be well-received by the Member States.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Madam President, I would first like to commend mr Geier's work and say how urgent it is for the European Union to finally have budgetary tools that are commensurny of the policies it is pursuing or should carry out. For 2016, we made the most of the tools available, the ceilings, the margins, we cut down partitions and pushed back walls. Faced with the accumulation of crises - economic and social, agricultural, migratory, geopolitical, terrorist - today the king is naked. Yet we cannot sacrifice the Union's strategic policies, such as Horizon 2020, research, the MIE, the CAP, to solve the perils of the moment. The question of budgetary resources is therefore acutely asked, and States must be aware of this situation and the need to find new resources. From this point of view, we look forward to the results of the work of the high-level group on own resources, which should allow us to give some oxygen to this European budget.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, on International Women's Day, I would like to say that we have already earmarked the area of female business angels for the 2016 budget, and we hope that this project will continue accordingly intensively. Women and family could play a major role in migrant entrepreneurship in particular. I am therefore pleased that we will continue to strengthen and continue this programme in 2017. "Strengthening and continuing" must also be said to the Heads of State or Government. My message would be that, in the multiannual framework programme up to 2020, it would now be time to increase from 1% to 1.1%, that is to say, to make 0.1% of GDP available for the refugee crisis. I believe that this would be a framework that is not too large and which could ultimately be used by the Member States to use the money where it is most efficient. I do not think that turkey and Greece need to be seen alone. Refugees, and especially asylum seekers, could also be placed in competition with the funds available to the Heads of State or Government in the other 27 Member States, alongside Greece. I could also imagine that not only Member States, but also NGOs, are applying for this money in order to achieve the best possible solution. So we have many alternatives, and we should not automatically go down a path. We need options.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Geier for his excellent report and, at this minute, I will focus on a particular issue, which has already been touched on, which is the issue of Turkey, and I will start with this very issue.  As the Commissioner knows, we are working hard in the Committee on Budgets to help the decisions taken by the Commission and the Council. After that, they cannot forget – and I say this to you, as Vice-President of the Commission, Mrs Georgieva – that there are still serious problems with fundamental rights in that country. I am thinking of freedom of the press, and I am also thinking of civil rights issues. We must, of course, make a great effort to respond to Turkey's demands, but we must not forget these events.  Secondly, I would like to say that 2017, as well as 2016, 2015 and previous years, will be a year that we will devote, also in terms of the budget and resources, to the issue of migrants and refugees and asylum seekers. We will do a great deal of work in this respect, but we can no longer regard this as an emergency issue: this is a stable issue. We need to find resources that are stable within our budget.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Absolutely every year this institution sets the tone and direction of the European budget. This is also the central task before us tonight, despite the artistry that some colleagues are capable of. Now is the time of year when we need to lift our head of numbers and graphs and look at the big goals ahead of us – young people, employment, innovation, business, creative economy. Now is the time of year when we also need to determine the properties of the results-oriented budget so that it takes on the next big challenge without piling up unpaid bills, having simpler rules, more own revenue, certainly more sustainable.  This is not the time to hear that the money spent on a youth guarantee has been wasted in the wind. Unfortunately, that's exactly the kind of change I read. However, it is time to set out concrete steps. Let's increase the Erasmus budget for young entrepreneurs – 55 million by 2020 is frivolous. Let's also develop member states' capacities so that they can successfully apply under both the Juncker Plan and Horizon 2020. On both programs, we can do a lot more than what we're doing right now. Let's also talk about cohesion policy after 2020, when we require Member States to plan so far ahead.  Last but not least, the budget we set today is the face of the Union we will see tomorrow, so it is up to us what we will bequeath to our children.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Firstly, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the coherent and precise recommendations on the European Union budget for 2017. I take the opportunity, however, to respond to those who are trying, through the amendments tabled to this report, to impose their own political interests. As a member of the Committee on Budgets, I cannot accept the desire of some to question cohesion policy and the funds allocated by the European Union to reduce development gaps and support local communities. In order to cope with the effects of the economic crisis, but also to respond coherently to the wave of migration, we need common development policies at European level. A united Europe requires a Europe with a similar level of development and proactive policies for local communities. Only together can we overcome difficult situations, and Europe's financial stability depends on maintaining the objectives set when the multiannual budget is achieved. I strongly oppose attempts to revise these objectives by mid-term, as they can have uncontrollable effects for the future of Europe.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to address two points raised in the report. Firstly, it should be noted that 2017 is likely to be a year of significant acceleration in the implementation of the Structural Funds. Although this has already been said many times, I too want to stress that it is therefore important to ensure that the necessary levels of payment appropriations are ensured in order to avoid problems from previous years with the resulting backlog.  Secondly, political developments indicate that the 2017 budget will certainly need to allocate significant resources to overcome the migration crisis. I believe that an emergency situation requires emergency measures and that quotas should be used to stabilise the situation. In parallel, however, efforts should be made to integrate refugees already admitted within the European Union, as well as to direct European Union measures to countries outside our region in order to contribute to halting migration towards the Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, we currently have significant challenges for the Union's 2017 budget. We have the refugee. We have unemployment. We are in poverty, and we need to support investment in order to grow. On the refugee issue, Mrs Georgieva, we are in a critical situation. There are currently 40,000 stranded refugees in Greece. As things continue, at the end of the month there will be 150,000 refugees stranded. Skopje and Albania have illegally closed the border. These refugees must be supported. Greece is a poor country. So far it has spent two and a half billion euros on 2015 alone. You understand that funds are urgently needed to deal with the refugee crisis. Funds must also go to the Greek local government. It is not possible to close the borders and create a humanitarian crisis. Decisions are also needed from the Commission.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I am very grateful for the debate this evening. It demonstrates how serious the task ahead of us is. We have many pressing needs in Europe and we will have to prioritise our resources and use the resources better. In that sense, I agree with those who have spoken about the necessity to prioritise competitiveness, growth and jobs, firstly, and then, secondly, to make sure that we are able to deal with what has been the biggest challenge for Europe in our lifetime.  We are extremely focused on anticipating where problems may arise and this is why we have changed the instruments in our hands, including the capacity to provide humanitarian assistance inside Europe, and I can tell you that in the Commission we started thinking about this long before it became a pressing need in Greece.  We do not know what else may come our way but we know that in a world that is more fragile, where shocks are more frequent, we have to be prepared to respond quickly and in a more agile way to protect the security of our citizens, to provide new opportunities where they are wiped out by crises, and for this I would conclude by saying that first I agree that never mind how stretched our budget is we have to have space for some flexibility for a quick response when needs arise.  Secondly, we do have to think in a more creative way about how we use money – can we achieve more than one objective with the same euro? I will give you a small example here. We took EUR 30 million from the EUR 500 million to deal with the milk crisis last year, to give it to the World Food Programme to buy milk from our farmers and feed children in refugee camps. We have to think in a much more creative way about the 2017 budget and those that are to follow.  My last point is yes, we need money, but in this very tough time for us we need our unity even more. Therefore, as we work on the budget we should be very careful not to create unnecessary clashes and battles that only undermine the unity of the European Union and which do not strengthen it.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Questions have not been asked of me. I would like to thank you for the debate and for the support of colleagues. Work on the budget is starting, but we should finish work for today. Good evening!

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, March 9, 2016. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – I congratulate the reporter and thank him for the cooperation in which most of the amendments we tabled to his report were included in the compromises adopted in the committee. We call on the European Commission to take account of the accelerated payment needs for cohesion investments at the planning stage and to raise funds to the necessary level. It is important that the European Commission already anticipates in its draft budget the accelerated implementation of regional development programmes in the Member States, thereby increasing cohesion resources proportionately. In 2017, our aim is for the European Commission to fully pay the bills generated by the projects already carried out in the Member States.  According to the European Parliament, the 2017 budget should also ensure that funds mobilised to deal with the migration crisis are not taken at the expense of other EU programmes already in place. This proposal protects cohesion and agricultural funds when determining resources to deal with the migration crisis. The European Parliament underlines the importance of school milk and fruit schemes. On our proposal, the European Commission should examine how the resources that can be used to finance these programmes can be raised in the 2017 budget. We strongly reject the Socialist initiative, which hypocritically wants to punish Member States that reject plans for the compulsory resettlement of migrants by means of EU budgetary instruments, citing 'solidarity'. We know that the Socialists aim to deprive these Member States of cohesion funds!

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. – What initially seemed like a very good solution to the migration crisis has completely got out of hand for both the Member States and the Commission. The pressure currently in which the European Union budget is located is unsustainable. The Council of the European Union should be aware of this as soon as possible. Of course, I support European financial assistance to Member States and human beings directly affected by the migration crisis. What I cannot continue to support, however, is the arbitrary decision-making by the Member States on the creation of ad hoc European financial instruments without consulting the European Parliament, which is one of the official budgetary authorities. These instruments, which parliament was faced with as a done deal, undermine the principle of unity in the European budget and raise questions about budgetary transparency and accountability. It is therefore necessary for the next instruments to be created under the standard legislative procedure and for the 2017 budget and the Multiannual Financial Framework to be prepared for them. At the moment, with a view to negotiating further financial support to Turkey, it is clear that European Union funds simply will not suffimposed. I refuse to support instant solutions such as moving funds from one envelope to another or cancelling already approved programmes, especially when they relate to environmental, public health or cohesion policies. I support a European solution to the migration crisis, but certainly not at the expense of other but equally important policies.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. – We have a difficult task ahead of us this year, too. Taxpayers rightly expect us to allocate European funds with utmost discretion. The budget for the coming year must further stimulate growth and job creation, while successfully tackling the problems associated with the growing migration and refugee crisis. At this stage of the (pre)preparations for next year's budget, I would like to point out, above all, that we must continue to work to reduce youth unemployment. Let me recall the joint declaration by the three institutions under the 2016 budget that reducing youth unemployment is an important common priority. I certainly welcome this binding statement, but I wonder why no new commitments have therefore been made for 2016 to further finance the YEI. According to a recent Eurostat survey, youth unemployment is expected to fall in many Member States – especially those with the highest rates. At EU level, it was 1.5% lower at the end of last year. This is a sign that our past efforts have been successful. I believe that the YEI is one of the main factors for this success, and I therefore agree with the rapporteur and call on the Commission to present its assessment of this initiative as soon as possible and to take it into account appropriately when preparing the draft budget for the coming year.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – A properly planned EU budget will be crucial in identifying the EU's response and dealing with the crises we face. I am thinking, above all, of the migration crisis, but also of the fragile situation in the EASTERN NEIGHBOURHOOD of the EU. I therefore pay particular attention to the need to set an appropriate payment ceiling in the 2017 budget. The late implementation of the programmes under the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 risks creating a gap between commitments and payments and the accumulation of late payments in the second half of the 2014-2020 MFF, which inevitably leads to new difficulties for ongoing programmes. We have already experienced this situation in the 2007-2013 perspective and we should avoid it in the current financial perspective.  Furthermore, I stress the need to seek to restore full employment levels, particularly among young people, through the YEI (Youth Employment Initiative) and the EU's flagship programmes such as Erasmus+. In this context, it is particularly important that programmes that invest in education and skills – Erasmus+, Creative Europe and Europe for Citizens – achieve their 'cruising speed' in order to achieve the expected results.
